I'm delighted that my 5 (almost 6) year old daughter loves to read, and I was thrilled that my wife managed to find some books that are at her reading level and yet tell real, and to some degree, compelling stories.But after my 16 year old daughter caught a whiff of the books and told me they may not be so great, I read "Junie B. Jones and the Stupid Smelly Bus" for myself. On the surface, it's no worse than what my 5 year old has seen in life before. But the fact is that literature does something to us, more than entertaining us. As I learned in graduate school in English literature and have been learning ever since as a father, teacher, and pastor, literature not only delights but (as Horace said) teaches by delighting.So what does "Junie B. Jones and the Stupid Smelly Bus" teach?1. It teaches that hating things is normal and even funny."I HATE THIS STUPID DUMB CIRCLE.""That Jim I hate.""I hate it in this stupid smelly bus."2. She calls lots of things stupid.3. Some of the pictures are pictures of how I want my kids NOT to act: going "Ta Da! Here I am, aren't I cute?", covering her ears and stamping her foot when she doesn't like something, and giving a sassy and pretentious turn of the head back to another child. I've seen this exact pose on my 5 year-old, and now I think I know where it came from!4. The humor in the book comes mostly from Junie doing things like hiding in the supply closet, wandering the school at will, and invading the nurse's office and dumping out band-aids and playing with crutches and plays with the phone. And, of course, calling 911 and having a fire truck, police car, and ambulance arrive because of the "emergency" she claimed to be having.The consequences of all of this? Her Mother (there's not Dad in the book) tells her that what she did was very wrong. That's it.The book is targeted for kindergarteners through 3rd graders. Is this what we want to communicate to them? Is this really the kind of literature that Publisher's Weekly and School Library Journal want to promote?Yikes!

"Gospel-Centered Parenting" can be summarized in the following slogan by its author, Rick Thomas: "Less Rules, More Attitude." The gist of the book is that we need to train our children for the long-term and not the short-term. We need to help nurture children who conform to God's standard from the inside and not from the outside coercion of parents.While the essence of "Gospel-Centered Parenting" is sound, there are a few weaknesses in the book. A lot of us parents need to hear the gospel again, especially as it applies to parenting our children.Rick Thomas organizes his book this way. Reading the chapter titles will itself give you a pretty good feel for the book. But Thomas doesn't adequately relate the need for rules and God's Law to the gospel. In "Gospel-Centered Parenting" it's all gospel, without an adequate explanation of exactly what the gospel is (Thomas does deal with it, just not in nearly enough depth, since the entire book revolves around the concept of gospel.) This is a major flaw in the book.Another weakness is simply that the book is too short. The very important truths with which Thomas is dealing deserve more explanation and practical "how-to" knowledge. I realize the book is a Kindle e-book, which tend to be shorter, and that I only paid $2.99 for it. But the book is incomplete as it stands.Chapter One: The Dangers and Long-Term Liabilities of Pragmatic ParentingChapter Two: Sacrificing Our Children on the Altar of the Sports godsChapter Three: Teach Your Children Less Rules and More AttitudesChapter Four: What Every Parent Should Know. What Every Child Should Do.Chapter Five: The List of Rules We Teach Our ChildrenChapter Six: It's too late. I've messed up. What do I do?In Chapter 1, Thomas focuses on having parents consider the long term vs. the short term parenting and advises that we give less rules and more attitude.In Chapter 2, Thomas makes parents ask themselves the question "Who do you want your child to be?" The goal should be (in case you were wondering) for our children to be Christ-like in all things. Parents should be so affected by the Gospel that their children will be as well.Chapter 3 is where I think Thomas makes a major mistake. While he's right that too many of us parents emphasize rules over the gospel, he incorrectly portrays Christ as a rule-breaker. This is the Jesus who perfectly kept the Old Testament Law and the one who taught us the true meaning of the Law (or "Rules" or "Commandments," if you want). This is the Lord who said in Matthew 5:17, "Do not think that I've come to abolish the Law." Christ was not a "rule breaker" but a perfect keeper of God's Commandments or Rules, which we're still bound to obey. We do this, of course, out of love for God, and not some external coercion.Thomas talks in Chapter 4 about the foundational truths that flow out of the gospel and out of loving God. He says that the point of the gospel is change, and in Chapter 4 Thomas talks about the process and goal of change. When we point our children to the gospel, then we will model for them these foundational truths:HumilityGratitudeKindnessServingRepentanceIn Chapter 5, Thomas expounds on each of these characteristics. I know that Thomas has already mentioned love, but why not include it explicitly in Chapters 4 and 5: it's at the heart of the gospel.Thomas gives a few good practical pieces of advice if we think it's too late for us or our children."It's never too late for your children regardless of their age.""Let your theology drive your hope and understanding, rather than your feelings.""Let your theology drive your hope and understanding, rather than your feelings.""Guard your heart from your children's accusations."At the beginning of the book, Thomas gives the reader ways to use the book as a "work" book and gives the reader some assignments to do in each chapter. He closes the book with a link to 30 related articles."Gospel-Centered Parenting" is a good, but insufficient book.

J.I. Packer's "Growing in Christ" is a wonderful introduction to the Christian life. For centuries, the Apostles' Creed, the Lord's Prayer, and the Ten Commandments have been at the heart of catechesis and Christian formation. And these are precisely the topics Packer masterfully presents in "Growing in Christ." I teach the confirmation class at my Anglican parish, and "Growing in Christ" has been an excellent resource for teaching the fundamentals of the Christian life. Packer also devotes ¼ of his book to baptism and conversion."Growing in Christ" is an excellent book largely because Packer writes in a very simple yet deep way that will be a benefit to just about any Christian, young or old, young in the faith or a pastor, teacher, or parent. One of the things Packer does best is to break down the structure of the Creed, the Lord's Prayer, and the Ten Commandments and show how the parts relate. And then he explains each phrase in a way that gives you something to think about. Packer is also good at providing some mnemonics for remembering key points. For example, Packer presents "provision, pardon, and protection" as 3 ideas that are central to the Lord's Prayer.Another great mnemonic teaching Packer presents is this triad of 3 C's:The Creed deals with "Christian Convictions"The Lord's Prayer deals with "Communion with God"The Ten Commandments deal with "Code of Conduct"Packer conveys a lot of rich meaning in a book this size. I highly recommend it for new Christians, Sunday school teachers, confirmation teachers, or even more mature Christians who want a deeper grounding in their faith. "Growing in Christ" is bound to give you a structure to think and meditate about your Christian life, as well as much profound teaching on how to live as a Christian.The structure of "Growing in Christ" is as follows:Part One - Affirming the Essentials: The Apostles' CreedPart Two - Entering In: Baptism and ConversionPart Three - Learning to Pray: The Lord's PrayerPart Four - Design for Life: The Ten Commandments

Maybe if I'd come to this movie cold without what I had experienced for the 4 days immediately prior to watching it, I would have dismissed it as a typical movie with a typical Hollywood happy ending.Other reviewers have written about the basic plot, etc., so I want to challenge you to watch this movie with new eyes. For the 4 days before experiencing this movie I was at a conference for young Anglicans (the Anglican Way Institute), at which the theme was "Marriage and Family for the Kingdom." In particular, we had just heard a series of brilliant lectures on parenting, and I had gone to a workshop discussing Pope John Paul II's incredible "Theology of the Body."When I watched "Martian Child" 2 days ago, the themes of God and His love, what it means to be made in the image of God, and the nature of Christian parenting jumped out at me! I've rarely had a movie-going experience as powerful as having watched "Martian Child." Movies have a powerful ability to teach and transform us, but this potential is rarely achieved. "Martian Child" is one film that reaches at least some of the potential power of film.I challenge you, if you're a Christian (or even if you're not) to watch "Martian Child" through the lens of what it means to be a human: made in the image of God, which means made to live in a harmonious relationship of love with someone who is other than you and different from you. Look at it as a primer on parenting - not that I think that the father, David (played by John Cusack), did everything right. But that itself is the reality of parenting. Look for how self-giving love is what heals Dennis, the "Martian Child" abandoned in real life by his human parents, and makes him "human" again.As a parent of 5, a school teacher, and a priest, I've made it my life's work to study how to love. "Martian Child" taught me or reminded me of a lot what I'm supposed to be doing in order to love and truly reflect the image and love of God.One of the most important things David says to Dennis, more than once, is that he will "never ever ever . . . " let him go. And he doesn't. He keeps pursuing Dennis with an unconditional love, even when Dennis steals and hides important things (like keys and driver's licenses) and runs away.The movie makes a subtle but powerful statement about the utterly destructive nature of parents abandoning their children, whether through divorce or psychologically. And it's not just about parent-child love but all love. Any time we humans abandon each other and live out of selfishness, other people and we ourselves get hurt.I like the way that "Martian Child" honestly arrives at its happy ending because it was cinematically and psychologically earned as the father manifested unconditional love to a child under a series of difficult circumstances. "Martian Child" showed the way the father had to love the Martian child no matter what, how he had to enter into his world, and how he had to shepherd him gently to the truth and to reality. Part of loving Dennis meant challenging his self-destructive self-deception (but understandable as an act of self-preservation) that he really was from Mars.In summary, the movie's theme is well communicated by this exchange between David and Dennis:David: Why did they send you here? You know, the Martians?Dennis: To join a family and to learn human beingness.The final words, spoken by David, also help us remember what we've just witnessed and what has hopefully now become a part of us:"Sometimes we forget that children have just arrived on the earth. They are a little like aliens, coming into beings as bundles of energy and pure potential, here on some exploratory mission and they are just trying to learn what it means to be human. For some reason Dennis and I reached out into the universe and found each other, Never really know how or why. And discovered that I can love an alien and he can love a creature. And that's weird enough for both of us."It's unfortunate that "Martian Child" is not a more well-known movie. But I'm glad that someone introduced it to me and hope this review can introduce it to others.

Elizabeth: Renaissance Prince by Lisa Hilton follows the biography of Henry VIII'S younger daughter Elizabeth, whose mother Anne Boleyn was beheaded at the king's best, who was imprisoned in the Tower by her older half-sister Mary, who had an inappropriate relationship with her father's ex-wife's brother, whose own brother became king and fought to change the succession so that their father's sister's granddaughter becomes queen instead of Mary or Elizabeth, and who ultimately succeeded in leading England during a stormy, lengthy period of time. What I liked about this book was the writing style, which leaned more towards leisurely reading than a scholarly work--though some sections did occasionally sound scholarly. This was an interesting story and one that fans of historical biographies should enjoy.

In comparison to the standard American over-sugared milk chocolate, this Swiss chocolate was much less sweeter but much better for it. It was sweet without being sugary. The list of ingredients--on the back of the chocolate bar--is also less "chemical" than most U.S. brands and more simple: sweetened condensed milk (milk, nonfat milk, sugar), sugar, cocoa butter, cranberries (sugar syrup, cranberries), hazelnuts, almonds, chocolate, milk fat, sunflower lecithin, and vanilla extract.Besides milk chocolate, this particular chocolate bar also includes cranberries and hazelnut/almonds. These were ok, but my favorite part was the chocolate itself, which I found more subtle in taste than the U.S. chocolate, without the sugar overload. Since the nuts and cranberries stick out of the chocolate (rather than get lost inside it). they're easy to eat around to get to the pure chocolate, which was pretty convenient in terms of the way the chocolate bar was designed. This chocolate bar is also decent-sized (6.87 oz or 195g) and not small. Overall, great chocolate.

This projector came very well packaged. The projector comes with a power supply cable, remote control, two AA batteries, and a manual with a CD. This projector is lightweight. The size on the Amazon product page is incorrect, since it's smaller than the numbers listed. It's portable and very comfortable to carry around.Despite being a home cinema projector, it can also be considered as a part of a family of multi-media projectors that go well with business meetings or anywhere where they can be placed on a low table (such as a conference table) or a cart on wheels. While the foot release button is present to lift the front of the projector, there's no such button to do the opposite, for example, and lift the rear of the projector while lowering the front.  I don't have a table in my living room where I can place it--only a shelf--so I end up having to put a book underneath the rear side of the projector, in order to project top to bottom.There's also a limitation with setting up the image projection size. It has limited zoom function, so it's hard to coordinate the distance of the projection to get the best screen size. There's also no lens shift.Overall, this is a pretty good budget-friendly (under $1k) home theatre projector that has everything including all the necessary connections. This projector is very easy to set up. It also has 3D capability, which works well with Samsung 3D glasses, that I got previously for about fifteen dollars. This projector also has a built-in speaker. The built-in speaker is fine for small devices, but not for home theatre movies, where you're better off using only sound systems.The image is very bright and has great contrast ration (35000:1). HD movies look great with high quality picture. Even in echo mode, when the fan works quietly, this projector still manages to retain bright picture quality.  It would have been even better if the remote control was a bit bigger and could light up in the dark. In comparison to the 1040 model, this model more closely resembles home theatre quality. For big home theatre fans, I would recommend more expensive Epson models.I was torn between giving this a four or a five, since I like it a lot, and the only reason I'm giving this a four is because of the above limitations. I have experience only with Epson projectors, but have never had a problem with them so far.

Orphan X by Gregg Hurwitz follows Evan Smoak, a former member of a secret government program that used handlers to recruit orphans to work as assassins. As a twelve-year-old Evan was picked and formed a close relationship with Jack. After losing Jack, he decides to go solo and use his skills to help people in need. Evan becomes known as the Nowhere Man and has each person he helps pass his number to another person In need, with the specification that his number can only be passed to one person in need at a time, since he can only handle one situation at a time.After helping Morena, a Latina, save her sister from a child molester police officer, Evan asks Morena to pass his number on to one person in need. A problem occurs when two people contact Evan, both claiming to have gotten his information from Morena. But which of them is the impostor? And more importantly, why? The only thing that quickly becomes clear is that the impostor is being used to get close to Evan, and that his life is in jeopardy from an unknown foe.Overall, it was a decent read. Evan is similar to the typical Hollywood action guy, and there's no shortage of technical devices in the story. The story with the third person in need of Evan's services would have been even more interesting if it started out earlier, was longer and as emotional for Evan as with the second person--that would have made the impostor storyline (which one is the impostor, the second or the third person to contact Evan in the story?) play out even better. All I can say is, I was surprised.My favorite part of this book was the interaction between Evan and his neighbors (the nosy old lady whose main concern is Evan's lack of attendance at the home association meetings, the attractive single mom DA, her adopted son Peter who befriends Evan, and etc.), which was both funny, touching, and made Evan's character more realistic.This book is getting the Hollywood treatment, per earlier reports in the media, so it will be interesting to see how it translates to the screen. I found the writing itself to be very visual and descriptive--whether it's gadgets, violence, or Evan's interactions with other people.

I use AA batteries with my Sony cd player. This is a nice twelve battery pack. These batteries are also 4% made from recycled batteries, so that's good in terms of the environment. The energizer brand is a big, well-known brand and it's the one I tend to use in general. Overall, nice batteries.

This watch came well packaged and looks expensive. A small booklet was included and instruction manual was included. The display is two-toned and besides showing the current time, the sub-dials display a second time zone of your choosing, the date, and the day. This watch is water resistant to 330 feet. The watch band is two-toned,  big and adjustable.The watch looks very attractive. However, it looks bulky and feels heavy. I like the sub dials as an idea, but you need to have very good vision in order to be able to see them. This may be a hindrance for the older folks. The band is metallic, but it would have been more comfortable and easier to adjust if it was real leather.Overall though, this is a nice, giftable watch.

Very nice fragrance. Came stylishly packaged and looking like a gift you would give someone. It's a 90ml bottle, so should last a while if used sparingly. Burberry is a British luxury brand, and this was made in France which piqued my interest as well. Overall, excellent fragrance and nicely designed bottle.

"Can I go now? The life of Sue Mengers" is an interesting chronicle of a powerful female Hollywood agent, her rise to the top, and her gradual descent, in kind of rags to riches story. In early childhood, Mengers immigrated with her parents from Germany and settled in New York. Her family struggled financially as all immigrants do. Her mother constantly nagged her father about their poor quality of life, and just as Mengers was entering high school, her father--a heavily in debt salesman--committed suicide by overdosing on pills after unable to borrow money for a loan. Sue's mother re-married, but she and her stepfather were never close.Having grown up, Mengers sought to become somebody. At first she tried her hand in acting by participating in radio skits and taking classes with a well-connected teacher. But pragmaticism soon took over. Shedding the life of an unemployed actor, Sue turned to then next best thing to acting--working in the talent agencies that manage actors. She worked as a secretary at one place, than another. She had brief glimpses of the inner workings of Hollywood, but wanted more. Even on the lower end of the pole, Mengers tried to pass herself off as someone--an agent (even though she was still a secretary)--or at the very least, as having the best things. Ultimately, one of Mengers's former co-workers remembered her when he decided to start his own agency and invited her to come and become an agent. This is what helped Mengers turn from a secretary into somebody. Even though the agency only started out with three clients--all has-beens--Mengers managed to accumulate a big number of clients, including stars and ultimately become a real power broker which was very unusual for a woman.  Her move to Hollywood from New York only solidified her rise. Mengers hosted parties in her Hollywood rental, where she  hosted unemployed actors with directors and producers. Actors mentioned included Barbra Streisand (a close friend of Mengers), Michael Caine, Anthony Perkins, Ali MacGraw, and Faye Dunaway, just to name.Ultimately Mengers became older, and her star power had lost its brightness by the end of the eighties. Despite helping negotiate aside an independent film so that Julia Roberts could star in Pretty Woman, Mengers's contract with William Morris was not renewed. Other agents--younger males like Michael Ovitz--now attracted the star clients, and Mengers's time was up. Ultimately, an interesting and somewhat sad Hollywood tale of a successful woman who climbed her way to the top, and made a name for herself in the Hollywood of the sixties and seventies, closely interacting with the stars of the age. It's interesting but also sad, as new faces substitute old ones, while old faces are left with having to re-live their glory days and are relegated to the has-been status, but with a certain financial well-being, provided that their income--while they were still making it--was invested wisely. Kellow's book re-lives the glory days of Sue Mengers--including the before, during, and after.

First of all, this projector is a lot smaller than the dimensions listed on the amazon product page. The actual dimensions of this projector are 11.7 inch x 9.6 inch x 3.1 inch. It's very light and mobile, so it's portable and travel-friendly. It's small and easy to carry around, and is great for making presentations at meetings.Since this projector is so small, it would have also been nice if it included a carry-on bag with it (just like some laptops do). The more detailed technical specifications for this projector can be viewed on Epson.com.This projector is described as "home theater" but is also for small businesses. Its design means it can be placed on a table. After placing it on a table, the image can be adjusted only by pressing the foot release button and lifting the front of the projector. The button is then released to lock the foot in position. The other side of this however, is that what if the projector can't be placed on a table, but on some less comfortable place--like a shelf. It would have been helpful to have a release button lifting the back of the projector as well--not just the front. While this is not an issue for business presentations where tables are always present, this is inconvenient for a more tight set-up--like a home theatre--where space is more limited and I end up having to raise the back of the projector by placing a book or something else to be able to project it from top-to-bottom (since the front lift is only meant for a bottom to top projection).Overall, for home theatre purposes, this is an entry-level projector. It supports the full HD 1080p resolution, including 2 HD ports (the second HD port supports mobile media devices).This projector includes a built-in mono-speaker, which works well with mobile media devices. For a home theatre, I recommend an external sound system. If an external sound system is connected, the built-in mono speaker should be turned off.The fan is a little bit noisy, but when the sound is turned on, it's not an issue since you can't hear it.The set-up is very easy. Unfortunately this projector lacks a lens shift, which would have made it easier to help configure projector set up image. This projector does have all the basic controls, and a good color and white brightness (3000 lumens). I watched a Blu-ray with it, and I was satisfied with the quality of the projection. It would have also been nice if this projector had 3D, which it doesn't.For a better home theatre experience, the contrast ratio needs to be a lot higher (it's 15000 on this projector) which are available on higher end Epson models. I have only had experience with Epson projectors so can't comment on other brands. However, I have had no problems with any of my Epson projectors so far. In conclusion, I'm satisfied with this projector but keeping the above in mind. This projector is budget-friendly and works well in tight spaces.

These are nice little light gloves, reminiscent of the kind the people in grocery stores use (like at the deli counter, etc.) though they are non-sterile. They are vinyl and anti-microbial, as well as latex free and powder free. They come in a rather big box that houses two hundred pairs. Overall, nice gloves that are light on the skin (they look less likely to cause allergic reactions than other types of gloves) and easily wearable, though lacking any sort of thickness. Also, avoid anything wet when in these gloves.

This is a 3-outlet 750 joules  surge protector that includes a surge indicator, sliding safety covers which also helps protect against dust or a child accidentally poking something inside. It's very light and comfortable. Unfortunately, it does not include the ground indicator and is limited in its connectivity capabilities. If you connect power supply or a charging device, it would immediately take up two slots. Overall. a decent surge protector for everyday use.

These Ammex ILHD Gloveworks Heavy Duty Latex Gloves came well packaged in a box. There are one hundred gloves in the box. The gloves themselves are thick and surprisingly, even though the size is small, they fit on bigger hands as well. I found them easy to put on, and they don't cause skin irritation. They're easy to do work in and don't tear. I think they also stretch nicely. Good for using in a home workshop or around the house.

This  Vita Coco Organic Extra Virgin coconut Oil box comes with 40 small travel packets of coconut oil. The box states it's "extra virgin, cold pressed, one hundred percent raw, one hundred percent organic." I used the coconut oil on my skin for moisturizing, and it felt very good, especially since I have sensitive skin. It can also be used on your hair (to slick it back and keep locks from sticking out) and obviously it can be added to food as well. It has a pleasant smell and the versatility (as well as the travel sizes) make it nice for use and to have on-the-go.

The Dead Sea Essentials cream is attractively designed and came well packaged. It has a very pleasant smell and is gentle on the skin. It keeps the hands soft and moisturized. However, I found the hands to be a little too oily for a long time afterwards (it takes some time for the cream to be absorbed into the skin). Also, the list of chemical ingredients is rather long. Overall though, not bad at all. A pretty nice cream.

I am a fan of shooting videos and photos, so I have other camera bags as well. Lowepro makes a lot of camera cases and bags, and my experince with them has been positive, This backpack has soft pads on the back for comfort, and the backpack has many departments and pockets. It even houses an entirely separate case inside (on the bottom pocket in the front) in order to put in all the video accessories. The separate case even has detachable sides for ultimate fit. The front pocket (separate from the numerous small pockets) is half-sized, while the back pocket is deep and goes down all the way. Besides housing a video or photo camera and separate small accessories (in the separate case), this backpack can also house things like a chromebook, headphones, tablets, etc. Although I prefer bags that go over your shoulder, which also would have been good, a backpack distributes weight equally and is probably healthier for long travels. This bag is versatile, although I wish there were more big pockets. Overall, this is a very comfortable bag and works especially well for carrying camera and video equipment.

This is an electronic surge protector that has 6 outlets and a 4ft cord, as well as sliding safety covers and a right angle plug which is especially convenient--it's something that I tend to look for. It also has ground and surge indicators. It provides medium-protection for any electronic devices. Just be careful of taking up too much space--a charger or power supply plug, for example, might take  up 2-3 of the outlets or even more. This makes this surge protector limited in terms of the amount of connections it can hold.The power switch is located on the side, which is good since it makes it less likely one might trip over it and turn it off, particularly if it's on the floor rather than hung up. Overall, a decent surge protector that's also compact and doesn't take up much space.

These white gloves are comfortable to wear and sit well on my hands. I haven't had any skin irritation from them, although the box does state "this product contains natural rubber latex which may cause allergic reactions." These gloves are good to do work in--I haven't had any issues with tearing so far. The box includes one hundred gloves, but is surprisingly compact so doesn't take up much space. Overall, I would recommend these gloves.

This is a basic 750 joules surge protector wall adapter, with 6 outlets, a surge indicator, and sliding safety covers. This is a very compact surge protector wall adapter, which I was pleasantly surprised to discover since the size makes it more convenient. At the same time, it's limited to small plugs--if you need to plug in a big plug, it would take up two spaces at once since it wouldn't be able to fit into one. While it has a surge indicator, it lacks a ground indicator which would have been nice to have as well. I also didn't see a re-set switch on it, in case something happens. The included instructions sheet has such tiny lettering, I could barely read it. Lastly, the amount of watts it could put up with is limited to low-watt items. You could probably hook up a printer to it, as well as a lamp, a clock, a small charger, or other small applications-- just be careful to avoid overloading it.

The PUMA Women's Pulse XT Geo Training shoes arrived well packaged. They are very light (made with ariaprene) and not for wet weather. They are good for walking on a sunny day or working out in the gym, and are well ventilated. I found these shoes to be very soft, which I love. The one negative, beside their sensitivity to weather, is that I found them to be somewhat smaller than the stated size. I'm usually a 6.5 or a 7, and the 7.5 was pretty tight on me. They are also narrow and might not work for you if you have wider feet. Overall, though, I found these shoes to be attractive and even cushion-like, not rought at all.

This LED desk lamp came well packaged and is attractively designed. The light is turned on and off by tapping on the power switch. The lamp head detaches from the unit by pressing the button at the base of the lamp head.This lamp has three preset lighting levels that are adjusted with the dimmer switch. After the lamp and the LED light is turned on, you hold down the switch to change the lighting level by switching between the three preset options.The ac power adapter was a bit hard to find and is located in the back, of the lower arm of the unit.Also included on the underside of the unit is a hex wrench, intended to be used if the joints on the light loosen which can happen over time. This feature reminded me less of a home office and more of some sort of workshop.Overall this lamp looks very modern and unique. I would have prefered if the power and dimmer switch was located at the base or at least on the arm rather than on the lamp itself.The best feature about this lamp is that it's power chargeable and doesn't rely exclusively on electricity.Overall, though, it's a nice lamp.

"Life among the 1 percent" by Richard Kirshenbaum is made up of diffent vignettes about Richard's interactions with the wealthy. No names are mentioned, and Kirshenbaum only leaves textual clues as to the topic of the gossip (e.g. "this seventies movies star, this revered socialite, etc.).Some of the topics covered include real estate (most celebrities In New York --no matter how rich are relegated to living on West Side, because the "old money" doesn't want to interact with showbusiness types), difference between East Coast and West Coast (to survive in New York, one needs real money versus in L.A. one can "pretend" to be rich without that being the case), extreme dieting habits and restaurant snobbery (from the chef and the staff, not the wealthy eaters), and excessive maintenance and "man-scaping," as well as the dating scene post rich-hubby divorce (the new divorcees can select between having a companion, having a lover, or marrying money but can't have all three). Other topics include entitled offspring and the ever present pressure to "keep up with the Joneses" among many other topics. The author is a journalist and at least a part of the vignettes in this book have previously been published in "The Observer" and can be read on its website (which gets you accustomed to the author's writing style and the topics covered).This was a light read, with the content focusing on the superficial side of being rich (private drivers moonlighting as babysitters, etc.) rather than the practical part (how the wealth was accumulated in the first place). Even so, this was an interesting read and study into the lifestyles of the very wealthy.

In "My Paris Dream," Kate Betts--an established fashion journalist--chrinicles her life in Paris during the late eighties and early nineties. After graduating from an Ivy League university in the mid-eighties, she searches for her calling and realizes she wants to fulfill a Parisian fantasy that she always had. Betts secures an internship at a magazine in Paris through her godmother's husband and moves in with a Parisian family. The magazine pays minimum wage and Betts years for something more. Through the French family she stays with, she meets a Frenchman called Herve and begins dating him. Herve is into hunting and Betts uses the experience to write an article that later gets published. The article catches the eye of Fairchild, a prominent American publisher who publishes magazines like W and Women's Wear Daily. He hires Betts for the Paris bureau, and Betts covers the latest It news for the American high socity before moving into what she believes is the ultimate career-maker--fashion, where she meets the likes of Saint Laurent and Karl Lagerfeld.Throughout the book, I always had the impression that Betts' life in Paris was not going to be permanent (as well as the French boyfriend) and I turned out to be right. Throughout the book, Betts chronicled her infatuation with Paris--at one point even stating that she couldn't divide her love for her boyfriend and her love for Paris, seeing it as one whole (this one should have been a clue about the fate of Betts' relationship with her french boyfriend). Betts envies the effortless elegance of the French and their focus on family and recreation over career (it's not uncommon for the French to take an entire month off from work during the summer), even as she feels that she will never be fully accepted into their society (she is often referred to as "the tall American" in her interactions), can't exactly mimic the French style of dress no matter how hard she tries, and feels homesick for her native New York. Despite living in Paris, Betts works with expats and that perhaps is one of the main signs about her lack of full integration into French society.Overall, this was an interesting memoir about living in Paris (which was the part that interested me) and working as a fashion journalist and attending fashion shows (for those interested in fashion). The author's Paris experience recounted in the book is mostly limited to late eighties early nineties, though some of the events recounted in her memoir--such as Paris terrorist attacks--were happening in the eighties but are just as relevant today. It would be interesting to read a memoir taking place in contemporary Paris.

This Queen Sheet Set came well packaged, and contains one flat sheet (90'' x 102''), one fitted sheet (60'' x 80''), and two pillow cases (20'' x 30''). The fabric is 100% cotton and percale weave. The sheet set has a 300 thread count, and fits mattresses up to 18''. The machine wash is cold, with no bleach and a tumble dry low.I found the fabric to be of very high quality and nice to the touch. It fit my queen-sized bed well and was very comfy. The sheet set came in its own case with a zipper, which makes it easy to store. It's small-to-medium sized, so it wouldn't take up much storage space either.

The main character of â€œThe Fixerâ€ is Rick Hoffman, a journalist who is left unemployed after a calm existence in a well-paid job, working in a magazine for the wealthy. All of a sudden the magazine owner noticed that the magazine is not profitable, and decides to switch it to online format only---either firing most of the magazineâ€™s employees or making them freelance. To make matters worse, Rickâ€™s girlfriend makes him move out of their apartment and he has no place to stay. Rick goes to his childhood home, whose only inhabitant was his fatherâ€”a lawyerâ€”who has long since stopped residing there after suffering a stroke and moving to a nursing home.Inside his childhood home, Rick accidentally discovers over three million dollars in cash, hidden in the wall. And thatâ€™s when his problems start, as Rick starts getting followed and starts receiving threats. He wants to find out where the money came from, and visits his fatherâ€”who canâ€™t speak, but lets Rick know with a gaze that the money isnâ€™t hisâ€”which leads to Rickâ€™s obsession with finding out how the money ended up in his childhood home.I found this to be a very lively but deep read, as Rick recollects his childhood memories and thoughts about his fatherâ€”attempting to imagine and assess his life. I like the idea said by one of the characters in the story: once life starts, you never know where it will lead youâ€”while you want one thing, the circumstances end up leading you to something entirely different.

The action takes place in the capital of Czechoslovakia, Prague, in the 1950s. World War II had just ended and Czechoslovakia was under the influence of the Soviet Union, sharing the same defense fears and terrified of penetration from Western spies. The victims of this political regime are ultimately a husband and a wife, as the husband is arrested after a false accusation in espionage. After he is arrested, the wife gets fired from her job and begins to work in a movie theater as an usher. As the authorities pressure the husband to confess to something he didnâ€™t commit, they also get the crazy idea that the wife was involved in espionage as well. In order to prove their guilt, the Czech officer in charge of the investigation comes up with an unthinkable idea.Even though this book takes place in the 1950s, it was a very interesting read. As I was reading it, I imagined a black and white movie of the events. Itâ€™s terrifying to imagine living in that country during that time, under such a political atmosphereâ€”when anyone could say anything about you and you could never defend yourself. The author put some of herself into the main character, since she lived through many of the same events in real-life that she describes in the story.

In "Invasion of Privacy" by Christopher Reich, Ian is a billionaire, owner of a computer company, who wants to live forever and is ready to take whatever is needed in order to prolong his life. The idea of death for him is inconceivable. He develops computer technology for the FBI and kills his competitor in order to acquire his technology--obsessed with the idea of a supercomputer. However the FBI is divisive in their reactions: One side of the FBI is very interested in Ian's technologies, while the other side wants to know about the death of his competitor. An FBI agent is involved with the investigation of the competitor's death, while Ian pays an FBI official money in order to stop the investigation.However when Ian realizes that the investigation still continues, he orders to have the FBI officer conducting the investigation--Joe Grant-- to be murdered. His wife, Mary Grant, is left to pick up the pieces and doesn't trust anyone--including the FBI, who deceives her about what really happened to her husband. Mary risks her own life as well as that of her daughters when she decides to investigate her husband's murder herself--with the aid of a journalist.I found the read to become more interesting later on in the story, from the middle onwards. The characters are well-written and it's easy to imagine them in real-life. I found this to be a very interesting read.

"The Billion Dollar Spy" follows the story of Russian engineer Adolf Tolkachev who worked in a research institute where he was involved with the development of sensitive aviation technology--before deciding to betray his country and hand over as much sensitive information as possible to the CIA, to inflict maximum damage on the Soviet Union. Spoiler alert: This isn't a Hollywood movie, but real-life. Things do not end well.While this book is about Tolkachev, who spied for the CIA in the late seventies early eighties, it also anecdotally mentions other spies of the time period who "went over to the other side," so despite Tolkachev's story being the main one--you learn about other real-life spy stories as well. The first thirty pages of the book in particular was devoted to describing the Cold War atmosphere of the time, and giving a bit of a background on the spy-situation at the time. For a while--back in the fifties/sixties--CIA had no spies in Russia at all. Angleton, who headed the CIA, was too paranoid to trust anyone--confident that any volunteer spies were actually a ploy by the Soviet Union to provide disinformation and deceit, and to attempt to entrap CIA officers.Against this history of paranoia, it was impossible to get anything done. It wasn't until Angleton was no longer in the CIA--in the seventies--that things changed. Against this backdrop, this story introduces us to Tolkachev and the invaluable information he provided, as well as other spies who risked their lives. Oftentimes the motivation given is ideological, but to me that's a bit too simple. I once read a memoir where the author--who was a member of the intelligence community--noted that spying is almost never done out of ideological reasons--it's done either for financial gains, out of blackmail, etc. But the point was it's always personal. Hoffman delves into the tragedy of Tolkachev's wife's family as part of the explanation, but she was not the one doing the spying and her story isn't Tolkachev's. It would have been interesting to gain a deeper psychological picture of Tolkachev and understand why people like him do what they do. As I was reading this, I honestly couldn't understand why he did what he did. In the end, he was just one lonely man against an entire system--and predictably, the system ate him up.Overall, this was a moving and tragic book. if you like reading about real-life spy stories (CIA officers changing disguises, dead drops, spying in a hostile environment, paranoia about being followed, and all the other interesting espionage-related things), you'll find this a slightly dated (story mostly takes place in the late seventies early eighties, with intervals that take place in the previous decades when we hear about other spy stories, family backgrounds, etc.)but an interesting read that is well documented (there are almost thirty pages of sources at the end of the book).

I found this faucet to be very impressive---unfortunately the product page doesn't include all of its advantages (which I only learned about after receiving it) and is very brief in describing it.This faucet came well-packaged in a pretty big box with 6 batteries, in addition to other parts. This faucet is expected to run for up to two years with the six AA batteries.The faucet's handle can control volume and temperature for both electronic and manual operations. With the handle on the position "on," the handle can be grabbed or tapped anywhere on the spout or faucet handle with an arm, forearm, or wrist to start and stop the flow of water. I think this is a good feature if my hands are full and I need to turn the water on, or if I don't want to touch the faucet with a dirty hand.This faucet has an auto shut-off feature as well, which means that the faucet automatically turns off after running for four minutes. I think this is a good feature as well, since that means even if I accidentally leave the water running and forget to turn it off, it will still turn off by itself and you won't get a large bill.In addition, I also like the fact that the LED light changes from blue to red as the temperature of the water changes.  This is helpful if I want to wash something under a certain temperature, and don't want to take the time to feel the water temp with my hands first--I can tell if the water is or cold just by looking at the color.The downside is the long installation--which takes several hours (assuming the faucet fits) and should be done by a professional to ensure high quality. On the up side, the instruction manual does an excellent job of depicting the installation process in big black and white pictures, step-by-step. My installation took up to two hours, but it can also take longer. However, this is a durable faucet and I found its construction to be of a high quality.

In comparison to a previous shower curtain that I reviewed--that was lace and had nothing to do with the actual shower--this is a true shower curtain. It's purely polyester and holds the water in well. It comes with its own shower hooks and bath mat, which is also purely polyester and comes with a foam insert and PVC backing.At first it was a little confusing to figure out where to hook the shower hooks, as there were no visible holes for them in the fabic (and no information prsent in the package). So it was helpful to view the product description page photo--white is up (at the top of which were the little holes for the hooks), multi-colored design is down.The name describes this set's use as being for kids and teens, which I agree with. The bright pink/fuchsia design is certainly more suitable for them than for adults. This set is also affordable and good for using in small spaces.

This certainly is an elegant lace curtain, but it's not for the bathroom. For starters, it's not just white--it's see-through. Imagine you're taking a shower and one of the people living with you accidentally steps into the bathroom--the curtain won't be much help.I also found this curtain to be very thin and not very good for preventing water from seeping right past it, when taking a shower.The curtain itself is attractive, but should not be labeled as a "shower curtain" since it's purely decorative, without serving any other purpose. It's better suited for a living room, bedroom, whatever--just not the bathroom.

Comfort zone? Whatâ€™s that:  Iâ€™ve read a whole lot of books the last few years. Iâ€™m pretty comfortable in the romance genre, and honestly, I didnâ€™t think I had any firsts left, but I was wrong. I havenâ€™t really been drawn to post-apocalyptic books (though I love The Walking Dead) and I wasnâ€™t sure about this one. Iâ€™d seen good things about Ms. Smithâ€™s earlier works, but I mean, weâ€™re talking about stories involving possible non-consensual sex/rape, alien/non-human heroes, violent and brutal worlds that are as far from safe as you can get.So...yeah. I was like, no thanks. Not my cuppa. I like being the fluffy bunny. Then I hit a bit of a book slump, and my twitter friend Lexxi spoke so highly of this, I couldnâ€™t resist. I am so glad I listened to her.  R. Lee Smith showed me why I should risk my cottontail every once in awhile. She took me by the hand and lead me into a world that dominated my thoughts for days, left me wrung out and loving every bit of it. Told from third person perspective of Lan, the world is merciless and it captured my attention in ways I did not anticipate.Brutal world: Azrael is Lord of the Beautiful Dead, able to raise the dead, though he himself is not a dead man. He simply cannot die. He unleashed The Eaters (aka zombies) on the living, took over the world and now resides in what is left of England, in the capital he has renamed Haven. Lan, after the death of her mother, travels from her small village called Norwood, for an audience with Azrael. Lan and Azraelâ€™s battle of wills takes center stage through most of the book, as Lan asks for Azrael to end the Eaters. Azrael has vowed to never end them, as they protect Haven and its inhabitants. Lan is just as determined to change that, since theyâ€™ve almost wiped out the human race, and her mother turned into one. She never wants anyone else to suffer that devastation, seeing their loved ones turn into mindless eating monsters.Erotic Horror: I think this was a good warning for me, and I didnâ€™t go into the story thinking I was getting a straight romance. Itâ€™s not, though I love that the romance is a big part of this twisted tale. There arenâ€™t wild and crazy sex scenes, though most have an unexpected heat. Iâ€™ve seen it described as having elements of a horror fairy tale, and I think thatâ€™s as close to the mark as anything else. Macabre and creepy at times, sweet and heartwrenching at others, I couldnâ€™t look away.Suffering, thy name is Azrael: Azrael is in my top 5 ever tortured heroes, ever. The atrocities heâ€™s committed and the atrocities heâ€™s had committed against him, helped to shape him and you really get a chance to understand his actions. He is not a bookboyfriend that is going to captivate you with his amazing looks. He is horrific to look at, but his tender side, and his connection with Lan, make you melt and root for him to find love with Lan. Azrael has other mistresses, or dollys, as Lan calls them, and normally I would shy away from this with a vengeance, but I could accept this because of emotionally, itâ€™s all Lan, no contest.Lanâ€™s emotional journey is fantastic: The story is from Lanâ€™s perspective, even if told in third person, and you get to see the best and worst of her without filters. Funny enough, her best and worst feature is the same - her stubbornness. It is admirable at times and frustratingly bullheaded at others, but sheâ€™s never dull and I appreciate her honesty. Sheâ€™s not perfect but sheâ€™s as fascinating as Azrael in her own right.As in any good fairytale: You need huge obstacles, torture, tragedies, and ultimately a HEA. There is all that and more in this story. At approximately 751 pages, itâ€™s a long read. I love it but be forewarned that this takes its time unfolding and I spent the last 30% or so finding myself in tears at the most unexpected moments but I closed my kindle with a smile on my face.I think it could be edited to tighten up the plot, but I loved exploring every facet of this world. The secondary characters that populate this, from Mr. Wickham, Lanâ€™s tutor, to Serafina, Lanâ€™s caustic and hilarious handmaiden and Deimos, the unwittingly sad captain of the Revenants, they all left their impression on me. Each contributed moments that enriched this story and made this world come as alive as a tale about the dead can get.Please ignore the cover: If thereâ€™s anything I didnâ€™t like about this, it would be the cover. No, itâ€™s not even remotely good. In fact, Iâ€™d go so far as to say itâ€™s pretty shiteous, but that is not an indication of the writing within. Really. If I had judged this book by its cover, I would have missed out on an excellent read.The Bottom LineSo emotional, haunting, bittersweet yet hopeful all at once, itâ€™s hard to put it into words how much I enjoyed this read. Itâ€™s one of those books that will stay with me long after I turned the last page. My favorite of the year. I highly recommend this for those willing to enter this post-apocalyptic world. I loved it.

Full review posted at http://afterdarkbooklovers.com/2015/11/20/blog-tour-book-review-just-one-taste-by-lexi-blake/#more-8245The Bottom LineI really enjoyed my time back in the Masters & Mercenaries world, and getting to know Eric and Deena. If youâ€™re a fan, I think youâ€™ll enjoy it. The Good: The old â€œin love with my brotherâ€™s best friendâ€ trope has a bit of twist here - Andrew, a player for the Chicago Aces hockey team, was taken in by his best friendâ€™s family when his father died and his mother was basically useless. Heâ€™s grateful for their care and their love and as a consequence, he would never think of getting together with Jenna, his friend Connorâ€™s baby sister Jenna. Except he totally wants to. Jenna has been in love with Andrew forever and a day, but other than one passionate weekend, she thought it would never happen. They both come home to Jennaâ€™s parentsâ€™ home for Christmas. Just the family...and Jennaâ€™s boyfriend, Jon. With that setup, I was definitely interested and novella length seemed like the perfect amount of reading for me at the moment.The Bad:  Unfortunately, it didnâ€™t work that well for me. The first book was light and fluffy, but it had some humor. This novella was a bit more on the angsty side than fluffy, which is fine. However, I struggled to connect with Andrew and Jenna. I understood why Andrew was scared of losing the familyâ€™s love and support, I understood why Jenna tried to move on with Jon. It was when my emotions should have engaged that I just didnâ€™t. It was when my emotions should have engaged that I just didnâ€™t, and I was honestly, a bit bored by it. The angst was mild, the boyfriend angle was mild, it was all just mild.Everything in Between: The writing, while it didnâ€™t engage me, was fine, if flat. The characters were likeable enough. I donâ€™t remember Andrew from first book, doesnâ€™t matter since itâ€™s completely separate story and the first bookâ€™s characters really donâ€™t come into play until the end. It would be easy enough to read this without reading the first book.The Bottom LineI usually love hockey romances, but this wasnâ€™t clicking for me. The writing wasnâ€™t bad, I think it was just a case of â€œitâ€™s not you book, itâ€™s my mood.â€ Overall, It was an okay read, and I would check out the next book in the series.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Two for two: This is the second Jennifer Dawson book Iâ€™ve tried in the past couple of months and the second one Iâ€™ve really liked.  I went into this story blind, as I didn't realize it was part of a series, but I was not lost or in need of reading the first one to enjoy this book. Note: Of this trio of friends (Leo, Michael and Brandon) I found myself desperately intrigued with Brandon and I want his story soon. Pretty please?Back to this story - I love that Ms. Dawson can work a well established trope (best friendâ€™s sister romance) and do it well. This talent is sorely underrated, because itâ€™s not easy to take something thatâ€™s been done before and make it still fresh and interesting. Thatâ€™s due to her way with character development. Thereâ€™s a solid supporting cast of family and friends rounding out the â€˜verse, along with excellent sexual chemistry between Jillian and Leo.D/s dynamic is smokinâ€™ hot: From reading the blurb, I didnâ€™t guess that the D/s in BDSM was in this. I was pleasantly surprised at the way it was done. This is much more about domination and submission than bondage but thereâ€™s just enough spice here to kick things up a notch. The scenes between Leo and Jillian are pretty intense and their attraction for one another really worked, but that is because there is time taken to demonstrate their history and connection with each other. The Firsts (meet, kiss, love scene) were firing on all cylinders and thereâ€™s just enough jealousy that brings out the possessiveness in Leo, which I love to read.Jillianâ€™s a good heroine: Beyond my surprise at the D/s, I was also intrigued with Jillian and her emotional journey. Jillian has wanted Leo since the moment she met him at her brother Michaelâ€™s graduation from the police academy. She is on her last ditch effort to get him to see her as more than just Michaelâ€™s baby sister or sheâ€™s walking away. When she realizes that Leoâ€™s into domination and control, she doesnâ€™t run, sheâ€™s intrigued and she asks legitimate questions that I would ask if I were in her shoes. I loved that sheâ€™s known to be a bit flighty by her friends and family but really, sheâ€™s the most determined one in this relationship. I thought her actions during their big obstacle was fantastic and I found myself really liking her, even in her slightly dramatic moments.Leoâ€™s issues: Leo is harder to get a bead on at first. Heâ€™s been irrevocably traumatized by the loss of his twin brother through violence. It drove him to become a policeman, and heâ€™s built up some impressive emotional walls. Usually a hero whoâ€™s all domineering but emotionally closed off drives me batty, yet here, I think Ms. Dawson spent a good amount of time giving a basis for his emotional problems and the fact that this is done in dual POV gives the reader a good amount of time in his head. When he feels that he has to do something that he hates just to please Jillian, I wanted to yell at him, but to his credit, he messes up but he gives good grovel and he finishes strong, just the way I wanted.The Bottom Line [4 stars]I really enjoyed this. If youâ€™re into D/s in your romance, Iâ€™d say check this out. Ms. Dawson, if you can give Brandon his HEA soon, Iâ€™d love to read it.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good: Never read anything by Ms. Paige before, but I did enjoy the time spent setting up the â€˜verse for The Heavenâ€™s Rejects and the war with Twisted Tribe. Itâ€™s crude, rude, misogynistic and violent, and pretty much exactly what I expect from an MC romance. This book doesnâ€™t shy away from the violence, so itâ€™s about a 4 on the WTFery scale. The war and the action sequences were dramatic, though I would have loved to see more time spent with it, since it's the strongest part of the book.I was settling into for a trainwreck of a romance - nothing wrong with that in an MC romance, because alot of them are dysfunctional at best. Honestly, some of the most fascinating MC romances are such big trainwrecks that you canâ€™t look away from them. However, this one suffers from a case of split personality.The Not So Good:  It starts dark and gritty and I expected a really messed up but strong connection between Dani and Hero. Unfortunately, itâ€™s not really developed well and as a result, I just didnâ€™t buy it. For the bulk of the first half, they either didnâ€™t know who the other was, or they were cursing each otherâ€™s existence. There were no conversations, little more than a physical attraction that isnâ€™t acted on much. Also, thereâ€™s continued contact with others - I can deal with that because they werenâ€™t in a relationship, but itâ€™s not pleasant.Then, a little more than halfway through, say 60-75%, it swings into the mild, sweet territory that was jarring considering the tone of the first half of the book. The attempt to build up a non-existent romance between Hero and Dani just didn't work. One moment, thereâ€™s barely any talk between them that isnâ€™t a threat, and then suddenly theyâ€™re in love. What I struggled with more than the insta-love was the saccharine sweetness of the way they expressed that insta-love. When theyâ€™re in the last place I expect a biker romance to go, and thereâ€™s â€œcolorful bombsâ€ bursting in the air over their heads, I really debated whether it could come back from this.Everything in Between: The story is uneven, and while it swings wildly into way-too-sweet-ville, it starts to pick up again once again to resolve the mystery of Daniâ€™s past. Unfortunately, it lacked that emotional punch to really resonate with me. The villain is a complete unknown for shock value and is EVIL for reasons. Also, the setup to drive Dani into the villainâ€™s arms felt way too contrived and over the top.Had the story melded the two sides (the current MC war and Daniâ€™s mystery) together from beginning to end, it would have had some real impact. Some of Heroâ€™s backstory just doesnâ€™t make much sense (I thought he was 29 but looking at the timeline objectively itâ€™s like heâ€™s older than that). Doesnâ€™t matter because 20s or their 30s, Dani and Hero just come off as very immature, searching for drama for dramaâ€™s sake and itâ€™s not done very well.Lastly, I have to comment on the editing/grammar - there's a serious need to re-edit this book again. Normally, I can gloss over typos or the occasional missing word because that happens even in the traditional published works. However, the grammar is noticeably bad, the missing or extra words numerous and it was very obivous. I'm hoping that these errors were corrected in the final version of the book.The Bottom LineIt was ok, and the MC club action was the most compelling bit of the story. Unfortunately, I just didnâ€™t connect with the romance. This is the first in the series for Ms. Paige, so I wouldnâ€™t rule out a return to this â€˜verse, because there were bits that had potential.**ARC provided by author in exchange for an honest review**

The Good: An ex-military hero who lost his hand and part of his during his service, and an agoraphobic heroine? You just donâ€™t see that every day. Their physical and mental issues, respectively, are dealt with in a believable manner. I enjoyed the fact that the story is told from both their POV, because I need that balance to the story.The Bad: Unfortunately, there is a lack of spark when it comes to the romance and it made everything feel stiffer than Jakeâ€™s artificial leg. I think in the desire to be accurate regarding Jake and Natalieâ€™s issues, the story felt stilted. Both Jake and Natalie have severe cases of insta-love and I just didnâ€™t buy it. Intrigued? Possibly, but they were practically in love before Jake set foot in her apartment. It really hindered my enjoyment. Add to this the fact that the villains can practically be spotted from space and I rolled my eyes more often than is probably good for my vision.Everything in Between: I guess I was more intrigued with Jakeâ€™s friends Ian and Kaga more than the romance I was reading, so if anything I might give their books a shot.The Bottom LineMeh. A really intriguing premise brought down by a clinical feeling romance, it just didnâ€™t work for me.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good: Itâ€™s a Kindle Unlimited read and itâ€™s super quick. Itâ€™s like cotton candy - fun while youâ€™re eating it, and melts away the second it hits you. I like the series, but itâ€™s not Shakespeare. Not every book has to be, but this definitely falls under guilty pleasure.The Bad: The story is intriguing but barely developed. Itâ€™s pretty repetitious and the resolution is super obvious which...whatever, I enjoyed myself for what it is. The way the heroineâ€™s weight is addressed is just trying to make this into a â€œmessageâ€ book, and it does it badly. I applaud making a heroine curvy or plus size. I donâ€™t need it hammered home at every opportunity. Itâ€™s just too much.Everything in Between: I love that the coverâ€™s a bit better than the earlier ones. I would have liked to see more focus on the emotion between Becca and Vikter. I canâ€™t stress this enough - thereâ€™s a good idea, but more focus on the romance and less on the â€œmessageâ€ would have made this loads better.The Bottom LineItâ€™s ok. For a dragon book, itâ€™s not setting the world on fire. I keep coming back for more because this is a premise I like, just the execution thatâ€™s hit or miss.

-The Good: It was the title. Titles and covers can hook me in, even when I should know better. That title sucked me in and had me hoping for something a bit over the top, a bit sexy and a bit funny because câ€™mon - virgin billionaire cowboys donâ€™t grow on trees. I am a big proponent of taking the virgin hero trope and running with it. Iâ€™ve read about 35 year old virgins before (within the last month, if you can believe that) so I know it can be entertaining.-The Bad: Unfortunately, it just doesnâ€™t work here. There is a decided lack of energy and fun to this tale and I was really surprised by it. The reasons for staying a virgin felt contrived at best and a hero whoâ€™s nagged at constantly by his mother isnâ€™t sexy in the least. Matt and Dara have very little sexual chemistry and frankly, Dara has bigger cojones than Matt does.-Everything in Between: There were good ideas that just seemed to get lost in translation. Honestly, this felt like a soap opera B storyline that got bumped up to A, but was lacking the spark to make it all work.The Bottom LineNo es bueno and I canâ€™t recommend it.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Full review can be found at https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1343609419 and http://afterdarkbooklovers.com/I really enjoy Ms. Meaderâ€™s writing: Iâ€™ve read Ms. Meaderâ€™s Hot in the Kitchen series, which was great fun, so I looked forward to checking out this book. I was not disappointed. At first, I was just enjoying myself, but as I got deeper into the story, I couldnâ€™t put it down. When 4am rolled around and I found myself saying "just one more chapter," well, I had to admit that I'd found myself a five star read.Diversity rules: Both of the series by Ms. Meader that Iâ€™ve read so far are set in Chicago, and I do appreciate that these characters do not exist in a lily white world. Thereâ€™s a variety of characters that come from different social, economic and ethnic backgrounds, even within the Dempsey family since theyâ€™re comprised of adopted and foster kids raised by Sean and his wife . I love that sheâ€™s taken advantage of the ethnic diversity instead of ignoring it. It lends a richness to the tale being told and I, as a Latina, always appreciate seeing minorities in leading and supporting roles in my romances.Work and play: Alex is a female firefighter, one of very few in her department, which is sadly very realistic. Her love to hate on Eli Cooper, the hunky mayor with diametrically opposite political views is integral to their struggle to be together. Theyâ€™ve butted heads in the past, but when Alex saves Eli (and he saves her right back) during a fire, they are thrust into a â€œfakeâ€ relationship to help Eliâ€™s re-election campaign. Personal and professional collide and I couldnâ€™t have been happier. Ms. Meader has created fully realized characters with personal and professional lives. They donâ€™t exist simply to service the romance, but have jobs and careers that influence every aspect of that romance. And their banter? At times crude, but always damn funny.Alex and Eli have combustible chemistry: Chemistry is like pornography - itâ€™s hard to define, but you know it when you see it. Alex and Eli have that IT. The story is told in third person POV so you get a good perspective on both of their characterâ€™s feelings without it becoming all about their inner monologues. As you can see below, thereâ€™s dirty talk (yay!) and the way Eli loves to dominate in the bedroom was smoking. It did verge on the guilty pleasure side for me, since he was pretty Me Tarzan, You Jane. He never crosses the line (too far) into alphahole territory though, and when he got bossy, I got buttery. The unresolved sexual tension (UST) they had in the very beginning kept humming just underneath the surface of all their conversations and some of the unintended dirty things that Alex said made me laugh out loud. I love romances where the protagonists canâ€™t help but antagonize each other then have mad passionate sex. This has that in spades.Eli, sexy ass caveman: Eliâ€™s love of Firefly notwithstanding (and let me tell you, that got ALOT of brownie points with me), he IS a big ole chauvinist. I struggled with his caveman tendencies, even if I firmly believe it makes sense for the character. I mean, is he super alpha, and super hot? Yes. However, his need to dominate Alex at times felt more patronizing than sexy, at least at first. I completely understood Alexâ€™s desire to kiss and punch him and Iâ€™ll admit it got my feminist hackles up.  Having said that, the deeper I went into the story and the more of his motives and pure love for his Alexandra is revealed, I just MELTED like Olaf on a summer day. Yes, heâ€™s a politician and has his share of flaws, but that makes him three dimensional instead of bland. That protective, slightly obsessive love and his grand gesture was just swoonworthy. Iâ€™ve added Eli to my stable of book boyfriends.Alex is my kind of girlfriend: I love a heroine I could see myself hanging out with and Alex is that kind of girl. Sheâ€™s tough but open to love, and even if sheâ€™s occasionally protective, she doesnâ€™t just push away Eli for the sake of pushing. She made me laugh with her ability to work an innuendo and she was NOT shy when it came to sex. She can be irrational, especially when angry at Eli, but again, like Eli, it made her human and three dimensional, instead of a Mary Sue. Her love of her family, her strength of character, and not just accepting less for herself had me admiring her.The Bottom LineIf you couldnâ€™t tell, I loved it. When I feel the urge to re-read a book right after Iâ€™ve finished it, I know itâ€™s going on my keeper shelf. This is a highly entertaining read that I would recommend to fans of firefighters and contemporary romances. Iâ€™ll definitely check out more in this series.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good : Sex and humor with dominant wolf shifters and the badass babes who love them. Thatâ€™s the Phoenix/Mercury Pack series in a nutshell. It works for me. I like the relationships that Ms. Wright has built between the wolves in the Phoenix and Mercury Packs and thereâ€™s alot of little bits that mean more if youâ€™ve read that earlier series. Thereâ€™s still the possessive, protective, mine! vibe, but itâ€™s not something that just explained away by â€œitâ€™s fate.â€ Ally and Derren have good chemistry and scenes where they get to connect through their childhood traumas to give a good foundation to their relationship beyond the usual insta-love thing youâ€™d expect from shifter romances, which I like.The Bad : Iâ€™m just tired of yet another crazy jealous female villain. It makes the formula feel more like a formula when you know itâ€™s going to be some crazy chick whoâ€™s crazy because you need a crazy chick.Everything In Between : There was a little bit of the human/shifter tensions and I would have liked to see that overarching storyline developed more. The deeper connection through anal play just makes me giggle. And the tease of Allyâ€™s BFF whoâ€™s like a brother, and his brothers? I want more please.The Bottom Line [3 ½ stars]I liked it. If youâ€™ve read the Phoenix pack books, Iâ€™d give it a shot. If you havenâ€™t, but you like shifter romances, Iâ€™d give the series a shot.**ARC provided by author via netgalley for review**

The Good: Luc and Camâ€™s story was one Iâ€™d been waiting on since the beginning of this series. Friends to lovers is a favorite, and the fact that Cam had finally let go of her infatuation with Z (the hero of the first book) gave me high hopes for this story. I love that it features a sport not often portrayed in romances, has a female athlete whoâ€™s at the top of her game as the heroine and the boarding scenes still have their own excitement and energy that helps pull the story along. The sex was good and I didnâ€™t have a problem believing in their feelings for each other. And finally, towards the end, the scenes where Cam and Luc finally pull their collective heads out of their butts were enjoyable. That said...The Bad: This is a personal preference, but when the hero or heroine have deep-seated insecurities that lead them to jump to conclusions, wellâ€¦I canâ€™t stand it. Lucâ€™s a deeply insecure hero and thatâ€™s not sexy. Camâ€™s oblivious in her own way, and thatâ€™s also frustrating. Add them together, and I spent way too much time wanting to smack them upside their heads.Also, this bitâ€™s spoilery, so if youâ€™re not into that, look away now. Seriously. Ok, for the rest of you....SPOILER ALERT I was unhappy with the time jump and realizing that Luc was hooking up with randoms. Yes, he was brokenhearted and drunk out of his mind. Donâ€™t care. Hated it and it really didnâ€™t endear me to him. It just made him seem weaker to me. END OF SPOILER ALERTEverything in Between: At the heart, Cam and Luc really needed to grow up. There is growth, but I have to admit that it felt all packed in at the end, past the point where my patience had frayed.The Bottom LinePerhaps my expectations tainted this, but it ended up being just an ok read for me.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good: The blurb really pulled me in. I loved the thought of seeing two wounded souls dealing with their issues, and if one of those souls is housed in a hot MMA fighter hero, all the better. Roryâ€™s injury was horrific and led him down the path of booze and pills to forget the pain and the loss of his career. Clareâ€™s had her share of pain and is doing all she can to escape her horrible, abusive ex. The setup was good and I was in for the ride.The Kavanaughs and their little corner of the Bronx almost has the feeling of a small town and thereâ€™s potential with the rest of the brothers (of course there are several just waiting for their turn at love). I think my favorite part was Ace, and the scenes involving working with abused animals. Those were the best and really showcased Rory and Clareâ€™s best attributes.The Just Okay: Unfortunately, the spark wasnâ€™t as strong as Iâ€™d hoped it would be between Rory and Clare. Perhaps it was a few too many references to their insta-connection and how they didnâ€™t really know why it was so different between them but it was. When the characters make comments like â€œI feel this [insert intense thing here] but I donâ€™t know whyâ€ then usually I, as the reader, donâ€™t know why either.I can get into a story that has unbelievable elements easily. I mean, I just read a book with a 35 year old virgin mercenary, so clearly Iâ€™m willing to suspend disbelief. However, the one thing that must ring true is the romance. Since that didnâ€™t click for me, when it came time to suspend disbelief that Rory could overcome his addictions simply through his love of Clare, it fell kind of flat. I was mostly disappointed with the missed opportunity to really give the story some depth through Rory's struggle to stay clean, and how Clare's past could play into that. What was done was mostly surface. The drive towards the end was a bit slow and the entire story with Clareâ€™s ex felt somewhat underdeveloped, since we donâ€™t really find all the details until the end and even then itâ€™s just sketched out.The Bottom LineIt was an ok read. That said, the setup for the series isnâ€™t bad, I would probably give it another shot and see what happens with the other brothers.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

-The Carpinos get better and better: Iâ€™ve enjoyed the earlier books in the series and seeing that Paige was the heroine for this book certainly drew me in. The Carpinos are a slightly crazy but fun, loving family who step up and protect their own and nowhere does that shine through as well as it does here. Ms. Asher has managed to grow as an author which each book and Iâ€™m excited to see what she has in store for the Carpinos, because so far, I think each story has its own little spin and itâ€™s own flavor that helps keep the interest alive.If youâ€™ve read my reviews, I need certain key scenes to be right on point for my enjoyment. I like to call them the Firsts - first meet, first kiss, and first love scene. Paige and Cam have a great first meet when he dumps a Dr. Pepper all over Paige. It sets up their antagonistic banter, and the action ramps up when they realize that Paige will be watching Camâ€™s kids after day camp for a week, since sheâ€™s filling in for her sister whoâ€™s in Hawaii. First kiss was sexy and and first love scene was...ok not what I was expecting considering what had just happened, but still brought good heat. The UST was good and it was easy to keep turning the page, even when alot of the tension came from Camâ€™s tendency toward alpha-hole.-Cam drove me a bit mad: Cam's a bit of a pushy a-hole at times, but I think I need that at times from the hero or heroine or thereâ€™s no conflict. Too perfect makes me crazier and Cam is far from perfect. His tendency toward caveman gave the story a bit of spark, moreso than if he was too easygoing. He had trust issues, and heâ€™s not the type to flat out say Iâ€™m sorry. He could run roughshod over Paige, but she managed to give attitude back to him enough times, though I wouldnâ€™t have minded if sheâ€™d done more.I would have liked him even more and possibly raised my rating, if he had that big moment where he shares and give a great apology, doesnâ€™t have to be a grovel but a truly soul-baring kind of moment makes up for alot. That said, he was never so alpha-hole that I couldnâ€™t connect with him, and it is clear that he cares alot for Paige.-Paige is still spunky: Paige Carpino is the youngest sister of Tony, the hero from the last book. Sheâ€™s been sheltered her whole life but that hasnâ€™t hindered her personality.
