Every member of her family tries to protect her and basically wrap her up in cotton batting, but Ms. Asher managed to convey that this protectiveness was born out of love, not because Paige was TSTL.-The storyâ€™s stronger:  This is what I want to focus on as the best part - I enjoyed the earlier books even when I thought the stories were a bit scattered, or lack tension.Athica Lane is Ms. Asher starting to hit her stride. I think itâ€™s the most cohesive plot of the series, and the threat that emerges was real and organic to the plot and woven well into the narrative. I liked that while some parts of the story stuck to the stereotypical (Hi Bekki), the big climax does not and the â€œvillainâ€ isnâ€™t just ev-ill for the sake of ev-ill. Also, the relationship conflict was so natural and when they inevitable happens, I loved that it made sense to these characters.-Even with the moments that could drive me a bit nuts: As much as I liked that the villain was integrated well and drawn in an almost sympathetic manner, I have to point out that the stereotypical, and completely useless ex wife, wasnâ€™t. It was an easy out storywise. Admittedly, I prefer when characters arenâ€™t drawn in broad strokes for the sake of simplicity and Bekki was just a basic bitch. Also, the resolution to Camâ€™s bit of asshattery was a bit too easy and verged on too violent. His tendencies toward explosive reactions wouldnâ€™t be cool in any type of real life situation. I didnâ€™t agree with Rosaâ€™s advice, because I think he shouldâ€™ve worked a bit harder for Paigeâ€™s forgiveness.The Bottom Line [4 stars]I really enjoyed it. Itâ€™s the best of the series so far. It drove me a little crazy, but I think itâ€™s that bit of bitter that made the sweet all the better. Paige and Cam â€˜s romance was fun and Iâ€™d recommend it, especially if youâ€™ve read the series so far or love KA-style books. The Carpinos are the type of family you donâ€™t mind visiting a few times a year.**ARC provided by author for review**

-Excellent take on an old tale: The opposites attract trope is a tried and true formula and the professor and the bombshell is something Iâ€™ve read plenty of times. Gracie is a small town baker who is in Chicago for her best friendâ€™s engagement festivities and sheâ€™s thrown together with James Donovan, the nerdy stuffed shirt Donovan brother. They fight like cats and dogs whenever theyâ€™re in the same room together and they are convinced that they know what the other feels about them. It could easily move into familiar territory with James being a stuffed shirt and Gracie being a ditzy blond, but I loved that neither of them fits precisely in their predetermined roles. The fun starts when they stop fighting it and start dealing with their attraction, and getting to know the reasons why each has decided to let the world believe what they want about them.When Iâ€™m reading a familiar tale (and letâ€™s face it, 99% of romance isnâ€™t about reinventing the wheel), what separates the best from the rest is the execution. I think Ms. Dawson has done extremely well with crafting some sympathetic and interesting characters, solid banter and ultimately making the obstacles that James and Gracieâ€™s relationship face play out in a believable manner.-Part of series yet stands alone: This is the third book in the series, which I didnâ€™t know going in, but Iâ€™m glad I didnâ€™t let that stop me. I was curious about the romances for Cecelia/Shane and Maddie/Mitch, but it didnâ€™t hinder my enjoyment of this story whatsoever. Thereâ€™s enough backstory supplied that I didnâ€™t feel lost or missing out on any goodies.-Smoking hot chemistry: I thought James and Gracie had phenomenal chemistry and the anticipation built steadily with each and every scene, until I just wanted to scream at them to â€˜just do it already!â€™ - I love when book makes me do that. Their first date was great and I read it more than once. The first love scene was compelling and squirm-inducing. Best yet, it was chemistry that translated outside of the bedroom.They have excellent scenes where you see James AND Gracie them get past their preconceived notions of the other. Their arguing was filled with unresolved sexual tension and I certainly connect with it.  I have a very rational husband who can drive me NUTS when he calmly ignores my rants, so the final payback when James finally sees it made me laugh out loud. They also had a wonderful playful side (hence the bookâ€™s title) and the games they played in and out of the bedroom were sexy and fun.-My quibbles: I wasnâ€™t really expecting the better living through sexual domination moment, which was ok, but I think needed a bit to flesh it out. Also, I have to admit that James calling Gracie â€œbaby girlâ€ seemed a bit off, considering his personality. I loved that he wasnâ€™t just a stuffed shirt, but personal nicknames should seem to fit the rest of his dialogue and it sort of didnâ€™t.The Bottom LineA pleasant surprise, I really enjoyed this well executed take on an old trope. Iâ€™m looking forward to reading more from Ms. Dawson and more about the Donovans.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Another Hitman book? Yes please: When I finished the last book, Iâ€™d wondered where the series would go next, since it felt like it was closing a chapter on the original overarching storyline. When I saw that the Tears of God, a group introduced in Last Breath, reappears to pick up where the original group left off, I was as giddy as a schoolgirl with a new boy band CD.When the story begins, Rafael Mendoza and his crew are following Ava, whoâ€™s been roped into being a mule for a nasty criminal to show buyers some documents for a potential auction, though weâ€™re not sure what it is. The story has the usual action and danger youâ€™d expect in a Hitman book, but with a fantastic amount of sex that wasnâ€™t present in the last book.Rafe is fantastic...ly huge: Now letâ€™s face it, most romance novels love to emphasize the size of the heroâ€™s package, but here, Rafeâ€™s has a monster of epic proportions (Ava calls it Godzilla), something I havenâ€™t read about before. Like possibly life threatening and vagina-damaging.Thereâ€™s enough discussion of Rafeâ€™s penis to make any size queen clench in joy. But itâ€™s anything but joyful for Rafe. As a matter of fact, heâ€™s been tortured his whole life, told by his horrible mother that heâ€™s the devilâ€™s spawn and that his cock is the reason for all the evils of the world, from global warming to Donald Trump.When women literally fear his penis, well I could understand that itâ€™s given him a complex and his sexual experience is limited, to say the least. When the first hints arrived as exactly how inexperienced he was, to say I was shocked would be an understatement. I mean, a 35 year old almost-virgin mercenary is pretty incredible. However, it somehow worked. It gave him a vulnerable and incredibly sympathetic edge that had me panting to snuggle him...and defile him.Avaâ€™s a mother hen heroine: You know the type - the one who has to save her friend, who takes care of everything, even to her own detriment. Thatâ€™s Ava to a T. She sacrifices herself to be a mule when her best friend Roseâ€™s boyfriend reveals himself to be the nasty scumbag he is and threatens to kill Rose if she doesnâ€™t. Sheâ€™s flying by the seat of her pants through most of the book, and it would be easy to make a complete damsel in distress but she pulls her weight when the occasion calls for it and she knows when to hold on, no matter how noble Rafeâ€™s trying to be.Maybe too much sex?: Before you slap me, I didnâ€™t mind it and actually loved Rafe and Avaâ€™s relationship. However, the focus on Rafe and his sexual experience and monster cock was a bit of a distraction and for the most part, the action is definitely secondary to the romance and sex. Even a bit implausible in life or death situations where the last thing Iâ€™d be thinking of is sex.When I think back to the actual suspense, it didnâ€™t feel like it really came into play until very late in the game, and even then it kind of ends with a whimper not a bang. Well, except for Ava and Rafe, who were banging like a screen door in a hurricane. Since the romance is what brings me to the party, it (mostly) worked for me, but if youâ€™re looking for an intricate plotline, it wasnâ€™t the strongest in that respect.The Bottom LineI really enjoyed Rafe and Avaâ€™s romance, even if the suspense part of plot itself was a mite thin. That said, the setup for future books with the Tears of God group has me intrigued. Iâ€™m eager to see what happens next.**ARC provided by author for review**

The Good: I think the sci-fi is strong and interesting. Xiaâ€™s backstory is heartbreaking and the worldbuilding is fascinating. Thereâ€™s alot of detail but I didnâ€™t feel overwhelmed by it at all. There is a glossary but I think alot of the terms are clear in the context of the story. It's the second in the series, and while I hadn't read the first book, it didn't affect my enjoyment of this one. If anything, I'm curious how I'd feel towards that first book, since I like the world.The Bad and Everything In Between: The part that I had the hardest part connecting to was the love in the love story - it didn't feel particularly strong to me. Cal fell hard and fast and Rahal and Xia just have a different sensibility about their bodies and sex and love in general. When the love declarations came, I wasn't sure I bought them, because they felt more insta-love than anything else. I think that's why it took me a bit to get through the story, since I found it easier to put down and just read a couple of pages at a time.Considering two sides of this triad are felinoid, the catlike responses and posturing made it feel almost like fetish play. I say almost because the sex was tame for a menage type of romance. It wasnâ€™t blisteringly hot, but it wasnâ€™t fade to black, it fell somewhere in the middle. Also, occasionally the very references that make the story unique felt a bit *too* cute (constantly referring to sex as sexytimes for example).The Bottom LineI liked it. The sci-fi was interesting, even if the love/menage story wasnâ€™t as strong. If you like an interesting sci-fi world with a little bit of menage, you may enjoy this. I wouldn't mind reading the next book.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good: I have a soft spot for the screwball comedy. The slightly ditzy heroine whoâ€™s convinced sheâ€™s right, even when sheâ€™s horribly wrong? The one who stumbles into danger and yet it all works out for her? Depending on how itâ€™s done, I can get behind that. It can be fun, escapist fantasy, and thatâ€™s what this book is - kinda crazy but fun with a dash of romance. Iâ€™ve enjoyed Ms. Caseyâ€™s writing in the past (I enjoyed Shine Not Burn), and this is has her humor all over it. It starts with some pretty funny texts between May and her sister Jenny and ends with May being way more than the ditzy chick she seems to be at first.  Also, big dog/little dog as a secondary love story? I was #teamFehara all the way.May, a wedding photographer whoâ€™s much more Ann Taylor than badass, ends up in a shady biker bar and everything goes to hell in a pee purse. Sheâ€™s been receiving texts from what she thinks is her sister, giving her weird cryptic instructions to meet her at Frankieâ€™s. When May gets there, she understandably sticks out like a hooker at a Sunday church social. The madness grows from there, but the strength of the book is in the security firm and May learning the ropes for her new and exciting job. The camaraderie between the characters, the training that May goes through, the nickname they give her, all add up to some cute and funny scenes.The Bad: The setup for May to work with BSB hinges on your ability to suspend disbelief...as well as not being completely disgusted with Mayâ€™s TSTL actions. I will admit, I laughed out loud at her sisterâ€™s texts one minute, and then wanted to smack May upside the head the next. The choices she makes to end up where she does beg for a head slapping. That said, I think itâ€™s due to Ms. Caseyâ€™s talent that I understood that it was a choice to make her do those things to position her for the rest of the story, and May really grew on me by the end of the tale, kinda like a fungus.Everything In Between: When I say thereâ€™s a dash of romance, thatâ€™s all it felt like - the spice on top of the tale of May and her badass training. Sweet moments, just not enough of them. Also, this is first person POV and itâ€™s all May, all the time. Thatâ€™s fine but it narrowed the â€˜verse and left me wanting more from everyone not named May.I liked Ozzie, though I would have loved to see his character fleshed out more and the ILUs didnâ€™t resonate for me because there was little time spent developing the relationship. Itâ€™s set up for an ongoing series, so Iâ€™m hopeful that the other guys will eventually get a bit more playing time.The Bottom Line [3 Â¼ stars]I ended up liking it, even if May has some serious TSTL moments that made me wonder if I would. If youâ€™re into screwball and can handle a ditzy heroine, check it out.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

-New to me author: When I looked up Nona Raines on Goodreads, Iâ€™d had no idea that she has so many books out, or that this novella was actually a sequel of sorts to her book, Read to Me. It didnâ€™t hinder my enjoyment of this story, but it does make me want to seek out more by her. I like Ms. Rainesâ€™ writing style, with a lyrical slant without getting flowery and a good amount of descriptors to set the tone.-Interesting setup: I liked that Bryan and Gloriaâ€™s meeting through a half-written letter left in a book of poems, an unusual opening gambit for a love story. Gloria has a soft spot for the romantic outpouring and Bryan is more than willing to use that for a chance to get to know Gloria. The misunderstanding is crucial yet believable.-Gloriaâ€™s a strong Latina heroine: I adored that Gloria is Latina and it informs alot of little moments throughout the story without becoming the focal point. That sheâ€™s loved and lost and is confident in herself and what sheâ€™s achieved is admirable and even when the inevitable happens, I really liked that she stood up for herself and called things as she saw them.-Novella length hinders development: I truly wished that the story was longer and more time spent in giving Gloria and Bryan more time getting to know each other. The transition from attraction to love was very quick and told to the reader instead of being shown, and shortcuts were taken to wrap up the story with the final reunion being sweet but rather abrupt.The Bottom LineI liked it. I think the writing was interesting. I only wish it had been a bit longer.**ARC provided by author for review**

The Carpinos are crazy fun family: Ms. Asherâ€™s managed to set up a full little â€˜verse with the very large and loving Carpino family. Iâ€™d read the first book in the series, Overflow, a while ago, but it was very easy to jump back into the mix. The family relationships and get-togethers were comfortable and funny. Paige is the next Carpino up to bat, and she features alot more in this book, making me want to read more about her.Itâ€™s a standalone, butâ€¦: While I think you could read this book on its own, it would be helpful to read the earlier book just to get the feel of the whole family and the events of the first overlap a bit with this one, so it will spoil several plot points for the first book. For a second writing effort, I think it shows continued growth and potential, and it didnâ€™t feel like a carbon copy of the first book.Leighâ€™s been through alot:  Between her childhood surrounded by her skanky mother and junkie sister, she didnâ€™t have alot of love in her life. Her BFF Gabby and her family brought her into the fold, but itâ€™s never the same when you have nothing but negative from your blood family. Then her horrendous relationship with her ex Preston (which, ew) made her feel about two inches tall. Her self esteem is shyte and thatâ€™s not necessarily easy to read, though it is in keeping with what sheâ€™s suffered. She has  What I would have liked to have seen is Leigh have some time to build herself up, and not rush into a relationship with Tony, because she needed to love herself before she could love someone else. Though with Tony, I couldnâ€™t blame her for falling into a relationship with him.Tonyâ€™s a pretty great alpha hero: Tonyâ€™s just what the doctor ordered for Leigh after her scummy ex beats the stuffing out of her. Heâ€™s as ideal as possible. Even his pushiness is perfect, because he never ignores her needs and makes sure to take her feelings into consideration at every turn. Honestly, he may be too ideal, but again considering everything Leigh suffered at the hands of pretty much every person that was supposed to love her except her friends, yeah heâ€™s just what she needed.The way he brought Leigh out of her shell was so sweet, from taking her to the mall to people watch, the fun of their car shopping adventures to adopting a Golden-doodle named Finland, he makes all the right moves. Thereâ€™s not a moment of eye-roaming or tension with another woman, so this is a completely safe read. Which...Needed more external tension: Overall, the weakest point of the story is that there is no real tension from anything except Leigh and her self-esteem. The external obstacles such as her family, her ex or the situation involving Tonyâ€™s client, werenâ€™t integrated as well as they could have been to really give some urgency to the plot.I guess itâ€™s the difference between a decent dessert and a gastronomic delight - itâ€™s the ones with a little more bitter that really make that sweetness pop. The obstacles werenâ€™t incorporated as thoroughly as they could have been, more like sprinkled on top. The leadup to the big climax was integrated better than in the first book, but still felt obviously inserted just for a dramatic moment. It was easy to put down, and a little bit more of a struggle would have been welcome to give a little more weight to their HEA.The Bottom LineI liked seeing the Carpinos again, even if I would have loved some more tension in the story. Iâ€™m looking forward to the third book, Athica Lane and more time with the Carpinos.**ARC provided by author for review**

Got it in a timely manner. Like that it provides coverage for the phone without adding too much bulk to it and the buttons are exposed which I like.The only thing I'm not so thrilled with is that there is a raised edge along the sides of the cover, so it's not completely smooth. It's not jagged, but it is noticeable and you can feel it when you hold the phone. Otherwise I'm happy with purchase.**discount provided by seller in exchange for an honest review**

A Stylo virgin: Iâ€™d never read a Stylo Fantome book before this, though she comes highly recommended by my girls on After Dark, so I was interested. When I saw the blurb and the cover for this book, I couldnâ€™t resist. I was concerned with the start and my lack of love for Marc (more on that later), but the writing style is on point, and I love when an author can take me on a ride and make me, kicking and screaming, come to care for her characters.Thereâ€™s another book and Iâ€™m good with that: I hesitated a smidge when I realized that this was not a standalone, but rather a duo with the second book coming out in December of this year. Iâ€™m happy to say that Ms. Fantome has managed to craft a satisfying book that ends on a To Be Continued that didnâ€™t leave me wanting to chuck my kindle. Most serials or multi-book series can drive me bonkers because frankly, they feel incomplete, they arenâ€™t meant to be read on their own and I hate reading half a story. This is NOT the case here. Best Laid Plans doesnâ€™t answer every question but it does have a satisfying payoff to a couple of plot threads, and leaves me wanting more.Lily is far from a do nothing bitch: Lily has been working for five years to get close to Stankovski, so she can avenge the death of her sister. Sheâ€™s done anything and everything, short of murder, to position herself to do this. Sheâ€™s capable and smart, yet imperfect enough to connect with and she saves the day, more than once under crazy tough circumstances. She thrives under pressure and thinks well on her feet, which is just what you need with a story like this.Excellent action: Hitmen/mercenaries? Kickass heroine? Action spanning a continent with loads of danger and hot sex to boot? Yes please. The action sequences are crazy, the fighting intense and the ultimate showdown kept me hooked, wanting to make sure that Lily ...ok yes, and Marc were alright. I would have liked some more follow through with certain plot points such as the Liberian gang, which felt as if it were essentially dropped to give closure to this particular book. Since it is a two parter, Iâ€™m reserving the right to be thrilled or less thrilled, depending on if they come up in second book. Speaking of booksâ€¦.Kingsley Law needs his own: Book, I mean. And woman, ultimately. While I thought he was a desperately needed character to shed some light on Marc and his dunderheaded thinking, I would like to see what woman would pair well with him since I do think Marc and Lily click (which trust me, I didnâ€™t think at first). Heâ€™s a solid secondary character who manages to steal most scenes heâ€™s in and made me really want to let him have his dirty, rough way with me. I connected with him in a way I didnâ€™t with Marc because, wellâ€¦Marcâ€™s a little lotta bit of a DICK: Truly this makes complete and perfect sense for his character. He is a cold blooded mercenary who has managed to stay alive and do it well by shutting off his emotions to do the job needed. Heâ€™s a cocky arrogant ass who REALLY made me want to nutpunch him in the beginning. Then at the end, he made me want to nutpunch him again, for completely different reasons. I ran the gamut of emotions with him, bad and good. While I do think he works well with Lily, Iâ€™d never think of him in terms of book boyfriend material.Thereâ€™s alot of violence in this romance: A big part of the hurdle for me getting behind the romance part of this suspenseful tale is the violence, in particular between Marc and Lily. Had there been scenes in the beginning showcasing their attraction and their friendly banter before their ONS and before the feces hit the fan, I could have handled the violence better. It took me a long while to soften towards him, though it did happen...against my will. The fact that Lily could go toe to toe with him and beat him when the occasion called for it, brought back a balance to the relationship that ultimately worked for me.The Bottom LineWell written, exciting mercenary romance that I thoroughly enjoyed. Iâ€™d recommend for those who love good action and suspense with their romance and can handle violence, between the leads and everyone else. Is it December yet?**ARC provided by author for review**

-The Good: I loved that hockey plays a big role in this romance, but not just on-ice play, but behind the scenes action, which was interesting. I think itâ€™s the strongest of the series in that respect. Gray being the GM of the Cold Fury gave an added layer that I really appreciated. Sheâ€™s a decent heroine who is working in a manâ€™s world but sheâ€™s feminine and has believable struggles choosing between her personal life and the career sheâ€™s worked towards her whole life.Ryker is perfect. I mean, when the story begins and heâ€™s braiding his little girlâ€™s hair. Even my shriveled up ovaries fluttered. He is a Gary Stu, and while immensely likeable, he was uber-perfect. He said and did just the right thing, every time and if I had to pick my fave Cold Fury hero, heâ€™d be it, no question.-The Bad: This is a style thing, but each time, the story is told in dual POV, and thereâ€™s always some scenes that are told via recap as opposed to playing out in real time. It has a bit of a diary-like feel to it, and alot of times thereâ€™s some beats that feel as if Ms. Bennett explains a bit too much, leading the reader with a heavy hand, instead of allowing the story to unfold naturally.-Everything In Between: The villain was obvious, and everythingâ€™s wrapped up in a pretty bow at the end. Itâ€™s very safe and a tad predictable. The whole story has a fairy tale quality. I didnâ€™t mind it, sometimes those reads are just what Iâ€™m in the mood for, and this is one of those times.The Bottom LineI think itâ€™s my fave of the Cold Fury books - I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s the plan, but I think itâ€™s the perfect way to wrap up this series. If you like your heroes perfect and your sports themed romances on the low angsty side, Iâ€™d recommend it.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

-Great football with my romance: First of all, Iâ€™ve been in a bit of a slump lately and Iâ€™m so glad I finally got to this book. It was the perfect pick me up. I loved that the author clearly has an understanding of the game and is willing to really make it part of the heart of the book, as opposed to just the sporty headband slapped on top of a romance.Itâ€™s inspired by Elle Kennedy and Kristen Callihanâ€™s new adult series, and you can see it throughout. The humor, the camaraderie between the characters, the friendships, itâ€™s all just geared up perfectly for a ongoing series. I loved that this didnâ€™t feel like just an excuse for a perfect physical specimen like Knox (which, letâ€™s face it, yum), but I loved the little sports trivia woven into the narrative, and the game sequences had a cinematic quality to them. I could definitely see this as a film.-Ellie is a good heroine: Ellieâ€™s had a tough go of it, always considered an extension of her brother Jackâ€™s life by her parents, her only purpose to get him through school. She makes alot of mistakes and she struggles against being with Knox because of her secrets, but I liked that about her. It made her human. It was necessary because, damn.-Knox is perfect: I mean he really is the male Mary Sue. Heâ€™s physically intimidating and gorgeous. A football god at Western, he is focused, driven. Every woman wants to bang him and every man wants to be him. And the literal cherry on top, yes heâ€™s a virgin. Thereâ€™s nothing he canâ€™t do. And while heâ€™s the sweetest thing everâ€¦-Itâ€™s all a bit too perfect: That was one of the things I struggled with. The entire story works itself out pretty perfectly. Knox never gives up, he never surrenders. He has the moment that is the very definition of insta-love the moment he meets Ellie. It was a bit much at first. Even Ellie's shyte-for-brains parents are fable-like villains and truly despicable pieces of dirt. The mistakes that Ellie makes, and some are fairly substantial, are wiped away as if by magic.Donâ€™t get me wrong, I definitely enjoyed myself reading this, but I wouldnâ€™t have minded a bit more conflict, or some doubt, something that made Knox or the story a little less storybook.The Bottom LineI really enjoyed this alot and Iâ€™d definitely recommend for fans of new adult sports romances. Iâ€™m definitely in for the next one.**ARC provided by author for review**See all my reviews at https://www.goodreads.com/review/list/7751086

The Good: This book had me at hockey romance. Add in that it would be a Russian player and his translator and I was intrigued. While there is alot going on, one of the best parts are Audenâ€™s friendships and the unexpected relationships that turn up during her investigation of her motherâ€™s life, who was killed when she was six. The other highlight was Auden and Aleksandr getting a chance to connect via their memories, hers of her her mother, his parents, all of whom died tragically. It gives them a bond that is believable and I would have loved to delve into their relationship more through those conversations.The Bad: This is first person POV and itâ€™s a bad sign when you struggle to connect with the character whose head youâ€™re in. Auden is almost textbook Mary Sue - stunning, athletic, blond hair/blue eyed virgin (but of course completely oblivious to her charms even though all the guys want her). She's a soccer player, translator, singer, hip hop fitness class instructor, studying for her social work degree while waitressing, and she creates an afterschool program in two cities? All while psychoanalyzing herself and telling the reader exactly why sheâ€™s struggling to fall in love because of her abandonment issues just made her irksome, not relatable. She has moments when I sympathized with her, especially in her scenes with her grandparents. I just wish overall I had liked her more.Everything in Between: I could probably get past that, because I have liked Mary Sue type characters on occasion. As a romance junkie, I need The Big Three Firsts (first meet, kiss and love scene) to knock my socks off. Do that and I can forgive ALOT. Here, the first meet made Aleks seem douchey like he was hooking up with another (no es bueno), the first kiss wasnâ€™t very memorable and the first time had a blink and you miss it vibe to it. Also, itâ€™s a slow burn, which added to my frustration. The scenes where they connect over their families were good but the transition from Aleksandr being douchey to dreamy too quickly didnâ€™t help. Thereâ€™s not alot of heat between them until late in the game and even then, itâ€™s fairly tame, considering how fast Aleksandrâ€™s declaring undying love. When it came to the romance, I wasnâ€™t drawn in.Much like Auden, this book tries to be all things to all people, and while there are scenes I enjoyed, most of it felt extraneous to the romance, which is what brought me in the door, so to speak. While marketed as a hockey romance, itâ€™s not quite that, since the hockey and romance seems almost secondary to the rest of Audenâ€™s life.The Bottom LineIt was ok. There are good moments, but ultimately suffered from a lack of focus on the romance, so it didnâ€™t really work for me.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

-The Good: Travis and Billie have a bit of a rough start, but I liked their connection. There was good sex, but there were proper conversations that showed their chemistry in a non-sexual way. Getting Travisâ€™ backstory and motivations was very appreciated and it made his actions make sense instead of just â€œbecause Iâ€™m a biker, b!tchâ€ and I liked that.-The Bad: Still not feeling the mystery of Priest. Itâ€™s a very tenuous thread thatâ€™s barely been expanded on between two books now. Essentially two bits of info, parsed out very sparingly is a disappointment. Iâ€™m hoping that we learn more in the next book, because it felt as if the first book was all sex, the second book is more sex with better character development, but thatâ€™s it. The final obstacle was predictable and resolved fairly quickly.-Everything in Between: For a biker book, itâ€™s not heavy into the culture, so itâ€™s still more of a 1 on the WTFery scale. Even if Travis and Billieâ€™s relationship works better for me than Ajax and Sophie did, itâ€™s still based on a very condensed timeline with little else to hold it together. That said, I did think that thereâ€™s enough here to make the read enjoyable and I think the little touches, like Billieâ€™s side job as a ghost tour guide, or Travisâ€™ soft spot for Baxter, make this work even with the tight timeline.The Bottom LineI liked it. This is better than the first, and two favorite authors are coming up so Iâ€™m reserving judgment on the overarching storyline til I see what their take is on the Deacons of Bourbon Street series.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

-The Good: I like the setup for the â€˜verse and thereâ€™s alot of things that seemed intriguing, especially the conflict between the Gold Coast vamps and the ones in Vamptown. I liked that all of this is happening in the middle of Chicago, using Chi-town landmarks. The different characters introduced seemed like it would be alot of fun and I always appreciate seeing Latinos as romantic leads. I thought the workaround for the vamps to travel under that big ole ball of heat called the sun was interesting. There were several twists on the traditional vampire mythology that I thought were clever and fun.-The Bad: Alex and Keira didnâ€™t really spark together and Iâ€™d probably have enjoyed it more if Iâ€™d connected with them. They said the right things, but I didnâ€™t feel the chemistry and the sex was a bit more clinical than sexy. Moist being used as a descriptor tends to be offputting, at least to me.-Everything in Between: Things go at a fast clip, and dialogue is rapid fire with few tags to really set the scene. Even with that, it still felt repetitive, especially in the beginning. It felt as if Iâ€™d read about Keira hiding her grandfatherâ€™s journal, and Alex thinks she may be The One over and over as a way to delay giving away the big beats. I get it, but it felt like recapping something I already knew, instead of giving me a better sense of the â€˜verse that I was just joining and really had no clue how everyone interacts.The Bottom LineIt was ok, but it felt like I was missing something, mostly a stronger connection between Alex and Keira. I wouldnâ€™t rule out a return trip to this â€˜verse, but I think Iâ€™d have to start from the beginning.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

- The setup is intriguing : How do you get two people who meet under incredibly tense and dangerous circumstances to find a way to survive, nevermind find the time to romance is always intriguing. Alot of romantic suspense is premised on implausible scenarios being the backdrop for romance. Ms. Tyler had an interesting setup, butâ€¦.- The execution...not so much : I think this is best summed up by that quote from Speed with Sandra Bullock and Keanu ReevesJack: I have to warn you, I've heard relationships based on intense experiences never work.Annie: OK. We'll have to base it on sex then.Jack: Whatever you say, ma'am.Cuffs is heavily dependent on the characterâ€™s chemistry and to have their connection work, even if the rest is the height of implausibility. Unfortunately, Alex and Laceyâ€™s romance didnâ€™t work. The transition from fear to sex is jarring and there is barely a conversation before their mysterious chemistry has them making them out. Once it gets to the sex scenes, there was alot of awkward phrasing which wasnâ€™t sexy (oozing and snatches and the like isnâ€™t a turn-on in a story with a cop and an innocent co-ed) and then itâ€™s insta-love. I couldnâ€™t believe that they were even attracted to each other, let alone willing to exchange I Love Yous.I was told about the wonders of Lacey, but all I saw was blunder after blunder that put herself and Alex in danger. Her level of TSTL took me right out of the story and any hope of connecting with the characters. Even Alex has questionable moments. There were times I was tempted to put this down and itâ€™s not a long book. By the end, I did think there was potential with the writing and the suspense part of the story, and had more time been taken to develop the relationship, this could have worked. As it is, itâ€™s too disjointed and implausible for me.The Bottom LineI canâ€™t recommend it because neither the romance or suspense really worked for me. I wish the author well, because there are some moments in here with potential, but the dependency on a TSTL heroine to drive the story and bad sex to cover the rest of it just didnâ€™t work.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The final book in the Sisters of the Craft trilogy finds the last sister, Willow Black, residing at the Northern Wisconsin Mental Health Facility. Sheâ€™s struggled all her life, having visions as soon as she sees water. It lead to shrieking, fainting and generally being thought of cuckoo. When she tries to kill a man who was going to try and kill her (she saw it in a vision), she lands in the asylum. When she sees Sebastian Frasier, she recognizes her true love, her soulmate from her lifelong visions. Small problem - heâ€™s the new administrator and her new psychiatrist. Thereâ€™s her sisters to meet, the looming threat of the Venatores Mali, and the big bad, Roland McHugh, to vanquish. In the midst of all that, romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Enjoyable urban fantasy/paranormal series: Each book focuses on one sister and her finding her true love in the face of overwhelming evil and this is no different. Ms. Handeland has created a great little â€˜verse that Iâ€™ve enjoyed visiting. Thereâ€™s humor and well drawn characters, and the stories (Iâ€™ve read the first and last) flowed well and can stand on their own, though I really need to get around to reading the middle book so the series is complete for me.Good hero and heroine: Willowâ€™s a great heroine. Sheâ€™s pretty pragmatic and level-headed, considering what sheâ€™s suffered in her life. Sheâ€™s never had a stable place to call home, always afraid of the future she could see and no one else would believe. Sebastianâ€™s a good hero whose struggle with the guilt of not being able to save his sister made him sympathetic and a good match for Willow. I would have liked to seen more regarding their romance.Not so much with the sexy: The whole psychiatrist/patient dynamic added a touch of the forbidden to the story that I enjoyed, even if itâ€™s only dealt with in very broad terms. This series is PG though (I think the first book had the most sexy times in it) and the focus is on the magic and vanquishing Roland.Sweet ending: Thereâ€™s some danger, but ultimately, it felt very safe, with a HEA wrapped in a magical bow. Not that thereâ€™s anything wrong with that, but I felt more danger and tension in the first book than I did in the finale.The Bottom LineAn enjoyable read and a nice change of pace from the books Iâ€™d been reading lately. I recommend for fans of paranormal/urban fantasy reads who like a bit of sweet with their witches, Ã  la Charmed.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-I like the â€˜verse and the friendships: I picked this up because I saw some promise with the first book, Loving Lo, and I think there continues to be promise with the series. I like the friendships between Cyn, Meg and Troy and the Devilâ€™s Knights also have good chemistry and camaraderie. Some of the highlights of the book are when they discuss their shared love of Sons of Anarchy. I would have liked to have seen a little less screaming at each other, but otherwise thereâ€™s decent banter between them all.-WTFery rating is on the rise, but still mild: Part of what I liked is that theyâ€™re bikers but it was a fairly mild MC series. On a scale of 1-5, last book was about a 1, but thereâ€™s more violence in this book than the previous one, so Iâ€™d rate it a 2. It fits the story being told and thereâ€™s potential for more as the series continues. These guys are trying to keep clean, but arenâ€™t afraid to step it up in defense of their women and those they love, which I admit I enjoy.Rigid and Cyn have their sweet moments: When the time is spent with Rigid and Cyn and they actually speak, I think thereâ€™s a connection between the two. The teasing about Rigidâ€™s real name, Cynâ€™s wish for a doughnut house, those were a bit wacky and had there been some real emotional scenes dealing with her assault, I think there would have been a good balance. Howeverâ€¦.-Not alot of soul searching: What I expected was some time dealing with the fallout from Cynâ€™s assault and there is some, but thereâ€™s not alot of deep soul searching. I struggled with the repetitiveness of the first half of the book and the insistence of Rigid as well as other characters, wanting to â€œfixâ€ Cyn. I would have much rather had them just admit they want to support her, and let her fix herself. In the end, she waffled back and forth for a while, but I wasnâ€™t completely satisfied with the emotional component because there I felt I was told about their feelings, but not so much shown them. More attention was spent describing the food for their cookouts and Rigid packing than their emotional scenes.-Not a standalone: I wouldnâ€™t recommend reading this without reading the first book if only because thereâ€™s little recap of Rigid and Cynâ€™s first meeting or even a glimpse of it from their perspective, instead of what we saw/heard of it from Megâ€™s perspective in the first book. Honestly, it just added to the overall feel of insta-love between them. Sexy times are also mild, but considering she starts the story having just been assaulted, it makes sense.-Continuity/typo errors: What I really struggled with were continuity, grammar and typographical errors. Normally I can gloss over an error or two, because those happen even with the big publishers. But there were quite a few here. For example, a character saying heâ€™s seen the villain three times, then later in the book heâ€™d only seen him once. Cyn has a broken arm but sheâ€™s gripping Rigid on the back of his bike with her broken arm, or carrying a plate of food and four drinks. So many missing little words or the incorrect version of them (such as to instead of too, youâ€™re instead of your, hear instead of here). All these little things that distract and pull you out of the story and I think a good beta reader or editor should have caught that or at least questioned it. It just felt as if it was rushed to print.The Bottom LineIt was ok and thatâ€™s mostly due to likability of the characters. I really wanted to enjoy it, but there were a few too many missed opportunities - not enough emotional buildup, too much repetitive dialogue and too many continuity/typos that took me out of the story too many times.

Original review at http://afterdarkbooklovers.com/2015/07/30/book-review-servicing-the-target-by-cherise-sinclair/The Good, the Even Better and Everything In BetweenThis is one of my favorite Shadowlands ever. Ben and Anne had a great, balanced power exchange - Ben's not too submissive and Anne wasn't too rigid in her need to top. They really worked as a cohesive unit. The conflict was genuine, the sex was steamy and the love was sweet. Add to that the glimpses of the earlier couples and the continuing friendships, and I was in heaven.The Bottom LineI absolutely loved it and I highly recommend it for fans of Cherise Sinclair, and for BDSM romance junkies. Check it out.

Alyssa Barrow, met her husband Rob at nineteen, and they lived happily ever afterâ€”until he died. He knew he was dying of cancer, and he urged his young wife to go on and find love again, and wrote up some sexy cards to encourage her opening up her body and soul to someone else, when the time was right. Two years later, that time has come - the moment Harrison Kemp moves in next door. Harrisonâ€™s not into a relationship and Alyssa just wants to feel again, but you canâ€™t stop romance when it happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenLoved the premise: Something about second loves fascinate me from a romantic perspective. The process of moving on and finding love again is a trope that I think plays beautifully in most romance novels. Knowing that Alyssa lost her husband two years ago helped with believing that she was open to the possibility of falling in love again, although her love for Rob felt more in keeping with great friendship than passionate love. The cards and how they inspired Alyssa and Harrisonâ€™s relationship was great. The setting in Toronto was fun and Alyssaâ€™s condo association meetings, and the little scenes with her neighbors, were funny and gave a good backdrop for this romance.Good sexual chemistry: Harrison and Alyssaâ€™s sexual relationship was certainly strong enough that I believed in the lust that they had for each other. Their love scenes were plentiful and I am so going to try out that grapefruit scene. I think as The cards left by Rob, Alyssaâ€™s husband, really drove Alyssa to re-explore her sexuality, which brings me to this point - the book played more like erotic chick lit - it was all about Alyssa and her feelings and desires, but unlike most chick lit books, thereâ€™s plenty of sex.Narrow first person POV: What held me back from really loving the book was the feeling of isolation, only seeing things from Alyssaâ€™s fairly narrow viewpoint. Her reactions to Harrison usually came off as too over the top to me, and honestly, we barely get to know him except for how dirty he loves to talk (not a bad thing, but still). I really wanted to understand how they were transitioning to love from amazing sex. Sex is great, but that doesnâ€™t mean real love automatically follows. All of their intense scenes played out strictly from her POV. Even towards the end, when Alyssa is declaring her love for Harrison, when the reveal of who has been calling him on the phone and what happened that drove Harrison to not want a relationship, felt rushed and cursory. Itâ€™s all about Alyssa, which made the romance pretty one-sided.The Bottom LineI liked it and read it quickly enough, though I wished more time had been spent on Harrisonâ€™s character to really elevate the romance. There is a second book, 30 Nights, which will feature another hero/heroine, and I would be open to checking it out.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Bennett and Linc, the best man and woman at their friendsâ€™ wedding, hook up for a ONS. Ten weeks later, a pregnant Bennett realizes that sheâ€™s in for way more than she bargained for...and along the way, romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Excellent cover: Because that torso...yum. I requested it based on the torso, and that itâ€™s a shifter romance. Then I realized that I had read the earlier book in the series, Take it Like a Vamp. That was a cute book and this is right in line with it.-Standalone: The story picks up at the end of the last one and Nick and Casey feature as secondary characters. It might be better to have read Take it Like a Vamp first. That said, thereâ€™s enough details here that you could pick up on the basics of this â€˜verse without feeling lost.-Funny and cute: Linc and Bennett have good chemistry and thereâ€™s not alot of angst, considering they never planned on continuing their relationship, even if theyâ€™re crazy attracted to each other. I give them both points for stepping up and dealing with it in an adult way and even when Bennett picks on Linc - alot of it is blamed on hormones, mostly itâ€™s just the way she is - I think they work together. I would have liked more about them, as opposed to all the madness of the pregnancy and secrets revealed about the past.-Some danger: Thereâ€™s some discussion of the danger that Bennett and her baby is in, and Linc is second in command to Nick, so theyâ€™re all about protection. I just think that thereâ€™s alot of build up for the danger that theyâ€™re in, and then not much happens on that front before the story wraps and theyâ€™re into their HEA. Itâ€™s light and breezy,  Itâ€™s light and breezy read though, so I wasn't necessarily surprised, I just wished it would have cashed in on the possible danger. I do think thereâ€™s potential for another book (I see you Mason...and Iâ€™d like to see more), so Iâ€™d like to see them living their HEA and whatâ€™s going on with the baby and its interesting supernatural heritage.The Bottom Line [3 ½ stars]I liked it as a easy read with funny characters and a healthy dose of paranormal happenings to spice things up. If youâ€™ve read and enjoyed Take it Like a Vamp, or a fan of light shifter romances, youâ€™ll probably enjoy this as well.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Woolf Jennings is a man with secrets. The biggest of which is his club, The Wicked Horse, and what kinky goings-on happen in the Silo. He loves his hedonistic lifestyle, until Callie Hayes comes back to Wyoming and shows him what heâ€™s really been missing, You know...romance.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-I love Bridger: Now this is rare that I start a review with this much love for a supporting player, but really? Bridger has the potential to be the shiznit. I have warned my fellow shorties that I have dibs on him. Heâ€™s the alpha, he has the dark and mysterious past, smoking sexuality, no problem with commanding a room and yeah, I want him. Like, right now would be great Ms. Bennett. Thank you.-Good chemistry between Woolf and Callie: Ok, onto the main event - when it comes to the featured players, Woolf and Callie, I thought they were a good bridge between your usual Sawyer Bennett hero/heroine, into a slightly kinkier iteration in this series, which is more sexcentric than any of the previous books Iâ€™ve read by her.  Woolfâ€™s always been attracted to Callie, but he felt he didnâ€™t deserve the good girl. Callie just wanted him since the moment she realized boys were different. Thereâ€™s a sweetness to their attraction and I loved seeing Woolf get possessive (even with some of the events later in the book) and Callie break out of her shell. I would have liked some more dialogue between Callie and Woolf, to really showcase an emotional connection. Thereâ€™s a hint of it when they go camping where you really feel their underlying friendship, but I just wanted more talking. But the sex did distract me, because itâ€™s titillating.-Kinky effery: Their sex scenes have a good amount of heat and theyâ€™re more daring sexually than traditional romances, especially with introducing another player into their personal mix. Like say, Bridger. Yum. Now, as long as dirty talkingâ€™s your main thing, thatâ€™s cool because thereâ€™s no real BDSM scenes. Thereâ€™s multiple partner sex and some anal play, but beyond that the rest is only implied. This book was more about Woolf stopping his kinky ways than any real exploration into the lifestyle. Thereâ€™s alot of talk in the beginning about what goes on in the Silo, but I feel that the kinky effery is only window dressing here.-Woolfâ€™s more of a beta: Woolf is hot with Callie, and their chemistry is strong, there is no doubt. But Bridger is the alpha man who captured my interest. Woolf deferred to Bridger for his kinks, and Bridgerâ€™s the reason heâ€™s even into the Silo. Bridgerâ€™s the one who guides Woolf through alot of this story and just felt like the man in charge. While I enjoyed this book, the one I really want is Bridger.-Callie wants to walk on the wild side: Callie meets Woolf after years apart when he catches her about to enter a wet t-shirt contest at the Wicked Horse. Callieâ€™s pretty clear about her feelings for Woolf and is willing to dip her toes into the kinky waters, but sheâ€™s really not built for that lifestyle. Especially considering her family connections. My only quibble with her is how she tends to back down and fall into â€œgood girlâ€ mode a little too easily. Sheâ€™s more passive than I would ave liked and she defers to daddy when the inevitable final obstacle happens. That didnâ€™t work for me that well, even if it fit her character.-Series potential: With the introduction of Bridger and the other employees at the Wicked Horse, there is good potential for future books. Basically, I felt thereâ€™s a good tease that makes you want more. Did I mention that I think Bridgerâ€™s book is going to be the one that really hooks me? Because, yeah Iâ€™d like that one now.The Bottom Line [3 Â½ stars]Woolf and Callie have their own sweet heat, and for a foray into BDSM for Ms. Bennett, I think it's a good start to a new series. I liked it, but I have a feeling itâ€™s the future entries in the series that will really be my faves. Yes, Iâ€™m still looking at you Bridger.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Kai Monahan, human, is drawn into the dragonâ€™s world through circumstances beyond her control. When sheâ€™s accidentally heartsworn to Rhys, the dragon king (it only takes a touch), they have to figure out if they can go through with completing the bond while dodging the big bad dragonâ€™s thatâ€™s trying to kill Rhys and eventually, the human race. You know, that old chestnut.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenMore urban fantasy/paranormal than romance: The writing is good and the world building is done well. There is alot to process though, so the first half of the book lagged a bit while I adjusted to all the bits of info being thrown at me. That said, I read this pretty quickly because the overarching storyline of the big bad whoâ€™s trying to usurp the dragon throne kept me intrigued.I think this works much more as an urban fantasy than the romance, but itâ€™s the first book in a trilogy, so I can only hope that the romance gets stronger as it goes along. Regardless, I am interested in many of the secondary characters (#teamCadoc!), so they are whatâ€™s keeping me coming back for more.About that romanceâ€¦.: In an interesting â€˜verse, it was the weakest part of it. I really wish tat more time and attention had been spent in really making the reader feel some chemistry between Kai and Rhys. For the first third of the book, they barely interact, and quite frankly, I thought Kai had more chemistry with Cadoc (who breaks my heart and needs a HEA stat). Rhys waffled alot, clearly didnâ€™t want a mate, but even when heâ€™s heartsworn, it felt more like an obligation than any kind of real feelings for Kai.Kai could be frustrating as a heroine, and as immature as youâ€™d expect a 20 year old to be, thrust into a very strange world where no one wants to explain anything to her. I was hard pressed to hold it against her completely, because the dragons were lacking in any kind of empathy for her and how strange this all was. Deryn, Rhysâ€™ sister, in particular, irked me alot. She was saved by Kai, more than once, and barely acknowledged it - she just came off as a jerk. I thought Ashem and Juli had the best chemistry of them all, and theyâ€™re a small part of the overall story.The Bottom LineI liked it, but more as an urban fantasy more than a romance. I would recommend for fans of UF who don't need a strong romantic angle. Iâ€™d be interested in the next book.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Sandra has just moved back from New York, to escape an abusive Dom. She still needs her D/s fix, so she goes to Club Desire, where she meets Brent. Brent knows Sandra from high school, where he carried a torch for her, but she doesnâ€™t recognize him. Can Brent protect Sandra while introducing her to BDSM kinky effery? Well, you know romance is gonna happen.The Good, The Bad and Everything in BetweenNew to me author: Iâ€™ve never read anything by this author, but I did like the set up to this club. I thought Club Desire reminded me of a little of other BDSM clubs in Romancelandia, where the Doms are tasty and itâ€™s all about the safe, sane and consensual, which I can get down with. Thereâ€™s a wealth of potential for other Doms to find their own HEAs, and Iâ€™d definitely like to check out Dexâ€™s story.BDSM 101: If there was one thing that took me out of the love story, it was the overly instructional nature of the BDSM scenes. I appreciate the need to emphasize the SSC motto but I felt that some of the spontaneity and chemistry between the characters was sacrificed for it. Brent would explain what he was about to do to Sandra, and then Sandra would describe the exact same thing. It made it feel repetitive instead of sexy. Now, Iâ€™ve certainly read my fair share of BDSM tales, so this may not bother someone who is less familiar with the genre.Insta-love: Brent and Sandra have that instant attraction and you could say itâ€™s insta-love, especially on Sandraâ€™s part. I mean, at 4% sheâ€™s already thinking that he could be the man that could dominate and care for her. It felt kind of quick. There is a bit of good chemistry at first, and thereâ€™s definite heat between them. When the â€œsecretâ€ that Brent knew Sandra in high school comes out, it plays out pretty much exactly as you expect it to.Crazy villain danger: Thereâ€™s the psycho ex Dom, who has some pages devoted to his crazy stalking. Even if heâ€™s completely irredeemable, it does add tension to the story.The Bottom LineI liked elements of this and I think thereâ€™s potential for the series. If you like safe BDSM romances, you may enjoy this.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Review originally posted at (...)Edie and Magnus have been enlisted to be part of the wedding party for their friendsâ€™ bridezilla wedding and sparks fly when they meet. Mostly of the angry hate kind. Sheâ€™s a cat lady, heâ€™s a gamer and ...well, itâ€™s a twist on Taming of the Shrew, and of course sweet, sweet romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Iâ€™m a sucker for Shakespeare inspired tales: So Taming of the Shrew is a weakness of mine, so when I saw the blurb for this book, I was into the idea from the very beginning. Thereâ€™s good banter throughout between all the characters, and I loved Edieâ€™s friendship with Gretchen. Theyâ€™re both abrasive in their own ways, but they absolutely click together and made it easy for me to connect with Edie.-Edieâ€™s has claws, but I loved her: Edieâ€™s had a hard go of it and after a horrible accident years ago, she has a limp to show for it. What I loved though is that the accident didnâ€™t make her a raging bitch. Sheâ€™s always been a raging bitch.She does not suffer fools gladly and she says what she feels. But sheâ€™s not a one note character - too many times, the focus on a heroineâ€™s hard edges for too long can make you not care once her soft underbelly shows through. In this case, Edieâ€™s shines from the beginning, through her love of cats. I loved that she cares for those that are thrown away, and well, letâ€™s just say I understood her love of cats, having at one point in my life owned four of them.  The accident did take her self-confidence and her ex took her trust, but sheâ€™s got a good core that makes her relatable, at least to me.-Magnus is a great match for her: He starts a bit dick-ish, and his intro to Edie was anything but love at first sight. As he explains to her later though,"Let me share something with you, my little cat lady. Guys that get together? Talk s*** about three things: sports, games, and chicks. None of it should be taken as gospel." He thought for a moment, then added, "Except the sports." After another moment, he added, "And maybe the gaming. But not the s*** about the chicks. That"s just guys talking crap to other guys."I think itâ€™s his story arc thatâ€™s my fave. He really gets Edie. Heâ€™s intrigued with her from the start, even if sheâ€™s prickly.  Their chemistry was good and the sex was fun with just enough raunch.-Their siblings? I have no love for them: They suck. No doubt. They are all about themselves  and when the big reveal happens I was happy that they both got what was coming to them.-Great, great grovel at the end: First of all, I have to commend the fact that Magnus mans up and does what needs doing when it counts. And when he has to prove his love for Edie? Iâ€™ll admit, I was completely touched by the gesture. It got to the heart of the story and really tied it all together. It gave me the happy fuzzy feels that I want in my romance and made me believe in their HEA.The Bottom LineThis is my favorite billionaire romance by Ms. Clare so far - I really connected with Edie, and Magnus really came through in the end. Iâ€™d definitely recommend for those who love a little prickly banter (and lots of cats) in their romances.**ARC provided by author for review**

Renner Blackfoot is tired of going from random hookup to random hookup, and when he sees the new masseuse at the clanâ€™s lodge, he has to meet her. Except heâ€™s already met her - he doesnâ€™t realize itâ€™s his Bethy, the girl he treated like poo when they were kids because, well heâ€™s a boy. Itâ€™s complicated, but romance does happen.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Freebie: sometimes you have to wade through alot of rocks to get a gem, but this is one.-Who doesnâ€™t like a shifter Christmas in July?: Well, a little bit of Christmas, but it wasnâ€™t so overwhelming that you felt like youâ€™re spitting up tinsel, so I liked it.-Novella length: Read it in a couple of hours, and it was worth the time. Surprisingly well done â€˜verse with good character development and intriguing shifter rules that arenâ€™t the norm.-Good chemistry between leads: Renner was going through alot when he was a kid and took it out on Bethy, and she wanted to comfort him. But when it comes down to it, Renner really did care about her and the little things that proved to her that he cared was just sweet. Thereâ€™s talk about his past hookups, but itâ€™s all off page, and he is definitely all about Bethany.-Not sure about the logic in not mating: Itâ€™s different, but Iâ€™m not sure how I feel about this being the big obstacle, besides Bethy and Rennerâ€™s history. That said, Iâ€™d read more books set in this â€˜verse, for sure.The Bottom LineI liked it and I bought the Ozark Mountain shifter bundle based on this book, so I'd say this freebie did its job. If youâ€™re into shifter romances with a BBW heroine, check it out.

Quinnâ€™s set up on a blind date by his sister Deb. Paige is Debâ€™s co-worker. Quinnâ€™s a bear. Thereâ€™s alot of sex, all the while avoiding the topic of fated mate. So of course, romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenThe Good: Shifter romance, sheâ€™s a BBW heroine, he loves all of her. Quinnâ€™s a bear, and sue me, I have a weakness for bear shifters. I blame Shelly Laurenstonâ€™s bears in the Pride series. She made me a life-long lover.The Bad and Everything In Between: â€œYouâ€™re my mate.â€ That sentence could have saved alot of time. I understand you need some conflict, but there has to be conflict that feels a bit more substantial than this. I didnâ€™t mind the idea of the problems with the jackals, and I would have liked to see that factor into the Big Mis instead of depending on this miscommunication about the fated mate thing.The Bottom LineI liked it, even if it had some silly moments. Iâ€™d recommend for those fans of shifter romances with BBW heroines.

The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenThis will be quick - while the first book wasnâ€™t perfect, this entry pretty much exemplifies why I think serials or multi-book romances are a) not my favorite; and b) not easy to pull off. I struggled to keep reading it, putting it down several times to complete other books because I couldnâ€™t keep my focus on the story.There were alot of declarations of love and plenty of sex, but no real excitement. All the tension in their romance was in the first installment, while this entry felt inundated with alot of sweet feels with no kick. I truly believe there is a good story here that would have been so much better with some good editing.The Bottom LineIt was an ok read that suffered from a lack of storyline. I would recommend for those hardcore lovers of student/teacher romances.

Cole and Christy are living their HEA, and dealing with small road bumps along the way relating to their relationships with their mothers.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenCole is one of my favoritest dirty talkers ever: Oh Cole. The man has a way with the dirty words that makes me fluttery. Heâ€™s just as gruff, cranky yet loving and completely devoted to Christy as I remember.Christy doesnâ€™t backslide: Sheâ€™s struggled with her weight, and this novella just reinforces the strength of will that Christy has. Her mother Martha is as horrible as ever, but itâ€™s great to see Christy handle her business.A love note for nerds: Part of Christyâ€™s appeal for me is her inner/outer nerd. Itâ€™s on full display here and the finaleâ€™s a fun postscript to their love story.Novella length:  very quick and satisfying read for fans of Heavy Issues. Which meansâ€¦Not a standalone: It really is a continuation of their story and you need to have at least a cursory knowledge of their romance. You also get a glimpse of Coleâ€™s brothers and their women, which is lovely.The Bottom LineSo, so good. Makes me want to re-read Heavy Issues (which I would read first before this book). Definitely recommend.
Kind of snug when you actually put it on, but otherwise, for the cost, it's a very good buy. Would recommend.

Carissa has a flat tire. Sheâ€™s on the side of the road, holding her baby boy, wondering what sheâ€™ll do, when a big bad biker named Joker rolls up to help her. Carissa knows Joker, but in another life. Will they reconnect and find love? *blinks* yeah, itâ€™s Kristen Ashley, so of course romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-MC romance Kristen Ashley Style: Kristen Ashley has been a favorite author of mine for a while now, anyone whoâ€™s seen my reviews may have noticed the overabundance of them on KAâ€™s books. Some books Iâ€™ve definitely connected with more than others, but the one that started it all was Motorcycle Man. It was my introduction to biker romances, and letâ€™s face it - you never forget your first.Since then, Iâ€™ve read milder MC romances and many that were way, way, way darker, so dark they make Chaos look like Candyland.  On the WTFery scale, Chaos MC is 1-2 and thatâ€™s just fine with me. They make you feel dangerous but also safe. At heart, about family first (whereas other MC romances are brothers first). These are bikers who love their women and hand out love advice to their brothers, and when they get their HEAs, itâ€™s uplifting and happy, gushy feels. Now, while Tack Allen will always hold a special place in my fluttery bits and he is the prez of my stable of book-boyfriends, Joker has moved right up there as my second favorite of this series.-Joker and Carissa had me at hello: There is so much to love about them, but the tone is set from page one. When you see their past, his abuse, and their interactions in high school I was completely on board with them getting together. He doesnâ€™t suffer any major douche-canoe moments, she doesnâ€™t get completely ditzy. Yes, heâ€™s a strong, silent type, and sheâ€™s sweet, kind, stubborn, sassy and funny. They are what you expect from a KA couple and they do not disappoint.-Oh the cameos:  There is enough backstory given so that new readers can still enjoy themselves, but these cameos are little happy presents for the longtime reader. I swear I had a smile on my face reading this book and none so big as when Iâ€™d read the names of fave characters from previous books making minor appearances. Getting those tiny glimpse of their continuing HEAs gave me the fuzzy feels. You get glimpses of heroes from Rock Chicks, Dream Men and Knight (yeah, Daddy). Those little moments just enhance that hometown vibe.Thereâ€™s little clothes/HGTV porn: While I love the tone KA can set with her descriptions, there are times when the text can get heavy with architecture/decorating bits and less on the characters and those books arenâ€™t my fave. Iâ€™m happy to say that is so not the case here. This is big on the feels, not so much on the furniture and itâ€™s great.So, the F word: Yes, formula, what did you think I meant? *blinks* Yes, KA has one and thatâ€™s not a bad thing. When she is on point? Those are some of my favorite books ever. The elements you expect are here. The story and setting is familiar, but when the characters come alive, as Joker and Carissa do, I can and will forgive the little things. So, while, yes, I do believe there are times when the story tips over to predictable and yes, the â€œdangerousâ€ parts are wrapped up fairly quickly and for the most part, off-page. You know what? I donâ€™t care. Yes, I would have liked some more tension in the story beyond Carrieâ€™s baby-daddy drama, but I enjoyed the story as it was presented to me.Theyâ€™re all coming together: And in the good way. I do think that the â€œdangerousâ€ part is building for what seems to be an overarching storyline involving the Dream Man heroes and Knightâ€™s Unfinished Heroes series.  Thatâ€™s fine because, I think any darker elements may work better in a romance featuring some of the brothers who arenâ€™t getting into relationships with a single mother.The Bottom LineThis was a very enjoyable read for me. While thereâ€™s no big danger, there are big, happy fuzzy feels that a Kristen Ashley fan will enjoy. I definitely recommend this.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Michael Anderson, stuffed shirt businessman who wants everything in order in his life, meets Mia Argaropolis, artist and basically anything but orderly. Sparks fly, disaster strikes often, and in the midst of all that, romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Had the feel of a screwball comedy, at first: Then things settled into a humorous, not too wacky read. Their first meet was probably the most screwball yet fun, and there are some very adorable moments with the Queen Bs and Clancy, the dog. The humor never went too crazy and was paced fairly well.-Michael and Mia have decent chemistry...: The big three (first meet, first kiss, first love scene) were a mixed bag for me. The first meet and kiss were very good, the first love scene took quite a while to get to and was a bit of a disappointment. Their feelings changed like lightning, instead of feeling gradual and organic to the story. It could change in the space of a paragraph and I wanted to side more with Mia, but the miscommunications...oy vey.-The dreaded Big Mis: Those miscommunications were pretty much all at Miaâ€™s feet and I wish it had been a bit more even in terms of screwups. The big ones, which lead to their separation, were all Mia jumping to conclusions, which wasnâ€™t as satisfying for me.The Bottom LineIt was cute, though the miscommunications felt a bit forced and didnâ€™t quite work for me. It was an enjoyable enough afternoon read that I would give this series another shot.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

Angie is hired by Charles to clean out his fatherâ€™s townhouse, but warned never to talk to his father, Grayson. Angie shows up at the dusty hoarder house and is intrigued, curious about the poor old man living in the ruins of this home. Until she realizes heâ€™s not that old and also, super hot. Then, romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenThe Good: It almost had a Beauty and the Beast vibe, since the hero hides away on the second floor of the house. I enjoyed the intrigue in getting to know Grayson, bit by bit. The build to his reveal did pull me in and I really wanted to love this love story, because the premise is solid. The idea of the hero being schizophrenic and having to live with that mental illness, as well as the glimpses of his struggle, are by far the strongest parts of this story.The Not So Good: However, the entire story is told from Angieâ€™s POV and sheâ€™s contradictory in her attitudes and actions, and at times, really hard for me to connect with. Sheâ€™s horrified at the way she invades Graysonâ€™s privacy one moment, then offended that he wants to keep his privacy. Moments that are supposed to be charming and cute, really didnâ€™t resonate with me.I appreciated that she had a full life, however, the narrative sometimes gets bogged down in the minutiae of her day. Also, her attitudes towards other characters can be fairly judgy, which is a bit of a turnoff and thereâ€™s certain things that she blames herself for that are disturbing to me as a woman.Finally, the villain of the piece has no depth. Heâ€™s just a greedy little bastard and thereâ€™s no explanation as to why or how he got to be that way. I would have loved to understand what possibly went wrong, or even have a modicum of understanding of Graysonâ€™s life before Angie, and there simply isnâ€™t offered to the reader. The potential was there for some really good emotional, confrontational scenes, but the climax fell flat.The Bottom LineIt was ok. There were good moments, but overall itâ€™s a good premise that just didnâ€™t come together in the execution for me.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

In the third book in the Beneath series, Elle walks into Chains, Lordâ€™s pawn shop, just as heâ€™s firing a thieving employee. Lord knows he shouldnâ€™t go for Elle since sheâ€™s his brotherâ€™s girlfriendâ€™s BFF. Elleâ€™s looking for something very important to her and she needs to work at Chains to do it. Will romance happen? Of course.The Good, The Bad and Everything In Between-Third in series but stands alone: I havenâ€™t read the earlier books, but after reading this entry, I am curious about them and I am certainly interested in the next. Curious, but not feeling as if I couldnâ€™t keep up with whatâ€™s going on in this installment, so points for that.-Good sexy times: Lord and Elle have good chemistry, insta-love that doesnâ€™t feel too forced and hot love scenes. Lord, he has plenty of chances to flex his alpha muscles, without ever feeling too OTT. Speaking of yummy Lord...-Lordâ€™s a good alpha: Protective and caring, yet respectful to Elle, he never looks elsewhere and heâ€™s a good dirty talker. Basically he ticked alot of boxes for me. Itâ€™s a very safe read, so no nonsense with other women to muck things up.-Elle has her issues but sheâ€™s likeable: Sheâ€™s a little overwrought in her concerns but she doesnâ€™t have any major TSTL moments, and since the story is told in alternating first person POV, you get a good amount of time her head as well as Lordâ€™s. Time that explains why Elleâ€™s so concerned about ending up like her mother. This leads me to...-Sometimes repetitive: While I enjoyed the story, there are several moments where the need to repeat their motivations, such as Elle saying she wonâ€™t get into a relationship...until she does. Or Lord being careful because of who Elle is. That kind of thing was repeated often and sometimes felt obvious in a way that didnâ€™t add to the story that much.-That climax: The ultimate villain was a bit of a surprise, if only because I could have pictured future story with that character. Though sad, Iâ€™m glad it wasnâ€™t something that came straight out of the blue but made sense and I liked that.The Bottom LineA simple yet enjoyable read, Iâ€™d recommend it for those who donâ€™t mind younger H/h and like a hot yet sweet Alpha hero. Iâ€™m looking forward to the next in the series.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

When the story begins, Alexandra, a Seattle cop, is on the hunt for Apollo, a drug that can make you feel like a god, at least until your internal organs incinerate. She meets Kell, a huge biker who is, of course, more than he seems on the outside. And then romance happens.The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenIntriguing setup: Besides this obviously established â€˜verse of vampires, witches and shifters (oh my), the explanation for â€œwitchcraftâ€ was a novel one and certainly got my attention. The overarching storyline of a drug called Apollo is a good one and makes me want to continue with the series, just to see what happens with characters like Bear and Daire.Good chem between Kell and Lex: Their first meeting, first kiss and first love scene all had the right amount of heat and it was easy enough to invest in their connection.For a smart heroine, sheâ€™s a bit dim sometimes: not all the time, but Lex is portrayed as a smart capable heroine.  I would have believed it full stop if she didnâ€™t insist on referring to her girly bits and waffling about her feelings for the hero. It didnâ€™t quite work for me.Bikers in name only: while there are a couple of biker gangs mentioned, itâ€™s really in name only. On an MC romance WTFery scale, it only rates about a 1.A bit purple prose-y: The softening of said girly bits and uncoiling of heat, phrases that tipped the love scenes over the line into the land of purple prose took me out of the moment. I enjoyed their setup, but once the lovemaking kicked in, I found myself wanting to skim the love scenes.Playing catch up with earlier series: I was able to read this and follow along, so this book can standalone. That said, Iâ€™ll admit to seeing alot of characters that clearly had a history and scenes that must have happened off page in that earlier series made me want to read those books, just to find out what I was missing.The Bottom LineI liked it, despite wishing I had read the earlier companion series. The witch mythology is one Iâ€™d like to learn more about, and I would read the next one.**ARC provided by publisher via netgalley for review**

The Good, The Bad and Everything In BetweenThe Good: The writing has hints of humor, quirky characters, and I liked Nox, Garrettâ€™s son alot. Seeing the hierarchy of the pack and other shifters in the town was set up well and I actually enjoyed the chemistry between the supporting characters and the world they helped to bring to life.  The question about the Averdeen womenâ€™s powers, the history of the pack, possible human hunters...thereâ€™s alot of potential in this â€˜verse and I would be willing to read the next entry.Everything in Between: The story has its twists and turns, and I will admit it was a ride I wasnâ€™t anticipating, not sure I enjoyed all facets of, but I did read it all and I think that has to do the Ms. Eamesâ€™ writing and the potential I see here. I appreciate that sheâ€™s gone against the grain when it comes to a shifter romance. Iâ€™m just not sure if sheâ€™s ultimately successful in executing this.The Bad: I have to delve into the weakest part of this romance...and thatâ€™s the romance. Lennox and Garrettâ€™s relationship is messy, hurtful, at times sexy and filled with bittersweet moments. Alright, messy is fine and not the usual in shifter romances, where insta-love and fated mates are the order of the day. I thought that this could make it a really interesting read. If youâ€™re going to tell a story about love the second time around, it can be done in a way that allows the reader to accept that and understand why the hero/heroine is letting go of the past, and embracing love. I could have gotten behind that. However, thatâ€™s not what happens here.SPOILERY BIT ALERT - FOR THOSE WHO DONâ€™T MIND SPOILERS PROCEED. OTHERWISE, LOOK TO THE BOTTOM LINE.When the story began, I felt as if Garrett was supposed to finally realize that you can love more than once. The human heart is capable of healing and loving again. Thatâ€™s a beautiful sentiment. Unfortunately, over and over, Garrett was quite clear about choosing his wife OVER Lennox. At one point, he even acknowledges that he knew Lennox loved him and that her love had been one-sided. Yet, at the end, he he tells her sheâ€™s his soul mate? No. Just. No. That itâ€™s all wiped clean in the epilogue doesnâ€™t fix that for me.END OF SPOILERY BITThat ending: At the eleventh hour, I felt as if the story then went against all it had built up until that moment and tried to have it both ways, just to have a HEA.
