I've heard of using a bag of frozen vegetables, like corn or peas, on injuries requiring ice, but no way I was going to  - or would ever - waste my groceries that way! This is much better AND you get to reuse it (and save your frozen vegetables for eating.)EDIT Sept 17: Back to say one the nine "cubes" soon lost its liquid, but I don't care - this continues to be very helpful to me for injury relief and for the price, I'd absolutely buy it again if only for that purpose.

I've had the verbosely named pillow for a year. As my title indicates, it quickly went flat. But I realize now, that I haven't been waking up with the neck problems I used to and I think I have my flat pillow to thank. I always see how pillow styles are sold according to what "kind" of sleeper you are, i.e., back, side or stomach. I used to wonder how did people know what they were?? I now think I'm an EVERYTHING sleeper, flipping around the bed like a rotisserie most of the night. A flat pillow makes sense because it goes with everything! It took a little getting used to after fluffier pillows but I have to say, for me it makes more sense.

I like glass refrigerator storage for anything greasy or oily, like pizza, lasagna, or pasta dishes. Plastic just doesn't clean up as well and over time gets/stays a little funky and off-color. I wanted something like this without having to buy a set. This dish has a good, solid weight to it; it feels heavy, not flimsy and easily broken. I was a bit surprised to discover the lid has what could be described as a rubber seal. I'm not too crazy about that, especially that it has a lip, which will make it trickier to clean (I'll put a picture in Customer Images). The box says "For a correct use, it is recommended not to fill the container completely." I imagine that's because the lid's seal protrudes into the dish.The inside dimension of the glass dish is 7" (smaller than listed) and the height, without lid, is 3". The container can go in the freezer up to -20°C/-4Â°F and the microwave to +70Â°C/+158Â°F. No stovetop or oven use. It is made in Italy as advertised. It may be silly, but as I'm half-Italian, I kind of like that, plus I do think of Italian goods as generally being well-made. Love my purple lid!One feature I like already is that I can easily pull this forward by the lid when it's in the fridge with fingertips alone. We've got a small fridge and I have to bend & reach to haul stuff out so I appreciate anything that comes out readily.  Finally, I got a deal at under 6 bucks. For that, I am most certainly pleased. If the plastic lid holds up, I expect years of use.

As of this writing, the product listing has a typo. It *should* say 1.5 liter, but says 1, 5-Liter.  I was clued in by the dimensions listed (which could not possibly be for a 5-liter jar), but even those are inaccurate. The jar measures 3.5" wide on all sides and 7.5" tall (without the lid), so it is smaller than the dimensions listed. The jar surprisingly did not come in a box, so the Amazon measurements were not describing the packaging size as sometimes is the case. It does not hold 1.5 liters but a bit less. This jar was a disappointment. Further, it is made of very thin glass, more like a vase.

As everyone says, the sizing is all wrong. My knee, per Shock Doctor's measuring chart (i.e., 2" below the center of the patella) is 12.75" around, which is a Small according to the chart. BUT because everyone was saying in reviews to go up a size, I bought a Medium. Guess what? There was no way to get it on! I was actually HURTING MY KNEE attempting to get the thing on. I ALREADY have a knee problem, which is why I wanted the brace.  I understand, again per the information on the description, that it should fit very tight and may take a few days to "break in". That's all well and good, but further injuring myself is just not an option. The only thing I might suggest, is that my calf is muscular and at its widest is about 13.25". But nowhere on the description is there any suggestion that a muscled calf might impede getting the brace on (look, I was just stretching here anyway, trying to find any explanation for such gross size discrepancies). People who are already hurt, don't need the "cure" to make things worse. I really can't comment in good conscience about any other aspect of the brace in light of the size issues.

I buy these on sale for a buck a 4-pack at my local grocery store (and I think Dollar Tree carries them sometimes). At that price, they're a perfectly good little battery, although I wouldn't call them long-lasting. It does help not to store them in the appliance, if that's practical, but I imagine the same can be said for most batteries. I like them fine - when I get them on sale.

I have to agree with the reviewer who commented on the sticks and stems. There are an unappealing amount of them in the bag. I posted two photos in the Customer Image gallery, one of a random sample of the basil and the other just showing sticks/stems. Beyond that the flavor is just not as sharp as I'd like. I much prefered Tone's Sweet Basil Leaf - 5.5 oz. shaker. The low price, under seven bucks - plus pure greed at the the thought of a WHOLE POUND of basil - led me to try the Starwest Botanicals. (Also, I've been happy with their one pound bag of Cinnamon). I was disappointed here.

I have been using my blender happily for about 6 months. It's been great, particularly for the price (I paid ten bucks from Amazon Warehouse). One of the keys to its use is to remember it doesn't have an on/off button but a pulse button. It's not meant to be run for long, unbroken periods (think of what the human "pulse" is: on, off, on, off). I expect pulsing is the key to not frying the tiny motor. Because the cup is plastic, I avoid using any greasy or oily substances (like peanut butter) because plastic just doesn't clean up the way glass does. Also, the bottom is not removable but all of a piece so it can be tricky to really feel like the blades and bottom are properly cleaned. For these 2 minor issues, I ding a star. I really like my blender.

At the time I write the review, the product photo is somewhat different than what I received. It's on a white card & says "sterling plated" but what I received is on a blue card and merely says "metal chain." Which isn't to say I'm unhappy with it (I did hand out 4 stars from the Star Vault), but I don't like misleading product photos/descriptions and moreover you should be warned in case you have your heart set on a sterling plated product.Although at $4 it is pricier than what can be found at a craft stores like Jo-Ann's or Michael's, I was delighted to find it here since I was unable to get to a store right now but needed chain immediately for a special project. I am fairly certain I have bought the same chain in the past from a store and generally think of the Blue Moon as decent quality, a step up from Darice, say (and priced a bit higher). The chain I received was exactly 70" and a bright silver tone. It feels strong, not flimsy, even considering its delicate appearance.

I bought the 2-pack just over a year ago. The first one, which I used daily, lasted 6 months, longer then I expected. The interesting quality to the concealer is that it's like a combination foundation/powder product. It goes on wet, yet stays where it's put and dries quickly. It does not have the sticky feeling many concealers do. I'm very fair and this is a good match for my tone, not too "white" or too "oompa loompa" orange. I'm a convert; not sure I could go back to the cheap, odd-colored ones I formerly used.

Okay, I waited till I used up the whole tube before saying that my teeth look no different from before I started. Darn. I found it at Dollar Tree so it wasn't a big risk. The ingredients are unremarkable: Sodium Fluoride 0.24 % (Anticavity), followed by the Inactive ingredients: Water, Hydrated Silica, Sorbitol, Glycerin, PEG-12, Titanium Dioxide, Flavor, Cellulose Gum, Cocamidopropyl Betaine, Sodium Saccharin, Sodium Benzoate. The toothpaste is supposed to "remove" coffee, tea, wine & tobacco stains. Of those selections I drink no more than a single cup of coffee a day (and often just a half cup) and occasional tea in winter. If the paste was gonna work, it should have worked on my teeth.

The presence of the always watchable Naveen Andrews is the only reason I gave this film two stars instead of one. He doesn't have much to work with, but his intelligence and integrity - and plausibility as Dr. Hasnat Khan - come through nevertheless.I knew the film was in trouble from the start. Naomi Watts looks more like Camilla Parker Bowles than Diana, particularly in a few of the misguided hairstyles the actress sports. I'm sorry, but Watts is TOO OLD for the part and I found myself staring intently at her face for all the wrong reasons. Diana had a magical, lit-from-within quality, a compelling way of carrying herself; in fact, in her later years, what would only be called regal bearing. Diana, whatever her faults (and most of us, the public, have been schooled in them over the years) was stunning. Watts as Diana, is none of these things. She is dull as tepid swimming pool water. Flat, uninteresting, charmless. It's inconceivable that Watts' character might have ever captured the attention of the future King of England (who inexplicably makes no appearance in the film), let alone the numbers of other men, she apparently did, including a brilliant heart surgeon. There's no chemistry, sexual or otherwise, between Watts' Diana and Andrews' Khan, which is more misfortune. I found myself slogging through their affair, uninterested and unprovoked to dredge up any feelings about it one way or the other.Despite the money poured into the production, evident from the lush sets, locations, clothes, etc., this film has made-for-TV all over it. I became embarrassed for the participants as I watched it. Speaking of, most of the people in the film seem to serve as living props - nobody really makes their presence felt in a meaningful way. Again, the script doesn't help matters.Thankfully, the film does not dramatize the car accident which killed Diana. I think that would have been unforgivable in this limp, uninspired production.

Great bags! I paid just under 7 bucks three years ago and I think that was a fair price. Evidently, they've gone higher and stayed higher since. I use them weekly, at least the two small ones. I started putting my undies in one right away and I think that's extended the life span of said dainties. It's very nice to use the bags for other *iffy* items that might generally require hand-washing and wouldn't enjoy laundry rough-housing.The drawstrings on both the small bags broke in recent months, but when I got around to it, replacing the strings wasn't any trouble. The hem on one also required stitching where it was pulling apart. I absolutely think - given what I paid - that I've received my money's worth.

I wish I could rate these about 3.5 stars. The lower sodium is a great idea, but the chips are a bit greasier than they need to be. Cut that oil and you'd have yourself a crisp, tasty, 5-star chip.Lay's isn't pretending this is a low-sodium food, which they admit right on the bag. The difference is a 1 oz portion of Lay's Wavy Original Potato Chips has 140mg sodium, whereas the Lightly Salted contains 70mg sodium for the same amount. The ingredients are: Potatoes, Vegetable oil (Sunflower, Corn and/or Canola oil), and Salt.Much as I love them, I rarely eat chips because of the fat and salt; they are a treat I indulge only a couple times a year. The portion sizes, as is true of almost all foods like chips, are absurd. Lay's considers there to be 10 portions in this 9.5 oz bag. Who eats chips like that?! Not me! I thought I was doing well to make this 3 portions, which I gobbled down in 3 consecutive days. That's 1600 calories total, 900 of them fat.I'd buy these again, but not any time soon, as I'm not to be trusted in the vicinity of an open bag of good potato Chips.

I didn't buy the mustard from Amazon. I first discovered [[ASIN:B00473XF58 Koops Mustard Deli Spicy Brown, 12-Ounce (Pack of 6)] and that led to trying this horseradish variety. Ohhh, it's good! Kicky but not overbearing. If it's too horseradish-y for your taste, you can just use a lighter hand in pouring. The ingredients are: Vinegar, water, mustard seed, salt, horseradish powder, red pepper. The only way to get actual horseradish, not powdered like this, is to buy a refrigerated product. For shelf-stable, it's very good. Hooked!

With the product description's emphasis on "wind patterns" and use with plants, I really wasn't sure if it would be suitable for indoor use. It is. It doesn't feel like the wind (what wind oscillates, in a distinct repeated pattern no less??), but feels like a regular fan. That part is fine.I haven't had it very long and am torn between a 3 or 4 star rating. I need a little more time to see if it merits a 4. It doesn't exactly shout "fine craftsmanship." The fan blade itself - well, let's not kid ourselves, it's hardly a "blade" - is made of cheap, thin, clear plastic. I get that the days of finding an actual metal blade in a low-end fan are over, but this blade is especially flimsy-looking. It does not look like a part that'll last. I hope I'm wrong. It's small compared to the housing too. It's just odd to have this big fan and one of the most important features (maybe second to the motor) looks like such a cheap afterthought. The fan wobbles a bit too, the more so if you want to extend the height.I did not find assembly difficult. I won't tell you it was fun or enjoyable, but the instructions made sense to me and I figured it out. When summer hits and I'm relying on the fan a lot, I'll try to revisit this review.JULY 19, 2014 update: It's been plenty hot this summer on the East coast and I'm sticking with  (or in this climate, "sticking to")  my 3 stars. This is not a powerful fan. The flimsy, small plastic blade is simply not powerful. I got a good Warehouse deal on this fan so if it lasts a couple seasons, I'll be happy. If you want it for indoor use, just don't expect gushing winds.

Full plot outlines are easy to come by in other reviews here or elsewhere. I want to review this film strictly to tell you it's worth your time to see an actress at the top of her game. From Amy Madigan's first frame, she's riveting. People talk about roles where all of an actor's personal vanity is dropped. This is one of those. You will not catch her acting; she even *thinks* in character.I have a deep appreciation for anyone who spends decades honing their skill in any field. Their mastery is a gift for the rest of us. I will be far from the first person to lament the absence of roles in filmdom for older people, especially actresses. It's a damn shame when the best far too often have to sit out on the sidelines. I am oh so happy to say Amy Madigan is not going quietly.

This terrific mustard is sold at the local Dollar Tree. It's my go-to mustard now. The ingredients are vinegar, water, mustard seed, salt and turmeric. The sodium comes in at 60mg per tsp (or 3% daily value) which is great because the lower salt allows the spicy mustard flavor to really shine through. With that great kick, I don't need to use a lot so one bottle lasts awhile. Despite vinegar and water being the first two ingredients the consistency is nice & thick, not watery. Koops' mustard is made in the U.S.Bonus recipe: Mustard-seasoned Potatoes. Without peeling, cut a bunch of potatoes - no more than can fit in an even layer on a baking sheet - into bite-size pieces. Put potato pieces in large bowl, add olive oil to coat and a healthy squirt of mustard. Stir. If you're feeling frisky you can also add fresh minced garlic. Spread on baking sheet and bake till done, stirring and flipping occasionally so all sides brown evenly. So good!

Oh man, are these good. I didn't buy them from Amazon but they're commonly available at grocery stores. I buy tortilla chips or any kind of chips for that matter, as a rare treat, basically just a few times a year. Sure, I'd LIKE to eat them more often but I can't pretend these should be a staple in my generally quite healthy diet. Having said that the ingredient list is happily short: white corn, yellow corn, vegetable oil (contains soybean, cottonseed and/or sunflower oil), salt, trace of lime. The sodium is 120mg (5% Daily Value) per 1 oz and as is typical of such products, the claim is there's 11 (1 oz) servings in the bag. They have a delightful crunch and perfect flavoring. Mix up salsa or guacamole, bake a tray with shredded cheese or just eat them straight from the bag - can't go wrong.

I did not but these from Amazon but found them at Dollar Tree which thrilled me - at first. The sodium is high at 550mg per 3 pieces (25% Daily Value) but that's not unexpected. With any product like this I rinse before eating so that cuts some of the salt and preservatives. Having done that though, the taste was a disappointment, somewhat vinegary/acidic. Not like marinated, like chemicals. The ingredient list after artichokes is water, salt, citric acid, ascorbic acid and calcium chloride. They aren't lousy enough to throw out but neither do I want to rush back to Dollar Tree to stock up. I'd pass on these.

My wife had good results with prenatal DHA: healthy, bright kids with good eyesight, and a clear mind for her before, during, and after pregnancy.  DHA an essential omega-3 fatty acid derived from fish oil.  Manufacturer recommends taking these DHA supplements during pregnancy and lactation.  My wife's sister is expecting her first child in 2016 so we let her give these Viva Labs Prenatal DHA supplements a try.  Ours and sis-in-law's OB deemed these supplements OK to take.  Recommended daily dosage is two softgels that contain 640mg of total Omega-3's: EPA (100mg),  DHA (480mg), and other Omega-3's (60mg).  We like these non-GMO, sugar-free, gluten-free, dairy-free supplements without any artificial sweeteners, colors, or flavors.  Be sure to consult one's own healthcare practitioner such as OB or prenatal nutritionist prior to using any type of dietary supplement!

All caring parents want their very young children to have a good foundation in learning.  My wife and I are strong advocates.Likes:*Toys developed in consultation with Stanford Professor Emeritus Don Roberts.  Sounds impressive.*"1-2-3 Count" and "Color and Shapes" (both for kids 6-12 months) are soft fabric activity "books" that teach our child about those topics.  Kids get to see, feel, and hear the numbers, colors, and shapes that they're learning about.  Press the button in the attached mini pouch to hear fun and melodic phrases.*"Let's Learn Sounds" (wooden sound puzzle for 18-24 months) are puzzle pieces that make seven specific sounds of instruments when placed correctly in their respective slots.  Worked OK when we used two fresh alkaline AAA batteries (not included).Limitations:*Counting toy only counts to five.*Color and Shapes sounds only provides seven combinations, example: green circle.*Wooden puzzle sounds became inconsistent after the batteries slowly drained.Overall:*While we agree with Prof. Roberts' philosophy of "encourage learning through repetition and coordination", our youngest child learned and mastered these simple activities very quickly and became bored with these learning toys after a week.  She did have fun playing these toys again with her little pals when they came over to visit.

Medium fits good for me: 5'10", 32" waist, 32" inseam.  100% cotton similar to 200tc bed sheet material; not the softest.  Got a bit softer after a few washes.  Workmanship variable.  One pair had one pocket sewn closed.  There were some excess threads hanging but easy to trim away.  Nice plaid color combo.  Convenient elastic waist with drawstring.

There are many fitness apps for the iPhone 6, therefore it's crucial to have a reliable armband case to carry the smartphone around.  This Sport-Fit Armband seems like a good choice.Likes:*Good, thin neoprene case with adjustable, heavy duty velcro band to securely fasten the armband to most size arms.*Flip the top cover back and slide in the iPhone 6.  It snugly fits my iPhone 6 along with a thin UAG protective case.*Built-in clear plastic screen protector provides an extra layer of protection.  The phone's home button and touch screen still works underneath it!*Overlapping top neoprene flap provides some sweat and water/rain resistance.  NOT waterproof!*Gray with pink accents cover with black neoprene back and strap that both my wife and I can wear.  Hey, even NFL players wear bits of pink for charity purposes.*Holds the smartphone securely during running, walking, hiking, and most outdoors activities.*Easier/safer for me to carry a phone around than using a front pants pocket or shallow shirt pocket.*Useful for carrying phone when there are no pockets, e.g., running shorts or tennis skirts.Shortcomings:*Only opening in in case is the earphone jack.  Need to remove the phone to access all other ports, microphone, and back camera lens, etc.*A bit tedious to remove the phone without first unfastening the armband.*Rather comfortable that I occasionally forget that I'm wearing it and accidentally bump into something with my arm.

This nozzle was exactly what we were searching for; a nozzle that lays down flat to approx 42mm, 1 5/8in. high to get into spaces and crevices underneath beds, tables, dressers, chairs, sofas, and other furniture's, etc.Likes:*The 35mm diameter attachment fits our Electrolux Jetmaxx Canister Vac and Bissell ProHeat 2X.*Nicely designed lay flat and side to side pivoting vacuum head for easy manipulation and use.*Average quality plastics, rollers, and construction.*Rolls easily and sucks up dust, dirt, and debris effortlessly with no loss of vacuum power.Drawbacks:*Make sure to measure one's current attachment diameters to make sure this accessory will fit!*This 35mm diameter tube attachment doesn't fit our Bissell CleanView and Dyson DC40 upright vacuums with 32mm (1.25") diameter attachments.*The included adapter is for an even larger 38mm diameter attachment; none for the smaller 32mm attachments.*No built-in headlight to illuminate dark spaces underneath furniture's.*Approx. 31mm,12.25in. wide vacuum head works OK underneath larger furniture's but is cumbersome underneath smaller furniture's.

We needed some extra cups for our huge family/relatives party so I selected these Hefty College Cups to try them out.  Each box contains three packs of 28 cups (18 oz./ 532ml) = 84 cups.  Yes, some family members and relatives are into college football but most didn't seem to mind these orange Tennessee Volunteers (Peyton Manning's Alma mater) cups when the beer started flowing from the kegs.  The cups are "hefty" and not easily collapsible like cheaper generic brands.  We'll definitely be purchasing these Hefty College Cups of our favorite teams in the future for tailgate and game parties.  Slight drawback: not all of the top NCAA football teams are represented.

Our baby was experiencing teething pain and irritability when her teeth started to erupt.  We wanted to avoid all teething meds with chemicals so this Hyland's Baby Teeth Gel was a better alternative.  Works pretty well when we were able to actually apply the gel on our twisting and turning baby's gums.  Hyland's teething tablets are somewhat easier to use because teething babies want to chew on something and the tablets quickly dissolve.

Our toddler loves trains and she was ecstatic when we let her play with the Vtech Connect & Sing Animal Train.Likes:*Four colorful, cute animals in a train engine and three cargo cars that capture kids' attention.*Color molded plastics with rounded edges and corners.  No flaking paint.*Many unique features including the "Magical Engine" that recognizes which cargo/passenger car is connected and responds accordingly.*Four modes of interactive activities controlled by the sliding blue switch on the engine: Music/songs, Quiz, Instruments, and Animals.*Sliding yellow power switch settings: Off, low volume, and high volume.*25+ songs, melodies, sounds, and phrases to keep our little one amused for hours.*Kids learn about music, animals, instruments, and colors and also develop basic motor skills, musical sign-alongs, and simple language/words skills.*Our toddler especially enjoy the Quiz mode where she can answer simple questions by pressing the appropriate animal/color/instrument.*Has a built in cord for child to pull the train along.*Includes 2 AA batteries.*Appropriate for children 1.5 to 4 years old.Miscues:*Phrases and songs are undertandable but the toy speaker doesn't provide the clearest sounds.*Continous play on "high" volume can get annoying after awhile.  Parents need to remain calm.*Rolling wheels on the engine only, not on the cargo/passenger cars.*Train engineer, "Cody" the blue Cub, drives the train but erroneously identifies itself as the train conductor.  Cody doesn't play an instrument (driving the darn train!) and isn't in any animal or color quiz question.*Song "The Train Conductor Drives the Train" is incorrect.  The train engineer drives the train.  Need to teach the correct facts.

My wife and I active sports participants and have our share of muscle and joints aches and pains.  We usually take 800mg tabs of Motrin/ibuprofen but that can cause stomach ulcers if taken in high dosages so we tried this Goody's "Back & Body Pain Relief" liquid.Likes:*2oz./60ml bottles for convenience on the go.  Don't need any water to help swallow tablet/gel caps.*Liquid 1000mg acetaminophen in orange flavor tastes alright, is easier to swallow, and is absorbed faster than tablets and gelcaps for faster pain relief. We start to feel our aches and pain dissipate after 20-30 minutes compared to about 45-60 minutes for tablets.*Antifebrile.  Reduces fevers.*No caffeine which is great for us; we're both very sensitive to caffeine.Concern:*1000mg of liquid acetaminophen is very high yet effective, non-narcotic analgesic/pain reliever.  However, maximum daily amount is 3 x 1000mg doses.  Overdoses may cause liver damage.

Both hemp seeds and marijuana are made from the Cannabis plant but proteins derived from hemp do not contain significant amounts of  tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) that is present in marijuana.What's good:*This 3 lbs. bag of Viva Labs Organic Hemp Protein is vegetarian/plant based, readily dissolves in liquids, is easily digested.*Each 30g (4 tbsp) servings provides 15g. of protein, 7g. of fiber (28% Daily Value), 390mg Potassium (11%), and Iron (64%).*Can be mixed with one's favorite drinks or made into baked goods, smoothies, oatmeal, protein bars, etc.*Other serving suggestions: mix with cacao powder, coconut oil, or maca powder for a protein fortified shake.Real life performance:*Tastes like flour (from hemp).  No flavor.  Needs to be mixed with one's favorite drinks or foods to make it more palatable.*Mixes into a pea soup green protein shake that doesn't look too inviting.

My retired father have taken Centrum Silver multivitamin supplements for years.  The UltraMan Daily Multi High Potency seemed like a good alternative to try.What's good:*Each serving size, two tablets, has much more potency, examples: Vitamin B-1 (2000% Daily Value), Vitamin B-2 (1765% DV), Vitamin B-12 (1667% DV), etc. than one tablet of Centrum Silver (most vitamin % DV at around 100%).*Additional supplements for men 50+:  Choline bitartrate, Inositol, Boron, Amino Acid Blend, Bio-Active Blend, Herbal Blend, and Vitality Blend.*My father seems to have extra energy and vitality after taking these UM50+ supplements for about two weeks.Concerns:*It's good to have extra supplements but the efficacy of those herbal and amino acid supplements are not clinically proven.*Each 120 tablets bottle only provides a 60 days supply.*Priced at around $0.25 per tablet or $0.50 for daily serving of two tablets compared to $0.07 per daily tablet/serving of Centrum Silver.*My father's positive results could be placebo effect or the fact that he exercises vigorously for 50 minutes (steep uphill walking) daily.

Our baby is full of curiosity so we try to keep the little tyke busy with child-safe toys that will help stimulate the senses and be beneficial during early development.  This colorful and fun "Shake, Rattle and Teethe" set consists 1 mini blanket, a stroller clip, four toys: a Squeak lion, A Mirror turtle, a Rattle toucan, and a Teether monkey, and a stroller clip to hold all the toys like a large key ring.  The mini blanket has different colorful patterns and textures on either side, and is machine washable/air dry.  The toys are cute, smiling animal characters that keep our little one busy and amused for hours.  This toy set comply with "U.S. Toy Safety Standard ASTM F963" so we're reassured there are no sharp edges, no flaking paint, no choking hazards, and no toxic materials used.

My young nephews and one niece love the WWE so I (their uncle and legal guardian) let them give these "Create a WWE Superstar" action figures a try.  They really like all the popular figures such as the Rock, Rey Lucha, John Cena, Bray Wyatt, and Kane Rocker.  Each ~7.5" figure comes with an assortment of masks, capes, weapons, armor, and removable tattoo decals/stickers so the kids can mix and those to build up an exact WWE character that the like.  The characters also have interchangeable torsos, arms, legs, and boots that snaps-in easily to connect.  These are truly action figures because the limbs articulate at the neck, shoulders, elbows, wrists, hips, and knees, and boots, thus allowing a wide variety of wrestling and action poses.  The kids love these figures.  The only drawbacks are that the smaller parts are easily misplaced and the kids have to learn to organize and store these figures away neatly; not leaving them all around the house.

My kids love Dreamworks movies and this game has all the popular characters such as Shrek, Kung Fu Panda, Madagascar, How to Train your Dragon, Penguins of Madagascar, etc.!  It is an easy and fun to play game that teaches children how to follow instructions, improving visual searching ability by finding specific objects printed on the large 6-foot gameboard, and cooperation during searching.  This game provides loads of fun for the entire family (not for kids younger than 4 due to small parts and ability to understand simple game rules).  Good, wholesome, old fashioned board game that gets the kids away from their mind-numbing smartphones, video game consoles, and tablets.  Slight drawback: kids know where most of the objects are after a few rounds of this game.

Our house is full of electronics, kitchen appliances, home office, multimedia, etc. therefore lots of surge protectors are needed.  My samples are three and six outlets surge protectors (one of each).What's good:*The three outlet protector can be plugged into the upper outlet of a dual plug wallplate and leaves the lower outlet accessible.*Both provide 750 joules of surge protection which is adequate for most basic home appliances and electronics.*Surge indicator light.*Has sliding safety covers to prevent young geniuses from sticking metal objects into them and getting electrocuted.*Light grey protector blends in with most wall decor.*$100,000 connected equipment warranty protection for peace of mind.*Work as advertised.Concerns:*The six outlet protector plugs into a top outlet of a wallplate and has a built in plastic prong that plugs into the lower outlet.  That means one 6 outlet protector per one dual plug wallplate.*Amazon shipped these in plain bubble wrap manila envelopes so the ground prongs were bent; luckily not broken.

My wife has long, silky, dark but dry hair that requires delicate care.  She was glad to try out this TRESemmÃ© anti-frizz creme as a final touch-up for getting rid of any split-ends and unruly frizzy hair.  The bottom capped tube is easy to dispense and apply.  The creme is readily absorbed, and really do control any residual frizzy hair.  We also like pleasant, fruity scent that's not overpowering.  This hair creme does work alright but for best results, the entire TRESemmÃ© Smooth haircare line of products is recommended.

With a family full of electronics and mobile devices, it's good to have a wall mounted surge protector/outlets with built in USB charger ports.Pros:*My sample comes with three surge protected 3-prong outlets and two 2.4Amp USB charging ports.*Top of outlet has a rubber coated cradle for a smartphone or smaller mobile device during charging.*Built in surge protection indicator light.*Fast charging for all of my mobile devices without hogging up all the outlets.Cons:*This charger/surge protector can only be plugged into the lower outlet of a standard dual plug wallplate.*Rather than a simple 3-prong plug in the back, my sample has a metal securing screw that replaces the main screw in the outlet wallplate, and a plastic prong that plugs into the ground plug of the top outlet.*This back plug/screw design secures the rather heavy and wide three outlet surge protector but limits its mobility.  Once it's plugged and screwed into a wallplate, it's a hassle to remove it.*This charger can't be plugged into the top outlet of a dual plug wallplate and keep the lower outlet available.

My six year old niece love all the Disney characters so she didn't hesitate to grab this Lonnie, daughter of Mulan, doll.  The child really likes the colorful outfit along with all the girly accessories such as earrings, bracelet, high heel shoes, comb, and a purse locket with flower sticker inside. Doll can be placed into different fashionable poses with the movable head, wrists, elbows, and knees.  My niece and her pals had lots of fun playing with the doll.  Materials and construction are good so the doll should be able to withstand normal wear and tear.  Only drawback is that the kids want to buy all the other "Descendants" characters too.  Parents/guardians be prepared to dish out the dough.

Lutein is found in many dark green leafy vegetables such as kale, spinach, turnip greens, and collard greens, etc., and is good for maintaining good vision and prevent macular degeneration.  The macula is a small area of the retina responsible for central vision.  Lutein accumulates more in the peripheral areas of the retina while zeaxanthin accumulates more in the macula region.  Both lutein and zeaxanthin are believed to have anti-oxidative properties and protect the retina/macula from harmful blue light.  My family and I try to maintain a well balanced nutrition but it's helpful to supplement regular leafy green vegetable intake with Lutein supplements.What's good about Eye Guard Lutein:*Each softgel contains a generous 40mg of lutein and 1600mcg of zeaxanthin.*My family's eyes tend to be less strained and our annual eye exams indicate no vision health problems.What's questionable about Lutein supplements in general:*40mg of lutein but how much of it is free lutein?  The amount of free lutein absorbed by the retina/macula is unknown.*We've taken other brands of 20mg lutein supplements since 2010 but 40mg doesn't provide any noticeable difference in vision.*There's no DV or Daily (recommended) Value for lutein or zeaxanthin.  Possible side effects with excessive lutein intake.*Each geltab contains mostly safflower oil and the softgel ingredients of gelatin, vegetable glycerin, yellow beeswax.Overall:Taking lutein geltab supplements is helpful but it's more important to maintain a balanced, healthy diet with plenty of leafy green vegetables, wear blue light blocking sunglasses, and don't overstrain one's eyes, etc., to maintain good vision and retinal/macular health.

The convenience of an instant meal is very enticing.  Let's give this Pace Ready Meals Fiesta Chicken and Rice a try.What's good:*Heats up in about one minute in our 2000+ watt microwave without need to open or create vent.*Let the pouch sit in the microwave for about a minute, grab it by the "cool touch" edges and tear it open to eat.*Easy to pour and scrape out any remaining food from the pouch.*Each serving provides 230 calories, 44g of carbs, and 9g of protein, only 1.5g of fat, 15 calories from fat.What's bad:*Each serving has a whopping 890mg of sodium, , 10mg of cholesterol.*Taste is subjective but this Fiesta Chicken and Rice with Green and Red Peppers flavor taste like a gooey, salty blob with a slight Mexican flavor and aroma.  There was a small piece of corn husk that I spat out.  I had to add plenty of black pepper and some salsa to make this meal more palatable.Bottom Line:Good instant meal that's edible only if you're hungry and have no other options.

The convenience of an instant meal is very enticing.  Let's give this Prego Ready Meals Creamy Three Cheese Alfredo Rotini a try.What's good:*Heats up in about one minute in our 2000+ watt microwave without need to open or create vent.*Let the pouch sit in the microwave for about a minute, grab it by the "cool touch" edges and tear it open to eat.*Easy to pour and scrape out any remaining food from the pouch.*Each serving provides 390 calories, 41g of carbs, and 14g of protein.What's bad:*Each serving has a whopping 880mg of sodium, 19g of fat, 170 calories from fat, 45mg of cholesterol.*Taste is subjective but this Alfredo Rotini flavor taste like a gooey, salty blob without any distinctive flavor or aroma.  I had to add plenty of black pepper and some salsa to make this meal more palatable.Bottom Line:Good instant meal that's edible only if you're hungry and have no other options.

Our 3 months old baby is very comfortable with this multi-purpose, all-in-one baby play pen, bassinet, seat, and change station.  We're really impressed by its versatility.Pros:*Relatively straightforward to assemble (no tools required) by carefully following the instructions and doing some trial fitting.*Playard folds and unfolds for portability but requires some effort.*Playard provides a safe, play zone for parents to keep an eye on baby.*Full size bassinet is good for sleeping.*Sway seat could be also used as napper/rocker and it sways or vibrates to soothe baby*Sway seat is very useful for carrying baby around the house.  It even has a built-in mini seat belt.*Diaper changer is at the right height for easy changes without straining parents' backs.*Parent organizer for storing bottles, wipes, diapers, powder, rash lotion, etc.*Electronic control panel provides lights songs, and nature sounds to help soothe baby.Cons:*Relatively heavy because of so many different functions.*Lifting baby up continuously from the bottom of the playard will strain backs.*Sway chair and change station don't always seat down completely level on top of playard.*Don't know whether multiple folding/unfolding of playard will damage the folding mechanism over time.*Materials and construction are average quality.*long term durability remains to be seen.

My wife works part-time from our home office which includes conference video/calls, messenger, and other online communications apps.  This 3 port Audio Mic Switch allows her to use one headset/microphone with her iPhone6 Plus, our landline, and her PC desktop all with the push of a button.  Very short Audio-Mic (6-10") adapter cables to the switch are included for one headset and one smartphone.  Adapter cables for landline phone and PC are NOT included and need to be purchased separately.  This is not a passive switch and required an (5V, 1.0Amp output) AC adapter.  Stickers are provided to label the buttons for the 3 connected devices.  An LED indicator shows which device is active.  Overall, she likes the sound clarity (volume still controlled by connected device), convenience, and ease of use.

My sister-in-law has coarse, curly hair so I let her give this Dove "Quench Absolute" Intense Restoration hair Mask a try when my brother and her visited during the summer.  She really like how the hair mask is easy to apply to wet hair, left in for about 3-5 minutes, and then rinses off easily.  She told me her curly hair felt silkier, more nourished by the nutrients, proteins, and Buriti Oil ingredients, and more manageable and defined curls; not as dry and prone to fall out compared to the Suave shampoo she uses at home.  This shampoo has a feminine, pleasant, unobnoxious scent so even guys can use this shampoo if they're OK with the scent.  Sis-in-law decided she will use the entire "Advanced Hair Series" from Dove from now on.

My wife and I participate in many types of sports especially swimming, cycling, and running.  Even with heavy usage of sunblock and other skin care products to minimize wrinkles, our skin still feels dry and tough after training and/or events.  This Neutrogena Body Oil seems like a good supplement to our skin care regimen.Performance in real life:*Sealed underneath cap to prevent tampering and leakage.*Easy to dispense flip-open top.*8.5oz (250ml) bottle is plenty of oil for both of us.  A little bit of oil goes a long way.*We've applied the oil after showers; spreading it mostly over our arms and legs; skin surfaces most exposed to the elements.*We don't use it on our faces because oil can clog pores and cause pimples and other skin problems.*When applying the oil, it gets very greasy, especially on our hands and on the bottle.*After about an hour, most of the oil dries up, leaving our skin smooth, supple, soft, and minimal greasiness.*We both like the mild, unobtrusive, clean scent of the oil.*We're definitely adding this effective, moisturizing body oil to our home skin care regimen.

My 12 and 8 year old sons and I were eager to try out this Hotwheels RC Terrain Twister in our backyard and pool.Performance in real life:*The proprietary 7.2V NiMH "flex back" rechargeable battery took about 5 hours to charge up.  2 Alkaline AA batteries for the controller were included.*Manufacturer claims a RC range of 65'.  We were able to control the RC vehicle from up to 45' away in our backyard.*The controller seemed simple enough.  Eight direction left controller.  Front and rear tilt/pivot right controller.*In reality, this RC vehicle does not respond to the controls on different terrain.  Good movement on lawn, gravel, sand, and water but harder to control on concrete and smooth surfaces.*My boys and I had to experiment with different controller input combinations to see the resulting movements.*With the Archimedes' screw type drive pods configuration, it's difficult to drive this vehicle in a straight line forward/back.  It's much easier to move the vehicle sideways, spin it, or in large arcs.*The vehicle works better when floating on our pool where the screw drive pods respond more precisely to directional inputs.*The top battery hatch looks water resistant, not waterproof.  Have to make sure the vehicle doesn't flip over when entering the pool.*5 hours of charging only provided 25-30 minutes of play as the kids fight for the controller.*More of a fun, stunt, multi-terrain RC vehicle with mostly random directional movements, rather than a precisely controlled RC race vehicle around a backyard course.

I selected this Big Boy's size 8 brushed twill pants for one of my nephews but realized from the size chart that it fits 7 year olds better so we let his younger brother try it instead.*SIZE: 8, General Size: S(8), Height: 47-50 1/2", Chest: 27 1/2-28", Waist: 23 1/2-24",  Seat: 27-28", Inseam: 24 1/2".*It fits a bit small for an 8 year old and is more appropriate for 7 year old boys in 2nd or 3rd grade:*The material is a sturdy, medium weight, 60/40 cotton/polyester twill fabric with four regular pockets and a utility pocket (3.5"W x 4"L: too small for cell phone or anything else) in the middle of right pant leg"s BACK panel (sitting on it and no button/zipper to secure items).  Buttoned on the left and right rear pockets.*The cotton/polyester (permanent press) blend reduces wrinkling of fabric, less fading, and it's easier to iron and maintain sharp leg crease lines.*Built-in adjustable elastic waist band for boys with thinner waists or younger siblings growing into these pants.*Quality construction with even, consistent stitching, and a smooth zipper.*Khaki color and plain, flat front pockets conform to certain schools/youth organizations uniform codes.*Nephew's mom (my cousin) likes the easy care fabric: Machine wash cold, no bleach, tumble dry low or line dry.  She doesn't like the useless utility pocket or the stitching around the knee areas and prefers a flat front.*These twill pants appear capable of withstanding the wear/tear dished out by 7-8 year old boys. Long term durability remains to be seen.

*Protac has the versatility of using the internal rechargeable Li-Ion battery, or 2 CR123A lithium batteries , or one Li-Ion 18650 battery.  However, Feit uses three affordable, readily available C batteries.*Protac includes USB charger cable with AC and auto adaptors.  My brand new Protac was charged immediately before use in about 2 hours using the AC adaptor.*850 Lumens Protac is moderately brighter than the 500 Lumens Feit when shining on objects 10-20 feet away (both at default/wide beam); Protac's narrower default/medium focused beam shines brighter at objects 50'+ away.  Feit becomes brighter with more focused beams using the sliding zoom at all distances.*Feit has the strong advantage of the sliding zoom adjustment from 20' (wide spread beam) to 1000' (narrow/focused beam) range.  Protac has a standard beam range to 200m, ~656'.*Protac has default 3 mode (High, Strobe, Low) switch (3 selectable programs).  Feit has default (High, Low, Strobe, SOS) switch.  The Feit switch is easier to operate: click on to High, tap once for each additional mode.  The Protac requires two rapid taps and click for Strobe, and three rapid taps and click for Low: harder to modulate.*After continuously on for 15 minutes, the Protac anterior 1/3 gets hot.  There's a "Hot" warning label near the tip.  The Feit gets slightly warm.*Protac (6.5", 7.6oz) is smaller and lighter than the Feit (8.5", 15.5oz).  I prefer the bigger, heavier Feit as an emergency/tactical/security flashlight.*Both Protac and Feit have durable and robust aluminum bodies. The Feit is listed as water and impact resistant.*Protac includes a nylon belt holster and metal pocket clip.  Feit includes a nylon wrist strap.*I purchased a Feit 500 Lumens 3 pack for $43.59 tax included and free shipping in June 2014 from well known warehouse outlet.  The Protac HL is priced at $119.89 + tax shipped from Amazon as of August 2015.Overall:I like the versatility of the rechargeable (USB/AC/auto) Protac but it gets hot during use, and doesn't have the zoom/focused beam capability of the Feit.

Unlike subject dividers for 3-ring binders, these are movable bookmarks with tabs that can be labeled (written or printed) to mark the current page that the user is on, or to mark important pages that require more focus.  These bookmark dividers work just like Post-it notes but are neater and more organized.  Each bookmark has a slit on the sides of the three holes for easy relocation to areas of emphasis.  The colorful designs help liven up typically dull topics/pages but appear more geared towards girls.

I needed a protective mouthguard to prevent dental and jaw trauma for my twelve year old son who participates in sports and self defense classes.  He's has a sports mouthguard custom made by his dentist.  This Shock Doctor mouthguard seems like a good backup.Likes:*Sporty bright yellow mouthguard is easy to find among kids' clutter.*Protective high density rubber outer frame and lip guard with a cushioning inner gel frame.*Center channels in the anterior for more airflow when clenching during heavy efforts.*Convertible quick-release tether included for attaching to helmets, etc.*Latex free.*Made in U.S.A. !Concerns:*Requires following the fitting instructions VERY carefully to achieve a close fit.  I wrote an outline of the heating, fitting, and cooling times for proper fits.  Steps may be repeated if fit is not close enough.*One size does NOT fit all even after following the fitting instructions precisely.  This mouthguard doesn't extend all the way back to cover all posterior molars for people with larger jaws and teeth.*I feel uneasy about my son biting into heated plastic gel.  Toxicity?Overall:An improvement over standard universal sized mouthguards in terms of fit.  Provides good protection against trauma and injury to upper/lower teeth and lips.  Not a replacement for custom made, precise fitting sports mouthguards from a dental office.

My wife thought it would be nice to get our son a cardigan sweater for his school's upcoming semi-formal activities during autumn/winter.  I selected this Smith's American Little Boy's Cardigan Sweater.*Made from 100% acrylic fabric which is less likely to pill up compared to wool and cotton sweaters.*Quality weave with even, consistent stitching and construction.*Size XS (6/7) on the label fits a bit short/small on our tall 7 year old.*Even though synthetic fabrics resist fading after repeated washes, woven acyclic clothing tend to retain odors more than natural fabrics such as wool and cotton.*We still prefer natural fiber clothing such as wool, cotton, and silk, etc.*My wife thinks our son looks cute in this cardigan.  I said he looks like a "mini-me preppy" which is uncool unless he's a future Ivy League preppy.

I selected this Little boy's 7 twill pants my son.*SIZE: : Little boy's 7,  XL(7),  Age: 6-7 Years, Weight:53-58, Length:50-52, measured waist: 23", measured inseam: 22".*It fits our tall 7 year old boy alright.*The material is a sturdy, medium weight, 55/45 (labeled) cotton/polyester twill fabric with four regular pockets; buttoned on the left rear pocket.*The cotton/polyester (permanent press) blend reduces wrinkling of fabric, less fading, and it's easier to iron and maintain sharp leg crease lines.*Built-in adjustable elastic waist band for boys with thinner waists or younger siblings growing into these pants.*Quality construction with even, consistent stitching, and a smooth zipper.*Khaki color and plain, flat front pockets conform to certain schools/youth organizations' uniform codes.*My wife likes the easy care fabric: Machine wash cold, no bleach, tumble dry low or line dry.*These twill pants appear capable of withstanding harsh wear and tear by little boys.

Please note that since the below review, this company was very responsive and sent me a new thunderbolt to USB adaptor without the 1 in 1 connector. I am totally happy with the new cable and use it with the charger, leaving thw 2nd USB connector for a USB mini. I am now completely satisfied with this product, hence the 4 star upgrade. I still dock it one star for the flawed 2 in 1 connector, which I do not endorse.This product seemed like a good idea. I love the 2nd mini USB charger. But for this iPhone owner this charger doesn't cut the mustard. It has a little insert in the lightening cable which when removed, reveals a 2nd connector, which is a kind of mini USB, although not one I need. The problem is, that 2nd connector kept popping out, which was annoying but not a deal breaker. That is, until the lightening charger started to charge only intermittently. Now it's constantly giving me that charging sound when it reconnects, because it's constantly stopping charging! Sorry guys, I'm going back to my trusty old car charger.Note: whiles this company did replace my messed up 2 in one cable, the charger itself is now falling apart. With just the normal wear and tear of pushing it into the lighter, and pulling it out, the unit has fallen apart and I have spent way too much time trying to fit the pieces back together. I'm giving up completely on this unit.

This is my 3rd Epson printer. In fact the last printer I bought was the previous model, the 620, which is still in service but having paper handling issues. The 630 is very much like the 620; in fact the only discernible difference is there's now a flexible spring loaded "handle" to pull the main paper tray out. But in every other way, this machine seems exactly like 620. As there are still 620s out there for sale at about $50 less than the 630, I would look at those before purchasing one of these units. Also, the 620 uses the 273 (and larger 273xl) black ink which has fallen in price, whereas the 630 uses a new black cartridge which is listing for higher.These little Epsons do a good job printing home office jobs. They are relatively fast and do double sided printing, a feature I've grown to really appreciate. Wifi setup is easy. You just have to type in your network name and password directly into the printer and you're good to go. Maybe it's because I've done it before, but in no time I was printing docs from my iPad and iPhone. The scan app is rather primitive - I wish they would update it. Scanner warm up time is rather slow and so is hi res scan speed. But it gets the job done and does it well. I don't use the scanner all that often so its slow speed is not an issue for me. If you are planning to do a lot of large scan jobs you might consider getting the 830 which has a nifty document feeder.The 630 also does a serviceable job as a copier. Sometimes you have to mess with the contrast level,  but even some of my hastily scribbled pencil music charts come out legibly enough with this very handy feature. I use to have to run into town to make copies for a piano student. No longer!One of the surprising things about my 620 was the quality of the photo prints. This machine does a comparable job. It can print up to 4x6 borderless photos and they look pretty gorgeous. If you use Epson's glossy photo paper you will be amazed by how good these look, although not quite as nice as you'd get if done professionally or from a photo printer.This printer will also print on CDs. Like the special photo tray, it also has its own tray just for CD printing. It has a little app for making the CD design with both picture and text. It's rather limited. but fun to fool around with. FYI:You need to use special printable CDs which are readily available here on Amazon and elsewhere. It's fun and the results look pretty cool.Of course a big con with Epson printers (although I have found it to be true for Canon and Hp,) is the amount of ink these puppies use. Like its predecessor, the 630 requires 5 cartridges, and also uses a lot of ink, especially if you're printing those high quality photos. Ink cartridges are not cheap. I've tried various 3rd party refills, but I have to say it's been hit and miss. In the end, I discovered the genuine article works best. One thing I hate is how when one just cart runs out of ink, the printer won't work until you install a new cartridge. So you have to have replacements on hand just in case. One hint: the Epson will start to tell you the cart is almost empty long before it actually is. Just ignore this message and continue to use them until they truly give up the ghost.Also, Epson often updates both its firmware and software, which in and of itself isn't a bad thing. However I've read the updater also keeps track of other information such as how you use the printer and may even snoop around to see what kind of websites you visit etc. I don't know how people know this. But as it's constantly monitoring cartridge use and is connected to the net via wifi at all times, I can certainly believe that besides sending us updates, Epson may be doing some customer research as well. Does that make it spyware? You be the judge.All in all, I like the 630. It's a nice home office printer that does a lot of things well and has a pretty small footprint to boot.

This is a solid surge protects that offers up to 750 joules protection. It is good to use with sensitive electronic equipment, laptops, hard drives, home computers, anything that might be damaged by a spike. On top of that, you get 6 outlets where there were 2. You do have to give up one outlet to install this puppy, so you're really gaining 5 outlets in most cases. I like the sliding covers for each outlet - a nice added safety touch. The only con is the bright LED light, making this a unit I wouldn't place in my bedroom.

This little device really surprised me. It sounds surprisingly good. But not great.Setting it up as a breeze. It paired instantly with my iPad Air 2. Getting it to pair with my MacPro desktop was a little trickier. After pairing with my iPad it was not discoverable on my computer. I had to turn off Bluetooth on my iPad first. It then saw the device-It thought it was a headset, so I had to go to Bluetooth settings and designate the TP-Link as a music playback device. Then all was well. I then turned Bluetooth back on on my iPad and all was well.After pairing I put on an album I know well, which happened to be Allan Pasqua's underrated trio album, "Badlands". It's a nice, well recorded jazz piano trio album that reveals a lot about a playback system. I should say at this point that am a wouldbe (would be if I had the money!) audiophile with a decent entry level system. It's good enough for me to enjoy audiophile recordings such as SACD's and high quality DVD audio. At any rate,  in truth I wasn't expecting much from this device. I went ahead and streamed it from my desktop off of iTunes. I then A/B'd it with the CD version thru the same system. Now it's not really fair to compare an apple lossless file with a CD, but I did anyway and I was amazed by the results. The TP-Link sounded really good. Yes, I could hear the difference, but part of that is I'm using really good connects with the CD player and anyway, CD files carry something like twice the data as an Apple lossless MP4. But it was far closer than I expected it should be. The main difference was the piano sounded a bit pinched and thin on the TP and the dynamics seemed somewhat curtailed. Detail was lost in the cymbals as well- that being said, it was still quite enjoyable to listen to.To make it a little more fair, I then compared the stream to my 7th gen iPod connected to directly to my system, encoded with the exact same file. The result? To tell the truth, I really couldn't tell the difference between the hardwired iPod and the Bluetooth stream off the TP-Link. In a blind fold test my girlfriend tried to fool me and she did.That being said, I listened to more stuff and the streaming quality varies. Last night I listened to some things, including my own mixes, which normally sound pretty good. Everything sounded "boxy" and hollow. So sound quality apparently varies. In its defense, it could be the stream was slower that night, but I think my original assessment nay have been prematurely over enthusiastic.I then tried streaming hi def files to my stereo. I played Steely Dan's great sounding "Two Against Nature" in 24/96. Oh my God, now that's what I'm talking about! It sounded freaking fantastic. So I have found my use for this thing. Obviously, source material is what it's all about. If you start with something this good, it's going translate well thru the link. Just amazingly good.So, rather than view this as a novelty item and an easy way to mix it up in shuffle mode at a party, in future I will definitely be using it to stream hi def files, until I upgrade my receiver for in that can do that from a memory stick or drive.

YAL author Mal Peet's first novel for adults succeeds both as a brilliant and snarky critique of the publishing industry and at the same time, a kind of black comedy horror novel.The plot is simple: Children's author Phillip Murdstone has a problem. His sensitive books about teenage boys once sold like hot cakes, but no longer. His agent, the desirable Minerva Cinch tries to persuade Murdstone to write an adult fantasy novel, even giving him a cynical but hysterically accurate outline as to what plot elements and characters must be present to achieve a best seller. As enamored with Minerva as he is and in much need of financial reconstituting, Murdstone simply abhors fantasy novels. Nonetheless, he agrees to give it a go. Dealing with writer's block, he ramps up his already questionable drinking habit and in a strange encounter meets a Greme (a kind of gnome) from another Realm. This Greme with the unlikely name of Pocket Wellfair (fantastic name that,) cuts him a Faustian deal: he'll deliver a "flaky ledger" (as he calls fiction,) if Murdstone delivers something else in exchange. Thus begins one of the more enjoyable and refreshing summer reads I can remember in some time.Mal Peet has a gift for colorful language. He effortlessly paints a poetic portrait of the northern England landscape, and goes on to develop a small cast of absurd characters that people Murdstone's little hamlet.  Perhaps his best creation is the character of Pocket. A scribe back home in the Realm, he is relentless in his colorful critiques of our hapless author, decrying his fondness for "damage" (alcohol)  and his pathetic need to write "nobbles." Has there ever been a more disagreeable muse?  Pocket's a great character with a distinctive voice; almost everything that comes out of his mouth makes me giggle.This book can be read several ways. On the surface, it is one of those fantasy novels in which the "other world" breaks into ours. Charles de Lint and Lev Grossman's "the Magicians" both come to mind, not so much style-wise, but for their ability to make the other world seem real. Think as well of Neil Gaiman, especially American Gods. We're talking about a sort of small, cobwebbed corner of the library in which fantasy intersects with neo-realism. Peet has found a unique entrance into this magical land, playing with the idea that perhaps this is more a description of the inner landscape of the writer's mind than a real life encounter with another world. He plays it both ways, leaving it open to interpretation, that is, until the wacky librarian sisters see strange things too...The tale which takes place in the "Realm", which is the substance of Murdstone/Pocket's novel, is given short shrift. We never meet most of the characters of the novel-they are for the most part mere names which are given at best a two dimensional rendering. Peet makes no bones about his real interest, which clearly is in what's taking place here in our world and inside Murdstone's neurotic brain.In a way, this book is also a glimpse into the creative process a writer goes through when creating worlds. He once said,  "Writing is a form of licensed madness."I found The Murdstone Trilogy to be that rarest of things, a genre parody that takes its characters seriously, while at the same time finding something to snort about at nearly every page. In this regard the late Terry Pratchett, a master of this balancing act, comes to mind. But this book gets far darker and creepier than Pratchett ever dared. Like Pratchett, Peet is also a master of creating hysterical set pieces that play out with an absurd logic all their own. But as the novel moves towards its close, it becomes clear that it's not all fun and games.The only reason I'm not giving this 5 stars is the rather abrupt ending. Without giving anything away, I feel that the story got away from Peet at the end and I was a little disappointed by the way it resolved. But then, in view of his recent passing, it may be Peet simply ran out of time.Peet's passing saddens me. After reading Murdstone, one wonders what would've come next. It was clear he was more than up to the task of writing adult fiction. I wistfully wonder what other delights he would've had in store for us next had he lived.

if you're reading this review, you already know these Keystone shows were the last recordings of Evans, made just weeks before he passed. I've owned the companion set (which contains the late sets) for a number of years, but only just received my copy of this, the 1st sets from that gig. Here we find more of the same excellence, but these early sets are a little more ballad heavy than the late sets, in that the late sets feature expansive, frenetic and often exploratory versions of Nardis, which are great but one has to be in the mood to get thru these 20 minute plus excursions. In contrast, Consecration contains ballads such as  My Foolish Heart, The Evans original Two Lonely People and Letter to Evan, and the delicate tunes, Laurie, Emily and Your Story. These sets really feature Bill's writing, and show just what a good composer he really was.Bill tends to take the uptempo tunes very fast, and while they don't sound rushed, there are times where the tempos seem too bright for the tune. A good example of that is the Theme From Mash. I really liked the way it was recorded on You Must Believe in Spring, where it is relaxed and breathes. Here it's a breathless performance; Bill seems to have so much to say he can barely contain himself.Although the Vanguard sets, recorded around two months earlier sound much better, these sets sound pretty darn good-audio quality is more than enough to get these performances across. The piano might be slightly hot compared to the bass and drums, but it's just a question of taste, and I'd rather it be a bit forward than too far under.After reading Laurie Verchomin's account of the last two years of Evan's life, where she recounts that Evans was trying to stay off heroin and was substituting methadone and unfortunately also ingesting massive doses of cocaine, I have often wondered if the coke affected his tempos. It's as though his brain is on overdrive at times, yet somehow he never misses a note. His playing is as assured as it ever was- the logic of his lines is as natural and organic as a bubbling stream.Perhaps as other reviewers have alluded to, Evans knew on some level these were his last performances and was simply giving it all he had. Whatever the impulse behind these intense performances, this is still Evans at his best and perhaps most potent ever. Most importantly, these sets swing with an intensity and abandon rarely heard from Evans.This set is a must buy for any Evans aficionado. More than a novelty or interesting collectors item, this is essential listening. No Evans collection would be complete without both sets. This is nothing less than a record of a meteoric artist going out in flames across the night sky in a glorious flash of epic brilliance.

Proactive One is a very soothing cream that is light and goes on very nicely. This moisturizer has as its lead ingredient green tea, a known antioxidant used in several moisturizing creams on the market. Besides green tea extract, it also contains iris florentina root as well as macadamia seed oil. It also contains wrinkle reducing retinyl palmitate. So we're off to a good start, that is, until we get to the rest of the list.Besides these few extracts and ingredients I know about, the rest of the ingredients are chemicals. This product contains several petroleum products such as butylene glycol, used both as a solvent and a viscosity decreasing agent. Although found to be benign by researchers, I still don't like using petroleum derived products. Besides butylene glycol, this cream also has PPG-2 methyl ether, which is both a fragrance ingredient and is also used as a solvent. While it has been found safe for use in cosmetics by the NCBI, I question its use in a skin care product. This cream has a host more chemicals, including methylparaben and polyparaben, both of which have been found in breast cancer tissues and also is known to contribute to oxidative stress when skin treated with creams containing this substance is exposed to UVB rays. This can potentially lead to cancer, although the chemicals in and of itself aren't supposed to be carcinogenic.Suffice it to say there are too many chemicals in this product for me to get behind it as a regular skin moisturizer. My girlfriend, after reading the list of ingredients, feels the same way. I tend to go after simpler, more natural products. I realize that some of the chemicals may just be fancier names for completely benign substances, but having researched just a few that I already had heard were somewhat questionable, I can't wholeheartedly recommend this formula, at least not for consumers who looking for a more natural moisturizer.I still give this product three stars because it does a good job keeping my skin moist thru the day, and has a smoothing and soothing effect that my partner really liked. So, if you're not too concerned about the above ingredients, you will be pleased with the results.

As most folks already know, Folkmanis makes some of the best plush hand puppets on the planet. My girlfriend (who was the editor of a major parenting magazine for 14 years,)  raved about this company when I told her I was getting one. I have to say this little harbor seal is totally adorable. While some reviewers have complained about his fins not being movable from the inside, I find his movable mouth to be quite adequate for making this little guy very expressive. His eyes are very sentient; he's so lifelike he almost looks like he's about to bark.This hand puppet is well constructed from polyester fiber and polyurethane foam and will probably last a very long time. He's washable on the surface with cold water.He completely charmed my girlfriend who wants to give him to her niece. That may be a problem though- he's beginning to feel like part of the family.

I had never heard of CAD before and wasn't sure what to expect when I received these. They are boxed quite minimally. I immediately put them thru the paces, listening to Steely Dan's Two Against Nature, which I consider a reference recording.  It's hard to find something better in terms of balance, sound stage and general audio fidelity. Within a couple of minutes it generally tells me all I need to know about a pair of phones.On the Dan album, these puppies showed their strengths and weaknesses pretty clearly. They certainly had enough punch in the bass, but it wasn't tight as the bass should be on this recording, having instead a somewhat wide and flabby feel. The top end is muted - I don't want to say dull but considering these are rated up to 22khz, I was surprised how much high end detail was missing. This is yet another example of how specs don't necessarily translate into the real world listening experience. In the end, you have to trust your ears.This Dan album has an amazing sense of instrument placement, defined by ambiences that are designed to separate the parts from one another-unfortunately the soundstage was not well defined on these, especially when compared to other admittedly more expensive sets of cans. Just for fun, I put them up against my Sennheiser HD 600s, a favorite amongst audio engineers for their unhyped flatness. As would be expected, they easily crushed the 210s, exaggerating their muddiness in the mids and lack of high end detail and transparency. I know, it isn't fair to compare a $30 set of cans with a $400 pair. But it is interesting to hear the differences.I compared these to the "classic" studio monitors which I generally use for tracking, the Sony 7506's. Is it fair to compare a $30 pair of phones to an $80 pair? I think it's useful as both are purposed for studio monitoring. The difference was like night and day. As many studio engineers know, the 7506's are overly pumped, both in the highs and to a certain extent in the low end - they are like ear candy: not particularly accurate, but exciting to listen to (until ear fatigue sets in.) While I would never mix on them (and contrary to one review, I don't know a single engineer who would,) I do like them for tracking. Contrary to one review which stated the two phones sound nearly identical, I beg to differ: The MH210's are a whole other animal - they sound quite dark next to the overly bright Sony's. They are not at all alike! I set them up for a recording client the other day instead of the usual pair of Sony's. He immediately asked to change them out for the Sonys.In terms of comfort, I like these headphones, as they  can easily be used for long periods without fatigue. They are very light and nicely padded on the top. Although light, the build appears to be quite good.In summary, I think these are a good deal for the price, although these would not be my choice for critical listening. I will however use the MH210 for tracking when I need an extra pair of decent monitoring headphones. For that, these are more than up to the task.

This red dragon arrived today. At first I was a bit concerned when I heard the scratching... It apparently really wanted to get out! I gingerly opened the box, when all of a sudden I felt a wave of heat singe my right hand. I instinctively tried to close the lid but alas, it was too late- the little dragon was now loose in my house! He flew around my living room, snorting fire and smoking- I had to dodge his tail and outstretched claws several times, batting him away from his menacing advances. He was small, maybe only 6 inches high, but very fierce, with a snapping (ie movable) mouth full of sharp teeth and a pointy barbed tail. While he was attacking me, I noticed his right wing had a small hole in it- perhaps he had been in a battle prior to his being dispatched?Anyway, after a while the dragon tired out, and settled on top of my refrigerator. I thought he looked hungry, so I fed him the only thing I could think he might enjoy from my larder, a can of sardines. As he tore with gusto at the little fish, he began to make a sort of purring sound, a thrumming that permeated my house. His red eyes glared at me, but behind that air of malice I thought I saw a faint smile. I think we're going to get along just fine.

I always thought the best incarnations of Weather Report had a percussionist on board. In fact for most of their existence, the band did have a 5th member. It was only some time after "Heavy Weather" that the band started touring as a quartet, with Jaco and Erskine holding down the rhythm section. With the release of "Night Passage" they had added Bobby Thompson to the empty percussion chair and went back on the road. This is a live recording of the "Night Passage" band recorded in February 1980 at the Michigan Theater.Right out of the gate on the opener, "8:30," the band is rambunctious, on fire and nearly out of control. Stark, biting synth textures collide with a virtual wall of sound-everyone's playing is pumped and the audience is going completely wild. At this point it's more of a theatrical experience than a jazz concert. After the initial controlled chaos subsides, the band gets down to business, which turns out to be playing material almost exclusively from the underrated "Night Passage" album. I personally have always had a strong affection for this material. That album felt like a return to form after the controversial and highly produced, Mr Gone. I think of "Night Passage" as the last truly solid Weather Report album, and it was the 2nd to last with the "classic" lineup, the last being bearing the same title "Weather Report" (same as their 1st release.)It's obvious from the outset that the band knows this material well-it's amazing how close the sound is to the record.  Zawinul has his sounds totally dialed in and the nature of the tunes allows for a lot of open blowing. After a nice reading of "Madagascar" and Pastorius's beautiful jazz waltz, "Three Views of a Secret," the band really begins to takes off on "Port of Entry." Now this is the Weather Report I remember from several live shows I was lucky enough to see:  Muscular playing from Zawinul, pointed, incisive solos by Shorter, beautiful flurries of bongo and color from Thompson; underpinning all of this are Jaco and Erskine, completely locked-It's explosive stuff. After a short and very literal reading of Dream Clock, the group segues into Fast City, one of  Zawinul's best compositions. This is bebop for the 21st century. The band really kicks it into another gear and the results are nothing short of electrifying. Shorter shines here, turning in a very free solo that uses the underlying changes as a springboard to lift the music up into the stratosphere. Fast City is followed by a 9 minute Jaco bass solo: it's the usual mashup of noise, feedback, harmonics and loops that Jaco was prone to in those days. As such, it's a good one. He plays his own tune,  "Continuum," over some tasteful looping which really works. There's a lot of indulgent noodling as well, and just when you think it's over, he puts on a recording of the first movement of Hovaness's "Mysterious Mountain" and improvises over it!  It must've been a somewhat spontaneous idea because it's clear he hasn't worked out all the harmony and is sort of winging it. I happen to love that piece and it's cool to discover that Jaco did as well. It's a fascinating, if somewhat raw reading. Oddly missing are the usual solos of Zawinul and Shorter or the duos they usually played in these shows. The band finishes out the set with the feel-good island grooves of Brown Street.So, how is the sound? Truth be told, it's an odd mix, originally done for FM broadcast. I don't think much thought went into creating the soundstage. It sounds like it came off a board mix. The only things that sound anything like stereo are the drums and the audience. Almost everything else, keys, sax and bass are pretty much placed dead center (percussion is panned slightly to the left.) The relative instrument balances are fair, getting somewhat more in focus as the performance progresses. At times Shorter's sax seems too far back and the keys go in and out of sitting in the right place. Generally, the drums sound a bit washed out, (especially the thin sounding cymbals,) and the bass is a little indistinct at times. I'm told this show has been available as a bootleg on torrent sites for many years. Having never heard those files, I have nothing to compare it to, so I don't know how much remastering was done. All I can say is, It sounds pretty good for a bootleg.The liner notes are taken from a review written by a critic for the Michigan Daily-they are interesting if somewhat snarky. The writer seems irritated with the band's performance, complaining that since Weather Report had achieved so much success doing something that was relatively uncompromising, any nod to commercialism such as their halfhearted attempts at adding lights and stage effects (smoke etc,) and Jaco's rock and roll grandstanding were somehow beneath them. Complete Bollocks. The liner notes as printed here have a number of typos and omissions, so much so that the very last sentence of the piece is rendered completely incomprehensible. Considering the content of the review, perhaps that was for the best. That being said, I would've appreciated a more positive assessment of the band written with the perspective of listening to this recording some 35 years later to balance out this review.All in all, I like this live album, despite its shortcomings in sound and presentation. For fans of the Jaco/Erskine lineup, this is a must have. While this release will mostly appeal to hardcore WR fans, as it's a document of the last great tour of one of the most influential bands of the era, it may appeal to a wider audience.

I have bought these combs from a couple of sellers and even though they look like what I used to have, they certainly aren't of the quality they used to be. The teeth of the combs used to be rounded in such a way they didn't scratch my scalp- no longer. I recommend Swisco combs, they are hand shaved (and tortoise shell) and the perfect pocket size. Only down side is they cost about $8. That just makes me keep better track of them.
