Anyway, they feel good in the hand and on the scalp.Also, on this last order, instead of receiving  the usual 4" Ace pocket combs I've been getting for many years, I received too banana sized 8.5" combs! I was able to get a refund thru Amazon as the seller uses the "fulfillment thru Amazon" system. But it was a hassle.

Among his many musical interests, Kurt Elling has long been an avid interpreter of standards. However in recent years he has focused his attention on more contemporary repertoire and occasional forays into original material, culminating in his stunning masterpiece, â€œThe Man in the Airâ€ and the less successful follow up, "Nightmoves." In this superb live recording dedicated to the musical collaboration of John Coltrane and Johnny Hartman we find him once again delving into the Great American Songbook.As any long time Elling fan can attest, the man can swing like crazy and is both a fearless improviser and creative wordsmith, especially when engaging in one of his virtuosic vocalising flights of fancy. Less apparent to the Elling neophyte is his ability to wrap himself around a ballad.  Anyone familiar with the legendary Coltrane /Hartman sessions knows the exploration of the ballad is what that collaboration was all about. (If you donâ€™t have that CD in your collection, stop reading this and buy it now.)  In an unlikely musical partnership,  Coltraneâ€™s modernist and unsentimental tenor sax was the perfect counterpoint to Hartmanâ€™s velvety smooth baritone, creating an instant classic.Elling is no Johnny Hartman, but he is a great interpreter of a ballad in his own right. What he lacks in timbre he more than makes up for in interpretation.  Elling has a literary bent and knows that a singerâ€™s first job is to focus on the meaning of the lyric. Listen to him on "Lush Life" â€“ you can hear the bitterness and self-indulgence of that timeless Strayhorn lyric. On "Dedication" he is his own man, long past imitation, comfortable and gracefully purring his way through such chestnuts as "Autumn Serenade" and "Over and Over Again." But Elling fans be forewarned: if youâ€™re looking for vocal pyrotechnics, there is almost no scatting on this album â€“ the songs are the primary focus here.Like the album it is honoring, "Dedicated to You" is also a collaborative effort, not so much with tenor sax man Ernie Watts as with Ellingâ€™s long time pianist Lawrence Hobgood. Opting for a string quartet over a larger section, Hobgoodâ€™s string arrangements are the epitome of good taste and refinement. The parts were clearly designed for each voice to mingle with and inspire the group interplay, augmenting but never stepping on the music.  Check out the magnificent strings only accompaniment to "My One and Only Love" or the lovely coda to "You are Too Beautiful." Hobgood has serious arranging chops.Special mention must be made of Hobgoodâ€™s piano playing. He is a consummate accompanist and a stellar soloist who really deserves wider recognition. He has the musical ideas, lyricism and rhythmic drive to make his solos a constant source of surprise and delight. Elling is one lucky singer. Ernie Watts also turns in some fine performances, particularly on "Say It (Over and Over)", where you can hear the spirit of Coltrane informing his solo in some of his more expansive melodic flurries.I heartily recommend this album for Elling fans and non-initiates alike. While I suppose it would make a charming addition to a candlelight dinner, "Dedicated to You" is much more than that. It is an album to be savored like fine wine, slowly and with total concentration in order to capture all its subtle notes.

Tales from the Earth is a collaboration between Cuban born marimba/vibist/pianist Omar Sosa and flautist Mark Weinstein. Both are innovators who have contributed to contemporary Afro-Cuban music and both have cultivated a passion for musical cultures that extend outside of the mainstream.Tales From the Earth came together shortly after the players involved with this project participated in an African-Cuban music Festival in Berlin.  The ensemble had not played together before and there were no charts. Harking from diverse cultural backgrounds including Cuban, Haitian American, Afro-American, African, Polish, Jewish American antecedents, all had one thing in common â€“ a dedication to a profound engagement with African music.What emerged from this session is not so much a collection of songs as a compilation of musical spaces. Much of the music consists of layered drums, bells and shakers, with another layer of tuned percussion such as marimba, balafon and vibraphone riding on top. Free form flutes interspersed with Haitian or African vocals drift through the air above this percolating trance groove.  It is an exotic and attractive aural fragrance that fills the listening environment with sensuous sounds.If one is looking for compositional development and form, this is not the road to travel. However if the listener can simply relax and allow the music to sweep him/her away on a sojourn through steamy jungles, swooping across expansive savannahs and luxuriating in the mist of a hidden waterfall surrounded by primeval ferns, this is a journey he/she will want to take.Occasionally, Weinsten and Sosa reveal their jazz roots, as they delicately walk the tightrope between strict modal and free playing. But the music, no matter how far out the melodic improvisation gets, is always firmly rooted in groove making the proceedings accessible to most listeners, especially to those accustomed to the occasional implementation of â€œoutsideâ€ playing.I found after a while that there was a similarity between tracks that led to a mild case of ear fatigue. While I wouldnâ€™t hesitate to recommend this CD to lovers of atmospheric groove music (that occasionally paints outside the lines,) I think the CD wouldâ€™ve benefitted with from the inclusion of a few actual compositions scattered in with the free jams.The melting pot of influences that are infused into Tales is also reflective of a deeper philosophical consideration of the Diaspora and how it has affected the peoples of many cultures. In that regard there is an underlying theme that pervades this CD that makes it a more profound and emotional statement than first meets the ear.  Also, as scientists have traced the roots of human evolution to the Africa continent, this CD perfectly illustrates the commonality of all races found in the true cradle of civilization.

Watching this DVD was a dÃ©jÃ  vu experience. Then it hit me: I had witnessed this group back in 1987 in San Francisco. What had drawn me was the rare appearance of the great composer and trumpet/flugel horn stylist, Kenny Wheeler. I figured I was in for a night of ECM lyricism. I was wrong. To my young ears, what followed was a cacophony that pinned me to my seat for the next two hours.  It was one of my first live exposures to free jazz.  That was over 20 years ago and it is interesting to revisit that moment of musical history with a deeper perspective.The 1986 Dave Holland Quintet was possibly the last group Holland had assembled that was devoid of a chordal instrument. Just a couple of years later he would add guitarist Kevin Eubanks (yes, the â€œTonight Showâ€ guy and Robinâ€™s brother!) to the mix and put out â€œExtensions,â€ one of the key albums of his mid-career. That release gave him broader exposure, and coupled with a return to a more harmonic approach to composition, eventually catapulted him to his current position of being one of the most acclaimed jazz composers and bandleaders of our time.The Holland band of 1986 was a different story. On this re-release of a 1988 laserdisc, this very capable  group of musicians is put through its paces in this challenging set of post-bop Ornette Coleman-inspired charts.The band charges ahead full force on the opener, Hollandâ€™s own â€œNew One,â€ a 16-minute tour de force. After the initial up-tempo opening line the band almost immediately heads for parts unknown in a brilliant free for all between the three horn players.Soon after the opening shout statement, the front men lay out for a surprisingly lyrical solo by Wheeler. It is amazing to hear Wheeler in this context, playing free and yet retaining his musical identity, the mournful tones of his flugel horn sounding like burnished gold against the solid swing of Smith and Holland.  Hollandâ€™s penchant for modal ostinatos is apparent here; a mesmerizing straight eighth interlude emerges that sets up Robin Eubanks nicely for an extended solo. On a dime, the band abruptly heads back into swing time eliciting a staggeringly creative solo from sax man Steve Coleman.The following Coleman composition â€œVortexâ€ also comes out swinging madly, the band suddenly dropping out for a pensive Holland solo, completely exposed, and outside a pulse. Holland has so much to say and embodies the perfect blend of technique and feeling. Just as Dave brings the focus to a quiet point of sound, the band revs up, underscoring a jaw dropping, frenetic Coleman solo. Coleman has to be one of the foremost practitioners of free jazz, his lines possessing a logic and architecture that makes his soloing hard to resist, even at his most oblique. After a tasty mallet drum solo by Smith, â€œVortex â€œsurprises the listener with a through-composed passage that sounds like a cross between a Latin marching band and a section of Stravinskyâ€™s â€œLâ€™Histoire du Soldatâ€. Wonderful stuff.The set takes a much needed break from the harmolodic inspiration of Ornette with the blues inflected â€World Protection Band.â€ An earthy concoction, this tune brings to mind Terence Blanchardâ€™s sophisticated, urban take on the blues. Robin Eubanks gives a soulful solo over the bluesy changes and Kenny Wheeler finds much to explore with some nice ensemble backing parts to bounce off of.The band picks it up again on â€œHomecomingâ€ a sprightly strut that once again acts as a launch pad for some great group interaction. Coleman really stretches out on this one, laying down his most convincing solo of the set . Here we find Coleman sculpting angular Dolplyesque lines, bravely pushing the melodic envelope to its extreme.The set closes with Colemanâ€™s provocatively titled â€œWight Waits for Weight,â€ a funky straight-eighth groove, forecasting Hollandâ€™s later polyphonic ensemble style.  The tune features a Middle Eastern melodic riff underpinned by Hollandâ€™s rock solid bass line, finding a balance between free playing and modal improvisation.All in all, this DVD is an important document of the development of the Holland Quintet (now a sextet in its latest incarnation), a snapshot of a bandleader in transition.  The video production is clean and transparent, the camera focusing on the right player at the right time with few exceptions.The DTS 5.1 sound is excellent, considering the year it was produced. However, the  transparent PCM stereo format sonically edges out the DTS and is the format I would recommend. If you are a fan of open or free jazz this set is not to be missed.

On Lawrence Hobgoodâ€™s third album as a leader we find him in a duo setting with consummate bassist Charlie Haden. Haden is a perfect collaborator for Hobgoodâ€™s piano excursions. Both are accomplished artists whose considerable technical prowess is kept in check by an unerring discipline and an artistic esthetic that leans heavily towards understatement.Hobgood is of course best known as the tasteful accompanist and artistic director for singer extraordinaire Kurt Elling.  Elling has such a commanding presence it is easy to overlook the man at the keyboard who provides the foundation for Ellingâ€™s vocal flights of fancy. Hobgoodâ€™s tasty accompaniments are the glue that makes it all work, night after night.This latest addition to the Hobgood catalogue is a mostly down-tempo affair consisting of a nice balance of standards and originals.  The album starts off with â€œQue Sera Sera,â€ a tune I have never really thought of as a  jazz standard.  It has always conjured up unpleasant memories of a too cheerful Doris Day singing it as though itâ€™s a simple minded childrenâ€™s song, which in a sense it is.  Like Bill Evans who took ditties like â€ Hi Lilly Hi Lilly Hi Loâ€ and  discovered hidden depths beneath their somewhat vacuous veneer, Hobgood  reconsiders the deeper philosophical implications of the lyric and gives the tune a plaintive re-harmonization, yielding an interpretation that is both intellectually probing and emotionally compelling.Having established an introspective mood, Hobgood launches into the medium up-tempo title track, one of several originals that pepper the album. â€œWhile the Heart Dancesâ€ is a smart and sprightly jazz waltz with some nice changes and a gorgeous melody. Hallelujah! A great player who can write a memorable tune!Kurt Elling joins the duo on the third track, for a vocal rendition of  the Haden standard, â€œFirst Song.â€ I hadnâ€™t been  aware there was a lyric for this tune, but Elling milks every ounce of meaning from this serviceable if uninspired lyric. Hobgood, leader on this date modestly leaves the solo duties to the composer who turns in a characteristically unhurried and well-constructed improvisation over the austere chord changes.Sanctuary, a gospel tinged Hobgood original is one of two solo pieces. It flows and meanders around a gospel theme that brings to mind early Keith Jarrett.  Even though the tune wanders far afield harmonically from its gospel vamp, crossing into European harmonic territory, it constantly returns home to its bluesy roots.Chickoree, a composition penned by both Hobgood and Haden is an adventurous little ballad that gives both men plenty of blowing room. Hobgood turns in one of his most inventive solos, occasionally flirting with a double time feel.The album is broken up again with another Elling feature , â€œStairway to the Starsâ€. He sounds absolutely divine on this old chestnut, masterfully drawing out his phrasing through the dreamy refrain.  Another highlight and probably my favorite track on the CD is an original tune entitled â€œLeatherwood.â€ It is a contemporary even eighth note composition performed solo.  This harmonically supple tune brings to mind the writing of west coast jazz pianist Alan Pasqua., whose  gorgeous composition â€œHighway 1â€ was covered on Ellingsâ€™ album, â€œNightmoves.â€ â€œLeatherwoodâ€ is as fine an example of contemporary jazz writing as one is likely to encounter. Itâ€™s also a great vehicle for Hobgood â€˜s prodigious technique. Here he lets loose with fiery 16th note lines that effortlessly spin their way across his finely wrought harmonic structure.Special mention should be made of the recording which was presided over by Ellingâ€™s personal engineer of many years, Ken Chistianson, who takes full advantage of lovingly-restored Steinway D piano residing at Roy O. Disney Hall at CalArts. Hadenâ€™s bass sounds fat and full. It is a very warm live recording, in what the liner notes refer to as â€œtrue stereo.â€What most impresses me about Hobgood is how articulate his playing is. Every musical gesture, from his creative single note lines to his energetic two-handed rhythmic passages, is precise and perfect in its execution. His strengths as a creative line player, mastery of voicings, compositional integrity and subtle rhythmic precision serve to make him a standout. In a world where an ever increasing pool of young players try to steal the limelight with cheap bravado and virtuosity, it is comforting to know that players of the of Hobgood â€˜s caliber are around keeping the art of jazz piano alive and well.TrackList: Que Sera Sera, Whenthe Heart Dances, First Song, Sanctuary, Chickoree, Stairway to the Stars, New Orleans, Why Did I Choose You?,  Leatherwood, Daydream, The Cost of Living

This album captures one of those rarest of rare moments in improvised music: the pairing is perfect, the rapport is flawless and perhaps the stars were in perfect alignment as well.  The recording quality magnificent and intimate. Although mostly recorded in Disney Hall in southern California, the sound is very intimate, close miked with just enough hall in the mix to feel the space. Haden's bass is captured perfectly here, sounding fat and full as it should be.The material is a mix of Haden and Taylor originals with a standard thrown in for good measure. The mood is introverted. Taylor, who has prodigious chops yet always tasteful, is particularly restrained here, perhaps in response to Charlie's approach. Haden, who is always restrained, is perhaps the perfect accompanist here, providing a clear foundation for Taylor's sophisticated and at times challenging phrasing. Haden's solos are thoughtful and as always, in service to the tune.It's sad to realize that both these masters are now gone, Haden having passed over over a year ago and Taylor only recently deceased a few weeks ago. We have lost two of our finest practioners of the art of improvisation. Thank God we have this artifact to listen over and over. This is how it's done.

Nando Lauria may be the the best singer PMG had since Pedro Aznar. Unfortunately,  I missed The Way Up tour back in 2006. But listening to this may be the closest thing to hearing a new PMG album from the Aznar period.Of course, Pat's not on the album! But the feel is there, the melodies, the intricate harmonies, Lyle Mays' piano and even Danny Gottlieb! This album exudes pure optimism. It's got the real Brazilian feel as only a native son can produce. A little synth-heavy at times, otherwise a well produced album that I will be revisiting often. How did I miss Nando Lauria? He's the real deal.

That Stowell has never stopped growing is amply apparent on this release.John Stowell is an Oregon-based jazz guitarist who has been on the scene since the mid 1970s. I first encountered his music while he was touring the west coast back in the 70s in a duo with bassist Dave Friesen. Freisen's visceral, earthy approach to the bass was the perfect counterpoint to Stowell's heady jazz conceptions, which together produced a wonderfully balanced mix of sky and earth. That fruitful collaboration produced one of the finest duo recordings of the 70s: "Through the Listening Glass" which is incidentally now available on CD.That Stowell has never stopped growing is amply apparent on this latest release, "Solitary Tales" which was recorded in front of a live audience at the home of his guitar maker and engineer, Mike Doolin. "Tales" is an intimate affair, comprised of a mix of originals and a few jazz standards performed primarily on nylon string guitar with the occasional use of the electric guitar, which makes for a nice contrast to this largely acoustic set.The general mood of this collection is comfortable and laid back. Much of the opening material is played rubato. Indeed, by the fourth tune I was beginning to hunger for a change of pace, my ears fatiguing in search of a more solid groove.On top of this tendency to play rubato, Stowell's melodic and harmonic concepts are very sophisticated and may prove to be too demanding for casual listeners. That being said, on my second go round, I began to hear more of his ideas as my ears acclimated to his advanced approach. Stowell has Very Big Ears; there is an innate logic to the way he develops his ideas. He is fond of deploying controlled dissonance and seems to enjoy playing with melodic ideas that develop out of unusual intervallic relationships. This penchant for abstraction demands much from the listener but for those who persevere, there is plenty of musical enjoyment to be found.Of particular note is his tender reading of Bill Evans "Funny Man" and his adventurous exploration on "House of Doolin," a contemporary original played to great effect on electric guitar. However, it is not until "Willow," a Steve Swallow tune that the album really starts to swing. The CD picks up steam on the following track, "Fun With Fruit", an intriguing Stowell composition that squarely lifts the proceedings off the ground. The groove intensifies with "Behind the Scenes," another Stowell chart that brings to mind some of Ralph Towner's thornier compositions. Indeed it almost inevitable to draw comparisons between these two artists as they both play the classical guitar in a jazz setting, drawing from a similar harmonic well for inspiration.Nonetheless I don't find Stowell's playing to be the least bit derivative. Indeed, if this latest offering were any indication, Stowell would appear to be a jazz artist worthy of far more consideration and attention than he has received thus far.The recording is itself is detailed and in focus. Engineer Doolin opts here for a tight upfront sound, revealing the intimate details of Stowell's considerable technique. All the squeaks and string noises are in sharp relief as well, but they are not a distraction and in this reviewer's opinion worth the tradeoff of choosing to close-mike the guitar over a more diffuse room sound.

I got this for my girlfriend who has had some urinary tract problems lately. She has had good results from taking cranberry in the past and this seemed like a good product, as each cap contains 175 mg of cranberry as well as hibiscus extract, which is also supposed to be beneficial to urinary tract health. Unfortunately, she is allergic to soy and this product contains soybean oil, which was a deal breaker for her. It also contains gelatin, an animal product Also, the ingredients in this product are not organic, if that matters to the buyer.

Sundown Ayurvedic Balance joint supplement has only two ingredients, ginger and tumeric. Both are known to possess anti-inflammatory properties. There has been quite a bit of research released in recent years on the health benefits of tumeric. This tumeric comes in the form of both the root itself and an extract form. While there are 1500 mg of ginger per three caps, there are only 140 mg of tumeric per three caps. This seems a bit low to me, but remember, some of that is pure extract, which is presumably more concentrated than root powder. For those who don't like the taste of ginger or tumeric, this is certainly a good way to get the benefits without the taste. Note this product is gmo free but not organic.

There are a number of Fellini/Rota albums out there, some are attempts at orchestral verisimilitude to the original soundtracks, and others such as Hal Wilmer's Amacord are more adventurous attempts at new arrangements, often employing jazz musicians to expand and extemporize on the melodic themes. Of these, the most successful are unsurprisingly done by Italian jazz musicians, the first being Enrico Piernunnzi's outstanding "Fellini Jazz", with no less than Kenny wheeler, Chris Potter, Charlie Haden and Paul Motian in the band. It's a spectacular album that while paying homage to the master, also allows some of the finest jazz musicians on the planet let loose on these tasty pieces. The other album that does justice to this material is Galliano's Nina Rota album, which may be one of best examples of how to be creative with this music while being true to the source material. You can feel the original orchestrations even while condensed to a small group. You can feel the humor and pathos, the street vibe of the Italian canzione tradtions that Rota drew from as well as the strains of Tin Pan Alley. It's all there. It's no wonder that such swinging music would attract jazz musicians to want to play it. The themes are strong, quirky, and at times eerie. This music has haunted me since I first saw Nights of Cabiria. It's interesting, as Galliano seems to have a particular affection for the music of that film, as he keeps coming back to it throughout the album. It's great, because he works in some of the lesser known themes from Cabiria and ingenuously spreads out the music from that film instead of keeping it all together in one suite, serving as a means to stitch together the disparate themes from other films. The result is the  album hangs together as a complete work unto itself.Of course it helps that Galliano is a master musician, and that the accordion is a natural for these poignant themes as well as the more circus-like pastiches. It's a pleasure to hear John Surman on soprano sax and alto clarinet in this somewhat unusual context. Trumpet player Dave Douglas sounds fantastic as well both in the ensemble sections as well as taking some magnificent solos.Since it's almost impossible to get the original soundtracks for these films, the next best thing is to pick up this album (and perhaps Fellini Jazz) to enjoy the timeless music of Nina Rota in the hands of some of the most creative musicians working today.
It's pretty and functional. My girlfriend likes it:  I guess it's official- when you get a toothbrush holder for her, you know she's moved in!

I am pleased by this set of tools. Ford has managed to offer a decent set of tools that are solidly built and properly weighted for a very reasonable price. Four of these are rubberized which increases comfort. All are made of steel. I can recommend these for anyone, especially someone on a budget who needs a decent basic set of pliers, including a locking pliers and an adjustable wrench.

I've used Mackie mixers on and off for many years, starting with the 16/04 and later with the 12 channel vlz pro model. Recently I've also had the opportunity to play around with the new 12 Fx pro. So coming to the 12fx, in a way I am uniquely qualified to say that with its all metal construction and low noise floor, it shares Mackie's standard in quality and build. While this little guy lacks some of the features in its bigger brother, it's quite a little workhorse and delivers a lot of bang for the buck.With the 12fx you get 4 channels with mic pres. Each of those channels has 3 band eq. The eqs are the same as its big brother which offers 6 mic pres. I am somewhat surprised Mackie decided to set the mid eq at 2.5k, which is in my opinion not exactly a mid frequency band. But it is useful for vocals, especially in live settings, and while this mixer can be used for recording,  (it even has a separate out for control room,) it seems primarily designed for live applications. Besides the 4 mic pre channels, the other 8 channels are line in and are grouped 2 per additional channel slider. Great for stereo keyboards or guitars that have been split into stereo thru outboard effects. Note that these line in channels have no Eqs.I found the mic pres to be surprisingly clean and low noise. The same could be said when I put a guitar thru the line in channels. I liked the effects, which far surpassed the Bose L1 in quality. (We were using this unit as a sub mixer into the L1.) there are 12 effects and they provide the kind of meat and potatoes reverbs and slap backs needed. These are really pleasing reverbs so no outboard effects will be needed, at least for vocals.The unit gives you "tape" ins and outs using standard rca inputs, so you can conceivable record analog audio directly onto a digital recorder with the right adapters. I am surprised Mackie hasn't dropped these or at least added a usb input for streaming and/or recording digital audio. It's big brother does have the USB connector, so this is just one of the ways they are able to keep the price point down. The other thing that's missing from this unit is an on/off switch. This is one corner I wished they hadn't cut. It just doesn't seem right.All in all, this is a great mixer for the money. It's loaded with features you wouldn't expect from a $100 mixer. It sounds quite clean with a very low noise floor. It compares favorably with the 12fx pro in that department. In fact, it sounded to me as if the mic pres are identical in both units.So, if you don't need streaming audio and a graphic eq, (which the higher priced 12fx pro has,) and you can live with only 4 mic pres as opposed to 6, this unit will work for you. And considering the 12fx is about double the price, it's a steal.

Daniel Goleman has written some important books in the self help genre, perhaps most notably "Emotional Intelligence", a title so pithy the phrase has entered the American lexicon. I was curious to see his take on the Dalai Lama, who so embodies many of the qualities Goleman writes about.First of all, to be clear this book is not co-written with the Dali Lama. Besides, the foreword, the Dala Lama does not contribute directly to this book, although Goleman had plenty of one to one time with him.The main thrust of the book is an impassioned plea to start seeing the planet and all its people as one family as opposed to being made up of various nations, states and races all scrambling to take their share of what is perceived to be limited resources. By beginning to practice being empathic towards others, the Dalai Lama says one can develop compassion and begin to trust, thus breaking down the barriers between "us and them." He asserts that this can be done in personal relationships as well as on the world stage.Goleman goes on to say the development of empathy in small children is taught through the immediacy of touch and argues that according to some neuroscientists, empathy is even wired into our DNA. the Dalai Lama has always been interested in science and often alludes to scientific research when speaking of the natural human inclination to trust and empathize with others. He makes a strong case that actions motivated by greed and are learned behaviors. The Dalai Lama also makes the point that cultivating a compassionate disposition towards others not only leads to acts of kindness but is actually good for our own health, again using the latest scientific research to back up his claims.The message is simple, but the stories are compelling. Goleman prose is steeped in wisdom and grace. If he seems a little in awe of his subject, well heck, it's the Dalai Lama- who wouldn't be in awe of someone who actually walks his talk? A good read.

This is a straight forward coffee brewer with some cool features. Setting it up for a first brew was easy. You just clean all the parts-the reusable filter and filter holder along with the carafe in soap and water and away you go. Well, almost. This unit includes a carbon filter for your water and you must soak it for 10 minutes before first use. (The manual states it can be used for 60 brews before needing to be replaced.)Once set up, it's about as easy as as it gets. Fill the water chamber to your desired level, (it has a nice visible water indicator on the side,) set whether you want regular or strong brew, pour the ground coffee into the gold filter (you can optionally use a paper filter, but as the manual warns, not both!) and hit the brew button. That's it. In a few minutes you will have a pretty tasty brew. I used my fancy beans from a local roasters and I have to say it was a strong and satisfying brew with zero unwanted "machine taste." It was not quite as subtle, aromatic and revealing of my lighter roast beans flavors as my manual pour over method made from the same beans, but close enough. And if you're going to entertain guests, you'll want a machine like this to make up to 12 cups. I should mention this machine's idea of a cup falls a bit short of 8oz. When measured out, I found the side calibration to register about 1 1/4 cups per 8oz of water. The manual said to use about 1 scoop of ground beans per cup (scoop included,) and after experimenting with a bit more than that, I would say they are about right in their estimation-my coffee was a bit too strong with three scoops for two cups. However, you'll want to play with it on your own to get your brew to align with your own tastes.Pros:1) makes a decent cup of coffee with little effort.2) This machine will allow you to set a timer so you can wake up to fresh coffee. It's easy and intuitive to set this feature up.3) has a self cleaning feature which is very convenient.4) looks good and has a relatively small footprint.5) has warmer control with choice of heat level and timer.Cons:1) The construction seems a bit light and somewhat flimsy; it seems to weigh next to nothing. Time will tell if it holds up.2) cleaning the metal filter is a bit of a drag. But you can use your favorite paper filters instead.3) you have to buy new water filters every so often. (But if you already have a water filter as I do, I wouldn't replace it and instead just not use it at all.4) The unit is very light and perhaps flimsy; it seems to weigh next to nothing. Time will tell if it holds up.All in all, I like this machine. It looks good on my countertop, sporting a brushed stainless steel look (it's real metal, not plastic,) and takes up a lot less counter space than my old grind and brew, (which didn't do nearly as good at its primary task, that of making coffee.) I am quite satisfied with the unit and whenever I need to make coffee for more than one guest, this will be my go to machine.

This is a classic of Malian music in the Mande tradition. Just two acoustic steel string guitars and vocals, It is performed live in a small room by two master musicians. It has the relaxed feeling of an informal session because it was recorded in a house as opposed to studio. If the vocals are a bit odd sounding acoustically, it's forgivable as the content is so relaxed and at the same time, mesmerizing and transporting. This is a magical recording that captures the freedom and beauty of this style of music. It meanders and soars. It is the essential sound of Mali. A must buy for anyone interested in the music of Mali.

This is a little gem of an album. I discovered it thru a Brazilain jazz forum and I am forever in debt to that anonymous person for their recommendation. Although it states that it is a Gil Golstein/Romero Lubamba recording, Toninho Horta's distinctive guitar and vocals make a strong impression as well. The writing is excellent, especially the Phoenicians which features Golstein's scintillating accordion and Luisa, A Horta tune which has a nice melody and chord structure. Toninho takes a beautiful solo on that tune that he whistles to perfectly. Lovely. It's one of many such unique musical delicacies that grace this wonderful recording. Golsteins piano lines swoop and swirl sending ribbons of sound through the musical landscapes-his phrasing is very much across the bar and very rhythmic, belaying his love for Brazilian music and his solid jazz training. Guest percussionist Alex Acuna lays down some sweet grooves on a few tracks as well. It's refreshing not to have a bass player-the music floats and caresses, yet at the same time is grounded in the strong rhythmic sense that all these players demonstrate with great aplomb. In other words, this music grooves! The ballads are also very nice. I love the first track, a beautiful arrangement of "My Foolish Heart." It inspired me to give another standard, "When I Fall in Love" a reharm and a similar bossa treatment. When an album inspires you to make your own music, you know it's really special. This is such an album. It will make its way into your heart and your playlist.

Premonition was McCandless's 2nd and sadly, last album on the short lived Windham Hill Jazz label. In a way, it's his most commercial album, but that would be misleading. Although superficially a more traditional fusion record, it never really veers into cliche or smooth jazz territory. The writing is so far superior to anything in that genre, it would be patently fallacious to dismiss it as such.The album does have a more traditional band instrumentation than previous McCandless recordings-with William Kennedy on drums, Gary Brown,  bass, Steve Cardenas on guitar (on some tunes,) and the great Lyle Mays, piano. When you've got a band like that, you know it's going to be anything but conventional! The tunes range from the dreamy Oregon sounding "Rainland" to the hard edged fusion of "Punch." Whidh I believe to be inspired from Paul's short lived stint playing with keyboard maestro/composer Kit Walker. Perhaps the tune that comes closest to smooth jazz is the opening track, "Robin", written for Paul's late wife. (Incidentally, The Oregon tune, "Round Robin" was also written for her.) Even though this tune starts out sounding superficially like that genre, the inner lines, tremendous attention to detail and care taken in the arrangement make it far more musically nutritious than anything played on those timid records. if you're a fan of Oregen, you're going to love "At First Sight", which sounds like a tune that band would've played. It's some of Paul's best writing ever.Produced by Steve Rodby, this one is a keeper. While it may not be as musically deep as Heresay or All the Mornings Bring, Premonition is an album that often finds its way onto my playlist. It's simply a wonderfully produced album of well written tunes played by some of the best musicians on the west coast. Get it if you can find it.

This is a quality all round chefs knife. From the moment I received it, I noticed the quality-the build of this knife is excellent. The blade is heavy and so sharp it cuts like butter-tried it on a variety of veggies, fruits and meats-I can't imagine this knife finding its match. Although the knife is somewhat larger and heavier than my other comparable Henckel kitchen knives, it has wonderful balance and feels great in the hand. The handle is made of hardwood and not only feels good, it looks fantastic. This is an excellent all round chef's knife and for the money it's a great deal as well. My highest praise is that I like it better than either of my two beloved Henckels.

This Kelty Sleeping bag states that it is warm all the way down to 6 degrees Farenheit...and I believe it! The uber-warm factor comes from its unique approach of using duck down near the shell and polyester on the inside. (Label states it is 25%duck down and 75% polyester fill.) It is cushy and as my girlfriend stated, like sleeping on a cloud. This model is 6ft long, plenty long for me and my partner. It is zippable from either the top or bottom and has a mummy style hood that tightens up snugly. According to the label, it's water repellant. I have yet to test that out.There is a certain amount of trade off in getting a bag this luxuriant. Although the label also claims that it is very compressible, it's in a different category from say, my Mountain Hardwear backpacking bag, which compresses so small it can fit in a little pocket at the bottom of my pack. Even compressed, I would have to strap this puppy onto the outside of my pack. No biggie-the label claims it stuffs down to 10.5x18 inches and I can live with that. The 6ft model I have for review weighs in at 4 pounds one oz,, so although it's light by car camping standards, it can't compete with my 2.5 pound bag. Nor should it: it is a whole different animal. And then again, my Mountain Hardwear bag is only rated to a mere 35 degrees.It's interesting that Kelty gives a different temperature rating for men and women. Apparently, women sleep colder than men, and Kelty gives separate ratings for both men and women. While this bag is rated down to 6 degrees for men, it is rated 19 degrees for women, so keep that in mind when shopping.All in all, this is a deluxe bag, extremely comfortable and ideally suited for car camping, but could definitely be used for short backpacking trips where weight isn't critical. It's simply one of the most comfortable bags I've ever had the pleasure of slipping into. Highly recommended.

This is a straight ahead lightening to USB cable. It's short and perfect for travel. It's high quality cable, very similar to Apple build. I would recommend it wholeheartedly, with the one caveat, that this is a very short cable.

I always try to use non-chemical cleaning products. I have tried a number of products for dishes, settling on a citrus/plant enzyme powder before trying this gel.  I have now tried this stuff a few times and my feeling is it works at least as well as the Citradish powder I have been using. Everything came out sparkling without residue or waterspots.Seventh Generation Utra Power Plus uses plant enzymes to micro scrub your dishes. It is biodegradable, and has just a slight natural fragrance derived from essential oils and botanical extracts. Note that the 3rd listed ingredient is ppg-19-laureth-7, an anti spotting agent, was given a "C" by the Environmental Working Group in their "Guide to Healthy Cleaning" database because of possible negative health effects. I tried to look up what these possible ill health effects might be, but couldn't find out anything about it. So I'm not letting that put me off. It's not listed as toxic anywhere else I could find on the web.In summary, I think this is a clean, effective product that will work under most conditions. Note that by Seventh Gen's own admission, it doesn't work very well with hard water. They suggest adding a little vinegar in homes with that situation. I love that this product is basically unscented and will continue to use it as my main dishwashing product. I also like the fact that being a gel, it is less likely to spill as been known to happen with klutzes such as myself!

I think the ilumi tunable led smart bulb is a very good idea. I like the idea of being able to create just the right mood lighting with an app on my iPhone or iPad. I like the idea of being able to create and save particular shades of light to recall at the touch of a button. And I think it's cool that I can get this thing to respond to music on my devices. Or create an "experience" such as simulating a dawn sunrise, a circadian rhythm or a series of on/off and color changes to create the illusion of being home while on vacation.The problem with this potentially great idea is the execution: nothing I tried quite worked as I had hoped it would. While pairing the bulb with my devices was easy enough, I found the interface to be buggy:pros: bringing up the color wheel was fun and changing the colors was quite smooth.(You can also change the amount of white light added to the color in a 2nd inner circle.) Underneath the color wheel is a dimmer bar.Cons: The problem is, the dimmer bar isn't smooth. As I slid my finger along the bar, the bulb barely dimmed. Then, all of a sudden, as I pushed the bar towards the dimmest setting, the bulb suddenly dimmed and abruptly turned off. I so wish the dimmer was smooth because I don't like bright LED light and had a hard time getting it to dim-instead of smoothly transitioning, it jumped around from bright to very dim and then to off. When I did manage to get the bulb to the color and dimmer setting I desired, I tried to save it as a "scene". But when I tried to retrieve the setting (or "scene",)  the bulb lit up with a shade and dimmer setting that was quite a bit brighter than the one I had saved. When I tried to get the bulb to respond to music, it did change colors, but for the most part, not in a particularly rhythmic or musical way-although in its defense, on occasion the light changed on a strong beat. Fyi: there are no fine tune settings for this particular application, just "dance", "chill," " fire" and a brightness setting.In summary, I think this smart bulb has tremendous potential, and as the Ilumi people update the firmware and the software, I think it might eventually prove to be a truly exciting product. As it stands, what we have here is a good idea that is still in its developmental stages. If you want something more than a static tunable mood light, this may not be the right choice. In its current state, I would say, with regards to the app at least, it really isn't quite ready for prime time. As the bulb gets smarter and the app improves, this could be one hell of an awesomely cool bulb. I'm giving it three stars because I still think it's pretty cool  as it is and because I can imagine how very cool it could get as it develops.

I've been moisturizing for quite awhile now. I understand the benefits and as a guy with dry skin it has made all the difference. I generally use the unscented moisturizers my dermatologist recommends. When I ordered this thru Amazon Vine I didn't look to see if it was scented, so it may be up there on the page,( I looked again it is-its described as white almond and orange flowers,) but when I first tried it I wasn't prepared: This moisturizer has a very strong floral scent that reminded me of lavender. But I have to say the scent was far too intense for me to use on a regular basis. In fact, even though I liked the luxurious feel of it on my skin, I will still would probably never use it again. It's a matter of personal taste-I just don't like scented body products of any kind. Now I suppose there may be many people who enjoy a scented moisturizer. If you can get past the scent, this would seem to be a decent product. It's thick, almost like whipped butter. It goes on nicely and has staying power. It really could last 24 hours! I could definitely tell it contains quality ingredients and my skin felt like it just soaked the stuff up, while at the same time it gave me a very "clean" feeling.Because of the floral scent, I would think this product is targeting woman. In an age where gender stereotypes are being blown out of the water on a daily basis, I can imagine there might be some men who wouldn't mind the scent. But I would say overall, this is a product designed for the female market. I'm going to give it to my girlfriend and see what she thinks, and if she doesn't like it, it's going to my mom. I'll report their reactions to the product after they've tried it.

Shauna Martin has written an attractive,beautifully illustrated hardcover book on the subject of using green drinks as a means to cleanse the body of toxins. The book starts with Martin recounting how she used the green drinks to help her recover from her battle with breast cancer. The rest of the book is divided into four sections, each one devoted to a 4 day cleanse specifically tailored for each of the seasons. Each page is devoted to one recipe which is accompanied by a nice photo. The recipe section includes a number of yummy looking salads as well as the drinks. At the beginning of each section, Martin thoughtfully provides a shopping list for all the ingredients you will need for your cleanse.As someone who already starts my day off with a green smoothie (which includes copious amounts of fresh greens), I am glad to have this book. I tend to use the same ingredients over and over and it's nice to see so much variety here. Most of the recipes which are relatively simple, look really great and I'm looking forward to trying them, even before doing the cleanse.  I'm going to do the spring cleanse soon and will report back on the results.One more thing: i strongly recommend using a really good blender such as a Vitamix or the equivalent to make these drinks.

The inspiration for the title suite of this ambitious album, Love is a Pendulum, comes from a lovely poem by Barbara Sfraga, which is printed on the inside cover. It is a poem that embodies the constantly transformative, evanescent flow of energy that we call love. The five part suite is the centerpiece of the album-Locke takes the first line of each stanza and attempts to capture its essence. Using the language of straight ahead,  post bop, elements of fusion, sophisticated pop inflected ballads and the occasional nod to world music, Locke brings great contrast to his extended compositions, while giving plenty of blowing time to the talented band he has assembled for this project.Locke has long established himself as one of the best vibe players of his generation, crafting a unique and almost instantly identifiable sound on an instrument for which that feat, as any vibes player knows (and I am one!), is particularly challenging. Pianist Robert Rodriguez has a deft touch and delivers a supple responsive accompaniment. His solos are rhythmically intricate while at the same time, completely lyrical. Ricky Rodriguez lays down the bottom on both acoustic and electric bass-his is also a melodic approach; Locke mentions in his liner notes that many of Ricky's tasty lines were so good that he often incorporated them into his writing. The core band is rounded out by Locke's longtime associate, Terreon Gully on drums. Gully deploys a powerful take no prisoners attitude in his playing, never dominating or pushing too hard, yet at the same time laying down some serious grooves, and always supporting the soloists and ensemble sections.There are a number of guest artists involved as well. Standouts include the great Donny McCaslin, a true force of nature on tenor sax (particularly when trading with killer alto player Rosario Giuliani on Love is Perpetual Motion), and rising steel pan master Victor Provost, whose refreshing melodic approach to soloing on the pan is wholly steeped in the jazz tradition. Special mention should be made of the cutting edge vocals of Theo Bleckman, who contributes some soulful vocalise moments, especially notable on Love is a Planchette. He sounds a bit like Bobby McFerrin at times, freely improvising a tapestry of vocal colors.I'm still getting into this album. It will take many listenings to begin to understand a score this complex, just as it takes many years to comprehend the mysteries of the human heart. Joe Locke has made an epic album that attempts to explore those mysteries and succeeds brilliantly, and has delivered what may very well be the best original work of his career. Five well deserved stars.

While his eponymous solo recording, Hubris, still stands head and shoulders above the rest, Beirach has produced a number of solo recordings. There are now at least two solo albums on which Beirach takes classical pieces and extemporizes on them, mixing in a few originals and sometimes a standard or two. Jazz Adagios is another one. Whereas Adagio has a slightly more consistent dreamy quality, this one has a little more variety in tempo and mood. Both are worth getting if you like the more classical side of Richies work. Beirach is a pianist who can really pull off the delicate feat of introducing a classical theme and improvising on it. This is a great sounding recording too, well worth adding to your collection.

I really like this vacuum cleaner. It's a little workhorse. It was easy to put together, needing only one screw to attach the handle to the rest of the unit. I will say, it took a few tries to get it to line up properly before I could get the screw to catch. After that it was smooth sailing. After charging the unit I got to work and found it effective and fun to use. It's so nice to go cordless and combined with the fact this little unit is so light, I actually found it mildly exhilarating to clean my bare wood floors. The head has a 180 degree turning radius which makes turning around corners a breeze. With the brush turned on, it effectively cleaned my wood floors. It also did a good job on my rugs and carpet.I really appreciate the detachable handheld unit. When the crevice tool is attached, it's easy to get to those hard to reach places. It also works well in my car which is a definite added plus.Cleaning out the bagless dirt receptacle wasn't that hard, although there are a couple of parts that must be taken apart to get the job done.  After having to deal with a heavy corded floor canister unit with a bag, I have to say I felt positively liberated using this machine. It's also relatively quiet.As far as battery life goes, this machine is OK but ran out of juice before I finished cleaning my 1500 sq foot home. It was close: I still had a couple of bathrooms and a small bedroom left.  For this reason I am docking the Electrolux one star. Still, considering the price I can highly recommend the Electrolux Ergoapido, but I'm not retiring my Hoover. I still need it for stairs and for ceilings etc, not to mention being corded, it never runs out of juice.

Although I personally like the brighter 120 lumen version for those nites I get off the trail a little late, , I got this one for my girlfriend who wanted it for her keychain. While there are smaller flashlights out there for this purpose, none are as bright as this little puppy. 85 lumens is more than enough to do the job of finding ones way to the door and the keyhole. A good price too.

A great bar :Lots of favor and subtle notes. Am going to try the other percentages. They sent samples of several other bars- I liked them all. If you like the taste of raw chocolate and you like it dark,, I recommend trying Xtasy.

As any fan of Keith Jarrett knows, over the past 40 odd years, there have been many many live solo piano albums. Most have moments of glory and some, like the famous Koln Concert or the less well known but even better Bremen Lausanne discs have longer periods of prolonged ecstatic spontaneous composition. Everyone has their favorite. Yet most of the live solo albums in which Keith played without interruption are uneven at best, while the master inevitably treads musical water until the next wave of inspiration takes over. Considering what he's doing, how could that not be so?For this reason and other considerations, health being one of them, Jarrett changed his approach to the solo concert, improvising shorter pieces with defined beginnings, developmental sections and endings. Rio and Paris/London were fine examples of this new approach.  With Creation, Jarrett takes things one step further, compiling the best of 4 separate concerts into one album. Although some reviewers seem irked by the idea, I personally applaud this innovation. When one considers how shocked purists were over the fact that after he retired from public performance, Glen Gould actually edited his performances from different takes to get what he wanted, it hardly seems like a travesty that an artist of the caliber of Jarrett, who is literally grabbing these pieces out of thin air, would decide to produce an album in this manner. It hardly constitutes musical heresy to do so and the results are startlingly coherent and beautiful.These pieces hang together well-the sequencing must have been difficult, but Jarrett has managed to put together an album full of grace and elegance. The music tends towards the contemplative, and as a longtime fan who is well aware of Mr Jarrett's predilection for playing "out" and wandering into contemporary non-harmonic territory at some point during his solo outings, I for one was happy to discover that he stays pretty firmly rooted in the tonal world here, producing a neo-classical hybrid sound that often strays into the harmonic world of the romantic period. (There is however, one piece that borders on atonality, but the logic of it is so fierce and confident that it never descends into chaos.)One caveat: if you're looking for Keith's jazz/groove side to emerge, this is not the album for you: Not a repeating ostinato or blues lick to be found here.Two other items of note: there is no applause on this recording, which I consider a big plus. Secondly, while Keith isn't vocalizing all over the place as he sometimes does, there are moments where he does so.  For some reason, his vocalizations are louder than usual here, but thank goodness, very infrequent.There's a purity evidenced in these pieces; it's as though over the many decades of taking on the monumental challenge of literally making something out of nothing on the concert stage, Jarrett has had all his excesses boiled away, leaving only the essence of his creative force. That is what this album represents to me-the essence of a particular driving creative force peculiar to his solo concerts that this master musician has been striving to bring to light these many years. It is in this listener's opinion, a profound step in Jarrett's evolution as a solo concert improviser.As a last note of recommendation, I played this album for my girlfriend who isn't really that into Jarrett. She played it again right afterwards, and once again after that. I know of no greater praise than that.

This album has always had a special place in my heart. The first 3:30 of this album comes close to being the purest outpouring of spontaneous composition on record. A friend actually transcribed it! Hats off because it's harmonically deep, as opposed to Jarrett's modal trance playing or his "out" stuff. It's a little like listening to a composer like Chopin at one of those legendary after hours salons. A bonafide master at work creating unbelieveably beautiful tone poems out of thin air.The rest of the album has many such moments. Really I always thought this was Jarrett's supreme solo concert, even surpassing Koln in many ways, not to disparage that amazing recording. At any rate, this is a must have for lovers of Keith's solo improvisation work. Certainly one of the top 3, if not the best.

I had heard of this album but never gave it much thought until I stumbled across it here. Amazon prime had a new copy and was letting it go for $4! Naturally I snapped it up. And it's not just a good example of early Richie-it's great. There's a wonderful consistent mood on this album. It flows from the guitar duos into the flugelhorn duos perfectly. You get to hear some of Beirach's great originals, Broken wing and the lesser known Zal and the dreamy Mavrodaphne. Beirach's penchant for exploring certain standards like Yesterdays and What is this Thing are nicely represented here. I love his interpretation of Black is the Color. He may have been the first to take it in this direction.Also, I have to say the sound of this 1976 release is nothing short of amazing. It was released in 2006. The remastering makes it sound like an ECM recording. I'm not exaggerating. Supposedly recorded in Richie's home studio, it was actually recorded by David Baker and judging from the audio, in a pro studio. It sounds way too good for a home recording.If you can find this at a decent price, I urge any fans of Richie Beirach to pick up a copy of this rare album.

A quiet little duo album by the great flugelhorn horn master Kenny Wheeler and unknown (to me) pianist Brian Dickenson. Kenny's tunes are treated reverently and Dickenson misses very little in terms of understanding Kennys unique harmonic and melodic world. He also contributes a couple of nice tunes of his own that fit right into the contemplative feel of the album. If you like the lyrical side of Kenny Wheeler, this ones for you.  The pair play in great simpatico-this is a very consistent and inspired duo set by two Canadian masters, one well known and one a well kept secret. Would like to hear more from Mr Dickenson. He's got a nice touch.

Hyaluronic Acid provides the fluid matrix for joint lubrication, skin hydration, and skin repair.* Jarrow Formulas Hyaluronic Acid is a low-molecular weight preparation derived from biological fermentation. It is clinically documented to be bioavailable and to improve hydration of the skin.*The above words are from Jarrows label. It is difficult to ascertain in just one month whether a particular product is having an effect or not. I've been having some joint issues so I was curious whether this stuff would help my funky shoulder. After a month of using it, I can't say I'm cured but my bursitis seems a little less painful. Of course this is all quite subjective and I might have experienced this improvement anyway. As far as skin goes, I haven't noticed anything, but again, I would imagine to see results might take several months.I've decided to continue taking this stuff for a 3-4 month trial just because I'm intrigued with the idea and because Jarrow is a name I trust. I'll add an update after several months of use.

It's hard to find words to describe something so unexpectedly fresh and beautiful as this new album by Tigran Hamasyan. It's sort of like when you look out the window at dusk and instead of a modest sunset, there is a strange and mesmerizing glow in the west-you are confronted with one of those rare confluences of light and shadow, cloud and sky where the colors become so intense it makes you realize what a gift it is to simply be alive. Listening to this album today gave me that kind of experience.For those who have been following Tigran's career, it has become clear that his is a unique voice. A trained jazz musician with an encyclopedic knowledge of rhythm (I suspect besides his native land's odd time signatures, he has seriously studied the Indian konecal system,) Tigran has returned more deeply than ever to his Armenian roots to mine the veins of gold hidden in his own cultural heritage. With his knowledge of western classical forms, jazz, progressive rock and electronica, Hamayasan continues to forge a unique musical identity that came to full fruition on his last album, Shadow Theater. Whereas Shadow Theater was a highly produced release with a lot of hype behind it, even a video, the somewhat less extravagantly produced MockRoot dropped without a splash, yet is no less complex and probing, and if anything, even more fearless and fierce than its predecessor. Armenian folk tunes in odd times play bait and switch with wildly explosive fusion episodes, sounding one minute almost like traditional world music and the next like something out of Return to Forever's Romantic Warrior. Women's voices soar over pastoral piano ostinatos, only to break into earthy stuttering grooves that startle the listener out of his reverie. It's Tigrans wonderful sense of compositional development and juxtaposition of disparate elements that take center stage here. There are hardly any extended piano solos, maybe just one or two.Listening to this astounding album for the 3rd time today, other contemporary innovators come to mind-I think of Nguyen Le's groundbreaking adventures, such as combining traditional Vietnamese folk music and modern jazz on "Tales of Vietnam" or his wonderful encounter with North Africa on "Maghreb and Friends". I think of Chick Corea's early Return To Forever recordings where one could hear the "Spanish tinge" mixing it up with the raw power of rock and fusion. I think of Egberto Gismonti's unique brand of classical music and jazz blending with the vibrant sounds of the tribal people of the Amazon Rainforest. I even hear a moment of early Jan Hammer (incidentally also of Eastern European extraction,) on the synths in the epic 12 minute track, "Out of the Grid." Tigran draws from everything, Hovhaness to Stravinsky, Zeppelin to Zappa.When I hear this music, I think of all those artists who early in their careers found their voice, and from that point on, were instantly identifiable from as little as just one phrase. At the tender age of 27, Tigran has already achieved that point of self actualization. For one so young this is quite an amazing accomplishment. It will be fascinating to see where he goes next.This album is a sort of miracle- it engages the mind, it touches the heart, and occasionally explodes viscerally to captivate all the senses. It is at once accessible and obtuse, familiar and exotic. Even if your mind can't grasp what time signature the music is in, your body will respond anyway; It already knows this is a kind of soul food it has always needed, but didn't know was missing, a special feast for the senses, one with a distinctly Eastern European flavor.

Tigran is not interested in being the jazz piano prodigy he once appeared to be, as evidence by some of his more recent work. But this, this takes it to another level. He mixes progressive rock, electronica, Armenian folk music, heavy metal, pop, jazz and God knows what else into a heady stew that sounds at times like King Crimson, Frank Zappa, Hovaness, Bartok or even Bjork but really, it's not like anything I've heard before. The production style is more pop than jazz, relying on all the technology in today's studio. The result is totally unique, an album like no other, best heard over a great system or better yet, with headphones.I can't emphasize how wonderful this recording is. It's a kaleidoscopic look into the mind of one of the freshest talents to come along in a long while. I can't recommend it highly enough. It is a trip, one well worth taking.

This is a really nice French press. It's a contemporary design that I quite like. It's all stainless steel except for the plastic handle and of course, the glass carafe. All in all, it does its job quite well. No complaints about the coffee- it's very good. It makes up to 8 cups-when I'm brewing just for myself I make 4 cups worth for my large mug. It was easy to measure the right amount of coffee and water. It was great the first time! I find it quite easy to clean. The only thing I would say that I'm not crazy about is that Bialetti has their logo in no less than 5 locations on the coffee maker. I get it: it's a contemporary look. But really, the logo sideways on one side of the glass would've been quite sufficient and in this reviewers opinion, more elegant.That's the only con. At this price, you'd be hard "pressed" to find a better French press.

Yep, it really works. As per the the instructions I put 3 pumps (spray) of the solution into every 16 ounces of water that goes into my Lab's bowl. By the time he finishes drinking through the bowl (around 32 ounces) through the course of his day the normal dog breath has been noticeably tempered and while not quite being 'minty fresh' has become pleasantly neutral and no longer noticeable.The product arrives in a small plastic spray dispenser holding 2.2 fluid ounces.  Based on suggested water/formula ratio each dispenser is good for over 32 servings. Most importantly the Lab does not seem to mind or notice the inclusion of this formula as he continues to consume his regular quantity of water at the same pace he always does.

This Garcinia Cambogia supplement comes in a 180 pill count bottle with each of the pills sized slightly larger than your standard gelatin capsules. Inside, a white powder is visible and there is no noticeable odors or aftertastes after consuming. Suggested daily allowance is a total of 6 capsules, taken 3x each twice per day, one hour before a scheduled meal. For me at least there is a mild to moderate appetite suppression effect that takes place. It's nothing too drastic as you'll have most of your appetite intact but I do find that if I serve myself a smaller portion of food then I would normally consume I can be left mostly satisfied with said quantity. If a milder effect is what you seek this particular supplement makes for a good starting point but it does require some effort to fit the 6 pills around your daily meal schedule.

This is a well organized resource written by the Director of Data Science at Warby Parker (that online eyeglass shop), Carl Anderson. The volume serves as a comprehensive executive-level walk through on what is involved in building, operating and utilizing a robust data platform to drive the enterprise through its decision making, forecasting and operational processes. The book is best suited for a non-techie, corporate level manager who possesses up to date biz-level technical acumen and if read from cover to cover will walk away with a solid understanding of the key components that comprise modern data infrastructures and how to put said resource and the people who operate it to proper use.The book itself utilizes a smattering of charts and graphs, some of which are printed in non-glossy full color. Presentation is sound with Anderson rolling out the content in logical fashion starting with a very articulate opener defining what exactly a 'data driven' operation and mindset is and works its way up to practical topics ranging from visualization, A/B testing, etc. A very effective and well written primer to get its intended reader up to speed.

A very interesting book - layouts and presentation are beautiful with each page utilizing full color printing on thick, glossed paper. The arts and crafts (and some food recipes) projects demonstrates plenty of imagination and creativity from Raphaele Vidaling ranging from the relatively simple to purely whimsical. The style of the projects encompasses a very hipster, DIY aesthetic that would feel right at home in the world of the TV show 'Portlandia' (check out the project to make keepsake boxes from the dried husks of tangerines). Regardless of your tastes and level of craftsmanship just about anyone can find 5 or 6 projects suitable for their liking. A fun book to work your way through designed for both the adult and youngster in mind.

A very well performing and fitting pair of earbuds delivering perky sonics for a reasonable price. This is a fairly basic product. There's no in-line controls or wireless connectivity but it manages to deliver on the points that are most important for me when wearing a set of earbuds 2-3 hours at a time. For starters comfort is excellent. Each bud is relatively light in weight and sits comfortably in my ears. The set comes with 3 pairs of eartips of varying sizes and after switching to the largest pair the sound seal was nice and tight and there's no irritation or fatigue on my ears even after several hours of consecutive use. Sound quality was also a pleasant surprise. Audio range is your standard 20-20,000Hz but balance is spot on with good articulation among the highs and lows. Great value set with excellent comfort and audio quality (product sample provided for review purposes).

Overall a good holistic approach, immune system boosting supplement. The product is based around berry fruit extracts - specifically 335 mg of European Elder Berry (Austrian sourced) and 50 mg of Black Currant extract to assist with microbial balance stability. New Chapter's extraction process utilizes no solvents, filters our sugars but still manages to allow allow phytonutirents to pass through. These are standard sized gel caps and if you've taken similar sized supplements in the past there should be no issues with swallowing.

These work for the most part in that it does open up your nasal passage and increases your level of in/out airflow which in theory allows you to continuously breathe through your nose while asleep and not through your mouth - which is where snoring comes form. The important thing with this product is to find the right sized pair for your nose. Fortunately this set comes with 4 different sized pairs and I suggest starting with the smallest version until you find the size that stays firmly in place without being uncomfortable. Should you use a pair that is too big you'll likely experience some discomfort at some point in your sleep and without realizing you'll remove it from your nose and find it under your bed the next morning (Discounted product received for review purposes).

Latex and powder free and several times the puncture resistance of latex this is a good chemical resistant glove that provides good tactile feedback with plenty of unencumbered dexterity motion.  Just keep in mind that this particular 100 box set is intended for industrial use and is not sterile or suitable for barrier protection in medical/healthcare scenarios.

Yep, the concoction is a bit of a salt bomb with an 8 ounce glass giving you 33% of your daily recommended salt intake (790 mg) but as a base for Bloody Mary's or Micheladas the blend hits all the right notes with distinct notes of veg, acid, umami and just a hint of heat. You could dress it up further with the addition of more tobasco or worcestershire sauce but if you're in a pinch this mix gives you everything you need quickly and easily straight out of the bottle.

Former McKinsey partner - Caroline Webb has compiled the latest and greatest findings from behavioral science and psychology resulting in this fairly thorough volume that guides the reader on shifts in mindset and habit processes that will lead to enhanced workplace productivity and efficiency. Webb covers 7 areas of improvement (priorities; productivity; relationships; thinking; influence; resilience; and energy) with each of these sections containing 3 chapters dedicated to fine tuning specific aspects of the process.Those who regularly peruse new releases from the worlds of productivity and behavioral economics literature will likely not find much that is new here but where the volume excels is through the sheer breadth of topics logically presented by Webb. The book functions nicely as a very thoughtful executive summary on the past 20 years of study and how small tweaks in mindset and perception can help you accomplish more throughout your day, communicate more efficiently and maintain a healthier, balanced life even through the stresses of modern work environments.

The cool thing about the WWE's 'Create' series of wrestling action figures is that each of the sets in the series comes as a full kit with body parts, costumes and accessories that can be swapped among the other wrestling figures in the series.  The Kane 'Superstar Rocker Set' comes with 17 parts including 2 swappable head parts, 2 unique masks, 2 sets of boots etc. In addition customization goes a step further with a sheet of 20+ tattoo decals that can be affixed to Kane's body and armor parts.Sizing of the figure is pretty good at approximately 8" tall. Facial detailing is better than expected, paintwork is decent and articulation on body points is fairly standard and holds up to rough play from your youngsters. The toy is designed for ages 6 and up and this seems appropriate as there are plenty of small parts that should be kept away from smaller children.

The ice skating Mickey ornament is the perfect size at 3.5" in height to hang on the tree. The porcelain figure has good weight at near 6 ounces and the hand-painted detailing is done very well except for a couple of small and faint red smudges on the green scarf (not a big deal really). Keep in mind that these Lenox Mickey figures are part of an annual line so if you haven't jumped on board with previous versions this 2015 edition is certainly a great starting point to build up your collection of these classic and very well made ornaments over the years to come.

From Euro board/card game designer, Bruno Faidutti, this is a fairly simple and streamlined play experience geared for 3-6 players ages 12 and up. Gameplay is centered around slaying dragons followed by the meat of the experience which is based around negotiating the divvying up of the loot. Determining the division of the spoils is kept under 1 minute through an included sand timer so the each turn is kept relatively fast paced. Game pieces which are mostly cards and fake gem treasure tokens are fine for the most part but just wished the artwork on the cards had a bit more detail. Overall the game was a bit too simplistic for my liking but it's not a terrible experience and makes for a good option when introducing this type of gaming to first timers.

Styling and fit is very good with this pair of casual, cycling sunglasses. The black polycarbonate frames has classic retro vintage styling reminiscent of a pair of Wayfarers. The product is very much a unisex set and looks great on my wider face as well as my SO's narrower facial frame. For cycling or outdoor purposes this product works great in that it blocks out wind from creeping in through the bottom as well as the sides. It has a slightly snuggish grip against the sides of your head but it's never uncomfortable and holds up very well while trail running on tough terrain. The product comes packed in a rugged EVA case with a soft case bag and microfiber cleaning cloth as well (product sample provided for review).

This is a very effective acne/spot clearing treatment. The 1 ounce of product arrives in a small, dark blue glass bottle. For application dip a q-tip into the bottle (do not shake the vial prior to using) and make sure it touches the bottom of the container in order to pick up the bentonite clay compounds and then dab the solution on the troubled areas of your skin. The solution is very fast acting and best of all it does not overtly dry out my skin. For best results I use this at night just prior to bedtime and I wake up with noticeably reduced spot inflammation where the solution was applied.  The treatment is a bit harshly scented with strong notes of alcohol and cucumber extracts but it's nothing particularly overwhelming or unpleasant. Overall a very nice treatment that efficiently deals with the occasional flare up (product sample provided for review).

This 'Ghost Pirate' island play set is designed for ages 3-8 and has a decent size of not being so large that it becomes cumbersome to store or too small to quickly lose the interest of your youngsters.  The set has a couple of interactive features by way of a secret entrance compartment and a hidden cannon compartment that gently fires the included 2 pieces of anchor shaped ammo.  The kit also includes a ghost pirate figure with various removable fashion and accessory pieces and a ghost alligator. The set does not require any batteries, is molded nice and soft without any sharp edges and provides a good play base for the included figures or others as well (the kids get a kick using lego figures with this set).

Very small, extremely durable and designed to be carried with you at all times whether attached to your keychain or dangling from a lanyard.  The unit utilizes an all metal external casing and the entirety of the drive is water/magnet/xray/shock and temperature proof. The 64 gig version arrives brand new with 59.7 gigs of available storage. Incoming/outgoing data transfers are as fast as you'd expect provided you're connected to a USB 3.0 port (up to 130 MB/s). The drive is around 1.75" long and .25" thick and is small enough where once you place it on your key ring you might even forget that it's there. Very convenient overall with good data transfer speeds and rugged durability.

The conditioner feels great going through your hair. After shampooing a small dab is all you need to work through all your strands. Product packaging suggests leaving the conditioner on your hair for at least 3 minutes for best results. The cream easily rinses out and really leaves a nice, lustrous finish. The product has a sweet, berry fragrance that is not overpowering and dissipates after around a half hour.The formulation of this product is based around marine collagen and pure elastin protein compounds. Designed to reinforce the cuticle walls this is a good restorative product as it nourishes each strand while providing vitality to your hair's appearance.

The best thing about this Gecko Active yoga mat backpack is the diversity of options the bag itself offers. Typically I've been using those standard yoga mat bags - the ones that are shaped like long and slender duffle bags. Those types of bags work great for their intended purpose which is to lug around a mat but for other purposes - the shape is a bit off putting and doesn't get use outside of its sole purpose.This particular bag though, is a legit multi tasker.  The bag is basically a sling backpack with 2 adjustable straps on the side that you use to hold your mat in place. The bag is extremely comfortable to use even when its weighed down by gear, a filled water bottle and a 5+ lb mat. If I don't need to lug around a mat I can still put this bag to use as a standard slingpack. Very handy and very useful with its dual functions. The bag itself has excellent construction with heavy duty and waterproof nylon materials.
