There are two smaller outer pockets perfectly suited for keys, wallets and other small accessories as well as a water bottle adjustable pocket on the side opposite where your mat is held and a pouch for your phone placed directly on the chest strap. There are 2 larger inner pockets with enough size to hold small towels, toiletries, reading materials or a lightweight change of clothes. Styling is also excellent with a functional and utilitarian design sensibility to it. I have the navy blue version which looks great if you prefer a rugged and masculine look (product sample provided for review).

A fairly comprehensive volume that has a dual function as a wild game field guide and fairly ornate cook book of 165 recipes. Be forewarned though the recipes within lean heavily toward the French Continental variety and for the most part are intended to demonstrate the preparation and plating of wild game proteins at its most refined levels. As a Canadian publication, flavor and seasoning are very much in line with influences of the region and recipes reflect this with sauces of wild blueberry, apple cider, etc.Physically the soft-cover edition of the book has a nice look to it with thick, glossy paper and plenty of vivid, full color photography (photos accompany approximately 50% of the recipes). While the book is indeed a 2015 publication the entire volume has a quaint, unintentional retro vibe to it due to the layouts, baroque recipe preparation, photo styling, etc that are very reminiscent of the cookbooks my parents used in the 70s/80s. Overall though a very fine book that elevates the preparation of wild game to near rarefied status.

The neat thing about this headphone stand is that it still manages to look cool even when it's sitting empty without a pair of headphone resting on it. Constructed from thick and clear acrylic this stand maintains a sleek and slightly avant-garde look to it. Measuring at approximately 5.5 inches cross wise -  the stand is just at the right size to keep the phones gently extended without excessively stretching it out.  Weighing in at just over 1 pounds and with 4 rubberized nubs on the base the unit has very good stability and there's no fear of tip over should you happen to inadvertently bump it. Very stylish visual and usage design to keep your cans mounted properly makes this one a winner (product sample provided for review).

Goody's still remains my go-to product when recovering the next morning after a hard night of revelry and merriment. The concoction of Acetaminophen (325 mg), Asprin (500 mg) and caffeine (65 mgs) coupled with the fast action of powder vs. pills is like a jump start on my system. If  you've never tried powdered pain relievers you'll be surprised at how quickly the recovery effects kick in and for me at least, Goody's always delivers when I need it. This particular 'mixed fruit blast' flavor isn't so bad. There is a bit of that artificial sweetener flavor on the aftertaste but the pronounced berry taste does indeed make the dose go down more smoothly in comparison to their non flavored powder.

Overall a good, minimalist laptop attache case styled for those who appreciate low profile design without a lot of unnecessary pockets and attachments getting in the way. The interior of the bag contains 2 padded compartments - one for a laptop up to 15.6" in size (it securely holds my 13" MacBook Air just fine) and a 10" tablet computer pocket. Unfortunately because i use a thick, padded case on my iPad I was unable to fit it into said pocket unless I removed the case. On the front exterior are 2 smallish, diagonal zipped pockets that have enough space to tuck in a phone, wallet, keys, etc. On the back exterior you'll find a luggage strap that allows the bag to be secured to the handle of a rolling piece of luggage.The bag has good structure and even when left empty maintains its shape well. Looks wise this is a bag that doesn't really stand out. The compact profile is the most attractive element but on closer inspection little details reveal themselves including the nuanced styling of the heathered fabric and the small pop of color from the yellow Case Logic logo. Because the bag goes for a flat and slim profile you won't be able to slip an excessive amount of goods into it. If all you need to lug is a laptop, tablet, some documents, a book/mag and some personal accessories then you'll be perfectly fine with this one.

This is an eye gel product and serves as a primer for your skin before applying another product (eg - eye cream). The way this product works is after applying a small dab of gel to the desired area there is a noticeable skin tightening sensation followed by anti-inflammatory, puffiness reduction. The product works great around the eye area for those suffering the symptoms of a less than stellar night of sleep as well as those looking to tone down the appearance of wrinkling. What you're getting is .5 ounces of product in a small and compact pump dispensed bottle. 2 droplets is all I need to cover up most of the needed spots on my face. The gel is clear/milky in appearance and has no noticeable odor. The gel does not dry out my skin but a separate layer of moisturizer can be applied on top if needed or desired (product sample provided for review).

I've been doing the salad jar thing for almost 6 months now and this Aladdin faux Mason jar container is going to be my go to vessel going forward. First off I really like the styling - while all components are plastic (BPA free) the jar itself really looks like a glass product and I appreciate the embossed designs on the jar giving the whole thing a classic retro vibe. The vessel itself is nicely sized at 34 ounces which gives you a lot of leeway in really filling it up. The mouth is wide enough to plunge your fork into with no problems for those of us who like to eat straight out of the jar.  There is also a 4 ounce dressing container that screws onto the bottom of the jar lid and even this separate container is leak proof so that if your jar tips over in your bag the dressing will not release into the salad. The fact that all components are dishwasher safe makes cleanup a no muss, no fuss proposition. A very attractive and well thought out product for salad jar aficionados.

There is just a very slight learning curve to get up to speed with this food thermometer - somewhere around 5 minutes with the printed out instruction sheet in tow. Once you've acclimated yourself with the basics the device doesn't seem so difficult - there are 3 buttons on the front and 2 analog switches in the back and through that interface you'll be able to do a variety of things ranging from setup of quick temperature settings, countdown timers, switching from F/C, etc.The device is well designed for use in the home kitchen. The back has 2 strong magnets that will keep it affixed to metal or a flip out counter top stand to keep is positioned nearby. The thermometer probe utilizes stainless steel construction with steel mesh used on the cabling which makes it plenty durable when letting it sit in a pot of boiling liquid or very hot meat. The wire cabling can withstand oven temps up to 482F. Overall, readings happen fairly quickly and I ran some comparisons with a similar product that costs twice as much and was pleased to discover that the measurements were identical. Very pleased with the performance of this affordable product (product sample provided for review).

Good and very functional yoga mat bag. Initial impressions of styling is that it's a bit staid with the flat black coloring but on closer look and inspection there are some nice detail flourishes including stylish zipper pulls, small perforated vent holes on the larger outer pocket and just a smidgen of bright green with the Gaiam logo tag on the bottom base of the bag.The bag itself has 3 pockets - the main compartment easily accommodating each of my 3 mats (just slight variations in size/thickness) with no issues. On the exterior are 2 additional pockets one of which is sized for personal accessories (wallet, phone, keys, etc) and a larger pocket to hold your just used garments after a workout. Good utilitarian styling in a well designed bag for practitioners of yoga.

For a compact travel shaver this is a fairly robust device that is extremely easy to pack and carry along. The device uses 2x AA batteries and is rated at 30 shaves (3 minutes per shave) per set of full cells. If you're bringing this along for travel the usage of batteries is a good thing as it omits the need to bring a charging cord. The unit is rated for use in the shower and the entirety of the unit can be rinsed under running water. The device is very easy to clean with the heads and foil being able to pop on and off quickly.Quality of shave is decent but if you're new to this type of twin blade powered shaving it may take a week or two of regular use for your skin to get accustomed to this type of product. Even with moderate growth (around 3 days) shave action is very smooth. I have yet to experience any tugs or snags but keep in mind that I also apply a thin layer of shave gel while using this. The shave motor also feels fairly powerful for a device powered by 2 AA cells. Overall, very easy to travel with and decent shave results to boot - hard to leave this one at home.

This is a relatively straightforward product with a nice design and excellent functionality and expands my network options on my MacBook Air. The adapter is designed for ease of portability with its relatively flat design and ability to tuck the USB cable into the casing of the ethernet jack. The device supports up to USB 3.0 giving you some powerful connectivity if your system supports this latest protocol. A great little device that does exactly what it's supposed to  and a definite buy if your system lacks a working ethernet port.

This is a nifty little cooking penetrative meat thermometer with a pop out prong making it very easy to store in the drawer or in your pocket while cooking outdoors. All the basic functionality that you'd expect from such a product is here including a F/C toggle, auto shutoff and easy to read LCD display. This product also has the unique 'Fast Calc' feature which is basically an algorithmic method to determine the probable final heat reading before the thermometer actually measures it. Fear not though, this feature can be toggled to a normal read but in most cases I found the Fast Calc reading to be fairly on the nose from the actual. Good simple, easy to use functions and attractive, compact design makes this a great accessory for my home cooking needs (product sample provided for review).
ok
very very good
didn't watch VCR
very good enjoyable
Pretty good enjoyed

A strange young woman goes down to an eerie basement to retrieve ice cream.  She turns on the overhead light which sways menacingly back and forth.  Horror fans will obviously flash back to the famous similar scene from Hitchcock's PSYCHO, one of several nods to the acclaimed Sir Alfred.Korean auteur Park Chan Wook guides the viewer through an often visually impressive film but ultimately a hollow and pretentious film, emotionally void and disengaging.  Actor Wentworth Miller's manipulative script plants an obvious twist evident early on that falls flat by the reveal.Nicole Kidman virtually whispers her lines to the point of incoherence, giving her weakest performance since the disastrous INVASION.  Matthew Goode as the disarming Charlie basically offers a one-note vision of the sociopath.  Mia Wasilowski (sp) barely rises above the Amanda Seyfried/Kristin Stewart school of emotional vapidness.STOKER failed to involve me, nice to look at but nothing to digest.

I am sooooo sick of these horror movies that are nothing more than unimaginative videographies that have no budget, friends passing themselves off as actors and absolutely no sense of cinematic knowledge.  PRANK is one of the worst yet.  I gave up after 30 minutes...it just doesn't merit my waste of valued time.  PRANK stank!

Director Bryan Singer's visionary flair and state of the art CGI helps establish JACK THE GIANT SLAYER as this year's classiest fairy tale reboot.Unlike the souped up world of HANSEL AND GRETEL, JACK's landscape is vintage fairy tale with disgusting and frightening titans, nasty and traitorous humans and honorably noble heroes.  While Nicholas Hoult and Eleanor Tomlinson are appropriately squeaky clean as Jack and Isabelle, they are also quite dull...not so much their acting, but the script gives the best roles to the secondary performers:  Ewan McGregor doing a smart Deppish flair as heroic Elmont; Stanley Tucci's foppish turn as the diabolical Roderick; Ian McShane, Bill Nighy, John Kassir....all get scene stealing moments.  JTGS is about 10 minutes too long but overall, it's a rousing and enjoyable adventure.
There are no words to truly describe how awful EXPIRATION is.  Nor is there any justification for its existence.  Just avoid.

This nineteen track collection is cretainly a fine retrospective on the distinctive blue-eyed soul singers solo career and his days with the Doobie Brothers.  I've always enjoyed McDonald's smoky deliveries and I have spent many happy hours with favorites like WHAT A FOOL BELIEVES, I KEEP FORGETTIN, IT KEEPS YOU RUNNIN and REAL LOVE.  I tend to skip over some tracks like the urban remix of OPEN THE DOOR and the over-recorded AIN'T NO MOUNTAIN HIGH ENOUGH.  One glaring omission is Mike's stunning pairing with David Pack and James Ingram on I JUST CAN'T LET GO---truly one of his best!  The beautifu; I CAN LET GO NOW would have been a nice change of pace.ULTIMATE is a must have for McDonald fans.

It's really unfair to compare this movie to THE WIZARD OF OZ, a classic that is incomparable.  While obviously a prequel, Sam Raimi has fashioned what's really a tribute to the original.  On its own, OZ is a engagingly enjoyable fantasy, visually impressive with delightful humor and a great set of characters.  James Franco avoids the Depp/Downey approach and offers a less ostentatious Oz that I found refreshing.  Michelle Williams is a glowing Glenda, a sharp contrast to the wicked pair of Rachel Weisz and Mila Kunis, who are delightfully evil.  No one will ever outshine Margaret Hamilton but Kunis holds her own.OZ is big, blustery and overblown but I had a grand time!

Fairy tale mutations are becoming  standard fodder for moviemakers these days.  This high budget revision of Hansel and Gretel is a chaotic, gory, often anachronistic story of what happens after the titular heroes take care of their initial witch.H&GWH suffers from inadequate lighting, many scenes virtually indeiscernible.  One has to question the duo's success when they get their butts kicked quite often.Most of the CGI effects are done well and the character of Edward the troll is a fun touch.  Acting is secondary element to movies like this but Jeremy Renner and Gemma Arterton are effective heroes.H&GWH is a fun popcorn movie or maybe cotton candy?

BABY BLUES is a horror movie that is more frightening because the monster is all too real---post partum depression.  As Andrea Yates and Susan Smith have painfully reminded us, this depression is devastating and can turn an ordinary woman into a heartless killing machine.Colleen Porch is absolutely chilling as the young mother of four children whose truck driver husband wants to go for five, not cognizant of the fact his wife is crumbling before his eyes.  What transpires in BABY BLUES is disturbing and hard to watch.  Ridge Canipe is heartbreakingly stunning as Jimmy, the oldest son facing the woman who once was his mother.BABY BLUES is a brave movie but the film loses focus of the real issue and devolves into a crazy mommy stalker movie with a really disappointing ending.  However, one can't deny the visceral impact of BABY BLUES nor ignore the importance of recognizing PPD.

CRUSH explores the oft-used theme of a predatory female terrorizing the popular high school jock.  Methodically paced and apparently predictable, CRUSH pulls a whopper of a 180 and pulls the biggest I GOTCHA in modern horror cinema.The moment before this deception occurred, I told my wife "I wonder..." and kaboom, I was right.  That twist did demonstrate the writer's cleverness in working his audience and makes CRUSH a tidy little thriller.  Lucas Till brings a sense of honor to a usually clichÃ© role; Crystal Reed has a disturbing edginess as mousy Bess and Sarah Bol;ger displays both sexiness and naivete in her role of Till's true love.CRUSH manipulates the viewer quite shamelessly and sets a new standard for cinema stalkers.

In the beginning, Steven Soderbergh's alleged swan song SIDE EFFECTS is an expose of medical ethics and pharmaceutical abuse.  However, it mutates into a quirky murder mystery that employs lots of twists and deceptions.  Further plot nuances would involve spoilers that other reviews have  already done so, so I'll just discuss my feelings on the film's impact.I enjoyed the movie overall---it held my interest and the acting is competent if unremarkable.  I'm not a huge fan of Jude Law but he comes across convincingly.  Rooney Mara who came on so strong in GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO seems like an upper scale Katie Holmes.  Catherine Zeta Jones who always looks good is somewhat miscast as Mara's first shrink and Channing Tatum has little to do as the hapless murder victim.Soderbergh's penchant for sharp characterization is diminished by tepid pacing and unexpected predictability.  SIDE EFFECTS is an okay but unmemorable experience.

An interesting premise and a brooding atmosphere are the strengths of NAILBITER, a low budget indie horror flick.Set in the plains of Kansas during a devastating tornado, NAILBITER focuses on a young mother and her three daughters traveling to pick up their father returning from overseas deployment.  The family is caught in the tornado in little bitty Wellville and seek shelter in the storm cellar of a nearby house....not the best decision as they find themselves prisoners of something horrifying.Since the effects aren't quite convincing, the director wisely "suggests" their appearance so we never really see the creatures so that is somewhat a letdown.  Performances are efficient if average and the ending rather anti-climactic.  Still there is an inventiveness that makes NAILBITER a notch above the usual fare.

HOME SWEET HOME is one of those sleazy little thrillers that sets viewers up with a truly despicable villainess (well played by Raquel Cantu) that we can't wait to see get her just desserts.  Well....no spoilers allowed right?  So......Director John D.K. Graham pads the frail script with too many Southwestern vistas and painted sunsets offering a static unevenly paced movie that had promise but caves in mid-way with a disappointing flaccid resolution.Alexandra Boylan as tragic Gwen, Lorena York as her devoted BFF Naomi and Christopher Dempsey as pussy-whipped Van are adequate at best but it's Cantu's self-serving vixen that almost validates HOME SWEET HOME.

I've always loved those big bug movies from the 50s----Tarantula, Them. Deadly Mantis, Black Scopion---they were such cheesy fun.Today's big bug movies have CGI effects but lack the fun aspect of the earlier films.  Still SPIDERS harkens back to those glory days and as such is enjoyable.  Forget the frail plot; forgive Patrick Muldoon and Christa Campbell's acting and remember John Agar and Mara Corday.  SPIDERS is hardly classic but fans of big bug movies should find entertaining.

Writer/director Brett Kelly deserves kudos for bringing us the year's Best Awful Film.  From its laughable special effects to incredibly bad acting and terrible music, ATTACK OF THE JURASSIC SHARK is a prime example of cinematic ineptitude.  SEE the shark swim in six inches of water!  SEE sexy girls run in slow motion boobs bouncing up and down.  SEE the huge shark jump out of the lake to chomp on the bad girl!SEE a movie with more padding than a Maidenform bra!This is often hilarious but ultimately really bad.  If you like bad movies, look no further!

After effectively spooking us with INSIDIOUS, writer/director Scott Stewart turns on the chills with DARK SKIES.We meet a couple in financial upheaval.  Daniel (Josh Hamilton) has recently been laid off from his job; wife Lacey (Keri Russell) is a dangerously honest real estate broker whose sales are dwindling.  They have two sons:  13 year old Sam (Dakota Goya) is entering the porno/dope enticements and 6 year old Jessie (Kadan Rockett), a precocious lad with an active imagination.  A series of weird occurrences plunges this family into a nightmare which ultimately leads them to question their sanity.Fans of THE X-FILES and POLTERGEIST should enjoy this tidy little thriller.  The first half is a little slow but its second half picks up steam and has some tense, frightening segments.  Russell and Hamilton are quite good as the fragile but determined parents.  Goya and Rockett do well as the sons and the ubiquitous J.K. Simmons has a nice brief appearance as a tragic soul who tells the couple what's transpiring.The whole scenario of outside unknown forces deconstructing a family's existence is inherently chilling and DARK SKIES effectively brings this point home.

Read my reviews and themes emerge. One is genre labels suck.Know who else believes this: Sigh. Sigh may use black metal, or death metal as a departure point, but this is a thread on which to expand the music, not box the music into a corporate fast food. Here is a band who uses an orchestral clip and horns--or keyboards that sound like horns--on the roaring first track, "Diabolic Suicide"This is just for openers--classical motifs, jazz-funk  riffs, synth rock, Sigh have created a music where anything can happen at any time--and always does.Music not to be labeled. Art not to be misssed.

I know Luiz Eca from La Nueva Onda del Brazil, his 1970 collective group album, which mixed Latin music with  progressive, mult-part style. It has been described as "The white album Brazil '66 never made."Brazil '70 is entirely different. Softer, sweeter, it experiments well with soft-pop and Burt Bacharach type melodies. But the writing is top notch and gives the music a subtley complex, layered sound.Rich, elegant easy listening music

The New Wave were a folk duo with Reid King and Thom Adreola. They recorded one album in 1967. The album was a masterpiece of orchestrated folk, and featured Van Dyke Parks, as well as session men like Ron Carter and Hal Blaine.What works so well about this album is its subtlety.. These are not the up-front orchestrations of, say, Sgt. Pepper or Love's Forever Changes.  Producer Gene Page keeps the strings and reeds secondary to the wonderful acoustic guitar playing. There are plenty of  garnishes here--listen especially for the vibraphone--but they are kept in spots you really have to listen for. This forces you to listen deeply and adds a depth to the musical appreciation.The album comes twice on thiss CD, mixed in stereo and mono. I prefer the mono mix, as it is cleaner, allowing you to hear the layers in more detail. There are also several stripped down bonus tracks, which I wish were given the same treatment as the proper album.

There is pop, then art-pop. No better type of music can  better describe the later then this album.On Polmareff's, Michel Polnareff writes brilliant, original pop songs: condensed, full of hooks and unexpected changes throughout, He applies his own, amazing voice to this, along with huge amounts of strings and horns.So what? Well, his songs are so well-constructed and unpredictable, every note sounds fresh,  Huge, warm, engaging to the mind, this is art no one should miss

Excellent vocal music by Dave Pell singers, released in 1970.Mah-Na-Mah-Na features covers of popular music of the day. Tracks like the theme from "Oh! Calcutta." and "Put A Little Love In You're Heart."This music is not vocal jazz but is not strict easy listening either. There is a very mildly psychedelic strain that runs through this music, an almost trippy vibe that grabs you and keeps you captivated. The harmonies are airy and angelic and the well-played music is arranged extremely wellAbsolutely worth the price of admission.

The Holy Mackerel was Paul William's first band, and they put out this album in 1968.What is always fascinating about Williams--who wrote for the Carpenters and Three Dog Night among many others--is his unique sense of cadence. He lines up chords like no one else. Listen to "Bitter Honey," or "Scorpio Red.' for great examples of thisEvery track here has loving care placed upon it, as you can tell by thee plush but economic  arrangements. There is no fat or filler here. It woks as album art.There are several bonus tracks, including the 45 mono mix of "Bitter Honey."

If you can afford this, get it. Really nice early 1970's funk from Mary Jane Hooper.There is nothing revolutionary here, but the playing and singing on these stripped down grooves is infectious. Hooper was a teenager when this music was recorded, but she sings about love and passion and satisfaction provocitively, with a voice beyond her years. "i've Got What You Need" is prime exampleREISSUE THIS

Jackie and Roy were a jazz vocal duo who turned to jazzy pop in the late 1960's. Grass is one of the first albums to do this-hence the subtitle The Electric Jackie And Roy.The first half of this album--mine is vinyl-- is a little sleepy. Covers of tracks like the Bee Gee's "Holiday," and even "Fixing A Hole" by the Beatles taken at moderate to slow tempos. The arrangements are good, but could use some fire.Which side two provides. There is the dynamic "Wings Of Heaven," and "How Do I Feel:" full of driving rhythms and pulsating electric piano. "Deus Brasileiro" is jazz vocalese at its finest. Frankly, much of Grass sounds like the most adventurous moments of the early Carpenters ("All I can do,")  who would have been a much more interesting bamd had they continued in this direction.Track Grass down.

If you know Sonny Charles And The Checkmates at all, it is probably through their 1969 hit "Black Pearl", Phil Spector's last 1960's production. helps to be a musical digger,  or person of a certain age."Black Pearl" is a wonderfully piece of orchestrated pop-soul, and the rest of this album follows suite. There is a version of "Proud Mary," and a long medley from the musical Hair, so big in 1969.What is fascinating about this album is the bigness of the sound. We all know Phil Spector's hits, but it is amazing to hear such production on relatively unknown music. It makes the production style sound fresh. Sonny Charles has an amazing voice, and the playing is, of course, perfect.Get it.

This is a wonderful album by Luiz Eca, a Brazilian musician  who was in the band Tamba 3 and Tamba 4.La Nueva Onda del Brazil has songs that are bluesy, but contain many extra parts. The music is constantly running down fascinating side roads and detours. Completely coherent but totally unpredictable  If there is such a beast as progressive Latin  music,  Eca makes it.All of  which makes a fascinating ride--a ride to be taken several times. Your going to need a few listens to absorb Eca's complexities here,  He bates you with his twists and turns and keeps you in with tons of texture---booming drums, amazing backup vocals, strange percussion --keeping your ears alert to catch every sound.Brilliant. Get it.

If you listen to blues blasters like Count Basie or experimenters like Don Ellis, the big band arrangements of Gil Evans will take a lot of getting used to. Evans, more than any of his contemporaries,rejected flash and musical acrobatics in favor of deep, subtle arrangementsThe title of this album, "The Individualism Of Gil Evans" is no 1960's marketing device or generic label to sell jazz to the hip. To appreciate Evans, you really have to have high volume to meditate on this quiet music. Listening to him is closer to hearing Mozart than most big band jazz.Evans on this album starts at a low simmer and scarcely gets to a flame. He uses soft volume, and works subtle but complex arrangements that rest within these dynamics and  that you have to listen intently to hear. Check out the soft woodwinds on the title track, or the way the flutes flutter like butterflies on "Flute Song." Listen to the fuglehorn and piano on "Los Vegas Tango."The amazement with Evans comes long after the first listen, when you have over time absorbed the intricacies he threads into the musical weave. Evans may not be the best first listen, because the depth of the music is so deep in the music.But patience will always reveal rewards, and for an example, I would point to this album, which shows the mastery of The Individualism Of Gil Evans.

Allen Toussaint is one of those names you only know if you really know music, and know marginally. His name may be only in even an astute  music collectors subconscious.This is in no way an insult to this master: its only that you can collect albums for your whole life and not realize how many small print credits this man has on the backs of your album covers in the deep recesses of your shelving. Glenn Campbell, Devo, The Meters, LaBelle: chances are right  now I am within five feet of three or more albums Toussaint had a hand in and I don't even know it.His stature as a songwriter, one of the best has been established by other reviewers here, and a Google search will shed light on this musical force, a force in all music, not just that of the big easy.What might not be as easy to learn is why Allen Toussaint didn't record more, or that he doesn't have more well known recordings. This album from 1971 is a perfect example. He of course records some of his own music here, "Working In The Coal Mine," and does fantastic renditions of other people's songs, like "The Chokin' Kind."All this is done perfectly in a spare but full style, with piano from Dr. John, amazing horn work, and  equally amazing backing female vocals. This stuff sounds organic--live and without an ounce of studio fat--but still reveals layers in this clean mix of sound each listen.But for me the Money sound is Tousaint's voice. He is not a belter or crooner, but has the exact singing  gift that makes me love the equally brilliant Bill Withers: just like Withers, Toussaint sings with the intimacy of talking, inflecting his voice so economically to the notes that it feels like he is conversing with you directly. He makes great vocals feel so direct but so casual, which makes him all the more genius.\When you don't have a class A voice, understanding that limitation and turning it into an advantage makes you a class A singer. Toussaint's ability in this, and his  second to none writing and arranging skills make this album essential.Sometimes the best is right in your face and you don't see it.

As much as I love my acid rock and free jazz, I have a secret place in my heart for 1960's soft rock--if its well done. While people like Bobby Goldsboro and Gary Pucket were untouched by the decades experimentation, brought by the Beatles, even the most radio friendly bands added elements like classical instruments and jazz spices like vibraphones. The Critter's "Mr Dyingly Sad," is such a song.I was at first let down to find this was not on this compilation, which includes the two albums the band recorded for Enoch Light's Project Three label, also home to the magnificent Free Design.Awake A Dream does have its  share if straight 1960s soft pop, though even these tracks, recorded 1968-69, have more layering and textures than the mid-1960s tracks, such as "Mr Dyningly Sad.""I've been wanting to touch her since I can remember," is the line that open's the CD, with the track, "Touch and Go." A line you might not have heard in 1965 starts a 1968 track from the album, perhaps an indication of new freedom and risk.  The CD hits its stride with the jazzy polyphony of the multi-part "Cold Sunday Morning," you hear this is a band that had the potential to be more than a three minute singles band.As the 1969 material comes in, you start to hear more Hammond Organs, and, slightly heavier guitars, and  sounds associated with emerging FM rock, even sitars and jazz flute, showing this bands ability to push into progressive terrain. By the end of the Cd your hearings a transformed band, with large jazz interludes integrated into the vocal pop.Interesting here is what is not included, the amazing "Look At The Girls" by Giant Jelly Bean Copout, which was the Critters preforming under an alias and flying into Brazil '66 airspace.As is, this is really good pop that  dips its toe itself inter interesting spaces, near the end infesting those spaces with..........well, how many feet does a Critter have

In one sense, Bobby Conn's albums don't change much among them. I know because I have made it my job to get them all and listen intently, I have thousands of albums, so for an artist to drawn so much of my precious ear time is no small feet.Conn reminds me of the Beatles: not in the sound of the music, but in the approach to music. He sees all genres and styles as his to use as tools in a toolbox, and spins them all into endless permutations. For Conn, he works from 1970's art rock, pop and glam, and 1980's new wave, These are his muses as the Beatles worked from Elvis and Jerry Lee Lewis and English pub tunes and, later, classical music.The Homeland is one of the best of this artist, who can't seem to make even a so so album, never mind an unsatisfactory one. He works recurring lyric themes as well as musical ones: government control, shady characters, sexual duplicity.Conn's decisive advantage over his rock and roll fathers is that he has fifty years of musical lineage to work from, and is dead certain to take advantage of every second of it. A ska tune slices into a heavy guitar riff that is as heavy as Led Zeppelin's "Heart Breaker." Electric keyboard pulses that could be from a 1983 Human League album throb through more heavy rock, right before a piano piece that could be Elton John cira 1970.Most modern rockers have the slightest of clues, thinking rock started in 1991 when Nirvana released Nevermind. At least this is the impression given by the digital compression of the stale guitars. Its a McDonald's rock and roll happy meal with a little advisory sticker for the happy prize.Conn will have none of this: sure, the recording is digital, but is so juicy as he packs so many layers into this musicburger-prime rib well done, the modern technology actually adds to the depth.Is Conn a genius: maybe, maybe not, but he is the most brilliant of musical synergists, proving in a world of digital fast food produced in digital cookie cutters, it is still possible to lead, even if no one follows. So possible to do so much better.

One test I use for film scores is, does the score work as well on the stereo as it does on screen.In Ali's case, no. I love Ali. I love Ali's story. I even love watching Michael Mann directing Will Smith playing Ali, and if you are a fan of the champ, see the film.When I did, I heard the Aretha Franklin track, here included, a blues track, which is not included, and some modern R&B which I thought I could at least  enjoy if not love.Ali the soundtrack is dominated by this modern R&B--R Kelly for example; song after song of this material making references to "the greatest," and the "Champ." All by artists who probably weren't born during Ali's active years,  and sung in modern digital production, clean as a gauze bandage and as sterile.The 1960's R&B of the Franklin track is strangely out of place on the album, and the modern tracks seem strangely out of place for a film set from 1960-1975. I wonder how many artists singing here really understand the turmoil of the era and why Ali was so important to the times, because if they do,  it doesn't show in the musicI am not saying atmospheric music can't work in a film about this era--it does. And I am not denying my basis against modern R&B in favor of vintage blend. But Ali as film soundtrack gives you little sense of the Ali the film's milieu, and is more cheerleading for "The Greatest" then giving you a sense of the story that made him "The Greatest." I could turn on any modern FM R&B station to hear music like this, and given the choice between that and this soundtrack, I don't want to do either.

Whatever you have to do to get The Johnny Otis Show at Monterey, just do it. This is a fascinating set recorded at that city's jazz festival in 1970.The whole album captures the rollicking, spontaneous  nuance of Otis' stage show. There is son Shuggie-who soon after recorded the classic space cosmic blues Inspiration Information which you should package in the same order as this album-Big Joe Turner, Esther Phillips, Roy Milton, and a cast of class A blues men and blues women.Different musicians, as far as i can tell, come on stage during different parts of the show--a trombone in one part, a new singer, a vibraphone adding jazz elegance where you least expect--and add a party atmosphere to the tight playing core band here.The blues is great, but there is an intimacy to this album that is rare and that really bolts it into the classic ranks. You really get the feeling you are being introduced to Otis' friends at a party that has many guests, but only special people are invited to. It really feels like you are there, and you will forget this is FORTY TWO YEARS AGO, THAT is how immediate this is, and how much we feel that immediacy.Incidentally, if some tracks here sound vaguely familiar, it may be because Clint Eastwood used some footage of this performance in Play Misty For Me (1971). I knew there was something I liked about Clint's movies.

This is an album I got by mistake years ago thinking I was buying the Incredible Bongo Band album of the same name,But this is a really nice take on early 1960's rock using the bongos. Basically, this features the sound of the era--Ventures like guitar, some rockabilly, and some female wordless vocals, and runs bongos through it.The effect is like giving a hyperactive kid a lot of sugar. The bongos drive this already driven music faster. We don't hear a lot of bongos in music, so there is a novelty to this sound, but the music is good enough that it remains as enjoyable when the novelty wares off.Great party music.

The crazy aspect of Sun Ra is NOT that he claimed to be from another planet and based his whole creative persona on this claim. The crazy aspect is that listening to his music, we believe him.In the 1960's, as John Coltrane and Ornette Coleman debated whether to use a chord base for free improvisation, and Archie Shepp made free jazz as much about racial politics as about music, Ra used free jazz as complete freedom play. Horns, percussion, the latest in emerging electric keyboards, Ra took the whole ball of wax and created his own space-age musical playground: music was to him child-like discovery where anything could happen at any time and always did. Each album was a brilliant kid's arts and crafts project that sounded fresh each time and completely different from all his others. New born naked.Atlantis is Ra using an early 1960's keyboard that sounds like an electric harpsichord, backed by surprisingly simple percussion lines. Ra improvises, not showing massive technique--though I am sure he had it-but plunking down little figures on his new, jet set of ivories.I love the primitive sound of these early 1960's electronics, creating such a sense of slightly awkward, wonderful mystery. Ra has a new toy, and he is so good, we have as much fun listening to him trying to figure out its use as he does doing so.  Little spurts of notes that seem to work in their disjointedness. Serendipitous musical finger paint. Ra's simplicity here is artistic choice.A lot of reviewers here say this music is out, and on a relative basis, sure, it's out. But Ra's finger stokes here create a fresh, unrepeatable experience. One we should all have.

Choosing your favorite Keef Hartley Band album may only come down to the type of music you like. Do what I did and start with Time Is Near and you have the band pegged as a more genuine Blood Sweat And Tears, creating brilliant R&B horn rock for the era's progressive FM radio; long after BS&T had gone from being a Al Kooper's brass experiment to a classy hit singles machine for David Clayton Thomas.Halfbreed however, reminds us that like most great bands of his era, Hartley came out of the blues. Halfbreed is a blues album: heart felt and true to the form. Hartly works a live, spacious strain of the blue form, backed by organ, great guitar work, and a live, breathing sound--the genuine strain of the form that both British and American rockers were playing to kids in concert clubs and theaters-this is before concerts moved to arenas--in both Europe and America.The horns are here, but don't play as prominent a role as they did a few years later as Hartley moved into a more complex, soul geared direction. I am not going to tell you witch is better, as the forms are very connected and Hartley mastered both with equally impressive albums. Personally, I like the more ornate compositions that he choose as his career progressed, but that is subjective.Get ALL of this under-known artist's albums, and listen with equal love and intent, and weather you like pearls then diamonds or diamonds then pearls, you'll be happy to have every single Keef Hartley jewel.

A friend of mine made me a copy of this years ago, so I don't have access to artists or song titles. I can tell you that this is quality from end to end, sticking to basic, three minute single funk grooves.How Good is Good is comprised of tracks that are not particularly polished northern, OR gritty southern soul, opting instead for solid, accessible grooves that were probably made around 1970 or 1971. All local talent and all very good. Absolutely worth the price if looking for a extremely consistent and enjoyable  funk comp.

It's 1989. I am at NYU and taking a class on French New Wave filmJean Luc Godard is the first director I learn of, and 1960's Breathless, or A Bout De Souffle. is one of the first movies shown: a great crime thriller about a man-child thief who accidentally kills a policeman and shacks up with an American girl until he can escape to Italy.I not only loved the film but wanted the score, Martial Solal's masterstroke of hipster crime jazz filled with vibraphones and muted trumpets and bongo drums. Jazz based on the blues. All uniquely 1960Even in 1989 Manhattan, it was impossible to get such a score. This was about three or four years before the world got digitally wired, and it became easier to release and buy  obscure material.Well, twenty three years later I look on Amazon, and there it was: The A Bout De Soufflee score on Cd at a reasonable price. And it is everything I remember, bursting off the CD in crackling sound the way it must have sounded recorded in 1960 with a big band and an overhang mike, so very long ago.Like many soundtracks, this one is based around a few thematic lines: some vibraphone jazz lines, other blues, the synergy of the two, and softer romantic themes. All this is based on a big band s sound--lots of warm, passionate brass, with the vibes giving the music the 1960 bachelor pad jazz thread that runs through this scoreIt reminds me of what Ellington and Mingus was doing at the time, and gets an A+ for creating nuance of time, dramatic situation, and place--Paris, 1960.If this sounds even remotely in your town, forget up your ally, you gotta get this while you can

I got Silent Movie for a dollar and what a find. Quiet Village reminds me of a softer edged Zero 7.The band functions on a modernized blend of 1970s mellow instrumental California rock and soul vocals here. There are orchestrations here, extremely tasteful, at times reminding me Bacharach, other times  of Brian Wilson's one off 1960's and 1970s instrumental experiments.But these are given surprise turns, like a guitar break repeating the riff of a song in an diametrically opposed texture. Little surprise aural rabbit holes and hidden caved lurk all over Silent Movie, which manages to combine a dynamic sound you could probably not get in the world of analogue with a warmth you rarely find on modern digital.This is absolutely NOT old ideas given a modern, sterile sound, but a synergy of the best elements of both.MUST HAVE.

Adrian Young's Black Dynamite Soundtrack does not quite sound like any 1970's Blaxploitation soundtrack I have heard, and I have heard plenty.But that is a good thing. It'd be easy on this project to fall into exaggerated wha whas, over the top strings, and a bunch of Issac Hayes cleche's. That would make as much sense as growing an afro now to show you're hipness. A listener would just return to the vintage real deal.Young makes JUST the right move: write really good soul songs and produce them with organic production.  Don't be alarmed: you will get all your flutes and wha whas and best of all, great soul vocals on these tracks. He is not IMITATING the 1970's, but understanding the essence of the sound and using this to create mood.You won't quite get the long funk essays you would back in the days of Superfly And Shaft, but there are some extrmealey tasteful-if truncated by 1970's standards--funky workouts here.Why parady when you  can exude.  Young exudes, and the results are goovey far out and right on.'

Michael Legrand must have eaten a sack of sugar before making Brian's song for Bell Records, around 1972.This album is  the type of music you used to hear in TV adds and during technical difficulties in the '70's before cable TV.This is not to belittle the music! Legrand here works a very specific, program music style ubiquitous in those days: very vaguely jazzy, a lot of strings, female background vocals, and Burt Bacharach style trumpet.  Sort of a hipper form of elevator music: if you were born before 1970 you know exactly what I mean, and if you were born after 1975 you most likely have no idea what I mean.Legrand applies this style to tracks like "Windmill's Of Your Mind," the title track, and other popular songs of the era.Legrand had done many soundtracks, including the Steve McQueen, 1968 The Thomas Crown Affair and the brilliant Young Girls ?Of Roachport. Most of these were combination of Euro-pop and elegant jazz, so his right turn here is to me a curious move.Maybe Legrnd had an contract to fill. Maybe he wanted to be more mainstream. Maybe he genuinely felt like experimenting in this style. Who am I to question the motives of a genius, which I wholeheartedly brand Lagrand.And this album does have its up moments of elegance, and is likable as a period piece in the sweeter sections, But there are too many areas where Legrand is playing it safe, where a jazzier approach would have made good music great, and great music brilliant.Still, for its better moments and as a curio--music will NEVER be made this way again, I am glad i got Brian's song, though I'd rather here that of Michel.

If looking at the platform gumshoe of this 9th Creation album makes you guess it is a 1970's funk record, you guess right, funky listener.This came out in the mid 1970s, when funk was just starting to become slicker thanks to 16-track recording, better musicianship, and synthesizers replacing organs and electric pianos..Bubble Gum certainly has its share of mid-tempo ballads, shining with such polish, but when this album gets down, it does so with big helpings of funk jazz. (Think of how Earth Wind And Fire and mid- period Kool And The Gang incorporated jazz,  not how Jimmy Smith incorporated funk.) Super sonic jet guitar solos and, echoing voices and electric flutes are all over the place here. These guys were not playing jazz, but if they had wanted to, they sure had the chops.Really nice underknown funk album. Someone (oh mr SHADOW!!!) should reissue this.

A creeping bass line and a guitar with heavy effects and distortion probably goes back to Jimmy Page and John Paul Jones on "Dazed And Confused" from Led Zeppelin's first album; a psychedelic template many have used sinceHeavy As A Death In The Family by Les RallizesDenudes is not nearly as song oriented as Led Zeppelin: The entire disc is comprised of acid-ish improvisations built on the bass and six string.There are enough permutations here, and enough drama through the musical dynamics, to keep this from becoming a jam album. The tracks all sound similar, but this is the thread that runs through the album, not lack of imagination.Fans of neo--or for that matter heavy 1960's psych will want to get this. You can be a fan of Led Zeppelin or a fan of the late, great Broadcast and still like Heavy As A Death Of A Family, and that wide net is one appeal of this adventurous band

The other reviewers have done an amazing job here of summarizing Cadillac Records, the story of the Chess Record Label in the 1950's.If you want to understand the blues, race and the dirty economics of the music business during the era, this film is the perfect place to start. You'll see great drama, and learn much about Chicago blues, the prototype for rock and roll that far too few modern  listeners understand.See it!

I knew J.J. Johnson through his work with Miles Davis and some of his work on ABC Impulse! such as Proof Positive.I never knew he was capable of composing great, 100% bona-fied soul, such as music on the Willie Dynamite soundtrack"Keep On Keeping On," included here, is sung by Martha Reeves, and could compete for the top of the early 1970's charts by any top flight single from Gladys Knight or Aretha Franklin. This soundtrack contains several such numbers.But Johnson's score also includes several Class A jazz interludes, featuring Fender Rhodes piano. and all the trimmings you'd expect from a Blaxploitation sound of the era.'All this talk about Blaxploitation is suspect when it comes to music. The genre title is for film. Willie Dynamite sounds nothing like Superfly or Shaft, but contains music equally fulfilling. Any track here works perfectly on its own, and helps create a classic album by Johnson, film score or not.

I wouldn't know a Jerry Goldsmith film score virgin to my ears like I would that of Quincy Jones or Henry Mancinoi. That is to Goldsmiths credit. He, unlike his many peers, didn't have a trademark style, but could write any music to fit any film.Patch Of Blue is a film from 1965, about an African American man (Sidney Potier) who befriends a young girl who is blind (Liz Heartman). Peoples treatment of race and disability are the themes: make Patch Of Blue today and you'd make a different film.Luckily this is a 1965 film, made when film scores worked as albums. Goldsmith choose tender, gossamer melody lines, based on spare uses of strings and piano, jazz flute, and pinches of vibraphone.What works so well about Goldsmiths score is the melodies he uses are simple but extremely distinct, cut like the best jewels, crystal clear.This score does not date a bit, its compositions and arrangements being so tasteful. Tender but never trite, poignant but never mushy.  You gotta hear this

It must have been hard for a vibes player like Gary Burton in 1969. Bobby Hutcherson was doing moving into uncharted free jazz territory, and Roy Ayers was moving funky prime form--his mallets leaving vapor trails.Where did that leave a player like Burton, as talented as his vibe contemporaries but making more conventional, but just as legitimate music.I am really not sure, but I hope he sold a lot of records, because one listen to Throb finds he absolutely deserved to. He here has the fire power of bassist Steve Swallow and guitarist Jerry HahnAmazing raw material, raw material Burton uses however he pleases: a psychedelic opener that could be Pink Floyd with vibes, a violin experiment that could work on Frank Zappa's Hot Rats, blues and trippy ballads.Basically, many experiments taking place in rock are visited on this album. These are jazz guys with jazz chops, but make a "jazz album" as of wonderfully unhinged experimentation the way most rock bands of the era were.Burton here does not show the flash of Ayers of the harmonic adventure of Hutch, but that is only because that is not the path Throb rides. Burton is more interested with--I guess literally--chiming  in and decorating his jazz rock psych stew at just the right point. You would probably not know listening he is the leader, and that is to his credit. His ensemble approach here shows incredible restraint and taste. The vibes being such an underused instrument, hearing them inserted in the sweet spot--our musical erogenous zone, our ears G-spot, has amazing impact.But one thing. Admit it. That is an a--- on the cover!

This is, unfortunately, the only album I own by Glitterhouse, its silver textured corer looking at me right now.Imagine Felix Cavalerie of the Rascals singing an octave lower, fronting a more soulful version of The Association. The Glitterhouse are not really blue-eyed soul, but the baroque organ in this music, the un-candied structures of this pop music, makes it more of an 1960's FM specimen. Yet the band does have fantastic harmonies, and puts their emphasis on uplifting melody,If you never heard this band, who got lost in that huge 60's music shuffle, they are worth the purchase. This band also did the title song from Jane Fonda's 1968 film Barbarella, and appear extensively on the film's soundtrack.

I only have the West Side Story album on vinyl, so I'll review only that.When music is big,, everyone wants to play and profit from it, and in 1961, West Side Story was the big film, winning picture of the year. There were countless artists covering its songs, including Stan Kenton, on West Side Story.Cal Tjader's take of this music is compelling. He covers the tracks, and adds little bridges and interludes that were not part of Leonard Bernstein's film or stage score. There are orchestrations, but these work as flourishes--especially the string swoops, which you should keep an ear out for.Tjader's vibes ring throughout the music, but are never flashy, adding just the right chimes at just the right moment (it takes a long time for a Bobby Hutcherson/Roy Ayers fan like me to adapt to Tjaders minimalist style.) This is not free jazz or funk, so Tjader does not have the open space for big solos. Less is more with Cal: when he plays those little phrases, it really rings in the ear.

As a guy three and a half years sober, this is the only bottle of wine I'll be having.And that is just great by me. The title track here is the only one known by this band, and from its sound, you would think the band were a rollicking garage combo. They are for that wonderful song (where the narrator asks the question all alcoholics do,"when am I gonna get sober," as if asking makes it so. ")But a lot of these tracks are ballads, some even a little sappy by today' standards, but far more tasteful than you would hear on a Garry Pucket album.Basically, these guys were a middle-of-the-road rock band, with quality material, but with nothing as outstanding as the title track.But now, i can finally call my friends and say I bought a bottle of wine, and I get to keep my sobriety. Who says you can't have your wine and not drink it, too.Or get two for one. This album has been issued on Cd with The Fireballs / Vaquero

Jimmy Smith's 1950's and 1960s albums are walks in the park; walks you should take.Most of the dozens of albums he recorded for Blue Note in this period are easy going blues. Smith used bands that never pushed the tempo of his music, but strolled leisurely through Smith's happy, roll with the tune take on the blues. There was not a lot of variation in the combo structure; sometimes Grant Green would show up on guitar, other times, like here, not.  It was Jimmy's lightening soloing--fast as a '61 Ferrari--that made this music come alive.On Prayer Meetin, he  works again with the great soul jazz sax player Stanley Turrentine. The two never cook, but volley back and fourth, phrasing with each other. It is like two old friends with charismatic voices shooting the breeze, and you could just listen the entire dayNot that Smith did not experiment: get his big band albums like Cat: The Incredible Jimmy Smith (Dig) with Lalo Shiffrin and Bashin with Oliver Nelson. And DO NOT MISS!!!!! 1972's Root Down, the hard funk album which surprised 'em all, when jovial Jimmy proved he could spit fire and chew nails with the most bad--s of any music mother out there.

If you know Terry Callier's work, you're part of a privileged all too few. His two early 1970's albums, Occasional Rain and What Color Is Love were soul-folk masterpieces; layered orchestral landmarks with Callier's amazingly warm, evocative husky voice. If Cat Steven's were black. he would have sounded like Callier, and been a much better singer than he already was,Callier, inexplicably,  never really caught on in his era, but DJ's collected his albums, and the critic's canned phrase of "small but rabid following" was really the truth in Callier's case. He ended up working with artists like Massive Attack and Beth Orton--people who collected all the right records and then hit the big timeIn between the two eras he made this album, Fire And Ice in the later '70s. As disco and soul were taking over radio, Callier's idiosyncratic soul folk must have seemed out of date. He thus made this album with female singers, using more conventional soul. Much of this is very good, as Callier continued to layer his music, dealing with spiritual themes. (Listen to the track here about Martin Luther King.)Callier's voice here is as earnest as ever, and had I not heard is early work, I would probably give this album a higher rating. Callier moved musically, to a place that worked for him on Fire And Ice, and if you are ready for a thoughtful soul album by a talented vocalist, this is just the prescription.Just don't go here expected the novelty of his early work, and don't neglect his two aforementioned masterpieces if you happen to start with Fire And Ice

I wonder how much pre-rock and roll music Paul McCartney listened to in his mums polar as a little kid, radio tuned to the beeb. Certainly before Buddy Holly and Elvis were known in the colonies, never mind England, this was the pop music people listened to.You could even tell in the 1960's. Even when the fabs were going all Helter Skelter with long hair and LSD and politics and Apples, Paul was writing songs like "Honey Pie" and "When I'm Sixty Four." Dancehall ditties that had nothing to do with rock--UNTIL THE BEATLES MADE IT SO! AND SO IT HAS BEEN SINCE.  The Walrus was also listening to Stockhausen and Biero at the same time, and if this does not prove how all-encompassing the fabs were, nothing does. You can even hear the Beatles on demo tapes of Sgt. Pepper, jamming old little pre-rock tunes between takes of rock revolution. All music was at their command.So does it surprise me that McCartney has recorded this album. No. Only that it took him so long. He probably had this in his head his whole life, working with the Beatles, Wings, Firemen. or just fooling with a ukalalie on the Beatles Anthology tapes. It is all music to be owned by the master.Kisses From The Bottom has Paul working with Tommy Lapuma, who was a staff producer way back in the 1960s at A&M, working with, for instance, the Sandpipers, and later, Barbra Streisand and Diane Kroll. He and McCartney here take standards  like "It's Only A Paper Moon," and "My Valentine," and treat them with bass, brushed drums, and piano. You can walk down Bleaker St. in New York and hear standards getting the same treatment. They even do "The Story Of Love,"--that pop from way back in '67 when Paul and John and George Martin were trying to find that 80,000 kilocycle highnote to end the "A Day In The Life." .He probably heard the song at a friend's flat between Hendrix and John Cage and loved itMcCartney and Lapuma are smart to give this track, and all the others, the stripped down treatment that they do on Kisses from The Bottom. Paul was always asking George Martin to give him clean sounds, and the result was making all music rock, and rock able to hold all other music. His voice here is outstanding, as Paul stays in that wonderful low register he does so well, singing to the classy instrumentation with the intimacy of a lover's speech, His voice here is totally unaffected. Why would the master need to do anything else.This is no black bow tie and tails affair. No digital ticket crossover coffee house puddle.  This is a man who can make any music he wants making the kind of music he wants.I am sure right now, Paul is planning a rock album, more electronic projects--maybe getting his fire hat ready-and has fingers in a million more of Admiral Halsey's butter pies. But for now, there is this, and if you are surprised by Kisses At The Bottom, think of Paul's history more, and you won't be. You'll love it, yeah, yeah, yeah, YEAHHHHHHHH!

I don't know if you would call this music jazz rock, and that really doesn't matter, except to give you an eyelash hint of what this album sounds like. Chuck Mangione sure did not sound like Miles Davis or Mahavishnu Orchestra, contemporaries of this trumpet player in the 1970s.But this music does bare some rock influence: listen the the samba beats and the drive of the bass, which cover the title track of this album. It is not rock, but is informed by the tone colors of popular music which flowed into jazz during this era.Mangione, though, casts a wider net: using a big band, and a large vocal section that at times sound like a church choir. At times you feel you are listening to sacred music, at other times an augmented Blood Sweat And Tears. You never get the experimental edge of Don Ellis or Frank Zappa. But Mangione can't be faulted for this, as it is not what he aims for.His music is nakedly accessible, invoking its era, where jazz and funk and vocal and horn driven forms were merging into endless permutations, if lines ever really existed at all. If so, they never mattered, as they never do.I'll bet money that this stuff gets more respect today than in its era, where lines were drawn between hip and straight. Deservedly so. Horn funk, so present on AM radio and TV adds then has, a lot more artistic credibility now, issued on countless compilations. There are no more long-hairs, no more squares, and serious music people devour and dissect every sound they can get their lasers, or even needles on.Doing so, they will have plenty to put under the microscope here: and in today's digitized focus-grouped musical toilet bowl. what was square then sounds fresh as a daisy, now.

Many headphone kids of the 1970;s and 80's listened to the best music of the 60's and 70's, when rock was redefined from dance music to a comprehensive form that could incorporate any other musical form.Bobby Conn is one of the most ambitious of these, and that is evidenced on Llovessongs. "Free Love" is track one, starting as soul, breaking into a ska-like jam,, and finishing in gospel rave up. All in three minutes. It sails as well as the best pop, but achieves its huge ambition as well as the best art rock. If this sounds messy on paper, it winds air tight in stereo.Because Conn  does not come to the music: he doesn't have to--he owns it. Just like a sculptor owns his clay and can make you an ashtray or a Statue Of Liberty. Take his cover here of Nilson's "Without You," a  hit we all know, but Conn sings it to a frightening keyboard chime, so spare it could work as the band NEU! or Brian Eno playing classic rock, with  Iggy Pop conducting.He has assimilated his influences so much, he can exude them like sweat of a rock idol, center stage, morphng them into endless permutationsExperimental?--Hardly! This is alchemy, and nobody rattles those test tubes like Bobby Conn.

If Quincy Jones spent the 1960s making dozens of great soundtracks, In the Heat of the Night, just to get your foot in the door, the master spent the early 1970s on on A&M, making albums for Creed Taylor. These took popular songs of their era and made them into great jazz funk.You've Got It Bad Girl is one, and is named for the Stevie Wonder song. Jones cover's it here as an instrumental, and it is a gem of shimmering keyboards. He does the same with a rework of his theme for "They Call Me Mr. Tibbs," and the album also features a full version "Streetbeater," which is better known as the theme for Sanford And Son.What makes Jones' work so brilliant is simply using the best musicians: Ray Brown, George Duke, Chuck Rainey, and Valery Simpson are here. Joens conceptions are brilliant, but when fleshed out by such upper-flight players, they come to their optimum funky light.And if this was not enough: I am always looking for music I here as unlisted samples, and one is a keyboard riff from DJ Shadow/Cut Chemists' The Hard Sell. When You've Got It Bad Girl showed today in my mailbox, I played its first track, a cover of "Summer In The City," to discover this was the sample. Who says you can't have two for the price of one.

Money Mark's Keyboard Repair reminds me of early 1970's experiments like Sly Stone's There's a Riot Goin on or Timmy Thomas' Why Can't We Live Together. These two artists used the organ's rhythm box as a backing track in their pre-digital work.This album won't be mistaken for a 1970's keyboard slice; you'll here a digital sheen identifying the music as modern. But these are delicious miniatures, simple little organ confections with melodic lines. Understated yet full. Like sketches from a master painter's notebook.

I reviewed this once in '08 but I guess as vinyl gets sold, the page and the reviews on it go.This is from a 1969 film with Sidney Portier and his wife--in real life--Joanne Shimkus. Portier plays a black militant who robs to fund the cause--very adherent to current events of the era.Quincy Jones composed this, and it may be his last great 1960's soundtrack. Huge orchestrations, vibraphones and frightening, creeping and then climaxing dynamics mark this truly stirring music. If you know Jones' scores of the period, several elements recur: the use of electric flutes, fuzz bass, and amazing use tone color. Ray Brown and Rassan Rolland Kirk were among many musicians Quincy uses on his scores--why the African-American forms sound so genuine.All the jazz, blues, gospel that influenced Jones is here, as are two tracks that should have been soul hit singles, "Sweet Soul Sister" sung by Nate Turner, and "Try Try Try" by Venetta Fields.I wonder who they were/I also think i spy Chuck Rainy on bass here. No musicians are credited but i would not be surprised

I got to know Johnny Winter in the 1980's, through his Alligator albums like Guitar Slinger and his late Muddy Waters productions likeHard Again. It was not until much later that I found out he had done a more rockified blues in the 1970's, when people cared less about genres and a wide range of genres could reach the same audience.Saints and Sinners is one of those 1970's album. It has more than its share of blues, even if that blues is in the subtext, sporting more than I IV V changes. The production is geared more towards 1970a rock, polished, some tracks even featuring  Memphis style backing  vocals.Thus I got to know Johnny Winter, the rock star, which only raises my already lofty opinion of him. As usual, his guitar work is amazing, and if I had not heard the 1980's albums first, I would still rate Winter one of the giants of post-Cream, post-Mayall, post-1960's blues.

Here is a fun game: go to the wall which houses your large collection, pull an album,  shut your eyes and play it without looking.This is what I did with Silver Convention: like you, probably, I knew "Fly Robin Fly," and scant else. So I really did not know what this was when I hit random on the CD player, and heard the popping funk and wonderful harmonies of this group.What struck me most is how this throws back to the vocal groups of the 1940's and 1950's. Silver convention is, of course, through and through 1970's disco. But I love the idea of vocalizing without a lead: the harmonies become another instrument. Here, among the popping bass and lush--but tasteful-orchestrations--these wonderful, unified harmonies really do the job.

Perhaps most interesting about this Gladys Knight album is Curtis Mayfield's production. Knight had recorded for Motown, a little after the heyday of that labels sound.Orchestrations are used in much of her music, but here, you can really hear Mayfield's elegant soul stamp. Listen to the thicker, slower use of the strings, and the emphasized wha wha guitar. This is trademark for late Impressions and early solo Mayfield. His approach works well, as Knight's voice has a muscular sound, which cradles perfectly with Curtis' elegant arrangementsTwo great talents can neutralize each other, but that is never the case on this royal album..........Folks, i have a heckler as of late, commenting on all my reviews. so here is preemption: yes Dylan, i know.....i know

If you are here, you most likely know Barrabas had a hit with "Hijack" in the mid-1970's, which jazz flute player Herbie Nann covered.What is really stunning about this track is that it mines the groove with a great rhythm section and backing vocal singers, but does not rely a lot on heavy orchestration the way a lot of disco did. You get a more visceral feel for what is going on in the music--the rasping hi-hat and driving bell clicks that ornament these tracks.The album--"Hijack" is here--pretty much sticks at the same tempo and grooves, all of which cook. You can really dance to this stuff, but don't forget to listen to the subtleties going on amist the non-stop mirror ball partyNow, lades and gentlemen, i hate to mix business with pain, but i have a heckler who is commenting on all my reviews, saying it sounds like a "retard" wrote them. so until i shake this lout.......yes DYLAN. we know. We all know

I fished this out of the jazz section, thinking it was a jazz album. I am slways telling people the uselessness of genre labels, and In The Light reminds me to practice what I preach.And reminds me in the best way: This is orchestral music, full or horns, murky, ambiguous textures, and of course, Keith Jarret's piano, though not in the quantity you may think.Which is just fine, because it is the master pianist who choose this direction, which is perfectly done. This music reminds me of the work of film composer Jerry Fielding, who scored movies such as the 1971 Straw Dogs. Jarret's music is hear is not nearly as dark as Fielding's, but the fluidity of the tone color, the way the instruments seem to meld like wet paint on canvas, is a quality i love, and one In The Light shares with Fielding.Get it and listen repeatedly. It grows on you in its many colors.

Melba Moore was in the cast of the musical Hair in the late 1960's/ Since that was such good music--I think she sang "Black Boys,"- it makes sense she would cover them on her own record."Easy To Be Hard," and "Aquarius/Let The Sun Shine" are here, as well as Laura Nyro's "Time and Love," and "People," the Barbara Streisand hit.Some tracks here have a slightly easy listening vibe: not my taste, but its subjective. Moore's voice is so good, so piercing and strong, it works in any arrangement. Listen to the invention on Bobby Hebb's "Sonny," which breaks from a mid-tempo arrangement to a shuffle with the riff of "Sunshine Of Your Love" inserted.It works, as does this whole album, whether it is my style of choice or not. If you can get this cheap on vinyl, grab and burn to CD.

If The Esquires remind you of Curtis' Mayfield's Impressions, that is no mistake. The smooth grooves of 1960's Northern Soul were in stark contrast to the stripped grits of Stax in the south.The Esquires don't have the socio-political content of Mayfield's group, but the lead singers falsetto-as with those of the backing singers--more than hold their own with master Curtis and his Impressions. If you have heard the cheerful soul bounce of the hit, "Get On Up," you will know what The Esquires bring to your soul table--melodic soul with a enough drive to compete with the best grooves, yet enough melody to rank with the best pop.I have heard the full album, and although the band sticks to a basic sound, each track here is as fantastic as the last--you can savor the entire album, which sounds fresh as a 1967  spring outside day with the transistor radio pumping out the best of the hits, and always will.

If you picture lapping waves in the middle of the ocean in the middle of the night,with small shifts in the light they reflect, this is what this album sounds like.Nurse With Wound are a band I always admire for tearing at the false distinction between sound and music. But relatively, this falls on the music end: the group and Jim O'Rouke create an oscillating, repetitive, thick bed of keyboards, and then insert a constant percussion pattern into it.But this is no minimalist exercise, as the music changes subtly as you hear, and is sneakily fluid throughout. Angry Electric Finger ill grow on you if you don't respond to it right away, but I doubt even that will be a problem

DISCO SUCKS! This was the 70's mantra that marked a culture divided by punk and disco, rock and soul, and, unfortunately, black and white. But there are some deep into music, neck deep: if you said "disco sucks," and listened to Hendrix, Jimi's wha wha led you to Funkidelic, and Funkidelic to Cloud Nine, 1969 Temptations, and soon, your shooting off into all areas musical, led by sound, not label or clique.Eventually, you'll land on an album like Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band, and discover they were the band that did that hit "Cherchez Le Femme," you heard in the station wagon, way back in '76. But informed by jazz, wha wha rock, Latin jazz, a million digs in the music clay, you'll realize how plugged in this music is to everything you've come to love. The soul of Dr. Buzzards music, the funkiness of Dr Buzzard's music, the Latin flavors that run throughout this elegant, royal purple music.Thousands of albums and thousands light years from those blacklit nights, listening to those fifty or so classic rock albums in your room. Whatever the albums were, wherever you're coming from, its time to put this piece into the whole, connected music piece. It's time for Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band.

We have a lot of hardwood floors in our summer cottage and our winter home and we have had our floors refinished in both places during that last two years.  The refinishers told us that "When the floor is scratched you will notice it immediately because the rest of the floor looks so good."  Boy were they correct.  I received this product for an honest review, tried it out on the wood block and then went to town on our floors.  We don't have a lot of scratches, but we had a couple of significant ones.  This product performed just like the WearMax company said it would.I also received a block of wood with three scratches on it. (Other reviewers report receiving a similar block of wood) I used some Old English Scratch Remover on the middle scratch and WearMax on the ends ones.  Initially the middle scratch looked great, but after 4 hours of light, the scratch treated with Old English was white again (but not as pronounced as originally) but the two outside scratches were almost gone.To be honest, I placed the piece of wood on the floor with regular ceiling light on it.  I didn't scrutinize it up close say 6-12 inches away.  My only con on this product is that the instructions on the bottle are VERY hard to read.  But we are reviewing the product, not the instructions.

The Titanic was large beyond belief.  After visiting the Titanic museum in Belfast, Ireland I wanted something for my grandkids so I bought this book.  The wonderful illustrations really present the various levels and classes of rooms that were on the original ship for a child's eye.  Speaking of museums, the Belfast Titanic museum is absolutely the best one I have ever visited - bar none!  This book would be a wonderful opener for a family to read and study if they were going to visit the actual museum.Highly recommend this book.

I loved the first 6 seasons of Doc Martin, but in my opinion, Season 7 is the best.  It's humorous, touching, serious and "the Doc" is so painfully human.  You will find yourself rooting for his marriage and his relationship with Louisa, his son, and his aunt. We are treated to some great appearances of "Buddy" the wonder dog.  It's been interesting to watch this show evolve into a really fantastic series.Am holding my breath for the last episode..............!  Just viewed the last episode and it was "so Portwenn!"  Fair well to a wonderful series, unless .......!Way to go, Martin!  Highly recommend.

Worked out well for our summer cottage.  My husband had fun this past summer experimenting with various foods for appetizers and unusual but tasty entrees.  Our nephew is also a smoker and when he stayed with us, great recipes were swapped.  One of my favorites was small meat appetizers wrapped in bacon and then smoked.  Wow!  Quite a hit.  I wasn't so fond of the meat loaf in a bacon wrap - but I like my meat loaf done in the oven.The unit is sleek and trim and looked good on the back porch (where a lot of people see it).  The first unit came with a dint in the side and the return of that unit and getting a replacement was smooth sailing.  Great customer servicing by Amazon.Caution - it's easy to get carried away with smoking and "oversmoke" or dry out the food.  Better to err on the side of undersmoking and finish up in the oven.

Really about a 4.5 on this one.  Love to exercise and listen to a Grisham book.  Makes my time walking in the water go quicker.  This is quite a different Grisham, more like short stories about different cases.  Other reviewers can fill you in on the storyline, but the audio book is great!  The reader was not only easy to understand, but changed his voice for different characters which made the audio book version even better.Probably not Grisham's best, but he was still to listen to.  Enjoyed it!

Love Liane Moriarty!  I thought it was a little hard to "get into" the book but part of that may have been we were transitioning in a return from our summer cottage.  Once I could settle into the story, it was truly enoyable and very thought provoking.  Alice's amnesia gave her a whole new slant on her life as it had developed.  Wouldn't it be nice if we could all take a refreshing step back and look at our present situations with a new attitude.Liane comes up with some very creative story lines and this one certainly doesn't disappoint.Highly recommend!

This spatula is 2 months old and I really wanted to love this item, but................it was in the drawer under our cooktop and when my husband closed the drawer yesterday, the spatula part came off the handle.  The spatula part was thin (which was a plus) and the holes allowed any grease or butter to drip from the cooked/fried item when you took it from the pan.  I checked the handle and found that the spatula had been  spot welded to the handle in two very small places - I mean dots.  So the pressure of the closing drawer simply snapped the welding.  Will try and get this re-welded locally but geesh......
