UPDATE: I sent this back for a refund.  The stink was just too much!  I replaced it with a LowPro, Format 120(That does NOT stink)I bought this bag for my EOS M with the EFS to EFM adapter, and Canon 10-18mm mounted.  It is a good bag, and has just enough room for the eos with the lens and adapter mounted, and room to put the 22mm pancake lens in the front.The bag seems well made, but the gripe I have with it, is that it has that "New Chinese Plastic" smell.This might seem like something silly to get hung up on, but I already own several bags for all my various equipment from both tamrac, and lowpro, and not a single one of them has that smell.  This smell I am taking about is very strong, and you can definitely notice it.  It will really clog up your nose.It also has an oily feel that gets on your hands.  Not something I want when I am changing camera lenses...Still not a big deal?Well the big deal to me is I bought this more expensive bag over a 20 dollar "Case Logic" bag that I liked, but had that smell, Thinking  the Tamrac is probably still made in China, but yet has better quality control, I ordered this." Chinese plastic smell" is a real thing.  Don''t believe me?  Type it into Google.  You will find lots of info on it.  You usually find it only in cheaper products direct from Chinese companies.Too bad, because otherwise, it is a nice bag...This is a little tongue in cheek, but I really wish we would go back to the American way of having our goods manufactured in Mexico....

Believe it or not, I don't seem to get that much run time with this on the Hero 4, over my Hero 3+ Black WITHOUT a battery pack.Record time on the HERO 4 Black is horrible!  I find when I travel that my GoPro 4, even with the battery bacpac, is problematic.  I am constantly having to charge it any chance I get, were as the other cameras I am carrying, Canon EOS M, 300HS ELPH, Canon 5D, and Hero 3 + Black are fine.In the field, I had to put a charge of at least an hour on  the Hero 4 battery with the bacpac, 3 or 4 times, were as my other cameras were fine to last the whole trip.We could debate that the cameras weren't used in the same way, but I can tell you from experience, the the bacpac, and battery don't last long on the Hero 4 Black.I was recording at 2.7K, and 60FPS if anyone wants those details.

Great bag for carrying around the EOS M with the pancake lens, which is what I use it for.This bag would easily fit a nice size point and shoot, but don't expect to fit our mirrorless camera in there, with anything but a slim prime lens.It is made very well for the price.  I have no gripes about it.

This allows you to make use of your other canon EF and EFS lenses, as well as a new lens like the EFS 10-18mm, which I find excellent for the EOS M, although it destroys the small form factor of the camera...This is available now for a  FRACTION of the previous cost, so you might want to pick one up her on Amazon.The efs 10-18 is about half the cost of the EFM 11-22mm, and you can't use the 10-18 without this piece of hardware...It came in a simple white box.  Not what I am used to, but looks, and works like genuine Canon.

I needed a wide angle lens for the eos m.  I have the 22mm Prime, but that doesn't cut it in some situations.I find that this lens works well with the EOS and the EF to M adapter.  So far the lens has sharp focus, and believe it or not, it seems better than the 22mm EFM that was made for the EOS m in focusing speed, and accuracy.The Good :The lens is sharp, accurate, focus is quick, and silent.  The Image stabilization works very well. I can't tell you how many stops, because I have never needed to use IS for still photos.  I use the IS for video, and it seems to help keep down vibrations, and jarring.The Bad:No focus number window!  One reason I wanted this was for long shutter night time shots of the stars....Summary:For the price, this lens is a great addition to our EOS M, along with the adapter.  It is MUCH cheaper than the 11-22 EFM that is made for the EOS M camera.  I am very satisfied with my purchase.  It slightly defeats the purpose of why I bought the EOS M in the first place, but it isn't that much more to lug along. I plan to use this lens just for the EOS M, as my other camera has a full frame sensor.Other lenses and cameras in my kit:  70-200 F4L, 17-40 F4L, 35mm Prime, 50mm Prime. Canon 5D, Canon 20D, 300HS, Hero 3 + Black, Hero 4 BlackI could talk about vignetting, and barrel distortion, and edge to edge sharpness, but the only one I have ever really cared about is Chromatic Aberration which is VERY well controlled on this lens.  The lens is also very sharp.You can easily fix vignetting, and a lot of the times, you crop out barrel distortion, so that isn't a big deal to me.P.S, I am not going to try and act like I am some sort of nuts and bolts photography expert, but I do know a little about photography. If you care to, check out some of my work below to decide how much weight to give my review...http://www.pbase.com/markcas

I was asked to review this book.I find this story to be a very unique, original, and enjoyable read, with some minor flaws.The flaws:There are numerous grammatical errors sprinkled throughout, the book, but not so that it is too distracting from the story.  There was a line that read something like, "Jasputin felt like he was in a room of physicists discussing particle physics"  There is no way Jasputin could feel that way.  He is a dog...  "Jasputin might as well be in a room of people discussing particle physics" or something like that would work.Problems in Character Development:I understood Caroline, but I didn't get why she was the character that was so important.  What in her background made her so smart? So willing and able to take the lead?Lucian was kind of like a ghost character.  I didn't get why he was there at all.  His character didn't really make sense.Dr. Fourer was another one that wasn't all that important to the story.The Good Character Development:Most of the characters are rich, and easy to empathize with.  All the main characters, like Caroline, are people you can relate to.As I said, Caroline was well developed, although maybe a mismatch.Rashid was well developed.Erin was a rich character.Aaron Sr, was very vivid.Murphy was the kind of person you would expect.Cody is someone I understand, and don't like...Which is the way it was intended I think...The ending:Everything is wrapped up well enough for me.  There is a part in the end that is just a little over the top, but the book wrapped up nicely.  It didn't leave me with questions, or irritation.Overall, I found this a very imaginative, well executed story, besides the few flaws.  It was very enjoyable, and I can recommend it to sci fi fans looking for something new and original.It was a satisfying read.Mark :)

These batteries provide plenty of flight time, but they age extremely rapidly, even under ideal treatment..I never have kept my batteries charged, and have kept them at around 50% unless I was flying them the next day.  I would commonly charge them the day off..Even so, my experience is that they don't last long, and I have read they are good for maybe 50 uses from reputable sources.  I have 31 flights on my one battery, and it is already down to 92%.  You really should be REAL careful about flying a battery that has less than 90% capacity.  Even 89% is a no no.Don't believe me?  Watch Micbergsma on youtubes video of his battery failure of a battery that has 33 flights on it, and 89%.  It is up in the air for 25 seconds, and he gets the red flashing low battery warning, and auto land...Brand new batteries don't get hot when you fly them.  You can tell your battery is starting to age(in addition to locking at the status on the Phantom assistant software) by seeing if it gets hot when you fly the quad.DJI is making money hand over fist on these!  Think about it.  If a new battery cost 129.00 and is good for MAYBE 50 flights, that is 2.58 per 12 minute flight!  It would be cheaper to take a drive in the car, and burn the gas.....I say 12 minutes, because that is the longest I fly my quad.  I fly it until it reaches 50% charge.I don't mind paying 129.00 per battery, but that price for a battery that only lasts maybe 50 flights is ridiculous!PS. I have lots of experience with Lipos.  I have two other quads, and 5 batteries.  In addition to all my other electronics..

This is an excellent lens.  It is sharp, and fast.  Meaning it has good optics, and a low F2 number, for great low light performance, and bokeh.The lens is a macro, with a minimum focusing distance under half a foot!  Although I have wanted a macro lens for years, I could never bring myself to fork out the money, just to take pictures of flowers and things...This lens not only fits the bill for a small form factor, but has a great focusing range, with sharp optics.See example photos below...http://www.pbase.com/markcas/eosmtestpics

The camera came updated with firmware 2.02.  Even with the new update, the camera still has major issues with auto focus.  It is not a lack of speed I am concerned about, it is inaccuracy.  I would say about half the time, or more, the camera gives me the little green squares indicating it has achieved focus, only to get back the computer and discover the focus was off...I would much rather have the camera indicate it couldn't achieve focus, rather than give me an indication it does when in fact it does not...Auto focus:simply does not work well at all.  It is rather pathetic.  A lot of the time, the focus squires turn green on several areas, but the image is not focused.Image quality:This is where the camera really shines!  When it does in fact get an accurate focus lock, the images can be stellar!Battery Life:Although I have taken quite a few pictures, and video snippets, I haven't had a chance to really test out battery life.  However, I took this on vacation, and took several video segments, and had no issue what so ever.Video Quality:When you are using manual focus, you can get some truly stunning results.Body and build quality:Excellent!  A nice sturdy metal bodyMenus/touch screen:Rather non intuitive.  The camera probably has every option you would care for, but they are all buried deep in the touch screen menus and not easy to get to...  When I looked at customizing buttons, I learned I couldn't do what I wanted, which was to map white balance to the asterisk key.Summary:  If the auto focus was more accurate, I could easily give this 5 stars.  However, the auto focus is terrible.  I don't find it too slow, just inaccurate, and that is a fatal flaw in a camera.If you want to see the video review with sample photos and video, click the link below...https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XFWa0axLivQ

UPDATE:I HAD TO GRUDGINGLY GIVE THIS DEVICE ONE MORE STAR, AS MY WIFE WAS ABLE TO PUT ON THE HEART RATE MONITOR AND USE WHILE SHE WAS STRENGTH TRAINING WITH FREE WEIGHTS...I was sent this device to review by MeasuPro.  Although I have tested a lot of excellent products from them, and one that was also mediocre, I have to give this device only 3.5(4) stars for the reasons I will list below..One, the instructions for this device are very poor.  There is no clear instructions on what to do before putting the heart rate monitor on before it will read correctly.  There is a vague line that talks about "wetting the electrodes" but no description of what the electrodes actually are.  I had to look into how a chest strap heart rate monitor works before I understood how to make this one work.Two, It is unclear exactly how to set the speedometer for accurate readings, and figgity to get working..  It should just be a matter of entering in the proper wheel diameter in order to get an accurate readout. Let the computer do the calculation for circumference.  Or at least list that is the reading you want.I mounted this on a mountain bike, with road tires that were on 24 inch rims.  That should have been a measurement of 60.9 centimeters.  With that setting, the speedo was WAY off as compared to the gps speedo on my smart phone.About the heart rate monitor:There are four components to the heart rate monitor.  The main sensor that has measupro silk screened onto it, two conductive rubber side straps(Electrodes), and the elastic strap that goes around your back.  You need to wet the underside of those straps/electrodes(the part that sits on your chest) before you put it on.After you get the underside of those rubber pieces wet, the heart rate monitor continues to operate accurately.  I compared this to the heart rate monitor on my smart phone, and they both agreed.Features:This device is loaded with good features like, Kcalories burned, heart rate, miles, etc.  For the price, it is a pretty full function device.Speedo:I spent quite a bit of time fighting with this to get it to operate correctly. In the misunderstanding that I was to calculate wheel diameter in metric and then enter that in. Probably over 20 minutes...  If i entered in the proper wheel diameter converted to centimeters, it was WAY off.  I could get close(within 2 -3 MPH) at 11mph by just using the default setting of 207CM.  I lastly figured out the device wanted me to enter in circumference in centemeters, or at least that is what I think it wants....  On a 24" wheel, with the tires it should be around 210CM.There is really no instructions about this, and it really isn't intuitive...  I have another, more expensive bike computer by Sigma, but one shouldn't have to have experience with bike computers to use a new one.  The manual should be written in a way that anyone can learn how to install and use this.Quality:It has the feel of a quality product, and a full two year warranty, but the trouble in setting up the speedo takes a notch or two away from the device.  The speedo is necessary to determine calories burned and distance traveled.On the plus side, I did contact them about the heart rate monitor not working and they did respond via email fairly quickly, although the reply really wasn't much help.Summary:I spent quite a little bit of time fighting with this device.  The directions aren't clear, and it isn't intuitive on what to set.  I do have another, more expensive bike computer on my road bike, but it has been a while.  Better instructions would make this a much better device.As it is, it probably is worth the money, if you can figure it out.  I hope this helps!The video review is below, but I spent so much time dittling with this thing, that I was not happy with the video review results.  Neat GoPro scenery though....https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zqtUoucq0wk

This gets 4 stars for such a bizarre storyline.  Sure I guessed it with 33 minutes to spare, but that didn't make the last 33 minutes unwatchable.This story gets a good helping of bad reviews, but what really interested me in watching it, was a 3 star review that said "I don't know if I liked it, but I was still thinking about it days later".  I am a sucker for movies that leave a lasting effect like that.Although you can guess it before it has ended, that doesn't make the story simple.In other areas, the acting by all the characters is great, and the execution of the story makes you feel for the characters.I think the reason this movie gets a large dose of bad reviews is it makes you think.  People generally hate movies that they have to think about I have found.If you like movies that are thought provoking, you will like this movie.  Just watch it, let it unfold, and don't think you are superior to everyone else....Enjoy.

This is a quality kit, with pretty much everything you need to get started.  You have I think the more useful, practical components in this kit, Like a photoresistor, and temperature probe.The kit is quality, there is a neat little plastic tray that your Arduino and breadboard fit into. The trim pot and all other components are suited well to this kit.It has a 9 volt battery adapter to power the kit.You go to the Arduino website to download the program interface that allows you to upload your custom code to the device, as well as downloading sample code directly from the Arduino site.This is a good little kit, and I find the kit pretty complete for learning how to use the Vilros.  I have another kit that is made by another manufacturer that has more/different components that doesn't seem as high of quality.It has a custom tray that the UNO board mounts to, and that the breadboard sits in making it easy to keep your work neatly organizedI think between this kit and some others, I would pick this one to start learning on.

There are some pros and cons to this kit.  I would say it is more like 3.5 stars.I will go over the cons first:1.  The real Arduino kit has a longer USB cable, which makes it more convenient than this kit.2. I like the tray that comes with the real Vilros kit.  It makes it easier, and neater to build projects.3. The jumpers fit more snuggly/precisely into the breadboard that comes with the Vilros kit4. I would like a temperature sensor in the kit.  I find that useful from the start.5. The Vilros kit comes with an adapter that plugs into the board so you can use a 9Volt battery to power itPros:1.All the example code, and data sheets are provided for you right on the cd that comes with the kit.  That is BIG plus, it keeps you from having to go out and search for the data sheets.2. This comes with more components for the same price as the true Arduino kit.  Check the listing.3.  I really wanted an gyro, which I think makes this kit worth it.  I am not too interested in the dot matrix display, nor the LCD.4. The tutorial booklet is much larger, and easier to read.For a learning kit, this is probably better, as it comes with more devices.  However, for making a circuit that is useful that you can just leave in the tray, I think the Vilros kit is probably better.In general, the Vilros kit has a more quality feel, however, it doesn't come with near the same components for the same price.
Nothing like the original story, but AFTER ALL, it is all just fantasy....  Yes, there was a Vlad the impaler, but Dracula was always just a fiction story.  Nothing is written in stone.
This is a good little adventure.  I enjoy the stories of the "good guys" that are actually something else entirely.

SETTINGS FOR THE DX6i WITH EITHER THE 350qx3, or 350qx with Version 3(350qx3) FIRMWARE AT THE BOTTOMI have the original 350qx upgraded to version 3.0(350qx3 firmware), and would like to take you through the changes I have seen in the way it flies from version 1.The differences between V1, and V3 are mostly in the Firmware that controls the craft.  The main hardware differences are, that the GPS antenna is in a mast that sticks up from the craft, and that there is a slightly larger battery in it.The four stars I gave it is in reference to the firmware characteristics and flight improvements over versions 1, and 2My experience:I have much experience with the 350qx.  I have crash landed mine because of mostly unresponsive controls, from wind, and from vortex ring state.  I have had it apart many, many times. In all that time, I have only cracked two motor mounts in one of the pods.  It is still flying on the original body, and I replaced two motors(Horizon sent them for free) originally from the start because they were noisy, and one later, because it got sand in it.  I have spend a quite a  few hours shielding the controller and gps board from interference from a camera and have gotten it to the point were it would position lock in 25 seconds with the original firmware.  I have replaced motor bearings, and put a "how to video up that is sponsored by Boca Bearings(type The Suburban Hippie Experimentalist, into youtube)My flight vehicles:I have an Ebay gimbal, Mobius camera, CNC prop adapters, and an FPV transmitter  installed on the 350qx.  I also have a Phantom 2, with a Tarot T, V2, and a Gopro Hero 3+ Black installed. and a Nano QXEvolutions in firmware:Version 1: "Smart" mode( the mode were you don't actually have to know how to fly, or think. If you push left it goes left, no matter which way it is facing). It also has altitude hold when in smart mode.Stability Mode, (the mode that has position hold, no altitude hold, and everything else flies as normal, meaning you have to know how to fly, and "put your head in the craft".Agility mode(without 6 Axis stabilization. You can do flips and rolls, IF you can fly it)Smart mode in version one worked okay.  When I first got the craft before I shielded everything, it lost GPS signal all the time. Of course this problem was throughout all modes.Smart mode worked as advertised, but it is basically useless to teach you how to fly the craft.Stability mode was my favorite.  It had position hold and 6 axis gyro stabilization, but it was quite jittery when flying around.  The controls responded to any SLIGHT movement, so if you have shakey hands, like after drinking a few cups of coffee, it will be ugly..Agility mode was not for me...Version 2 firmware(350QX2):Every mode was the same as above, except they added "AP MODE".It flew barely okay in AP mode, but it could NOT maintain altitude very well at all, nor could it position lock very well. A slight wind would blow it all over the place. It was a neat idea, and looked good on paper, but was a crash waiting to happen.Hardware changes in version IIThey also moved the GPS antenna into one of the back arms to get it away from the center of the craft, and any camera you had mounted. They also added a slightly larger battery.Version 3 Firmware(350QX):All modes are the same as version II, with the exception that stability, and AP flight modes are much improved!AP mode works better.  It holds altitude BETTER, but not perfect, and also does a better position lock, and Stability mode is less Jittery, more smooth, and more confidence inspiring. There is no bobbing around, like there was before version III.The hardware changes were that they put the GPS antenna in a mast that stuck up in the center of the craft to get it away from any camera causing interference.  From what I have read it is much improved, however, after shielding mine with copper tape, I have no issues..The 350qx3 AP combo also has longer flight times, over both the V1, and V2.  I think because the gimbal is lighter.With Version III firmware, this is a much better air vehicle than it was.Add the 3 axis gimbal, and CG02 in the AP Combo and I think you have something.The 350qx3 AP combo is quite a bit cheaper than the Phantom 2 vision + Still I have to be honest, with my experience with both, my preference is still the Phantom 2 over the 350QX , which has a longer light time and is more stable.HOWEVER, THERE IS A BIG ISSUE WITH THE PHANTOM 2 with the zenmuse gimbal for GOPro, WHICH IS THAT THE ZENMUSE 3 AXIS GIMBAL IS JUNK, AND CAUSES ALL SORTS OF PROBLEMS...Cons of the Phantom 2, Vision Plus:The Vision plus has a VERY fragile gimbal. I don't know if the 350qx3 AP gimbal is less fragile, but it is about 300 dollars cheaper than the Phantom 2 Vision +, so perhaps if you break the 350qx3 AP, it is less of a a strain on your pocket book to replace...About Fly offs:  I believe some Phantom 2s are flying off on their own not caused by user error.After all the experience I have had with the 350QX, I DO NOT believe they are flying off due to anything else BUT user error...  perhaps people are flying them up too high, and the wind is CARRYING them off, but I am sorry, I do not believe they are flying off on their own, due to firmware malfunctions.At least that has been my experience with firmware Versions 1, and 2.P.S, I have never had ANYTHING fly off, whether it be the Phantom 2, or 350QX.Of course, I keep them both on a pretty tight leash, and don't let them get too far away from me....  I always make sure I can tell the orientation, and have full control.  If not, I bring them down.  I have had to bring them down in the distance, and crash land them to make sure to not risk a "Fly off".I had crash landed the 350qx lots of times, and the Phantom 2 once. In all those crash landings, I have broken some props, and cracked one motor pod on the 350qx, and the only damage I ever sustained on the Phantom was a broken prop, and burnt up motor due to a tip over(which happens all the time).The downfall to the Phantom 2, is that it has not automatic shutoff, if the props come in contact with something, like the 350qx does.  That means if it tips over, you likely just burnt a motor up...I sincerely hope this helps your decision process!DX6i settings for 350qx3.  First watch the horzon video on how to set it up.  Then come back, and change the settings to what you see below.Mix 1 gear gear act Rate d -60% u 0% Sw ele d/r trim in Mix 2 gear gear act Rate d +75% u 0% Sw ail d/r trim in gear sw 0 elev sw 0 ail sw 0 = smart mode green gear sw 0 elev sw 1 ail sw 0 = ap mode purple gear sw 0 elev sw 1 ail sw 1 = stability mode blue gear sw 0 elev sw 0 ail sw 1 = agility mode red gear sw 1 rth no matter position of other switchesMark :)

UPDATE THE NEXT DAY AT THE BOTTOM OF THE REVIEW:This isn't a bad speaker.  The speaker is rather directional, so that if it is at your level and pointing right at you, the highs and mids sound much clearer.Too be clear, the mids, and highs sound much better, more real, and less jarring than the 1.5 watt auvio blue tooth speaker.  However, surpisingly, the bass response from the much smaller auvio 1.5 watt is much better!  Overall, you get more volume for mids and highs, with less bass.  The 1.5 puts out great bass for it's size, and actually has more bass punch, because it has a down firing subwoofer, but the mids and highs are piercing to me.If the shack, were to combine this design, with a down firing subwoofer, instead of a bass port, they would have really have something.As it is, it is a good speaker for what I paid for it on sale at the Shack....About the connection notification:I seriously don't know what people are complaining about...  There is a voice telling you the speaker is on, and once again when you are synced on blue tooth, but it is NOT loud at all.  I would say mid, to low volume.Overall, I am satisfied, and even though the bass response is better on the little one, I find this speaker will be less jarring for what I wanted it for, which was to listen to music when I am going to bed....UPDATE AFTER A DAY OF USE:I HAVE RAN THIS SPEAKER THROUGH SOME TESTS, WHICH ARE ON YOUTUBE. TYPE IN "The Suburban Hippie Experimentalist"Now, having said that, I have found that after a day, I have really started to like this speaker.  I think you will be very pleased with it for everything except Hip Hop music, which really relies on the lower bass scale.  That R&B "thump" everyone loves will be the only genre were you will find this speaker missing something...Playing music from your computer, or phone through the AUX in jack sounds GREAT!  There is enough bass for most music genres, and the sound from the speaker, is very nice, clear and fills the room with enough volume.Every speaker/ receiver system I own, has distortion when played through blue tooth.  I think it is because of digital clipping.  Which means the A/D is less bits than desired, and or some math is done that clips the music in such a way that you end of getting harmonic distortion at the receiving end.Hope this helps!  Mark :)

I won't make this some long drawn out review.  I will just say this is an incredibly emotional ride.  It is a very powerful movie, that is pretty much true to life, and after watch it, it will be hard to forget.It is a great movie, and a great drama.That being said, it means there was great acting, a great story, and it was greatly executed.

As the title says, this speaker is quite exceptional for the size, and weight of it.  I bought this for 40 dollars at the Shack.  It sounds much better than its size would indicate to you, with GREAT bass for the size, and good bass in general.  It works fine for what it is, but the mids, and highs don't sound as pleasing coming from such a tiny driver.It gets five stars for what it is, but I am not sure I actually like it...Price:For the price Amazon lists, I think it is not bad.  I WOULD consider it too expensive were it not for the blue tooth function.Design:The design is very good.  As I said it delivers exceptional bass for such a small device.  Much more than you would expect!Sound Quality:After you get past the astonishing bass this device puts out for its size, you will start to think about the sound coming from it.  I would not describe it as pleasing.  The bass sounds good, and has a semi rich sound to it.  The part where I think this falls short IN MY MIND, is the highs, sound too sharp coming from such a small driver.  The highs are clear enough, but when you are listening to this on your bed side, the highs are a little startling to you, and aren't something that will lull you to sleep. The mids are fairly absent.  You get highs, and bass.  It is probably fine if you want to listen to this while you cook, or watch a movie.What I don't like:If you are using the 3.5mm Aux in jack, there is not volume control as the buttons on the top of the speaker do not work.  You have to set your volume on the playing device.  If you have this set full blast on say your laptop, the speaker comes on full blast.Summary:I am on the fence about taking this back.  I am not sure I like the sound.  Sure it sounds great for what it is, but I am not sure if I would prefer a bigger device that doesn't have such piercing highs.About me:I am a former Audiophile.  Now a days, I am less picky, but I still know what good sound sounds like.Video Review:I did a small, unprofessional review of this on one of my youtube channels using a sound analyzer I downloaded on my phone.  Just go to Youtube, and type in "The Suburban Hippie Experimentalist"i will also put a link in the comments section to the video.

I would say this is worth watching.  It is a little cheesy in the very end, but all and all not a bad story, with good acting, great special effects, and a nice dark feel.I almost didn't watch it because all of the bad reviews, but am glad I did.Mark

It is really hard to properly rate oil, unless you have all sorts of fancy equipement.However, I have read about Valvoline Synthetic Oil on sights like "Bob is the Oil GUY" site online, and others. It makes the phone much thicker, and has a few flaws.There is no silicone on the sides, so that you are more likely to drop your phone when in this case.Yes, the color of the white version is off white, but I could care less.It also makes the phone quite a bit heavier.There also is no Aero Armor imprinted in the outer most silicon like the picture shows.The Good:The molded button extension work fine. I have to say this phone is pretty cool.  My first foray into smart phones was with the Samsung Stratosphere(silde out).  These phones easily broke on me TWICE.  Both times they were in my pocket.  The first time, there was no visible damage, but I must have leaned up against something.  The second time. It was in my pocket and I bent down.That was if for me and smart phones, until I discovered how cheap Virgin Mobile was, and that this phone(LG Volt) was on sale for 149.00 with no contract.I  have to say the phone is pretty neat.Battery life:I fully charged this phone 24 hours ago, and now it has about half capacity left.  I used it to download a few apps, and used it as both a gps for about 25 minutes today, and for Rhapsody.Actually, it can drain the battery MUCH faster than that...  It was at 100%this am, and 7 hours later it was at 50%...Features:It has almost all the bells and whistles, and some that other don't like the Quick Remote, that is pretty cool!  It works like a charm on my Toshiba TV,  I don't know for sure, but I am thinking the LED just under the camera lens must be capable of transmitting infra red.The phone has a quad core processor in it, so it is pretty fast.It has the Google 4.4(kitti Kat, I think)  The google search tool works flawlessly for me with voice.  you click it, say what your looking for and google finds it, and you can then get gps directions to it.  Simple.Really what makes an android smart phone useful is all the free apps, and there are thousands for you to download.Size:The phone is very thin, and light. and about as wide as you have come to expect for a smart phone with a decent sized screen.performance:As stated, the phone is pretty quick to open your apps.I am on Virgin Mobile, in Carroll County Maryland, and so far, I have not had issues with data connectivity.Minuses:I don't find the menus all that intuitive.  I often have to use the back button several times.
Exactly what i wanted! A four wire, 4 pin connector to plug into my lipo to control my gimbal.  It Arrived in time, and just what I needed!

I was sent this to reviewI find this scale to be pretty accurate for my needs.  The only reason it looses a star, is because if you turn the scale on, and don't use it, it tends to drift a few grams.  To measure very small weights, you need to turn it on, wait for it to say zero, and measure it right away. I am not certain that other scales do not have this problem.Apparent build quality:The scale is very light, yet seems to be pretty solidly built.  It has a stainless steel plate on which to weigh your items on, and the UNIT and Power/Tare Button are neatly fit into the face besides the display.Accuracy:I do not own calibrated weights on which to test the scale against, so I used US coins.  I found the weights on the US mint sight, and weight them.  Although they probably aren't exact as they have been in circulation, possibly picking up dirt, or having some of the material rubbed off, they are as accurate as I could find. I find the scale to be accurate generally within .5 grams in most cases.Usefulness, and range:I find the range to be phenomenal on this scale.  Especially for one so cheap. One that will measure between a few grams to 11 pounds is pretty impressive.Warranty:A two year warranty on something like this that cost so little, and could possibly be abused is pretty impressive to me.Recommendation:If you choose to buy this scale, and want to measure heavy items(like 11 pounds), I recommend that you are careful to not slam the item down on the weight table.  This is a plastic scale, I doubt it is a good idea to let something pound down on it with more than one G of force.  For example, just a two G drop on 11 pounds weighs 22 pounds.  Dropping something from just a few inches can easily give you 5 gs to 100s of gs or much more depending on the surface it lands on.The point is, don't drop you weight on the table....If you want to see this scale in action, and see how I determined this scale to be accurate, go to Youtube, and type in "the suburban hippie experimentalist", and look for the TZ5000 in my videos. It should be up within a few hours of this review..Hope this helps!Mark :)

This review is for firmware 2.0.  I already have a review of the 350 Qx on here.  There I gave it 4 stars largely because of Blades great customer service..I have since upgraded my 350 Qx with firmware 2.0.  The only differences in my original 1.0 350 qx, and the version 2.0 would be a different placement of the GPS antenna.  With the version 2.0, they moved the gps receiver and antena to the right back arm in order to attempt to get it away from the interference.A little background:My original 350 Qx flew fine after I replaced the noisy motors, WITH THE EXCEPTION that it did not acquire GPS with the Mobius camera I was using.  When I tried, the quad would always take a long time to acquire GPS, and ultimately, it would loose some control, so I would have to bring it down for a hard landing.I had to come in sideways once, and the quad struck hard as it was flying from the left, and rolled several times, making my camera fly off, and bending the attachment hardware.Months of experimenting, and moding:It took me quite some trial an error to get the mobius shielded from the GPS antenna and reciever, but I at last did it!After upgrade to 2.0:Then I was enticed to upgrade to 2.0 because of how useful the AP mode seemed on paper...Unfortunetely, it does not work quite like advertised.In AP mode, the design is that you must take the throttle up to at least 75% to raise the quad, and everything below 50% lowers the altitude.  Everything in the middle on the left stick, is supposed to keep the quad at your set altitude.However, it doesn't quite work.After you set a height in AP mode, and fly forward, the quad quickly loosed height.  You can't reasonably feather the throttle like you can in stability mode either.Also, with version 2.0 sometimes the throttle cut doesn't work the first time I push it, which is troubleing for me.  I want the ability to ditch the craft if it tries to fly away, or over people, but now throttle cut is unresponisive.The other issue is that the start up procedure doesn't always work well either.The throttle cut, and start up worked perfectly before upgrading teh firmware.I will be anxiously awaiting firmware 3.0!I have some videos I made with the quad on youtube at my "mark daniel imaging" channel.The thing that this quad REALLY has going for it, is that it won't fly off on you!  In firmware the firmware one version, It would occasionally, or even often get a gps error, and make it fly funny, but I always had partial control, and could bring it down.Could a strong wind blow it off course, and if you weren't profficient on the controls would it float away?  Sure.However, with the DJI Phantoms, I have seen clearly automated flight, where the quad flys off, like it has a mind of it's own.  Good solid robotic flight that take that quad away from you.  There is a saying, "it's flying back to china"The 350QX won't fly off, but be prepared to work on it. Tune it, and such.Hope this helps!Mark

I was sent this thermometer to review.I am still using this, and loving it quite some time after my initial review.We have had several meat thermometers over the years, and none of them even come close to the TF5000.It would normally be hard for me to get excited about a meat thermometer, but this one is pretty advanced.Upon receiving it, I immediately checked it for accuracy, and found it to be right on.To check accuracy:A. First I put a bunch of crushed ice in a glass of water, and measured the temperature.  I got a measurement of 32.5 degrees almost instantly.B. I then boiled a pot of water, and measured the center to be 212.3.  Again almost instantly.Speed of Measurement:The package says it has a 6 second response time, but I find it to be almost instantaneous.  All my other thermometers took forever to read the meat.  Long enough that my hands start to feel uncomfortable from the heat...Accuracy of device:Judging by my experiment, I find this device to be right on.Calibration button:The fact that it even has a calibration button is impressive to me.  I have never owned a thermometer that you could do this with. To do this, you crush ice, and put it in water.  You stick the thermo in the ice water, and hold the cal button for 2 seconds.  It will read 0.0 C, which is the freezing point.  You have just calibrated your thermometer.Max/Min button:The max and min button tell you your extremes.  I can't currently think of a use for this, but perhaps real chefs can.Auto Power Off:None of our other thermometers have had this feature either, and I always end up leaving them powered on laying on the countertop, draining the batteries.Reliability:I haven't had this long, so I can't really comment on that, but I can say the device has a nice solid feel, and seems to be made well.I hope this has helped you in your shopping!Mark:)
Well it keeps me from dropping my remote, while I am trying to concentrate on the task of keeping my expensive quadcopter in the air and filming!
I like the look of this little thing, and it SEEMS to work... Haven't had any annoying door to door salesman so far, and if they come, I will just yell out the door, "READ THE DAMN SIGN!"...

This prop reamer works flawlessly, and I would think it would be a lot easier to manage than what most people use to ream out the props for their 350 QX with the Small Parts, CNC prop adapter.Be careful when using this, as in plastic props, this can take a lot of material away in a big hurry.  Only apply very slight pressure, and ream the props out just a little at a time.Ream the props, check fit, ream the props, check fit....If you take too much material from the hub of your prop, no matter how well balanced the prop, you will never get smooth flight, as the prop will end of slopping to one side when you tighten it.This item is very sharp, very solid, and works very well.Good luck!Mark :)

These replace the carbon fiber blades that came with the prop adapter kit for my 350 QX.  With the Maytech carbon fiber props that came with the kit, I get 2.5 to 3.5 minute flights.  With these props, I get 4.5 to 6 minutes of smooth flight.These were well worth the purchase price for me.Mark :)

The battery balance connector is too short to put the battery in the bag and let the balance connector stick through the bag to charge it.  I need an extension cable to charge it.I will have to get an extension.Even the reviews I saw on youtube were with people stripping the battery wires, wire nutting them together with an extension cord, and applying enough energy that they explode.Way to go bag!  But how about some real world application?If anyone tried to use this the right way, it would be discovered right away that you need an extension cable...It will be great to store the batteries in to transport them in the car, but it is called a "charging bag"A port at the bottom corner of the bag would work great so that you could stick the JST connector out...

These batteries seem to last longer than the original.  I am getting 10 or more minutes out of these, and something like 8 out of the original.  I don't know if that is because these were brand new, and the other one had been used for a while, but I am pleased.These were cheap enough that they are almost an essential for the Syma x1Size:These batteries are the exact same size as the original, and look, feel and fit the same.

A BIT OF HISTORY...This makes my third, and probably last quadcopter...My intention before buying any of my quads was to do areal video with a 350 sized quad.Before shelling out the money, I got the SYMA X1, and mounted a camera to practice areal video.  After about a month with that, I bought the 350QX over the DJI Phantom.After flying the 350 a few times, I decided that if I was going to fly such a capable, and expensive device, I really needed to hone my flying skills so that in the event the 350 tries to fly off, I can take the reins so to speak' and place the 350 in agility mode and fly it back to myself.The Syma was too big and clumsy to fly inside, and too small, and symmetrical for me to fly outside with any hope of determining the front and back of the quad, so I needed something really small to fly in small distances inside.The Nano Qx seemed to fit the bill.  It was either that or the Estes Proto X, and the Blade product won out, since you can bind it to a regular transmitter avoiding the only complaint I have seen about the Proto X, which is that the controller is useless.MY EXPERIENCE WITH THE NANO QX:I am happy that I chose the Nano QX.  It is everything that I wanted it to be.  It is very small, very precise, and light enough that when you crash, it doesn't break itself.This little quad is really quite capable and precise.  At first, I flied it in Safe mode, with low rates with my DX6i controller, then moving on to Safe Mode, and high rates.This quad is small, light enough, with the durability needed to fly it very aggressively in my small living room, which is exactly what I needed.  I plan on flying this very aggressively in a tight area, to learn to fly well.  I plan on flying this flight learning tool, much more aggressively than I will ever fly the 350QX.  The idea it to learn to fly really well in case I ever need the skills on the 350qx(video machine)Agility mode inside is a bit much. Perhaps if one had a huge room, with high ceilings, it would work but I think for that mode, you might just want to fly it outside...Charger:The provided charger is nice.  It is small, and the battery just fits right into a socket.  You just plug it right into your computer USB.Spare Parts:  It comes with two canopies, a yellow and a green, another set of rotors that match the color of the other canopy, and like 4 spare little rubber grommets that are used to hold the body in place.  I am not sure about spare parts like motors and such, but will most likely have to replace those things at some point.  When I do, I can see that there is no soldering required, which will be nice. Plug and play motors will be much appreciated!STABLE HOVER:It requires just a little trim to tune into a hover, but otherwise it is a GREAT flyer.  I will learn to be an expert flyer with this little guy.TIP:With the DX6i, it is said that you need to bring the flap switch down and back up to get it to go into Agility mode in the manual.  For me, I have to just switch the flap/gryo switch down to (1), and leave it there.  When I tried to flip the switch down and back up, the led on the quad turned red, but only the throttle and yaw worked(left lever) and not the aileron(right) lever.Other than that little hiccup, nothing else.Hope this helps,Mark

I was REALLY underwhelmed with the quality of video this puts out.  I had an 808 #16 that seemed to take just as good of video inside, and actually BETTER video outside...This camera had all washed out colors, with a preference toward the blue,  Meaning white balance was way off, in a snowy environment,  As compared to the 808 it was really poor.  The 808 recorded true colors without any bias towards any hue.The picture is sharper across the entire frame than the 808, but I just can't live with the fact that the white balance was off.I liked the image stabilization and that is why I bought it over the Hero.  Also, the image quality looked batter to me than the hero.I bought it to mount it to my newly purchased quadcopter, but it was just WAY too much work to mount for such lack luster video quality.  That and even when I turned "Remote(wifi" off, it still seemed to interfere with the GPS of the craft.I really hate to say it, but I returned it, and bought a Mobius direct from the manufacturer.  We'll see how that compares.I really wanted this camera, with image stabilization, but I just wasn't happy.FYI, I had downloaded the newest firmware, and was recording at 1080, 60 frames per second.There is a video I just uploaded on youtube.  Just go to google, and type in "the suburban hippie experimentalist" to find it.Hope this is helpful...

UPDATE, I FELT IT WAS FAIR TO COME BACK AND UPGRADE THIS FROM 3 STARS TO 4.  THE REASON WHY IS AT THE VERY BOTTOM.I ordered this over the Chinese competition, for a few reasons.A.  I did not want to give such a large amount of money directly to a Chinese owned company,B. I did not want to have to TRY and deal with Chinese customer support if I had issues.C.  I did not like the toy looking transmitter of the Phantom.D.  I wanted a real hobby grade transmitter.C.  I wanted to support and American company,E.  I have heard Horizon Hobby customer support is "second to none"I open up the DX6i  transmitter box, and I am happy.  It is what I wanted, a big, complicated, computer transmitter that reminds me of my hobby days 15 years ago.  I feel like it is a precise tool, not some toy. Inversely, I open up the box on the 350Qx, and am not so impressed.  It is smaller than I imagined, and has kind of a cheap feel to it. The light weight, brittle plastic body is someone flexible, and two of the motors make clicking sounds when you spin the props(rotors).I watch a couple videos online to see how to program the transmitter for the 350qx, and I am flying it in about an hour.SMART MODE:  The Smart Mode does what is says, by making it so you don't have to remember what direction the craft is going.  You push the stick to the right and it goes right, regardless of which direction the vehicle is facing.However, in smart mode, it feels like the quad is fighting me.  It is sluggish to respond, and doesn't do what I want it to.  It flies rough, and you can see that on the video camera.STABILITY MODE:  In Stability Mode, the craft flies like you would expect.  For example, you need to keep in mind the orientation of the craft versus where you are.  It flies responsive enough, that you can fly it just fine though.AGILITY MODE: I have not tried Agility Mode yet.  I am not as skilled as I would like to be, and don't want to risk a crash.RETURN TO HOME MODE: Return to Home mode is something that I did try, and works perfectly.WHY DID I RATE THE CRAFT AS I DID?The reason this craft only gets 3 stars is that it came with two motors, with bad bearings that introduces a lot of noise into the vehicle, and makes poor video. The reason it didn't get just two stars, is that I called Horizon Hobby, didn't have a long wait time, and spoke with Chad, and without any fuss, he is going to ship me two new motors, free of charge of course.DID YOU TRY IT, BEFORE WRITING THIS REVIEW?I have done some experiments with video, and I find the front mount is problematic for a camera as heavy as the Sony AS15.  It makes the vehicle tip forward, and try to fly away from you. Also, even though I had "Remote(wifi)" turned off on the camera, it still seemed to interfere with the GPS.DO YOU HAVE ANY SUPPORTING EVIDENCE TO BACK UP THIS REVIEW?I have a few videos I put up on youtube, if you want to type in "the suburban hippie experimentalist" into google, you can see them...SUMMARY:For now, I am satisfied.  Even the next day before I called Horizon, and was considering sending it back, I still didn't want to by the Phantom. I will keep it, and use it, and in the future maybe build my own, if I need to upgrade.WHAT IS THIS 350QX INTENDED FOR?This thing I am sure will fly circles around the Phantom.  It is more of a hobby grade flyer, whereas the Phantom is more a strict video tool.Hope this helps!UPDATE:One major thing happened that made me change my mind on how happy I am with this quad.  One, I called Horizon Hobby customer support.  I called, I was on hold for about a minute, and then I did the option to leave a call back number.  I received a callback in about 3 minutes.  I spoke with Chad. He was very nice, helpful and understanding.  He said it was no problem to ship me two new motors.The second thing that happened is that, without me asking, they rush shipped me the motors VIA FedEx.  I got them on a Saturday, which if you get things delivered to your house, you know that is kind of rare, and cost more.The third thing that happened, is after I replaced the two new noisy motors, I began to play with different camera mounts.  I have discovered which modes work best for what.  Without a gimball, and camera anti shake, Smart Mode is not the best for video.  Stability Mode however, is useable.Because of those three things, I have decided I am in fact happy with my purchase.  There are some bugs to work out, but now I am confident, that it will be no problem to get the results I want.Although the two motors I was sent, or quiet, I  have decided that I will probably upgrade the motor bearings to ceramic ones from Bocca bearings in the future.I have also ordered a Mobius camera, and will get an 89 dollar gimball off of Ebay that unfortunately is from Hong Kong(I would rather buy American, or at least Japanese)Based on my bad experience with the Sony AS15, and my good experience with the 808 # 16, and ordering a Mobius over the Sony, it isn't so much about money rather than trying to get stuff that works right away.  The Mobius gets great reviews, and the seller of this 89 dollar gimbal gets 99.3% feedback.I REALLY HATE TO SAY THIS, BUT I THINK THE CHINESE ARE ACTUALLY STARTING TO BEAT THE REST OF THE WORLD IN QUALITY.  Seriously, that hurts to say, but I think it might be true...Mark :)
Incredibly smooth, and relaxing music.  The quality of the sampling on this album is excellent!  I would recommend these shorts songs for a relaxing time. maybe some yoga or something

However, there is a higher than normal defective rate with this quad, and also A LOT of returns due to the poor user manual.REVIEW:Let me start by telling something the manual doesn't.  HOW TO SYNC THE CONTROLLER.The manual isn't very clear on how to bind the transmitter to the quad.A. Put the battery in the quad and set it on a level surface to calibrate level flight and leave it there until after the quad LED starts to blink in rapid succession.B. After you see the rapid blinks start on the quad, turn on the transmitter and watch its led blink for a few seconds.C. take the left control and push it all the way up to the top, and then quickly back down to zero throttle. The light on the controller should now be glowing solid, as should the led on the quad. It should be ready to fly! Enjoy!Now that the above is done.  Let me tell you about the quad.There are lots of people on youtube that are thrilled with this little guy, and rightly so!  It takes little time to get to learn how to fly it.Low and High Settings:In low level or "L"  you will have a tough time flying this in any wind outside.  In "H" or High level you should be able to fly this no problem.First try to learn to hover and control it inside in a large room on L mode.  learn to hover, and move the quad around within say a 5 foot diameter inside.  Learn all the controls and then take it outside.Cons:They make these cheaply(selling them for around 35 dollars), and there are some quality issues.This isn't so much a toy for untechnical kids or adults because of the quality issues.However, since there are some quality issues, as they slap these together cheaply, if you don't want to look at the board, or know how to solder, you are stuck! Look at the WLtoys 9X9 series.MY USE:I ordered an 808 #16 camera to mount on it, and use it as a video platform. In the future I intend to step up to one of the large quads like the Horizon Hobby 350qx, or the DJI phantom.MY EXPERIENCE WITH RC FLIGHT:15 years ago, I had a 60" nitro powered  Trainer, with a .40 nitro engine, and two electric HobbyZone Firebird IIs.  I really enjoyed flying the 2 channel firebird II planes.I did enjoy those electric planes a lot, and it got me outside.  After I became busy, I sold the two Firebirds, and whished I had kept them ever since.MY CONCLUSION:I am quite pleased with this.  Despite the quality  issues(cold solder joints) it works quite well.  I think the toy is quite advanced for the money(3 axis stabilization, the motors shut off if the bind to keep you from burning them up, and the replacement parts are quite cheap)Hope this helps!UPDATE TWO DAYS AFTER OWNING THE QUAD.After just two days, and about 5 flights, I have learned to hover this quadcopter in mild winds(say gusts of 5mph) outside, and keep it pretty stationary to maybe a 15 feet x 10 feet rectangle area, which pleases me.  Gusts are the hardest to manage, because it is constantly changing.I have learned to pretty easily keep the copter oriented to what direction I want it in so that I know which controls to push.When the battery gets low in the quad, it slowed the propellers and landed landed,UPDATE AFTER A WEEK OWNERSHIP; To be honest, I had to come back and take two stars off the review.  This thing is great while it lasts, but when it breaks after a week like it did with me, your going to wonder if you have a fine enough tip on your soldering iron to fix it.You can get replacement parts for this pretty cheaply,  a control board for 9 dollars, and motors for 2.25 a piece.UPDATE AFTER A MONTH.I ordered 4 new motors, and a control board form banggood.  I replaced the bad motor, and the quad flies, and hovers like new again. I can now hover hands free at any engine speed. I have 3 other motors, and a control board, so I should be able to keep it running for quite a while.I think I am just going to keep it.  After everything I have done, I am somewhat attached to it now.  I have made a custom carrying case for it, and it all fits in neatly so I can hike with it to a destination.IF YOU WANT TO SEE A VIDEO I DID, TYPE Mark Daniel Imaging into google, and look for "3 Days of Hiking in Snowy Maryland" on youtube...Mark :)
I had a very hard time finding this song anywhere.  The sound is adequate, and I am glad just to have it in my collection!

The sound track is great.  However the quality of the reproduction of this into an MP3 is not stellar.The music is very low quality, without the clear highs, and there is an overriding muddiness to the reproduction.  There is some sampling errors in it, and this is not something I would play on my high quality 500 watt stereo system.

If you have ever been stuck for 5 hours along side of the road waiting for the snow plow, you will begin to think about ways of preventing being stranded in the future.These chains fit the bill.They do what they are intended to.  Get you out of an emergency situation.HOW EASY ARE THEY TO PUT ON?There is not expertise required.  They are just cumbersome to get around a tire when it is freezing outside.  less so than regular chains I am told.HOW DURABLE ARE THEY?They will get you unstuck, and get you home if you have 10 miles to drive.  I wouldn't expect much more.  I have read they will break.  Don't expect to be driving on them all winter for the price.HOW DOES THE CAR DRIVE WITH THEM ON?Like a paint mixer.  Just put them on, put sugar and crÃ¨me in your coffee and drive around the block.  After one block, you will have a nicely frothed cappuccino!Seriously.  Rough.  You don't want to drive any length with these on!HOW WELL DO THEY WORK?Even on an icy road with no snow, but a very thin sheet of ice(this is what myself and about 200 cars where stuck in) along country roads making it hard to make it through even the most mild turn at 10 miles per hour, they perform excellently to get you home.SUMMARY:For the money, buy them, and don't expect much but to get you out of a harry situation where you are stuck along the road.Getting home, rather than sitting alongside the road for 5 hours is worth 30 bucks!Mark :)

This book is interesting.For those who read this and think "this type of fumbling wouldn't happen today", you are sadly mistaken my friend...Our federal government isn't good at handling/managing ANYTHING.  There is so much red tape, and so much lack of motivation to do work, that it will seriously take a year to do something that should take at most 2 weeks.  I have experience in this.Have you ever heard the saying "good enough for government work"?  There is a reason people say that..Not just my experience working for the government, but also my experience growing up as a military brat using military health care has shown me just how stupid and inept the government management can be.For one because the establishment is so massive, and two because it is run by politicians who are really concerned with furthering their carriers.If a disaster would happen today, you can count on a few things:1. First, if the government didn't have to tell you, they wouldn't.2. If they did tell you, they would say "they are still assessing the situation", but at this time there is no need to panic.3. Then they would consistently tell you things aren't as bad as you think. An example of this is during TMI partial meltdown, they said there was no radiation leak, and that it was safe to come back to you homes in the area.  Even while Jimmy Carter visited the plant, at the same time, there was a huge hydrogen bubble growing inside the reactor that they didn't know how to deal with, or if it would explode(if it did, it would be game over for the surrounding area).  Look it up if you don't believe me.4. The response to actually manage things would be very slow. Once they started to "manage" things, there would be great areas missed.Think Katrina.I am not trying to tell you to hide in your bunker down in your basement. In fact, I recommend getting out and enjoying life, and remembering that you can't control everything, or even a lot of the things you think you are managing.However, after reading this interesting story, maybe store a few weeks of food and water in case you have to shelter in place,  and if something happens, do not wait for authorities to tell you to leave if you can.Be ready to think, and act on your own.I guess as a book review goes I should be talking more about the writing of this book, and less about what this book is really about . How the government delt with a very serious threat.Well, the book is an interesting, enjoyable read.  It really gives you insight into how the government has worked in the past, and show it still works.It makes you wonder a little about how safe you really are, and I think this book is well worth the read just to open your mind.Beyond all that, it is a good, intricate story.Mark :)

This tea deserves some rave reviews. This tea has a delicious fruity smell, and taste on account of the bergamot oil I presume.MY EXPERIENCE WITH TEAS:I am not a tea expert, but I have to say out of all the different teas I have tried(including many brands of Earl grey), I find this tea to be the absolute best Earl Grey, or even the best tea I have ever had.I have tried all the fancy teas in the regular, and organic grocery stores, and I have to say when I first tried this tea, I was in for a little surprise.HOW DO I DRINK MY STASH EARL GREY?The tea is good by itself, but great with just a little whole sugar, and half and half!WHY DO I DRINK TEA IN THE FIRST PLACE?I often drink tea instead of coffee to cut down on my ever present caffeine addiction.  Yeah I love coffee, but it can get way out of control if I don't watch myself!Also, there was a period where I drank nothing but tea with two tea bags at a time when I couldn't drink coffee for a while because for some reason, the coffee gave me indigestion, and tea didn't.AM I A TEA DRINKER?I can't say I ever really "liked" tea in the past.  It was just something I drank when I either wanted just a little caffeine, or if I wanted a hot beverage with no caffeine that wasn't so sweet.HOW DID I FIND THIS TEA?Stumbling across this tea that is a standard black tea that tastes 10 times better than the fancy fruity teas was a pleasant surprise...WHAT ARE SOME OTHER TEAS I LIKE: In the past, I have enjoyed Red Rose tea, which I had always liked much more than standard Lipton tea(I know they are now made by the same company) and I liked Twinnings, English Breakfast tea.For non caffeinated tea, I really like rooibos.  I really can never get enough red bush.....This Earl Grey surpasses them all in my opinion!  It is delicious, and with less than half the caffeine of a cup of coffee, I don't have to feel guilty or jittery if I have 3 or 4 cups in a day.This by far has become my favorite tea!Mark :)

It took me probably over 20 years before I stumbled across this group on youtube which brought flooding back some memories of my youth, and how I felt in those days.The quality of the sound of Hangin on a string, and Slow down, is an excellent resampling, and I can play the songs the way they were originally intended.  On my huge, Mach II speakers with thier 15 inch woofer drivers, through my excellent quality receiver of around the time when this song came out!For those of this day and age, you may not understand what I mean, but your Ipod, small speakes of the day, and cheap and poorly produced amplifier may not do these songs justice.

A REAL survival story!This is an exellent docu/drama.  It tells the true story of Jewish families that with thier strong will, self reliance and innovation were able to survive long term living underground in two caves to evade persecution by the Nazi occupiers in the Ukraine.This isn't some hollywood sensationalized story of a thrill seeker that just made an accident.These people were fighting for thier lives from the start.  They did not go underground for any other reason than thier basic need to survive.This movie was good from start to finish.  I like the duel formats.  The movie starts out as just a documentary, but then evolves into some dramatizations, with narration from the real survivors of this "adventure" for lack of a better word.The movie has a great ending, and some enlightment about how our neighbors can act in the real world.  I also liked how those indomitable people were able to pass on some perspective to thier grandkids.On another note, it is good to see another side of the Jewish people of that time, which is a group of strong, smart, and self reliant people that beat the Germans.  Instead of just the countless hapless victims that had no hope or way of protecting themselves from an overwhelming wave of only what I can describe as "evil"

There is an intricately woven story in this book that turns out to be less of a thriller, and more of just hours of boredom.. Reading through detail after detail that goes no where.I would give it 2.5 stars if I could, but this is really isn't quite a 3 star book.Do I really need to know all the mundane details of how Indy is fed up with the liberal judges?  Not really.A little back story about Youseff enables the reader to understand his character.  However, on and on and on and on it goes....Hours and hours of painstaking work of the TTIC combing through every detail to try and find the terrorists.  Is this a manual on intelligence, or is this supposed to be a novel?I did enjoy reading about Turbee.  His story was interesting.  There was a real sense of Drama with that character, and I was interested to see what happened with him.In fact, all the character development was great.  It was just way over done, to the point that the reader was no longer interested.There really is nothing compelling or engaging about this book that makes the reader wish to keep turning the pages.I wanted to like it, I just couldn't.  Kudos on the character development, but there is just to many mundane details.Shorten the book by about 300 pages, and you might have something!Mark

I would say this is one of the best books I have read recently, and it was FREE for the kindle.I would give this five stars, but for the ending being wrapped up a little too neatly for my taste.  For a free book, it deserves 7 out of 5 starsThe story:The story idea was excellent!  It took an important topic from our daily lives and made it undoubtedly sinister which adds to the fun.  I would say the story idea was one of the most interesting I had read recently.  The idea that there could be an intentional plot to destroy the human race with GMOs is fascintating.The writing:The story flows very well, and the writing was right on.  I did not find any irritating errors in grammer or spelling that I can remember.The character development:Excellent!  You really get a feeling for what makes each character tick.  The characters are rich and well developed.  You know Jack like he is an old friend.  The reader even gets a feel for minor characters like Richards, and Renee.  Both of those two have interesing personalities that give the reader a vibrant mental image of who they are.Excitement level while reading:Not a complete page turner, but defintely not boring either.  There were only two parts I skimmed over.  Maybe a page or two, when I didn't really want to tolerate mundane details while I was in the midst of a "cliff hanger"The ending:There really wasn't anything wrong with it.  It just seems like one moment you are in the midst of the excitement and then next thing you know, everything is wrapped up neatly with no drama at all.  Kind of like "they lived happily ever after"  However, there is a sequeal that I just downloaded, so I guess the ending can be forgiven.Summary:I really enjoyed this book.  It gave me hours of entertainment.  I think the story line is EXCELLENT!If I didn't have a kindle, and had paid the price for the print version, I wouldn't have been dissatisfied with my purchase.

This book is hailed as part Science Fiction novel, and Part Philosophical Exploration.Forget the former, and go with the later.As a novel of any kind this is a poor representation.  The author should have just stuck with the Self Help Genre.This book is written at a elementary grade school level.  Let me try to explain.There is no real character development in this book.Instead of trying to lead the reader to what kind of person any particular character might be, it is almost like simply telling you. Arnold Wheeler is bad.  The plant manger is good.There is an accident in the mine.  The plant manager says "Oh my God, those men may die. We must do something"  Okay, I can see that the plant manager is a good man, however, no one talks like that..  In fact, in America if someone said something like that, the other person would think they the person who had said that was being sarcastic...Oh and then Arnold Wheeler shows up...  The character doesn't try to hide his lack of concern, but basically says, "just let them suffocate" to paraphrase.Plant manager Ken Good.  Arnold Wheeler Bad...There are numerous Grammatical errors in this book that could be over looked if the story was good.  In this case, the grammatical errors can't be ignored.The dialogue between the characters is frankly ridiculous.  No one talks like that.Gayle ".....I can assure you Feminine Energy is real"Arnold "I do not doubt that there is such a concept as Feminine Energy"Arnold " I also do not see how what you are calling authentic feminine energy is any different than pure animal instincts"The words feminine energy is written 3 times within one small paragraph... It is like the reader is expected to have no attention span, and keeps forgetting what the characters are talking about...In this book, Gayle writes another book, and the title of the CHARACTERS book is mentioned 4 times.  "FULL FEMININE POWER"Then we get to the orange planet in one of the multiverses.  An interesting concept.  Only one color with infinite different shades.  Of course the dialogue between the characters is just as bad.This is a very simple story that is irritating to read.The author really should have just stuck with the Self Help Genre.  Of course, I wouldn't have read it, but there wouldn't have been this poor review from an avid reader of Sci fi books.I understand from some of the reviews that there may be some people out there that are interested in this type of subject, but that doesn't make the book a good sci fi novel, or even a novel for that matter...Mark :)

Initially, I thought mine might be defective.Imagine my frustration when instead of getting several small, uniformly sized pieces, I got 2 or 3 very long thin slivers of floppy banana pieces that didn't really fit into my cereal bowl!A friend suggested I re-orientate the banana with respect to the chopper, and now everything is golden!Hence it gained a few stars to become one of my favorite kitchen utensils!Now, I am so pleased that a great part of my holiday shopping is finished!

System stats: Milled Aluminum Case  i5-6200U -2.4 ghz processor  8 GB ram  64 operating system  built in touchpad and Bluetooth connectivity, speakers  Comes with Windows 10  SD Slot - HD Video Slot - 3 USB Slots  Pros:  Very light weight  Responsive touchpad  Great Sound  Nice Screen resolution  Cons:  It would be nice to have been slightly larger so as to have DVD drive  There's a lot of power in this little package.  It has a stylish clean case and housing. Edges of case around touch-pad are polished for a pop to that area of case.  I have found that it is so polished, that a bit of felt on and edge of case to keep it from slipping out of note-book bag would not be a bad idea.  As for operating software, runs great!!  I do architectural design work and it seems to run software like Sketchup and basic cad very well.  I have a home network and it connected right away with little effort.  Also, as a bonus it didn't come loaded with gobs of bloatware.  The one exception being Dropbox, but I use that so it didn't bother me.  Battery life seems to hold well.  Wrote review on notebook; spent half hour or so to get all my thoughts down and only lost a few percent of battery.  This notebook is for those who want style in their hardware.  For the additional cost this notebook seems to be well worth the investment.

I put a very scratched up dvd in that my other dvd players reject and it played perfect with no issues! FIVE STARS!!!
