Eddie Murphy... you either love him or hate him. I loved him in the role of Norbit and Rasputia in this hilarious comedy! Poor Norbit got picked on a lot in this movie but it was hilarious!!! I can't praise this enough. Unlike some movies you will want to watch this again from time to time.

Delicious and versatile! I use these in soups, stews and many different pasta dishes. It's also very tiny so it's easy for kids to chew and swallow. Despite it's tiny size, it is pasta and takes just as long to cook as regular dry pasta.

I use this a lot in many recipes for so many different things. You can also use it to bulk up your hamburger helpers and use this as a crust or sprinkle on as a topping! These crumbs are very fine and well granulated so if you are looking for something chunky/crunchy or crouton like this is not going to work.

Absolutely delicious and unsulphured! I use this in too many things to mention. I love the taste of molasses and it reminds me of my childhood as my mother used it a lot in cooking. I'm not sure what the shelf life is but I've had this big jar forever and still have about half left after dozens and dozens of uses.

This series started out with a bang but slowly petered out as the season progressed. Dr. Lechter is very intriguing and curious character and will keep you guessing. His calm demeanor was a nice change from the typical psycho killers we see. After about half way through the series it just got old, contrived, and tiresome. I think it's an ok series to watch on a rainy day but you won't be watching it over and over like some of the better series out there.

Bitten is a total bomb. I would not recommend this at all. The special effects are stupid, the characters are washed out and the plot is non existent. I went as far as to watch season 2 of this and it was even worse. You might buy this and watch it once but it will sit on the shelf after that... it's not something your going to "get in to" or "care about" enough to want to watch over and over.

Not as good as season one but good enough I will check out season three. This is a great comedy/drama and keeps me laughing from start to finish. I think it will appeal to a corrections audience and inmate audience but this so well written and the story moves along so well that just about any person with a sense of humor will like it. There is some nudity, adult themes, and language so this is not for kids or anyone who is soft nerved.

This series was a big bomb. Even though it's a tv series I would call it a bad B movie. Bad special effects, poor story structure, and the characters are too washed out. You might buy this and watch it once (if you can stomach your way through it), but it's not something you will want to watch again and again.

I liked all 4 of the movies on this dvd set. I can't say that they are the greatest hits ever but if you just want something to entertain yourself on a rainy day this will do the trick and the price is right.

This was a total pain in the rear to install, set up and maintain. The instructions read like a child's riddle book and left me pulling my hair out. I frequently install new technology at my home with no problems so dealing with this was very irritating.

This is my second Dexter Schlage entry handle. The lock wore out on the first unit after 2 years. I'm single so there's not a lot of traffic through this door. I went ahead a tried this second one because I'm on a budget and these seem to be the cheap, yet still quality locks. So far the second one seems to be holding up ok. If the second one wears out as fast as the first one with the little to no traffic at my house I will buy one of the expensive brands and leave an updated review.Overall they were both easy to install and are very attractive.

This is a very fruity scent and some may find it's scent strength a bit on the overpowering side. If smells bother you might avoid this one. As far as effectiveness it keeps the odors and wetness down for just under 20 hours. I goes on smoothly and doesn't stain my shirts.

I like this deodorant. The scent is a bit on the fruity side and strong when you first put it on. The scent seems to dissipate after an hour. It is very effective and stopping odors for about 24 hours. I don't know if it works beyond that because I shower every day.

It works great. It goes on smooth and doesn't stain my shirts. I love the scent as it's different but not overpowering. Also it's nicer than the typical fruity or sporty scents that most deodorant is known for.

Works great on my elbow. I got a large. It helps support the joint and all your muscles, tendons, etc. It actually helped relieve chronic pain I was having. My only complaint is the sizing. I bought a large and I have average to small sized girth arms. So if my small arms are wearing a large, I can't imagine what size an average girthed mans arms would need. I don't think ACE's sizes are industry appropriate.

This are very nice for spreading pastels but they are too expensive for what they are. I've found many alternative sponges that work even better than this. I feel the package should have double the product for this price.

These are great colored pencils and I had lots of fun coloring with them. I bought some of the adult coloring books which are really popular right now with artists. These pencils colored evenly and flowed across the page smoothly. I'm bad about breaking them but I do that with all brands I try so I don't think this is an issue with the brand. These are definitely suitable for kids or students and work fine for basic art needs.

These are much coarser than what I was expecting a "medium" grit to be, but they did work on the plastic I was sanding. Size wise these are also a bit smaller than the standard drywall sanding sponges by 3M so these might be nicer for hobby/craft people.

These are perfect for mixing paints for my arts n crafts. You can use them for tons of other craft ideas. I don't use them for medicine but I'm sure they would be ok for that purpose. As far as using them to hold ketchup or other dips, this 3/4 ounce is a bit too small for that. You might want a 1.5 or 2 ounce.

This is an another awesome scent from Yankee. I would describe is as more a sweet smell. I find that most people in my home enjoy it. I get very few negative reactions from this scent. I love it and will order this again.
Another awesome comfort aroma. I really enjoyed this one and have ordered it several times. Most people will enjoy this. It's very rich, hearty and good anytime of the year.

I really like this fire pit. It comes with a cover to keep it dry when not in use. It's also fairly light weight, enough that I can carry it by myself... I'm a female with a chronic shoulder injury so this is an important quality in any large item. It has several vent holes to allow the heat and light to flow freely. I highly recommend this for small backyards or patios where large  bonfires are not possible.

I LOVE THESE!!! They are made of a tough, durable yet flexible plastic material similar to vintage Tupperware but BETTER! They don't stain with tomato and grease like other storage containers and have 3 compartments for lunch foods. I highly recommend these for reusable lunch containers. I just wish they came in 5 packs instead of the 4 pack.

These are nice "blackout" curtains for a bedroom. They keep the light out and I'm a night time worker so blocking out the sun during the day is very important to me. I don't really see a purpose for the tan extensions at the bottom.

This doesn't have all the bells and whistles of other rangefinders out there but it works and gets the job done. It is easy to open, operate, and change the batteries. Accuracy is very good. I would definitely recommend this for the hunter or craftsman who is measuring distances. If you just want something simple and easy to operate this is it.

I love the Farberware 15 piece knife set! THe block & knives are easy to clean and the knives are very attractive. I don't put mine in the dishwasher but rather wash them by hand to keep them looking nice. They are very sharp and cut very nicely. I would only change this and ad another paring knife to this set as it only comes with one.

This blanket is super soft, warm, and light weight. It is very comfortable. My only complaint is that I've had ones made from this material before and it is so thin that it eventually starts developing holes. For the time being it is very nice and I will continue enjoying it. I give it 4 stars for the soft feel.

I love these! The lenses are super dark!!! You can't find dark lenses like this in the stores. I get migraine headaches so any sunlight is devastating for me. I LOVE wearing these as they as super mega dark. I can drive all day with these and not get headaches.

These are very small and some came with broken spokes. I would not recommend these for large tomato plants, but only smaller varieties. Make sure to check the measurements BEFORE ordering these. They are not the large ones you see at the stores.
This is one of my most favorite perfumes. It smells GREAT, is affordable and comes in a generous portion. I was so happy to see it's still being made after all these years.
Cheap and small! This is a very small container so check your measurements before buying this. Also it is cheaply made and the lid doesn't fit right. I would not recommend this at all.

This is a very POWERFUL reflective tape. It's adhesive is very unforgiving so make sure you want it where you are putting it. The reflectivity is one of the highest I've seen. I use this on my front yard fence posts to keep the neighbors from running my fence down. This tape really lights them up!!!! I also have a couple squares on my mailbox.

Great product! This carpet tape is sticky on one side and rubber like on the other. You put the sticky side on the rug/mat and the rubbery side will touch the floor and prevent skidding/slipping/sliding. I'm using this on my front door mat and my bathroom rug. I'm very pleased.
My dog loves this! I love the color (cinnamon). I have 3 German Shepherds and they all share it throughout the day. It's washable, plushy and my dogs seem to think it's very comfortable!
This is very attractive and gives my kitchen a nice warm glow. I use the 40 watt antique Edison mercury bulb in mine. It's very quaint and welcoming without using a lot of power.

I love these! I have two in use in my house and it keeps me from accidentially hitting a switch and messing up all the clocks. There are little air holes on it so you can stick a pencil inside to flip the switch without taking it off.

I love this. Those stumpy little cables that come with cellphones are ok if you don't need to use the phone while it's charging. This awesome 10 foot cable reaches anywhere and is great for use while on the couch or in bed.
The shade is made of fabric. Good luck getting this to work without the bulb being too close to the wall or fabric shade.
It has a nice smell but it is WEAK and doesn't last. I would recommend something else like KOE if you are wanting something concentrated. This is NOT concentrated.
This is very uncomfortable and the various materials it is constructed itch like crazy!!!
Awesome! It fits regular switch plates perfectly and does exactly what it says it does!

3:03 Mins This battery charger is really great and fast. It has 12000mAh capacity. It's not as light weight as my other ones but this one sure has some power.I like the style of this one. It has Faux Leather textured outside casing. I got black but you have 4 great colors to choose from. It's durable, sturdy and another great thing about this battery charger is it's scratch-resistant. It also has 5 LED light for charging status indication.mAh (Milli amps Hour) is important because it's the easiest way to distinguish the strength or capacity of a battery. The higher the mAh, the longer the battery will last. Batteries with different mAh ratings are interchangeable. If your battery is rechargeable then the mAh rating is how long the battery will last per charge. Here's an example that best describes what mAh is.Think of a cars gas tank.  Voltage is how much gas is being used, and mAh is the size of the gas tank.  The bigger the gas tank (mAh) rating the longer the device will run. If your battery is rechargeable, then think of the gas tank as refillable (rechargeable).It seems that the smaller and light weight power banks the less mAh and the heavier the more mAh it is. At least that seems to be so with the ones that I have or have seen. Anyway, over all it does the job for home or office and I have not had any issues with it so far and have not observed any flaws.â–ºi received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased review. i was not influenced by anyone in any way of my opinion of this product.

What is PU leather?PU leather, sometimes described as split leather is a material made with a split leather backing covered with a layer of polyurethane (hence the term "PU leather") that is applied to the surface and then embossed. PU leather represents the look and feel of genuine leather but it's not. PU material is far less durable, considerably cheaper in cost, and may not last long if used often.So with that said, that would be my only concern for now.I think that the price is about right, I think it will last for a while as long as you take proper care of it and maybe just use when time is appropriate.â–º I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased review. 1:52 Mins I was able to fit my S4 in with it's cover as well as fit my main 2 credit cards, my ID and some dollar bills. What is PU leather?PU leather, sometimes described as split leather is a material made with a split leather backing covered with a layer of polyurethane (hence the term "PU leather") that is applied to the surface and then embossed. PU leather represents the look and feel of genuine leather but it's not. PU material is far less durable, considerably cheaper in cost, and may not last long if used often.So with that said, that would be my only concern for now.I think that the price is about right, I think it will last for a while as long as you take proper care of it and maybe just use when time is appropriate.â–º I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased review. *2.5 stars*When the nicest thing you can think of about a story is, "Well, it wasn't that bad" then I think you have a problem.I'm not going to lie, the first two chapters were ROUGH. There is an alternating POV, which I normally love, but the first two chapters were near mirrors of each other, just from different perspectives. There was almost no new information, and I was preparing for a VERY bumpy ride. Fortunately, it improved a bit from there, but not all the way to "like" for me.Mason, for some reason, is obsessed with his lack of money and keeping up appearances. He insists on pretending that he is well off, and he hides the fact that he has to work for enough money to get the tutoring that he needs. This all made no sense to me because I went to a pretty elite college and most people there were saving their pennies for beer money and working during the summers or on weekends. The whole "rich kids are the cool kids" was too "Pretty In Pink" for my taste.Carter has a bizarre relationship with his parents. His dad wants him to follow in the family business and doesn't want to face facts that his son is gay, and Carter wants to be a photographer. His mom appears timid and a little afraid of her husband. I didn't get the characterizations of Carter's parents (and their weird 180 in their personalities near the end), and I didn't fully get the chemistry between Carter and Mason. It seemed a bit forced for my taste.While this book was a quick read, and honestly pretty pleasant overall, it had lots of cringe-worthy issues for me. Solidly 2.5 stars.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

*3.5 stars*A.M. Arthur loves angst. She loves it so much that she usually doesn't know where to stop, and her characters end up getting murdered while escaping drug addicted mothers WHILE overcoming dyslexia, or something to that effect. There is good angst and there is bad angst, and this author always just steps over the line for me. This book was less angsty (but think about the scale here!), which I really appreciated.I really enjoyed the slow way that the relationship between Boxer and Riley developed. Riley is hesitant to trust and very skittish, having lots of baggage in his past. Boxer is VERY patient, very giving, and extremely kind. He is a gentle giant, and he uses his calm nature to win Riley's trust and bring out his kinky side.A warning for all readers, there is a near non-con scene here so if that is a trigger for you, be forewarned. Other than that, I really enjoyed seeing Riley come into his own and discover his toppy side. I think the sex could have been a bit hotter and a bit more confident, if I'm being honest, but it was still pretty decent.Communication-wise, these guys were very good. However, my main issue is that I just didn't feel that special umph of a 4 or 5 star book. These guys were nice together, but not something I'll think on later.I can't wait to read Elliot's story, though. That poor guy... now THERE I'll be expecting some major angstage!**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

A little historical, a little paranormal, a little fantasy, a little cowboy, a little kinky... and a whole lot of AWESOME!! Holy shiznit, I loved this. When Marie Sexton and I get our mind-meld thing going, she can do no wrong.This is another book that I started in the bath, and I didn't want to ever get out. I read until I was all pruney... I got ultra-pruney for you, Marie Sexton!Song of Oestend takes place in a fictional historical western town. It is pretty similar to our wild west, with a culture like our Native Americans, but with a paranormal twist: wraiths rise up and kill those who are unprotected at night.This story was very beautiful. A very slow burn romance with some expected and some unexpected twists. First of all, I didn't see the type of BDSM coming... and I loved it. I have a huge weakness for the bigger guy being the bottom, especially if they have a place in their kinky hearts for being bossed around, ESPECIALLY if they are butt virgins! I mean, could it get any more perfect???The romance between Deacon and Aren was truly lovely. Tender, meaningful, interesting... just everything. The plot also worked. The ranch scenes were very atmospheric, and I got into it right away.Don't be scared by the mention of a menage scene. I'm not a big fan of menages but I was okay with the small play scene here. It was pretty hot, if I'm being honest.Gah, this was just SO well done and right up my alley! Thanks you for delivering such a scrumptious read, Marie Sexton!!

I hate to upset fans of Me Before You (hell, I'm a huge fan of Me Before You), but this was a very underwhelming sequel. I think if you are expecting the emotional punch of the first book you are going to be sorely disappointed.I'm not ashamed to say that Me Before You had me up reading until very late at night and then crying my eyes out until very early the next morning. It was the kind of book that sticks with you, the kind of book that is extremely hard to follow up. It ended on a very powerful note, so any book that calls itself a "sequel" has to match that kind of power. This didn't, not even close.We follow Lou's life a year and a half after the death of Will, and we see what her life has become. Honestly, I didn't enjoy this Lou very much. Gone is any spark, any vitality, any humor, and without those aspects of her personality I had trouble staying engaged with her. I didn't like this pushover Lou, and I barely recognized her from the previous book.Her life is wholly depressing. Lou is stuck completely in this sort of limbo, and reading about her mostly boring day to day things felt one note and tedious. Lou's family details, like her mother's newfound feminism and her sister's meddling, seemed contrived and almost silly. I didn't get what those side plots added to the story, and I didn't find them compelling.Lou's love interest was just... there. He was sexy in a classic romance way- the patient, motorcycle-riding savior- but I simply didn't feel the chemistry between him and Lou. It felt like a relationship without weight, certainly without the intensity of Lou's relationship with Will. If you are going to present a love interest to follow the one from Me Before You, it would have to be absolutely epic... this wasn't.And don't get me started on Lily. No spoilers from me, but Lily just irritated me to no end. She was SO selfish, and I struggled to feel much sympathy for her rich girl plight. I know the author tried to give us reasons to empathize with Lily, especially near the end with her convoluted backstory, but I was rooting for Lou to branch out and have more of the story-line to herself.However, this book's greatest crime, IMO, was that it was boring. I kept putting this book down and starting other stories, only to force myself back to this one after a few hours. And though this book has brief moments of greatness, and it wasn't bad or offensive in any way, it also failed to grab me the way I was expecting it to. After the way Me Before You gripped me, I think this was the biggest let down of all.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

*4.5 stars*Woah, Vanessa North, pain sluts are SO not my kink, but you made pain sexy and you OWNED this book!I solemnly swear that Vanessa North is the ONLY author that can make me like first person, present tense. When other authors fail and make this format painful to read, this author thrives. She has skills, ladies and gentlemen. I am a HUGE fan of this author and Rough Road just confirmed why that is, yet again.I was interested in Kinky Eddie from Double Up and I LOVED him in this story. Eddie is amazing. Rich, flamboyant, loyal, and knows what he wants, I fell in love with every swishy ounce of him. While his pain kink made me a wee bit uncomfortable at times (some of the scenes made me want to run for an ice pack!), I recognize that it turned the MCs on, so, in turn, it turned me on. Despite the kink thing, I just loved being inside his head, and I loved his interactions with Wish.Wish. I adored him, too. First of all, I LOVE me an age gap, and I really liked how Wish didn't care one iota about the pretty sizable difference in age between him and Eddie. He was sexy, self-confident, and kinky as hell.The tension in the story was pretty much the perfect amount. Everything felt effortless and flowed naturally. Sure, I could have used a bit more length (heh), but overall, this author didn't make a misstep. While this isn't a gushy romance, it was romantic enough for me for sure, and I think it reflected accurately on the characters.For all fans of this author, get excited for this one. It's a winner.*Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review*

*4.5 stars*Yes please, daddy.One of my top favorite kinks of all time is daddy kink. In fact, I think it is my favorite kink in the BDSM umbrella. And this was some top notch kinkery right here.I think I highlighted half of this story, I loved it so much. When you combine daddy kink with a butt virgin you make me a VERY happy camper.How much do I have to pay to get a full length daddy kink story out of these two authors??? After reading this, I'm willing to pony up the dough.

Everyone has their favorite kinks. As some of you may know (those that pay attention to the nonsense I blurt out of my face), I am drawn to some specific kinks in the BDSM realm, namely domestic discipline, daddy kink, chastity, and humiliation kink. I actually cringe reading about flogging or whipping, and tying someone up does nothing for me. I get why some people love certain things, but a lot of those things are not for me and I don't love reading about them.If you analyze it further, all of my kinks are in the power control category. I just like it when someone has control over else that has nothing to do with pain or restraints. With domestic disciple, the idea that someone else is in charge and is keeping you in line feels just so... freeing, in a way. Now, in real life I don't think I could handle that, but I TOTALLY get the desire and it is very easy for me to get into a DD character's headspace.I found both main characters to be really, really interesting. The beginning was a little hard to read. Anyone could recognize the signs of an abusive relationship between Scott and Aiden, but I liked how the author made it a slow progression, like a real abusive relationship, so that we saw why Aiden was sucked in. I wanted to save him soooo badly, but it set the stage nicely for Aiden and Keaton's relationship. Keaton was a great guy. He was patient, loving, and gentle, and he took his role as a partner and DD top very seriously. I liked how he let things sort of evolve between him and Aiden and didn't push him too quickly.I did have some minor complaints. For one, Aiden was almost unbearably bratty at times, and I thought that he acted too immature at certain parts of the story. Also, I didn't get the weird personality shifts in Scott. I didn't find him acceptable in any way, and I wasn't sure if the author was trying to set up a future book with him as the MC so she decided redeem him a bit. It was odd.Overall, this book is a very quick, lovely read about the journey to a DD relationship. All DD fans should try this one.

*3.5 stars*Woah... I mean, where to begin? Do you like angst? I mean ANGST? I'm not talking about baby angst, I'm talking about serious, advanced-level angst. Like addiction, mental illness, abuse, rape, neglect, priesthood... the whole angst package.I'm a huge, HUGE fan of Mel Bossa. Mel Bossa can write her ass off, and is, to be frank, above and beyond the skills of most writers out there right now. This story is... just insane, and she makes it so compelling that you won't be able to put it down for a second, I promise you that.For all of it's brilliance in writing and amazing, crystal-clear characters, it is also probably medically wrong, or at least it felt that way to me. The whole mental illness thing, which was barely touched upon in the blurb, is a HUGE factor in the book. I felt iffy about its treatment, and I'm not sure how I felt about the whole religion thing as well.I also still can't tell if this book is pro or anti-religion? Maybe both? Either way, religion plays a strong roll in this book, so if that is a turn off for you, be aware.The part of the story, however, that bumped my rating down is that I found Ryde and Alister's relationship to be so obsessive and insane that it was almost scary. To be fair, the characters know that their relationship is not normal, but it was hard to relate to such a desperate, strange, crazy dynamic. I'm not sure what these two had for each other, but I'm sure it isn't healthy.Again, this book is extremely hard to rate because it was so beautiful in it's gritty, screwed-up-ness that part of me wants to 5 star it, but another part of me was saying, "NOOOOOO" for a large portion of the story. I think if you are a Mel Bossa fan, like me, you have to at least try this one. It was a unique, special, difficult, interesting read... just throw in some adjectives and pick up the book.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

*4.5 stars*Lesson learned: never doubt K.J. Charles.There is no getting around the fact that the start of this book is sort of slow. At first, I was feeling a little iffy about the story and having a really hard time connecting to the characters, which was freaking me out because this author is usually SO on point... like ALL of the time.Then things started to get interesting.The plot of the book is deceptively simple. A poor man comes into a fortune and needs to be tutored in the ways of London high society. However, the author makes this story so utterly compelling and way more nuanced than you'd expect.The character development really makes this story come alive. The MCs are such divided, flawed characters and I adored every bit of them. But as much as I loved Henry's rags-to-riches story, it was Julius who stole my heart. Julius was so contained, so in charge, that I just DIED with joy when Henry broke through that exterior, bit by naughty bit.This series has so much potential. I liked how the side characters were included (and how their own individual stories were teased) but didn't take away from the main couple's story. K.J. Charles struck just the right balance.The writing was sharp, the story was engrossing... I couldn't ask for anything more.**Copy provided in exchange for an honest review**

*4.5 stars*The 4th book in the Lost and Founds series takes place in 2002 at Burning Man. Now, I was only vaguely familiar with Burning Man before this book (I watched a very sandy flash mob marriage proposal there on youtube and that was the extent of it), but with a little help from Wikipedia, I got the gist. Burning Man is SO the logical place for Vin to be. It is eccentric and full of life and energy, so I wasn't surprised at all that he gravitated there. Through a set of unusual and fortuitous circumstances (duh, it's a Lost and Founds book), Vin meets a man named Alistar, who recognizes Vin and insists that Vin king him.I think I start off every book in the series the same way. I always sort of loath the main character, the guy getting Kinged, for the first half of the book. The Lost Kings always seem so selfish, so indifferent to my man, Vin Vanbly, and his obvious sacrifices. I'm always indignant on his behalf, and with King John, it was no different. Alistar is eager, way too eager, and too big, too inquisitive, just too. I had trouble loving him, and I was impressed when Vin found a way to love him.For about 40% of the book I was feeling a bit checked out. The writing was amazing, but I was getting frustrated with the back and forth between Vin and Alistar. Then, things took a turn for the worst. Something HAPPENS. Something big. After that point, when the action started really going, I could NOT put this book down.Many things happened that really made me love this book. I learned to love Alistar, like really love him, which I doubted I could do at the start. We also learn so much about Vin, more than ever before, though everything we learn about him is heartbreaking. We see Vin's humor, his resilience, his self-loathing, his generosity, and his spirit. There are some magical elements in this one, to be sure, but I liked them a great deal more than in The Butterfly King.That ending though... be prepared for a major cliffy. You'll finish this book not sure if you want to strangle Edmond Manning for leaving you in the lurch or love him for dreaming up such an emotional, well conceived story.**Copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review**

Ava March, my sweet, sweet Ava March. You are usually so spot on! Perhaps my own personal feelings came into play here but I wanted to SLAP Gabriel for most of the story!I'm the kind of girl who doesn't forget easily. You screw me over and I'm going to glare at you for the next bazillion times that we see each other. Now, I'm too much of a wimp to actually say or do anything, but you can bet I'm telling you off inside my head. Harshly.When Gabriel broke Anthony's heart as a teenager, I was ready to see some serious groveling the next time they met face to face. I was almost gleeful waiting for it. It never came. When Anthony sort of sucked it up and was friendly to Gabriel, giving him another chance so easily, I was like WHAAAAA?? I would have been one cold lady in those same shoes.Gradually my ire wore off. Gradually. But I still didn't like how Gabriel played hot and cold with Anthony, and I have no idea why Anthony put up with his crap.In terms of their secrets, I thought that Anthony's was a pretty clever plot element, but I was irritated by Gabriel's excuses and borderline abusive behavior.As usual, Ava March's writing was extremely readable and her sex scenes were hot (though less kinky than usual). I liked this story, in many ways, simply because Ava March wrote it and she is such a queen of historicals. But in terms of this series, this one was fairly lackluster.**Copy provided in exchange for an honest review**

So beautiful that it will make you cry. This is Kim Fielding's best work, I'm telling you.I'm going to tell you folks a story about patience.Once, I started a book by one of my favorite authors. It was a little slow going at first, and I wasn't sure if I was going to connect to the main characters. I was pretty sure that it was going to be a middling read for me, despite the gorgeous prose. But I stuck with it and, little by little, it just grew on me.At about 30% in I was feeling pretty good about it. By 50% in, I had a serious crush on the story. At 75%, it was love. By 100% I was crying because I didn't want to let it go.This is absolutely not a razzle-dazzle story. It isn't in your face in any way. The sex is hot and sweet, but you wouldn't read it for that alone, and there is almost zero drama in the story. It is simply a character study of two men in a small town who have lived and lost and how they come to fit in each others lives.I'm not kidding when I say it isn't action-packed. These guys spend most of their time tending bar, fixing things around the inn where the story takes place, doing mundane chores, really. But you know what? You will love reading about the mundane stuff because, at the same time, the real stuff is happening beneath the surface.Jimmy... just such a complex, perfectly imagined character. He starts off the book coming across as a aloof drifter, but then he becomes so much more. We find out what shaped him, and I simply loved having only his POV. Sometimes single POV books can be tricky, but it worked here.Shane, he just stole my heart. Disabled from an accident, he is still unflaggingly brave, loyal, interesting... I can't stop thinking of positive descriptors. I loved his sense of community and family and how willing he was to open his heart to Jimmy.If you are a Kim Fielding fan or a fan of well-crafted, slow burn stories, you must pick this one up. I can't stop thinking about the characters and you won't be able to either.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

Retellings are so hard to get right, but when you combine a retelling from a borderline unlikeable character and you don't add anything new to the table, things go downhill VERY quickly.Just in case anyone was wondering, this CANNOT be read as a standalone. It is completely dependent on Every Day for context and plot. In fact, if you are expecting any sort of story structure, look elsewhere."Another Day" jumps around from notable event to notable event from "Every Day", just from Rhiannon's perspective. And let me tell you, I almost wish I'd never gotten a glimpse at her POV. First of all, her relationship with Justin was painful to read. PAINFUL. It is so clearly an emotionally abusive relationship that I wanted to shake Rhiannon. Justin is an epic douche, and I simply wanted to punch him in the nads the entire time.But what was most difficult to read were the details about Rhiannon herself. She is just less... special than she seemed in the first. More shallow, more insecure, less unique. It was disappointing, if I'm being honest.Despite knowing some more unsavory things about Rhiannon from this book, I would still have said that this story had merit except for the fact that this retelling brings very little extra to the table. The purpose of a companion piece is to shed new light and bring new information to the original book. Instead, I think this book and this author tried to milk an already successful book for more than it could give (ahem, "Grey").**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

This series of Heidi's is a tricky one for me. I really want to love each book, but I always have some stumbling blocks that make me pull back on my ratings.I was pretty much dying for this book before it came out. I mean, BAZ AND ELIJAH!! So much angst, so much sexual tension, so much POTENTIAL! My rich, dreamy, cool guy gets it on with my angst-ball kinky sex snark-monster... le sigh. But while parts of this book were pretty awesome, I also didn't enjoy other parts of it.I'll start with some good stuff. Baz and Elijah don't skimp on the personality or the emotions. I mean, the FEELZ in this one... just off the charts. I really got a sense of Elijah's feeling of loneliness (hence the title, duh), guilt, and anguish from all that he's been through. I liked the fact that he was skittish and afraid, especially around Baz. Baz was also great as the reformed player struggling to find his place and path, and also trying to come back from some pretty serious physical and psychological injuries. Really interesting, well thought-out stuff here.So what's my beef? Well, for one thing, I found this book to be overly long and somewhat preachy-feeling. The preachiness is something that I've come to expect with this series. A lot of heavy-handedness with the messages of openmindedness, which is a great message, to be sure (!), but it gets a little after-school-special after a while. As far as pacing, the story really dragged towards the end for me, and I struggled a bit to pick it up again. This book took me DAYS to read, which isn't ever a great sign.Also, there were too many side characters for my liking. I like a lot of focus on my MCs and this book felt spread too thin. The side characters get a ton of playtime, and while I like visiting with characters from previous books of Heidi's, I really want to get to know the two MCs more and I sort of want to ditch the distractions.While this book was good, and I'm sure it will please most Heidi fans, it wasn't the Elijah-Baz explosion of awesome that I was looking for.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

If your favorite Market Garden books were the ones featuring Nick and Spencer, than this book is for you.Do you remember Red Tie guy from Nick's book? He is back and needs a spanking in the latest HOT edition from the Market Garden series.In my opinion, this isn't as intense as Nick and Spencer's books and the chemistry isn't quite as strong. However, it is a surprisingly tender story about the evolution of a BDSM-themed relationship. I liked both MCs and the interplay between them. The mix of the real life driver/employee relationship with the bedroom dominant/submissive relationship made for an interesting dynamic. However, the strength of this book lay in the sex scenes. Like all of the books in this series, it delivered on the heat. Hello limo scenes! I love the way these authors write BDSM and they did a great job, once again, with this book.Though it made me a bit nostalgic for book 4 (my fave in the series), "If It Drives" was a very satisfying and successful read that set my Kindle on fire.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

3 very conflicted stars...Gahhh! What to say?! Parts of this story were REALLY good, just like the incredibly charming Knight of Ocean Avenue. However, parts of this book made me want to tear my hair out.Some people categorize this as a gay-for-you... it really isn't. Only someone deaf, dumb, and blind wouldn't have realized they were gay for 27 years when they secretly wacked off to yaoi and had trouble getting erections with women. Jim, come on, man.I liked Jim, overall. He was a very well-meaning, sexy, rough-edged guy who won me over throughout the course of the book, despite drunk driving...just NO, and faking a relationship with a woman who deserved better. I also liked Ken, the multi-talented doctor who feels pressure from his traditional mother to make a approved marriage. Their chemistry was... decent, though I've read much hotter, but I liked the contrast of them together. I also liked that they both had some history and mystery about them.What I didn't like was how Jim was so easily manipulated by everyone. He was like a puppet with other people pulling the strings for the majority of the book, and I HATED the fact that the two MCs didn't really get together until the very end of the story. Not nearly enough time, IMO, for them to develop "love" feelings; they just didn't spend enough one on one time together sober!!When I think about the particulars of this book, I get sort of angry. There are many of my pet peeves present in this story. But when I think about my overall feeling that I got while reading this book, I realize that I liked it, despite some of the choices that the author made. Apparently, I have a soft spot for this series.Looking forward to the next book where the two characters actually date EACH OTHER a little bit instead of other people.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

*2.5 stars*Charlie Cochet, why did you do this to me?! Ash and Cael's story was supposed to be epic!!I'm having a pity party over here, folks. I've been waiting on this story for the past few mediocre THIRDS books, and I was honestly expecting greatness. I've seen some glowing reviews, so I guess some people loved this one, but for me I think I'm being generous with my rating.What really bothered me was Ash's lackluster and totally wimpy excuses as to why he wouldn't or couldn't be with Cael. It was just... lame. I've heard some excuses in my day but this just took the cake. Gimme something real, something that makes sense, because you guys have been pining after each other for YEARS!Also, there is barely any sexual tension in this story. There are a lot of miscommunications and lots of missed opportunities, but sexual tension is just out the window. It was all so... boring.And was I the only one who thought that Ash treated Cael like a little kid, or a little girl? He always calls him "blushing" or "sweet" or "cute". Cael felt very neutered for me. I didn't get the fire and passion between them, and the relationship dynamics felt very M/F romance in a bad way.The plot... ugh. It is getting so muddled and confusing. Stop complicating the story, Charlie Cochet! This isn't Inception over here!I think I need to tap out of the THIRDS world. When my favorite character isn't even the main focus of the book (love you Dex, my boo), I think it's time to move on to greener pastures. Though this book had some bright moments, I felt mostly irritated and let down when I finished.*Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review*

Every once in a while I want to read something low drama. No pain, no angst, just two people meeting, romancing, and falling in love. This fit the bill perfectly.I want to state for the record that this story is NOT perfect. Some might call it slow (it is a pretty slow-burn romance) and it has a very abrupt cliffhanger ending, but I still found it utterly charming and totally smile-worthy.I sort of knew I was going to like this when I realized that James was as close to a virgin as you can get, despite fathering a child at 14. He was blushing, inexperienced, and really adorable. I liked the leisurely way that James and Gabriel got to know each other, and I liked the slooow corruption of James. *grins* I'm a dirty girl.Sometimes I'm not into meddling family members, but I really liked James's son, Dylan. He was supportive and just everything you'd want your son to be. I give Dylan the highest of fives!Easy to read, nice dialogue... I simply enjoyed this one. Just make sure you are willing to wait in anticipation for the next one before starting!**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review**

*3.5 stars*Remember that time I read the first five books in the Fever series in three days and dreamed about the characters for months? I certainly do. This series will always have a special place in my heart, and though I think that the series ended perfectly at the end of Shadowfever, I will never complain about more Mac, Barrons, or even more Dani.I also maintain that Karen Marie Moning is a genius. She created a world that worked so amazingly well and enraptured me so much that I feel like I own her a boot kissing. I'm so just grateful for the reading experiences that she gives me.When many readers hated Iced, I was one that stood firmly in the "woohoo!" camp. It wasn't perfect, for sure, but it was still pretty freakin' awesome.This book... a little less so.Yes, there were some amazing twists and turns, and yes, the writing was still very engaging, but I'm with other reviewers that said that they didn't like Mac as much in this book. She was certainly more... whiny? Bratty? Immature? Not overly so, but not exactly what I was expecting.It also felt very much like a middle book in a series because there are a LOT of cliffhangers at the end of this one, which was just maddening. I need the next book, like yesterday, please oh please.Still rounding up because I read this in basically one day. Moning just does it for me.

I hate to crap on newish writers, but this just didn't work for me.This novella was a pretty political story about homophobia in the Republican party and a budding romance between a chief of staff and his intern. For the majority of the story, the MCs are not dating or really interacting, which I found to be a bit odd. I also wasn't really into the plot in general, though I thought the concept was cool.My first issue with the story is that the writing style was a little awkward. It felt a little too... planned? Ostentatious? Distant? Hard to describe, but I didn't connect at all with the author's voice.However, my real issue was with the characters. I found Brad to be sort of mean-spirited and self-involved, and I wasn't rooting for him at all in the end. I'm not sure what Sam saw in him, and I'm not sure really why they even got together (no sex content, BTW). They didn't have a lot in common, and their interactions were stilted and formal.There were also a lot of plot elements left unexplained or unexplored which I had an issue with.Not horrible but not the story for me.**Copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review*

I was a big fan of Kursonâ€™s prior non fiction book Shadow Divers, and this is another excellent book about a similar topic. Pirate Hunters includes some of the same characters who populated Shadow Divers, but this time they are looking for an even more elusive quarry: a real pirate ship. I was not aware how few of these ships have ever been located. It makes sense after reading this story: pirates were secretive, and never advertised their location, their ships, or their cargo. After a space of a few years, a ship on the bottom of the ocean can be completely covered over, and never seen again. To find any remnant would be a major historical feat.Kurson gives a lot of background information on history, pirates, the Caribbean, diving, searching for sunken ships, and the men who do this. I enjoyed every page. He makes the material interesting, understandable, and entertaining. I was not particularly interested in pirates when I picked up this book, but before the end of the first chapter, I was hooked. Perhaps the author occasionally adds a little drama to his descriptions, but the story he tells is a true one, and the technical details are accurate. I could read anything this author writes, and be entertained as well as informed.I recommend this well written book to everyone, pirate lover or not. You will be sucked into the story, and come out on the other end with a lot of knowledge, some happy memories, and perhaps an ambition to do a little wreck diving yourself. At the very least, you will remember this as a very good book.

This is a medium duty hammer tacker that handles 3/8 inch staples with ease. I used it to staple grade D building paper to wooden studs, and after a few swings I figured out just how much effort I had to put into the swing so that the staples would bury themselves. It weighs just under five pounds empty, and that is the proper weight for the job. The handle is well contoured and textured for my hand, which is small for a man. My wife has very small hands, and found this tool to be too large and heavy for her, but she doesnâ€™t share my love of toolsâ€¦I have arthritis in all my joints, and this tool did not bother me in any way. After tacking up the paper, I went over the staples with a hammer, to make sure they were all buried. It took very little time, since most of them were fine. It was an unnecessary step, but my OCD took over.The tool is well made, of quality materials, and feels solid in my hand. The staples load easily, and it did not jam once during my single day use. I would rate this as a solid and reliable hammer tacker.

This is a highly readable novel about the aftermath of a terrible auto accident. The driver finds herself in a mysterious diner, peopled by dead celebrities, a kindly owner (Vinnie), and a mysterious, kindly man who turns out to be, well, I wonâ€™t give away the whole story. We learn the story behind her life, how she came to be in the accident, and how her life was full of misunderstanding and unnecessary suffering. In other words, she is just like every other human. She is full of plans for her future, but God has other plans for her.The story is well written. The characters are realistic, at least in their personalities, and the story moves along quickly. I read the entire story while on a long plane flight, and it made the flight seem very short. It is a Christian novel, and it is realistic without being didactic or preachy.Most of the action takes place in the diner while she lies in a coma. There are many flashbacks to her past, and her parentsâ€™ past, which help her understand how she got there, and help her to make the most important decision of her life. The story is full of Godâ€™s saving grace, hope and love. This is not great literature, or a sure-fire best seller, but that is irrelevant. This book brought me closer to God, and that was its great purpose. It can do the same for you.

This is a highly unusual subject for a graphic novel. It consists of short scenes in the life of Iwan James, a GP in a small Welsh town. The doctor doubts himself, struggles with severe obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), hates and resents his senior partner Dr. Smith, and obviously yearns for the attractive Dr. Lois. Dr. Smith mistreats and frequently puts him down, especially in front of Lois. Iwan fantasizes about telling Dr. Smith off, but never summons the courage to stand up for himself. He mostly gets along with his wife, although he feels unhappy in the marriage. He dreams of buying yet another bicycle (his wife tells him he doesnâ€™t need to have four bikes). The story is intensely personal, with flashbacks to his youth, the early days of his marriage, and above all his struggle with self-doubt, a common manifestation of OCD.The story is disjointed at times, with abrupt beginnings and endings. I had to check back sometimes when a character reappears after an absence of many pages. The artwork is ok, although details such as facial expressions are usually missing. As good literature does, this book reveals the inner life of a human being. Doctor Iwan is a pathetic creature at times, but who isnâ€™t?In one scene, while Iwan is laughing with Lois in their lounge, Dr. Smith enters and announces that â€œyou are way behind, Iwan, and losing us money.â€ That is his performance review for the day. When someone collapses on a bus nearby, Dr. Smith says he is too busy, and Iwan has to go, even though he is with a patient. Upon his return, he finds Dr. Smith reading the paper. Of course, Iwan had just left the nurse alone on the bus to patch up an uncooperative bleeding patient. His outrage is a bit tainted.This story is preoccupied with the psychology of the main character. The novel is more about obsessive compulsive disorder, and the daily struggles that OCD people face, than it is about a doctor.There are lots of patients in the book, ranging from tragic to annoying to menacing. You get to see what Iwan thinks about them. Some of the scenes make you cringe, some make you laugh, and some make you shake your head. Iwan is a real human being, and he exposes himself more than a doctor normally would. Most patients donâ€™t want to know all the stuff that might be going on in their doctorâ€™s heads. This book will show you what goes on in one doctorâ€™s mind. You may be sorry that you asked. Is Iwan a bad doctor? No, although he feels like a bad doctor. As a doctor once said, if you donâ€™t feel like a bad doctor sometimes, then you probably are one.

I relied on this guide as my sole real world book when travelling in New Zealand. It is colorful, with beautiful pictures, large pages and enthusiastic writing by natives who live there. I read the book before leaving on my vacation, and I felt very excited to be in one of the most beautiful places on earth. The great outdoors did not disappoint: this is an incredibly beautiful country. Unfortunately, the book might have been written by the New Zealand board of tourism. It heaps praise on things extraordinary, and equally on things quite ordinary. My final conclusion was that this is not a guide to be trusted, and I left it behind in Queenstown.The writing is technically competent and well organized. There is background information, not in detail, but adequate for a travel guide. The writers enthuse about their happy New Zealand history, Maori history (glossing over the violence) and culture, and how New Zealand is a nation â€œwith a proud tradition of enlightened social policies.â€ My conversations with New Zealandâ€™s people leads to a very different conclusion. There was plenty of sorrow in their history, and there is plenty of trouble today. A tourist can ignore this, and simply enjoy the sights and adventures. But if you get into conversation with the locals, youâ€™ll discover that life here is not any more problem free than it is in San Francisco or New York.The book directed me to several attractions that did not deserve a stop, especially museums. I did enjoy a few museums, but concluded that New Zealand is a country with natural wonders, and a paucity of manmade attractions.Some of my most sublime moments in country came while visiting places I had discovered in other sources. A written book is at a disadvantage when compared to online sources: each page adds weight and cost. For that reason, I hope that a written guide would select special sights and places. It just didnâ€™t work out that way with this guide, on this trip.I do not mean to condemn this book, because it has a lot of good information. I simply found the information was questionable at times. On vacation I do not have unlimited time, and after a few obvious mistakes, I had to discard this volume. I did not read the whole book, or visit the whole country. When I return, I will carry a different guide.

Lonely Planetâ€™s latest take on Scotland is a good review of the highlights, plus some sidelights that you might otherwise miss, covering the entire country. It is generally well written, by locals, in clear, concise language. It comes with the usual Lonely Planet mix of eco-tourism, subdued lefty attitude, and good basic research that make these guides so beloved by some, so loathed by others. If you are of a certain age, you already know what to expect. If you are under 35, you probably wonâ€™t read this review, because anything current about travel will be online, naturally and inevitably. As a co-worker explained to me recently, â€œWho would carry a book when they travel?â€ Having just stormed the aisles of a discount airline, I see her point. These days, you need to travel light.Still, when my cell phone battery is low, and my service provider warns me that I have exceeded my international data allowance, I still like to have a real world reference, one that doesnâ€™t need a cell plan or a signal. Call me regressive, but I love the feeling of real paper, even the heft of it. This guide fits the bill.With chapters on all of the major cities and regions, plus details about those boring practicalities, you could rely on this guide as a single stop guide. It does give good suggestions on food, lodging, and entertainment, plus overviews of the cities, attractions, and culture. I didnâ€™t find any significant errors in this guide during my travels. It did alert me to some things that my online links failed to highlight.Although I still used my cell phone for finding restaurants near me, and online maps, I felt reassured by having this guide in my bag. There were times when I didnâ€™t have a cell phone signal, and times when I just didnâ€™t want one. If you can relate to that, you should probably take this guide.

Oscillating tools are a bit mysterious. I didn't see a need for one, but once I got it, I began to use it  more and more. Now I donâ€™t remember how I did without it. Any cutting, sanding or grouting job that involves a small piece or a small place calls for the oscillator. Being a cheapskate and a skeptic, I bought mine at Harbor Freight. It works just fine.I didn't know at the time, but most of the expense with these tools is not in the purchase price. It is in the accessories. Imperial blades makes this metal and wood cutting blade, claiming that it can fit any oscillator out there. I canâ€™t verify that, but it is just fine on my Chicago Electric unit (Harbor Freightâ€™s brand). It fits snugly, cuts well, and hasn't worn out after a few Saturdays cutting wood with nails hidden inside. I am only a family handyman, not a pro. I use this episodically. For my purposes, this is a good blade. It doesn't stand out as any better than my previous blades, and I donâ€™t know if it will last a long time, but it easily cuts through metal and wood. Sixteen dollars seems like a lot for a single blade, but that is what the marketplace demands right now. Soon it will cost even more!

This book is well written, gripping, and fascinating. Sometimes it is sad or gruesome. It is accurate in the descriptions of medical details, surgical procedures, and the life of brain surgeons. If you like to think of your physician as a demi-god you should not read this book. If you can handle the truth, read on.As an anesthesiologist, I read with a mix of amusement and rueful resignation. Dr. Marsh is a true representative of his species, the neurosurgeon. They are by turns kind, irritating, cocky, courageous, arrogant, brilliant, obsessive, awe-inspiring, and lonely. They usually graduated at the top of their medical school class. Their residency did not end until they were well into their 30â€™s. Many hospitals have lots of pediatricians, intensivists, internists, and hospitalists, but they only have one neurosurgeon. Even in a field of doctors, a collection of brainy nerds, they stand alone.Their arrogance is undeniable. Henry Marsh relates how he was stuck in a line of shoppers at the grocery store and thinks with irritation that none of them could do what he just did today, so why does he have to wait behind them? Like fighter pilots or Special Forces, society is not comfortable with such people, but when we need them, we need them desperately. And we always need them.There is a moment before every invasive medical procedure when you could pause and contemplate the enormous consequences of failure. If you spend too much time doing that, you will end up paralyzed, and the patient will suffer. If you spend too much time thinking about the appalling human carnage that will result from surgery gone wrong, you will never take up the knife. No matter how skillful, knowledgeable, and careful you are, there will be carnage. No one knows this better than the neurosurgeon. To cut into a human brain takes enormous hubris. Every procedure includes the risk of death, but there are worse things than death. Most doctors will see worse-than-death only rarely during their career, but the neurosurgeon sees it often. It is the nature of their specialty. It is beyond extreme. For example, I induce a death-like coma in my patients daily, then rescue them from it. Yet I could not abide such a life of enormous risk.Dr. Marsh is a writer of depth and skill. He probably does everything well, if he does it at all. If you think that neurosurgery is fascinating, you should read this book.

This is a lightweight, slim-bodied protector for the i-Phone 6. It fits around the sides of the phone, and covers the back, but there is no protection for the glass, which is the part most likely to break. I think that the otter is a more protective (and expensive) solution, if you are really worried about damage. This is much smaller and lighter than an otter. You have to balance protection against size and weight. The edges are easy to grip, and provide a more positive feel than the naked phone itself. I did not test it by dropping the phone onto a hard surface, because I didnâ€™t want to risk one of these infernally expensive things. The case seems to be made of a resilient material, which is flexible but strong. It snaps on and off the phone easily. There are holes for all of the buttons and controls, as well as the camera. It does not interfere with the function of the i-Phone.My sons thought that the gold on this case was too gaudy for their tastes. It does have a reflective quality to it. I didnâ€™t mind, but I am not a fashion guy. It looks exactly like the picture, so you get what you see. I think that this device offers decent protection for your phone at a very reasonable price.

This is a well written, action packed novel that kept me reading compulsively until the end. It is full of suspense, and the main characters became people that I cared about, although they have major flaws. Although this is science fiction, there is a lot of real life detail about the importance of water in the western United States. I would have given this book five stars. But there are some problems.There is a lot of graphic violence, and graphic sex in this novel. The author has written books for young readers, but this is aimed at adults, and would not be appropriate for teens. The relationships between the main characters were not realistic, and required a long stretch of the readerâ€™s imagination. The author paints a bleak future for the United States, in line with the current beliefs of progressive environmentalists. His scenario of water scarcity is a real possibility, regardless of the debate over climate. The prospect of states going to war with each other, while still nominally part of the United States, presents another exercise for the imagination.I thought that the book was excellent in many details, but the problems make me reluctant to recommend this to many readers. If you are not put off by violence, and enjoy a wild tale, well told, this may be a great read for you.

This handy little speaker runs off of batteries, which can be recharged by USB or any AC outlet. It connects to your audio device via blue tooth or via an aux cable. As advertised, it allows you to enjoy external audio playback without draining your playback system's batteries.The setup was easy, intuitive and self explanatory, which was good, because the package insert was brief to the point of extinction. I charged the unit overnight, and the next morning had it playing in less than two minutes. The controls are on one end of the device, four simple buttons. Unfortunately the symbols that reveal the functions of these buttons are engraved into the buttons, black on black, which made them difficult to read, even with my glasses on. You can discover their function by pressing them, but this is a minor design flaw. The unit is very compact, lightweight, and portable.The sound is underwhelming, not as full or as voluminous as my simple PC speakers. You can't expect a concert hall for this price, but I expected more than I heard. Speakers are a highly variable personal product, and you should listen to them before buying, whenever you can. I would not buy this at the current price ($46.00), but might spring for them if they were under $30. (I received them for free through the vine program, in exchange for my review).

I was afraid this book would be a poorly written diatribe about Christians in a hostile world. Instead I encountered a well written, well documented account by an accomplished and professional author. I admit that I should have been better acquainted with Mr. Shortt, the religion editor of the Times Literary Supplement, and author of a biography of Rowan Williams. He writes clearly, concisely, and skillfully.The introductory and concluding sections are the best part of the book. Shortt makes some revealing statements.  Christianity is not a "western" religion, and most Christians are not westerners. By sheer numbers, Christians are the most persecuted people in the world today. Most telling is the revelation that secularism is being soundly trounced by religion in the public sphere of our world. Residents of the US and Europe may assume that the secular and scientific viewpoint is ascendant today. That is not a valid assumption.The middle chapters each deal with one country, or one region. They are comprised of a brief history, followed by a catalogue of oppressions and atrocities against Christians. The reading of these chapters is difficult, depressing, and ultimately numbing. There is not a strict narrative structure to the bulk of the book. It is in large part a summary of events. This is not a casual or enjoyable read.Christianophobia works as documentation of the excesses of governments and ethnic groups against the people of that faith. It is not destined to become a best seller, but it is an important entry on a topic that will surprise many Americans. The major news media ignore this story. It doesn't fit their view of the world. Nevertheless, the story unfolds.

I am a lifelong user of electric shavers, and I have owned this shaver for over one year. I use it every morning to shave. I also use the trimmer to cut longer hair around my face. I have never used it in the shower, always shaving dry, with no shaving cream or oils.This is an effective shaver, although the cutting ability has declined moderately over time. It takes me longer to shave now than it did when new. I have had no other complaints with the quality of the device. The foil has been remarkably durable, more so than the remington micro foil shavers I had in the past. The cutting action is about the same as my prior remington shavers, and slightly better than norelco electric shavers. It cuts better on the flat surfaces of the face than it does on the curves.The battery allows me to shave four or five times before requiring a recharge. My main complaint with this unit is the battery recharge. Unlike some other electric shavers I have used, this unit does not function while recharging. If the battery dies, it requires at least 20 minutes to recharge enough to finish the shave. Since I can't wait that long on most work days, I have to finish my shave with a conventional razor.I would buy this unit again. The price is pretty good, and the quality is equal to any other electric shaver I have used.

Mr. Thomas knows the Irish, in a way that they only know themselves. He is one of the tribe, but being fatally afflicted with the writer's curse, he cannot keep the secrets. They are out there for all to see in this novel. He is a good writer, crafting characters who live and breathe, dialogue that rings true, and a family history that tells it as it was. Some have hailed this as a great American novel. It is premature to say or write those words, but it is a fine book, skillfully wrought, knowingly plotted, full of truths mostly told.It starts slowly, but gathered momentum by the fourth chapter, and  became a winner. If you come from an Irish family, you will read this with some pain of recognition, but you could do much worse than to read it. Anyone can read it, because it tells a universal story, one that should appeal to all readers. The story of Eileen Tumulty is the story of America, how it grew through the 20th century, the land of opportunity and of exile. In the end, this story is an affirmation of life. As a story should be.

This novel took me by surprise, so accomplished was the writing, so skillful the plot, and so memorable the characters. Ms. Mandel is a writer of considerable style and acumen. The story revolves around an philandering actor named Arthur, who dies of a heart attack just before a devastating flu  kills over 99% of humans on earth, ending modern life, throwing us back about one thousand years. The plot bounces back and forth between the years before the event and a couple of decades after, tracing the development of several key characters, their lives intertwined in important and surprising ways.  There is a sustained level of tension, a suspense that kept me turning the pages. There is some violence in this story, and the flu is described in general terms, although not with graphic detail. Mandel depicts the discomfort and hardship faced by the survivors in vivid imagery. Some details of this story are farfetched. Nevertheless I was satisfied with the degree of realism, and I enjoyed the novel as if it were a true story.I felt a special affinity for several of the characters. The author makes them into real and complex individuals, even if they don't get a lot of time in the story. Other characters are frightening in their cruelty and cunning, which is also realistic. Although the story is sad in many ways, it is also has moments of great beauty. I agree with reviewer  J W Kennedy that this book is not especially "fun" to read, but I am glad to have read it anyway. Some of the best books are not fun, yet they leave a lasting impression, and stimulate your thinking for years after. Highly recommended.

Michael J Sullivan is a decent writer. He has some problems with plot transitions and occasionally lapses into awkward dialogue, but he is a good story teller. He creates two believable characters in this novel. Their story is affecting, engaging and occasionally delightful. They represent the high points of this novel.The other characters are mere props, including the main villain. The author missed a chance to make the villain a real human, someone with complex motives, understandable flaws, or just a characteristic that would allow the reader to have some sympathy for him. This is the heart of my disappointment with Hollow World, and with other Michael J Sullivan stories. The villains are people who hold a particular view of the world. The author disagrees with that view. So much does he disagree with them that he makes them mean, nasty, narrow-minded and murderous creatures. This is otherwise a good story, with some moments of exciting action, genuine emotion, and an uplifting message.The author wades into contemporary politics, making his villains into a caricature of right wing bible readers. It is difficult to strike a blow for tolerance by demonizing your fellow Americans, but Mr. Sullivan makes a gallant attempt. He assumes that his readers will agree with his prejudices. Like many political partisans, he believes that he is above the narrow minded opposition. Unfortunately for this novel, he is not.I enjoyed the adventure of this novel, the time travel element and the suspenseful action. The world which the author creates is a beautiful and fascinating one. I wished that he had explored it further. The story devolves into a struggle between two contemporary humans, with the future world as a backdrop for the action, the future humans as mere background. It is a conflict between a liberal and a conservative from present day Michigan., a peaceful, flawed but reasonably likeable liberal and a crafty, violent, destructive right winger.  The conservative misunderstands the bible, while quoting it in a, dare I say it, liberal fashion. This is not an entirely one-sided tale, as the author allows the protagonist to muse about the possibility of God. The main character dispatches more than one villain with a gun, so this is not a philippic on handgun violence. Still I was disappointed with the author's parochial world view, and his focus on contemporary politics. It marks the novel with the stain of prejudice, and denies the universality of the human struggle.

This is a fine and engrossing novel, based upon real historical events, fashioned into a human story by the skilled pen of Ms. Christie. The main character is not Gutenberg, because this story focuses on Peter Shoeffer, first a scribe, then an apprentice, and ultimately the world's first widely successful printer. He was instrumental in the making of the Gutenberg Bible, the world's first book published by means of a printing press. He founded the Frankfurt Book Fair, and published the Mainz Psalter. I especially enjoyed the wonderful description of that ancient book fair, which is still in existence today.This novel has a solid plot, realistic characters, and an engaging story. The first printing of the bible was a perilous undertaking, and very well might have failed utterly. The men who accomplished this herculean task had to work in secrecy, often under threat of arrest, imprisonment, and worse. There was never enough money, and the constant danger of bankruptcy.  Adding to this was the unstable nature of Gutenberg himself, and the constant bickering that went on within the small company. All of these elements lead to a memorable story, one that I read in a single long airplane flight. In spite of several flight delays, I was happy enough with this good book.The only complaint I would mention, and it is a minor one,  is that the constant fighting between two of the characters became tiresome. This may have been the way it really happened, but I was a bit tired of them by the last chapter. Nevertheless, this is a fine story, one which I recommend to bibliophiles and general readers alike.

I wanted to like this story. It had the mechanics of a good novel: an experienced, award winning writer, a good plot, a story of adventure and constant danger, and a claim of historical accuracy. Unfortunately, this novel is a wasted effort. The claim of accuracy does not survive the first chapter. The author creates a world of noble savages, the eco-heroes, with organic diets and lives of happy harmony.  Although they live in constant warfare with each other, under continual threat of starvation or torturous murder, they are depicted as happy, nearly flawless creatures. They greatly exceed the white men in strength, knowledge, wisdom, even in appearance. Their propensity for torturing the members of nearby tribes to death is described by the author as the way to pay a wonderful compliment to their enemies. The only wrong they can do is to become friends with white men.But oh the white man! It is fashionable to depict them as evil, to attribute the bad things in history to their misdeeds. Mr. Boyden excels at self hatred, and he has done a yeoman's job at that dubious task. He is so much the yeoman that he loses any semblance of verisimilitude. The white men in this novel are evil minded, small, scrawny, disease ridden (although it is the native population that is devastated by disease), incompetent in every way. Champlain's bodyguards hold muskets at the ready, but the author says that his Huron guests could easily kill them all, such great warriors are they. In fact, they laugh at the white men, because they are such ineffective, insignificant fools.Christophe, ostensibly the protagonist, is a Jesuit priest full of ignorance, prejudice and fumbling misunderstanding. The priest thinks that the epidemics sweeping through native American tribes are God's plan to eliminate "the weak and the wicked." He tries to win the Hurons over to Christianity by trickery and bombast, never quite realizing that they laugh at him. Why did the author need the priest to be a fool and a stinker, at best a crafty villain? Apparently Mr. Boyden is still angry about his expulsion from a Jesuit high school. The only positive aspect of Christophe's character is his ability to die well.As other reviewers have pointed out, the characters are caricatures. There is a lack of balance in this novel. There was no suspense in the later chapters, because there were no real human beings here to capture the reader's imagination. The author tries to pay tribute to first nation people by describing them as demigods, idealizing their culture and their character. He does them a disservice. This novel is so unbelievable that it is not even effective as propaganda. I was hoping for an historical novel that would immerse me in a distant time and place. What I found was a modern political screed with false historical trappings.

If Tom Clancy had written about space travel, he might have done something like this. This, the second in a series, centers on the captain of a small but stealthy destroyer, his friend the brilliant medical officer, and the formerly demoralized crew of the ship.  They are engaged in a desperate struggle against a larger, better prepared alien foe. Humanity is losing the war, and extinction is a real possibility. This is no Star Trek with its idyllic view of the universe.The action is fast and intense, with the deadly Krag forces menacing them at every turn. The author builds a believable story, with friendship, rivalry, honor and treachery enough to keep the reader wanting more. The author also displays a good knowledge of history, culture, and naval tactics, expanding and adapting them to the three dimensions (and sometimes more) of space. The danger never lets up, making this a true page-turner.Honsinger writes extraordinarily well for a self published author. If you look at the distribution of the ratings for this book, you will see that his readers appreciate him. Although you can sometimes tell that the editing was thin in places, it is a totally readable and enjoyable novel. There are some abrupt transitions, and some places where the action bogs down in discussion, but I enjoyed this book immensely, and you will too.Some reviewers have noted that the story is told from a particular point of view. The tone is very gung-ho, and mostly uncritical of the military. This series is almost a celebration of the navy, albeit a future navy. There are no shades of grey, no HR reps telling the heroes that they shouldn't shoot at their enemies because we're all peaceful government workers now.  If you like moral relativism and ambiguity, look elsewhere. The title should have warned you off anyway.

Digital calipers are versatile and easy to use. I have a pair that I use frequently, switching between metric and imperial units on the fly. They don't last forever, as I found out. Dial calipers are easy to read, but they can get out of calibration, and they can break when dropped. I wanted a mechanical set of calipers, one that will work well 50 years from now, one that I can hand down to my children. These are excellent, highly accurate and absolutely foolproof. I do need glasses to read them, but other than that, they are very easy to use. Highly recommended.

Rebecca is a once famous photographer who faces a dwindling stream of income, now that her best work is many years behind her.
