To save money, she rents out her Manhattan apartment, and moves to an inexpensive place in the country.  Things do not go smoothly.Anna Quindlen has a practiced way of nailing her characters. Rebecca's ex husband  is  "so European"  a short but pregnant phrase. These two words pin him down to the dissection plate, a man who refuses to help around the house, and refuses to stop screwing around with other women.Sometimes the main character contradicts herself. I am not sure that the author intended this. Rebecca hates to think that her bed is now occupied by "the renter" a man whom the reader should dislike, because we only learn negative things about him. He is described as a retired executive, the type of man who is used to having things done for him. I laughed when I read that line, because no one is more used to having things done for her than our protagonist. She is an artist though. Maybe that changes loathsome qualities into endearing ones.This is a small quibble. Quindlen has a winning way with her characters, revealing them gradually, by action and flashback, until they become old friends to the reader, people that you can love, people that you root for.  Still Life is a pleasant story, dealing with love, growing older, losing one's past and making new starts. Although I had my doubts at first, I enjoyed it greatly. It kept me up late one night, eyes drooping with fatigue, until I had read the last page. Even though I really needed the sleep, I was disappointed that the story was over.

The building of the first two subway systems in the United States makes for an epic adventure in storytelling. Doug Most is certainly equal to the task. He presents the story as a rivalry between two cities and two brothers, with obstacles galore, and tragedies by the dozen. It is a story worth the telling, and I enjoyed it. This represents a detailed history of the time, as well as a valuable recording of grand events in the life of two cities, events which still resonate today.Mr. Most has done an enormous amount of original research in preparation for this work. As he mentions in an afterward, in a tribute to the public libraries in Boston and New York, it is amazing  how much history is contained in the papers held in these libraries. Much that is worth knowing is still missing from the pages of the internet, and perhaps perpetually will be out of the digital realm.If you are interested in the history of these two enormous transit systems, a history which reveals much more than the details of transportation, you should get a copy of this book. It is well written and well researched. You will be entertained and informed at the same time. There aren't many ways to do that!

This is an encyclopedic novelization of the relationship between Fanny VanderGraaft and Robert Louis Stevenson. The details and the historical elements are accurate.The characters are realistically portrayed, and the action moves along at a pleasant clip. I learned a great deal about the author and his love, their trials, and even some interesting details about the guilded age. I was greatly pleased to read and review this novel through the Amazon Vine program.My only criticism, and it is a small one, is that the story did not stir my emotions. I enjoyed the book, but it was easy enough to put down when other duties called. Even when a heart breaking event happened, I did not feel a large emotional impact. Ms. Horan is a fine writer, with excellent skills. I simply did not connect with the story in a way that was deeply felt. Hopefully other readers will. Recommended.

This is a fine adventure tale by a  writer who is lacks basic writing skills. The plot is wonderful, the imagined future world believable, and the main character is realistic. The writing is badly done. Description, dialogue, and word choice are lacking in many important ways. Although I liked the story, the clunky mechanics were impossible to ignore, and they detracted from my enjoyment in reading this novel.I had read The Maze Runner, which was also a good story, badly executed. I hoped that Dashner's writing would improve with experience,, but that has not happened. Eye of Minds has been compared to Ready Player One, and the story is similar in some ways, but the writing is not nearly as accomplished.I am reluctant to write a negative review, because Dashner has done something that I have not, and probably could not do: he is the successful author of several books. I wish him continued success. His fans do not object to his writing style, so I am left like a vox clamantis in deserto, but I cannot stop the vox clamantis in me. If you love writing, and you are a fan of great literature, you will probably not enjoy this book.  If you enjoyed The Maze Runner, you will probably love it.

This is the fictional history of a group of young New Yorkers who come of age during the 1980's. From a summer camp in upstate New York to Manhattan of the 1980's, we watch them grow up, some successfully, others with disappointment, and all with dissatisfaction. The cardinal sin of envy divides friends, but there are other divisions in these pages.The family at the center of this small universe, the Wolfs, is portrayed as attractive, glamorous, capable and slightly mysterious. Once they are revealed, we discover that they are riddled with pathos. The false fronts, the carefully crafted and nurtured lies, the wealth and mismanagement, all collide in a life of pain and anguish. Still, the characters believe that Wolfs are as they seemed, in spite of the evidence. Their portrayal is realistic enough that you can recognize them, but the author sympathizes too much. Each of the main characters is devoid of grace, humor and charity (except Ethan), and without a clue towards the meaning of life. They attach great meaning to their own lives, but for the wrong reasons. When Ash's mother dies, Jules consoles her with "She wasn't supposed to die so young." The narrator steps in: "Or ever, was what Jules meant. Betsy Wolf at sixty-five had still been a beauty. She was a docent at the Met, and taught an art class there for children on Saturdays. Everyone always said how young and elegant she looked." This is the author taking the measure of Betsy's life. The things that don't matter.The third person omniscient has some pitfalls, and this author falls into one of them: the narrator interjects her own opinions, interrupting the flow of the story, presenting her opinion as fact. The facts may be whatever the author decides, because this is her universe, but the technique disrupts the story in a way that veers from storytelling to preaching. The previously mentioned quote about Betsy Wolf is an example. Another occurs at the end of the book, when Ash's daughter criticizes her parenting. Wolitzer writes: "That isn't true," said Ash, who'd been a tremendous motherâ€¦ If Ash had been a tremendous mother, that should be evident from the story. Writers don't need to tell us- they show us.The characters and the author espouse a view of life, politics, and money that personifies the bitter  divisions of contemporary America. They are "nice" people, not the type that transgress the boundaries of polite society. Nevertheless, they display a ready hatred of people who think differently than they do. Their harshest words, and espousals of violence, are directed at their political opposites. This could have been a character flaw that shaped the plot. Instead it is presented as a mundane fact, an acceptable attitude.  Due to her writing technique, I concluded that the author is of a similar mindset. Ms. Wolitzer says that she writes about things that matter. If she could overcome her narrow view of the world, her book would have a greater impact.Great writing embraces the universal in life. Regardless of your outlook, opinions, or character, you can find important truths in the pages of the great books. Meg Wolitzer is a talented writer, but this is far from a great book.

Family tree maker, essentials is a necessary program for amateur genealogists who want to save their family tree information on their own computer. There are several good websites that will allow you to save the info online, but none of the ones that I have used, whether free or fee based, allow you to save your work in a usable fashion.I have worked mainly on ancestry.com, finding a lot of info about my family, but I wanted to work offline, and have a secure storage solution. Not only does this program allow me to save and view my family tree offline, it also has many features that are not available online. If you are serious about researching your ancestors, you need more than an online subscription. Family tree maker, while not perfect (I have some reservations about their formatting), fills the need nicely.

The American legal system is so complex that most Americans cannot comprehend it. Yet this lack of understanding does not excuse anyone from following the law, even laws that you have never heard of. The easiest way to navigate this minefield is to hire a lawyer, who will happily explain the complexities to you at $400 per hour. This is not surprising, because laws are made by legislators, who are mostly lawyers. Since you can't avoid the law in our increasingly scrutinized and regulated lives, most of us are caught in a bind: we need legal advice, but we can't afford it.Nolo press fills this need with their publications and their website, [...] Nolo books cover a multitude of legal subjects, including financial (How to file for bankruptcy), traffic law (Beat your ticket), and family (Essential Guide to Divorce).This handy little book covers a seldom discussed topic: how to take your money out of a retirement plan. Most people assume that this process is automatic. You retire, stop earning money, start taking money from your IRA or 401k, and live a care-free life. Unfortunately, taking your money out of a retirement account is even more complex than putting it in. If you take it out too fast or too soon, you lose a lot of it to taxes and fines. If you take it out too slowly, you might get a %50 fine. Even after you retire, the IRS will loom large in your life. The government watches retirees closely, to make sure that they can tax all of their retirement savings. Again, ignorance of the law is no excuse, even if you are getting on in years, and becoming a bit forgetful.The time to read this book is now, because decisions you make during your working years will have a huge impact upon your retirement. I wish I had read the chapter on Roth IRA's before I created one. If you have any sort of retirement plan, you should read this book.This is not a page-turner. I didn't stay up late reading this. But it is necessary reading, and it can save you thousands of dollars. It is a reference, so you shouldn't read the whole book, just the chapters that deal with your retirement. You may be very glad that you did.

This very short book gives details about important buildings in the Colonial Williamsburg area. It is small enough to fit in a large pocket, light enough to carry around. I found that it was too short to include enough details about the places I visited, and left it in the hotel after the first day.  It is well organized and written, but the contents gives only a little more detail than the pamphlets and free information available. By far the best guide to Williamsburg are the people who work there, dressing in period costumes, and staying in character through most of the day. They were knowledgeable, friendly, and eager to share their knowledge. There is no guide book that substitutes for the experience of buying a ticket, and entering the buildings to converse with the staff.

This is a great story. A callow, cowardly architect agrees to design a hiding place for jews in a Paris apartment during world war two. He has no love for them, but he is greedy beyond his own good sense. He thinks that he might get away with it, but (unbeknownst to him, his mistress is sleeping with an SS officer, and his assistant reports to the Gestapo.  All around him the French are turning each other in to the Germans, the Germans are shooting them dead, and Parisians spy on each other constantly. Everyone lives in dread of the knock on the door in the middle of the night.There are lots of details about the city of Paris, focusing on the architecture, art, and history. These elements are skillfully weaved into the story in a way that seems natural, not intrusive or distracting.  The author has written non fiction books on these subjects, and his knowledge is imparted to the reader in a way that made me want to know more.Unfortunately, Mr. Belfoure is not a good writer. His sentence structure is disastrous, his descriptions clunky, his narration a constant intrusion into his own story.  The characters are mostly flat, one dimensional, and static. Fiction is a much more difficult form than non-fiction, and requires greater attention to style, plot, and storytelling. I enjoyed this story, but not the writing. This will be a good book for readers who don't care about the details of writing.

This is a sizeable collection of essays on scientific topics, stories about scientific inquiry, and personal reflections by a few scientists themselves. Journalists and writers are better represented in this collection than scientists, but these are writings about science, not scientific articles.The topics are varied, but all hew to scientific orthodoxy. You won't find any Galileos or Darwins in these pages, only science writers who stay close to the scientific mainstream. In a brief introduction, the series editor reveals his own limited views, and a tendency to lash out at those on the fringes. He cites Galileo as an example of a real scientist, and in the next paragraph uses the Pisan iconoclast as a club with which to beat the iconoclasts  of today, without a hint of irony. Such are the limitations of the orthodox. Mukherjee's introduction "on tenderness" is much more satisfying, and  more engaging.There is plenty of good writing here, and even some science worth reading about, interspersed with a few uninspired chapters. Benjamin Hale writes about the distinction between humans and other species. He reviews the fascinating and disturbing history of language experiments with chimpanzees, experiments that few have considered in detail. The devil is truly in these details. Hale proposes that language is the last dividing line between human and not human, a distinction which is faulty, because there is no true distinction between us and the higher mammals. His thesis is unconvincing.Tim Zimmerman from Outside magazine introduces us to the observation of dolphins in the Caribbean, and the prospects for communication between species. The articles on quantum mechanics and the digital nature of the universe are amazing, and  difficult, because they describe mathematical phenomenon in written language. You cannot read more than a few chapters before you confront the magnitude of the changes that are happening in our natural world, especially the widespread extinction of ocean life.There is a bizarre entry by Oliver Sachs, recounting his midlife drug abuse. Neurologists are a strange bunch, but this story is of surpassing strangeness. The other physician in this volume writes a fascinating summary of the exciting possibilities of immunotherapy in "The T-cell Army." Mark Bowden of Blackhawk Down fame introduces us to an extremely inquisitive man who is quantifying his body, and the final chapter reveals the wisdom of psychopaths, and although psychologists don't use that term anymore, it is a good article.I always preferred science to any other subject when I was a young student, so it was predictable that I would like this book. I recommend it to all those who love science, and all those who don't. You might hop from the second camp into the first, with a nudge from one of these articles.

This is an interesting, mostly accurate, but uncritical account of JFK's cabinet. Robert Dallek is a professional, polished and engaging writer, one who has written many books on US presidents. He writes mostly about democrats, and mostly with a measure of deference. He mentions scandals and shortcomings in relation to the 35th presidency, but dwells mostly on the high points. It is a readable but incomplete portrait of the cabinet.We hear about Joe Kennedy briefly, about his rapid rise from the son of an Irish immigrant to the heights of power in the Roosevelt administration. We don't hear about his rum running, or how he turned on his former business associates, jailing them for the very misdeeds that he understood so well, indeed, the very ones that he employed in building his fortune. He mentions Kennedy's Pulitzer in 1957 for Profiles in Courage, leaving out the bit about how Kennedy didn't actually write most of the book, and that Joe Kennedy bought or leaned on the Pulitzer committee, who dutifully delivered the prize. This is strangely similar to another president who won another prize.The subject of this history,the members of the cabinet, garner much praise, some of it deserved, but their faults and shortcomings are downplayed. After finishing Camelot's Court, I was left with the impression that this was a brilliant group, perhaps rarely equaled in American politics. Their lack of achievement can be partly blamed on the untimely death of the president, but only partly.There is still an adoring audience for this tragic president, and many journalists, writers and pundits remain firmly in this camp. Unfortunately, hagiography is not history.

This is a translation of an Italian language novel, set during the breakdown of modern society and a descent into lawlessness. It is the story of a passive coward, a writer and English professor, who wakes up to life when it all falls apart. The writing is skillful, clear and beautiful, the characters realistic and well formed, but the writer creates an action tale that is unemotional and dry, the climactic scenes devoid of emotion. The protagonist finds some inner strength, but he remains mainly passive and non violent, except to himself. Terrible things happen as a consequence.The story captured my interest, never quite becoming a page-turner, but engaging my attention and my imagination. The main character was willfully stupid and passive through the first half of the story, then a helpless prisoner for most of the second half. The author allows us to witness much of the brutality and horror that are rampant in this apocalyptic world, but the description of events remained unemotional, even with graphic depictions of sex and violence.The story veers away from realism near the end, when a key event changes everything. I lost some respect for the writer as a result.  I recognize that he is a skillful writer, but I remain disappointed with the plot.

This is a well written history of George Washington at war. Many biographies of our first president have been written, but none have taken this view of the man, a warrior, sometimes reckless, sometimes wrong, but always a man who saw himself in military terms. I enjoyed reading this book, although it was not always a page-turner. It tends to bog down in the administrative details of military life, since those administrative details are the remainders that historians work with. I love history, especially early American history, so this was a natural fit for me. If history bores you, pass this by.There were many details of Washington's life in this book, as well as the momentous events of his time. His troubled and troublesome foray into battle at Fort Necessity, an event which started a world war, is the subject of chapter two. It was an inauspicious start to a military career, but, fortunately for the United States, he learned from his mistakes.The author does not often delve into opinion, mostly sticking to the facts. He presents his own view of Washington at war, but it is a view presented with historical details. I discovered that the straightforward presentation was more convincing than any essay. Recommended.

This is a winner on many levels. It is delicious, easy to prepare, takes about 10 minutes, and tastes good every time. As a side dish it goes with many different meals. Couscous is a healthy grain, with a lower glycemic index than rice or potatoes, and it is pretty hard to wreck during cooking. I did not eat pine nuts before trying this dish, but now I love them. Buying  this 12-pack from amazon is much cheaper ($1.94 per box) than buying the boxes individually at our local market ($4.25 each)!As other reviewers point out, this is still an expensive way to eat couscous, because you pay for the little spice packet, the packaging, and probably the promotional budget of Near East as well. For inexpensive couscous you can buy it in bulk, measure it out, season it yourself, plus you can throw in any spare vegetables or fruit you have on hand. If you are like me, some of those spare veggies might otherwise be neglected until they grow fuzzy, and get thrown into the compost heap.When I am tired or rushed for time, this is just the ticket for a well balanced meal. Near East has better quality than the other couscous vendors I have tried, and the pine nut is my favorite of their flavors. It might become your favorite too.

Nicholas Sparks writes about ordinary people. They are not attractive, rich, extraordinary or extremely evil. They don't run with the rich and famous. They live ordinary lives, like most of us, but their lives touch the extraordinary in all of us, and remind us that we, and those around us, are miraculous. It may not be great literature, but I like to read these stories for a reminder of what is really important in life.  His characters come to life, and you feel for them like you feel for a friend. Their stories may be triumphant or heartbreaking, but they are invariably good stories, well told. I am grateful that Mr. Sparks writes the way he does.I didn't like Ira, the main character, in the opening chapter. He spent several paragraphs  explaining how he likes to watch the weather channel, while he was freezing to death in a car wreck. I have listened to randomly chatty people like him, and it is hard to listen to them for long. By the end of the chapter, I had changed my mind about Ira, and about the book.Nicholas Sparks always starts his stories slowly, but they build, and before I know it I am hooked, whether I wanted to be or not.I won't ruin the ending for you, but please don't avoid this book because you don't like to read sad stories, or stories that make you cry.  I will just say that you have to read this story. You won't be sorry that you did.

I enjoyed this story, and felt myself drawn into it at times, but it is not written for adults. Young teens who are good readers will enjoy it. The Tower of the Five Orders is a solid adventure story with strong characters, plus some real history, geography and literature. It is a well written and wholesome alternative to the demonology and death novels that are aimed at this age group.This is the second in a series of mysteries, following The Secrets of Shakespeare's Grave, wherein our heroine Colophon Letterford continues to search for the family treasure, in an effort to save her father's job and her family's reputation. She is an entertaining and likeable character, full of determination and courage. Her adventures take her from Oxford College to the sewers of London, pursued by a nefarious relative who wants to steal the treasure for himself. There is a good buildup of suspense, some action and adventure, one episode of understated violence (a knock on the head) and a satisfying conclusion.The story includes brief mentions of William Shakespeare, Christopher Marlowe,the Bodlean library, and other literate topics, which might invite the curious to read more on their own. These elements are incorporated into the story without being overly didactic or pedantic. The novel maintains a fast, entertaining pace. Deron Hicks is a quality writer. I recommend this to all young readers, and those who love them. But read the Secrets of Shakespeare's Grave first. That will make everything more clear.

There are artists who can create the likeness of a person or place with a few skillful lines, conjuring up an entire world with a deceptively simple presentation. Haruf is such an artist, although his medium is words, not lines. In Benediction he continues with his spare, precise prose, He brings us into the world of the high plains in Colorado, the dry desert where people try to make a living out of the sun scorched land. He breathes life into a man who grew up desperately poor in Kansas, and although he makes mistakes, pushes people away, and keeps them there, he changes, and he is changed. There are no momentous happenings in the story, just a plain, unadorned reality.The sub plot involving a minister from Denver was an unfortunate distraction in this story. I never had the sense that he was a real character, a person with motivation and personality. Although he gets a lot of time in the narrative, his inner workings and his past remain obscure. He remains one dimensional. His actions came almost without explanation. The reaction of his congregation to his last sermon seemed stilted and artificial. It stood in stark contrast to the main story. If Harup had left this out, his short novel would have been even better.I didn't like this novel as much as Plainsong, but that does not make it better or worse. I recognize the author's considerable talent, his unusual but effective way of telling a story, and the discipline that he applies to his writing. I recommend this to all interested readers.

Katzen is famous for her Moosewood cookbooks, for introducing vegetarian cooking to a wide audience, helping to bring it out of the earth shoes and granola era into the mainstream. Although the early recipes suffered a bit from blandness, 35 years of experimentation has brought great improvements. Her recipes are mostly simple, easy to follow, and frequently delicious. She writes well, if that can be said about a cookbook, and she gets right to the point with clear, uncluttered prose.I particularly enjoyed her advice on making your own soup stock. I have tried the French Cordon Bleu way, which seems overly complicated and fussy. Katzen's stocks don't take nearly as long, and give you a simple, delicious result. My other favorite recipe is the ginger-pecan mini biscuits. They are easy to make and delicious.There is still something that bothers me about this book. When Katzen writes that the reader can feel "virtuous" for their cooking habits, she betrays a prevalent modern attitude. Some vegetarians believe that they represent a higher life form. But humility is one of the heavenly virtues, so she might find a better word than virtuous to describe their behaviors. Katzen softens the smugness with self deprecating humor, which makes this book easier to read, and more enjoyable.There are  many reasons to eat vegetables in preference to meat. Good taste has to be somewhere near the top of the list, or I just won't do it, no matter how healthy it might be. The Heart of the Plate gave me lots of  delicious reasons. I am keeping this one in my kitchen.

This is a fascinating tale, full of history, geography, human drama and risk taking. It is about a horse and a young woman, not a subject I usually enthuse about, but I read this on my wife's recommendation. I was glad that I did. It is a story worth reading.My wife summed it this way: a good story, but not a great writer. Sadly I agree. The writing is technically competent but lacks feeling. This could have been a great book, but it was devoid of emotion and engagement. Ms. Ours does not reveal a talent for telling a story. She simply  relate the events as they happened. If you are interested in the subject you will still enjoy this, but I can't recommend it for a wider audience.

In the years leading up to the Civil War, Kansas was a lawless, bleeding frontier, riven by warring pro- and anti- slavery factions. People supporting one or the other side poured in to take part in the fighting. One of those was a wild eyed militant anti slaver from the east named John Brown. He believed that he received messages directly from God, and that he was on a divinely inspired mission to eliminate slavery. Unfortunately he was not averse to killing innocent people along the way. In this fictional account of that brief and violent campaign, a young black slave is caught up in the fight, and narrates his adventures to a later audience.McBride is a wonderful writer. His first book The Color of Water, was autobiographical. It remains one of my favorite books. He brings all of his considerable skill to the writing of The Good Lord Bird. I was engrossed from the first chapter. The plot follows the historical trail of the crazy abolitionist with great accuracy, and although the author has necessarily embellished the details to flesh out the characters, he remains faithful to the actual events and period details. The main character, nicknamed Onion, is invented, but he is a marvelous storyteller and an entertaining adventurer. The tale is darkly violent by necessity, but very funny in unexpected ways. Onion is a lot like Huck Finn, and McBride has far reaching talents as a writer, just like Samuel Clemons.  Reading this book gives the reader an immediate sense of our nation in 1859, bringing to bright life the people and living conditions in our already war torn nation. We witness the strained relations between slaves and free, black and white, pro and anti slavery factions,and all manner of unexpected divisions that people made, and still make.I love the way some authors can bring the past alive for us, transporting the reader to a different time and place. The sights and sounds are important, but more important are the people, their attitudes and  reactions. James McBride has re-created the past in The Good Lord Bird, and we are the willing beneficiaries of his enormous talent. Highly recommended.

This is a good review book for the A+ exam, comprehensive, well organized and accurate. Perhaps it is difficult to make this stuff interesting, but I found myself nodding off at times. Nevertheless, it is a reference, not a novel. You don't have to read the whole thing, just the parts for which you need review. In fact I don't think I know anyone who has read the whole thing. I don't think I want to know them.There are a lot of other books out there that ostensibly do the same job: prepare you for the exam. I have read one other, the All in One guide by Mike Meyers. I think that Darril Gibson has an edge in content and readability, but both are very good.

This is a funny and fascinating story about a woman who finds herself on a small farm in Northern Michigan with three young sons, and very little income. She finds herself in the middle of a divorce from "Mr. Wonderful" who moves across the street. Although she is not exactly impartial, she refrains from ranting about Mr. Wonderful. The story is full of humor and honesty. Although I read a publisher's proof, Ms. Link's writing is polished, professional, and superbly edited.The author has an engaging style, which held my interest from start to finish. I finished the book in two days. I recommend this story for everyone, especially anyone who has dreams about moving back to nature and growing their own food. It is a little bit of a cautionary tale about farming, but on the whole it seems like a wonderful life. For everyone except Mr. Wonderful.

Theft of rare books may not garner the same headlines as murder, White House investigations, and American Idol, but it is a fascinating subject, one that most people would never imagine. Librarians have been fighting a losing battle for generations against a determined and relentless group of thieves, who steal any book that might be resold for a little money. Many times they try to destroy the record of the book too, so that the library cannot discover that they have been burglarized.Although it is easy to lapse into nostalgia about the long lost book row in Manhattan's lower 4th ave, this story exposes a less salubrious side to the trade: dealing in stolen goods. It is surprising how many dealers were willing to overlook the checkered past of some rare and valuable items.McDade has done a yeoman's job researching this never before told tale of literary larceny. I enjoyed reading about the characters involved, the history of that time and place, and the story of rare books. All are covered in great detail within this volume. I found it enjoyable, but I admit that this is not necessarily a story for everyone. If you are not fascinated by the subject of books, you will find far too much detail here.

Easy Rawlins is an easy guy to follow as he drifts through the underside of Los Angeles, looking for his quarry. The quarry is not always a bad guy, because almost everyone is a little bit bad in these novels, but whomever his client wants him to find. He has a checkered past, having grown up "in a hard place" which lends a certain outlook to his character. Unfortunately he has a character fault that ruins the positive aspects of these books. He simmers with a racial hatred that permeates his thoughts and his actions. He tries to do the right thing in most circumstances, except when he is angry, or under the influence. He is not above a fantasy about killing a white liquor store owner who reminds him of Grouch Marx, revealing the racism and anti Semitism that seems to come not just from Easy, but directly from the author.  Misunderstanding, fear, and rage against another because of their race is an evil force in anyone's heart, and Easy has plenty of evil forces surging through him.Aside from that, Easy is presented as a good guy, who tries to do the right thing, sticks up for victims, and rescues those who need rescue. This story moves along at a relaxed pace. It is not a page turner, but it did hold my interest. The plot and the dialogue, the description and the characterization are all skillfully done. Easy makes occasional comments that reveal an active intelligence and a wide ranging intellect. The story is more thoughtful than most mysteries, and more interesting.Mosley is a skillful and gifted writer. I was hooked by the first paragraph. Normally you don't expect good writing in a mystery, particularly a hardboiled detective story like those in the Easy Rawlins series. But Mosley has a way of writing beautifully and brutally in the same sentence. He speaks with an authentic voice, and speaks it well. All the problems and pathos of the urban desert that makes such a large part of 20th century America comes to a boil in these novels. It is a shame that some of those problems damage an otherwise excellent novel.

The author, a veteran of the Afghan conflict who served in the US Air Force, presents a powerful alternative to our fumbling approach in the graveyard of empires, making an impassioned plea for a novel strategy. She knows the country, the languages, and the customs like few Americans do, since she lived in Afghanistan before 9-11, speaks most of the languages, and understands the people. She also writes beautifully, concisely, and effectively. Before I read this, I felt that we were hopelessly wasting lives, time and money in that far off place.  Farzana Marie convinced me that I was wrong.Published almost simultaneously with William Dalyrmple's Return of a King, a history of Afghanistan that reads like a novel, Farzana's book is a history that reads like a military report, concentrated and succinct. Both authors know their subject intimately, and both reveal the human comedy and tragedy that is Afghanistan. If American military leaders would pay attention to Farzana's ideas, this could be a breakthrough into winning the "hearts and minds" of the local people that we once sought. I remain sanguine about our chances there. Even as violence and extremism continue to claim our young men and women, Americans have decided to think about other things. It is sobering to contemplate the absence of Afghanistan in American media and politics during the last election. Our president said that this was a fight worth winning, and that he cared about it deeply, but actions speak louder than words, and he now appears to care more about golf than he does about Afghanistan. I single him out because he is our president; it is likely that most of our leaders will ignore this war, and never hear important advice like that contained in this book. We will become only the latest empire to waste its youth and wealth on a losing cause.This book presents some detailed methods for approaching, engaging and relating to Afghans, taking their culture into account. Although there are some American soldiers who do engage the locals, that approach can be damaging to a military career. Most Americans are intent on getting out alive, a reasonable strategy for an individual, but a recipe for disaster when applied to an army. Our established practice of creating armed camps, dealing with corrupt leaders, and ignoring local people will not win many converts. Even those Afghans who cooperated with the US are in jeopardy since we announced our withdrawal.If you want to know what is going on in Afghanistan now, read this book. If you are interested in an alternate strategy, read this book. It reads quickly, and it reads well. When you finish it you will understand more about our efforts in that unlucky country than you would after months of reading our media, mainstream or otherwise.

I love learning about new things, and I have trouble staying focused on anything long enough to become an expert. Therefore I must confess a weakness for the ubiquitous yellow and black "Dummies" books. They cover just about everything now. Although I never liked their use of the dummies word, and I could have suggested lots of better choices, it has become iconic, and it won't change. Thirty years hence a movie set in this decade will date itself when an actor waves one of these books around.Urban gardening is hot right now, with failed cities like Detroit turning back into farmland, and lots of bytes spilled about climate change. Environmentalists mostly live in cities. Although we really care about the environment, we find it inconvenient to actually live in it. So we can grow lots of stuff in our tiny plots of yard, porches, balconies or windows. This is the right book for getting started, telling you what you can grow, where to put it, and how to tend it. It assumes no prior knowledge. If you have lots of prior knowledge then you should not buy this book: it is mostly concerned with the basics.I like this book series because they offer quality at a reasonable price: good, informal writing, excellent organization, instructions I can understand, and a sense of humor. These are not page-turners, unless you are really into the subject. Nor do they have pictures. I have several expensive gardening books full of nice pictures, but they didn't tell me what I needed to know. Now they sit on a shelf, waiting to be donated to the friends of the local library. My Dummies book is already getting dog-eared. That is why it deserves five stars.

Trans Atlantic is historical fiction. It starts with several disparate stories that are separated by many miles and many years, seemingly unrelated to each other. Each is completely adsorbing, but I could not see the connection for quite a while. Eventually the author ties them together in a fascinating and satisfying way.McCann's storytelling is immersive, with vivid portraits of people and places. He maintains a tight focus each scene, like a series of snapshots. You get a lot of detail, but you only see what the author wants you to see. The point of view goes from person to person, while the voice remains the same. Much is left unseen and unsaid. The sentences are spare, short and devoid of artifice. They are occasionally expansive and poetic, but more often prosaic, carefully trimmed. He requires some adaptation from his readers, an effort that I was glad to provide. The rewards are considerable.Using historical people is a difficult challenge in a work of fiction, because the author loses a lot of freedom. If the author deviates from the known personality, the story loses its verisimilitude. McCann handles these characters with consummate skill. He plunges into their minds, revealing their thoughts, impressions, and feelings. I was fascinated by Frederick Douglas' journey through Ireland at the onset of the great famine, his ambivalent reaction to the Anglo-Irish, his shock at the wildness and poverty of the great mass of people.Transatlantic does not contain straightforward plotting and prose, geared for the popular fiction market. It is nevertheless easy enough to read. One of my friends related that her book club rejected his previous novel, Let the Great World Spin, because it was "too intense." The intensity of his writing has not diminished, and for that I am thankful.

This is a wonderful and true story about the 1936 University of Washington varsity crew, eight young men who rowed into history. Daniel James Brown writes so well that history becomes personal, the distant past becomes immediate, and the now dead men and women are alive again in the mind of the reader. He describes the sport of rowing in great detail and with accuracy, no mean feat for someone who never rowed. His writing is comparable to David Halberstam, author of The Amateurs, in quality and in scope. In fact, Mr. Brown has surpassed him with this book. The author, who is unfortunate enough to share a name with Dan Brown of DaVinci Code infamy, does a thorough report on the men in the boat, their families, their coaches, the history of the 1930's, and the science of sport.Many of the old luminaries of American rowing are in this story, the good, the bad, and the legendary, including Hiram Conibear, Tom Bolles, Al Ulbrickson and George Pocock. The story of the Pocock racing shell, which was still the best racing boat in the US when I started rowing, is detailed, along with the life story of George Pocock, his personality, and his contributions to Washington crews.At times the author gets a bit over enthusiastic, and comes close to melodrama. Some of the rowing details were overwrought, particularly during the races. He describes the crews as "furiously hacking at the choppy water..." That doesn't describe the sport of rowing, except for raw beginners. Nevertheless, I only have minor complaints: it is a well written story.This is a recommended read for anyone who has suffered through a season of rowing. It brought back all the anxiety of fighting for a seat in the boat, the hours of self doubt, the pain of training in bad weather, with bad combinations of rowers, and the joy of getting it right, feeling the boat fly. This is an inspirational story, one that will lift you up, and it is wonderful, not only because Brown is a great writer, but because it is true.

The main character of this novel, Hannah Price, is based on Maria Mitchell, a woman born into a Quaker community on Nantucket in 1818. She eventually leaves to pursue her dream of becoming a leading astronomer and the first female professor at Vassar College, an extraordinarily difficult feat for a woman in that time and place.The author has studied the history and the location, because many of the details align with actual events. She includes small details from Sweeper in the Sky, the occasionally melodramatic 1949 biography of Miss Mitchell. Some of the characters are invented, especially Edward, her brother and Isaac, her love interest, which may bother readers. In defense of Ms. Brill, much of Mitchell's personal life has to be imagined, because after her death, her sister destroyed all of her writings that she considered personal, "to make it proper."The story suffers from anachronisms. I hoped to hear the voice of a 19th century woman, but Hannah often thinks and talks like a 21st century person. When Hannah's father (mildly) objected to her walking at night with a dark skinned sailor, Hannah reacts angrily, because she always considered her father "tolerant, even progressive" about race. The reaction was realistic, but is a modern discussion, not something a person would say in 1840. The progressive era was 50 years in the future, and even then the word progressive meant something radically different than the way people use it today. More jarringly, I doubt that a father in that time and place would have reacted mildly in that situation. Especially a father in a Quaker congregation that forbid marriage to non-Quakers, one that expelled women for wearing a colorful bow in their hair.The story takes place in a deeply religious community, but only rarely in 370 pages does a person mention God. His name is not invoked in daily conversation, or even in church. Was Hannah a believer, an agnostic, or an atheist? The author avoids this question for most of the novel. Hannah's decision to leave the congregation is a central event, but it was not a crisis of faith.Amy Brill is a good writer, but for all of the passion in the life of Maria Mitchell, the novel has an emotional flatness to it. One reviewer remarked upon her desire to like this story more than she actually did, because it was "right up my feminist alley." The author describes a woman who lives more in her head than her heart.  The final effect of the writing leaves the reader with a catharsis of emotion. Catharsis is fitting in Greek tragedy, but I had hoped for more in the life of Maria Mitchell.

I expected a light hearted comedy about a pair of brothers who were con artists, and that is what this movie represents, but only in part. It also has a slightly serious side, with some real emotion and sadness. The lack of morality that underlies the entire premise of the movie bothered me, however. This is true of many movies about the (somewhat) bad guys who are supposed to be the good guys. You have to be willing to pretend that the bad things they do don't matter. The characters build their lives on lies, which makes it harder to believe anything they say. It also makes it harder to sympathize with them. Once you do that, a friend assured me, the movie becomes very entertaining.I did not reach that oblivious place. My problem is not with the nature of the characters, for many great stories are built on flawed characters. My problem was with the nature of the screenwriters, who want you to accept the lies as just another lifestyle choice.This is a professional production, with excellent acting, plotting and filming. The plot is complex, with lots of unknowns, revelations and head scratching on the part of the viewer. In the end there is some ambiguity. If you watch the movie a second time, you will understand more, but there is lots of room for discussion and disagreement. This could have been a great movie.

I was looking forward to this book with great anticipation, so some disillusionment was inevitable. I found some chapters difficult to follow, and re-read a lot, because  I would find myself repeatedly in the middle of a page, with no idea what the writer was going on about. Often this happens because I am not paying attention, but in this book it happens because the author cannot stay on topic.This is not a novel, nor a nonfiction tome, but a series of disconnected musings on life, literature, and meaning, told with lots of personal asides by the author. In fact his personal life and inner musings are not really asides, they are the main course.The tone of the writer put me off. I don't have to like a writer or their writing to acknowledge ability, or greatness. David Shields has ability, but not greatness. He can be smug, as when he compares himself to Bart Giamotti (but as a parent, not as an actor). He can be creepy, as when he stole into his girlfriend's room to read her diary, not just once but repeatedly. Then he used that knowledge to woo her. He does not excuse this behavior, but he is not exactly penitential either. I simply could not trust this man.In everything he thinks about it, analyzes it, exhausts it, until he becomes a bit like his own version of the greatest book ever written.  Maybe I am not a good enough reader to appreciate this writer. This book was not for me, and I cannot recommend it.

This new author has great talent, the ability to create a scene, a world, or a character that absorbs the reader and transports them to a new place, the place of the author's creation. There is a genuine skill in her prose that invites the reader into her stories, bids them sit and stay, takes their imagination and fuels it with ready sustenance. She reads like a writer who has been perfecting her craft for many years.The author uses her talent to create a tale of woe. The world that the author creates is one of debauchery, despair and death, fueled by alcohol, racism and constant conflict. There is plenty of casual sex, straight and gay, lots of sweat from the Georgia swelter, and a shadowy presence of evil, personified by the thinly described white people. In this story men and white people vie for supremacy in evil deeds. The main characters endure years of misery, oppression and hopelessness.The Oprah book club has chosen the subject it usually chooses. The story illuminates just how awful the United States was, how awful it is, how awful men and white people will always be. But it really isn't their fault. They are all victims. Like the young, disfigured boy named Six, the preacher, who was "especially wronged and especially indignant." This author creates a nation of Sixes. Some of the details of Ms. Mathis' stories are skillful wrought and believable, but she gets other things jarringly wrong. In this world of Ms. Mathis, even the gift of the Holy Spirit can be evil. Fair is foul and foul is fair.My best friend read this for her book club, and advised me not to read it. I should have taken her advice.

The photographs in this oversize book made an indelible impression on me. There are pictures spanning the century, showing people in every decade, under every condition, engaged in everyday life, the struggle for survival, and outright warfare. You cannot look through this book without being enormously affected. The prose is well done, a personal summary of the century by the author, who writes well, never pretending to be impartial, but completely involved and knowledgeable, telling a story that is worth reading. If you want a one book summary of Ireland during the 1900's, I don't think you can find a better one than this. I am glad that I bought it when it was in print, and I am sure that I will keep it in my library for the next century.

This movie was a bad concept, a Hollywood version of a modern, wealthy Manhattan power couple who are forced to go to a red state. They have to be forced, because who would go to a red state voluntarily? There they are flabbergasted by all kinds of new experiences, like a visit to a Costco/Wal-Mart store. The portrayal of small town America is pathetic, but I shouldn't have expected anything else. I blame myself for even considering this movie.I used to be a Hugh Grant fan. He did a wonderful job in About a Boy, and Four Weddings and a Funeral. Unfortunately, he does not just play awkward and aging badly, in this film he really is awkward and aging badly. Sarah Jessica Parker, never my favorite actress, does herself no favors. Mary Steenbergen  is unconvincing as a gun toting, horse riding country woman. Sam Elliott looks like he is resigned to his fate.They must have realized how bad the scrip was, because the actors are so uncomfortable that I actually felt uncomfortable watching them. There were a few comic moments, but most of those were too obvious to generate a real laugh. My wife said that I missed a couple of them because I fell asleep. I feel that I had a better movie experience than she did.

Initally I had trouble with the title of this book, because it seemed awkward and meaningless. The explanation comes in the early chapters: ship it is a poker term meaning push my winnings to me, and Holla is a word that a young poker champ, nickname Raptor, uses as an online greeting, because Eminem uses it, and he believes that Eminem is really cool. Ballas are a rap term for cool guys, although they would certainly sneer at "cool guys."This is a real life example of how an advance in technology changes the lives of a few talented and opportunistic individuals, allowing them to exploit something that didn't exist a few years ago, making themselves rich and famous, if only for a while. The U.S. government swooped in and shut down the party. It is a good story nevertheless, even if it is history now. Perhaps online poker will rise again.The authors follow the lives of several online poker wizards, men who could make a small fortune by cranking out game after game, winning more often than they lost. You never do find out what their strategy was, how they maintained an edge over all the other players who thought they could strike it rich. You won't even learn the mechanics of poker here. For that information the authors provide a few references, but few details. This is the story of the winners, not the story of how to win. It is well written, entertaining, and reads quickly. Most follow a rags to riches to rags path, but some do better. It was a wild ride.

This is a funny, entertaining, and scientifically literate introduction to the life of an astronaut, or more precisely, the way to keep an astronaut alive and well. Far from the romantic ideal of a star trek adventure, life in space has often been uncomfortable, disorienting and just plain boring. I enjoyed reading as Ms. Roach tagged along in parabolic flight (which gives a temporary sense of weightlessness), rode in Tom Cruise's stunt plane (did she really hurl her lunch into his chiseled face?), and After reading this book, I had a much understanding of the technical details of astronaut life, which adds to my fascination with space travel, but makes me happy that I never actually got on board.Some parts of this book are not for the faint of stomach. Skip chapter six if you are the least bit susceptible to suggestions of nausea. There she dwells on the topic to the point of obsession. I once viewed a lecture on the subject by an anesthesiologist, wherein he rattled off over a dozen silly euphemisms for the act of losing your lunch, at which point the crowd had grown abnormally silent, except for a few anesthesiologists who were still laughing. Ms. Roach, I suspect, would be one of them. This is not a chapter to dwell upon.The author writes well, with a slightly excessive use of footnotes, which are required reading, because that is where a lot of the humor resides. I confess that I love the way Ms. Roach writes, and consider her a kindred spirit, but I admit that this is not for everyone. If you are a nerd, in any slight degree, or full on, this is a book that you will treasure. I was going to pass it on to someone, but after reading it, I have to keep it in my personal library. Go buy your own copy.

These water storage units are at the upper limit of size for portable water storage. Selling for approximately $2.50 per gallon of storage, they are a fairly good internet deal (another reviewer says that Wal-Mart sells them for 12.99). They are tough, durable, and yet weigh next to nothing when empty. I bought them for emergency water in case of an earthquake, or similar disaster. They stack (although the manufacturer says only stack them when empty, I have them two deep and full for several years without a leak) and take up little floor space, but I put them against a wall for stability.They are good for casual camping, if you have a nearby water source. Seven gallons will satisfy a city-slicker family of four overnight, unless someone wants to take a shower. When full, they weigh almost 60 lbs, and they are too wide to carry easily: they dig into your leg and essentially hobble you. You can put a pole through the handle and make them into a two person carry, but it would be a lot better to have a pack mule. The mule probably won't like them either. This is not a practical backpacking solution, because they are just too big.I have had mine for over four years now. There was an initial plastic smell and taste, even after washing out, but that is long gone. Now the water comes out tasting like it went in. Aside from some dust, they are as good as new: there is no evidence of degradation of the plastic yet.The spout is a handy design, on the reverse face of the screw-in cap. As others have mentioned, it doesn't always face downwards when tightened. You can take it off and restart the threading process at a different rotation, but it won't always face straight down. We just put a rock under one side of the container to realign the spout when necessary.

This is a good movie, one that I watched on DVD. My kids are too old to watch Disney movies now, but I'm not. My wife watched it with me, and we were captivated by the story, the brave, bold young woman who makes a foolish choice, then pays for it, makes amends, andâ€¦ well I won't ruin the story. It was well done, with a strong story line, good, believable characters, an adventure that will keep you watching, a struggle between good and evil, both internal and external.There are lots of sly jokes for the adults, which were truly funny. All the males in the film are treated like bumbling simpletons, which is a pernicious but officially sanctioned form of sexism today. I was willing to overlook it here, because the story was such a good one. The true story of the making of this film is a cautionary tale, because Brenda Chapman, the person who conceived this story based on her relationship with her daughter, started as the director of the film, but was shut out from the final product. Doesn't seem fair, but that is the way they do business in the movies. The final product is a good one, no matter how many bodies lie beneath the parking lot at the studio.

These tabs are easy to insert into standard file folders, easy to see, and a substantial improvement over the file tabs that came with the folders. I obtained these for free through the vine program, but they are worth the price. How many times have I thumbed through my files, overlooking the folder that I sought? It is worth all that wasted time to have something that works. The material is sturdy, something that should stand up to constant abuse. My only complaint is that 18 is not enough. I need more.

The author spent many years in a state of severe deafness, unaware of his hearing problem. This is the story of his life, an unusual life to be sure. Shea provides a lot of information in an entertaining and easy to read format. He describes the science of hearing and language, the history about the deaf community, the history of education in that community, and most importantly, his own personal history.It was difficult for me to accept the author's cluelessness about his hearing problems. I too have an acquired hearing loss, not as severe as the author's,  and I am reminded of it daily. I remember sitting in class, hearing very little, wondering how I would ever pass this course. But there was never a moment's doubt that I had a hearing loss. Mr. Shea went on for 30 years without a clue about his profound deafness. I am not saying it didn't happen. I just have a hard time believing it.I didn't like the author's voice. I didn't enjoy this book, although I found a fellow sufferer, someone who shares a common experience with me. Someone close to me suggested that it hit too close to home, but I don't think that is the reason for my dissatisfaction. I found the writing style to be highly idiosyncratic. I suppose you should expect that from a social outcast, a person who misunderstands most of what people say to him. Nevertheless, I'll save my five star ratings for a writer who has style, verve, and organization. This wasn't bad, it was interesting in places, but after I put it down, I was ready for something else.

I only have the Brandenburg Concerti from this Andrew Parrott set and normally wouldnâ€™t review a re-released set that includes the Suites which I havenâ€™t heard.  But I wanted to add a few comments because Amazon shoppers are faced with two wildly divergent evaluations so far, the negative one with the usual bunch of down-votes for critical opinions.Well, I agree with the negative review.  This is a mechanical and thoroughly mediocre version of JS Bachâ€™s six famous Brandenburg Concerti from Parrott and the Taverner Players.  The recording is not helped by a shallow sound engineering job with no trace of richness or depth.The performance flaws involve Parrottâ€™s typewriter-like presentation of Bachâ€™s meter and rhythm as well as flawed playing by many of the individual Taverner Players.  The orchestraâ€™s technical weaknesses are exposed in the finale of the 1st Brandenburg Concerto, where the sections put the spotlight on the isolated groupings.  There are ensemble problems, sloppy cut-offs and, over and above these problems, a general lack of finesse.  The inexpressive and metronomic rhythmic aspect of the performance can be heard in the very beautiful opening movement of the 3rd Brandenburg Concerto.  The rhythm punches along, nary a sign of expression anywhere.  For example, the Vivaldi-like section (at 3â€™45â€) is rushed through, the warm sound of the massed strings intended to provide a climax. In Parrottâ€™s hands, it is done at mezzo forte with clinical metronomic precision.These flaws all seem to exacerbate each other.  The orchestral playing can be ragged and lacking in richness â€“ this is compounded by the poor sonics. The Brandenburg Concerti, as fine as they are, can sound machine-lie â€“ this is compounded by Parrottâ€™s metric insensitivity.  You can tell I didnâ€™t like this recoding one bit.  Not recommended.  The Suites may be better but theyâ€™d need to be a whole lot superior to the Brandenburg Concerti to make this set worthwhile.

This is a mechanical and thoroughly mediocre version of JS Bachâ€™s six famous Brandenburg Concerti from Andrew Parrott and the Taverner Players.  The recording is not helped by a shallow sound engineering job with no trace of richness or depth.  Iâ€™m rating it three stars as a consequence.  Itâ€™s not a terrible interpretation and it is admittedly possible to enjoy the Brandenburg Concerti through the interpretation.  But why would you with with an extensive, even overwhelming group of alternatives?The flaws involve Parrottâ€™s typewriter-like presentation of Bachâ€™s meter and rhythm as well as mediocre performances by many of the individual Taverner Players.  The orchestraâ€™s technical weaknesses are exposed in the finale of the 1st Brandenburg Concerto, where the sections put the spotlight on the isolated groupings.  There are ensemble problems, sloppy cut-offs and, over and above these problems, a general lack of finesse.  The inexpressive and metronomic rhythmic aspect of the performance can be heard in the very beautiful opening movement of the 3rd Brandenburg Concerto.  The rhythm punches along, nary a sign of expression anywhere.  A soft contrasting section (about 2â€™ 45â€ in) simply decreases the volume a bit with the ensemble chugging along, a section where the individual playerâ€™s technical blemishes come out.  The Vivaldi-like section (at 3â€™45â€) is rushed through, the warm sound of the massed strings intended to provide a climax, but in Parrottâ€™s hands is done at mezzo forte with clinical metronomic precision.These flaws all seem to exacerbate each other.  The orchestral playing can be ragged and lacking in richness â€“ this is compounded by the poor sonics. The Brandenburg Concerti, as fine as they are, can sound machine-lie â€“ this is compounded by Parrottâ€™s metric insensitivity.  You can tell I didnâ€™t like this recoding one bit.  Not recommended.

This disc is marked for me by the three impressive chorales, each very different, which open the cantatas.  The biggest and most ambitious composition here is the â€œO Ewigkeitâ€ Cantata (#20, 1724) and the eponymous chorale with which it begins shows JS Bachâ€™s contrapuntal mastery on full display.  Bach writes a full French overture for orchestra, with the slow sections distinguished by dotted rhythms opening and concluding the chorale, and faster fugal section comprising the inner core.  On top of this overture, he layers a hymn-like composition for chorus, in slow even notes.  The idea harkens back to medieval forms using the cantus firmus, but in its high baroque incarnation in â€œO Ewigkeitâ€, it is an imposing and majestic creation â€“ as if two different compositions were welded together - from a great polyphonic writer.The opening chorales for Cantatas 2 and 176 are shorter and less ambitious â€“ but they are beautiful, too.  Cantata 176 is introduced by a very dramatic chorale which reminds me of the more impassioned parts of the Brandenburg Concerti.  The chorale for Cantata 2 is more plaintive and emotional, and is affecting because of that.The performances are thoroughly and consistently top notch, as one would expect from Philippe Herreweghe and the Collegium Musicum.  Bass Peter Kooy is very strong, of course.  The duet â€œO Menschenkindâ€ from Cantata 20 (track 16) is one of the best numbers in this release and soprano Johanette Zomer and tenor Jan Kobow do very good work to bring out its beauty.  The orchestral playing and choral singing from the Collegium Vocale is strong and accomplished throughout and the sound engineering is excellent.  All involved are pros and the results show it.It took a while for me to warm up to this disc.  The Cantatas found here, all written for the Trinity services in 1724 and 1725, are not as accessible as others from Bach.  There is something austere and ungiving about some of the recitatives and solo numbers.  So I would recommend the disc for cognoescenti.  I am an admirer of Herrewegheâ€™s efforts in his consistently excellent partial survey of Bachâ€™s sacred music and would recommend the â€œTrauer Odeâ€ CD (cantatas 78 and 198) or the release on Virgin Classics (cantatas 73, 107 & 131) as better choices for less involved listeners.  I compared Cantatas 2 and 20 here with the performances in the Ton Koopman complete cycles and, while I preferred the Koopmans opening chorale in Cantata 20 to Herrewegheâ€™s version due to its liveliness and sense of occasion, Herrewegheâ€™s is overall more beautiful and certainly more consistently polished across the cantatas.  (For example, the soprano/tenor duet in Cantata 20 which I describe above is in Koopmanâ€™s version rough and not always very attractive.)  This is a successful and very worthwhile effort from Herreweghe and his musicians.  Kudos to everyone involved.

Although I donâ€™t consider this release to be quite up there with Maria Joao Piresâ€™ very finest recordings, that is a high standard.  This 1996 selection of Frederic Chopinâ€™s beautiful Nocturnes is worthwhile and at times terrific, exhibiting Piresâ€™ sensitive musicality and her wonderful rhythmic fluidity.The pair of Op. 9 Nocturnes that open the disc particularly successfully fit Piresâ€™ strengths.  Consisting almost entirely of melody and accompaniment texture â€“ the right hand presenting the melody supported by arpeggiations in the case of Op. 9/1 and chords in Op. 9/2 â€“ Piresâ€™ ability to sensitively introduce rhythmic inflections into the lead line heightens the Nocturnesâ€™ expressivity and variety.  Piresâ€™ mastery of touch and color is also impressive.  In the crescendo that concludes Op. 55/1, she shifts from one timbre to another to create an effect of two different voices alternating, something which I had never heard before.  I also very much liked the playing of the Op. 32/2 Nocturne where Pires presents the outside section in an utterly musical way and then transitions into that awesome middle section which she presents with sweep and power.  Piresâ€™ Op. 32/2 may be the best recording of this Nocturne Iâ€™ve heard and justifies the release just by itself.While there are many terrific Nocturnes here, not all of it in my opinion works so well.  I was expecting the limpid Op. 15/2 Nocturne to be an awesome version given Piresâ€™ talents, but I thought it was taken a tad too quickly and aggressively, with the pacing just not quite right.  An alternative version of Op. 15/2 by Yuri Egorov captures the magic of this Nocturne, which epitomizes Chopinâ€™s efforts in the genre.  The two big Nocturnes gathered together in Op. 27, forming some of Chopinâ€™s best music, would also seem to be perfectly suited for Pires.  While she does a good job, her performance doesnâ€™t capture the power and mystery of my favorite interpretation of Op. 27/1 (Arthur Rubinstein) or the heart-wrenching sadness of Op. 27/2 (Dinu Lipatti, of course).  This is high level criticism; I am unfavorably comparing Pires to some of the great piano recordings ever set down on tape, so take it in context.  Piresâ€™ approach to Op. 27/2 is quite a bit different from Lipattiâ€™s, in fact, emphasizing the sensuous atmosphere of the main section and the dynamic build-ups rather than emotional intensity and sadness.  I imagine some listeners would prefer it.  One of the other weaknesses is a substandard sound engineering job from DG, unfortunately typical of this label.  Piresâ€™ sound is muddied and the pedal thumped in my subwoofer.Expectations always matter.  Given my profound admiration for Piresâ€™ pianism and how her natural gifts and inclinations match Chopinâ€™s writing style in the Nocturnes, I had anticipated this would be one of the best Chopin recordings I had ever heard.  Instead, it has some wonderful and sublime tracks mixed with other overaggressive, even hasty ones.  Canâ€™t win them all -- but Pires certainly wins some of them.  The high points are what really matters, though, so Iâ€™m assigning this 5 stars without hesitations.

This installment in Masaaki Suzukiâ€™s cycle of JS Bach cantatas features one of my favorite of all of them, BWV 64, an austere and tragic work with an exceptional soprano aria (â€œWas die weltâ€) along with BWV 25, a cantata that was new to me but which I very much enjoyed discovering.  The three other works, the celebratory BWV 69a, the BWV 77 and a fragment for chorus designated as BWV 50, struck me as less impressive while still being solid Bach.  The five were all written in 1723 and 1724, so are unified chronologically.  The cantatas included range in quality but there are some real highlights in Bachâ€™s cantata writing.How is the performance?  This is my first exposure to Suzukiâ€™s performances and Iâ€™d rate it as good but not great.  The performances are well executed throughout, with very adept solo singing, but the interpretations sometimes donâ€™t present the full intensity and power inherent in them.The Cantata 64 is stunning, from its initial and gripping chorale through the soprano aria I mentioned to a very beautiful alto aria with obligatto oboe solo.  Suzuki takes the work faster than in my favorite interpretation, an old German LP,  making the presentation a tad pedestrian.  The opening chorale flows along nicely but without special intensity.  The soprano aria (â€œWas die weltâ€), with its memorable ritornello in the strings, is walked through a pretty nimble pace.  This robs the music of its full meaning, a protest against the cruelty of the world.  The bass recitative is underperformed, a bit lackluster and neutral.  But Suzuki does better than what I think is another flawed interpretation, the inelegant one from Nikolas Harnoncourt.This levels sets the Suzuki. It is not as good as the really excellent or profound Bach cantatas I have heard, but itâ€™s better than quite a few alternatives.  For example, I compared the very attractive Cantata 25 to the performance led by Ton Koopman in that conductorâ€™s cycle.  Suzuki is more musical and sensitive than Koopman, and benefits from some fine solo performances.  Soprano Yukari Nonoshita gives us a technically accomplished version of the BWV 25 soprano aria (â€œOffne meinen, track 13) and star bassist Peter Kooy is mostly outstanding, with a light touch in the bass aria from BWV 69a, (â€œMein Erloser:, track 19), which, though it lies high in his range, he goes through without the slightest difficulty.So this is a solid but not exceptional release which you will likely enjoy, especially because of the wonderful Cantatas 25 and 64.  The release is from 1999 and is done in very good sound.  Four stars.

This 1950 collaboration between three stars â€“ Jascha Heifetz on violin, Grigor Piatigorsky on cello, Arthur Rubinstein on piano â€“ features two very similar piano trios written in the key of A minor.  The disc begins with the later Trio from Maurice Ravel, written in 1914, and concludes with the hefty example from Piotr Tchaikovsky, from 1891.  The Ravel is a fine piece, sleek and moody, while the Tchaikovsky is melodic, with a particularly memorable set of theme and variations making up its central movement.The performance is very good.  Relaxed and natural, the Ravel is done fairly slowly, a sense of ease throughout.  The Ravel Trio surprised me by reminding me quite a bit of my favorite recording of this piece, led by Andre Previn (on BMG), which is also brings out the composerâ€™s relaxed and elegant side.I have never heard a really perfect recording of the Tchaikovsky Trio.  If a reader has a version they think is outstanding, Iâ€™d welcome a comment recommending it below.  But Rubinstein, Piatigorsky and Heifetz come closest among the other versions I have.  The Tchaikovsky is done more passionately than the Ravel, as is appropriate given their respective compositional styles, yet never feels rushed or particularly agitated.  I attribute this approach to Arthur Rubinstein, a performer with an effortless style who always projects musically.  He sounds as if he had been playing piano since he lay in his crib, something which is close to being true.Piatigorsky does excellent work as well, with a rich tone.  I am less enthusiastic about Heifetzâ€™s violin playing.  As elsewhere, I find him wooden, lacking in expressivity.  Though this is a â€œsuper-groupâ€ ensemble â€“ made up of three musicians famous from their solo careers â€“ a sense of pressing and striving to be on center stage is nowhere to be found.  The trading off between the three is unpressured, with the performers putting Ravel and Tchaikovsky first and their egos in the backseat.The Trio had a short-lived career, partly thrown together because each of them, a Jewish Ã©migrÃ© from central Europe, had relocated to Beverly Hills in California, where they began rehearsing together.  Besides the exigencies of their busy solo performing careers, Rubinstein and Heifetz did not get along particularly well on a personal level, apparently.  This friction, if it existed, wasnâ€™t audible to me, although Heifetzâ€™s fiddling sometimes recedes into the background, which is surprising because the violinist is so often the lead in piano trio interpretations.The recording was made in LA in 1950 but sounds very good.  Though not a modern recording, it can be bought without fear of poor recorded sound.  This is a very good historical disc.  Recommended.

This Italian presentation of one of Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s most important and personal collections, the 6th book of Madrigals (1614), is handicapped because it exists as an alternative to what I consider a downright great early music release, the version of the 6th Book from the Consort of Musicke led by Anthony Rooley and headlined by soprano Emma Kirkby (on Virgin Classics).  I recommend all listeners interested in madrigals to seek out the Rooley/Kirkby, a stunningly beautiful, ornate and polished interpretation.  The disc under review, recorded in 1992 in Bologna and conducted by leading early music specialist Rinaldo Alessandrini, is very strong in its own right and offers a type of performance and sound world distinctly different from the Consort of Musicke.There will be some listeners who in fact prefer the Alessandrini.  With the Concerto Italiano vocal group, Alessandrini avoids homogenizing the vocal timbres of the different singers in the ensemble, making for a rich variety of sound colors.  This is different from what the Consort of Musicke tries to do â€“ they present a unified texture, with the individualâ€™s vocal types subsumed into a blended texture.  There are pluses and minuses to both approaches.  The Concerto Italiano allows a quilt of different sounds to come through at all times, giving each phrase and musical paragraph a large range of colors.  I also received an impression of different people joining together to sing the ensemble pieces while preserving their individuality, a pleasing sensation.  But the Consort of Musickeâ€™s tightly controlled blend of vocal color better distinguishes between the different sections.  The tight blend also permits some of the spectacular vocal ornaments they introduce to bet set off particularly well.  The Concerto Italiano highlights the moment but variety can end up sounding ever the same; the Consort of Musicke builds large coherent spans of music, but a sense of freedom is gone within the discipline of the group.This contrast is heard in the second madrigal from the group, â€œZefiro torna,â€ a wonderful work opening with quick canon entries and ending with an ascending chromatic texture down in the ensemble range, a luxuriant and adventurous section that is the epitome of Moneteverdiâ€™s compositions.  Both versions are good, with the Concerto Italiano shining in the fast beginning.  But the Consort of Musicke succeeds in building to the chromatic concluding section, the layered sound done a bit more slowly and with greater impact.I have been commenting about the performance so far, but itâ€™s worth mentioning that the Sixth book is a truly great collection of music.  Though published in 1614, it seems to have been written over several years as a response to personal tragedy.  The collection is separated into two mini-cycles, each commemorating the death of a woman close to the composer, his wife Claudia Cattaneo in 1607 and a young adoptee and singer Caterina Martinelli the next year.  Judging from this music, Monteverdi felt the loss deeply.  The two mini-cycles each begin with a â€œmega-madrigalâ€, an ambitious setting about 15 minutes in length, elegiac in mood, complex musically and structurally.  These mega-madrigals are followed by four or five madrigals of more conventional length, each mini-cycle capped by a duet between male and female soloist.  Monteverdi is at all times a creative thinker in terms of form and structure but the layout of the 6th book points to a special intent, a personal memorial to the two women.  And the music is luscious and perfect.So this disc from Alessandrini and the Concerto Italiano is a very worthy release.  The singing strikes me as technically accomplished, with a sense of conviction throughout.  The label has given the ensemble very good engineering, to aid matters.  Texts and an interesting set of comments from Alessandrini are included with the disc.  Recommended â€“ but check out the Consort of Musicke, which is a special performance.
