And the music is luscious and perfect.So this disc from Alessandrini and the Concerto Italiano is a very worthy release. The first volume of Bernd Glemserâ€™s Alexander Scriabin cycle, recorded in 1994 for Naxos, is uneven.  At times, the playing is inspired and absorbing; at others, flat and wooden.The Fantasy in b minor, Op. 28 from 1900, one of Scriabinâ€™s best works, encapsulates the strengths and weaknesses of Glemserâ€™s playing.  The stormy, slow opening is inexpressive and Glemser doesnâ€™t sound fully engaged.  Then, the Fantasy transitions into a lyrical and very beautiful melody in the treble register, marked â€˜Piu vivoâ€™ and about 2â€™ into track 7, and suddenly the playing is alive and sensuously beautiful.  There are some very fine moments later on.  The complex â€˜three handsâ€™ passage about 4â€™ in, fortissimo and rousing, is presented with passion.  Later on, the â€˜Piu vivoâ€™ lyrical section is reprised and to my ears Glemser loses intensity, before he regains his enthusiasm to give us a fiery concluding section.  So the interpretation of the Fantasy is uneven.This mix of quality can be heard elsewhere.  Glemser presents a first rate 5th Sonata: the sonataâ€™s mysticism and grasping at the elusive is fully apparent, with a nice build to the final climax in the central section before the music evaporates into smoke.  The 5th is followed by one of my favorite Scriabin efforts, the 6th Sonata from 1911, with its arch-like principal melody rising up, â€œwith heatâ€ as the composer marks in the score.  The 6th was almost feared by Scriabin, who described it as â€œnightmarish, murky, uncleanâ€ but that weighted meaning, the attribution of evil to an inanimate object, is not to be found in Glemserâ€™s distracted and neutral interpretation.Glemser is clearly a talented musician but he is off and on here.  Naxos provides him with mediocre recorded sound, typical of the labelâ€™s below-par efforts from the 90s.  Distinct weaknesses combined with sections that are very nicely played.  4 stars.

This Maria Pires performance of Franz Schubert impromptus and other short pieces was expanded into a double-CD set by the label and given a separate title, â€œLe voyage magnifiqueâ€, to set it apart from rival versions and point to its special quality.  In my opinion, this is well-deserved.  Pires has given us one of her best recordings, one that ranges from the very good to the downright sublime.Piresâ€™ version of the long theme-and-variations 3rd Impromptu from the Op. 142 set illustrates her inspired playing.  She is extremely musical throughout the contrasting variations, playing with a remarkable rhythmic subtlety and fluidity.  The lead melodic line is never pat, often with slight anticipations or delays that make it really sing. But this fluidity isnâ€™t soggy; it is combined with a snappy tempo that allows variations like the 5th, marked by running sixteenth triplets in the right hand, to flow with momentum and charm.This performance of the 3rd impromptu is enough to justify the entire recording by itself but there are other terrific moments throughout.  I thought the performance of the 4th impromptu from Op. 90 was easily the best Iâ€™ve ever heard.  Just inspired pianism.  After a charming outer section, fleet and projected with utter command, Pires imbues the minor central Trio with weight and desperation.  Itâ€™s one of those outbursts of melancholy and dismay that crop up throughout Schubertâ€™s later music and Iâ€™ve never heard the Trioâ€™s intensity projected quite like it is here.  The melancholy of the Trio is in fact enhanced by the crisp approach to the delicate outer sections, so the large scale form building is there, too.One of the setâ€™s benefits for me was drawing attention to the often-overlooked D 946 pieces, which are as long individually as the more famous Impromptus.  While not quite in the Impromptusâ€™ class, there is delightful and delicious writing here.  The long first piece in E-flat minor is rendered wodnerfully by Pires.  Her utter musicality and knowledge of the piece allows a beautifully integrated -- yet soulful -- performance to come through.  I have pointed to three tracks that attracted my attention but the others are worthy, with for example Pires playing the notable 1st impromptu from the Op. 90 set very well, and generally excellent pianism throughout.The only criticism I have is that the sound engineering provided by DG is somewhat hazy and certainly not ideal.  I have gone through several performances of the Impromptus over the years, listening to the older Jorg Demus recording earlier on and listening to Alfred Brendelâ€™s strong 1970s recording more recently.  Those are worthy alternatives but the Pires is in another class, frankly.  Itâ€™s a downright great Schubert recording and one of Piresâ€™ best.

I certainly donâ€™t own every early music recording but do have a collection of about fifty and this 1992 recording from Anthony Rooley and the Consort of Musicke, helped by notably great singing from soprano Emma Kirkby, is at the very top.The music is sublime.  Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s 6th Book of Madrigals, published in 1614 but written over several years, is separated into two mini-cycles.  Each cycle commemorates the death of a woman close to the composer, his wife Claudia Cattaneo in 1607 and a young adoptee and singer Caterina Martinelli the following year.  Judging from this music, Monteverdi felt the loss deeply.  The two mini-cycles each begin with a â€œmega-madrigalâ€, an ambitious setting about 15 minutes in length, elegiac in mood, complex musically and structurally.  These mega-madrigals are followed by four or five madrigals of more conventional length, each mini-cycle capped by a duet between male and female soloist.  Monteverdi is at all times a creative thinker in terms of form and structure but the layout of the 6th book points to a special intent, a personal memorial to the two women.  And the music is luscious and perfect.  The 6th book may be the apex of the madrigal form.The performance is splendid.  Rooley and the Consort of Musicke take a blended approach to their ensemble, one in which the individual voices are shaded into a unified sound, different from performances which accentuates each individual singerâ€™s idiosyncratic tone color rather than the groupâ€™s overall sound.  This blended approach struck me as helping to project the madrigalsâ€™ structure, allowing the building blocks and differentiation between sections to come through clearly.  The sound is lush and perfect, supported by a larger-than-normal instrumental continuo.  In his notes, Rooley sounds almost defensive when discussing his choice to use this continuo, but based on the results, he neednâ€™t have been, because it complements well the singerâ€™s full sound and the luxuriant aspect of the madrigals.  Added to this is a wonderful performance by Kirkby, technically assured and making the most of her outstanding high range.  Kirkby is an esteemed singer and her rep is certainly supported when you hear her work as lead soprano across this release.Special and memorable moments occur throughout.  One of the most spectacular is the decision by the Consort of Music to embellish some of the cadences in â€œSestina,â€ the second of the two â€œmega-madrigalsâ€, with exotic scale runs high up in Kirkbyâ€™s upper register.  This is something that stood out to me immediately when I first got this recording a couple of decades ago and I think it will stand out to most listeners, too.  The ensemble is capable of terrific coloristic touches.  Take the stanza â€œO chiome d'or,â€œ towards the end of the Sestina, where the accompaniment voices descend to a very warm and palpably solid texture while the soprano enters on a high note.  The final madrigal, â€œPresso in Fiume tranquilloâ€ contains coloristic touches used to evoke running water, another effect that is done superbly.The interpretation of â€œZefiro Torna,â€ a more bouncy and less reflective madrigal following the â€œLamento dâ€™Ariannaâ€ which opens the 6th Book, features some really nice fast passage work from the sopranos.  â€œZefiroâ€ encapsulates this recordingâ€™s excellence.  About 2 minutes in, very fine upper register singing is followed by a chromatic progression lower down with all singers engaged.  The brilliant high passage followed by the warm chromatic progression is strikingly beautiful.  The singing is musical, technically top notch and fully attuned to Monteverdiâ€™s sophisticated and luxurious pre-baroque style.The sound engineering is pretty good though not excellent.  Full liner notes including texts are included.  Despite Monteverdiâ€™s many achievements, including the wonderful â€œCoronation of Poppeaâ€, the Vespers Mass of 1610, and other fine madrigals, this 6th Book is for me his defining achievement.  And this wonderful performance completely fulfills the promise in the music.  Warmly recommended.

Take the stanza â€œO chiome d'or,â€œ towards the end of the Sestina, where the accompaniment voices descend to a very warm and palpably solid texture while the soprano enters on a high note.  The final madrigal, â€œPresso in Fiume tranquilloâ€ contains coloristic touches used to evoke running water, another effect that is done superbly.The interpretation of â€œZefiro Torna,â€ a more bouncy and less reflective madrigal following the â€œLamento dâ€™Ariannaâ€ which opens the 6th Book, features some really nice fast passage work from the sopranos.  â€œZefiroâ€ encapsulates this recordingâ€™s excellence.  About 2 minutes in, very fine upper register singing is followed by a chromatic progression lower down with all singers engaged.  The brilliant high passage followed by the warm chromatic progression is strikingly beautiful.  The singing is musical, technically top notch and fully attuned to Monteverdiâ€™s sophisticated and luxurious pre-baroque style.The sound engineering is pretty good though not excellent.  Full liner notes including texts are included.  Despite Monteverdiâ€™s many achievements, including the wonderful â€œCoronation of Poppeaâ€, the Vespers Mass of 1610, and other fine madrigals, this 6th Book is for me his defining achievement.  And this wonderful performance completely fulfills the promise in the music.  Warmly recommended.

I recently had bought Rafal Blechaczâ€™s version of the Fredric Chopin Polonaises and found it one of the most gripping, wonderful piano solo recordings Iâ€™d heard in the last few years.  It had made me eager to hear more of this highly talented young Polish pianist and so I moved on to this set of three piano sonatas from the grand masters of the Vienna school, Franz Josef Haydnâ€™s 52nd sonata, Ludwig van Beethovenâ€™s Op. 2 no. 2 sonata and Wolfgang Mozartâ€™s earlier 9th sonata, K. 311.  Blechacz presents us an accomplished result but it is not a particularly exciting one, so isnâ€™t quite up to his Polonaises recording.The three sonatas are each on the drier side of the composerâ€™s efforts.  This dryness is underlined by Blechaczâ€™s performance approach, underemphasizing any sense of romanticism and even drama, in favor of a clear and objective presentation. The Haydn sonata which opens the disc (dating from 1794), one of his best known, is given a clear-eyed and utterly unsensual reading by Blechacz.  Iâ€™d never put this sonata among Haydnâ€™s more emotional pieces but it does have a sense of grandeur, but this interpretation is very neutral.The following selection, Beethovenâ€™s A-major sonata Op. 2/2 (1795) is among his most objective and purely classic efforts.  I thought this represented Blechaczâ€™s strongest effort here.  There is very little tonal variety in the pianism here and I found it welcome when Blechacz introduced a timbral effect in the thrice-repeated three repeated D#s in the conclusion of the Scherzos A section, setting off these higher notes by projecting another color.  The performance is lively and technically assured, as is all of the playing here.  The Mozart sonata is played well but hews to the same idea.DG has provided Blechacz with very average sound, not up to current standards.  Based on the Chopin Polonaises release, Blechacz is a gifted and often inspired pianist but that level of playing isnâ€™t found in this Haydn/Beethoven/Mozart disc, which is a solid but unmemorable effort.  4 stars.

I found this set of four JS Bach cantatas presented by Philippe Herreweghe and his musicians extremely beautiful and consistently excellent across all parameters: the cantatas themselves are terrific, the soloists are all very strong, and the choral and orchestral work is likewise excellent.  The performance is complemented by excellent sound engineering.All 4 cantatas date from the 1720s, with BWV 22 & 23 written in 1723 and BWV 127 and 159 later in the same decade.  Consistent with the cover of the suffering Christ, they are generally very serious in character although BWV 127 is in major and is more joyful.  All are unified by being intended for performance in the last Sunday prior to Lent, which provides a basis for their serious tone.The cantatas are simply ravishingly beautiful.  Iâ€™ll point to some of the highlights but I predict that you will find other tracks and passages that are just as striking.  The Aria â€œâ€Ich folgeâ€ from BWV 159 (track 16) for countertenor accompanied by chorus is striking, as is the succeeding Aria â€œEs is vollbrachtâ€ presented by star bass Peter Kooy (track 18), a grave and majestic aria.  Kooy is just excellent, perfect technically and singing with feeling. â€œEs is vollbrachtâ€ also features a major part for the solo oboe, performed Marcel Ponseele, who is highlighted often in this disc.  Ponseele and the other oboist, Taka Kitazako are also featured in one of my other highlights, the opening duet â€œDu wahrer Gottâ€ from BWV 23 (track 6), for a sort of concertante ensemble piece for the soprano, countertenor and oboes.  â€œDu wahrer Gottâ€ encapsulates this recording: serious in tone, each detail nailed, the technical aspect done perfectly.  The overall effect is wonderful.  Iâ€™m just pointing to these three movements, but there are others.  The opening chorale of BWV 127 is just wonderful (track 10), to point to another instance.Obviously, I love this disc.  The only criticism I can make is that Herreweghe, a conductor with a restrained style, doesnâ€™t try to accent the musicâ€™s passion.  The performance is highly musical throughout, but it is on the neutral and balanced side emotionally.  This is consistent with Herrewegheâ€™s style throughout his large catalog of recordings.  But for me the sheer beauty and consistent excellence of every part of the release made Herrewegheâ€™s restraint unimportant.  I think you will love this release.  Highly recommended.

This release represents a very good pick if you want just one collection of Anton Webernâ€™s music.  Pierre Boulez includes several of Webernâ€™s best compositions and the performances are very strong, with Boulez stepping outside of his comfort zone and delivering interpretations that fully express the angst and expressionism of terrific works like the Op. 5 movements (1909) and the Op. 1 Passacaglia (1908).Iâ€™ll point to the performance of another major Webern score, the Op. 6 pieces for orchestra (1910), as a highlight.  The hyperexpressive, fleeting moments of darkness and pain that permeate this set are brought out particularly well.  The uncharacteristically long â€“ at 4 minutes â€“ march written in response to the death of Webernâ€™s mother, has never in my experience sounded so urgent or meaningful.  It repeatedly led me to reimagine the shrouded terror and physical details of the funeral ceremony.  Boulez takes the piece quicker than other recordings I have, and the drama is put forth without any of the intellectualism that Boulez sometimes brings when he steps onto the podium.  The disc would be worth it just for the Op. 6 but I found the playing of the Op. 5 movements inspired.  Boulez also presents a very successful and dramatic version of the Passacaglia, a work I have always associated with hysteria and noir drama, almost like a musical evocation of Sigmund Freud.Boulez and the Berlin Philharmonic also present us with a nice performance of that early score, â€œIm sommerwindâ€, a 1904 effort done when Webern was just 21 and then controversially reconstructed by scholars after the authorâ€™s death. Whatever the musicological complaints about this reconstruction, I found it an interesting pre-modern score which shows Webern working interestingly in a chromatic but tonal idiom.The release has just one drawback â€“ a pallid, thin record engineering job - especially detrimental because of its impact on the miraculous transcription Webern made of JS Bachâ€™s Ricercar.  Done in 1935, the transcription is remarkable, bringing Bachâ€™s complex contrapuntal conception into the timbral arena, with the â€œpolyphony of notesâ€ extended into the â€œpolyphony of sound colorâ€, the strands of melody split up among different orchestral instruments to create a kaleidoscope of sound.  Boulez and the Berlin Philharmonix give us a strong interpretation.  The engineering drawbacks are particularly unfortunate because the same flaw afflicts the earlier and equally superb version of the Ricercar Boulez did around 1970 with the London Symphony.  So we have two versions of this hard piece led by maybe the leading conductor of modernist music, both performed exceptionally well by the musicians, and both ruined by subpar sound engineering.  Very unfortunate.But besides this flaw, and the irrelevant inclusion of some uninteresting transcriptions Webern did of Franz Schubert German Dances, this is really an exceptional recording, with terrific performances of the major original Webern orchestral pieces.  (Only the short Op. 10 pieces are left out.)  Strongly recommended.

Letâ€™s start by evaluating this CD without any mention of the pianistâ€™s biography.  An outstanding, consistent and technically highly accomplished 2013 recording of the 24 Frederic Chopin Etudes included in Opus 10 and 25, Jan Lisiecki takes a lyrical approach to the etudes, algned with Shura Cherkasskyâ€™s wonderful older recording.This lyrical approach is heard well in the 2 wonderful etudes which open Op. 25.  I havenâ€™t heard more taking, affecting versions of these two works.  Lisiecki doesnâ€™t slow them down too much and yet gently brings out their emotional component while preserving momentum.  The lyricism can also be heard in some of the more active pieces.  To take one impressive moment, Lisiecki slows down the portion towards the end of the famous opening Etude, Op. 10/1 where the bass shifts into fast even half-notes walking through the circle of fifths.  I know this Etude very well but have never heard that passage brought out to such great effect.Lisieckiâ€™s technique is also world class.  The â€œthree handsâ€ effects in Op. 10/10 are done with command and lucidity.  Lisiecki brings out of the central line in the complex texture so as to make it sound easy and clearly delineated in what I count are three different streams of accompaniment.  The passagework in the most famous track here, the â€œRevolutionaryâ€ Etude Op. 10/12 in c minor, is remarkable in its precision, the runs done effortlessly and perfectly.  This highly impressive technical ability is heard throughout the disc.  These pieces are hard to play, but you wouldnâ€™t know it from listening to Lisiecki.I compared Lisieckiâ€™s vision of the Etudes to Shura Cherkassky earlier.  As much as I love Cherkasskyâ€™s performance, at times he bogs down and loses the overarching sense of structure and momentum heard in Maurizio Polliniâ€™s brilliant recording.  Cherkassky at times seems to meander off the path; Lisieckiâ€™s similar interpretation never loses its sense of forward motipon.  The structure is palpable and it never drags.So here I am comparing Lisieckiâ€™s Etudes favorably to one of the master performances from the 20th century.  A few minutes ago I looked Lisieckiâ€™s bio up and was absolutely gobsmacked to find that he was born in 1995 and was 18 (!)â€¦ ok, one more exclamation point â€¦ (!) when he set down this interpretation.  Listening to the recording, I was under the impression Lisiecki was an emerging pianist, maybe in his early 30s, impressive enough on the basis of such a coherent and individual approach to the Etudes. That this performance could come from a teenager is scarcely believable.  This has to be among the top handful of performances ever to come from a teenage pianist.But Lisieckiâ€™s age is besides the point, given the quality, originality and technical mastery displayed in this Etudes.  The only complaint I have is the slightly fuzzy and mediocre sound engineering from DG.  I have several Etudes recordings in my collection, and they are a strong group overall.  Lisieckiâ€™s is up there with the best of them.  Amazing and strongly recommended.

I have three versions of Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s 1643 historical opera â€œThe Coronation of Poppeaâ€.  One is an outstanding and austere version of â€œPoppeaâ€ reissued by Brilliant Classics, a live performance done in Corsica in 2004 and conducted by Sergio Vartolo.  The Vartolo performance is purer, lasts about 4 hours and makes no concessions to personal schedule, luxuriating in the beauty of early baroque monody.  Because of its lack of concessions, I recommend the Vartolo to convinced early music fans â€“ itâ€™s a remarkable recording.  Vartolo and his musicians also take things very slowly; the tempi taken in the version headlined by soprano Arleen Auger in the title role and conducted by Richard Hickox (Virgin Classics) is generally snappier and swifter.  The Auger is overall an easier version to digest, and features some outstanding solo singing from both Auger and others.  Generally very beautiful, I recommend it for more general listeners or those just getting to know â€œPoppeaâ€.  Both the Auger and Vartolo are significantly better than Nikolas Harnoncourtâ€™s earlier recording, under review here.The issue with the Harnoncourt is some shaky solo singing, with problems occurring throughout the opera.  Act II of â€œPoppeaâ€ is the heart of this wonderful opera, featuring the suicide of Seneca, Neroâ€™s tutor.  This suicide â€“ with Seneca presenting his noble sense of duty â€“ is emblematic of the operaâ€™s big theme, the decline of the Roman empire into moral decay.  The ensuing scenes, including some beautiful â€œcourtâ€ ariettas and duets, are capped by the long set of scenes involving the courtier Ottoneâ€™s attempted assassination attempt on Poppea.  This stretch of music, key to the dramaâ€™s success, are lacking in vocal precision, making for some downright unattractive moments and quite a few other numbers which are mediocre, but could be better.  In the scenes showing Senecaâ€™s last moments on earth, the opening scene of Act II done by Giancarlo Luccardi (as Seneca) and Enrico Fissore (Mercurio) is slipshod, with erratic pitch.  Or the very taking and beautiful court scene between an amorous page and â€œdamigellaâ€ is not helped by somewhat sloppy singing (Act II, scene 4).  Famed soprano Elizabeth Soderstrom takes the â€œpants roleâ€ of Nero; I found her very shaky in this role, with pitch issues, and a feeling she was struggling with some of the passages.  The next scene (5 in Act II) has an exchanged between Nero and Lucano (done by Philip Langridge) that is all over the place, passage work slipshod enough to really detracted from enjoyment.Iâ€™m selecting from many examples of subpar singing:  Helen Donath takes the title role as Poppea and she is pretty good, but she strains in some of the higher passages, as in the final love duet in Act III (scene 5).  Another famous singer, Cathey Berberian, takes an important supporting role as Ottavia, and while she does well in the upper ranges, she struggles with the lower passages (again in Act III, scene 6).  Paul Esswood takes another key supporting role as Ottone, the lovelorn and wannabe-assassin, and he exhibits that lack of fluency and deft technique I associate with an earlier generation of countertenors. The countertenors who take on this role in the Auger and Vartolo versions I mention above are far better, and make the most of what is a great role.  Generally, the first Act shows the singers doing ok, but the quality level drops with Acts 2 and 3 marred by so many issues with the soloists that I am wondering whether a lack of rehearsal time prevented the performance of this very long and complex opera from coming together.  Whatever the cause, I heard problems throughout.Iâ€™m assigning this Harnoncourt release 3 stars.  The audio engineering is actually very good.  Overall, this isnâ€™t a terrible release, but itâ€™s fair to say that itâ€™s been superseded since its release in 1974.

Whatever the cause, I heard problems throughout.Iâ€™m assigning this Harnoncourt release 3 stars.  The audio engineering is actually very good. Any 3-disc release presenting complex music like Anton Webernâ€™s with many different performers contributing is bound not to be perfect in every respect.  But I have been listening and comparing this Sony collection with alternative Webern performances recently and found it stands up very well, with several performances being downright brilliant and many others falling in the good to very successful range.  I have no hesitation in rating the set 5 stars and, if you are interested in Webernâ€™s fascinating music, recommend it.Highlights include the performance of the 4 Orchestral Songs, Op. 13 from 1918.  Heather Harper sings the lead vocals with passion and a strong sense of the expressionist feeling, with Pierre Boulez and ensemble providing effective accompaniment.  I compared Harperâ€™s version with the more recent and very fine Boulez recording done with Francoise Pollet (on DG) and found Harper on a higher plane of performance, more naturally expressive, communicating the musicâ€™s feeling.  Itâ€™s impressive when you compare two performances and find one excellent and the alternative inspired in comparison.Turning to Webernâ€™s abstruse later twelve-tone work, the two Cantatas, finished in 1939 and 1943, are done very well.  This is extremely difficult music to perform so you have to credit Boulez and soprano Halina Lukomska for both the technical execution and the musicality they bring to these cantatas.  I also need to single out baritone Barry McDanielâ€™s performance in the longer 2nd Cantata â€“ long within Webernâ€™s world of fragments and miniatures â€“ which struck me as exceptional.  The performances of the Op. 21 Symphony (1928) and the freely atonal 6 Piece for orchestra Op. 6 (1910) by Boulez and the London Symphony are worthy and stood up well in relation to alternatives.  Finally, Iâ€™ll also point to a sensitive performance of the Piano Variations (1936) from Charles Rosen.  The Variations are certainly not my favorite music but Rosen presents them in the best possible light.There are less successful portions here as well.  I found the Juilliard Quartetâ€™s performances of works like the Op. 5 Movements (1909) and Op. 9 Bagatelles (1913) to be inferior to alternatives I have, due to some clumsiness in the technique and a relatively unpolished sound by todayâ€™s standards.  The Op. 7 piano and violin pieces (1910) featuring Isaac Stern and Rosen are also mediocre in my opinion.The sound engineering is mostly pretty good â€“ the recordings took place across a half decade in a variety of locations â€“ but there is one notable fail.  Webernâ€™s orchestral transcription of JS Bachâ€™s Ricercar from the Musical Offering, done in 1935, is a remarkable achievement, extending Bachâ€™s complex contrapuntal music into the timbral area, with the â€œpolyphony of notesâ€ extended into the â€œpolyphony of sound colorâ€, the strands of melody split up among different orchestral instruments to create a kaleidoscope of sound.  Boulez and the London Symphony give us a very strong interpretation, accurate and musical, of this fiendishly difficult piece but the sound on this release is washed out, a key negative in a transcription dependent on sound color.  That engineering fail detracts from the actual performance in an important way.The set includes a very thorough booklet.  It does not include that orchestral reconstruction of â€œIm sommerwindâ€, a youthful post-romantic work from 1904 which was reconstructed by scholars subsequent to the original release, or a number of youthful works Webern completed in his early 20s.  Not a consistently perfect release, but it is an excellent compendium that still sounds good, with several excellent performances and many good ones.

Not a consistently perfect release, but it is an excellent compendium that still sounds good, with several excellent performances and many good ones. Worthy complete Webern led by Boulez

Franz Josef Haydnâ€™s transition from the rococo style â€“ relatively unstructured, florid, with more fluid forms â€“ to the high classical style â€“ the long-term structure developed â€“ took place in the late 1760s and early 1770s.  Both sonatas selected by Ivo Pogorelich in this 1992 recording come from before the transition period.  My first reaction to this recording was that it didnâ€™t sound like the Haydn I know and love, but as I looked into the dates of the two sonatas, with the 19th dating from 1767 and the 46th finished in 1770, it came home that the music had more in common with Domenico Scarlattiâ€™s mid-century rococo sonatas than Haydnâ€™s later music.  So this release is in a way an extension of Pogorelichâ€™s fine Scarlatti disc.Pogorelichâ€™s performance is both effective and a bit weird.  The style of the 19th and 46th sonatas allows him to show off his sensitivity of touch, clean yet colorful passagework and beautiful sound.  Pogorelich is keen on making the most of the timbral effects, which he plays gorgeously, taking the emphasis off the harmony and meter.  But it is also a bit weird.  Pogorelich plays the sonatas very slowly â€“ I mean very slowly.  Beyond the tempo selection, the meter is further bent out of shape by his occasionally slowing down.  This happens repeatedly throughout the disc.  To take one case, in the exposition of the 19thâ€™s opening Moderato, the 3rd measure contains an interruption of the opening dotted rhythm strain and Pogorelich inserts a pause, stopping the momentum.  The same sort of pause is made at the end of the 11th measure.  The sounds are very nice but they are isolated, with the pace, momentum and metric structure of Haydnâ€™s later style absent.While I partly attribute this lack of cohesion â€“ much of both sonatas sound like a series of pretty yet disconnected phrases â€“ to Ivo, I think this basically transmits what Haydn wrote faithfully.  When Haydn takes a more traditional approach, Pogorelich really shines.  The best individual track in my opinion is the last one, the finale of the 19th sonata, still done slower than one would expect from the Allegro assai, but not that much more slowly.  Pogorelichâ€™s precious and exquisite passagework provides very attractive color to set off the contrasting phrases here; yet the sense of structure sounded clear to me.  This finale is built out of short 8 measure phrases, each set off and marked with double bars, so it is a more organized than the other five movements.  Within this music, weird Ivo becomes much more normal, like a wild child tempered by a regimented school day.Pogorelich is helped by a superior audio engineering job from DG.  This is a strong disc, often beautifully done, but be aware it is of atypical Haydn.

This 1995 release led by Pierre Boulez is a well-executed compendium that traces the Austrian composer Anton von Webernâ€™s evolution from a young, developing composer writing in a late romantic style through the free atonal works circa 1910 and then on to the vocal works which he wrote as he adopted the twelve-tone method conceived by his mentor, Arnold Schoenberg.  In this way, it serves as a very good overview of Webernâ€™s work as a whole.  As youâ€™d expect from Boulez, the performances are perfectionist and accomplished, the most prominent being what I think is an outstanding and downright powerful interpretation of the Op. 10 Orchestra Pieces (1913), which is also probably the best single opus in this collection.The disc opens with a 1907 Piano Quintet written in a chromatic late romantic style.  While accomplished and clearly revealing Webernâ€™s ability at the age of 24, it isnâ€™t memorable.  Webern quickly developed in the next 5 years, producing major mature works within a couple of years of writing the Quintet.  Boulez next programs a choral piece named â€œEntflieht auf leichten KÃ¤hnenâ€ for a capella choir which is well done by the BBC Singers, followed by the Op. 10 orchestra pieces, written in the compact, freely atonal and expressionist style that Webern adopted in this part of his life.  Then â€“ and this is the center of the disc â€“ sopranos Francoise Pollet and Christine Oelze and the BBC Singers presents a series of vocal works written from 1914 and 1926 where Webern transitioned into the twelve-tone style.  The highpoint of this portion for me were the 4 Orchestral Songs Op. 13 (1918), which are sung very well by Pollet.  I compared this newer Pollet interpretation, where she is accompanied by the Ensemble InterContemperain led by Boulez, with the older Boulez version on Sony headlined by soprano Heather Harper and found that older version to be a special one, marked by the sort of heightened awareness and sensitivity to each event I associate with Webern music and performances in peak form.  Still Pollet and the Ensemble do well, as does the talented Oehlze in her numbers.  These vocal works are capped by two compact instrumental works, each about 6 minutes long, the 1930 Quartet for saxophone and other instruments and the 1934 Concerto for nine instruments, both done in the fully-developed twelve-tone style Webern, characteristic of him in the 1930s.So why do I rate this worthy and well performed disc at only 4 stars?  I found the music selected to be of uneven quality and interest.  I have been reading for decades in various music history books that Webernâ€™s adoption of the twelve-tone style represents a very natural evolution of his personal style; with the twelve-tone method adapted to his own ends.  While this is certainly an accurate appraisal as far as it goes, this disc brought home to me the fact that something very important was lost as Webern discarded the free atonal style of works like the Op. 10 orchestral pieces.  The twelve-tone pieces lose the emotional power and sense of grasping towards the ineffable that these free atonal pieces intimate.  The twelve-tone works, like the Saxophone Quartet or the 6 Georg Trakl Songs (op. 14, from 1921), seemed hemmed in, preoccupied with technique rather than expression and meaning, too cerebral.  The magic disappears.My reaction was this generously-filled disc starts with so-so developmental works like the Quartet and â€˜Entfliehtâ€™, hits a high point with the Op, 10 orchestral pieces and the Op. 13 orchestral songs, than grows less and less interesting as it goes on.  The quality of much of the music is light, in other words.  If you are interested in these exact works, Boulez and the other musicians do an excellent performing job, making this a good choice.  The audio engineering from DG is acceptable although no better than that.  I found the two other Boulez discs in the Webern trilogy he set down for DG to contain Webernâ€™s better music with this one a mixed bag.  4 stars.

I would characterize Mstislav Rostropovichâ€™s conducting as sensitive to timbral nuances, highly musical and relaxed rather than passionate, and often very successful in sustaining long paragraphs of music in a coherent way.  Iâ€™ve heard these things in the very worthwhile interpretations of Dmitri Shostakovichâ€™s 4th and 10th symphonies that Rostropovich set down with the London Symphony and was curious to see how he would approach the authorâ€™s most famous symphony, the 5th, here leading the National Symphony, from Washington DC.  The results are good but not really exceptional.This performance is musical, reasonably emotional and technically executed well, but it isnâ€™t outstanding in any of these individual parameters, in my view.  One thing I was expecting based on my very positive experiences with Rostropovichâ€™s conducting across the Russian repertory was a very finely done Largo, all the subtleties of this complex and stunning slow movement presented with care and a balanced musicality.  Instead, itâ€™s a successful but not memorable performance. The memorable high string melody in the long opening Moderato is done with finesse, but I couldnâ€™t help comparing it to the well-known recent version Vasily Petrenko did his Liverpool orchestra on Naxos, which holds an exquisite Largo, spooky and rich, and a whisper-soft Moderato main theme.  And while the more assertive, powerful sections are done well, they are without a sense of overriding dramatic power.The spooky interlude 5 minutes into the Largo (track 3) illustrates this performanceâ€™s general character.  This is that almost spooky passage where the music settles down into the gloom with the flutes presenting a sad melody in the middle of their register.  Rostropovich and the National Symphony play the music in a perfectly fine way, but it has neither a special intensity that the section can hold or particularly finesse in working out the delicate orchestration.  This encapsulates this performance.So this is a bit of middle of the road performance.  It is a good one but not outstanding in what is a crowded field.  The partnership of Rostropovich with Teldec, a label with a history of very strong audio engineering, would seem to be ideal given Mstislavâ€™s interpretative style, but the sonics in this release, while good, are not especially striking either.  4 stars.

Because it combines strong work from the solo singers, a very capable instrumental group, good sound and cuts down this lengthy opera down to about 3 hours, I recommend this very beautiful version of Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s 1643 opera â€œThe Coronation of Poppeaâ€ to all listeners who arenâ€™t familiar with the work.  I have two other versions.  One is an outstanding and more austere version of â€œPoppeaâ€ reissued by Brilliant Classics, a live performance done in Corsica in 2004 and conducted by Sergio Vartolo.  This Vartolo performance is purer, lasts about 4 hours and makes no concessions to personal schedule, luxuriating in the beauty of early baroque monody.  Because of its lack of concessions, I recommend the Vartolo to convinced early music fans â€“ itâ€™s a remarkable recording.  Vartolo and his musicians also take things very slowly; the tempi taken in the Arleen Auger version being reviewed here are snappier and swifter.  The Auger is overall an easier version to digest.  Both it and Vartoloâ€™s are significantly better than Nikolas Harnoncourtâ€™s earlier recording, which is held back by uneven singing.This recording is headlined by soprano Arleen Auger, a wonderful singer at the peak of her powers.  Auger plays Poppea, the homewrecking seductress whoâ€™s ambition and luring away of the Emperer Nero is used to symbolize the moral decline of the Roman Empire, the potent theme of this ambitious historical opera.  It is traditional today to cast Nero as a soprano in a â€œpants roleâ€, filling in for the castrati who did the part in the 17th century.  In this version, British mezzo-soprano Della Jones is Nero and she is consistently good, doing her best work I think in the concluding marriage sequence in Act III.  The duet that initiates the marriage scene, â€œAscendiâ€, features some especially good stuff from Jones.  The supporting cast is quite strong although not perfect.  Gregory Reinhart is assigned to the crucial supporting part of Seneca, Neroâ€™s tutor.  Reinhart has a bass voice on the lighter side of things but does well, singing with precision and feeling in the 2nd Act, which to me is the heart of the opera.  The choral sections marking Senecaâ€™s suicide are well done, with effective part singing that throws us back to the madrigals Monteverdi wrote in the earlier part of his career, several decades before the aging composer set down â€œPoppea.â€  The sensual and attractive â€œSentoâ€ duet in Act II (scene 5, track 7 of the 2nd disc here) receives an adept presentation and the supporting work is generally strong.  I also enjoyed the playing of Richard Hickox and the City of London Baroque Sinfonia, who give us an instrumental accompaniment that is beautiful without being obtrusive.The performance isnâ€™t perfect -- although none of it is bad. Besides Seneca, one of the other key supporting roles is Ottone, the enamored courtier tied in knots by love and honor. James Bowman is the countertenor who takes this part.  While he is OK, he suffers in comparison to the brilliant Ottone, William Mateuzzi, who does so well in the Vartolo version I mentioned above.But for such an ambitious staging, weaknesses as neutral as this are to be expected and donâ€™t overall mar a very strong release of what is an intriguing and frequently awesome drama.  Recommended.

This recording from 1999 presents Finnish mezzo Monica Groop in three JS Bach canatatas for solo alto, numbers 35, 169 and 170, all of which were written within a few months of each other in 1726.  Groop has a lustrous dark mezzo that is often quite beautiful but she is also not a particularly expressive singer.  The accompaniment provided by the Ostrobothnian Chamber Orchestra led by director Juha Kangas, also from Finland, is just as important in setting the performance tone as Groop but the same tendency is present in the instruments.  Kangas has a tendency to flatten out all tempi to a moderate pace - fast and slow sections are blended - which unfortunately accentuates Groop's lack of emotional dynamism.  The organ obligato part provided by Hakan Wikman is also more important in these cantatas than in other Bach works in the genreand seems to be done well.The lack of dynamics and tempo variation -- and ultimately emotional range â€“ is very clear in the performance of the beautiful Cantata 169 (â€œGott soll alleinâ€).  To take an example, in the recitative â€œWas ist die Liebe Gottesâ€ and the following tragic aria, â€œStirb in Mirâ€, Bachâ€™s mood of tragic sobriety isn't matched by a rather monotone solo vocal interpretation.  In Cantata 170 (â€œVergnugte Ruheâ€), one of the most striking numbers is the almost mystical â€œWie jammernâ€ aria, with a featured organ obligato part but without continuo, apparently a symbol representing those who lead a God-less life.  I feel this aria has much more potential than in this performance, which takes it at a moderate pace restricting its impact.  The best part of the release I think is the opening Sinfonia to cantata 169, which I thought Kangas and the Ostrobothnian orchestra do pretty well.I hope Iâ€™m not coming off as excessively critical.  This is technically well-executed recording.  Groop has the chops and she has a very nice voice.  The orchestra is technically able if not dazzling.  The recorded sound is actually very good, as youâ€™d expect from the Finlandia label.  But itâ€™s not an inspiring recording and doesnâ€™t do justice to three Bach works from his prime.  Three stars.

Nikolai Lugansky, aged 27 when this recording was made in 1999, gives us a promising and generally pretty good set of Fredric Chopinâ€™s magnificent Etudes, including the Op. 10 and 25 sets as well as the three Nouvelles Etudes written later on in 1839.  Lugansky is a somewhat emotionally restrained performer but he is a musical one.  Technically, he is strong without being outstanding, at least among the current field of pianists, many of whom are dazzling in this area.Some of Luganskiâ€™s best playing comes in the two first etudes of the Op. 25 set.  In the â€œAeolian Harpâ€ op. 25/1 etude, he shows real feeling in presenting the luxuriant melody.  The turning triplets that make up the foundation of the Op. 25/2 are done with delicacy and a sense of rhythmic nuance that is wonderful.  I enjoyed Luganskiâ€™s playing of the three nouvelles etudes and think it is one of the better portions of this release.  In the amazing first etude, Luganski very affectingly presents the main melodyâ€™s cresting to the high C-flat  that marks this compact pieceâ€™s highest point in the register.  In the Op. 10 set, the main section of Etude 9 possesses a well-presented forward momentum with the transition into the brooding contrasting sections paced perfectly.But quite a few of the etudes donâ€™t have the emotional power I have heard in alternative performances.  Op. 25/4 is played by the numbers with the sense of tragic momentum I hear in this Ã©tude absent.  The Op. 10/2 etude lacks the Ã©lan and sense of momentum it can bring.  I also found Luganskiâ€™s version of the big 25/7 Ã©tude pedestrian; Luganski has a leaden unengaged feel in this etude, a centerpiece of the set.  The desolate Op. 10/6 etude is presented nicely but the poetic conclusion can be more emotional and overwrought than Luganskiâ€™s staid conception shows.I made a comment about Luganskiâ€™s technique earlier.  He is a strong pianist but not a perfect one, at least here in this Chopin. For example, both Op. 10/4 and 10/5 etudes shows a lack of tightness between the faster passagework and the accompanying chords.  In Op. 10/4, the passagework and chords are presented in alternation in the right and left hands; in Op. 10/5, the chords are restricted to the left hand.  Now anyone who can play these etudes professionally is a very good technician â€“ they are hard â€“ but the issue is that stronger technical alternatives exist (see Maurizio Polliniâ€™s famous set).  Recorded sound is very good.You get the idea of my reaction.  This is a promising and accomplished recording from a young pianist who has no doubt developed greatly since setting down these sessions.  Itâ€™s good and enjoyable but lacks emotional impact in etudes scattered throughout the disc, so it varies between the good and the very good.  I recommend alternatives such as the Pollini I mention above and the older and very different recording from Shura Cherkassky.  Four stars.

This exquisitely beautiful version of Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s â€œThe Coronation of Poppeaâ€ (1643) is for purists.  A fair bit longer than other versions of the opera I have, it emphasizes the beauty of the declamatory monody which makes up most of â€œPoppeaâ€, with the sung and instrumental portions appearing as breaks within the action, rather than the opposite.  I generally found the reviews here on Amazon donâ€™t do justice to just how excellent and ravishing this recording is.  It comes from an obscure source, a 2004 performance in Corsica, so we can thank a perceptive A&R person at Brilliant for hearing its quality and reissuing it.  The recording seems to have been done on a tight budget, with many of the singers serving in multiple roles; despite these constraints, the sound engineering is audiophile quality.  Itâ€™s certainly one of the best sounding opera releases in my collection.The cast is on the whole very good.  Patrizia Biccire does well as the conniving Poppea.  I very enjoyed Raffaele Costantiniâ€™s work as Seneca, one of the most rewarding of the parts, and Gabriella Martellaci gives us a successful Arnalta.  The weakest solo singing I thought came from Liliani Rugiero, who does the â€œpantsâ€ role of Nero in Acts I and III (surprisingly, a different singer does Nero in Act II).  Apparently, castrati singers handled the part of Nero in the 17th century, so the common adaptation for modern stagings is to give this part to sopranos.  But Rugiero isnâ€™t bad, so itâ€™s a pretty high floor for a cast recording.But the real stand-out for me was countertenor William Mateuzzi in the role of Ottone, a surprise for me as Iâ€™m not usually taken with this vocal type.  He truly shines in several luxuriant numbers towards the end of Act II, including the solo raging number in Scene 7 and the foiled assassination attempt on Poppea presented in Scene 13, foiled because the god of love appears to defend the immoral but amorous target.  The 2nd Act is for me the heart and the best part of â€œPoppeaâ€.  Besides the latter sequence, concluding with the assassination attempt, the suicide of Seneca, symbolizing the death of Roman republican virtues and the growing decadence of the empire, is very attractive music.  The performance here is excellent and Costantini is both expressive and sonically rich, with a wonderful bass voice.  The austere tragedy of the suicide gives way to a contrasting supporting scene, in which a page and lady-in-waiting from the Roman court engage in a duet celebrating their very physical love.  Itâ€™s a measure of the quality of this performance that even such a scene, with two supporting singers, is highly attractive and executed with such panache.For general listeners, I would generally recommend the â€œPoppeaâ€ released by Virgin with Arleen Auger in the title role.  It is a more colorful and condensed rendition.  But this version, led by Sergio Vartolo from the harpsichord, will greatly please early music or baroque opera fans.  The release contains the text in both Italian and English along with informative notes.  It sounds great, the singing ranges from the good to the exceptional, and the art of Monteverdi is presented in a pure, unapologetic way.  Strongly recommended.

Anton Webernâ€™s mini-miniatures arenâ€™t just short, they are condensed, with each phrase often taking the place of an entire section in other, more normal music.  In such a telescoped environment, the details and intensity of focus on each individual note is all-important.  Though outside their normal repertory, the Quartetto Italiano seem to understand the importance of detail.  The final moments of the 4th of the 5 Movements Op. 5 (1909) illustrates their success.  This fourth piece, a one-page fragment, ends with a rising phrase in the viola, followed by a slow-moving pianissimo passage constructed from harmonics ending with a lower pizzicato, and capped by an echo of the violaâ€™s brief line, this time higher up in the 2nd violin part.  In this performance, the different timbral effects are precise and I had a palpable feeling that time had slowed down; the Quartetto makes each note count.The famous 6 Bagatelles (Op. 9, from 1913) are even briefer than the dense Op. 5.  The Quartetto brings admirable attention to the sound color changes, which Webern creates using many special string special effects, and rhythmic placement.  The 5th bagatelle, whisper soft, is a series of allusive dynamic surges, but not surges from piano to forte, rather, surges from triple piano to double piano, often done over a single note.  In such a context, the pizzicato F in the 1st violin arriving mid-way through the piece is a major event.  Played here, this beautiful Bagatelle, clocking in at well under a minute, has the same Zen-like attention to each detail in the hands of the Quartetto that I heard in the Op. 5 movements.This is a beautiful performance.  I hadnâ€™t taken it off the shelf in well over a decade but listened to it recently and, unsure what to expect, was taken with the result.  The Quartetto live up to their reputation as one of the best quartets ever and have given us a precious and utterly successful disc that I warmly recommend.  The performers are helped by outstanding analog engineering from Philips.  This engineering is a significant contributor to the releaseâ€™s success as it allows the spacing of the instruments to come through, something which creates a special presence and helps the timbral effects so important to Webernâ€™s atonal music to come through.I compared several of the pieces presented by the Quartetto Italiano to the recordings by the Juilliard Quartet on the Sony complete Webern set.  The Juilliard versions are pretty good, but they donâ€™t have that focus and sense of intense attention to the moment found in the Italiano version.  The Juilliard plays the music; the Italiano seems to live, not just play, each note and gesture.The disc is not a long one.  It is filled up by a formative post-Brahmsian Langsamer Satz (1905) which Webern wrote when he was 22.  Then â€“ and this is really remarkable â€“ from the same year, we have a String Quartet close to 20 minutes in length very different from the Langsamer Satz.  It is still tonal, but written in an adventurous chromatic language that I would compare to Franz Schreker.  Then we jump four years into 1909, the Op. 5 set and a completely different world, of compact, allusive atonality.  The speed of Webernâ€™s development is astounding.  Also included is the late twelve-tone String Quartet, a very abstract, almost inscrutable work from 1936, commissioned by an American patron.  So the disc doesnâ€™t give us a wonderful interpretation but presents to us Webernâ€™s voyage from immaturity to adult achievement.  If you are a fan of Webernâ€™s abstruse art, you will want to hear this recording.

Coming back to it after several years Iâ€™ll shy away from such hyperbole - the greyness and moderation of age interferes -- but Maurizio Polliniâ€™s achievement in this justly celebrated performance remains inspiring.  It isnâ€™t a perfect recording, but it has many tracks which are incredible.Polliniâ€™s interpretation is characterized by both his awesome technical ability and a relatively strict meter and sense of beat, with less tempo flexibility than many other pianists in these etudes.  It isnâ€™t fair to view Polliniâ€™s stricter metric approach as machine-like; he applies great sensitivity to some of the Etudes.  The wonderful Op. 10/4 Etude receives an emphatically dramatic treatment from Pollini.  In the dark and brooding Op. 10/6 Etude, Pollini builds towards the sigh that is the concluding theme in a way that doesnâ€™t show a detached or emotionless interpreter.  That said, the objectivity Pollini brings has its less successful moments, notably in the long and lyrical Op. 25/7, a wonderful composition which I think can use more sensitivity.But a freer, less rigid frame for the Etudes has its downsides as well.  One of my favorite alternative recordings of this set comes from Shura Cherkassky (included in the Philips Great Pianists series).  Cherkassky brings a wonderful freedom and sensitivity, especially successful in some of the slower Etudes.  But this freedom and lyricism also lessens the impact of Chopinâ€™s contrasts and makes both the Op. 10 and 25 sets more homogenous and unstructured. Great interpretations shape the music in a strong way and this shaping both produces insight and a downside.  Pollini creates momentum, drama combined with utter technical command, but at a cost of sometimes underplaying the emotion and lyricism in the Etudes.I havenâ€™t mentioned Polliniâ€™s performance of the final 3 etudes of the Op. 25 set, number 10, 11 and 12.  Now whatever criticism can be made of Pollini, when you have performances of this caliber anywhere in any release, it marks it as a success.  Polliniâ€™s passagework is incredible.  The ff octaves in Op. 25/10 are frighteningly intense.  His fiery performance of the â€œWinter Windâ€ (no. 11) is sweeping and gripping.  The tragedy and grandeur of the final etude, 0p. 25/12, is revealed in a way I havenâ€™t heard from any other performer.  I donâ€™t believe this sense of climactic ending would exist without Polliniâ€™s strict frame and his careful treatment of textures and tempo contrasts.  Itâ€™s a memorable and intense conclusion to this great release.

The 3-star rating applies only to the sound quality of the new â€œOriginalsâ€ release of Maurizio Polliniâ€™s celebrated performance of the Chopin Etudes.  Polliniâ€™s Etudes remains a justly famous and pre-eminent interpretation of this wonderful music and one of this famous pianistâ€™s signature achievements.  This remastering unfortunately doesnâ€™t do anything to elevate the experience.I am baffled by how Deutsche Grammophon could let this pass release through any sort of reasonable quality control process.  The original CD release has richer sound with a more impactful bass.  The remaster has a thinner and less rich sound, with more distortion in treble.  Some harshness is present in both the original CD release and this Originals remastering pointing to weak origjnal engineering â€“ so we arenâ€™t dealing with a perfect original recording from an engineering standpoint -- but the remastering doesn't improve matters.  The more lyrical Op. 10 no. 10 Etude has a broader and more flowing texture than many of the other more technically-focussed etudes; the remaster does nothing to make Polliniâ€™s sound richer or more true to the sound of the instrument.Youâ€™ll have to excuse me for something of a rant here.  Iâ€™ve recently been listening to a digital recording of a baroque opera produced in an obviously resource-constrained setting at a provincial opera house in Corsica at about the time this remaster was released.  Yet the engineers generated a recording with audiophile-level sound.  In contrast, the producers of this Original remaster worked for one of the premier classical labels with much more expertise and money available, and they produce an inferior product like this reissue. And once they produce it, they donâ€™t examine it self-critically and decide that it needs to be redone because [underline] it doesnâ€™t sound as good as the original unremastered CD release [end underline] no, they release it.Great pianism.  Beautiful music.  Awful output from the oft-criticized DG audio engineers.  3 stars.

Herbert von Karajan.  Pierre Boulez.  Two great conductors, one steeped in the music of romanticism; the other a prominent modernist, both as a conductor and as a composer.Based on their background, youâ€™d think Boulez would be clearly superior in presenting the music of arch-modernist Anton von Webern, yet I don't find that to be the case.  Coming back after a few years to Herbert von Karajanâ€™s short release of four Webern orchestral pieces done with the Berlin Philharmonic, I was at first taken aback by how much I liked the performances.  Karajan shouldnâ€™t be good at this repertory, right?  But what I was hearing was incisive music-making that showed genuine understanding of Webern and presented him in a new light.Listening to the Karajan was not just enjoyable, but also thought-provoking.  Emphasized overwhelmingly in the writings about Webern and the New Viennese School is their move towards atonality, placing the changing treatment of pitch and harmony at center stage.  But coming from a more practical and traditional world of classical performing, Karajan to my ears highlights two other aspects of Webernâ€™s art which, once you consider them, are just as important to the composerâ€™s artistry as the pitch/harmony angle.One is the barely suppressed subcurrent of emotional hysteria.  This is readily apparent in the longest of the Op. 6 pieces for orchestra (1910), the fourth, an acknowledged funeral march written when Webernâ€™s mother passed away.  It is also at the forefront in the Passacaglia (1908), marked as Op. 1 in certainly one of the best debut works in the classical repertory, a tonal work about 8 minutes in length.  Karajanâ€™s performance is brilliant.  It is a melodramatic and always gripping version, stinting at nothing.  It evokes a recurrent image of a careening car from a 1930s black & white movie about crime and madness; this is â€œnoirâ€ music before the genre was created.  None of this is surprising or novel â€“ after all, Expressionism was the most prominent artistic movement in the Vienna of this time -- but I think itâ€™s fair to say that many Webern performances de-emphasize it, including the performances from Boulez.Then there is the concision.  Nothing new here, again, but Karajanâ€™s dramatic and forceful performances emphasize it.  His version of the 3rd of the Op. 5 pieces, a later orchestral transcription of a set originally written for string quartet (1909), exemplifies this.  It is as if a lengthy violin concerto has been distilled into gestures, each condensed into a few seconds and not repeated.  The accompaniment begins with a tense pattern, repeated just a few times, then the soloist comes in, with the just the opening gesture presented â€“ and the rest of the concerto follows, taking up just two minutes.  Karajanâ€™s sense of drama highlights the charged nature of each note.  Expressionist hysteria and Webernâ€™s telescoping to time into brief moments â€“ â€œa novel in a single gestureâ€ -- are common associations in the artistâ€™s music, but I found Karajan stressed those ideas with particular success.The odd Symphony Op. 21 (1928) is different from the three earlier works included here in terms of emotional temperature, the twelve-tone technique used to create a more neutral and objective palette.  Karajanâ€™s performance is charismatic and forthright.  The way he brings out the long held notes in the first movement, emerging from the kaleidoscope of pitches in the rest of the texture, grabs me each time I hear it.  To return to the Boulez comparison, the French conductor is superb, but his interpretations donâ€™t seem as incisive as Karajanâ€™s.  Thereâ€™s something a bit fussy and inhibited. In particular, I found Boulezâ€™s Symphony a pale shadow of Karajanâ€™s robust vision.  (I listened to both Boulez earlier London Symphony version and his later one done, like Karajan, with the Berlin Philharmonic.)  I found the same to occur in the Op. 5 Movements, where Karajan seemed to penetrate deeper than a perfectionist but somewhat sterile Boulez performance.  Itâ€™s as if Boulez had read too much about Webern and had attended too many seminars analyzing the pitch language of the New Viennese School.  Something has been lost.The only complaint I will make about the Karajan disc is the mediocre sound, a common problem with his recordings from around 1970.  But this is a perceptive interpretation that engages with Webernâ€™s art in a sympathetic and profound way.  It may come from an unusual source, but remains very worthwhile.  Recommended for fans of 20th-century music.

Straight from Poland, Rafal Blechaczâ€™s set of 7 Chopin Polonaises is an exciting, alive recording, the performerâ€™s tremendous technique married to a sense of drama and a palpable enjoyment in presentign this repertory.  I consider it the best of three sets of Polonaises I have heard, more exciting and cleaner technically than the excellent one from Arthur Rubinstein, who takes a more relaxed and low-key approach, and the less satisfactory one from Maurizio Pollini, which has nowhere near the passion Blechacz brings to the music, despite the Italianâ€™s undoubted technical excellence.  The Blechacz recording also benefits from first-rate sound.One of my â€œguilty pleasuresâ€ is the â€œSerbianâ€ Polonaise (track 2 here, Op. 26 no. 2 from 1836), with its heady melody and dramatic exposition.  I loved the way Blechacz builds up from the somber opening, exploding into the 2-octave run that leads into this melody.  This Polonaise is just terrific throughout and brims with excitement.Another reviewer had pointed to Blechaczâ€™s way with the long Op. 44 Polonaise (track 5, from 1841) as notable.  I agree â€“ this interpretation is vivid.  Like the â€œSerbianâ€ Poloniase I mention above, the big Op.  44 Polonaise begins with almost ominous octaves in the lower range and then surges into the main melody, this time through a difficult octave passage.  The playing of this opening section here is brilliant and exciting.  Although Iâ€™m not convinced that the more lyrical ascending secondary theme marked â€œsostenutoâ€ is up to the quality level of the rest of the Polonaise, Blechacz makes the best case for Op. 44.  Other tracks are also consistently very good, including the final â€œPolonaise Fantasieâ€ (track 7, Op. 61, from 1846), with its more complex structure typical of Chopinâ€™s later works, and a successful Op. 53 Polonaise, one of the authorâ€™s most famous pieces.This is my first experience with Rafa' Blechacz and I now plan on buying all of his recordings.  Strongly recommended.

This is the second Bach solo piano recording from Piotr Anderszewski I have purchased.  The first one â€“ an earlier 1990s vintage recording including the Overture in the French Style on Harmonia Mundi France â€“ is terrific and whetted my appetite for more from Anderszewski, who has such a strong reputation in this repertory.  But I am mildly disappointed; the present recording has its moments but it also has its dull sections and, overall, it never seems to lift off.  Certainly not a bad release, but I was expecting more.Among Anderszewskiâ€™s strengths is his very strong and deft left hand.  This allows him to create vivid and times marvellous textures, as he has such control and sense of touch in the lower registers.  Maybe the highpoint of this release for me was the very concluding fugue that caps the ambitious Gigue of the 6th Partita.  The fugue almost seems three dimensional as the different voices are each presented with different touches.  Another success is the Allemande (2nd mvt) of the 1st Partita, nicely played with a liveliness and sense of attention.But Anderszewskiâ€™s attention comes and goes.  Often, the dances seem to just pass by; thereâ€™s an automaton-like quality to some.  The lovely Air from the 6th Partita (4th mvt) is taken sluggishly and presented without any feeling.  How could Anderszewski transform such an interesting and attractive movement with this dullness?  The Sarabande that follows the Air is a majestic and contemplative dance that Anderszewski plays without a sense of drama and grandeur and I thought the same occurred in the long Sarabande in the 1st Partita.Anderszewski sounds authoritative at times and elsewhere he sounds a bit disengaged.  He is helped by a very nice sound engineering job from Virgin.  This is a decent release but I expected more.

This RCA compilation of three different recordings from American pianist William Kapell is of uneven value.  The highpoint is the set of 10 Fredric Chopin Mazurkas, which are outstanding and distinctive and fortunately done in very good sound despite the fact that the sessions took place in 1953.  Also included are a 3rd Sonata with very dated sound from 1951/2 and finally a live 2nd Sonata from Australia where the sound is downright problematic.  My short review then: get this one for the Mazurkas, but not for the Sonatas.Kapell has a reputation for technical prowess and professional intensity, but for me what stands out about his best performances is their emotion.  This is very true of the Mazurkas here.  I also hear it in the memorable version of the Sergei Prokofiev 3rd Piano Concerto Kapell did with Antal Dorati conducting, which highlights the Concertoâ€™s emotional power.  I have been sampling a number of different Chopin Mazurka interpretations recently and each pianist brings something different to them, from Rubinsteinâ€™s natural directness to Arturo Benedetti Michelangeliâ€™s eccentric technical perfection.  When I turned to Kapellâ€™s Mazurkas, what I heard was the powerful emotions and moods that lay at the heart of Chopinâ€™s conception.  Take the A-flat Major Mazurka Op 17/3 (track 12 here); Kapell presents the outer A section with strength and a sense of tragedy matched by a particularly dramatic central â€˜Bâ€™ section.  The Op 33/1 Mazurka (track 14) is jubilant yet swinging into moody contrasts.  Kapell fully conveys the disappointed depression of the Op 41/2 Mazurka (track 16).  Kapell has something unique and personal to say about this repertory and, combined with unusually good engineering for their vintage, it justifies the entire re-release in my eyes.The 3rd Sonata has received several great recordings, including a classic version from Romanian pianist Dinu Lipatti contemporaneous with Kapellâ€™s.  The question here, as it always is for historic reissues, is whether the defects in sound are outweighed by the playing.  It most certainly is for the 10 Mazurkas but I didnâ€™t find the 3rd Sonata from Kapell distinctive enough to compensate for the dated though not awful engineering.  It is a good interpretation but just doesnâ€™t stand out.  The 2nd Sonata is to my ears more successful playing, with intensity and a sure sense of structure.  But it fails the cost/benefit balance because the session, done on acetate at a radio performance in Australia, sounds downright lousy.A very good and individual Mazurkas makes this a release Iâ€™m glad I own. Hopefully, this helps you make an informed decision.

I went back and compared this more recent Pierre Boulez recording of Anton Webern with the the older complete Webern set on Sony, done in the late 1960s with the London Symphony.  My summary is that the performances are similar â€“ Boulez has a very strong and idiomatic interpretive style â€“ with the later DG release holding a minor marginal edge over the earlier performances.The older LSO version on Sony stresses the metric regularity heard in certain portions of Webernâ€™s 12-tone work a bit more than the newer DG Boulez, which is a bit more romantic and impressionistic.  I heard the biggest difference in the orchestral Variations, the only piece where I had a clear preference for the new DG alternative.  Otherwise, differences are small.  The new DG has marginally tighter orchestral playing; it has marginally better engineering;  Christiane Oelze, the terrific soprano in the DG, is a bit more technically secure and nuanced than Halina Lukomska, the soprano in the older version.  The way Oelze confidently hits the final high note about 3â€™ into the final track of the 1st Cantata (1939) is a plus for the DG.On the other side of the ledger, I have a marginal preference for the older LSO version of â€œDas Augenlichtâ€, that very interesting short choral piece Webern wrote in 1935.  The two numbers for bass that open the 2nd Cantata (1943) are handled a bit more musically by the fine soloist, Barry McDaniel, who fronts the older LSO version.  But the quality of the performances is close.  If you already have the older version, you shouldnâ€™t necessarily spring for the DG if you are interested in the four major works from Webernâ€™s last decade included here.This disc also contains two pieces that were only discovered in the 60s, the Five Pieces for Orchestra and a set of orchestral songs, here sung by Oelze.  They date from around 1910 so have that more impressionistic sheen of Webernâ€™s purely atonal works, before he adopted his masterâ€™s 12-tone technique.  I found them a very nice discovery.  Though they had been tucked away in a folder and forgotten, they strike me as first-rate Webern.  Oelze is absolutely terrific in the 3 Songs; her strong performance is key to making this recording work.For a lark, I compared Boulez performance of the Op 21 symphony, with Herbert von Karajan's, both done with the Berlin philharmonic (and both on DG ).  I realize some readers will stop taking me seriously for saying this but I was surprised to find I preferred Karajan's -- and by a fair bit.  Karajan simply projects more personality.  It is a bold performance, the long held notes in the middle part of the 1st â€œRuhig schreitendâ€ movement rising out of the kaleidoscope of sounds assembled by Webern.  In contrast, Boulez is clearly more familiar with the musical language of the symphony, but he leads a somewhat fussy and antiseptic interpretation, that doesnâ€™t have the impact or personality of Karajanâ€™s.Although I find Webernâ€™s music â€“ especially his late 12-tone works â€“ positively inscrutable, there are very many fascinating and impressive moments in this very strong Boulez release.  Recommended for fans of 20th-century music.

Arthur Rubinsteinâ€™s talent and origins tie directly to his approach to Frederic Chopinâ€™s music.  A native of Lodz in Poland, a few miles from Chopinâ€™s birthplace, he grew up in a culture with an intimate closeness to the composer and his musical language.  Besides being connected to Chopinâ€™s background, Rubinstein was also a phenomenal musical talent, developing perfect pitch at the age of two and showing astounding technical prowess untied to any rigorous practice regimen.  Rubinstein once presented a Franck piece with a Spanish orchestra without ever practicing it on a piano (!) and he frankly admits that he achieved his early successes on the stage without doing much practicing, only beginning to seriously learn and perfect the music in later years.  So everything suggests his having a natural and direct relationship with Chopinâ€™s Mazurkas, the set of works which perhaps most directly spring from the authorâ€™s Polish heritage.  And this is what I hear: Rubinstein is relaxed and utterly at ease playing the Mazurkas.Take the interesting and dissonant opening to the well-known Op. 24/4 Mazurka, which can -- and has been -- presented stringently.  Rubinstein is gentler and tapers off the initial tempo as he takes the introduction into the main section; this slowing down is done with wonderful effortlessness.  The dotted rhythms in the main section of this Op 24/4 are done with perfect grace, yet Rubinstein still inflects the piece with drama and emotional power at the minor climaxes which conclude the main A section.  The slightly mysterious wistfulness of the Op. 33/4 Mazurka is similarly done with ease and sensitivity, the left-hand interjections in the bass presented in an uncomplicated way.Deft handling of the metric and rhythmic ambiguities is found throughout this set.  Chopin inserted a sort of shift into the contrasting passage in the â€˜Aâ€™ section of the Op. 59/3 Mazurka.  Rubinstein presents it so naturally that one can forget the difficulties the shift presents.  This is just a sampling of the beautiful playing in this set.  I could go on for much longer.But Rubinsteinâ€™s easygoing charm does imposes a few limitations. Intensity varies: the great C#-minor Mazurka Op 50/3 lacks the passion of certain other interpretations.  Some other more serious Mazurkas fare better.  The quietly tragic Op 56/3 Mazurka is done with genuine feeling.  Any interpretive approach will de-emphasize musical or emotional dimensions of great music like the Mazurkas â€“ and the downsides of Rubinsteinâ€™s take are few and offset by instance after instance of wonderful sensitivity and directness.I have been sampling a number of Mazurka performances from other pianists, using the Rubinstein set as a reference with all of them included.  Rubinsteinâ€™s is the one I enjoy most.  The sound engineering though from a few decades back is actually very good.  This is one classic version that surpasses expectations.  Strongly recommended.
