I was recently bowled over by Khatia Buniatishviliâ€™s Franz Liszt disc, an honest-to-god great recording, even a landmark one.  Based on that experience, I hurried to get her Chopin disc.  It is not quite up to the Liszt but nevertheless is very good and has a few tracks that are memorable and outstanding.The interpretation that caught my ear was the 2nd Sonata, where Buniatishvili emphasizes its lyrical side.  This sometimes terse and dramatic Sonata can sound very different.  Evgeny Kissinâ€™s excellent 2000 recording on RCA shines by emphasizing the aggression and energy of the opening â€˜Doppio movimentoâ€™, the outer sections of the Scherzo and the terse finale.  Buniatishvili shines on the other hand in the more lyrical sections.  Her version of the slow central â€˜Bâ€™ section of the â€˜Scherzoâ€™ is ravishing â€“ just this couple of minutes justifies the entire release.  Equally exquisite is the famous slow section of the Funeral March which follows â€“ this is playing that makes time stand still.The 4th Ballade is also presented very well.  This is one of Chopinâ€™s best compositions, in my humble opinion, and the Ballade can be presented from many angles.  Buniatishvili does it both a bit more quickly than many other competing versions but also more gently.  The idea of distant lands in the Ballade is a call from far away in her hands and not an adventure.  There is also a sense of large-scale architectural thinking here, something very apparent in Buniatishviliâ€™s powerful Liszt Sonata in B minor.  Even 3 or 4 minutes into the 4th Ballade, Buniatishvili is still building towards something, finally realized in a fiery concluding coda.  This is a terrific performance, to set next to my own favorite, Bela Davidovichâ€™s glamorous version, and displays Buniatishviliâ€™s particular strengths, her ability to construct long paragraphs of music and to re-think familiar repertory from the ground up.Also included are very appealing versions of the famous Op 17/4 Mazurka and the Op 64/2 Waltz.  The weakest part of this release is the performance of the early 2nd Concerto, done with Paavo Jarvi and the Orchestre de Paris.  Iâ€™m at a bit of a loss to explain why this interpretation doesnâ€™t work for me.  All the musicians involved play with energy and commitment, but they arenâ€™t helped by a very mediocre sound engineering job from Sony (thereâ€™s a surprise â€“ yes, Iâ€™m being sarcastic).  Itâ€™s one of those presentations that puzzlingly sounds a bit rushed, the moments in between different phrases not quite right and the pianist and orchestra, though all the notes are done perfectly, not aligned perfectly in terms of timing.Buniatishvili is clearly a major talent; I look forward to her future releases with anticipation.  This disc is uneven but the performances of the 2nd Sonata and the Ballade make it a notable release.  5 stars.

In a master class several decades ago, I heard Janos Starker deliver the following advice: â€œStudents often ask me how to prepare for a concert.  I tell them to leave plenty of time.  Dress at home, slowly.  Make sure youâ€™ve had a small meal before the event so youâ€™re not hungry.  Drive to the concert hall slowly, leaving plenty of time for mishaps and arriving well ahead of time.  When you get to the concert hall, warm up a lit, leaving time to become comfortable with the hall.  Next, you go into the rest room and throw up.  Now, youâ€™re ready to go onstage and perform.â€Clearly the guy had a sense of humor, but his musical personality is different, stark and severe.  These famous recordings of the six solo JS Bach Suites for cello, paired with two of Bachâ€™s Sonatas for cello and piano done with fellow Hungarian Ã©migrÃ© to the American midwest, Gyorgy Sebok, are cornerstone midcentury baroque recordings.  Dating from 1963and 1965, the engineering holds up pretty well and still sounds good, not surprising coming from the esteemed Mercury label, although the sound of the cello is bare rather than lush.Starkerâ€™s interpretation of the very beautiful 5th Suite reveals him at his best.  The Prelude of this Suite, with the noble dotted rhythms typical of this overture form, sees Starkerâ€™s severity projected with power, a power which extends to the fugal 2nd section which follows.  There is a real sense of forward momentum in this fugato, making for exciting listening.  I also think the 2nd Suite comes off particularly well.  The 2nd ends with a Gigue finale which can be presented in a lighter, merrier way.  Starker presents it with strength instead, the opening leaps not joyful but a launchpad into the scale runs, done with intensity and with a great sense of coherence.  The slow Prelude to the 2nd also suits Starkerl.  Constructed differently from the Prelude of the 5th suite, this 2nd suite Prelude presents a weaving and mostly even melody that builds into a climax about 2â€™ in.  It suits Starkerâ€™s temperament and he does it perfectly.With the sternness, though, there can come a drab sense of sameness, the downside of the Starker approach.  This dullness is found in the Bourree II from the 4th Suite, a beautiful, sunny â€˜Bâ€™ section built over double stops; Starker plays it like he is bored, and I was bored as a consequence.  The 4th is not as successful a performance as some others on this set and I found both Bourrees and the final Gigue sound bored, with a lack of rote sense of rhythmic fluidity not up to Starkerâ€™s formidable reputation.  I am also not fond of the two cello sonatas done with Sebok, a pianist with a sterling reputation within the profession.  Starkerâ€™s austerity, which can be so successful in the solo suites, suppresses the brio and sparkle of these sonatas, which are lighter fare.  Even the sadder portions of the sonata arenâ€™t successful.  The Sicilienne from the G major Sonata is a somber piece but it sounds dull and lacking feeling.  The thin sound of the cello in this recording also doesnâ€™t fit what I think is luxuriant music.  (I have the old LP set of these sonatas and the remastering canâ€™t be blamed for the thin sound in the sonatas; it didnâ€™t sound great on vinyl either.)  Get this set for the suites.This is beautiful playing, but of a certain type.  It is Bach without frissons, the Lutheran churchman, dour, austere, imposing.  And that would be fine -- but Starker is uneven on his own terms.  This Starker cycle, despite its reputation, doesnâ€™t equal the standard setter for the Suites, the recording from French cellist Pierre Fournier, and it doesnâ€™t match my current favorite among the modern cycles, from American cellist Zuill Bailey.  Still, I found parts of the set powerful and generally enjoyed it.  4 stars.

Before covering the performance, I must underline that the music Krystian Zimerman plays is some of the most incredible ever written.  Chopinâ€™s 4th Ballade, the Barcarolle and the F minor Fantasie back to back?  Each is an inspired masterpiece from Chopinâ€™s peak.  The first three Ballades are no slouches either.  So the selections are fantastic and make for an hour of spellbinding listening.What about Zimermanâ€™s performance?  It is studied and perfectionist.  The placement of each note and each chord is carefully considered and then carefully practiced.  Articulations are varied; the different lines and accompaniment harmonies are played with precision.  An upper echelon technician, Zimerman is in fine form here.  And there is thought put into the interpretations as well.  I wouldnâ€™t call his interpretation cerebral; self-conscious is a better word.  I could feel the weight of many excellent prior interpretations of this familiar music on Zimermanâ€™s shoulders as I listened to his playing.  Each of the six pieces found here have a big, rousing final section, some of them absolutely wonderful.  As he builds into them, I didnâ€™t feel much sense of relief, but rather Zimermanâ€™s conscious thought that passion and excitement needed to be generated now.  I think listeners just getting to know this Chopin wonâ€™t experience this particularly strongly â€“ Zimerman after all is an outstanding pianist and the attention to detail here is impressive â€“ but some who know it well will feel this is all a bit stilted.There are outright successes here.  I really enjoyed the big concluding section of the 2nd Ballade, where Zimerman just seems to be freer.  The sense of momentum and enthusiasm makes for really beautiful musicmaking.  The details in the first section of the Barcarolle are jewel-like, with Zimermanâ€™s precision and control coming out in the best light.  But there are weak points, too.  The 4th Ballade â€“ a favorite of mine, with its intimations of the exoticism and distant lands â€“ is just a bore (strange to ever find myself applying this adjective to this composition!). In the Fantasie, the open sections dotted rhythm contrasting theme suggests a funeral march, making the whole section a sort of premonition of death.  None of that sense of tragedy comes out of Zimermanâ€™s playing.So this disc is a mixed success.  I also want to complain about the sound engineering.  Audiophiles have been complaining about DG sonics for decades and this disc -- fuzzy and with a weird piano timbre -- is a case in point.  Zimerman provides a fine effort that obviously has generated a lot of throughtful reactions from other people, as you can tell from the interesting reviews here on Amazon.  But it wonâ€™t replace my favorite versions of these pieces â€“ Bela Davidvoch in the Ballades, Dinu Lipatti of course in the Barcarolle, and Shura Cherkassky in the Fantasie â€“ although it is a creditable, accomplished effort.  I just wish Zimerman had felt less on the spot and more liberated to give us what he has in many of his other very fine recordings.

Iâ€™ve had a longstanding fascination with Bedrich Smetanaâ€™s 2nd quartet.  Though it is an overlooked piece, the Lindsay Quartet, in their recording on the ASV label, have given us an interpretation that emphasizes the pieceâ€™s terse, compact and almost aphoristic character.  After reading that the Prazak were viewed as leading interpreters of Smetanaâ€™s pair of quartets, I sought out their version.  The comparison with the Lindsayâ€™s was very interesting and forced some careful listening and thought.  The Prazak are superior in terms of musicality on the phrase-by-phrase level. This is true of this entire recording; the lines flow and are presented with flexibility and sensitivity throughout.  There also is a sense of conviction in the playing.  But at the same time their 2nd quartet didnâ€™t strike me as remarkable or unusual.  In the Lindsayâ€™s hands, it stands out from other late romantic chamber music.  Not longwinded, but nervously shifting between short phrases, full of contrasts, all bunched into four brusque movements coming in at about 18 minutes.  There is something â€œout of timeâ€ about the 2nd.  But that unusual tinge of non-romanticism didnâ€™t strike me as I repeatedly listened to the Prazakâ€™s performance.The disc overall is good.  The most famous work here is the â€œFrom My Lifeâ€ Quartet, with its autobiographical basis and that strident moment in the finale which represents the hearing diseases (tinnitus?) that afflicted Smetana in his later years.  The Prazak, as in the 2nd quartet, is unfailingly musical, but they also tend to overplay, with a lack of textural variation.  Their approach is not helped by a flawed digital recording with a tendency towards harshness.The Prazakâ€™s lead violinist, Vaclav Remes, joins with pianist Sachiko Kayahara for a performance of the rarely-performed duo â€œFrom the homelandâ€ (1880).  Remesâ€™ playing as a solo violinist here illustrates the strengths and weaknesses of the Prazak Quartet: he is highly musical but also unstintingly applies high levels of vibrato.  I drew the conclusion that all four of the Prazak members really lay on the vibrato and that lends their sound a uniform and thick quality.  Some listeners will enjoy this; personally, I prefer a performance style more reliant on coloristic and timbral variety.With the inclusion of â€œFrom the Homelandâ€, the Prazak presents all three chamber works from the painful last decade of Smetanaâ€™s life, the quartets being completed in 1875 and 1883, the last one written a few months before his death.  This is valuable.  While it looks to me like â€œFrom the Homelandâ€ was written to make a buck, as it was commissioned by a German publisher interested in Eastern European style music, I enjoyed getting to know it, especially the second part, which is played very nicely by Remes and Kayahara.So I have some criticisms but I do recognize the quality and attractions of the Prazakâ€™s performance.  A solid 4-star effort.

Italian pianist Aldo Ciccolini, who just died earlier this year (2015), had a strong reputation as a performer of Franz Liszt's music.  I admire his wonderful recording of Emmanuel Chabrierâ€™s â€˜Pieces pittoresquesâ€ but I find this complete recording of Lisztâ€™s â€œAnnees de Pelerinageâ€ mixed in quality, although it has its moments.Ciccolini plays the more traditional, early romantic works from the â€œAnneesâ€ with a winning directness.  His interpretation of the â€œBells of Genevaâ€, from the first Swiss Annee, exemplifies Ciccoliniâ€™s performance style.  The â€œBellsâ€ is often approached as an atmospheric study, with a focus on its pure sound.  Ciccolini takes it quickly and emphasizes clarity and the foreground melody.  It is a straightforward performance that relegates the pianistic and tonal effects to a background characteristic.  While I enjoyed it, I donâ€™t think the piece emerged in a particularly memorable way.  The long â€œVallee dâ€™Obermanâ€, also from the Swiss Annee, is done simply and with a crisp tempo but the result is affecting and cohesive.  Again, a nice performance that I enjoyed but one that doesnâ€™t tap the depth of â€œdâ€™Oberman.â€While the first two Annees are mostly successful interpretations with a specific viewpoint, Ciccolini I think trips up in an unsuccessful 3rd Annee, a set from Lisztâ€™s austere and experimental final period.  The 3rd Annee badly needs an excellent recording as my listening history with it over the years has involved one disappointment after another.  Unfortunately, Ciccoliniâ€™s version here is part of this unsatisfying group.  The playing has a stridency and a lack of attention to the pianoâ€™s potential for coloristic touches that for example completely fails to bring out the beauty in the well-known â€œFountains of the Villa dâ€™esteâ€.  I also felt an aimlessness, the lack of any particular point of view in the two ambitious â€œCypres of the Villa dâ€™esteâ€ that join the â€œJeux dâ€™eauxâ€ as a sort of central trilogy.  These â€œCypresâ€ are, according to some writers, masterpieces of Lisztâ€™s late period, yet Ciccolini is less inspired and also less sure-handed with them.  I also thought the stridency, and the tendency to bang the keyboard harmed the interesting short piece â€œSursum Corda.â€If he had performed a strong 3rd Annee, this would have raised the set into a cornerstone Liszt recording, given the quality of the first two Annees and the need for a very good 3rd.  Unfortunately, this is not the case.  One alternative recording that I recommend is Alfred Brendelâ€™s very successful 2nd Annee from Italy.  Ciccolini is helped by a pretty good EMI recording job, which shows some age but is still pleasant and revealing.  4 stars.

Crossover into popular music structure: the performers may be a string quartet, but the formal structure of the selection of pieces here is popular.  They typically are constructed from a verse and chorus, with some bridges and introductions thrown in.  To me this is the defining aspect of this album: it doesnâ€™t have the formal variety found in classical or art music, but hews to the typical verse/chorus structure of pop songs. The listening experience is far closer to taking in a Paul Simon album than Dmitri Shostakovich.Crossover into the polyculture: Most other compositions or albums grow from a single musical culture, often a very specific, localized one.  â€œCaravanâ€ is different in character and telescopes out to bring us flavors from many regions.  Not rooted in place, it is a â€œtravelogue,â€ the styles originating from Eastern Europe, Bollywood, Argentina, California, Mideastern Arab culture and Iberia.Any compilation of recent music will be of uneven quality.  Several of the compositions have been very rewarding.  Iâ€™ll point to the two numbers from Carlos Paredes, an older composer from Portugal, the mournful â€œCancao Verdesâ€ and the Romance No.1, which to my mind is closest to an â€œartâ€ composition of any of the selections in â€œCaravan.â€  I also enjoyed â€œAaj Ki Ratâ€ from Indian composer Rahul Burman quite a bit.  Many of the selections were arranged for the Kronos by well-known Argentine/US composer Osvaldo Golijov.I have great respect for the Kronos Quartet, a very high quality ensemble both technically and artistically, and they live up to their high standards here, providing engaged, musical and accomplished playing pretty much through the entire disc.  For example, the playing of the sliding intro to â€œLa muerte Chiquitaâ€ from Mexican rock songwriter Enrique Rangel is beautifully executed.  They are also recorded well â€“ the disc sounds very good.  Is the album perfect?  No, there are some clunkers here.  In particular, I will point to the abomination from Terry Riley (â€œCortejo Funebreâ€), an artist the Kronos have long championed.  I also thought the final track, â€œMisirlou Twistâ€ from Nicholas Roubanis, is a yawner.  But there are also some really fine efforts from little-known composers.  It also serves well as background music, if you are able to skip over the Terry Riley track.  I enjoyed getting to know this album.

Mixed is how Iâ€™d describe the results of French pianist Jean-Louis Steuermanâ€™s 1987 performance of Alexander Scriabin solo piano music.  Steuerman has impressive technical command of what is some very taxing music and he sometimes imprints it with real emotional oomph but he also has a tendency, repeatedly shown, for a dry, too clinical and emotionally uninvolved playing of Scriabin.Although I found the performances of both the 3rd and 4th piano sonatas that start off the disc as disappointing, Iâ€™ll first focus on Steuermanâ€™s rendition of the beautiful Poem Op. 32 no. 1 to illustrate his interpretive weaknesses.  This is a short, glowing and ecstatic piece of tone painting, the patterns spreading out into a vibrant set of chords supporting the calm and memorable main theme.  Steuerman executes the notes perfectly with admirable sensitivity to the polyphonic writing embedded into the Poem, but there is also a very clear lack of feeling or understanding of what Scriabin intended.  Steuerman is playing the notes only.  The 4th sonata, that short jewel of fin-de-siecle messianic spiritualism, should glow with the impending arrival of a new age, but in Steuermanâ€™s hands, the sense of excitement is not to be found.  I was also disappointed in the lack of power in his performance of the 3rd sonata; a comparison with Emil Gilelsâ€™ tremendous 3rd from the Soviet era shows just the sort of enthusiasm and fervor that is lacking.That said, Steuerman has his moments.  I enjoyed his playing of the 5th sonata, the summoning of â€œmysterious forcesâ€.  His technical command of the rumbling passage that begins and ends the sonata allows him to do it exceptionally swiftly, which I thought worked, and I appreciated the excitement he brings to the crescendo to the final climax of the main section, where the theme marked as â€œAllegro fantasticoâ€ is repeated in a falling sequence.  Steuermanâ€™s 5th struck me as being on another, better level than much of the rest of the disc.  He also has included miniatures from Opp. 34, 44 and 57.The recorded sound is pretty good, especially for its era.  Steuermanâ€™s disc was released at a time when Scriabin recordings were relatively hard to come by.  In todayâ€™s era, with Scriabin better represented in the discography, I can name several versions of each of the works contained here that I prefer by a fair margin, with the possible exception of the 5th, where I find Steuermanâ€™s effort very creditable.

Vladimir Feltsman has paired two major late Ludwig van Beethoven piano sonatas here, the Op. 101 in A from 1816 and the famed and massive â€œHammerklavierâ€ Sonata Op. 106 completed in 1819.  The more successful performance here in my view is the Op. 101 sonata, but the Op. 106 sonata also is worthwhile and, while not my favorite version, is enjoyable and musical.Feltsman takes a lyrical approach to the Op. 101.  The opening Allegretto is done more softly and slowly than I am used to, a conception which I find compelling as the piece gains a more unified and coherent aspect from Feltsmanâ€™s gentleness.  The March which follows contrasts pretty strongly, the dotted rhythms not brought out aggressively but with assertion.  I particularly enjoyed Feltsmanâ€™s way with the fugal Allegro which concludes the Op. 101 â€“ it is an alive and creative presentation of one of Beethovenâ€™s late fugal experiments.The big Op. 106 sonata is given a less exceptional performance.  Feltsman presents what I would call a balanced view.  My favorite performance of the â€œHammerklavierâ€ is from Christoph Eschenbach, who projects great intensity, especially in a very slow but absolutely memorable â€œAdagio sostenutoâ€ that clocks in at over 20 minutes.  Feltsmanâ€™s playing of the Adagio is more traditional and also quicker, with a time of about 16 minutes.  It is a nice version, and one which I enjoyed, but here and in the transition into the big fugal finale, a baroque-tinged fantasy-like passage that is one of my favorite portions of the Op. 106, he doesnâ€™t bring the intensity Iâ€™ve heard from some other pianists.Sound quality is good.  This isnâ€™t a great recording, but itâ€™s a good one marked by a particularly successful Op. 101 Sonata.

Arkady Volodos plays the solo piano music of Franz Liszt found here with an emphasis on color and sensitivity and nuance.  He starts off with the â€œVal dâ€™Obermannâ€, from the First Year of Pilgrimage, an ambitious composition that I have found over the years is susceptible to radically different interpretations.  Volodosâ€™ vision of â€œValâ€ is coloristically precise, with more emphasis on the polyphonic lines weaving through the textures, very different from performances which, to mention some options, emphasize the pieceâ€™s reliance on a small set of chord shifts or more emotion-centric ones that focus on the workâ€™s depression and sense of tragedy.  The emphasis on the color allows for the climactic passage towards the end (about 10â€™ into track 1) to be especially vivid and rich as done by Volodos.Volodos has an absolutely marvelous control of the exact weight and pressure applied by his hands.  The â€œmicro-controlâ€ of each note is at times astonishing.  An austere late piece written to commemorate the death of Richard Wagner, the â€œLugubre Gondole Iâ€ (track 9) benefits from Volodosâ€™ ability to shape the slow-moving lines with subtle dynamic variations within the individual melody.  This style of performance doesnâ€™t just benefit some of the more atmospheric numbers.  The  â€œWeinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagenâ€ Prelude, a delicious example of mid-romantic Bach-iana, is given a fine performance, the individual lines differentiated coloristically so as to fully bring out the musicâ€™s polyphonic conception.This emphasis on preciousness and color and detail can de-energize the music, almost as an automatic by-product.  So Volodosâ€™ Liszt isnâ€™t fiery or wild, two adjectives commonly associated with the composer.  The 13th Hungarian Rhapsody (track 5) is likely the least successful track here.  It is tamed and Liszt the demonic Magyar begins to turn into the sensuous sonneteer.  Volodos manages to project more energy in the final ostinato build-up from â€œFuneraillesâ€ (track 8), so the 13th Rhapsody seems more flawed than it should, even given Volodosâ€™ approach.Overall the performance is outstanding, original and shows yet again that Volodos is a world-class musician, even disregarding his phenomenal piano chops.  I have highlighted certain tracks so far but others, such as the â€œIl pensorosoâ€ (track 2) and the wonderful â€œEn reveâ€ (track 10), are very effective.  Audiophiles have been entranced by the sound engineering job given Volodos by Sony.  I found the sound on this disc too reverberant but very detailed during the cleaner passages.  All in all, this is a terrific Liszt recital that I know I will be pulling out for decades to come.  Warmly recommended.

As men and boys likely sang all parts in Heinrich Schutzâ€™s music during his lifetime, this 1982 French effort experiments with full authenticity by featuring boy soprano Sebastian Hennig and countertenor Rene Jacaobs (who was later to gain fame as a conductor) singing 13 numbers from the Petits concerts spirituels (1636/39) and Symphoniae sacrae Book II (1647).  But whatever their take on historical authenticity, musical performances from today stand and fall on their qualities.  The vocalists here sing with a certain ability but donâ€™t approach either the technical or musical ability of average soloists in other recordings.  This makes this recording not a terrible one but it is definitely a non-starter.Comparisons with established artists arenâ€™t fair of course as Sebastian Hennig was all of 13 or 14 when he made this disc.  So when I make the comparison, I am well aware thatâ€™s itâ€™s like evaluating say a high school player going up against a National Basketball Association professional (or pick your analogy).  But if Iâ€™m listening to the powerful â€œHerr unser Herrscherâ€ (track 6, from the Symphoniae sacrae), my favorite version, the unusual, heartfelt and bracingly original one from Anna Mikolajczyk done with the Capella Augustana is on another musical level.  A more traditional version from Early Music star Emma Kirkby and the Purcell Quartet may come second to Mikolajczyk but it is also on a much more elevated plane of artistic accomplishment than an earnest but more developmental effort from a talented teenager.Countertenor Ree Jacobs was a fully-formed artist when this disc was made and, while he has some good moments, I also heard dynamic control problems throughout the recording and also intonation issues that often shaded into full-on pitch at times.  No other vocalists are featured.  The instrumental ensemble is led by prominent Early Music specialist William Christie, who like Jacobs has also been based on France.  They do an OK job.  Besides the weakness of the vocalists, I found musical shortcomings afflicting the entire ensemble.  â€œIhr Heiligen lobsingetâ€ (track 12) for example is a short but exceptionally creative and interesting number which is dragged to an utterly insensitive conclusion â€“ it doesnâ€™t end, it stops.  The performance overall tends towards the bland and reserved.  The audio quality is quite good.Apart from those wishing to experience unusual vocal types, I donâ€™t see any compelling aesthetic reason to abandon using female singers for soprano and alto parts in Schutz, something which has been standard in both traditional and authentic style efforts.  Besides the two strong Symphoniae Sacrae efforts I have pointed to above, Philippe Herreweghe has given us a lovely version of the Petits concerts spirituels and other works (also on Harmonia Mundi France).  Compared to all of these, this Jacobs/Christie collaboration is a miss.

With his recordings of Beethoven piano sonatas, Friedrich Gulda took steps down an unusual road in this musicâ€™s performance history.  Gulda chose to strongly constrain metric and tempo flexibility so the music arises from a very steady beat, the foundation a rigid bedrock.  As an idea this can strike one as too cerebral, corralling the pianist into a narrow range of emotion.  In practice, I found this disc to be refreshing emotionally and at times very moving.  The precious and indulgent is excised completely and what is left is a direct and straightforward presentation that seems to fit Beethovenâ€™s conception so truly.The approach is particularly successful in the much-loved â€œPastoralâ€ sonata, Op. 28.  Gulda plays the opening movement at a pretty snappy pace and maintains the meter very evenly.  But this is not at all a dull or faceless performance. Iâ€™ve found the opening Allegro is generally played with some rubato (tempo flexibility) to present expression. Guldaâ€™s direct simplicity instead eliminates a tendency to mawkishness and intensifies the serene sense of meaning held by the Allegro.  It is given an absolutely wonderful interpretation of -- and I have heard many. Guldaâ€™s approach to the famed Andante that follows is also pretty fast and, as with the Allegro, the approach leads to great expressivity, but one joined to a sense of momentum.  One aspect of the performance is worth clarifying and the opening Allegro of the Pastorale can be used as an example: when Beethoven tells the player to slow down, Gulda does so.  Gulda simply reduces greatly the tempo variation when no written instructions are found in the score.Gulda also stands out in an excellent performance of the Op. 13 â€œPathetique.â€  The tempo may be rigid but the exciting cadential passage that concludes each of the fast inner sections in the opening movement are energetic and vital.  Gulda made an exception to his general style, it seems to me, in the brilliant opening Allegro con brio of the â€œWaldsteinâ€ Sonata Op. 53, where he infuses the score with as many tempo fluctuations as in more mainstream performances.  His â€Waldsteinâ€ is strong and enjoyable, but it would be interesting to know why Gulda felt the need to do the Allegro con brio differently.  The disc also includes the lesser known and short two-movement Op. 54 sonata written the same year as the â€œWaldsteinâ€ (1804).So Guldaâ€™s sonatas are not an experiment but a very good and at times downright great re-envisioning of some familiar compositions.  The one criticism I would make of it is that the sound quality on this re-issue is quite mediocre.  Guldaâ€™s instrument is robbed of richness and the sound is a tad echo-y without being rich.  But if you are interested in unusual takes on the sonatas, Gulda â€“ a man who always thought for himself and played music in the way he considered artistically true â€“ has given us an exploration that helps bring forth the sonatasâ€™ sincerity, emotion and meaning.

A return to a work of art can sometimes be a rejuvenating rediscovery, the thrill reborn.  Or it can be a deadened retread, executed professionally but passionlessly.  Alfred Brendelâ€™s version of Beethovenâ€™s famed â€œWaldsteinâ€ Sonata Op. 53 found here is the latter kind, shot through with the greyness of middle age.  Brendel sounds bored here, like heâ€™s heard this piece a few thousand times â€“ which no doubt is true.  Whatâ€™s more, there is a surprising lack of technical proficiency.  The difficult opening Allegro con brio of the â€œWaldsteinâ€ is marked by difficult figurations and runs throughout; Brendelâ€™s execution of the passage work lacks precision, not just gusto.  This sloppiness can also be heard elsewhere.  The fugato subject in the opening Menuetto movement of the Sonata Op. 54 in F is not as tight as one would expect from a world-class pianist.  I found the same thing to be true of the finale of the Op. 54 but Iâ€™ll give Brendel a pass on this track, as Iâ€™ve always found this Allegretto difficult to project without blurred rhythms and a sheen of sloppiness.  The Andante favori which Beethoven originally wrote as the middle movement of the â€œWaldsteinâ€ is included here and holds the same sense of boredom as the rest of Op. 53.The ambitious A-major Sonata, Op. 101, fortunately is done better.  The opening Allegretto and the finale of the Op. 101 are to my ears the best part of this release.  While I found the technical execution better than in the â€˜Waldsteinâ€™, more importantly Brendel sounds engaged here, like he is interested in playing this music.  This is a difficult sonata for the listener.  Though I donâ€™t think contains the appealing freedom and sense of adventure of the 3 late sonatas (Op. 109 110 and 111) that followed it or the Delphic mystery of the late string quartets, it shows real thought and a feeling of exploration.  Written in 1816, after Beethovenâ€™s lapse into a temporary silence and at the inception point of his late period, it sounds like a transitional work, without the cryptic and beyond-human aspects of the later sonatas and string quartets from later on.  A bit drab and tired of grand and aggressive gestures, maybe the greyness and middle agedness of Op. 101 make it a more interesting piece for Brendel, because his performance his very creditable. Itâ€™s not a great version, and it unfortunately occasionally lapses into the sloppiness heard in the â€œWaldsteinâ€ (for example, in the middle section of the engaging Vivace alla marcia), but itâ€™s one where the pianist is alive to the music.Sound is fairly good.  This is not a terrific CD but if youâ€™re interested in the Op. 101 sonata, itâ€™s a pretty good choice.

Pianist Martha Argerich and cellist Mischa Maisky deliver another very characteristic recital of cello and piano duets, this time recorded in Kyoto, Japan in 2000.  The music as far as I can tell was all written in Paris so the program is neatly unified.Argerich and Maisky as always play with a great deal of freedom and rhythmic nuance, and this is obvious from the very first phrase of the Chopin Cello Sonata (1846), which Argerich presents with poise and sensitivity.  Though the performance of the sonata is excellent throughout, the final couple of minutes of the Largo are just remarkable, the luxuriant music presented with calm freedom.I am a big fan of Claude Debussyâ€™s Cello Sonata (1915) and one of the big â€“ and pleasant â€“ discoveries is hearing Maisky and Argerich put together what is probably the best performance of this sonata Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of hearing.  Like elsewhere, the two musicians are utterly at ease and play with a great deal of freedom.  This is a Cello Sonata that emphasizes the spectacular diversity of sounds and textural effects.  The inner Serenade, which has always struck me as an easily-overlooked intermezzo in between the striking outer movements, receives intense attention from Maisky and Argerich, who generate a rich palette of timbres and effects.The disc also contains a transcription for cello and piano of Cesar Franckâ€™s famous Violin Sonata.  I approached this performance with skepticism â€“ a transcription of a great work like the Franck?  To my surprise, Maisky presents the string part so effectively that it left me wondering whether this transcription actually didnâ€™t work better than the original scoring for violin.  Maybe only Maisky â€“ a free, almost impetuous cellist â€“ can bring this off.  But the result is beautiful and very natural.  The disc concludes with Chopinâ€™s slight and early Introduction and Polonaise brilliant (a teenage work from 1830).You can tell from my comments that this is a remarkable chamber music recording, which completely lives up to the stellar reputations of Argerich and Maisky.  The one criticism I have is a thin-sounding and not particularly textured sound engineering job from DG.  (Audience sounds are edited out successfully.)  But the performances are just so terrific â€“ they veer all the way from the very good to the downright brilliant â€“ that the sonic flaws should be overlooked.  A must-hear disc for the serious classical music fan.

This Baroque recording has a special and fond place in my heart as it converted me into a die-hard fan of Heinrich Schutz.  Schutzâ€™s emotional and melodic art is anything but dusty; its sincerity traverses the cultural chasm which lies between Schutz and ourselves.  I continue to find Schutzâ€™s â€œmini-requiemâ€ the â€œMusikalische Exequienâ€ (1636), a half-hour-long cantata for solo voices, choir and small instrumental group, particularly beautiful.  Since first listening to this disc, Iâ€™ve come to know the Symphoniae sacrae and other central Schutz works, but the Exequien holds its appeal.So how does this Swiss recording conducted by Hans-Martin Linde hold up?  It may not be perfect but itâ€™s still beautiful.  The performance is helped by some talented soloists, including countertenor James Bowman and tenors Ian Partridge and Nigel Rogers. Lindeâ€™s approach is half-way between early music and traditional Baroque performance styles.  The performance uses a choir, but not a particularly big one.  A countertenor has a significant role in the Exequien, but the soloists donâ€™t shy away from a restrained vibrato.  The instrumental forces are limited, with the three violins and eleven brass players, but they provide a letâ€™s say expansive support to the voices.  Linde takes things at a fairly stately, moderated pace, but the performance is very musical, with some tempo flexibility.  I thought the choral and instrumental groups generally do well.  The transitions between soloists and choral segments are handled adeptly, which helps the Exequien flow nicely.The Exequien is paired with a Pslam setting, number 136, a more majestic and I think less interesting work from earlier on in Schutzâ€™s career (1619).  As the Psalm is a fairly short work, coming in at under 10 minutes, this is a short disc.  The release dates from 1980 and it suffers from a downright mediocre sound engineering job, unrefined and blunt, although thankfully not annoying.  Despite some flaws, what is here is engaging and always fresh and honest.

Vladimir Sofronitsky, probably the leading performer of Alexander Scriabin, combines an awe-inspiring command of the pianoâ€™s range of timbral colors with an ability to convey the musicâ€™s long-range structure and what I always feel is an innate understanding of what the music means.  That last point is important because Scriabin considered his music a path towards spiritual enlightenment and not as a purely aesthetic creation.  Sofronitskyâ€™s place as a Scriabin performer helps make this release from specialty label Chant du Monde particularly valuable and enjoyable.  The release compiles six different live performances made in the 1950s and early 1960s.  The sound quality varies but, for several of the tracks, it is good and doesnâ€™t detract at all from the enjoyment of the pianism.  Crowd sounds are few throughout the disc. That said, this is a disc for Scriabin fans, despite the very capable remastering work by the labelâ€™s editors.  General listeners should seek out more modern recordings.The six sonatas included here are among Scriabinâ€™s most adventurous efforts.  I feel that Sofronitski is at his best when Scriabin had ventured past the brand of post romantic writing he channeled in his earlier years a.  His playing of Scriabinâ€™s is later work, intensely mystical and constructed from his characteristic rapturous assemblage of symmetrical modal scales and exotic tonal effects, shows a particularly strong affinity.  Highlights found on this Chant du Monde release include Sofronitskyâ€™s 10th sonata which I have thought for years was a reference recording, with its sensuous yet polyphonically-conceived whole-tone slow section.  The live 9th sonata which Sofronitsky recorded at the Moscow Conservatory I believe in 1960 has always been for me one of the peaks of Scriabin playing.  The version contained here is a different one, dating from June 1958, but still brings forth Sofronitskyâ€™s utterly assured rendition, both architectural and mystical.  Sofronitskyâ€™s ability to convey this musicâ€™s structural dimension is for me always striking.  A particularly good example is the re-transition into the coda of the 5th sonata, with its recap of the compositionâ€™s opening rumbling flurry of notes. Another highpoint here is the introduction of the second theme in the Andante of the 4th sonata, about 1â€™30â€ into track 2, where the falling cascade of notes is combined with the surging second theme first appearance.  Sofroniskyâ€™s performance of this 4th sonata is jewel-like and utterly brilliant.The recordings compiled here are:3rd sonata â€“ June 1958 â€“ some noise in the upper register, the least good sound quality on the release4th â€“ May 1960 â€“ one of the best sounding tracks here5th â€“ January 1955 â€“ pretty good sound8th â€“ June 1958 â€“ sounds better than the 3rd although itâ€™s from the same event9th â€“ June 1958  â€“ some noise in certain louder passages in the treble but actually very good sound outside of those few passages10th â€“ Feb. 1960 â€“ decent, Iâ€ve certainly enjoyed this performance over years of owning this disc(The three June 1958 tracks come from a recital at the Moscow Conservatory that has been released elsewhere by Denon and Vista Vera.)So I strongly recommend this disc for Scriabin fans.  Chant du Monde also released a companion compilation of Sofronitsky live performances from the 1940s and 1950s, assembling a complete set of Op. 8 Etudes and Op. 11 Preludes from a diverse set of sources. That Preludes/Etudes disc, although it is an impressive curatorial effort, doesnâ€™t have the same consistency of quality of this Sonatas disc.  5 stars for this one, as long as you belong to its intended audience.

This short but often incredibly beautiful release of Heinrich Schutzâ€™s sacred music is a very good entrÃ©e into this excellent composerâ€™s work.  It includes the â€œMusikalische Exequien,â€ a funeral cantata from 1636 that lasts a bit under half an hour, along with some selections for vocal ensemble from the 1630s and 40s.The â€œMusikalischen Exequienâ€ is the piece that was my first introduction to Schutz a couple of decades ago.  It is melodic and highly appealing and, like much of Schutzâ€™s music, emotionally open.  Although the Exequien presents with Schutzâ€™s typical sobriety, the cantata is neither somber nor tragic.  The interpretation found here from Chapelle Royale and leading early music conductor Philippe Herreweghe may not be perfect but its strengths are so evident that Iâ€™d place it among the handful of the finest Schutz recordings Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of hearing.  Herreweghe gives us a very polished rendition, with tight ensemble, outstanding solo and choral singing and a flowing sense of line that presents the Exequien as elegiac and harmonious.  The sheer sonic beauty of this interpretation is often astounding; it is a real joy.  Why isnâ€™t it perfect?  Herreweghe accentuates the workâ€™s calm perfection and understates its bare emotion.  For example, the entrance of the soloists about 2â€™ into the long first section, â€œâ€Nacket bin,â€ is typically declamatory and speeded up slightly, which I think allows the music to take flight to express mourning.  Herreweghe rigidly maintains the tempo, with no speeding up, something he very intently does throughout this entire disc.  I have no doubt this was a conscious decision on his part, but I think it robs the music of some of its potential.  That criticism aside, I found listening to this version of the â€œExequienâ€ incredibly rewarding.  Just a beautiful performance.Aside from the Exequien, 6 shorter sacred works are included, pulled from a number of different collections from the time period of the Exequien, all for groups of solo vocalists with and without continuo accompaniment.  Extracted from the â€œSacred choral musicâ€ of 1648, the motet â€œSelig sind die Totenâ€ (track 5) is so wonderful that it is worth acquiring this release just for it alone.  For eight solo singers, Schutz builds the motet from an upward turn which is worked into a rich contrapuntal fabric.  The ensemble here, which includes leading singers like bass Peter Kooy and soprano Agnes Mellon, provides a performance where each voice is distinguished by a different timbre, so that â€œSelig sindâ€ appears almost like a kaleidoscope of colors.  This ravishing motet is my favorite but other listeners may derive great pleasure from the other ensemble works, which are often absolutely lovely.The sound recording is both terrific and marked by occasional noise in the treble.  When that noise isnâ€™t present, it sounds just great, something which is very important for a performance style like Herrewegheâ€™s.  Obviously, I loved this release.  If you are interested in learning about Schutz, try this out; if you are a Schutz fan already, you will want to hear Herrewegheâ€™s interpretation.  Warmly recommended.

This ravishing motet is my favorite but other listeners may derive great pleasure from the other ensemble works, which are often absolutely lovely.The sound recording is both terrific and marked by occasional noise in the treble.  When that noise isnâ€™t present, it sounds just great, something which is very important for a performance style like Herrewegheâ€™s.  Obviously, I loved this release.  If you are interested in learning about Schutz, try this out; if you are a Schutz fan already, you will want to hear Herrewegheâ€™s interpretation.  Warmly recommended.

The subjects Peter Gabriel deals with in the eight songs found in â€œSecurityâ€ point to the albumâ€™s general theme:Rhythm of the Heat: African religionsSan Jacinto: Native American mythologyThe Family and the Fishing Net: Caribbean SanteriaAnd the subjects of modern western existence:I have the touch: Craving for human contactShock the Monkey: The cruelty of scientific researchLay your hands on me: A yearning for belief in a post-Christian worldWallflower: Madness as resistanceKiss of Life: an optimistic coda â€“ a better tomorrowThe mysteries and substance of non-Western cultures are contrasted with the dispiriting, dispirited loneliness of modern life.  â€œLay your hands on meâ€ is interesting because it expresses a yearning for religious rebirth, but within a western -- and I assume Christian -- context.  That may shift the way you view the things being contrasted to one between ancient religious solace and unsatisfying modern rationality.This was a favorite album of mine maybe two decades ago and I recently sat down to listen to it again, for the first time in over a decade.  Gratifyingly, itâ€™s held up quite well.  The substance of the lyrics is matched by some inspired songwriting.  And though it clearly sounds like 1980s music, it hasnâ€™t dated or aged badly.  The sounds are often intricate and rich.  The spooky opening of what I think is probably the best song on the album, â€œThe Family and the Fishing Netâ€, is a particularly good example, with (what I think are) synthesized flute sounds beginning almost inaudibly.  Bassist Tony Levinâ€™s â€œstick bassâ€ work also adds a visceral and original element to the sound.What are the flaws?  Iâ€™ll name two: Gabriel is simply not a particularly skillful lyricist.  â€œSecurityâ€ is actually better than his other work in this respect but itâ€™s really unfortunate in a terrific song like â€œFamily and the Fishing Netâ€ that there is a chorus-and-solo-response to the words â€œheadless chickens.â€  Some of the lines are evocative and meaningful, but there are some clunkers included.  The second flaw is a tendency towards over-repetitiveness.  I found the second half of the albumâ€™s big hit â€œShock the Monkeyâ€ mind-numbingly dull and would also point to â€œKiss of Lifeâ€ as too lengthy.  (This is a criticism Iâ€™d make of a lot of rock music â€“ it should be cut, cut, cutâ€¦ Donâ€™t even get me started on U2â€™s recent releases.)But those flaws donâ€™t negate some thoughtful and wonderful songwriting, a terrific back-up band and a very creditable sound engineering job.  This looks to remain as one of the rock eraâ€™s best albums.  5 stars.

This will be more like a paean than a review: of the couple thousand recordings in my collection, Pierre Fournierâ€™s recording of the Bach cello suites is in the very top echelon.  Its consistent excellence and beauty makes it a pleasure every time I listen to it.  I consider it the reference for the Bach suites and, while I certainly havenâ€™t heard every alternative, to me Fournierâ€™s performance is superior to the highly-regarded cycles from Pablo Casals and Janos Starker.Fournierâ€™s interpretation emphasizes rhythmic flexibility, musicality and a relatively light touch.  The deft sense of rhythm allows the music to flow naturally without ever dissipating into blandness.  The Prelude of the 2nd suite is I think particularly fine and reflects Fournierâ€™s many strengths.  He manages to both present flexibly within individual phrases while creating a sense of long-term structure.  This Prelude is built in a wave-like form, with the smaller eddies at times reaching a particular crest.  So the music flows up and down the register and reaches a high F (measure 20) before subsiding, followed by a gradual build up to the higher range in a passage that concludes with an understated but climactic triple stop in the dominant.  Fournierâ€™s performance is affecting and perfectly judged throughout.  The â€œtacticalâ€ phrasing is full of nuance without obscuring structurally-important pitches.Another very fine moment occurs in the concluding Gigue of the 3rd Suite, a dance which shows Fournier is capable of great intensity when he thinks the score calls for it.  This Gigue is relatively light-hearted and Fournierâ€™s style fits it perfectly, allowing it to be light but with a rhythmic fluidity stemming from his always sensitive treatment of the downbeats.  Within this calm and carefree external portion, though, the central section is built over a drone-like D.  Fournier shifts wonderfully from a light, understated approach into playing this central section with passion and a sense of urgency.The Fournier cycle combines rhythmic dexterity with emotional variety.  His technique is assured with no intonation issues anywhere.  The recording, dating from 1960, isnâ€™t modern but it sounds very good.  This is a landmark recording.  I have heard alternative versions of the Suites that have impressed and pleased me greatly, but Fournierâ€™s continues to stand as the exemplar.

There are very strong solo singers appearing here but their efforts can't surmount a generally tepid performance.  The disc contains most of the twenty Latin numbers for various soloists and instruments which Heinrich Schutz grouped together in his Symphoniae Sacrae, Book 1 and published in 1629.  The Symphoniae are strongly influenced by the Venetian style of such greats as Giovanni Gabrieli and Claudio Monteverdi and were likely written in the 1610s after Schutz had returned to his native Germany from the life-changing visit to Venice.  A Parisian recording dating from 1985, the disc freatures several solo singers along with the early music group, Les Saqueboutiers de Toulouse.The singing as I mentioned is excellent.  Iâ€™d point to the work of bassist Bernard Fabre-Garrus, who does beautifully in â€œBenedicam Dominumâ€ (track 3) and in perhaps the best single number in this 1st book of Symphoniae, the lament â€œFili mi, Absalomâ€ (track 8).  The performance of â€œFili mi, Absalomâ€ exemplifies this performance, with Fabre-Garrus periodically trying to inject some passion and life into the proceedings, but vanquished in this attempt by the uninspired instrumentalists.  Likewise, one of the tenors (not sure which one â€“ the accompanying materials are not informative â€“ but either John Elwes or Guy de Mey) sings very nicely in the beautiful â€œVeniteâ€ (track 9) but the performance again fails to take flight.  Two of the concluding tracks featuring the trumpets are particularly leaden (â€œAdjuro vosâ€ and â€œInveneruntâ€, tracks 14 and 15, respectively).Iâ€™ve owned this disc for a couple of decades and, despite my love for Schutzâ€™s music, itâ€™s never grabbed me or made me want to listen more to it.  It is recorded very well, a credit to the Erato engineers who seem to have surmounted the issues facing early digital sooner than some of their competition.  Unfortunately, I canâ€™t point to a better comprehensive performance of the Symphonia Sacrae Book I but four are featured in the Brilliant re-release of excerpts from the 1st two books of Symphnoiae from Cappella Augustana led by Matteo Messori, who give us a much more lively presentation, and I would recommend that as an alternative.  Three stars for this Saqueboutiers de Toulouse effort.

The disc contains most of the twenty Latin numbers for various soloists and instruments which Heinrich Schutz grouped together in his Symphoniae Sacrae, Book 1 and published in 1629. A Parisian recording dating from 1985, the disc freatures several solo singers along with the early music group, Les Saqueboutiers de Toulouse.The singing as I mentioned is excellent. The â€œLaetatus sumâ€ motet here is so beautiful the set is worth getting for that alone. The motet perfectly displays this performanceâ€™s virtues, the vocal and instrumental timbres carefully deployed to set off the sections and voices.  Often the strands in the polyphonic texture are differentiated with each of the voices set apart by a distinct color.  At other times, the soloists modify their tone color to make them similar and create a unified effect.  For example, at about 2' into the motet, the lower male soloists blend their tone together during a warm passage in the lower register.  Using the bassoon to mark the motetâ€™s â€œwalking bassâ€ may not be original to conductor Philippe Herreweghe but it's used particularly well here, with the instrumentâ€™s sound standing out vibrantly.  Emerging from a blending of older polyphonic thinking melded with baroque concepts, including a harmonic support from the continuo, that were new when Monteverdi wrote the vespers in 1610, this wonderful â€œLaetatus sumâ€ receives an inspired rendition.Overall, this â€œVespersâ€ from Herreweghe and his long-time group La Chapelle Royale along with some affiliated ensembles is the acme of technical accomplishment.  The solo and choral singing is impeccable and at the same time expressive.  As mentioned already, the use of different vocal colors to set off the individual lines in the polyphonic sections is carefully thought-out and brilliantly successful.  The next motet after â€œLaetatus sumâ€ is the duet â€œDuo seraphimâ€ and it also exemplifies this performanceâ€™s success, with beautiful solo singing and a resonant, rich continuo accompaniment.Herreweghe tends to be a more objective, less emotional musician and that has its downside. The tuneful and attractive chorale â€œAve versus corpusâ€ shows the weaknesses of approach. Itâ€™s a bit plodding, and in general this motet and the long, concluding Stabat mater isn't as fine as the concerto-like first section of the Vespers.  Itâ€™s in this first forty minutes that Herreweghe and La Chapelle Royale really shine.The highly successful emphasis on polyphony is helped by audiophile-level sound engineering, which allows each of the voices and instruments to be clearly heard and prevents the chorus, an ensemble that is often just so difficult for recordings to reproduce, from suffering from distortion.  This is the fourth recording of Monteverdiâ€™s Vespers that I have had the pleasure of sampling in recent weeks.  All are very good but I thought it would be helpful to provide a capsule summary of each one:Musica Fiata/Bernius: Heartfelt, emotional, outstanding soloists, mediocre sound.Boston Baroque/Pearlman: Balanced, stress on polychoral spatial effects, weaker soloists, very well recorded and performed choral numbers.Chapelle Royale/Herreweghe: Technically astounding.  Emphasis on polyphony, vocal timbres, audio engineering.Tragicomedia/Stubbs: Smallest forces with tiny chorus.  Strong soloists.  Least moving to me but a good â€œintimateâ€ version.Happy listening.
