This 1985 East German recording of selections from Heinrich Schutzâ€™s Symphoniae sacrae, Book 1 has some good moments but overall lacks the polish and consistency we usually hear in Baroque music performances today.  The label prominently displays the involvement of the esteemed tenor Peter Schreier, but he only appears in one selection, â€œVenite ad meâ€ (track 6),  certainly the releaseâ€™s single best number.  I also enjoyed the work of bassist Gunther Schmidt, especially his work in â€œAttenditeâ€ (track 7).  Both Schreier and Schmidt have mellifluous voices and interpret the music with musicality and technical command.But the same canâ€™t be said for all the performers.  I found the work of countertenor Werner Marschall substandard, and his individual number â€œExultavitâ€ (track 3) is shrill and strained.  Tenor Ekkehard Wagner is better but still not at a wholly satisfactory level,  his performance cramped by a nasal tone color.  The three boy tenors featured in â€œVeni dilecte meâ€ (track 5) do nicely.  The instrumental band is technically acceptable but suffers from a conductor, Hans Gruss, who barely exercises any directorial control.  The lack of control is heard in the way voices and instruments often just play along without much tempo flexibility or setting off of foreground and background.  Recorded sound is good.  So this is just an OK performance.A more comprehensive recording of the first book of Symphoniae sacrae by Les Saqueboutiers de Toulouse (on Erato) is listless; while better than this recording, it isnâ€™t wonderful.  Iâ€™ve been listening to a small selection of the first and second books of the Symphoniae Sacrae from the Cappella Augustana led by Matteo Messori (rereleased on Brilliant) which is a much more lively presentation, and I would recommend that as an alternative.  Three stars for this older release under review here.

Though Beethovenâ€™s 4th Piano Concerto stands as one of the great pieces ever written, the actual orchestration maybe isn't ideal, with a tendency to muddiness.  I seem to have spent decades listening to flawed performances of this wonderful concerto, many displaying thickness and a lack of clarity in the orchestra, such as in the well-known Leon Fleisher/George Szell release.  (If any readers want to recommend recordings of the 4th they particularly like, I encourage you to leave a comment below.)  With such recurring experiences, I turned to the Arte Nova release led by David Zinman, hoping that Zinmanâ€™s stress on textural clarity might fit well with the 4th concerto.  What I found was a musical interpretation from pianist Yefim Bronfman, a performer whom I think is both excellent and consistent, offset by wayward conducting from David Zinman, who doesnâ€™t really seem to be paying attention much of the time.This is lack of focus in the conducting is apparent throughout the disc but Iâ€™ll point to the Andante con moto from the 4th concerto (track 5) as a particularly disappointing example.  Zinman rushes the marcato octaves in the strings and doesnâ€™t lend them the imposing weight they need, with the breaths between the phrases exchanged by the piano and orchestra sped up to.  Flaws are apparent in some of the faster music as well.  The â€œHungarianâ€ second theme about 1 minute into the 3rd concertoâ€™s opening Allegro con brio (track 1) is almost always stirring but in Zinmanâ€™s hands it is fussy, with the secondary orchestral parts overemphasized at the expense of the musicâ€™s energy.  The performanceâ€™s nature I think is perfectly captured by the famous opening solo piano passage of the 4th concertoâ€™s Allegro moderato: Bronfman provides an expressive opening solo piano passage with the orchestra entering in a neutral disengaged way.This disc isnâ€™t helped by the downright weird sound, a sound also heard in the other Zinman Zurich Tonhalle Beethoven series.  The strings just sound off, like neither the live sound of an orchestra or conventional recorded reproduction of the section.  Zinmanâ€™s uneven and wayward approach is something Iâ€™ve noted before in this series.  His recording of the 1st and 2nd symphonies pairs a scintillating and enjoyable 1st symphony with a stymied, uneven 2nd.  So Bronfmanâ€™s characteristic excellence is offset by disappointing orchestral playing and odd engineering.  Three stars.

Despite stiff competition from some worthy alternatives, this 1989 release from Frieder Bernius and Musica Fiata has become my favorite version of Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s â€œVespersâ€.  Marked by very fine solo singing, what is most important is the emotion, grandeur and warmth that these musicians bring to this ramshackle, diverse â€œmega-workâ€, recreating it in its full glory.Much of the set is astonishingly beautiful but Iâ€™ll single out certain tracks as particularly noteworthy.  The â€œDuo Seraphimâ€, a concerto-like section springing from secular music of the time, is given just a wonderful performance led by tenors David Cordier, John Elwes, and William Kendall (disc 1, track 7).  Soprano soloists Monique Zanetti and Gillian Fisher combine with countertenor David Cordier in the â€œPulchra esâ€ concerto (disc 1, track 5) provide a fine, harmonious rendition, the trio of singers uniting in a blended sound. These soloists are joined by star bassist Peter Kooy at several points, including a fine â€œQuia fecitâ€ (disc 2 track 6).Bernius approaches the Vespers with reasonably large forces, and a â€œblendedâ€ choral style, the individual sections of the chorus united into a homogenous harmonic sound, an approach I would contrast with that of William Christie and Les Arts Florissants, where the individual lines within the choral textures are emphasized.  The polychoral effects â€“ spatial sensations following from setting the different forces across a physical performance space â€“ are heard but again not stressed.  In this way it is different from the fine recording by Martin Pearlman and Boston Baroque, which focuses on these spatial results.  The work by the instruments adds to the â€œVespers.â€  Bernius restricts the band to strings, horns and continuo, a bit less varied than other recordings, but they provide effective, often joyous accompaniment.  The bandâ€™s work on â€œDeposuit potentesâ€ (disc 2, track 9) is particularly memorable, a sense of entering into paradise projected by the viols and the arpeggiated chords in the continuo.The only real criticism I will make of this â€œVespersâ€ is that the recorded sound is mediocre and weaker than the alternatives.  But the level of the singing and the sheer beauty of this performance make up for it.  This is a must-hear for ancient music fans, the glory of Venice in 1610 brought back to life in a ravishing way.  Warmly recommended.

This re-release of a 1955 recording from Nicolai Malko and the Philharmonia Orchestra is noteworthy for a delightful and musical and version of Sergei Prokofievâ€™s 1st Symphony, the â€œClassicalâ€, one of the artistâ€™s best-known compositions.  The 1st brims with life in Malkoâ€™s hands, zesty and full of youth.  Itâ€™s always rewarding to hear playing like this, but unfortunately, the performances of the 7th and two excerpts from the â€œLove for Three Orangesâ€ arenâ€™t at that level.The Malko compares unfavorably to a more recent recording from Mstislav Rostropovich and Lâ€™orchestre National de France (on Erato) which contains both the 1st and 7th symphonies.  This performance also contains a wonderful 1st, fully the equal of Malkoâ€™s version, and a sentimental, often grand rendition of the 7th symphony.  The Rostropovich is comprehensively just plain old better than Malko in the 7th and technically better in the 1st.  Malkoâ€™s 7th is musical and done with the rhythmic flexibility and affection for the music we heard in the 1st, but the Philharmonia is simply not in top form for this session.  The 7thâ€™s opening Allegro â€“ for me, an aging artistâ€™s look backwards at the lost world of the romantic symphony across a chasm of pain and loss â€“ contains a running secondary line in the strings repeated several times throughout.  This line is typically subdued in the overall texture, but Malko chose to emphasize it, a decision which is then undercut by choppy playing from the Philharmonia.  What we have is a perhaps a wrongheaded directorial decision which is in any case executed poorly.  The relative lack of polish in the orchestra is maintained through much of the 7th.  Another instance of this subpar execution comes in the march-like second theme of the Andante espressivo (track 9), which is played choppily.  Malkoâ€™s effort isnâ€™t helped by the recorded sound, which isnâ€™t at all bad for a 1955 recording, but is not up to modern standards.  In contrast, Rostropovichâ€™s 7th is more interpretationally acute, more emotional and meaningful, and also displays superior orchestral execution and sound.  Iâ€™m not  clear why the Malko would be anything but a curiosity item given this competition.  I grew up listening to the 7th in the well-known recording from Gennady Rozhdestvensky and that performance is also more emotional and accomplished than the Malko.As an alternative to the â€œLove for Three Orangesâ€ numbers, I recommend an absolutely outstanding recording from Antal Dorati done with another London orchestra, the LSO (released on Mercury).  So this Malko recording has its attractions and provides a wonderful 1st but it faces some stiff competition and its flaws show as a result.  It stands as a good release but also as a superseded one.  4 stars.

The awe-inspiring, shambolic jumble that is Claudio Monteverdiâ€™s Vespers is given a very successful and balanced performance in this 1997 release from Martin Pearlman and his Boston Baroque, one that emphasizes the musicâ€™s polychoral spatial effects.  The set has many high points, absolutely beautiful sections that make the disc highly appealing.The tuneful â€œAve Maria Stellaâ€ is fetching throughout but Pearlmanâ€™s rendition of the forceful concluding choral segment has absolutely grabbed me (end of disc 2, track 2).  Pearlman provides a choral sound that is halfway between the more analytic sound obtained by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants in their Vespers recording and the more blended sound featured in the splendid version from Frieder Bernius and Musica Fiata.  Choral sound is generally difficult to reproduce in recordings so you have to give the Telarc engineers credit for the releaseâ€™s clarity and its general lack of distortion.  Another highlight is the â€œLauda Jerusalemâ€ Psalm (disc 1, track 15), given a stirring, powerful presentation by the Boston Baroque.  This â€œLauda Jerusalemâ€ strikes me as notable as this portion of the Vespers had not in the past made a strong impression.  Not so here.  Capping the first big section of the Vespers, the Lauda will knock you back.  Beautifully done.Pearlman also emphasizes the polychoral nature of Monteverdiâ€™s writing, a trait key to Venetian music from this time.  Polychoral effects rely on positioning musicians in different parts of the performing space and, again partly due to the quality of the engineering, we can clearly hear this â€œsoundstagingâ€ throughout the Vespers.  This is very well heard in the â€œGloria Patri,â€ towards the end of the Magnificat that constitutes the big multi-section finale of the Vespers (disc 2, track 14).  In the â€œGloria Patriâ€, the two male vocalists are located far apart and use the distance to make the repeated melodic lines into an echo effect.  One of the best known parts of the Vespers, the concerto-style â€œDuo seraphimâ€ (disc 1, track 10), also displays the emphasis on spatial effects, with the singers varying their tone colors while located far apart to fully bring out the weaving contrapuntal effects.Any criticism of this excellent set is limited.  Iâ€™d point to solo singing that is weaker than in the alternatives Iâ€™ve sampled â€“ although itâ€™s important to say that these alternatives have notably impressive solo singing, so itâ€™s a high bar to reach.  For example, the â€œNisi Dominusâ€ psalm in the first section (disc 1, track 12) contains some sloppy singing in the faster sections and the solo voices, especially the men, arenâ€™t quite as focused and precise as alternatives.  But that doesnâ€™t mean they arenâ€™t good â€“ just not very good.This is a consistently excellent Vespers that contains portions that are downright great, even perhaps groundbreaking.  Iâ€™d want to own it just for the â€œAve Maria Stellaâ€ and the â€œLauda Jerusalemâ€, but thatâ€™s just part of its attractions.  Strongly recommended.

Though the 13 Barcarolles on this disc are as always attractive, the high point in this very fine release for me is the concluding Theme and Variations, a more traditional effort that Gabriel Faure wrote in 1895.  Constructed from a simple yet affecting scale-wise melody, Faure adeptly builds a set of ingenious elaborations, often polyphonically-conceived, with variants of the main melody joined to new melodic lines over a bass providing harmonic support.  Germaine Thyssens-Valentin is wonderful in this piece, able to maintain the musicality of each of these complementary melodic lines perfectly while keeping them independent.Thyssens-Valentin also does very well with the 13 Barcarolles, written across the span of his compositional career, the first in 1875 and the thirteenth during his final, dark days in 1921.  She is very musical and succeeds in externalizing the emotions subsumed in Faureâ€™s refined, sophisticated art.  The 6th Barcarolle is a fine example which displays her gifts.  The scales in the final section are played with wonderful delicacy.  She adeptly presents the Barcarolleâ€™s opening theme, a melody that can be either cloying or nondescript in the wrong hands, with rhythmic subtlety and a sense of the musicâ€™s emotional depth.I compared the Thyssens-Valentin with the complete set of Faureâ€™s piano music recorded for Hyperion by UK pianist Kathryn Stott.  This comparison has brought home to me what an achievement Stottâ€™s cycle is.  The two pianists actually take similar approaches to the music, conceiving it as strands of music weaving together more as equal partners than as melody with accompaniment. They both do very fine work but I think Stottâ€™s versions of both the Barcarolles and the Theme & Variations are superior, on several fronts.  Stott presents the music with more atmosphere and emotion than Thyssens-Valentin while also being superior technically.  Compare their 12th Barcarolle: Thyssens-Valentin handles it well, but she doesnâ€™t bring the technical assurance that Stott does.Aside from any comparison with other performers, the flaw in this Thyssens-Valentin recording is to my ears a lack of understanding of Faureâ€™s abstruse late style, a style which begins to be apparent in the 7th Barcarolle (1905), and intensifies into the austere final four, numbers 10 through 13.  While the rest of the disc is very well done, I am critical of the palpable lack of comfort in Thyssens-Valentin playing of the rhythms in these later Barcarolles as well as their emotional flatness. The finest of these late pieces is likely the 11th Barcarolle, from 1913, a severe, gloomy piece that in Stottâ€™s hands is rife with atmosphere and gloom.  This power isnâ€™t heard in Thyssens-Valentinâ€™s version, where it is thick and uncommunicatively abstract.  Finally, while the sound of the Thyssens-Valentin is good for an older recording, Stottâ€™s set holds a decisive edge in that area.The Testament label deserves credit for re-issuing the overlooked but excellent performances from this unfairly neglected Belgian pianist.  My comparison with Stottâ€™s playing, while unfavorable to Thyssens-Valentin, doesnâ€™t mean that the older pianist doesnâ€™t provide a rich, effective presentation.

The speed which Fischer takes her tempi often makes the contrapuntal lines joining together the harmonic landing points secondary.  The experience of listening to the famous and familiar d-minor Double Violin Concerto in Fischerâ€™s performance is unusual.  The most important part of the band seems to be the continuo, their chords, bass line and harmonic progressions forming the backbone of the work, around which the fast ornamentations of the soloists and orchestra flow as background decoration, a furbello.  Such a shift in emphasis is odd for a composer like Bach, who thought more in terms of horizontal lines than in vertical harmonies.If there is Bach that is more amenable to Fischerâ€™s approach, it would be the two solo violin concerti.  And these violin concerti are in fact more successful than the d-minor concerto and the Violin and Oboe Concerto in c minor.  Sure enough, the Adagio of the 2nd Concerto in E major (track 8) was the highlight of Fischerâ€™s performance, with the tempo not speeded up quite as much as elsewhere in the disc.  The more moderate tempi allows Fischer to relax and she begins to play with a welcome dose of expression.Which takes us to the second problem with this release: the lack of spirit and musicality.  All the performers saw away, very competently and efficiently, at high speed through much of the four concerti.  But this isnâ€™t really an energetic performance; rather, itâ€™s a fast one.  Thereâ€™s a palpable lack of emotion here.  Although Iâ€™ve loved all four concerti for decades, listening to this release turned into a somewhat dispiriting experience.So a fast performance with little expressivity and a limited view of Bachâ€™s compositional philosophy.  It sounds to me like a budget price release from a second-tier set of musicians.  Typewriter Bach. Though this release has been hyped and comes from one of the new generation of international solo stars, itâ€™s unfortunately an insignificant interpretational event.  As this is my first experience with Julia Fischer, Iâ€™m going to listen to her other releases with an open mind but boy is this unpromising.

In this 2006 recording, David Jalbert emphasizes the melody-and-accompaniment aspect of Gabriel Faureâ€™s 13 Nocturnes, playing musically and with rhythmic fluidity.  Jalbert is an accomplished technician, has command of the Nocturnes and presents with beautiful tone.  He is helped by an outstanding sound engineering job.  While I criticize some of Jalbertâ€™s playing below, I want to emphasize that this is a good and enjoyable recording from a talented musician.When I write that Jalbert emphasizes the Nocturneâ€™s melody-and-accompaniment, it is to contrast his approach with the more polyphonically-inclined interpretations from the two pianists whom I think are the leaders in Faure pianism, Kathryn Stott and Germaine Thyssens-Valentin.  Both Stott and Thyssens-Valentin conceive of the Nocturnes -- and Faureâ€™s other terrific piano music -- as fundamentally polyphonic, in that two or more often three different strands of music intermingle in an accomplished interplay.  The view is fundamentally different from Jalbertâ€™s, who presents a melody in the foreground with subsidiary melodies and harmonies supporting that lead line.  Jalbertâ€™s approach is similar to the older recording of the Nocturnes by Brit pianist Paul Crossley.  Crossley succeeds due to a tremendous rhythmic flexibility and a more assertive, masculine approach to the music.  That said, I think the insight about the musicâ€™s construction from Stott and Thyssens-Valentin greatly enrichens the listening experience.Jalbert also doesnâ€™t consistently bring out the emotion and power of Faureâ€™s writing.  There are some moments that are thoroughly successful.  The 6th Nocturne contains a middle section that begins with a syncopated melody gradually building to a fortissimo climax, which Jalbert brings out with genuine feeling.  After the fortissimo, the Nocturne settles back into a very soft arpeggiated passage, a passage that sublimates the powerful passion of the middle section.  Jalbert unfortunately does this arpeggiated passage in a flat, unemotive way.  I noticed the same thing in the transition back to the reprise of the A section in the 5th Nocturne, a piece which has a similar emotional pattern as the 6th.  The severe, almost enigmatic 11th Nocturne, a somber example from Faureâ€™s later life, is liewise done with a lack of expressivity, a flaw I also detected in the chilling middle section of the 1st Nocturne.  Letâ€™s say that thereâ€™s uneven emotional depth in this playing.These criticisms aside, this is a promising disc from a talented pianist.  My criticisms donâ€™t negate the discâ€™s many positive qualities.  While it falls short of the achievements of older pianists Iâ€™ve mentioned above, Jalbertâ€™s performance is a rewarding one to which I assign 4 stars.

Over the last several months, I have been listening to this cycle of Sergei Prokofiev symphonies recorded by Mstislav Rostropovich and Lâ€™Orchestre Nationale de France and have found it overall a well done and successful set.  Rostropovichâ€™s characteristic conductorial approach involves careful attention to orchestral balances and timbres combined with a relaxed, but not inert, emotional temperature.  This approach has yielded many very good moments across the repertory, and that holds true here.The set contains a wonderful interpretation of the best known of these pieces, the â€œClassicalâ€ 1st symphony (1917), full of feeling and high spirits.  I also have very much enjoyed Rostropovichâ€™s wistful, even yearning take on the 7th symphony (1952), a late work whoâ€™s initial conception as a childrenâ€™s symphony has left in it traces of nostalgia, making for an old artistâ€™s backward glance at the lost world of the romantic symphony.  While I consider the long and ambitious 6th symphony (1947) only a partial success as a composition, Rostropovich delivers a very accomplished and effective rendition, aided by an excellent orchestra.While I already knew these pieces well, this release allowed me to appreciate some of Prokofievâ€™s less famous compositions.  Rostropovichâ€™s interpretation of the long Theme and Variations ending the 2nd symphony opened my eyes to the beauty hidden within a work that has borne the brunt of heavy criticism ever since its unsuccessful 1925 premiere in Paris, criticism originating both from the composer and from listeners.  The key is to get past a first movement so off-putting, angular and plain old ugly that it saps the spirits of listeners before they arrive at the Theme and Variations, a 25-minute long finale that contains some singularly beautiful, unusual inspirations.  The Theme consists of a diatonic oboe melody over rustling strings and clarinets, luscious and hushed.  After this long theme, which takes almost four minutes to present, the variations that follow are often very attractive.  The first begins with an ascending set of scales in the strings, almost three-dimensional in character, culminating in a turning, tired figure high in the flutes.  The orchestration is often stunning, for example in the 5th variation, the shimmering, overlapping ostinati remind me of the first tableau of Igor Stravinskyâ€™s â€œPetrushka.â€  This is a major artistic achievement played beautifully by Rostropovich and the Orchestre.Combined with its excellent sound, these performance high-points lend the set many attractive qualities.  A few issues with the set have caused a downgrade to 4 stars.  The main problem is a baffling version of what is probably Prokofievâ€™s most important symphony, the 5th (from 1944).  Often presented with thick, rich textures as an almost neo-romantic example of Prokofievâ€™s later style, Rostropovich is the perfect conductor to introduce more transparency and diversify the sonic effects in the 5th.  Instead, we have a slipshod, unfocussed rendition.  Sins range from the technical (strings are sloppy with imprecise ensemble) to interpretation (the performing style swings between different approaches within the span of a few minutes).  The symphony seems almost out of control at points.  A Prokofiev cycle with such a 5th is like a well-prepared meal spoiled by a poorly executed main entrÃ©e.I also am mixed about some of the music.  Besides my distaste for the 2nd symphonyâ€™s opening Allegro, the 3rd symphony is only sometimes successful.  The 3rd symphony is played well by Rostropovich and the Orchestre but I recommend you check out the Riccardo Chailly performance with Concertgebouw Amsterdam (on Decca), one that I think is marginally better.  The 4th, which both the original version from 1930 and its overhaul in 1947 included here, is a total miss with the exception of an attractive Scherzo.  After years of trying to appreciate it, I think the lengthy 6th symphony is dutiful rather than inspired.So Mstislav, Sergei and the Orchestre have their very good moments in this 4-CD set but also suffer some setbacks.  If Rostropovich had delivered a 5th he was capable of, this probably would be the reference release for these symphonies.  Iâ€™m happy to own it but rate it at 4 stars.

Martha Argerich approaches the three JS Bach compositions included here with her characteristic sense of drama and energy.  All three are in a minor key, and all are among Bachâ€™s premier keyboard pieces, so they form a well-chosen set unified by a coherent and often powerful interpretive vision.  There is little playfulness here and little dance and no frivolity at all â€“ this is Bach the Lutheran.The distinctiveness of Argerichâ€™s approach is particularly apparent in the Gavotte of the 3rd English Suite in G minor, which is far more energetic and aggressive than what I am used to from other performances.  Her playing is strong and relentless, with the sparkle of the rolled ornaments that is often brought out by other pianists subdued into a streamlined forward momentum.  My favorite English Suites disc is of numbers 2 and 3 from Ivo Pogorelich (like this one, on DG), which is far more sensuous, generally slower and more sensitive than what Argerich does here.Argerichâ€™s rendition particularly well suits the 2nd Partita in C minor, one of my favorite Bach works.  In the Courante, her energy combines with an austere avoidance of timbral effects.  The dramatic contrast between the soft and melodic, almost plaintive, middle section of the beautiful opening Sinfonia and the aggressive fugue with which it ends shows Argerich setting off sections to highlight the level of drama, but without using much timbral differentiation.  This all culminates in a powerful presentation of the concluding Capriccio, a difficult and to my ears magnificent capstone to this Partita.  Argerich also presents a fine Toccata in c minor, the earliest of the pieces found here.  The Toccataâ€™s central fugue and its related fugal conclusion have sweep and the sort of relentless severity that is a hallmark of this disc.Any criticisms of this disc would apply to the very mediocre sound engineering from DG and, on a more sophisticated level, the way Argerich seems uninterested in Bachâ€™s polyphonic conception of this music.  Even in passages written in two voices, Bach always implies layers of different voices folding into each other.  Argerich flattens this implicit polyphony.  But these weaknesses donâ€™t negate Argerichâ€™s playing.  Monochrome, streamlined, and stern, this recording comes from a master pianist with a cohesive and intense vision of the music.

Over the last several months, I have been listening to the cycle of Sergei Prokofiev symphonies recorded by Mstislav Rostropovich and Lâ€™Orchestre Nationale de France over the last several months and have found it overall very well done.  Rostropovichâ€™s characteristic conductorial approach involves careful attention to orchestral balances and timbres combined with a relaxed, but certainly not inert, emotional balance.  This approach has yielded many very good moments and it does so again in this moving recording of Prokofievâ€™s late 7th symphony.  But the consistency Iâ€™ve come to expect from these performers falls through, very unexpectedly, in this recording of the 5th symphony.  This is particularly unfortunate as the 5th is probably the composerâ€™s main statement as a symphonist and is a piece I think would have benefitted from successfully applying Rostropovichâ€™s aesthetic.Letâ€™s start with the good.  Beginning its life as a childrenâ€™s symphony, the 7th (1952) is a wistful and nostalgic work, a real throwback to the era of the romantic symphony.  Rostropovich, who is not a heart-on-your-sleeve maestro, veers from his approach for a performance that is full of yearning, sweet, with some wonderful evocations of Prokofievâ€™s timbral effects.  With its well-known main theme, the opening Moderato is tender to the point of pathos; an old man walking in the woods beset by memories of a long-gone era.  Unlike one of the other reviewers, I thought the leaping secondary theme in the Moderato was presented brilliantly, helped by this discâ€™s very strong sound engineering.  This approach isnâ€™t for everyone; I was at first put off by Rostropovichâ€™s bordering-on-treacly interpretation, but I warmed to it and then after a time started to be downright moved.The 5th (1944) is a long and ambitious symphony often presented with thick, rich textures, an almost neo-romantic example of Prokofievâ€™s later style, and one that had gone beyond the bristly wit and flashiness of his earlier music.  Rostropovich is the perfect conductor to introduce more transparency and diversify the sonic effects in the 5th, which is after all written by a past master in orchestration.  Instead, we have a sloppy, unfocussed performance.  Sins range from the technical (strings are sloppy with imprecise ensemble) to interpretation (the performing style swings between different approaches within the span of a few minutes).  The performance seems almost out of control at points.  I really wish Rostropovich had asked for a flyer, gone back for a couple of more rehearsals, and done another session.  A Prokofiev cycle with such a 5th is like a well-prepared meal spoiled by a poorly executed main entrÃ©e.Iâ€™m assigning the disc 4 stars, an average of the 5 for the wonderful 7th symphony and 3 for this strangely botched 5th.  This should have been a near-reference recording but ends up worth buying for the 7th only.

This is a decent recording of JS Bachâ€™s 7 Toccatas from Canadian pianist Angela Hewitt but lack intensity and a sense of drama.  Hewitt could use a vitamin injection.  I listened to the disc, found it satisfactory but unexceptional and then was taken aback by the praise the press had heaped on her Bach series, and so I would class this release in the overrated category.  The Toccatas, which I think are attractive and fine pieces, date from earlier in the authorâ€™s career, all of them written before Bach turned 30 in 1715, and as early works they have received relatively few recordings over the years.  So Hewitt is one of the few on offer.The strengths and weaknesses of Hewittâ€™s interpretation can be heard clearly in the E minor Toccata (track 4, BWV 914).  The Toccatas are constructed from alternating episodes, made up of fugues, meditative slow passages that serve as contrasting sections, sometimes in the proud â€œFrench Overtureâ€ style, and virtuous passages built from flourishes showing off the performerâ€™s technique.  The E minor Toccata characteristically ends with a fugue constructed of running sixteenth notes, a section that is instantly recognizable as Bach.  Hewitt plays this fugue with some panache.  But the rest of the Toccata, such as the severe opening, tied thematically to the concluding fugue, is undernourished. The meditative Adagio that occurs a bit later in the piece is presented in a restrained, even dull fashion.I compared Hewittâ€™s performance of the best known of the Toccatas, in C minor (track 1, BWV 911) with Martha Argerichâ€™s on DG.  Argerich presents a dramatic and sweeping version, with her characteristic brand of intensity.  In contrast, Hewitt is a bit listless, selecting tempi that are considerably slower.  Hewitt chooses to take the beautiful central fugue, built out of the C minor triad, slowly at the beginning, a long-standing and successful strategy in playing Bachâ€™s more severe fugues.  So far so good, but that strategy usually involves a gradual build-up in intensity as the textures and re-introduction of the main subject become more complex.  Hewitt doesnâ€™t achieve such an increase in intensity, both here and in the related concluding fugue.  The superiority of Argerichâ€™s exciting and involved interpretation I think is pretty obvious.The disc isnâ€™t helped by what I consider a regrettable performance of the D major Toccata (BWV 912).  The sloppy execution here indicates that Hewitt and the producers should have bit the bullet and done another few takes.  This Toccata is tucked in at the end of the disc as track 7, which isnâ€™t called for by the work sequence number and indicates that the producers knew full well they were releasing a substandard track and wanted to hide it in the back.Sound engineering is very good.  Despite this, I am rating this 3 stars both because of the hum-drum nature of Hewittâ€™s playing found here and an unsatisfactory D major Toccata.

Thereâ€™s something prelapsarian about Gabriel Faureâ€™s earlier music.  Springing from a world of sophistication and urbanity, it is at times sad but seems completely unthreatened by disaster.  Faureâ€™s later years were marred by the war and by personal devastation, but the first seven Nocturnes written in the earlier part of his life between 1875 and 1898 and presented here by UK pianist Paul Crossley, come from an era where any more minor personal misfortunes appear against a background of beauty and placid delight.  These seven Nocturnes contain some very fine example of the composerâ€™s piano efforts, including the memorable 4th with its well-known falling fourths theme and the 1st Nocturne, with its high bell-like opening melody segueing into the dark and moody lower central section melody.  This is very fine music presented successfully by Crossley.Extroverted and masculine, Crossleyâ€™s combines these characteristics with a great degree of rhythmical flexibility and an emphasis on the foreground melodies.  Faureâ€™s piano music is typically texturally rich, which several complex streams of music joined together.  I compared Crossleyâ€™s playing with the terrific set of nocturnes from another British pianist, Kathryn Stott (in her cycle on the Hyperion label) and found the contrast revealing.  Stott emphasizes the polyphony and texture, with the foreground melody more integrated into the complex accompaniment.  Her sound also pushes Faure closer to the impressionist and post-romantic composers from circa 1900.  Crossley, focused on the main melody, presents a Faure that sounds much more traditionally romantic and mid-century.Crossleyâ€™s approach brought a new perspective to the music for me.  The wonderful 2nd Nocturne, which is often presented so peacefully, has a new sense of forward momentum and energy in his hands.  He gives us a thought-provoking 6th Nocturne, a critically-esteemed work, with a wonderful interpretation that builds to a powerful climax in the final section.  This is not placid Faure.  There are some undersides to Crossleyâ€™s approach: the 4th Nocturneâ€™s middle section is a bit plodding and lacks the rhythmic fluidity of the rest of the disc.  But most of the disc sustains that balance of energy and rhythmic fluidity to realize Crossleyâ€™s cohesive vision of these Nocturnes.This is a 1983 recording using analog technology with only decent sound.  But Crossleyâ€™s gifts and thought make this a worthwhile and interesting Faure release.  Recommended.

This outstanding performance would be a clear reference in most of the classical repertory.  But due to the incredibly strong field of JS Bach solo cello suites recordings, Bailey's 2010 effort is only one of several excellent traversals.  Baileyâ€™s approach emphasizes the instrumentâ€™s rich and deep sound combined with a masculine interpretation matched with musicality.Bailey's virtues are exemplified in the long and ambitious Prelude to the 5th Suite, a very beautiful instance of Bachâ€™s art constructed in typical slow-fast fugato form.  The slow introduction, filled with dotted rhythms, is done with strength and grace. In the long faster section, where Bach mimics a fugue in only one voice, Bailey uses his lower register to contrast the lower sections with the polyphonically-conceived passages in the treble.  Baileyâ€™s approach is in this way used to bring out one of the Preludeâ€™s latent features, which for me is always the sign of a high-level interpretation.  This is one of many high points in this consistently excellent set of performances.  I also very much enjoyed individual movements like the 4th suiteâ€™s Bourree or the Minuet II from the 1st suite, but other listeners will have their own preferences.  I canâ€™t cite an individual dance or prelude that I thought was weak.  If I have to isolate any flaws, Iâ€™d point to occasional glitches in the articulation of notes but they are infrequent and are a quibble.  Bailey is generally very strong technically, is musical and has a point of view through which he approaches the Suites.For me, Pierre Fournierâ€™s set of Bach suites from 1960 is one of the high points in classical music performance.  Whatâ€™s interesting â€“ and what sets Baileyâ€™s achievement in context â€“ is the slim difference in quality between his recording and Fournierâ€™s.  The two have quite different approaches -- Fournier builds his around rhythmic flexibility and a sense of improvisation, Bailey around the celloâ€™s sound and the musicâ€™s majesty â€“ but in terms of quality, they are close.  Baileyâ€™s interpretation strikes me as a superior version of Heinrich Schiffâ€™s very good set of suites done in the early 1980s (on EMI).Given Baileyâ€™s interpretational angle, he has been fortuitously blessed with an audiophile level engineering job from Telarc.  This 2-CD set has been very enjoyable to get to know I and I strongly recommend it.

This release in Vasily Petrenkoâ€™s series of Dmitri Shostakovich symphonies is coming in for some criticism from Amazon reviewers and I want to state upfront that the criticism, while I do agree with some of the specific points, is unbalanced and ignores this releaseâ€™s many strengths.  Iâ€™ll instead emphasize that the glass is three-quarters full rather than one-quarter empty.I am in the minority as someone who prefers the 9th symphony to the more famous 5th.  The 9th is one of those compositions that belie any easy connection between biography and musical content.  Completed in 1945, in a country where a third of the population had been killed off in the terror and the German invasion, it is a deft, graceful, even happy work.  Before hearing the Petrenko rendition, my preferred performance was the old Brit one from Malcolm Sargent (on Everest).  Characteristically, Petrenko takes an energetic, aggressive approach overall, one that is musical, exciting and vivid.  After direct comparison with the Sargent, I have a marginal preference for Petrenkoâ€™s.  I want to point especially to a sensitive and inspired performance of the finale, a track which is tucked in at the end of this long disc, and so needs to be highlighted as special.  The 9th by itself justifies this release.Then we have the 5th symphony (1937). If the 9th speaks of an almost bizarre happiness rising from the ashes, the 5th has come to serve as the musical emblem of Stalinâ€™s terror, an almost mythic piece that defies criticism.  (Sooner criticize the stars.)  But Iâ€™ll venture a critical comment anyway: the finale, where Petrenko has been criticized, is not the symphonyâ€™s best moment.  I very much like Shostakovichâ€™s march-like passages â€“ and appreciate their extramusical significance â€“ but this finale has over the years worn on me as somewhat clichÃ©d.  For me, the long opening Allegro and the lovely Largo are the core of the 5th.  Petrenko has an integrated, cohesive approach to these two movements.  Under his baton, they are mysterious, soft and sensuous.  The high opening violin melody of the Allegro is stunningly beautiful and the Largo is rich and full of emotion and different sounds.  The Largo is a striking performance.  Petrenko' still and quiet approach serves to emphasize the desolation in its flute and harp sections. .So what if the finale slows down a bit too early.  This is an unusual 5th, but terrific musicians like Petrenko think for themselves and envision music in new ways.  Petrenkoâ€™s 5th is such a performance: nonconformist, with new things to say, and at times rivetingly beautiful.The playing of the Royal Liverpool orchestra is generally very good although not perfect.  I have been very impressed with the sound engineering of the other Naxos releases from Petrenko and, while this one could be a tad more refined, still like it a lot.  Strongly recommended for a reference-standard 9th and a highly original 5th.

I am thrilled with this beautiful band. Its so elegant and fits my small wrist perfectly. Its very smooth with no rough spots. Feels and looks like a much more expensive watch band, like maybe the $149 Apple version! The weight feels substantial yet its not much heavier than the Sport's plastic band. The magnet is very strong, feels very secure. I normally wait awhile before reviewing, but I was just so impressed that I couldnt wait. I think I'll order another color!

My two cats love this turkey flavor. We switched them from the Salmon and Chicken which they also loved. I know they're getting quality food because there is very little gravy, unlike supermarket brands. The price is higher than Publix, but the convenience is great. I have had two sealed empty cans, so I'm deducting a star for poor quality control.

First off, I was skeptical due to all the phony sounding 5-star reviews and I also discount those who receive a special deal in exchange for a review. But I recently had an outstanding customer service experience with Anker. So I didn't hesitate to buy this product...at full price!My husband hates selfie sticks, but I bought this one anyway so I could be in some of our travel photos! It worked great with iPhone 6 Plus and everyone in our travel group was planning to go home and buy one for themselves and for gifts. I never worried about the security of my expensive iPhone, but I do have to re-glue the rubber piece that holds the bottom of the phone, so I deducted a star for that (thankfully I had duct tape with me for a quick repair while on the trip). Simple to set up, pair, and recharge. Bluetooth worked flawlessly, but you do have to reconnect after turning off the stick. It's surprisingly lightweight and folds up small to fit easily in the outside (water bottle) pocket of my camera bag. This is a very high quality product at a very fair price. You won't be disappointed!

I'm 5'3" and often the plane seats are too high for my feet to be flat on the floor. This was my second purchase. The first one lasted a few years before springing a leak. I decided the product is worth buying again, even if it is basically disposable, because it keeps my knees from hurting on long flights.

These are very nice soft washcloths, fairly quick drying and good for travel. But they do not remove my tinted moisturizer (actually CC cream) with just water. After drying my face, there was quite a bit of residue on the white towel. The sellers' and reviewers' claims were a stretch for me, but for normal washcloth use, I would give them 4 stars.

I ordered two 18 x 18 pillows, but they measured only 17 x 17 and didn't fill out my pillow covers. I requested a return, but it would have cost me as much as the pillows inserts themselves. The quality looked good, but they were not as described and this seller doesn't pay for returns.
Authentic Sony lens cap, so glad to be able to get it fast and at a good price.

I bought 5 of these crewnecks to wear under sweaters on an October trip to Europe. They are soft and very lightweight for layering. Quick drying overnight when hand washed and hung to dry. They're nice enough to wear alone but the cream is a bit too sheer. Gray and Black are opaque. I normally wear a small in tops (5'3", 120#), but bought medium in these and they are a little big, but better than too tight. I live in Florida and these will be perfect here under fleece in the winter. Highly recommend!

I'm so happy I decided to spend more money than I'd planned for a really good camera bag. On a recent trip to Central Europe I felt totally secure in crowds. All the compartments are easy to access and lock. It fits my camera Sony A7II with attached zoom lens and bulky Pacsafe camera strap, cards, and extra battery. And I still have room left over for personal items I need for sightseeing. The quality is excellent, well padded and yet not too heavy for a petite woman. The pockets came in handy for water, umbrella or selfie stick. I never got tired of the shoulder strap worn cross-body. A non-obvious feature that I really liked is that the bag can serve as a resting platform when you have your camera out and hanging around your neck, taking some of the weight off your neck and shoulders. I highly recommend this bag - you won't be disappointed!

This low price doesn't prepare you for the excellent quality of this little device. It's a firm, rubbery material with substantial weight that keeps it on your nightstand without having to use the optional sticky tape on the bottom. My Apple Watch Sport sits on it just like the one in the photo and it's easy to thread the charger into the stand, and easy to take it out for travel. I couldn't be happier!

This day pack is as great as all the other reviews claim. It's going on its second overseas trip this week. Very handy to use, well made and durable. It is so convenient for tucking in to your luggage when folded up into the little pocket size. Great value!

This is my 4th pair and these socks are great for travel. I wore them on the plane and every day on a driving trip around Ireland. My legs never felt better. I'm 5'3 and slim so the bands were no problem. Just enough compression for someone who doesn't have bad circulation issues.

I bought this because I can't find Dryel anymore. It is a better value and seems to work just as well on my pricey dry-clean-only rayon scarves. They come out looking like new, like they've been dry cleaned, and not creased or wrinkled. I did similar colors together, but the colors that looked like they might run were done individually. The loss of a star is due to the heavy fragrance. I don't know how anyone would want to wear a garment right out of the dryer. The scent filled my house, just like Dryel. It's not a bad smell, but strong. I needed to hang them out to air for at least 4 days. If you don't mind fragrance, it won't be a problem.
I bought these for a road trip around Ireland. They worked well, but the water flow is slowed by the filter, as would be expected. Very lightweight and good quality.

My husband and I heard this album playing in a small London restaurant in 2000. He found it at the time but it has since been discontinued. He was so happy to find another copy on Amazon to give to a friend at a great price.

I'm 5'3" 120 lbs and my legs are not heavy. These socks may be fine for taller women, but the top is too tight where it hits me in the calf. They may work on longer legs, but the elastic at the top digs into my legs. Also the quality does not seem as good as my husband's Gold Toe socks.

Perfect for desserts and vegetables that need a small bowl. They match my other Cordon Bleu dishes perfectly. I don't know what other reviewers meant by them being thick - I would not want very delicate edges on a bowl like this. Great price for six bowls. I may buy another set since this size is impossible to find!

I was looking to reduce the heavy water pressure from my shower and this works very well by offering several different types of sprays. My husband installed it in minutes and I have enjoyed every shower since. I plan to buy another one for a small stall shower that is hard to get into without getting hit by the spray. It adjusts easily to move the head around. Funny looking, but great product!

This is a nice, plush towel and it does a great job of drying my hair. It's also a good size and dries quickly. I bought it for travel, but I'm afraid its a little too big to be bringing along when I'm trying to pack light.

I was looking for a lightweight sleep shirt for travel, one that would dry quickly after hand laundering. Maybe I read the reviews incorrectly, but this is not a light fabric, though it is very soft and feels like good quality. Also the shape is very boxy.

I already had four of these great bras (34C) and so when I saw them on Amazon at $20 less than the local department store, I bought 3 more. And should get another three. Softest, most comfortable underwire bra ever! I normally took bras off when I got home and put on a stretchy sports bra. Not with this one. Also like the smooth back for no back-boobs. I wash them on delicate cycle in lingerie bags and hang to dry. Highly recommend!
Very high quality caddy but it is not a great fit for my non-Kohler sink. But it does the job and without moldy suction cups!
Great basket for use inside my Kohler stainless steel drainer. Deep enough that tall utensils don't fall out. So far no rust. I may buy another one!

I bought this to use in my living room for TV watching and to complement my color scheme. The color is really brown with a slight olive cast, very attractive. It should work great on a plane because I've fallen asleep while watching TV while using it. For home use I cut off the strap and the cords. Love the carrying case and will use it for my other travel pillow.

These would be great if you could get the cups out of the rack. It's such a tight fit at the top that you risk breaking or chipping. So I'm returning the set. Also, check the size of your espresso. My Nespresso Lungo with crema would overflow - I think these are just barely 4 oz. Very nice white porcelain. Too bad!
This is WHITE not Cream. If color is important to you, don't order. Also, with Homedics name I expected better velour.

UPDATE: The Anker company went to some effort to contact me to offer a replacement for my 3 cables. I posted my 1-star Update review below after the return period, so I never contacted them for a return. When I received their offer I had already replaced their cables with Apple brand cables and will stick with them, but I want to up my review to 5 stars based on the customer service offered. They insisted on refunding my purchase. If you have issues with their products, be sure to contact them first.UPDATE: 3 months later and these 3 cables are totally unreliable. I don't get the warning message that they aren't authorized Apple to tell me that they might not be charging. I have to keep looking at the battery charge icon. Just moving the phone slightly can cause it to stop charging. Too late to return - I will never buy an Anker product again.ORIGINAL REVIEW: So far these cables are performing perfectly with no scolding messages from iPhone or iPad. I have had bad experiences with other 3rd party cables so it was worth it to pay more for 3 of these.

These slippers have a very strangely shaped sole. The toe is kind of boxy and it doesn't show up in the photo on Amazon. This made them way too wide for my medium witdth feet. I sent them back for this reason and also because I followed the suggestions here to size up, and that was not good advice for me. I found a pair of the terry style locally, so I bought them and like the fabric much better, as well as the toe shape.

I bought 2 of these to use for travel and in our home theater. Thanks to this great pillow, I slept for the first time in my life on a flight and also used it on top of hotel pillows for great support for my neck. I also enjoyed using it on the plane for just watching a movie or listening to music. The thin strap is great for attaching to a rolling carryon. Great purchase, you won't be disappointed.

Great purchase at a great price for those of us who travel with 3 phones, an iPad, GPS and camera charger. It worked well in 6 hotels on our recent Ireland trip. Just plug it into a universal adaptor and you're good to go in other countries. Love the folding up feature.

Great socks! I bought 3 pair for a trip to Alaska. My feet really sweat when they are cold, but wearing these prevented that. My feet were dry and warm all day in my leather boots. I've even worn them this past winter in Florida. They seem to adjust well to the climate they're in. I'm adjusting down one star because they shrunk after several trips thru the dryer - so if you don't want this to happen, line dry.

This product is not adjustable for small treats or dry food. My cats eat Organix food and the kibbles are very small. When I adjust it to dispense this size food, too much falls out. Apparently the device doesn't stay locked very well. Also be prepared to be sweeping up the tiny pieces the cats don't want to bother with.
The quality is fine for the price. One of my 2 cats loved it for about 5 minutes. The other sniffed it. Neither has been anywhere near it for 3 days. It's going to Goodwill.

Perfect fit and looks great. Very good feel, slight tackiness to the grip. Let's my iPhone 6 Plus shine thru. I'm deducting a star though because I think it's beginning to yellow some after only 4 months.

I rented one from Oreck prior to buying and I am very pleased to own my own orbiter now. I'm a petite woman and have no trouble working with this. It's actually easier to maneuver on tile than my Dyson Animal vacuum. I have a huge shower and it's great to clean it effortlessly now. I also have rough textured tile in my main living area and this is the only answer other than hands & knees scrubbing. Expensive, but worth it!
Nice quality and good looks. Works very well too!

I bought this book to loan to my friend's granddaughter with the idea that I would read it when she gives it back. Well she likes it so much it ain't coming back. So I guess I will just have to buy my own (2nd) copy!
Great quality, generous size. I have purchased 6 sets. I can't say how effective the dust mite and allergy protection is because we don't have allergies, but the waterproof fabric works great.
These knives are beautiful and high quality. What a nice surprise to find butter knives that go very well with my Pottery Barn flatware.

Very nice map and this is coming from a GPS addict. We will be traveling Ireland by car on our own and the detail on this map is exceptional. The coated paper should make it durable for folding and unfolding in the car. I will certainly buy the same map for other countries where we plan to drive.

I have tried a few different brands of 3d fiber lash mascara. This infinity 3d fiber lash is number 1 on my list. In my opinion I like it better than the yonique brand.The Infinity 3D Fiber Lashes mascara contains all-natural green tea fibers for lashes that go on and on. Plus, high-potency beeswax which stimulates lash growth and cell regeneration which in overall terms you see healthier lashes with each wear.I use this everyday and it is easy to apply.There are 2 tubes one is the fibers ane the other is the transplant gel (holds fibers in place) and they come in a nice case that is compact and fits right into your makeup bag or purse. The inside of the case is made of like a satin material.I apply the 3d mascara different than some people and realized a big difference compared to the normal application.-First I always start off with a mascara primer (make sure to prime the lashes evenly) on the top and bottom-then I take a volumizing mascara and use it as my base coat-next is where the 3d lashes come into play and you need to play close attention when applying. You need to have both the transplant gel and fibers open at the same time. First take the transplant and apply it as you would like regular mascara (make sure it is even on all lashes) then evenly apply the fibers followed by the transplant gel to lock the fibers in place.-repeat as many times as you want to get the dramatic lashes you like. I usually repeat 2-3 sometimes 4 times. But if you don't want the bold dramatic look apply 2 times.-finally take the eyelash comb and comb the lashes to make the lashes evenly spaced.I experienced no flaking or clumping like I did with some of the other fiber mascaras, and don't have fibers everywhere on my face.I usually try to apply the mascara first before the shadow for a few reasons. The main reason is your bound to get. Mascara on your lid, so what I do is have a qtip dipped in makeup remover to remove the unwanted mascara. 2nd reason you don't want to mess up the blending of your shadow.The Infinity 3D Difference compared to other mascaras isâ€¢ High-quality natural ingredients with beeswax & green tea fibersâ€¢ Safe to wear with contact lens & sensitive eyesâ€¢ Water-resistant, yet easy to remove with soap & water (won't have your mascara running down your face from tears or rain.)â€¢ Flake-free and Hypoallergenicâ€¢ Non-toxic, Paraben and SLS freeâ€¢ Environmentally friendly packagingâ€¢Truly Natural & Truly Easy to Apply within 3 minsI had received many compliments on my eye makeup,  especially my lashes. I had people ask me if I wear falsies, and I tell them no. I leave them in amazement when I tell them that I used 3d fiber mascara.I highly recommend this 3d infinity fiber lash mascara to makeup artist or even if you do your own makeup or a beginner. It is reasonably priced. It will also make a good gift for any makeup addict.Disclaimer I received this in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I apply it everyday like mascara, wait for it to dry then apply my favorite mascara. I've been wearing Vionics for years since developing plantar fasciitis.  I own several pairs.  I've never found a better brand for superior arch support and comfort.  If my plantar fasciitis flares up, all I have to do is walk around in a pair of Vionics, and the pain is gone within seconds.  I'm not kidding.THIS particular shoe, however, is NOT comfortable.  As another reviewer noted, the cut out is too tight at the base of the toes which results in pain and a blister.  Also, the little raised round thingies on the foot-bed rub the balls of my feet when I walk.  I'll probably get used to all this when I break them in, but in the meantime, they hurt!One of the shoes appears to have been worn before.  There's a perspiration or oil stain on the left shoe foot-bed.  (Ewww!)Finally (although less importantly) they are big and clunky-looking.  Granted, I realize my sexy shoe days are over, but do orthotic shoes really need to be so ugly?  When I wore them for the first time, my husband said, "You're not going out in public in those things, are you?"  LOL.Unfortunately, I can't return them.  The seller wants me to pay for the return shipping (approx. $18!), a 20% restocking fee, plus a possible additional 20% if they can't sell the shoe.  My fault for not having bought them directly from Amazon rather than an Amazon vendor.  Still sucks though.I think it's time for me to find another orthotic shoe brand.

I can't add anything to other reviews other than to agree this is superior lotion to anything else I've tried - and that's saying a lot.  It's very effective without being greasy or oily and it doesn't irritate my rosacea-prone skin.  It's my favorite lotion.HOWEVER, and as others have noted, it's so thick, it won't pump.  I wish it were in a regular "pour" type bottle, because in order to dispense the product, I have to take the top off and lay the pump thingie down while I squeeze the thick lotion out.  This is a hassle.  Otherwise, I would have given the product 5 stars.

Be forewarned:  The creature on the cover is not the creature you get.  The actual creature in the movie is the worst CGI I've ever seen - or at least since CGI first started when?  In the early 1990s?  And it looks more like a large lizard who's incapable of attacking a cat, much less tearing a big rig to pieces.  Even my easy-to-please husband looked at me and said, "This movie is TERRIBLE!"Don't waste your money or time on this one folks.  I love B-movies, but this one is a D for Dud.

Why don't they make dog harnesses with adjustable necks?  I have a 22 lb. Dachshund mix who should wear a Medium according to the manufacturer and to the reviews.  I can't even get it over her head.  Hopefully the Large will work, but be forewarned:  These harnesses run VERY small.

Who wrote the glowing reviews for these wipes?  Bausch and Lomb employees?  Stockholders?These wipes SUCK!  First, they are VERY wet and therefore leave a lot of moisture that doesn't dry and leaves streaks on my glasses (and on my computer monitors.)  The box says they "contain alcohol," but it sure seems like they contain water too.  I end up having to use a microfiber cloth to clean off all the moisture and streaks, but the whole reason I bought these wipes to begin with was so I wouldn't have to use a cloth.I've used other brands of eyeglass cleaning wipes before that seemed to be nothing but alcohol, weren't nearly as wet as these, and didn't require a secondary means of cleaning.  Less expensive too.  I guess you don't always get what you pay for.  I'm returning these.

A wonderful product that doesn't irritate my sensitive, rosacea-prone skin.  I use it at night after applying serum.  Creams like this one are usually heavy and greasy, and I end up changing my pillow case every morning, but this product seems to be lighter than others I've tried.  And my skin looks "glowy" since I started using it.  I like that it's free of fragrance, parabens, and other yucky ingredients too.

I "weaned" myself off perked coffee a little over a year ago for several reasons, and I've been drinking good quality instant instead.  Starbucks makes a delicious, high-quality instant coffee, but it's way too expensive for this working girl.So I tried this stuff, but it's just awful.  It reminded me of the freeze-dried Taster's Choice my parents used to drink.  I poured it down the sink with some lemon rinds to freshen the garbage disposal and tossed the jar in the recycle bin.

I've tried several cleansers for super-sensitive, rosacea-prone skin, but nothing works as well AND as gently as this product on my face, neck, chest, and upper back.  (Cera Ve comes close though.)  In fact, I've been trying a lot of the Paula's Choice skincare products lately, and I'm very impressed.

I love that this product is made with high quality natural ingredients - including Stevia (the only sweetener I use) - but I sure wish it weren't so expensive.  I go through two little bottles a week, which adds up to a LOT per month.  Maybe they could cut costs by offering it larger amounts and in less expensive packaging.  Until that happens though, this working girl is going back to plain water.

I decided to try this brand after using Crest 3D for a while.  I should have stayed with what works.  After several weeks of use, I see no improvement in my teeth.  In fact, they seem to be duller and more yellow near the gum line now.  (I drink a lot of espresso coffee.)  I'm going back to my Crest 3D.

I have had limited exposure to Susan Mallery's books (I read one or two of her Fool's Gold series, which didn't inspire me to read more). However, I decided to start fresh and to give this offering in a new series a chance - I am glad I did. I thoroughly enjoyed "The Girls of Mischief Bay" and look forward to the next installment.The Girls are three friends spanning three decades of life: Nicole is 30, Shannon is about to turn 40, and Pam is facing 50.  Each women is addressing the unique issues of her particular period in life, including love, loss, relationships, parenthood and career.  What they have in common is, that despite their outward success, each has an underlying insecurity that colors her view of herself and her decision-making in the face of inevitable change.  As each one addresses her individual challenges, there is a deep, abiding friendship between the women that buoys them up and sustains them despite their different life stages. The caring relationships between the three characters draw out each one's strength and talents.Mallery has crafted a wonderful introduction to this new series.  The characters are likeable, engaging and realistic; the storyline is well-crafted and highlights the emotional challenges most women face.  I look forward to experiencing how these women evolve in coming books.  Which brings me to my one complaint about the novel: labeling these women of such depth and complexity as "Girls" in the title belies the real value of the novel.  If it is true that one shouldn't judge a book by its cover, then one should also not judge this book by its title.

I have tried several Fiber One products and found them to be edible, sometimes even tasty. This was not one of those products.The first thing I noticed when I tore open the package is the aroma of "fake strawberry." I ordered these because they promised real fruit but the smell is the first clue that "real fruit" is far down the list of ingredients and probably used in trace amounts to call it such. I took a tentative bite and found that the pastry itself is reminiscent of cardboard and is not streusel-like at all. The strawberry schmear on the pastry tastes a lot like a certain cheap toaster pastry filling that no grown up palate should tolerate.Fiber One has much better products out there (their brownies are actually pretty good!). I think I could eat this if I was starving and there was nothing else at all in the house but I will not be a repeat purchaser of this product. If you loathe fake strawberry taste, this is definitely not for you.

I have enjoyed all of the books in the Thunder Point series, but One Wish is not Robyn Carr's best work.The storyline focuses on the developing relationship between Grace Dillon, the owner of the local flower shop, and Troy Headly, a dedicated high school teacher who loves extreme sports and adventures.  Unbeknownst to the town, Grace has left behind a stellar past as an Olympic Gold medalist figure skater to create a new life for herself away from the ruthless competition of professional sports and the pressures of her demanding mother.  At first she and Headly are determined to focus on fun to keep the relationship free of long-term expectations: in other words, friends with benefits.  Predictably they fall in love in spite of their intentions and reach a crisis point when "complications" arise in Grace's life.While I found the characters likeable, I thought the storyline too predictable and the dialogue was often stilted and formal.  For example, when Grace reveals that she is a virgin before their first love making, Troy's response seems too stiff and "canned" - more a proclamation than true communication about intimacy. The resolution of the challenges in their relationship also seemed overly simplified and abrupt.I recommend the book for those who have been following the series, but if this is your first exposure to Carr's work, you may be left with the wrong impression of her talent.  She has a wonderful ability to create believable characters, weaving together the lives of members of a small community in a remarkably entertaining way.  This book is just not the best representation of that talent.

I have read all these stories and I find them quite wonderful. If you are unfamiliar, the book centers around three main characters: Seymour Hope, his adoptive father Ignatius P. Grumply and his adoptive mother, who is a ghost, Olive C. Spence. Together the group publishes a story, written in chunks and sent to their readers via mail (you know, those envelopes brought by those nice men and women in blue shorts with eagles on their trucks!). Their story is wildly popular and the trio clamors to meet deadlines and reader demand in every book.In this particular story, Mr. Grumply, simply known as Iggy to Seymour and Cemetery Road readers, learns that his uncle has passed away and left his Scottish castle to Seymour. Seymour and Olive take a trip to Scotland to see the property and decide what to do with it and Iggy remains in Ghastly, Illinois (the setting of the six prior books) because he holds his uncle in disregard for something that happened a long time ago. The uncle, however, takes up residence with Iggy after his passing, in ghost form of course!Hilarity ensues as a creepy developer tries to buy Seymour's castle and turn it into Loch Vegas. He winds up stealing a $10,000 turtle, Mr. Poe, from Seymour and in attempt to rescue this turtle, people believe that the Loch Ness Monster, Nessie, actually exists and sightings abound!All these books are very cleverly written with charming characters and engaging plot lines. The stories are quite short and are suitable for bedtime reading as even though they are marketed as ghost stories, there is little that is scary about them. I was saddened to read that this is the "last installment" according to the description but fear not because the book leaves the reader hopeful that we have not seen the last of our favorite Cemetery Road writers!I highly recommend this endearing story and the other six books to one and all. I do hope there are more to come.

Katherine Center has written an engaging and thought-provoking novel related to how attitude shapes perception and experience â€“ all cloaked in a highly readable novel.Helen Carpenter is the thirty-something protagonist desiring to reinvent herself following a year of post-divorce doldrums. Having let her infinitely annoying, younger brother talk her into a three week wilderness survival course, Helen discovers, much to her dismay, that her brotherâ€™s best friend has also signed up.The survival course is everything advertised and more, with emphasis on survival.  This is not a course for beginners despite Helenâ€™s lack of any experience in outdoor living.  Discovering that she is the oldest member of the group by at least a decade, Helen starts out feeling isolated and alienated from the other survivalists.  She soon discovers that it is her own attitude that is contributing to this rift and over the course of the trek learns to set aside her judgments and biases to really connect and develop relationships.  One of the young women is a psychology major who introduces Helen to the tenets of positive psychology which lays the foundation for creating happiness through gratitude.  By the end of the course, Helen has achieved her goal to begin to rebuild her life.I enjoyed this book on two levels â€“ one, it is good storytelling and two, it challenged me to think about my own relationships in a different light.  I recommend it as an enjoyable and fairly fast read.

I was not impressed with this product. First of all, it works no better or worse than the Herbal Essences Naked line (without extra chemicals like other brands) and it costs more than the Naked line and you get less of it for your money. I don't find this to be a superior product that I would pay upwards of $1.00 more for less product.It does smell nice but I think the Naked line smells just as good and it's cheaper.

The opening chapter introduces us to Leigh Ann Henion,  a part-time teacher and free-lance writer, who has just become a mother.  Anyone who has survived that first year with a newborn knows it is full of incredible challenges.  However, the back cover notes describe her as "shocked at the adversity a young mother faces with a newborn," which seems overly dramatic and sets a tone for the whole book.I found the book disappointing on several levels.  First, the writing style does not inspire awe and wonder as Henion describes her experiences.  Fortunately, each chapter is a self-contained adventure, which allows the reader to set the book aside and come back to it without much disruption.  Unfortunately, I had difficulty even getting through one chapter without putting the book down.  There are a few engaging passages, but most of the writing is overly descriptive of things that don't matter and sadly falls flat - lacking in any real emotional or spiritual depth. Elizabeth Gilbert (Eat, Pray, Love) contributed a cover quote; however, if you liked her work I believe you will find Henion's offering missed the mark.My second objection has to do with the motherhood issues.  I understand that there are many ways to parent and that what works for one person would be a disaster for another parent/child relationship.  Given that, I felt uncomfortable with the author's justifications for her choices.  It felt as if she was dealing with her own guilt by defending her lifestyle in every chapter.I can't recommend this book either as a inspiring spiritual quest or as a travelogue.

Maxine Revere is an independently wealthy, investigative reporter with her own monthly cable true crime show, "Maximum Exposure."  While her dedication to truth has gained her respect, her lack of interpersonal skills has left her personal and professional lives littered with people who resent her methods.  Her wealth allows her pick and choose the cases she takes on and unresolved issues from her past drive her to find answers to cold cases of missing persons.This is the third book featuring Maxine and I thoroughly enjoyed it as well as the preceding works (Maximum Exposure and Notorious).  In Compulsion, Maxine scores an interview with a serial killer prior to the beginning of his trial for five murders.  Previously she had looked into the disappearance of a middle-aged couple on behalf of their three adult children without much success.  Now there seems to be a connection between the missing couple and these five murders.  Following her intuition, Maxine deepens her investigation, much to the dismay of the district attorney and the producer of her show.  The story unfolds with many twists and turns, including putting Maxine's own life at risk, before the facts come to light.The story is well-crafted and the characters are engaging.  I read it in one day - it was that hard to put down.  I highly recommend this book for those who enjoy the mystery/suspense/crime genre.

This was a great story, reminiscent of one of my favorite books ever, Inkheart. The story starts with our young protagonist, Billy Gilfoyle, who is doomed to spend his summer in a cabin with no TV. His mother is working on her dissertation about parallel universes all the time and Billy has nothing but the library of the cabin's owner, Dr. Libris, to entertain him.Upon solving the riddle of the locked cabinet in the library, Billy pulls out a book about Hercules and suddenly realizes what is transpiring on the page is actually happening on the island in the middle of the lake near the cabin. He dismisses the realism of the situation and opens another book about Robin Hood with near the same result.The next day Billy travels to the island and find out that the characters he thought he was imagining on the island are actually on the island! He gets to meet Hercules and Robin Hood and becomes known as "Sir William of Goat" after describing himself like the Billy Goats Gruff and being misunderstood. Billy is trying to understand the situation and brings his neighbor Walter into the secret of the island. Suddenly Billy and Walter are caught up in a frenzy of literary characters while having grand adventures and looking for treasure.The story is superbly written and very well thought out. As I said, this book is much like Inkheart, where characters are read in and out of stories by the protagonist, though this is one is a little more tame and the premise is different. I very much enjoyed reading this book and I found it a very quick read that was difficult to put down. I do think the ending sets up for the possibility of more books and I very much hope this to be true because I will be first in line for the next installment!

I am an avid reader of fairy tales and I grabbed this up as soon as I saw it. I am very pleased to say I was not at all disappointed.The story is a nod to Goldilocks and the Three Bears but it differs greatly from the original story. This is the story of the three bears, in this case The Vaughn family, who live in a large house in Bremen Town (a nod to another fairy tale "The Bremen Town musicians" and indeed there are musicians). Mr. Vaughn is a business-bear who is quite well off and hires a governess, Ms. Ursula Brown, to educate his young son Teddy. The story is told from Ms. Brown's point of view about her missteps when she first comes to the family and as the story progresses, her thoughts and feelings about political goings-on in town regarding the humans in a group called the "Anthropological Society" and the "Enchanted", or the group of animals that have been anthropomorphized and now behave like humans and have the power of speech.The story becomes further enveloped in the original Goldilocks fairy tale with the appearance of Goldilocks herself. She is a disheveled human child who broke into the Vaughn home to steal things and was found sleeping in Teddy's (i.e. baby bear's) bed with the pilfered items next to her. Mrs. Vaughn is a tender soul and takes on care of the child. As Ms. Brown progresses in her teachings with Teddy, she is also asked to work with Goldilocks, who quickly takes to Ms. Brown. As mentioned before, as Goldilocks come further out of her shell (though she is mute for most of the story) the Vaughns begin to treat her as a member of the family, which outrages the Anthropological Society and they recruit Mother Shoe (as in, there was an old woman who lived in a shoe who had so many children she did not know what to do) to pretend to be her parent to take her away from the Vaughns.The book has a happy (obviously) and satisfying ending. I quite enjoyed the wonderful story woven by Ms. Coville and her subtle nods to other fairy tales and nursery rhymes. She is obviously very talented and I would look forward to more stories from her.One thing: I noticed this book is written for 10-year-olds. Expect many questions and to have a dictionary handy upon reading this because I had to look some words up including velocipede. I doubt many 10-year-olds know what vicissitude and miasma mean. Consider it a good vocabulary lesson. Otherwise, great book, great story, well crafted characters - definitely five stars! More please!

I don't usually gravitate toward books relating to spirituality, but this one caught my eye and really delivered!Linda Leaming moved to the tiny Himalayan country of Bhutan in 1997 and married a Bhutanese painter in 2000.  Since that time she has moved back and forth between the two cultures of her native Tennessee and her adopted country bridging two radically different worlds.  This experience has given her a unique perspective of the advantages and disadvantages of both places...but the bottom line seems to reinforce the viewpoint that less is more when it comes to happiness.
