The Bhutanese may not have all the high tech toys that so much of our lives depend upon in the West, but their simpler lifestyle seems to have rewards that we only dream of: less stress, more harmony and deeper fulfillment.Each chapter of the book is a self-contained gem that addresses a theme or principle supporting the cultivation of happiness or, as Leaming defines it, "well-being."  Each goes beyond providing a prescription or formula for happiness by unfolding as the author's personal insights of her own emerging awareness of the theme in her daily life activities and relationships.  Slowing down the Western mind is no easy feat and Leaming's descriptions of her process are filled with humor and humility.  While the book is primarily based on Buddhist teachings, there is no need to embrace Buddhism to enjoy these offerings.I rated this book 5 stars because I am now reading the book for a second time, savoring one chapter at a time.  I am curious to see how this Bhutanese approach to reading it again will be reflected in my own life and relationships.  I thoroughly enjoyed the author's writing style - very practical, very heartfelt, and very honest.

This was a great heist novel that I think would make an excellent movie.Our young "hero" March is the son of famed jewel thief and I would say criminal mastermind, Alfie McQuin. When Alfie dies in a tragic mishap, March is left alone in the world with little to his name and only what Alfie taught him about grifting to survive. With Alfie's dying words constantly playing in his mind, March learns he has a sister, Jules, whom he finds shortly after Alfie's death. Unfortunately, the two wind up in the system in New York. Fortunately, March apparently has his father's talents for escaping crummy situations. He and Jules meet Darius and Izzy and together they form a gang determined to recover seven moonstones for an heiress, stones Alfie himself had stolen. However, Alfie's old partner is out of prison and also wants to recover the stones. The rest of the story is a race to the finish line as the stones have to be recovered and returned before the blue moon.I found this story very engaging. It really captures you and makes you feel like you are part of the gang. You are horrified when something goes wrong, happy when something goes right and satisfied when the bad people are thwarted. All the characters are smartly developed and fun to read about. I secretly hope there will be more stories about March and his friends but we will wait and see.A little warning to the reader, if you get down to the last sixty pages or so, make sure you have ample time to finish before you start reading. I was very displeased when I had to stop at the last 30 and go back to work. You will not want to put the book down!

This is a light-weight plastic crate that collapses easily for storage when not in use. I have several plastic totes that are cumbersome space hogs when not in use - so this "utility box,"  as it is called, is great.Its capacity is 47.5 quarts and the weight capacity is listed as 66 pounds.  I have carried thirty pounds of books in it with no problem, but I doubt I will ever lift over 60 pounds without help.  The physical dimensions are: length - 21", width - 14.5 " and height - 10".  It collapses down to 2.5" high. The open slats in the sides make it easy to clean and the molded handles on the side make it easy to carry.I foresee using this for organizational purposes and for carrying light loads.  It is great to store in the trunk of the car for transporting "runaway groceries" on the trip home or even for permanently organizing trunk contents. It would be great in a laundry room, a gardening shed, the garage or a closet.  Toys for kids or pets can be gathered in on spot. The one drawback is no top or lid.I recommend this multi-use crate for its attractive colors (mine is blue and black), its ease of use and its capacity for easy storage when not in use.

This book was full of violence, which I found a little disturbing. This book was marketed for fans of Warriors and Survivors, series I have not read, so maybe the violence was to be anticipated. However, when I think of horses I do not think of violent creatures. I found some of the violence to be graphic and frankly horrifying. When I finished the book, I honestly thought if the author had used some other animal besides horses, perhaps ones known for being territorial and capable of violence like this the book would have been far more acceptable. The Warriors are cats and Survivors dogs, things that do fight and are easily more believable than horses.My other complaint about this book is that the author uses a lot of horsey jargon I do not understand. While I think kids who have horses are drawn to books about them, I think there are plenty of readers out there who do not understand the jargon. I found this particularly confusing in reading the cast of characters section at the beginning of the book.The storyline itself (other than some of the unnecessary extreme violence) is rather clever. It is about a young foal, Star, who is the mysterious and possibly dangerous black foal Pegasus. This foal, should he survive, receives power from the Hundred Years Star and he can either emerge good or evil. Star's predecessor, Nightwing, was evil. Since Nightwing is the only comparison the herds have, everyone naturally fears Star. Star's guardian herd is the Sun Herd and their over-stallion Thunderwing has promised to kill him on his first birthday. Star is living everyday to the fullest with the knowledge he will be killed. However, things get out of hand when several events beyond Star's control end unfavorably for the Sun Herd, culminating in the capture of two of their foals by a rival herd. Star is spirited away by the lead mare, Silvercloud, to save his life. Except the rival herd wants Star in exchange for the two foals. When word gets out that Star is no longer among his guardian herd, war ensues (which could have been less vividly described, just my opinion).I initially did not like this book because I felt the author had these characters be pegasi when it suited them, then they took on more human characteristics (applying medications for example). She also uses descriptors that a horse is incapable of (like "coiling one's hooves... it is NOT possible). I truly think that this book would have been just as good and the whole story better had the characters been something other than pegasi, something more predatory.

I am a big fan of the Septimus Heap novels and this new spinoff did not disappoint. We start off in the Pathfinder fishing village at a meeting of the Secret Circle of Pathfinders. The newest recruits are being let in on a huge secret of the Pathfinders, something they must keep to themselves or risk being exploited by those who would do others harm.Here we meet Alice TodHunter Moon, a young girl of 12 who is about to have her world turned upside down. I don't want to go into a lot of plot detail because this book is so thrilling to read and want to keep the pages turning that I fear most plot points would spoil it. Suffice it to say, Alice eventually makes her way to the wizard tower and meets Septimus, now 21 and the ExtraOrdinary wizard. Together with many other prior Septimus novel characters, they must save a snow kingdom from an evil villain.My issue with this, which I doubt very much most young readers would even know, is that Alice insists on being called "Tod", which is the German word for "death." I assume this is meant to be pronounced like "Todd" (the author never really tells you) but I just kept reading it as the German word and I found it a bit distracting. However, as I said for young readers in America I don't think this will present itself as an issue.Angie Sage has a very vivid and pleasing imagination when it comes to creating a new world filled with wonder and magic. I found the tie in to the original Septimus books to be seamless and was very happy to revisit old characters. If you are a fan of the other seven Septimus books, I highly recommend you jump into this one and get to know Tod and her friends. I would definitely bet you cannot put the book down. Great new book, I look forward to the next one.

Dog lovers will enjoy this story - it describes the healing power of an adorable dog to open hearts and even minds. Yet the human side of the story illustrates both the dark and light sides of human nature.Andrea has gone through the trauma of a divorce from a charming, but cheating husband.  After a rocky year, she has regained her balance, but doubts she will ever allow herself to be vulnerable to love again.  Dan and his teenage daughter are still grieving the loss of their wife and mother when their cherished dog, Anni, is abducted from the driveway of their home.  Thus begins a synchronistic adventure of crossed paths and overlapping relationships until, predictably, they are united by their love of Anni.The storyline is sweet and somewhat inspiring, but as mentioned the plot is far too predictable to be great reading.  It is a refreshing change from much of the contemporary, violence-driven literature that seems to dominate much of the popular offerings.

This is an excellent debut novel in a series and I cannot wait to see what else happens to the characters.Albert Flynn's parents are divorced. He usually lives with his mother in New York but summers he spends with his dad in the teeny tiny town of Herman, Wyoming. Here Albert spends his days in the dead letter office of the post office reading mail that could not be delivered in hopes of finding some clue to either return it to the sender or the recipient. Until a mysterious dog delivers him a letter that he actually must deliver.Farnsworth, the dog, leads Albert to a giant tree, which is actually a gateway to another world (if the Path Hider allows you to find it). He delivers the letter to the Path Hider and meets two other kids around his age (Leroy and Birdie, both wonderfully developed and funny characters). Together they reach the center of the Earth, also known as "The Core." It is here they will train to be Balance Keepers, those who keep the realms under the Earth balanced to maintain life as we know it above ground. Here they undergo training to become Balance Keepers, where they will eventually become the First Unit for the title realm, Calderon. Crisis happens of course and eventually Albert, Leroy and Birdie are called upon to enter Calderon despite rookie status and save the world.The exceptional detail the author goes into to create these worlds beneath our world is very imaginative, you can almost picture the passageways and mysterious creatures she develops easily. She also writes wonderfully buffoonish bullies and other minor characters, making each one an integral part of the story.I could not put this book down and the times I had to I was very disappointed in having to tear myself away from the story. I eagerly anticipate the next book in this fantastic new series. Highly recommend!

I have read all three books in the Chronicles of Kazam books and this one did not disappoint. The book starts out where the previous left off shortly after the bridge game to see what house would hold the enchantment license for the Kingdom of Snodd. The gang has to capture a vicious Tralfamosaur (like a T-rex but â€œwithout the sunny dispositionâ€).The book progresses that Jennifer Strange manager of Kazam and Court Mystician to the King is summoned to the palace before the king and queen. Jennifer is tasked with looking after their very rude and spoiled daughter to groom her to become a humble ruler. How she does this is up to her. On the way back from the palace she is accosted by the minions of the Mighty Shandar, whom she is taken to meet and given a quest. Shandar wants her to find the elusive and mysterious Eye of Zoltar or he will kill the two dragons (Feldspar and Colin) that Jennifer has spared from extinction (done in the first book in the chronicles). Having no choice, she undertakes the journey, not quest, as a quest needs to be registered with the Questing Federation with lots of paperwork and permits involved.They have to go to the Cambrian Empire, a place where perilous tourism keeps the national economy stable and everything can kill you (kind of like Australia, but with fewer pleasant citizens). Here danger and some hilarity ensue as Jennifer, the princess, the wizard Perkins and several others they take on to flush out their 50% promised mortality rate, embark on a journey to find the Eye of Zoltar and save the dragons.I love Jasper Ffordeâ€™s ability to create wondrous places full of daring characters and weirdo critters. All of his books are very much like this but his imagination clearly does not lack material so that every book is different. His humor is always very clever, usually also very dry.  Jennifer is a truly magnificent person, so much so I wish she was real and I want to be her friend. All of his characters are very well written and well developed and from his descriptions I can picture the creatures and settings alike. I only wish this book had more of the quarkbeast (though he would have been woefully out of place). I eagerly look forward to more books in the Chronicles of Kazam series and a peek inside Ffordeâ€™s expansive mind.

This was a hard book to read due to the bullying aspect. Everywhere now you read how children are so cruel to other children simply because they are poor, have long hair (like Brendan), have birthmarks, talk/dress funny, etc. Most of the time bullying is simply because someone does not like you and it is wrong regardless of context. These children in this book are no exception and are just plain awful.Poor Brendan is an outcast who has been abandoned by his mother and foster mother (figuratively speaking as she pays little attention to him). He has been passed around in foster homes and has an overall feeling of worthlessness. It is only when he fails the sixth grade (because of lack of attentiveness, not because he is unintelligent) and meets Shea in summer school does he start to blossom. He finds the perfect place for a tree house and meets the Green Man in the woods.This is a story about overcoming self-esteem issues and bullying, well done.

This is a story of bigotry and turmoil. There is little done to brighten the story even a little and it makes the story very hard to read. The clash between the kasiri and halini echoes many of our current struggles in the world today. Overall, a rather bleak plot line made this something I doubt I would read a second time.

Was kind of disappointed in this because after sharpening a knife with it ONCE, the coarse sharpening "blades" (not sure what you call them, but the part that does the sharpening LOL) have a chip out of it on one side. I was not unduly rough with it, in fact quite the opposite. So I feel this is not a really well made sharpening tool.

This is okay. I returned mine because I realized that due to the size it really wasn't any easier to use than the virtual keyboard. Maybe a little... but the weight and bulk of the case/keyboard made it not worth it to me.

Excellent music from that late 60's period where jazz was merging with rock in a lot of projects. This is one of the most interesting jazz-rock "fusions" and has some excellent players. Definitely good if you like this genre.

Rather more "cheaply" made than I expected for Stanley but nevertheless for the very low price I paid, it is a nice little tool to throw in the glove compartment of the car. I bought 3, and will give 2 away.

Like everyone else, I love this knife! Perfect size, perfect weight, nice handle, nice spring action for opening quickly, and a nice sharp blade. The ability to move the clip is good because they put it upside down as far as I'm concerned.If this knife lasts then it will keep the 5 stars I've given it.If not then I'll down-rate it at that time.

You get what you pay for in this case.It's good but not great.Hard to close the blades with the little release "buttons" on  the sides. And I'd rather it have a good solid keyring loop to attach it to my keyring rather than using the lever to attach it as it looks like it could come off the caliper type lever pretty easily.That said I'll carry it until I lose it and maybe it'll come in handy before that happens.I can't really recommend it nor would I buy it again but it's "okay".If they made a higher quality one and charged more I'd buy that.

This is a very well made knife for the price. I doubt you'll find a better made one.I only take off one star because it's a little heavy and it doesn't have a way of opening it quickly like some similar knives do.But it's a good knife, and I like it. Sanrenmu makes some good knives.
I like this

Mine does not have titanium dioxide in it. It did there for awhile but it seems they've taken it out.I like this gum because it tastes good and cleans my teeth after I eat and the xylitol is also said to be GOOD for the gums and so far I don't find any evidence that it's bad for health, in fact Life Extension Foundation published one article stating it was good for the heart in some manner.
Havne't really used it yet but it seems like a good product. At first encounter it works and seems like a nice thing to have in case I have to walk on a dark road at night.
Most hand sanitizers really bother my hands which are prone to eczema.This one generally doesn't bother me and that's why I buy it.
Got it only about a month ago, using it on our land line, and already the connection at the phone base end is coming apart.I won't be buying from this company again.

This was a very good price and now I have a lot more room on my Samsung Galaxy tablet. That's all you can ask of a Micro memory chip and if it's made well and lasts a long time then I'll be happy as a pig in excrement.

Case Logic makes good cases.I am putting all my cd's and dvd's into cases for moving into a smaller home and having less clutter.I still need to house 300-500 more and I will buy more Case Logic cases.However I am seriously considering buying smaller-capacity cases because they are easier to handle.This is a personal preference that you'll have to decide for yourself but for me I think a smaller number of cd's/dvd's per case is better.

This is a great knife with a beautiful leather sheath.It's heavy but not too heavy, and it's long but not too long.It feels nice in my hand and is fairly well balanced.It's made in the USA to boot!And has a lifetime warranty against defects.On a personal note when I was about 12 I bought a knife that looked just like this and it was my first fixed blade knife, but it was about half this size. So when I saw this one I wanted it but first I compared it to about 5 other fixed blade knives in this price range and size. There are quite a few knives to choose from in this range and the most notable competition was an Ontario knife. But the Ontario is much heavier and I want something I can wear all day when I'm "out on the farm".So this is I'm sure going to be a great purchase, very well made and very utilitarian.

Perfect for the Sansa Clip MP3 player.My only complaint is that it doesn't have an elastic mesh screen inside on both sides, only one side, to keep your stuff from falling out. If it had it on both sides I'd give it 5 stars.Also the price is a bit high what with shipping being more of a gouge than it should be. If it were an amazon prime add-on item it would be a much better value but it's not.Overall I recommend it to anyone who wants to protect a small MP3 player like the Sansa Clip, or perhaps a large thumb drive or several small thumb drives.

Seems like a quality compass though I am only judging it based on how it appears right out of the box.After I get back from my 2 week trip to the rainforest I will be able to update my review as to how it held up and how well it worked.

Well I would have loved this knife if it wasn't slighly defective out of the box.The part of the knife you have to push to close it is VERY stiff and I actually hurt my fingers from pushing on it. I am a guitar player so I do not have weak or delicate fingers; my fingers are strong. Also I bought it with 3 other knives and both the other 2 had a lock-release that was very easy to use.So I had to send it back for a replacement. If the replacement is fine then I'll chalk it up to "random chance" and raise my review to 4 or 5 stars.What I like about this knife is it's just the right size and weight for a pocket, as opposed to one of the Sanrenmu's I bought which is just way too heavy for a pocket knife.I also like that this Gerber has a lifetime warranty. Of course as with most such warranties, who knows if they will actually honor it; only time will tell.I also love the flip out lever on the bottom of the knife that makes this knife very easy and quick to open with one hand.Except for the lock-release issue it seems very well made and if most of them do not have a manufacturing defect like this, then I would say this is a great knife to buy as an Every Day Carry pocket knife!Again, I will revise my review to 4 or 5 stars IF they send me a replacement that has a lock-release that is as easy to release the locked blade as it should be.

I originally gave this 5 stars... It worked so I put it away until I needed it.I needed it today - after having turned it on 2- 3 times previously then taking the batteries out to store it for a power outage.So I put the batteries in today and it wouldn't turn on. Then the batteries got stuck and I couldn't get them out without shaking it.I shook it and finally got them out and tested them to make sure they were in right and that they still had sufficient energy in them. Put them in another flashlight and they worked fine.Took them out of that good flashlight and loaded them back in, positive end towards the bulb, and checked to see if they would work. No.Took them out and checked again that they were in correctly. No power. No light.Thus I tell you that this light is a typical Chinese P.O.S. and if you don't know what P.O.S means it means it is a piece of excrement, that is to say, it is junk. Garbage. Crapola.Do not buy this. It's a total waste of money. Too bad because it put out a good amount of light - the first day.Now I have to find a similar light that actually works when needed and doesn't break the 2nd time I use it!

Comparing this, the Sanrenmu 7056 Series Pocket Folding Knife, the Sanrenmu 7010LUC-SA 710 Pocket EDC Folding Knife and theGerber 22-41493 EVO Jr. Serrated Edge Knife.First the 2 Sanremnu's:The 7056 is noticeably heavier - it weighs in at 111 grams vs 88.5 grams for the 7010LUC-SA.Both knives are well made and almost exactly the same size, folded, with the same size and shape of blade.As it turns out I would like to have features of each one in the other one.I wish the 7056 was as light as the 7010.And I wish the 7010 had the lever on the bottom of it like the 7056 does, to flip it open.As I said, both are made well and - not having used them yet and judging only by look and feel and judgment of quality from looking and handling - both are good buys.However I would not keep either one for myself due to my own personal taste. Hopefully the 2 guys I'm giving these 2 will not care about the same issues as I do and will be happy to get them, as I would be if it were a gift.So what I want is a knife with the lever on the bottom for opening it quickly, but the weight of the 7010 or perhaps even a little lighter weight than the 7010.I just find this knife, the 7056, too heavy to carry around in my pocket all day. I'm not a knife expert so maybe there's a big advantage to having a heavier pocket knife. If so please enlighten me (no pun intended). But for my taste I think I prefer a lighter knife. If I need a heavier knife for heavier duty I will have my Buck 119BKS Spec Hunting 6" near by.Now the Gerber:The Gerber is much lighter at only 52 grams, less than half the weight of the Sanenmu 7056. It is also smaller which helps account for the weight. The Gerber has a lever on the bottom to open it (or get it started opening and then just a flick of the wrist can open it the rest of the way). The Sanrenmu 7056 also has this feature.However the Gerber came with the mechanism to fold the knife back up after it locks into place, being very stiff and it actually hurts my fingers to push it in in order to close it. I have very strong fingers (I play guitar) so this is in fact a defect. I have ordered a replacement and hopefully it will be better. If not I will refund it. It *might* loosen with use or I might be able to put some silicon or oil on it to make it work better. I'm not a knife expert so not sure but I feel it should work out of the box so I'll give it at least one return and then see what happens. If it still doesn't work, I'll try lubing it before returning it for a refund.That said, I like the Gerber the best of the 3. If it were as easy to close as it should be it would be my favorite by far.I prefer it for the weight and slightly smaller size. I realize that you really can't compare a larger knife to a smaller knife because it comes down to what you prefer. But I wasn't sure what I wanted so I bought all 3 so I could make a decision which one to keep for myself and then give the other 2 as gifts.All 3 are well reviewed and all 3 are quality knives - again, notwithstanding the unlocking problem with the Gerber which I hope to be replaced with one that closes more easily as it should.I feel that anyone would be happy to get any of these 3 knives as a small gift. For a bigger gift, get a more expensive knife, perhaps a higher quality Gerber, Buck, Ontario, or Scrade... preferably an American made knife.These 3 are all Chinese made (not 100% sure re the Gerber but pretty sure it is Made In China as most cheap knives are and I know that even Buck and other famous "USA" knife companies are farming out their cheaper knives to China manufacturers. They may say "USA" on them but not "Made In USA"!) but the Gerber one has a limited lifetime warranty whereas these 2 Sanrenmus are only warrantied for 90 days.

It's okay but the flavor doesn't last long at all. Not sure what the problem is but I like the Spry better, especially now that Spry quit using titanium dioxide. (though some stores still have the old ones with it)

I won't buy Duracell rechargeables any more.I have 2 AAA's that are 1000 mAh and I put them in a brand new device. They would not work so I sent the device back saying it was broken (I had checked the duracells in another device and knew they were good and I also checked them with a battery tester.They sent me a new device and said they'd tested it and were sure it was good. I tried it again and again it did not work.Since they said they tested it I suspected maybe it was possible the device would not work with recharageable batteries.So I tried some Eneloops which have the exact same 1000 mAh.The Eneloops worked just fine.Tried the Duracells again. NO GO.Checked the Duracells in the battery tester again. Full Charge.Go figure.All I know is I won't buy Duracells any more.

I used to buy this all the time. Now I find out it has titanium dioxide in it so I won't be chewing it any more!Why a HEALTH brand gum would put an ingredient used in suntan lotion and cosmetics in their gum for us to chew is beyond me. DUMB and DUMBEST!Sure, I know "they say" it's okay. They also said cigarettes were okay, back when they first came out!The only reason to buy gum like this is to avoid aspartame and sugar!So why then would I want to NOT avoid titanium dioxide???SPRY management: Are you people insane?All anyone has to do is look up titanium dioxide on a search engine like yahoo and you'll find the scientific reports saying its a possible carcinogen; or a likely carcinogen as the case may be. I KNOW they say it's the powder that's bad. But that's like saying smoking cigarettes is bad but chewing tobacco is not... (They used to think THAT too!)Also, everyone searching as I am for a healthy chewing gum should read Dr. Mercola's article on "5 Common Chewing Gum Ingredients That May Cause Cancer". A search engine should come up with it if you type that title in.According to Dr. Mercola "gum base" often contains:petroleum-derived paraffin wax, polyvinyl acetate (carpenter's glue) and talc, which is linked to cancer.So far even BFresh says it uses gum base. The question is: What is IN the gum base or what is it made out of? I'm going to try to find out and update all my gum reviews with the info.
These gave me heartburn.I have used a lot of multis and only these and one other brand have been such that I could not tolerate them.I will not buy them again and cannot recommend them.

Insurance is one of those things you don't really know how good it is until something goes wrong and you have to use it.One thing I like is they give you points for not using the warranty so if you use them a lot you will eventually get a free policy on something with the points.I only had to make one claim - on a trackball - and they handled it very efficiently and professionally. I will continue to use them unless they screw me. Hopefully they won't.
Good stuff. It seems to help my aching shoulder and back.
Amazon gift cards are great for anyone. If only they'd offer free or discounted shipping on stuff you buy with them , that would really be great!

I generally like this jacket and I bought it because it seems to be made well.There are a couple things I don't like though:* It says it's breathable but it doesn't feel that breathable and I thought since it was breathable it would have holes here and there to let out condensation from within like some other rain jackets I've had. It has no holes under the arms or anywhere so I am doubtful about how breathable it is going to be.* The hood comes way down over your eyes when you pull it over your head. I figured out that I can fold it under so I can still see but if you don't, you will basically be walking around only being able to see downward, say, 20 feet in front of you. I think this is another design flaw as above. I am going to attach some velcro so I can make sure it stays folded under when I wear the hood so I can see ahead of me.I almost sent it back because of the above issues but decided to keep it and try it out in real rainy weather to see how it is. I do like the style and the fit and the quality so I am keeping it.
I'm convinced this stuff boosts one's immune system and that's what I take it for.

Really great interview. If you're a Robbins fan you want this!The interviewer knows Robbins' work well and asks good questions.Of course we fans would probably ask different things but nevertheless it's a good interview, albeit a bit overpriced for what it is.
This juicer is a superior tool for citrus juice. From limes to small oranges, this juicer fills the bill. Stainless, no flaking. Durable and functional. You will never need another.
Exceedingly comfy - Really nice to wear in the back yard or walking the pups.Not the best from a fashion sense point of view.Fit as expected.

This stuff is about the perfect shoe polish.I spent 23 years in the Navy - using plenty of other brands the entire time - I wanted to get some good neutral polish recently and found this here on Amazon - the reviews were good so I decided to give it a try.I have to say this stuff is the best wax polish I have used. Simple to apply, polishes up beautifully with or without water.Overall superb!

For the price, this is honestly hard to beat.9 foot diameter means you get some substantial shade.LED lights work and are a nice touch - comes with the rechargeable batteries. Easy to install solar charging.Not too bad to raise and lower - once you get the hang of it.We purchased six large patio pavers to weigh the base down and that has done the trick (they are 25lbs each)The only issue we have is the wind fairly easily moves the canopy. They have two screws in the base to keep it stable, but the large canopy combined with any light-moderate breeze means the canopy will move to some degree.

I have read the 'unbalanced load' reviews - oddly the reviews on Lowes and Home Depot are VERY positive. The one review here that made an impact on me was to ensure the washer is properly balanced.The delivery guys came and set them up - I brought out the level and adjusted the feet to ensure it was truly level.Here we are after a  month of regular use- never had an unbalanced load - never had any issues.Great washer - on high spin, the clothes come out nearly dry already - great washer!

So it's paper - so what right?Well - it's 16-lb paper - which is lighter than you're used to. I would not use this for my resume or other high-quality required printing - it's what it says - eco-efficient - more sheets per tray, more sheets per ream. Good efficiency.I use this in my Canon inkjet printer - no problems feeding, no jams, takes the ink well without issue. crisp printouts.Overall I like it - I like the efficiency of it.

Belkin has made multiple charging in the car easier than ever.The 4 USB ports are great for those long trips when you need extra power - four ports - two in the 12V plug and 2 several feet away - Plenty of power for your phones or tablets.The back seat connection can easily be routed under the front seat and clipped to the pocket behind the seat. Extremely convenient.Overall a solid charger for anything USB.
Great price for the exact match for the part I needed.Selected expedited shipping and the part arrived within three days.Easy to install and worked perfectly.
High capacitysolid performanceworks perfectly well in my high power dive light.the 6000 mah power cell does the job and then some.- I use the Trustfire LED Display 3-slot smart battery charger.

This roller is versatile and sized very well for many uses.- more rigid than most for a deeper impact- the knobs on the outside supposedly help by varying the impact - not sure if this is working or not - the outside foam is fairly soft.- the length makes it very useful for all parts of the body and it's much easier to move around and target specific areas.Overall a solid performer and great results.
Unlike many after-market lightning cables, this one from Belkin works perfectly.6' length gives extra space and flexibility for use.Overall a good, functional lightning cable.

Update 6/7/15Took the light on a short weekend trip - here are my impressions:- Performance - excellent - the light operated perfectly.- Water tightness - excellent - no issues at all. I kept the o-rings well lubricated with silicone and there were zero problems.- I used a Trustfire 6000mah battery - no issues- Magnetic switches worked perfectly.Overall I am very pleased with the operation of the light - for the price, I think it's hard to do better.I have yet to take this light underwater - so this initial review is solely based on my experience thus far.Pros:- PRICE - the equivalent light is twice the price from Big Blue.- Construction - solid aluminum construction. Double O-ring for water-tightness - Switches are easy to operate and understand.- Simple to use - one switch for white, the other for the red/blue/violet - intensity changes with a simple switch push- Great light temperature - this throws a warm light - not ultra-bright almost blue - but more like a 'soft white' in your house.- Huge light 'volume' - this is likely going to be my sole light for my small video camera.- Fast shipping - came from overseas - arrived in less than a week.- Rechargeable Lithium battery - the large battery should be a lifesaver and cost saver - purchased a second battery and it operates the light perfectly.No cons to this point - I will update once I dive the light and see how it performs :)

these are heavy latex gloves - for me - with medium hands, they are easy to put on and remove.- powder free - a plus- quite heavy duty for tough jobs or to protect your hands.- I have medium hands - these are '1-size' fits all. They are somewhat loose, yet I don't lose any dexterity with them. I find the fit just fine.I can see a pair lasting for several uses around the house before having to discard.

This clip is interesting in the fact that it has a magnetic catch and it holds very well.- the idea is that the part that attaches to the Lifeproof case is grabbed by the belt clip - when you want to remove, just rotate the phone and it lets go - very easy and simple to use.- Easy to install the attachment piece to the case - just clean it with the included alcohol wipe, let it dry and use the included template for placement.The real drawback is that with my iphone 6plus - having the phone on my belt is a bit odd - the thing is huge.I honestly don't know a lot of people who still use belt clips - however this one is VERY secure and quick access to the phone is easy.Overall it's ok.

These are solid and work very well. I originally purchased plastic snap caps, those broke very quickly. these are solid aluminum and fit the chamber perfectly. Function and ejection work as advertised. Great for malfunction training and safety.

these mini retractors are great. I have these at work as well as at home for other items. At work they do a great job for my ID badge. Over a year of use and no worries.At home I use them for all sorts of small items I need to have at hand and don't want to drop - you are only limited by your imagination.

Lifeproof certainly makes some of the most, if not the most protective cases out there.I have been waiting for this case for quite a while and was very pleased when it showed up as an option to test on my Vine list. The idea of a waterproof case is just awesome!I received the case - LOTS of packaging - and checked out the installation instructions - fairly straight forward.WARNING - make sure you have the seal visible on the screen to ensure it will remain waterproof - if the seal is folded, it will be obvious and you can remove the case and start over.Installation was not challenging other than making sure everything snapped together properly. Removal is actually a bit more challenging than installation, however working the case from the 'coin' slot around got it done.One quite impressive feature is that this case installed fine over my Zagg Glass screen protector - the Glass is a very thick screen protector, so this is a huge positive.Pros:- Protection in the extreme!- Waterproof!- no need for a screen protector as it uses the screen to seal the case.- Installed over my very thick Zagg Glass - no issues.- Fits like a glove.- Fingerprint ID works fine with this installed.Cons:- Initial indications are that the sound quality is reduced when using this case. There are covers over the speakers and the microphone (there have to be to keep it waterproof) - one person I was talking to described it as sounding 'muffled'.- You have to use their screw in cable connector for your wired headset - not a great feature, unless you plan on swimming with this thing using waterproof headphones.- Silent/ringer button manipulation took some getting used to to get it right - once you work on how the external button manipulated the little switch, it gets easier.Overall, if you are worried about using your phone in potentially wet areas, or are particularly hard on your phone - this is definitely the case for you.It has some drawbacks, however the idea that it is better protected than any other case probably makes up for that.

The Parrot Zik 2.0 is a very expensive headset. That's the opener and there's no way around it.What do you get for the price? Well that's where Parrot has done a very nice job.- Noise cancelling (note - noise cancelling does not work when using as a phone headset)- lightweight- easy to adjust- simple controls - the touch pad is interesting- user-replaceable battery- great Bluetooth connections- Very comfortable to wear (a little hot on warm days)I started off just trying these out for music - very nice sound quality and I could leave my phone/pad downstairs and walk around the house without losing the connection. ++I find the size adjustment to be just fine for my regular sized noggin.Very cool features, such as auto-Bluetooth disconnect so you can reconnect to whatever you have at hand without going through gyrations. Auto-pause when you take them off your ears - starts right back up when you replace them. :)setup and charging is simple and easy - I haven't done a time test for how long they will last but no issues so far.phone use as a headset is fine - kind of nice not to have that dangling cord.So - for the price you get a soft bag - and with them in the bag and in my briefcase - that can and have inadvertently turned on. I'm not sure why Parrot does not include the hard case for the price :(The only source for additional batteries appears to be Parrot - hmph......Overall very nice, full featured and great quality.Update - 4/2/15- So I had a request to determine how these sound in a dead battery condition wired - they can be used wired to the source like any other headphone.- Sound quality remains excellent- Can also still be used as a phone headset - the included cable has all three connections - l/r/micI remain a fan of these headphones.

This curry paste is simply ok. The flavor is nice enough, however there is a large excess of oil in the product.The flavor is decent as I said, however there are several other options out there that are plainly better.Personally I prefer the Pataks brand curry pastes and this one just does not rise to that level.Overall it's not bad, yet it's not great.

The Honest Kitchen is a great US based (San Diego) company that makes REAL food for dogs. Species appropriate and human grade ingredients for your best friend. Get away from kibble and start feeding your pup a species appropriate diet!Honest kitchen foods are awesome - three minutes to re-hydrate with warm water and it's ready to go.Our pups LOVE this new formula. They can tolerate grain - so that's not an issue - this is a whole grain food, so if your pup has grain issues, it's not going to be right for them.Great protein and fat content for the younger pups and those who might need a higher protein food.

This is comparable to other high quality duct tapes.The main difference I noted is that while it has plenty of adhesion, there seems to be less residue than other heavy duty duct tapes.Don't get me wrong - this stuff will stick and stay stuck - however in my limited tests it leaves less 'goo' behind than other heavy duty tapes.Overall - great stuff!

These snap caps do function as advertised - I used them to check the function of my new rifle.The main drawback is that one of them broke very soon with light use. The plastic body is just not robust enough for even regular practice use.

This keyboard has a lot of benefits:- Wireless works great- full function keyboard for Mac- Solar charging keeps you from having to replace batteries- The solar panels work well even with indoor typical lighting- responsive and accuratethe only drawback is you have to give up a USB port in order to use the dongle (Granted that will work for up to six logitech devices, so if you have a logitech mouse, not too bad)Overall a great value for the money.

For the size and money there is finally a relatively compact, capable USB 3 - 7 port hub.I truly like having seven ports - my new Macbook Air only has two - and they are typically used by a keyboard dongle and the input for this type of hub.USB 3.0 is fast - it's not lightning, yet it's nothing to sneeze at. Keep your older 2.0 or 1.0 devices off if you want to keep the speed up.Power switch! - This USB hub has a small button on the top - lit up means on, no light means off - just be careful you don't hit the power while transferring data or some such as you can cause problems.Overall great, compact, more than enough ports. All at a solid price.

Two hundred high quality laminating envelopes for less than $40 - superb deal!The laminating envelopes are excellent for letter sized items.If you want to do smaller items, just load up the envelope with a couple or more smaller items and you are good to go.One pass through and good to go - no peeling, no issues.Good quality, great price.

What an amazing cooking tool.Sure, it does wafflesIt also does omelettes and grilled cheese - and all the other fun things you can cook with a waffle iron :)USE non-stick spray - I prefer PAM coconut oilWAIT for the cooking process to finish! Otherwise you get a 'split' waffle and a mess.For regular waffles or blueberry (use wild blueberries - they are smaller) use setting fourFor eggs/omelettes - use setting 3 or 3.5For bacon  (yes bacon!) use whatever ;)Easy to clean (Use PLENTY of non-stick spray!!!) and use. Lots of fun and not just for waffles!

This worked great for a few weeks - I mostly used this to slice mushrooms and it was going great.Then the inevitable occurred - a wire came loose - these things simply are not made for anything other than eggs - don't listen to the manufacturers - they don't hold up to the stress of cutting mushrooms.Ah well - back to the knife....
What an excellent set of scotch glasses!The perfect size for a single or double pour.Great bowl for nosenice, weighted base for stability.These are the perfect scotch glasses.

This update for the PD35 simply makes this already great light even better.Upgraded to 960 lumens in turbo mode - water tight to 2m - and the best part is the 18650 rechargeable battery compatability.You cannot do better for the price and function - long run time and variable brightness for all of your needs.

This case is very good and frankly excellent for the price. Solid construction - good latches. Easy to lock with a regular padlock or TSA locks.The pluck foam allows for custom padding for your gear.I have a new Sig 716 patrol and it just fits with the stock fully retracted.Overall for the price it would be extremely challenging to do better.

This case was built for abuse. Add to that the excellent bluetooth keyboard with extreme battery life and you have a combination that is perfect for the person who loves to abuse their electronics :)- the keyboard is easy to charge and pair. Keys have a very nice tactile feel and are responsive.  Extra keys to lock the ipad, volume control, Siri access, battery check and more - very versatile - Apple should take some of these as an example of what's missing on their bluetooth keyboard.- the case is solid - ruggedized rubberized - magnetic hinge - holds my ipad perfectly.OK - it's not perfect - that's because I have an Air2 - they are slightly different. However, the Air2 does fit into the case - the openings are slightly off as Apple changed things a tiny bit - however it works well even so.I fully expect the Air2 version will be awesome once it is released.Overall you cannot go wrong with this case/keyboard combo.Sure - the $150 MSRP is a bit high, but you get what you pay for.

Worst customer service on the planet. Check their Facebook page and you will see that 99% of their comments by others are angry customers.I bought this for my wife a few years back, she tried it and was unhappy with the software and unhappy with the overall over experience. She told me to sell it.I posted it on eBay and Rosetta stone told eBay to pull the listing. Apparently they do not allow the transfer of their software at all.Treated me and my wife like second class citizens.I purchased this set from the military exchange - recently retired after 23 years of service, I will never use their products or recommend them to others,Apparently my experience is not uncommon.  Poor company, poor product. Avoid at all costs.

This is a very good little personal heater - it is very small, yet it puts out a nice amount of heat.Even on high the heat is not so much that it will make you very uncomfortable. It appears to be quite safe.The tip over switch is about as simple as it gets - if the switch is not on a hard level surface, it will not heat - a solid and very simple safety feature.It's a simple, compact heater that will keep your toes or hands warm when you need it.

The Tacwise Z1-140 is a good, functional compact staple gun.It uses 6mm or 8mm staples - which are not the 'heavy duty' type you may be accustomed to using in larger, heavier guns.In my initial testing, this staple gun performed well - you do have to ensure the handle gets ALL the way to the up position in order for it to engage properly and fire the next staple.The force required to fire the staples is fairly light when compared to other, larger staplers. This would make it much easier to use for younger users or those with forearms less bulky than Popeye's ;)The handy integrated belt/pocket hook is a GREAT feature.The ability to fold the handle down and lock it is also a great feature.I think the only issue I have with the staple gun is that it's nearly entirely made from plastic - this gives it a less than hefty feel. That along with the couple of misfires due to not allowing the handle to completely engage upwards - even though I thought it had - make this a four out of five star item.

The Sonos Playbar is the centerpiece of your sound system. The left/right and center functions that used to be taken up by three large speakers are now all handled by this single unit that produces amazing sound.Setup was a bit of a challenge at first - I did not start out with a Sonos bridge - which I highly recommend as it creates a separate wifi network for your Sonos system.You can wire this directly into the network and it should work fine - however I had it wired into an airport express and that is not sufficient to run the system.I have now integrated the playbar with a sub, and two play 3s for surround - the sounds is impressive and alleviates the need for a separate AV receiver.

Includes a paper template that allows you to pre-drill holes without having to hold the mount on the wall - just use some masking tape to attach the template and drill the holes.The mounting tabs that attach to the playbar are exactly what is needed for very simple installation.Easy one person installation and mounting.Tools needed - Driver/drill - hammer - appropriate drill bit/screwdriver attachment - level.

This is a nice LED bulb that is the same size as your old filament bulbs.Soft white color is spot on - just like your old bulbs.Low energy usage and super long life make this an easy choice. Add to that the lack of mercury that you find in the CFLs.the only issue I have is the price - there are less expensive options out there these days - GE needs to scale up and lower the price.

What can you say about an inexpensive scale that works well and sports a low profile?- Simple setup - just unpack and go.- Step on the scale and it starts up and give your weight.- keeps the reading for a few moments after you step off.- nice form factor - very clean and modern looking.

I ordered this on the special for $19.99 - expected delivery was January, it arrived today! Superb!Setup - VERY simple - plug into the wall, plug into the TV, batteries into the remote and follow the instructions.Connect to the wifi and off you go!Very nice introductory video starts playing right away - great resolution and easy instructionsIf you are familiar with Apple TV - this will make a lot of sense - the remote is FAR more user friendly and not a lot larger than the apple TV remote.Content - AWESOME - as a Prime member, there is a HUGE amount of content both audio and video available for no extra cost. Truly impressive!Easy interface, simple watchlist setup, what more could you want?I am VERY impressed - even at the current price a steal! Get this!

I ordered this after having huge issues with connecting my system together.All of the frustration I experienced attempting to connect my system to my wifi vanished as soon as I connected this to the system.Just hardwire this to your router and your Sonos system will work as advertised.Cannot recommend strongly enough and for the relatively low price, it's more than worth it.

Updated - 4/17/15- Once again this screen protector is a disappointment. I have replaced it once under warranty - and now the protector is broken again - this is not from impact - the protector is just cracked. I am seriously disappointed. For my Ipad - AWESOME - for my phone - terrible!!Below this update is my original review. This protector is awesome on my iPad, however this is not my long term impression.Problems:- the protector is not a perfect fit for the new iPhone screen, this leaves tiny gaps and this causes chipping around the edges of the glass protector. This can cause damage to your fingers - not a good situation.Overall a great idea, not the best execution.This is simply the best screen protector I have ever experienced- the touch sensitivity and feel is essentially identical to the device without the protector installed.- Installation was a BREEZE! - no more wet devices and worrying about placement - line it up and it just about installs itself!- I had to reposition it slightly and it was no trouble to pull up carefully and reposition - and it installed itself again!- Absolutely clear!- beveled edges make this so it won't catch on anything.- simple registration on the ZAGG site to ensure replacement if something does go wrong.There is simply no better screen protection on the market today.

These strips are basically like velcro - you clean the surface to mount on - attach the strips - wait a few minutes - let the adhesive set - and your are ready to go.Installation is simple - if you mess it up - get extras so you can do it again. removal is simple as with all command products.Each strip will notionally hold about four pounds - so putting four strips on heavier items makes it not only secure, but safe.Smaller/lighter items can be attached with a single pair or two.

These sights are fairly nice - very solid construction and heavy duty polymer.I actually kind of like the diamond sighting - I'm not fully sold on the 'traditional' sights anyway.Slide onto the picatinny rails without much problem - slide in the bolt and tighten - viola - easy to install.Unlike others - I have no issues with the push-button pop-up - works well and the springs are solid.Adjustments for elevation and windage can be made without specialized tools! major plus!Issues:- the night sight on this requires you to use a light on the sights to enable the glow - I'm not a fan of potentially harming your night vision in that manner. The treated areas are large enough and make it very easy to see on the positive side.- Polymer - cannot be used on some rifles due to heat issues (read melting) - Not a fan.Overall these are lighweight - easy to install, and work very well!

The AllStrike is a bit odd when you first receive it. Basically a disembodied head with a handle deep inside.I took it to my Krav Maga school so we could evaluate it and see how we liked it.It's easy to hold, the hand hold bar inside the head is angled well for proper alignment.The head is made from durable foam similar to other products used in martial arts.Striking is simple enough and you are able to strike without gloves with no harm to your hands. It's like striking a head shaped pad.Also great for knee strike practice as the chin area and sides are thick foam. The person holding is well protected.It does become challenging to hold for any length of time as there is only the one hand hold.Excellent for targeting training.Overall the class really likes it.

For those times when you just need to squeeze a lime or two, no need to get out the large juicer. These do the trick well enough.The enamel appears solid and the squeezer is just like the larger ones I have for lemons and oranges.For those who break these, I cannot imagine doing so. You can only get so much out of a lime. If you are squeezing hard enough to break the handles, you are going way overboard.Easy cleanup :)

This is a solid iphone 6 case that provides very good protection via a rubberized inner 'jacket' and also has a rigid plastic outer protection that can snap on and off.Properly sized and allowing full access to all buttons and switches, it certainly adds bulk to the phone, yet provides excellent drop protection and scratch protection for the covered areas.The apple logo is uncovered - while this is a nice esthetic, it's a gap in the coverage and I feel unnecessary.Overall I consider this a decent basic case providing good drop protection.

This is a very fun toy for adults and children alike!Very small - perhaps 6 inches across without the blade guards.The battery charges fairly quickly - perhaps an hour.The only thing not included is the charger itself - you can charge from a computer or from a USB plug in charger.The included micro SD card fits into a slot in the bottom of the copter - it does not fit terribly well - In fact I have been able to get video - however after I take video the card refuses to indicate it is inserted properly and I cannot take photos. It is a bit annoying.Overall the video quality isn't bad for a tiny camera on a tiny quad copter. - there is no sound - so it's whatever you can see. I imagine if there was sound all you would hear would be the propellers.Download the manual from the site - charge the batteries and go! It's fun and easy to fly.
High quality lapel pin. Well made - looks sharp. not too big. Exactly what was needed.
My original lapel pin was not included with the medal in the presentation box. This is the exact item that was missing.

Sadly I love these - so do my co-workers. Why is this sad?You get what you pay for! These are high-quality, very superior tasting, throat soothing pastilles.ANDThey are EXPENSIVE - and worth every penny.The flavor is very nice - not too sweet.It's a challenge not to chew them because they taste so nice.The large tin lasts me a couple of months - so perhaps it's not too bad ;)

I am trying to use less paper towels.  I have kids so I am pretty much always washing something.  So these towels are a good addition to that. They are more absorbent than a lot of dish towels.  And they are a good size to actually clean with.They are also thick enough to use as a hot pad in a pinch.

I will be honest, I thought this was 3 ft, not 3 meters. So it is a bit longer than I thought it would be. But if you are looking for a long cord this is a very good one.  I have it set up to run under my bed so that I can have the plug on the opposite wall where there is more plugs.This is also a heavy cord so it should take some wear.

Ever since I ran across Sarah Besseyâ€™s writing and especially when reading her first book Jesus Feminist: An Invitation to Revisit the Bible's View of Women, I have been struck by her ability to be inclusive and draw people together through her writing. Traditionally discussion of womenâ€™s roles is an exclusionary task, but Bessey, while clearly advocating for more inclusion of women in leadership and teaching roles in the church, was careful to not alienate those that disagreed with her.In her new book, Out of Sorts: Making Peace With an Evolving Faith, she is equally adept at drawing the reader in. Out of Sorts is a hard book to describe. It is memoir-ish. It is a book about church and Besseyâ€™s difficulties with the church, but it is not a complaint book. It is about spiritual growth and formation, denominations, Women, maturity, community and a variety of other topics.The overriding theme is that faith changes over time. The faith we have as children is not the same faith we have as teens, which is not the same faith we have in our 20s or 40s or later. Besseyâ€™s parents came to faith when she was a child, but old enough to remember. She grew up in small town Western Canada, where there were few enough Christians that she was relatively unaware of the differences between Christian groups. As she ventured out into the world she came to new understandings as she became acquainted with other Christians.Other than her pentecostal childhood, I think she is telling a story that is not too different from my own and many others that I know. Age and experience brought questions, but also a new ability to trust in faith. Most people I know have at least some difficulty with church abuse or burnout, and then most of those make their way back to church. Many people recently have been exploring more liturgical forms of Christianity.Bessey, at least at this point, is a bit of a fish out of water everywhere. She is not quite comfortable in her historic pentecostal background. She is not quite comfortable with the more liturgical settings, the evangelical mega church, likewise has many positive features but also many negative ones.There is very little judgement from Bessey. She wants people to land where they need to land. But she wants them to land in a faith community. If there is a single takeaway, it is that while they may be flawed, our faith communities are essential.

NT Wright is not only an increadibly prolific writer, he also seems to be continually updating his earlier books.The Meal Jesus Gave Us was originally published in 2002 and was revised this summer.Wright is known for his academic publishing, but this is one of his books that is oriented toward the non-professional. If anything this might have been over simplified. This new version is slightly edited and has added discussion questions. It would make a decent study for an adult confirmation class or a small group.The book opens with a short introduction imagining what a birthday party might look like to a martian unfamiliar with human rituals. After a brief discussion of human rituals conveying meaning, Wright spends a couple of chapters imagining what a disciple at the Last Supper and then an early Christian would think about communion.The second section (the last short 9 chapters) attempts to put some theological meat on the previous imaginings. Because it is Wright, communion is placed in context of early Jewish thought, the kingdom of God, the eschatalogical vision of Christianity (end times), how communion reflects Jesus death and resurrection and more.Along the way Wright briefly explores the ways that different streams of Christianity view communion, he explores the different names that it is given, and some of the church history and theological issues.The final chapter explores some of the practical theology that goes along with communion. How often should it be taken, who should take it, who should officiate, etc.NT Wright, when this was first written was an Anglican Bishop and this book follows Anglican theology, although non-Anglicans should not be afraid to read it.It is very brief, only about 95 pages of main content and I read it without any problem in an evening. It raises lots of good questions and does a good job presenting the importance of communion to the church theologically, practically and ritually.I do think that in the end, I expected a bit more meat to the book. It is definately an introduction and I think it makes a very good introduction. He does a good job presenting some of the controversial issues in a non-controversial way. It is clear that he believes that communion is very important and along with the Word (preaching and scripture reading) is central to Christian worship.For less than 100 pages of content I am not sure what else needed to be added as central. But I am again amazed at Wrightâ€™s ability to write to a wide variety of audiences well.

These are large, very good chocolate bars.  The different squares in the bar have different mixes of ingredients, so each bite can be slightly different.I will say that the delivery was on a warm day (around 80 degrees) and after sitting all day in my mailbox, it was clear that at some point (either in transportation or in the mailbox) it got too warm and slightly melted the bar.  Didn't affect the taste, but it did change the visual presentation.

Update: I am dropping to 3 stars.  When it works it works great.  But for a reason I have not discovered yet, it seems to leak about every third refill.  I am not sure why it is leaking but it is.  So I always put it on a towel so that it doesn't ruin the dresser it is sitting on.______________I got this for my nearly 2 year old's room. She loves the stars and the humidifier works well.There are a couple of issues with the design that keep it from being 5 stars.  First the area of the projection, while fairly bright is not all that big. I have this on a dresser out of her reach so she does not pull it down on herself. But the actual projection is only about 24-28 inches wide. Second it only points straight up.  In other room designs this might not be a problem, but in her room that means the projection is on the opposite side of the room as her bed.The first time I used it, I must not have gotten the seal closed properly and it leaked all over the place.  Every time after that I have checked the seal and it has not leaked a drop.  So it was clearly human error.  It is always a problem with humidifiers.  But the seal is on the bottom of this (you have to turn it upside down to fill.  I would prefer the seal be on the top so that isn't an issue.

have been vaguely aware of Thomas Oden but I have not previously read anything by him.I was first aware of his books on early African Christianity such as The African Memory of Mark: Reassessing the Early Church Tradition. I was not really aware that he was also the driving force behind the Ancient Christian Commentary on Scripture series.People I know of kept mentioning how good this memoir was and when I had some Amazon promotional credit I bought it (it is the most expensive memoir I have ever purchased, which is why I have not read it previously.)Oden is similar in age to Eugene Peterson, Kalistos Ware, Pope Benedict, Martin Marty and Richard John Neuhaus. All of these theologians lived through a strange time. They were born between the wold wars in a global recession. The first wave of progressive modernity had passed with the world wars and a new death of god liberalism came to the fore with their adulthood.Oden fully embraced liberal theology as an academic theologian (and unusual for then, but not today, also a working pastor). In his late 30s he started to struggle with the weaknesses of the liberal movement, ecumenism (as illustrated by the World Council of Churches) and his own faith.A major turning point was his first sabbatical, which he spent in Europe interacting with many of his theological heroes and as an observer with Vatican II. Over the next decade he started promoting â€˜classical Christianityâ€™ through â€˜paleo-orthodoxyâ€™, a theological method that rejected innovation but instead relied on early church (Patristic) sources.Once committed to paleo-orthodoxy (he was differentiating from neo-orthodoxy), he pledged to not intentionally write anything new. For Oden, the way forward was by fully understanding those that were closest to the time of Jesus. These early writers were following in the steps of Paul in 2 Cor 2:2 by saying nothing new about Jesus.  Oden is also committed to the consensus teaching. One of his other projects was to determine exactly what is agreed upon by different groups.  So one book project was taking over 100 evangelical statements of faith and determining what was affirmed by all of them. (And this was really what at heart was the point of the Ancient Christian Commentary series as well.)For an armchair theologian such as myself, this was a fascinating book. Oden has had a global reach, geographically, denominationally and historically. He was friends with a number of Roman Catholic, Orthodox and Protestant theologians. He credits a conversation with Joseph Ratzinger (later Pope Benedict) for encouraging him to attempt the Ancient Christian Commentary series. He was involved in the Evangelicals and Catholics Together movement as well as a number of other ecumenical movements based around traditional Christian orthodox beliefs.Oden was also an incredibly prolific author. Based on my count he was the author of at least 58 books, not including the Ancient Christian Commentary series which he was the general editor and also the author of a couple of the books in the series (also not counting different editions of books as multiple.)As someone that has been seriously working through my own journey of faith and looking back toward the historic Christian streams of faith, it is clear that whether I knew of him or not, Oden is someone that has influenced many that have also influenced me.For those that are less theology nerds and less interested in historic Christian streams of faith, this will be less interesting. Like many memoirs there is a lot of â€˜and then I wrote thisâ€™ and â€˜and then I met these peopleâ€™. If you are not aware of at least some of the players and background story it could get a bit boring.

This is a present for my daughter's second birthday.  I have removed it from packaging and it is prepped to be giving but it has not actually been played with yet. (I will update if it matters).The size is great for my 2 year old.  I also have a six month old son, so my daughter has been playing with baby dolls quite a bit since he was born.I do think that the scent is too strong, at least initially. I don't know how much it will fade over time. If it doesn't fade soon I will probably try to wash it (a good feature.)

We got this for my nearly 2 year old daughter. She is starting to count and identify numbers and letters (that they exist, not the specific ones) and her colors.She is too young to really play hopscotch, but she loves to jump.  So we put this in her room and use it to jump on and point out colors.  It is a good size for a runner for her toddler bed. Although she moves it around the room so it does not stay in place. (There is a rubber backing that if it was on a hard wood or tile floor would keep it in place.)The colors are bright and it rolled out flat right out of the box.

The fit is pretty much perfect.  And it is a nice looking shirt.  I didn't realize I had bought the 'trim fit' one until I started to write the review. I am not too heavy but I this is not what I would consider an 'athletic cut' so if you are pretty skinny, this might be a bit too big, but it fits me perfectly.The description says 100% cotton, 100% polyester (which is obviously a misprint).  The actual shirt says 60% cotton and 40% polyester, which is standard for a shirt that is wrinkle free.  I washed it right out of the package and put it on right out of the dryer and it needed an iron.One other nice thing is the packaging. Normally with a dress shirt there is about 12 pin that keep the shirt in place and looking good in the package.  But those small holes can show up for a long time. (I have bought dress shirts on more than several occasions for immediate use.)  But this short was primarily packages with fancy looking paper clip things.  So no holes. There was two or three pins, but only in places that could not be seen.All and all this is a good shirt and a decent price, but I will have to post back later on the 'wrinkle free' portion.

I used these bottles for my daughter (and now my son) so I was interested in these as a gift set for friends that are are newly pregnant.The gift packages is well designed.  It comes with four bottles (4 oz) and four size one nipples.  There is also two size 2 nipples and 2 size 3 nipples. My daughter started using the size 3 around six months.  And it is about that time that you would most likely start using the 8 oz size bottles.The gift set also includes a specially designed bottle brush.  These bottles are a bit oddly shaped so the bottle brush that will get into the crevice at the bottom is a good idea.Also there are two adapters for your breast pump to be able to pump directly into the bottles, which is  a really nice addition that I wish we had for our bottles.  Because after two years these are still the primary bottles I use.One other nice feature of the bottle that is included in the gift set is the seals for travel.  I have used a couple other bottles that have different types of seals. Other than these ones (and Doc Browns which I don't like for other reasons) all other seals required you keep the nipple separate away from the bottle.  But these bottles allow a seal to fit underneath the nipple and then you can just remove the nipple take the seal off and put the nipple back on.  Everything is stored all together.

I have really enjoyed this bubble bath trio. I tend to use bubble bath as my shaving cream and these products work great. All three scents are pleasant (the honey is my favorite) and relatively mild although my skin keeps a hint of the fragrance most of the day. I have had several friends comment on how clean I smell. The soap isn't at all oily yet leaves my sensitive skin very soft with no reactions thus far.

Unlike other cream make-ups I have tried this one goes on without smudging or creating lighter spots where your fingers have been. Once it has been applied, you do not even feel it on your skin, again, unlike other cream make-ups I have tried. If you are someone who doesn't like having multiple make-up brushes, going with this cream based make-up that is applied using your fingers is a great alternative. It also doesn't create the dust mess that powder blushes do. If this was the same price as my normal powder blush, I'd buy it instead...however it costs about 3 times as much. With a lower price I'd give it 5 stars and buy it!

I ran out of the plain rice cereal (that was originally purchased for my almost 2 year old daughter.)  So I picked this up as something different.  My daughter still likes to sit and eat cereal when I am feeding my 6 month old.  So I relied on her sense of taste more than my son's.  My daughter made an odd face the first time she tried it (not what she was expecting) but went right along and kept eating it. She is a bit picky, so it seems to taste alright.I can't comment about any allergy issues because I didn't pick it up because of allergies.

I got this for my daughter's 2 year old birthday in a couple weeks. She will be excited.  it is bigger than I really expected.  (I know it says jumbo).  But it is a good soft doll.  The packaging is easy to take off (two twist ties) and you are ready to go.The only issue is really the size, this is going to be a toy for the house, not the car.

The most noticeable thing that I am surprises about is how quiet it is.  I have a Dyson, which I really like, for carpets. But it does a lousy job on hardwood and tile floors.  I also have a dog that sheds like you wouldn't believe.  I have lived 9 years in the house just using a broom, but I have a six month old and he is always covered in dog hair.  So I decided to get this to try to get rid of some of the dog hair.But I have no issue vacuuming when the 6 month old is sleeping. This is the quietest vacuum I have used.The only negative I have come across so far is the attachments.  They are designed to attach to the handle but fall off. So I keep them in the closet where the vacuum is stored.  But other than that minor issue, I really like this.

I, as an expectant father, was particularly drawn in because the book opens and closes with birth stories. Birth and death are natural places where we see God because they are such transcendent experiences. But in between birth and death God sometimes gets a little lost (or at least we lose sight of God in the midst of our busyness).Most of the stories are in some way about family, community and the church. We have a tendency to live as if we are alone. But it is in community, our families, the church, neighbors, friends, that we often most clearly see and hear God. (This is very similar to the focus in Eugene Peterson's Practice Resurrection).Except for the fact that Weber can write prose more beautifully than almost anyone I have ever read, she is a normal mom, wife, teacher, writer, Christian. She does not have a particularly large circle of influence, she is not a pastor to thousands or leader of a large business or non-profit. She is not a household name. So I can relate to the way she loses sight of God in the mundane. Because it is in the mundane that most of us live our lives.

If you asked me what my favorite thing to do, on the list would be floating in the ocean reading. Several years ago I found a floating waterproof case for my Kindle 2. And up until recently I had still been using it. But it finally broke and on impulse I picked up a Waterfi Waterproof Kindle Paperwhite two weeks ago right before I went to the beach for a weekâ€™s vacation.The first thing you notice about Waterfiâ€™s waterproofed Paperwhite is that it is basically indistinguishable from a regular Paperwhite. The waterproofing is not visible and doesnâ€™t add any weight (at least not enough to be noticiable).Waterfi is an aftermarket system. So you purchasing one from Waterfi voids the Amazon warranty.There are two main negatives about the Waterfi system that was not true of my old floating Kindle case. First, it does not float. So if I dropped it in the ocean, I would have go grab it. I have thought about how to create some type of float for it, but I havenâ€™t worked that out yet. I was just careful when I was swimming with it.The second negative is that because the Paperwhite is a touch screen device that moves by electical conduction, hard spray from salt water can turn the page or turn on the screen. It was not a huge problem, but I did need to try to keep it out of the spray to actually pay attention to the book.But those two negatives aside, it was waterproof, the screen was not at all fuzzy as the one waterproof case for the Paperwhite that I have tried was.The Waterfi Paperwhites are the ad-free version, which is $20. So essentially the waterproofing is a $1000 premium.Waterfi also sells waterproof iPod shuffles (and headphones) for swimmers, waterproof Fitbits and several other items.

I really like these large muslin blankets for swaddling.  I think they work better than the velcro designed swaddle blankets, which tend to be too heavy and hot.These are a standard muslin, fairly thin and light, which is great for warmer months. These are not quite as soft as the ones that are cotton/bamboo mix, but they are a bit lighter weight.

As an adult, I was a little disappointed by this book.  It is basically a long fold out book.  I also thought it seemed a bit young for my 20 month old daughter that is actually learning colors and shapes right now.  But my daughter liked it and my 6 month old did as well.  I didn't initially realize that the dongle spoke when you push it the right way, but my kids figured it out.

I am a big fan of Mr Rogers. Part of what made me pick up this book was a desire to re-connect with the peacefulness of Mr Rogers for my children. My daughter is just old enough that she is starting to pay attention to TV and enjoys the cartoon adaptation of Daniel Tiger. It didnâ€™t hurt that I picked up the book while it was on sale.Peaceful Neighbor explores Mr Rogers pacifism in two parts. The first is the direct understand of pacifism as being against war and violence.
