This is explored through looking at Mr Rogerâ€™s personal history as well as how he dealt with war and violence on the TV show and how in later years of the Gulf War and post 9/11 he was politically active in small ways.The second section is a look at peace in other ways, including Mr Rogers understanding of racism, hunger, gay rights, environmentalism and his personal vegetarianism.I found much of the book interesting as an abstract understanding of Mr Rogers as a liberal mainline Christian. That may seem dismissive, but it is not intended to be. Many liberal mainline Christians do not spend their whole lives living out their ideals. In many ways Mr Rogers is one of the best spokespersons for Christianity of the late 20th century. Many, many people know he was an ordained minister. Many people have commented about his real love of the other and how he cared for those around him.But as with any good book, Long is aware of Mr Rogerâ€™s faults as well. He primarily wanted to speak through his show and with few exceptions, he did not act politically or become a spokesperson outside of his show for the causes he believed in. Mr Rogers also had some blind spots. For instance, he paid his staff quite poorly and they did not have his personal wealth to fall back on. One instance he gave to hunger relief organizations on behalf of his staff instead of Christmas gifts, without really understanding that the Christmas gifts might have been important to some of the staff.As much as I love the subject, the book I thought was too long and not biographical enough. It spends more time analyzing episodes of the TV show than biographical details. This is not a biography, so maybe I am asking too much, but I think more biography and less episode analysis would have been helpful. Similarly, the method of walking through different subject areas for each chapter seemed repetitive here. It worked well in the recent biography of Billy Graham because the subjects were so varied. But here the subjects were too similar and I by the time I was about 2/3 of the way through, I was getting bored.In spite of my boredom, I finished and it sparked a desire to watch some of the old episodes, which are available via Amazon Prime and other streaming methods. Mr Rogers was important and the subject is worth the book. As far as I can tell there is not a well reviewed full biography of Mr Rogers. There is one other book that looks interesting, The Simple Faith of Mister Rogers, but again it is not a full bio.

These are great little cables perfect for battery packs or to use in cars for charging or media.This is a replacement cord.  The only reason that I am replacing it is that I accidentally dropped the cord and then ran over it several times with my car before noticing it.  The plastic around the place that you insert into the phone was broken but it still works just fine as a charging cord (I am just concerned that my 1 year or or 5 month old will get ahold of it and start chewing on it.Otherwise I have used the old cord for over a year and this one is just as good.

Update 2: So After using both at the same time for a while, I still come back to the fact that I like the screen and accuracy of the nuyu, but the software of the Jawbone.  Also I never take the jawbone off.  I could use the nuyu as a watch which would eliminate the need to take it off the clothing keep it on, but then I would have two things on my wrist.  If the software that goes with the nuyu gets a major upgrade I might use it instead of the jawbone at some point.  But even though I think the hardware is better than the jawbone, I am going to be using the jawbone.Update: After a backpacking trip I am even more impressed by the hardware, but more disappointed by the software. I comparison to the Jawbone24 which I also took this was much more useful and accurate. I wore it in my pocket compared to the wrist with the Jawbone. For some unknown reason, the Jawbone just didn't record steps for two days of the trip. Also the screen made it actually useful while hiking to check time and steps.The screen is sometimes hard to get to turn on, especially when you are all sweaty.The major weakness is still the software. I can't record calories and the ability to look at historical data is present, but not as easy or clear as it should be.Neither of these are perfectly accurate, but the nuyu seems much more accurate than the Jawbone24. That being said, I never take the jawbone off and usually wear the nuyu on my belt loop. So I forget to wear it sometimes.  I might just stop using the Jawbone, but I really like the calorie counter part of the software._________I have only used this briefly, but I am going to take it on a backpacking trip this week and I will update.After my brief use there are several really good features.First it fits well as a watch. It is snug and does not take up too much space. (I am a guy with relatively small hands and wrists. This is will fit a much larger wrist, but I think it will look better for women and men that have smaller wrists.)I like the clear numbers. They are not super bright outside, but still quite readable.The battery is a positive and negative. Because it is replaceable, you will have an ongoing cost. But because it is a watch battery it will last a long time.I have a jawbone 24 that I am comparing it to. The jawbone is much thicker and I usually take it off when I am typing because it is too thick to type comfortably. Also its battery is built in and must be recharged about every 10 days.  That is not a big deal either, but it really depends on how you use it which you would prefer.I like that there is an option for clipping it on clothes or putting it in a pocket.  One of the major negatives for the jawbone is that It doesn't record steps accurately when I am pushing a stroller.  Because I am a stay at home Dad, virtually all my exercise is while pushing a stroller.  When just walking both the jawbone and nuyu seem very close to one another in counting steps.  But when pushing the stroller, the nuyu is more accurate, even when I put the jawbone in my pocket.The major negative for the nuyu is that the software is not as complete.  The jawbone allows me to put in food and counts calories and makes health suggestions.  The nuyu counts steps and distance and estimates calories but nothing related to food.  Although you can put in your weight and track that on the nuyu if you want.  Also the nuyu does not work with other apps. So you can't sync with a number of iPhone health trackers or nest thermostat or many other apps.One more place where there nuyu is not as good as the Jawbone is in notifications. There are a number of notifications you can set up the jawbone for. You can have it ping you every 30 minutes (or whatever time you want) to get up. Or you can set it up to let you know if you have not been active in  specified time. You can use it as silent alarm in the morning. You can ask it to let you know when you have completed 2000 steps or to remind you that it is a specific time of the day.  The vibrations are all good and strong, but silent.  This just isn't an option for the nuyu.Honestly I like the nuyu better as a device, but the software on the jawbone.

Update: After using about half the bag I am changing my review.  Consistently about every other one does not dissolve and leaves a mess on the bottom of my dishwasher. I don't yet see a pattern for why some work and some don't.  I have tried different cycle types to see if some cycles work better than others.  But the point of these things is to work, not dissolving and leaving a mess that needs to be cleaned up (not to mention distinctly less clean dishes is not working.______I have tried basically ever version of Finish tabs. The soft ones melted in damp places. The packages that you had to open were an extra step. These ones seem to be the next generation that actually just allows you to throw it in and not have to worry about opening something.It really isn't a problem to just open the package, but I have always make putting in the soap one of the jobs that my youngest kids can do. They could never open the package on their own, and once open, they wanted to play with the tabs and see if they could get it apart.  These ones are already packages, and just need the child to put it in the dishwasher. A good job for a 20 month old.

First of all this is a big playset. Make sure you have place for it.  Mine is in the basement and it is not moving anywhere else.Second, this really is a good set for kids ages 1 to 5. My daughter is 21 months and loves playing with it in her own way, although not necessarily as it was intended.  She likes to 'zoom' the car around and make noises.  She occasionally will use the remote control portion of the toy, but mostly she watches while I remote control the car.This also gets marks for being flexible, it can set up in a couple different configurations and once I sat down and started I had it set up in about a half hour (not including stickers, which I refuse on principle to ever apply.)There are two negatives. First the elevator has not worked since the first day. I think there is a broken gear somewhere, so I either just doing include it in the track or the car gets lifted up.  It goes up about 2 inches and stops.The second negative is that the car batteries (which were included and installed) were dead enough to not move the car, but had enough juice to keep making noise.  I should have guessed earlier than I did, that the batteries needed changing, but I spent a while trying to figure out what was wrong with the car and track.  There is not a lot of directions or help provided, but I would have liked the batteries to not come installed so I knew they were working.I would really rate this about a 3.5 if that were an option.  I like it, I think it will work well for a while.  I think that except for the elevator, there isn't much else that could break.My last comment is that things like this should always come with two cars and two controllers. I know you can buy more, but it feels cheap to not include at least two cars in something that is billed as a race track

My daughter is 23 lb, 21 month old. This seat should last her a good long time.Overall I am very happy with it in the few days I have had it.  It is easy to understand. The hooks to get it in the seat are convient and have places to store for the ones that can't be used.  I have a couple of vehicles that I will need to use seat belts to connect.  I have not used that yet, but it is easy to see how they connect and it is better than the way several other seats I have used connect with seatbelt.There are a couple issues.  I like the built in crotch protector, but the crotch portion of the seat seems to far back to the seat. My daughter is still very small and I almost moved that strap up. And there is only one more slot forward to move it up to.I like the cup holder's placement. One of the issues with other toddler car seats I have used is that the cup holders are out of reach of the child. My daughter can reach this without a problem and can reach to the bottom of the cup.  The only issue with the cup holder is that by its design, you can't use any cups that have a handle on them. At this age they don't have to have handled cups, but the cup that traditionally we kept in the car for water had a handle in it and I had to switch it out.The only other consideration is the head rest.  I have a Mazda 5 and all of the head rests in the car lean slightly forward. I am not a fan of this design, but this seat does not fit well with that.  Right now I have it at its lowest setting.  It is right below the car's headrest.  I tried to move it up and I can't move up the Graco seat without removing the car's headrest unless I am willing to create a space between the carseat and the back of the seat of the car.  Most people won't have an issue with this, but if you have a headrest that leans forward and can't be removed, you might want to consider a different type of seat.

I have not actually slept on these sheets. They are for my guest bedroom.  But they are a nice light weight summer sheet set.  The last set of sheets I had for my guest room started ripping after a few months with only four or five washes.  I have only washed these twice so far, but they already seem to be better made.I thought microfiber might be a bit heavier weight (my guest bedroom is in the basement and tends to be a bit cool) but these are a nice weight for summer.

I have tried Hefty's Odor Block bags as well as these Glad Fabreeze bags. The odor block are black, which I prefer, seem to be a bit stronger bags and have a much more modest scent.The glad bags I can smell just walking into the kitchen.  I do not have an overly strong sense of smell, so I think if you are sensitive to smells you want to avoid these

I have a similar animal for my daughter.  She has a monkey.  I was expecting both to be about the same size.  This bunny is about 8 to 9 inches (not including ears) and my daughters monkey is about 14.  The smaller size is probably better for most people that don't want the extra bulk.  But that makes the light only about 2 inches sq.  My daughter's monkey is night light bright.  This Bunny is a very soft glow.On the positive side, you can turn this one off.  My daughter's can only be turned off by opening it up.  But it does not have any sound levels.  I am of the opinion that every child's toy that makes sound should have multiple sound levels

This is a thin, protective case with nice high end looking smooth leather.  The pocket for cards is not big enough to hold more than one, maybe two cards.  The magnet on the cover is nice and holds closed well.One negative is that it feels like closing the cover should turn off the device (as the iPad and kindle paperwhites do), but it does not.  And it shuts well, so you may not see the light.One more area that is particular for me, is that I have a cell phone holder on my car dash that holds from the sides.  Because of the way the case folds it forces the screen to turn toward the passenger's side.  It isn't a big deal, but if you have a similar holder, you might be aware of the problem.

I very much respect Mark Nollâ€™s work as a historian.  So after re-reading The Civil War as Theological Crisis I found God and Race in American Politics.Noll is primarily known as a historian of North American Evangelicalism.  But this is a natural followup to his Civil War as Theological Crisis.  Instead of looking at the theological response to issues of race and slavery (as he did in Civil War), Noll expands his view to take a quick survey at how Race and Religion interacted over the history of the US until the 2004 Presidential Election.As you might expect a good historian to say, the reality is much more complicated than the traditional story that is told in your 4th grade US history class.  But Noll does a very good job surveying those complications in less than 200 pages.His first chapter covers a lot of similar ground as the Civil War as theological crisis.  Essentially, the common reading of the bible prior to the Civil War was that slavery was a biblical practice, and calling for the end of slavery as a theological statement for most people meant that they had to reject the common reading of scripture and be accused of rejecting orthodox Christianity.  And many abolitionists did explicitly reject Christianity (or at least the more orthodox forms of Christianity).  But here, Noll spends a good bit of time observing that it was not slavery, but racially based slavery that was the real issue.  The widespread belief in white racial superiority meant that Christians were able to accept the plain reading of scripture that said that slavery was acceptable, but not the plain reading of scripture that said that Blacks were of one faith with Whites.This became even more pronounced in the post-civil war era.  Because many of those abolitionists were more focused on the restraining the institutions of government than on solving the problems of integrating former slaves into the political and social system of the US.The rise of the independent African American church was important to the racial identity of African Americans.  This is a more widely understood narrative, and the shortest section of Nollâ€™s book.  But it is still important.  Modern complaints about racially divided church, often ignore or gloss over the reasons for a racially divided church.It is when Noll starts talking about the rise of Jim Crow and then moves into the Civil Rights era that I think the book really starts being important.  Traditional history if it talks about religion and Jim Crow or Civil Rights tends to paint a fairly straight forword picture.  Noll suggests that while religion is important (and he believes that it is), it is important to different sides for different reasons.Noll suggests that post Civil War, the segregationist impulses of the Christian church still used religious language and revivalist methodology, but there was a shift and by the Civil Rights era, defense of segregation was mostly using very little scriptural support.  Similarly, prior to the Civil War, almost no abolitionist pointed to scripture to defend the equality of Black humanity (because there was a wide spread belief that Blacks were literally a separate and a sub-human species.)  But as African American churches became independent and started mining the depths of scripture for themselves, a new story emerged that a racially insensitive White majority slowly became aware of.Noll points out that the institutions of Christianity may not have been supportive of Civil Rights, but they were also not supportive of segregation either.  There was very real problems of socially integrating White and Black culture that had been separate.And so Noll suggests that the modern political history needs to be viewed through the Civil Rights movement to properly understand it.  It is not as much that the separation between the Republican White Evangelicals and the Democratic African Americans are theologically separate, but politically separate as a response to the movements of the Civil Rights era.  And while the Civil Rights era cannot be properly told without the African American church, the continued separation is not primarily theological, but historical.This is a VERY brief retelling of Nollâ€™s own brief book.  So I really skimmed over most of Nollâ€™s argument.  At the end of the book, Noll has a brief theological response.  And I think that Noll is both hopeful, but has strong words for the church, and government, about how the role of how race influences both theology and political leanings.  Ignoring that influence continues to keep Christians separate.I donâ€™t think this is Nollâ€™s best book.  He is clearly moving outside some of comfort zones and he is a bit uncomfortable with the brevity of his argument.  But it is a good introduction to areas that are often skimmed over or not given sufficient weight. The Story of the United States cannot be told without the Christian Church.  And the story of the United States cannot be told without the very mixed role that race has played.  More often than not, there was a combination of Race and Religion that was really at the root of the US story.

These are good decently heavy duty bags. I use them in my basement garbage cans which get a bit of everything. I have had any rip yet, so they are good enough for me. The draw string also work better than the last tie type bags which always seems to be just not quite enough material left to tie together well

Update: This is still going strong. The arms are great for the now 2 year old to carry it around. It has dropped innumerable times at this point and has not fallen out once. Not a scratch or ding on it._______my 19 month old is a significant user of this IPad. She dropped it twice in the first 2 minutes and it was fine and even bounced a bit. It stands on flat surfaces well but will fall down if at all uneven.  As an adult the case is a bit unwieldy but it is worth it to stay protected

Good light shoe. But fit is a bit narrow. I normally wear 7.5 but got an 8 since other reported them being small. The length is fine but the shoes are a bit narrow. Otherwise they are fine. I have been wearing without socks and after about two weeks they are loosening up

My mother in law has a cabin and we always keep several hummingbird feeders there.  The other animals (including the occasional small bear) tend to knock the feeders around a bit so we have quite a range of feeders. This one had a hummingbird with in a few minutes of hanging it. I really don't see much of a different in how the hummingbirds use the clear or colored feeders (we use clear nectar, so that part doesn't matter).  But the red color does make it easier to find if the wind or an animal knocks it down and/or drags it off.

I got this screen proctor for my wife's iPhone 6 after my daughter dropped it and shattered the screen.  So once the screen was fixed it got a screen protector.  I am not sure that would have done anything in the case where it originally shattered but it can't hurt.My wife put it on herself in quite quickly and had no issues.  I wonder about whether I should have gone for the glass protectors, but this one feels nice and is not really noticeable once it was put on.

This is an umbrella I keep in my car.  It fits nicely on the side of the seat or underneath the seat.  It is a nice size to keep my and my 2 year old dry. (Not golf umbrella obnoxious, but not tiny either.)  I do like the idea of the reflective portions, but I don't know how much that actually helps.The only thing that really surprised me when I used it was how much force it takes to close.  The spring is strong, so when you hit the button it pops right up nicely.  But the corresponding problem of that is the amount of force required to close it.  I don't think anyone that is an adult would have a problem closing it.  But you do have to push a bit and I had to do it a couple times each of the first several times I used it.Overall well designed and compact

My dog is great, but she is not interested in fetch most of the time.  My daughter is old enough that she wants to try to play fetch with our dog like she does with my brother in law's dog. So I picked up this ball. It seems is pretty indestructible. The ball is good size, so my young (toddler) daughter can pick it up and throw it.  The size is also good for a large dog (we have a black lab).  But it didn't change the fact that my dog is mostly uninterested in fetch.

The Narnia books, and maybe Screwtape Letters or Mere Christianity, is all that many know of CS Lewis. I am far from a Lewis scholar, but I have read books over 20 books by or about Lewis over the last 3 or so years. I continue to gain insight into Lewis as I read different perspectives.Rowan Williams in his 2011 Holy Week lectures talked about Lewis and Narnia and how both can speak to our Christian lives. This book is the result of those lectures (similar to his later book, Being Christian that I read earlier this year.)I did not realize until I was done that this was based on a series of lectures. This did not feel at all like a series of lectures, but like a planned book.What I most appreciated about this book was its generous nature. Williams illustrated well what it means to read with the intention of giving the author the benefit of the doubt. Especially the chapter about Narniaâ€™s critics, but also throughout the book, Williams wants to make sure we are not unfair to Lewis and his time or what Lewis was attempting.Williams also keeps the focus on how Lewis is trying to communicate faith to his audience. There is clear wonder here. Williams himself read Narnia as a boy and while he has grown and is a scholar, he has not outgrown the desire to see wonder in literature.Rowan Williams has also done his homework. This is a book that does not limit itself just to Narnia. He quotes freely and frequently, but appropriately, from the full range of Lewisâ€™ work.Like other good books on Lewis, it makes me to want to read more Lewis.

I have read a ton of books on prayer. About a year ago, some book that I donâ€™t remember suggested that we as Christians should stop reading about things we are not prepared to put into practice immediately (because it can inoculate us against actual change.) So I have tried, somewhat successfully, to lay off of Christian Living books and focus on Christian history, biography, informational non-fiction and fiction. Roughly 2/3 of the books I have read this year have been either fiction or Christian History/Biography.But after virtually universal 5 star reviews, when I saw Prayer by Tim Keller as an audiobook on Scribdâ€™s subscription program I picked it up. It would have been a very different read if I had not just read Rowan Williamsâ€™ book on CS Lewis and Narnia. Williams was such a good example of generous reading that I really was conflicted about how often I was frustrated by this book.I want to start positively. Toward the end of the book there is a significant section about prayers of repentance and confession. I do not think I have ever read a general book on prayer that also spent time on confession and repentance, and Keller did it well. I was convicted, but also I think Keller did a great job helping to illustrate what it means to truly repent.That was followed up by an even better practical section on how to actually pray and put into practice the theological reflections of the majority of the rest of the book. It was practical, still based in theological understanding of what we are doing and why we are doing it, and I think what many were probably looking for when they picked up the book. The problem is that many of the people that were looking for the practical prayer suggestions, probably did not make it to the end of the book.Much of the rest of the book was also helpful but it was not without frustration. Keller is known for being a likable and irenic pastor. He has a significant role at the Gospel Coalition, a group that is not known for being irenic.I was encouraged when Keller quoted three different catholics in the first chapter. It is clear that Keller has read widely on prayer. But I was disappointed though that throughout the book when Keller moves into a teaching mode, his quotes tend to be from John Owen, Martin Luther, John Calvin or occasionally Augustine. It felt to me, and maybe I am just not being a generous reader, that teaching roles in the book needed to be from â€˜safelyâ€™ Reformed or Reformed Friendly theologians.One of my favorite books on prayer is Richard Fosterâ€™s classic that is also simply called Prayer. Both survey the wide range of prayer that is a part of a variety of Christian traditions. While Foster is content to just survey and speak of the benefits of different types of prayer, Keller feels the need to evaluate different types of prayer. According to Keller prayer is best when it is word based (he is not a fan of centering prayer or other apophatic prayer traditions) and he is concerned that short repetitive prayers like the Jesus Prayer (Lord, Jesus, son of God, have mercy on me a sinner) can be misused by becoming mantras or incantations.So while Foster would point out how a prayer could be misused, Keller seems to suggest that a prayer type that he is not in favor of should be avoided completely instead of used properly.I may have understood Kellerâ€™s position too harshly. He repeatedly lays out a path and give illustrations of what veering too far one way or another looks like. He is attempting to keep to the balanced middle. That is more my personality, but in prayer I am just not sure that is a helpful position. Prayer is in large part Godâ€™s work that we participate in. If we feel called to a particular type of prayer, it is worthwhile to understand how that type of prayer can be misused, but we should not be rejecting the work of the Spirit if the Spirit is calling us, just because some people misuse a particular type of prayer.Kellerâ€™s definition of prayer did not help. Keller defines prayer as a â€œpersonal, communicative response to the knowledge of Godâ€. This allows Keller to account for the universal nature of prayer, without needing to say that all prayer is either the same or equally valid. The problem is that he seems to be suggesting that right theological (academic) knowledge is essential to right prayer.However, most of the people I have known that are praying saints are not theologically trained. They are orthodox Christians, but there is not enough nuance for me to be clear what Keller means when he says that that right knowledge of God leads to better practice of prayer. This seems to be a part of his reformed bias toward theological correctness as most important (and minimizing fruits of the spirit or other manifestations of the Christian life that are not academic or theological).Keller explicitly says that he is not writing anything new here. His intention is to take what is good and important from many of the classics on prayer and make it accessible to modern readers. I support the goal, but maybe not the actual way it is worked out here. Keller is incessantly quoting. I understand that he does not want to portray otherâ€™s ideas as his own. But the method makes this seem much more like a textbook than is necessary.My final point is that prayer, more than any other spiritual discipline I know, is something that must be done. Preferably with mentoring and/or in a group. Near the end of the book Keller talks about the Book of Common Prayer and how Cranmer was attempting to create a liturgy that was for the laity, soaked in scripture, with prayer as a central part, so that a culture of prayer and worship could be absorbed into the people.This is one reason that I think that James KA Smithâ€™s work has been so important at helping us Christians understand how worship helps to form us into Christ-like creatures. It is repetition and habit over time that help us be transformed. It is not in the end simply better knowledge or even wisdom that leads to a transformed life. (Smith uses the helpful phrase, we are not brains on a stick.) But it is practice (and repetition of the spiritual life and liturgy of worship) that opens us up to wisdom that helps speak into our lives through the Holy Spirit that creates transformed Christians.I do not want to suggest that this is not a helpful book. There were many sections that were helpful. I think something about the conception of the book missed the mark. It is too intellectually focused (and I say that as someone that I think it too intellectually focused on my Christian life.) It is too oriented toward right theology over and against right practice. It is too focused on the Reformation theologians and not enough on those known as people of prayer throughout Christian history. It is also fairly disjointed trying to cover a wide swath of material without fully connecting all the pieces to the whole.

A warm loving tribute to John Ford, the making of "The Quiet Man" and to Ireland.For "Quiet Man" fans, probably the ultimate companion piece to the movie with clips from the film (could have been more pristine), knowledgeable comments from directors Martin Scorsese, Jim Sheridan and Peter Bogdanovich,  Professor William Dowling and noted Ford biographer Joseph McBride.  A revisit to many of the original locations especially the town of Cong which substituted for the film's "Innisfree" including meeting some of the townsfolk who worked on the film and others who remember when "Hollywood came to town."The saga of how John Ford battled for more than twenty years to achieve his love ode  to his ancestral home of Connemara and his eventual shrewd deal with Herbert J. Yates (head of Republic Pictures) is well documented  and Pappy's cranky quirkiness is lovingly recounted, especially by star Maureen O'Hara.Lots of little things about the film regularly pop up to surprise and delight all those who love the film, especially those of us who have more than an ample share of the green running through our veins.There are a number of bonus materials included as extras on the disc although there is nothing particularly significant except for an extended O'Hara interview.For those interested in learning more about  "The Quiet Man", may I suggest the fascinating, superbly researched  book "The Complete Guide to The Quiet Man" by Des MacHale (briefly seen in the documentary, hosting a bus tour of the sites) and published by The Appletree Press in Belfast. A large scale book filled with comprehensive detail on every aspect of the film including the pre-expanded version of Maurice Walsh's original story, more than 150 photos and maps, interviews and a unique minute by minute timing of all the scenes.  If you love the film, this is a must have book and well worth searching second hand bookshops or specialist cinema and Irish shops for.  Also note that MacHale is spelt McHale in the documentary.

Oscar voters were set quite a dilemma in deciding which Alexandre Desplat nominated film score should win the 2014 Academy Award.  In the end, his rollicking, enchanting score for "The Grand Budapest Hotel" won out but his other contribution for "The Imitation Game" couldn't have been far behind and would have been just as worthy as winning the accolade.This is obviously a much more serious score dealing with the complexities of Alan Turing's mathematical genius and life as a social outcast, set mainly during World War II with Turing's task of breaking the Enigma code which would be a significant event in the eventual Allies victory.Apparently Desplat  only had two and half weeks to compose this exciting score.  A truly remarkable achievement from this brilliant composer as he has successfully captured the scope of WWII and the London blitz to superbly exploring the delicate inner mind of Turing.  From the director Morten Tyldum in the liner notes: "He had to compose the music of a tender romance, but also a tense and dangerous espionage thriller. He had to write a score fit for a period piece, but that was still contemporary and unique."

Whatever the real truth behind this fascinating story dealing with Lillian Hellman and her friendship with Julia and assisting her with anti-Nazi resistance work in pre-war Germany and Austria, no one can deny the sheer storytelling power and brilliance of this superbly crafted  Fred Zinnemann, one of the truly great movies of the seventies.  As per the Mary McCarthy allegations that Hellman fabricated many of the events in this segment of her "Pentimento" memoir, the bitter rivalry between the two writers is a matter worth pursuing away from this brilliant film..Impeccable acting by Jane Fonda (Hellman), Vanessa Redgrave (Julia), Jason Robards  (Dashiell Hammett) and Maximilian Schell (Johann, the messenger) - all of whom won Oscars or critics awards for their flawless performances under the guidance of one of the truly great craftsmen of the cinema Zinnemann, directing what would be his next to last film.This is classic storytelling and masterful filmmaking from Alvin Sargent's Oscar winning screenplay with its multi faceted characters and superbly etched dramatic situations to the  stunning location photography of Douglas Slocombe, the brief but telling Georges Delerue music score and perfectly realized production design of the period (apparently Zinnemann used three different designers to create the essential look for each location).A brilliant, richly detailed and thought provoking drama.  A remarkable achievement and Lillian Hellman deserves our thanks for creating the brilliant source material and Fred Zinnemann our praise for his tasteful execution in raising our social conscience to these tragic events.

A generally interesting slice of history, current affairs, sports and trivia, this collection of ten Universal-International newsreels were produced fortnightly and cover the period from January 1951 through to June 1951.These newsreels narrated in excellent fashion, mainly by Ed Herlihy, were an important movie going experience in the days before television newscasts became the norm, thus giving the average citizen an insight (albeit selected) into world events.  The latter get well covered especially due to the Korean conflict and the general phobia of "Reds" taking over the world.  Scary scene of napalm bombs being introduced into the war, a forerunner to the nightmare known as the Vietnam war some years later.  Harry M. Truman, U.S. President of the period is featured prominently with the plain speaking statesman a natural in front of the camera, especially announcing the dismissal of General Douglas MacArthur.A few snippets of natural disasters, a terrible fire in Quebec, fashions of the day and sporting trivia (a lot of boxing and snow skiing items for some reason) make up the 71 minutes of this deserved budget release.  Perhaps better viewed in more than one sitting as the format can get a little tiresome.  Quality is more than adequate.  A fascinating look back of how studio newsreels reflected the national mood.

A mixed bag of vintage Toby Ross gay adult features in this two-disc collection. Produced in 1982-83 in the era of pre-condom sex and pre-razor men; a time when the participants looked more like they had been plucked from the street than from a week of flexing in some fashionable gym.The first film "The Diary" is the weaker of the two, suffering from being two "indoors" and lacking the casual humor and zaniness of the best Toby Ross offerings.  The sex is more than adequate and what star Jake Stryker lacks in personality (including a dull voice over), he certainly makes up for as an enthusiastic performer in the bedroom, taking on some impressive duties.  This film was lengthened for theatrical release at the time which was unfortunate as the added scene with a couple of irrelevant characters in a gym seems totally out of synch with the rest of the film."The Last Surfer" is Ross at his best.  Very much a companion piece to "Cruisin' 57" right down to fast cars, hip guys, groovy clothes and credible storyline.  This is California beach boy stuff set in the mid-60's, a carefree time about to change forever with the shadow of the Vietnam war threatening.  Lots of well done outdoor scenes to compliment the indoor action.  Boyish Jeff Folger is surely one of Toby's cutest stars and performs with relish alongside seasoned performers Michael Christopher and Daniel Halt.  The highlight of this little gem is the terrific soundtrack of hits of the day which cleverly interact with the action on the screen.This is the director's cut featuring a voice over with references to the long lost days of the sixties especially the Vietnam war, sound effects (could have done with less of those "natural" sounds during oral sex!) and some significant editing changes (especially during jockstrapped  Folger's erotic dream) from a Blue Pictures version released some years ago.Extras in this set includes lots of trailers and the charismatic Toby Ross on-screen memories on the making of the films.

An early Hammer horror and easily of the best and most successful entries from this famous British studio with its unique take on distinctly original exploitation features.Aided by the wonderfully atmospheric color photography by Jack Asher, the creative sets of Bernard Robinson and James Bernard's strident, chilling music score, this brisk 82-minute retelling of the Dracula story is a classic example of what can be achieved on a small budget, in this case less than a one hundred thousand pounds.Under the sure hand of two of the foremost talents of Hammer, director Terence Fisher and writer Jimmy Sangster, "Dracula" provides more than its share of chills, thrills and sex, earning the wrath of the British censor ("X" certificate) and blue-nosed critics, and no doubt enhancing its box-office success.A fine cast with Christopher Lee commanding as a very imposing, frightening and sexual Dracula, matched all the way by Peter Cushing's masterful performance as the meticulous Van Helsing.  This was one of twenty-two collaborations between these life-long friends.  And typical of this type of British fare, the supporting cast is universally fine and interesting with excellent performances from Melissa Stribling and John Van Eyssen.

Towards the end of the silent era, King Vidor directed this delightful, very funny satire on early Hollywood featuring Marion Davies.It's one of the tragedies of Hollywood history that Davies has been stigmatized by her association with William Randolph Hearst and somewhat parodied in "Citizen Kane" because she was an exceptionally fine comedienne as shown in this terrific film.  Her portrayal of country lass Peggy Peppy aiming to be a fine dramatic actress but finds herself an unexpected hit in slapstick comedy before becoming the vain Patricia Pepoire in "respectable high class" melodramas is first rate.  William Haines, who would later quit movies to become a distinguished interior designer is equally good as Peggy's comic and neglected partner Billy.A wonderful send-up of Hollywood in its infancy, this silent (with original music score) also boasts great cameos and walk-ons by a long list of film luminaries including Charlie Chaplin, Elinor Glyn, William S. Hart, Douglas Fairbanks, John Gilbert, Mae Murray and even Vidor and Davies playing themselves in some very funny moments.And there is a great supporting cast with  scene stealing performances by Harry Gribbon  as the "comedy director", Sidney Bracy as the "dramatic director" and Dell Henderson as Colonel Pepper.An excellent finale to his outstanding career as a director of many silent classics,  Vidor would move on to an equally distinguished career as a director of many fine "talkies".

The beautiful two-time Oscar winning music  (Best Original Score, Best Song; 1940) to Walt Disney's timeless classic "Pinocchio" has been released in many variations through the years.This current double disc not only has the complete score but some added bonuses to make this a worthy collectors item.  On the second disc are included a few selections from the film which did not make the final cut as well as a number of delightful "Jiminy Cricket" songs which were performed by the inimitable Cliff Edwards on the "Mickey Mouse Club" television show.The presentation of this new release is superb.  Packaged in an attractive small book form with 24 pages of comprehensive film and music notes, lyrics and a collection of gorgeous art work from the film, this is the ultimate edition and the sort of loving treatment that this Disney masterpiece deserves.

This British series produced in 1954-1955 by ITV  (syndicated in the U.S. in 1957) is a real curiosity piece.  Based on Carter Dickson's (John Dickson Carr) book  "The Department of Queer Complaints", Boris Karloff, in his first television series, plays Colonel Perceval Clovis Adelbart March, head of the Scotland Yard department solving strange cases.  This allows for some unusual storylines which make up these four presented in this budget Alpha release.  Unusual but nothing very distinctive except for Mr. Karloff's masterful performance - just his suave appearance, beautiful tone of voice and whimsical approach to the cases he investigates is enough to consider collecting this item.Some interesting supporting players in these episodes:  Dagmar (Dana) Wynter, Patricia Owens, Arthur Hill and would you believe, the director of such classics as "Darling", "Midnight Cowboy" and "The Day of the Locust", John Schlesinger in a small role as a Dutch ship's captain in the episode "Death and the Other Monkey" !!Be aware that this Alpha transfer to DVD is pretty bodgy.  It is quite watchable but as these episodes appeared to have been transferred from American television broadcasts of many years ago,  they are a long, long way from being anywhere near pristine.  Mind you I doubt even ITV have the originals in their vaults!  So these might be the best we will ever see of this quaint mystery program of the fifties.As a footnote, there were 26 episodes produced of "Colonel March" between December 1954 and Spring 1955 for television with three pilot episodes (credited to director Cy Endfield and writer Leo Davis) combined into a 70 minute feature "Colonel March Investigates", released in British cinemas in 1953.

The San Francisco based studio has been at the forefront of quality gay porn since its inception in 1972 and has been responsible for introducing us to many of the iconic stars of all male filmmaking.In this finely produced all-color publication, all culled from the studios advertising brochures, mainly from the '90's, we are presented with stunning solo portraits of most of Falcon's most outstanding models.  So many legends from the awesome Ken Ryker who graces the cover to other buffed, clean cut and generously endowed superbods such as Mike Branson, Tom Chase, Jeff Palmer, Kevin Williams, Giorgio Canali and Chad Knight -just to whet the appetite- are among the eighty represented here.  All very much in the renowned Falcon tradition and still very much to be fondly remembered in the years to come.

Don't dismiss this autobiography by Sophia Loren, thinking it maybe just another self indulgent exercise by a screen super star.  This is a fine memoir, beautifully constructed and written and is a wonderfully entertaining book, especially concerning post war Italian cinema.  Loren captures all the necessary elements of her amazing life and career as an actress.  Love of family is at the foremost and she benefitted enormously from the strong family of women in her life, groing up during the tumultuous times of war torn and poverty stricken Naples. .Her early career, appearing in beauty pageants, as "queen" of magazine photo-romances, as a Cinecitta extra before being "discovered" by Carlo Ponti and hitting the big-time in a series of Italian classics by maestro Vittorio de Sica  ("Gold of Naples", Oscar-winning performance in "Two Women" and with Marcello Mastroianni in "Boccaccio 70" and "Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow") and a host of international hits including "Boy on a Dolphin", "Houseboat" and "El Cid". are all nicely covered in this highly readable memoir.Nothing too scandalous or controversial and certainly no mean spirited tales of her many collaborators during a long and momentous career.  She does cover extensively her and Ponti's battles with the Italian legal system re their marriage and tax evasion, including her brief stint in an Italian prison.Lots to treasure here including wonderful reminisces of the golden age of Italian cinema with charming vignettes of de Sica, Marcello, Fellini, Toto, Scola and Wertmuller.  And of course the international set including Chaplin, Brando, Sinatra, Grant, Peck and Altman to mention a few.  And packed full of awesome family memories, making Carlo, Mammina, Maria and sons Carlo Jr. and Edoardo feel very much part of our own extended families.A gracious Sophia.  A marvellous career and a rich rewarding life, still beautiful in every degree.

The high standard of first rate gay themed dramas coming our way these days deserves to be lauded.  The Hungarian film "Land of Storms" is another fine example of a film that can be enjoyed and appreciated on many levels and provides very satisfying fare for the discerning viewer. I hesitated with my * rating as in my opinion falls between **** and ***** but I'm going for the higher as I think this film deserves a wide audience.Promising footballer Szabolcs gives his German team the flick after disagreements and returns to the Hungarian countryside for solitude and the task of rebuilding an old farmhouse he inherited from his grandfather.  Very much a loner until he encounters a local lad Aron who helps him with the rebuilding, only to find their attraction to each other transcends into a sexual relationship.  Aron is torn between caring for his disapproving sick mother and the homophobic abuse from the village boys with his ever reliant love and desire for Szabolcs.  Matters become even more complicated when old soccer buddy Bernard arrives in town to reignite his love for Szabolcs, creating a very difficult triangle for the boys.Complex characters in generally inhospitable surroundings are portrayed in a wonderfully realistic style by an excellent cast.  An absorbing story, excellently directed by Adam Csaszi from a fine script by the director and Ivan Szabo.  All technical credits are top notch, making this film an excellent, thoughtful drama.

A thoroughly entertaining read in what should be the last word on the infamous William Desmond Taylor murder in 1922 Hollywood.I was familiar with the one of the previous accounts via the Sidney Kirkpatrick version ("A Cast of Killers") which heavily relied on distinguished director King Vidor's research papers who was a living witness during these turbulent times.William Mann's account which takes in a much broader scope of the period and many, many more personalities and diversions is impressively researched and captures the film business of the time in detailed, almost epic style.  He comes up with different solutions and a different guilty party, all very convincingly, to the Kirkpatrick/Vidor version.At times I got a little put off by some of the writing and assumptions, particularly by the author's obvious dislike of Adolph Zukor and while his observations of the old Paramount tycoon may have been correct but continual references to him as "old creepy" became rather tiresome.Whilst not criticizing Mann's portrayal of early Hollywood, I wonder if any of us can really comprehend this tumultuous time in show business. Suddenly in a blink, actors, directors, producers et al, many barely speaking English, some poorly educated, were suddenly catapulted into the public spotlight and  blessed with unimaginable fame and fortune.  A nice position to be in but were these people psychologically and physically suited to cope with this rapid transition with wisdom and grace?  It makes me wonder and  I now tend to look back on those crazy times with perhaps a little more understanding than I once did.

A dangerous book!  Once you pick it up and start flicking through the pages absorbing the unlimited lists of facts and figures, you won't be able to put it down.  Love this type of book!  An invaluable compilation of statistics, some of which you may not be particularly interested in but find absolutely fascinating, and endless information regarding world history and affairs.  An indispensable reference work of 1000 pages in a lightweight, easy to access, sturdily bound trade paperwork.

Produced at J. Arthur Rank's Gainsborough Studios in 1947, this five-part children's serial is extremely well made and a lot of fun.The highlight is seeing Tony (later Anthony) Newley's  very assured and likable screen debut as Dusty Bates, a stowaway on his sailor uncle's ship who discovers a jewel smuggling racket, unbeknown to the ship's captain played by the estimable Bernard Lee.  A very young looking sixteen at the time, it is not difficult to understand why David Lean perfectly cast him as the Artful Dodger in his classic film version of "Oliver Twist" a year later.Newley gets a lot of solid support in this film with the other two featured juveniles effectively played by Billie Brook and Michael McKeag and the usual contingent of fine British character actors. Apart from the ever reliable Lee, there is the typical middle class mum of the period (Grace Arnold), Dusty's uncle (Wally Hatch) and his seafaring mate (Ronald Shiner)  and amongst the villains, Ralph Truman and John Longden.A bit thin on plot but with a thrill packed final chapter, this serial makes excellent use of location filming around the London docks and I presume the Islington Studios of Gainsborough (which was once a power station) came in handy for the warehouse scenes, etc.  Sadly Rank closed this old studio down in 1950.Thanks to Alpha Video for resurrecting this "lost" post-war children's entertainment which even us older kids can still enjoy.  The print is more than presentable;  no restoration (if that was ever possible!) or extras from this budget label.  A bargain at less than six bucks!

A novelized version of a murky chapter in U.S. naval history.  An insidious and pointless task to recruit and train sailors into a special force to lure other sailors and  particularly in this case, a Newport R.I. clergyman,  in an effort to instigate charges of perversion against their victims.Presumably a forgotten episode of gay history (it did get three lengthy paragraphs in the Randy Shilts mammoth  history of gays and lesbians in the U.S. military: "Conduct Unbecoming"), until the author chanced upon the events and we should be grateful he has enlightened us with a very readable and interesting book.Fleshing out obscure characters and mixing real-life incidents into a novel has many pitfalls but I think the author has successfully achieved his purpose.I did find it lost a bit of momentum towards the end but overall it worked pretty well and deserves wide readership as this tragic event needs to be remembered.  For once, considering the secretive and frequently unjust military treatment of this type of case, this incident did reach a reasonably happy conclusion.  Although I doubt if any of the participants ever fully recovered from the scars inflicted during these ugly and foolish times of nearly a century ago.

With the added charm of some Swiss yodelling and Gregorian chants and the persuasive use of unique instruments such as the cymbalom, balalaika and alpenhorn, Alexandre Desplat has created a rollicking, enchanting and utterly gorgeous music score to compliment Wes Anderson's latest quirky gem, "The Grand Budapest Hotel".All the tracks on this CD are universally delightful (especially the lovely "Mr. Moustafa" theme) and are a credit to the versatility and brilliance of the composer and this rich and beautifully realized score thoroughly deserved the Academy Award and overdue Oscar recognition for Desplat.A handful of the 32 selections come directly from traditional sources including the wonderful "The Linden Tree" and "Kamarinskaya" expertly performed by the Osipov State Russian Orchestra.With the loss of so many legendary composers  (Bernstein, Goldsmith, Barry, Delerue and Jarre) in recent years, many of us though the era of great film composing  was well and truly over.  Fortunately Alexandre Desplat has come along with a rich outpouring over the last decade to keep our interest in film scoring alive and well.

Wow! I was so impressed by this brilliant Dutch film I watched it twice before writing a review.  Simply a stunning coming of age story detailing the blossoming love between two high school track athletes, "Boys" deserves the highest praise.Director Mischa Kamp has superbly captured the many moods of a teenage boy coming to terms with his sexuality.  Gijs Blom is exceptional in the difficult role of Sieger, a brooding 15 year old dealing with a complex home life, stating that he is "not gay" but being overwhelmed by his feelings for Marc.  The latter, a colorful and outgoing free spirit played with remarkable sensitivity by Ko Zadvilet, who coming from a very open family, has difficulty in understanding Sieger's mixed messages about his sexuality.  The whole cast is nothing short of superb, none more than the touching performance of Jonas Smulders as Sieger's widowed father, trying to make a good home for his two sons.Everything about this film is spot on.  From the sensitive direction and intelligent, realistic screenplay to Melle Van Essen's faultless photography of the beautiful Dutch countryside and the fantastic pop music score by Rutger Reinders.Less than eighty minutes in running time but every moment of this uplifting gay romance is precious and beautifully put together.  A feel good movie for sure, but one with substance and intelligent observation.P.S.  Even the running/athletic scenes in this film look real and are entertainingly well done.

A superb collection of "film noirs", five from Universal and an equal number from Paramount and apart from the 1958 "Touch of Evil", all made in the classic and appropriately black and white era of the forties.Probably only a few outright classics ("Double Indemnity", "The Killers" and "Touch of Evil") but all wonderfully well made and intriguing from beginning to end.  Billy Wilder's "Double Indemnity", one of the all time greats and the Orson Welles more recently reconstructed and rediscovered gem "Touch of Evil" both get a single disc while the other eight films are scattered across the other four, two to a disc.  These two are the only ones with significant extras and they are substantial with "Indemnity" containing three audio commentaries and a first rate 40 minute documentary. Two separate commentaries accompany "Evil" with one featuring the stars Charlton Heston and Janet Leigh and there a couple of short "making of" featurettes.All the films in this collection are stacked with interest, fascination and excitement and they all range from better than good to excellent. They all contain the fine Hollywood craftsmanship of the time, move with style and pace and have storylines which will have you engrossed throughout.From the stunning debut and early film career of Alan Ladd (matched with the intriguing Veronica Lake) in "This Gun For Hire",  "The Glass Key" and  "The Blue Dahlia" to the powerful screen presence of Burt Lancaster in "The Killers" (an astonishing debut performance opposite Ava Gardner) and "Criss Cross", these films won't disappoint.  The two Lancaster films were directed by one of the best, if not the best, film noir directors Robert Siodmak, and he is also represented by the 1944 gem "Phantom Lady".  This was the real discovery for me: a fantastic thriller with an excellent Ella Raines and with a limited budget, just marvel at the way Siodmak has created it with such marvellous, inventive and stylish filmmaking.  And the unforgettable scene where Elisha Cook Jr. reaches an orgasmic fury during a drum solo is priceless!To round out this collection, Ray Milland does battle with a couple of newspaper tycoons (the sticky, slimy Charles Laughton and George Macready) in the complicated but fascinating "The Big Clock" with Elsa Lanchester as an eccentric painter stealing every scene she's in.  And Roy William Neill getting a break from all those Universal Sherlock Holmes programmers, with "Black Angel", beautifully made with a fine performance from Dan Duryea in one of his more sympathetic roles.An appreciation of fine filmmaking during the studio factory years with not only fine directors and actors but terrific writers (eg Raymond Chandler, W.R. Burnett, Albert Maltz, Jonathan Latimer, Anthony Veiller), outstanding cinematographers (eg John F. Seitz, Russell Metty, Franz Planer) and great music composers  (eg Miklos Rozsa, Victor Young, Henry Mancini) all in collaboration to create  top of the list movies for art and entertainment.

Although all the models featured are Caucasian, I think the title really refers to the white underwear these young dudes are displaying in this second volume of Sam Carson photos.  A nice array of simple shots of handsome "boy next door" types.  A few nudes, even a few with semi-erections but the best photos are of the lads looking tantalizingly sexy in their very white briefs, boxers and the like promoting some promising bulges just waiting to pop out of their fashionable undies from Calvin Klein, Merona and Abercrombie & Fitch.Not quite in the class of Howard Roffman, Benno Thoma or Joan Crisol but still a worthwhile addition to your library of photographed male beauties.

Always preferred this classic series to the more recent darker and large scale Batman movies.  Insanely funny and totally wacky with very original and creative concepts.  All those bright colors, crazy camera angles, campy dialog and capers  which we enjoyed on our small 1960's television screens, we can now relive and appreciate all this nutty stuff on our widescreen tvs.  A fantastic set of the complete series - all 120 episodes with loads of extras.Great cast of regulars and endless guest villains with Burgess Meredith as Penguin always being my favourite.  And let's not forget Neal Hefti"s unforgettable theme music which sets the pattern for all the hi jinks.

A wonderful collection of soundtracks composed by one of the all time greats - Henry Mancini.  You can't go wrong with this nifty collectors box containing eighteen scores, two to a disc, featuring most of Mancini's memorable film music from 1960 - 1978.  The great music speaks for itself but special praise to  Sony Music for respecting film music lovers by replicating the original soundtrack covers on each sleeve and in the 48 page booklet which comes with the set, listing all the tracks with times and even giving us quite a few bonus tracks which weren't on the original albums.  All the LP album cover notes are included (although a magnifying glass might come in handy with some of the small print!) and even a few extra pieces of poster art.For Mancini collectors who would like to go one step further, it should be noted that Intrada has recently released vastly extended and complete original soundtracks for "Breakfast at Tiffany's", "Charade" and "Hatari!".  These are essential collectors items but in no way do they diminish the importance and value for money this superb nine disc set provides.

The annual pictorial and statistical record of the movie season as compiled by John Willis brings, in volume 21, the films of 1969.  And what a great year for movies!  The output of films clearly indicated the changing times, the end of the so-called "angry decade".In my opinion the two best films were both directed by Englishmen:  John Schlesinger's outstanding "Midnight Cowboy", the first X rated film to win the Academy Award and a movie that captured the times so perfectly and with two simply great performances by Jon Voight  and Dustin Hoffman leading a fascinating cast of characters.  The other great was Lindsay Anderson's "if ...." a magnificent,  surreal portrayal of rebellion in an "upper class" British boys school with a remarkable performance by Malcolm McDowell.  Other fine films included Sam Peckinpah's revolutionary "The Wild Bunch"; Paul Newman and Robert Redford forever immortalized as "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" a film which also boasted George Roy Hill's fine achievement as director, Conrad Hall's sublime photography and Burt Bacharach's wonderful music; Sydney Pollack's powerful and gritty "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" with Jane Fonda unforgettable; Arlo Guthrie in the unique "Alice's Restaurant" directed by Arthur Penn;  a great young cast of up and comers in Frank Perry's thought provoking "Last Summer"; Maggie Smith brilliant in her first Oscar winning role as Miss Jean Brodie and John Wayne riding off into the sunset with an Oscar for "True Grit".Lots of fine directing debuts;  Dennis Hopper and the box office sensation  of alienated youth, "Easy Rider"; Paul Mazursky and the swinging "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice", Michael Ritchie with his "Downhill Racer", Bob Fosse adapting the hit stage musical "Sweet Charity" featuring an excellent Shirley MacLaine,  Alan J. Pakula's touching "The Sterile Cuckoo" with a superb Liza Minnelli, ace cinematographer Haskell Wexler's turn at directing as well with "Medium Cool" and Richard Attenborough's sadly neglected version of Joan Littlewood's monumental stage revue  of World War I which through songs and vignettes told us of the foolishness of that war in "Oh! What a Lovely War".Along with more than 1000 photographs from all the domestic and foreign releases for the year,  Mr. Willis also lists the Top Box Office Stars, Academy Awards, Promising Newcomers, Biographical Data on Film Actors and Obituaries.  The latter detailing the loss of personalities such as Judy Garland, Jeffrey Hunter, Boris Karloff, Josef von Sternberg, Thelma Ritter, Robert Taylor and Sharon Tate et al.An essential book for all film buffs.

To me, the seventies was the last great decade of filmmaking and the films produced in 1971 and catalogued in this latest volume of "Screen World" bears fruit to that claim.  A great listing of quality films from all over the world including:  Stanley Kubrick's controversial and brilliant masterpiece "A Clockwork Orange",  Bernardo Bertolucci's stylish political thriller "The Conformist" (with incredible photography by Vittorio Storaro), Peter Bogdanovich's adaptation of decaying small town America with "The Last Picture Show" boasting an ensemble cast par excellence and William Friedkin's superbly directed and acted crime thriller "The French Connection" with the fascinating duel between Popeye (Gene Hackman) and Frog One (Fernando Rey).Other notables: Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland in the edgy, suspense filled "Klute", Dustin Hoffman in Sam Peckinpah's brutal "Straw Dogs", Vanessa Redgrave and Glenda Jackson squaring off in "Mary, Queen of Scots",  Clint Eastwood's debut as a director with "Play Misty for Me",  Julie Christie and Warren Beatty heating up the frigid conditions in Robert Altman's beautifully shot "McCabe and Mrs. Miller", the first rate musical "Fiddler on the Roof" (even without Zero), George C. Scott in Paddy Chayefsky's satire "The Hospital", coming of age in "Summer of 42",  Murray Head sharing more than a kiss with both Peter Finch and Glenda Jackson in "Sunday Bloody Sunday",  Dirk Bogarde finding beauty and death in Venice and foreign-language Oscar winner "The Garden of the Finzi-Continis" featuring the stunning Dominique Sanda.All these wonderful films along with all the other domestic and foreign releases  are all featured in the latest volume by John Willis and one that all serious film buffs and collectors need to have in their library.  Plus the usual features: Top Box Office Stars, Promising Newcomers (incl. Al Pacino), Academy Award Winners, Biographical Data and Obituaries.  All very nicely collected in one compact 256 page book containing more than 1000 black and white photos.

A fine work.  Beautifully written, colorful characters, interesting and unusual setting, this new book by Denis Johnson is certain to be in the running for literary awards.  A fascinating insight into the political and social upheavals which plague many African countries and the dealings and doings of the mysterious underworld of foreign agents and mercenaries.  I must admit the story is not one of my favourite themes and had me rather confused at times but I admire the author for producing a fine work of literature.

John Willis has assembled another great pictorial and statistical collection, this time for the year 1972.  With a listing of all domestic and foreign-language films released and supplemental items such as Top Box Office Stars, Promising New Actors, Academy Award Winners, Biographical Data of Film Actors and Obituaries, this 254 page volume with more than 1000 great photographs is a treasure trove of information for film buffs.Any year that boasts films of the stature of the superlative Francis Ford Coppola opus "The Godfather" and Bob Fosse's stunning musical drama "Cabaret" is certainly worth celebrating.  Lots of other fine movies including a few from "old masters": Luis Bunuel's sublime "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie", Ingmar Bergman's stunning "Cries and Whispers", Alfred Hitchcock's return to his home soil with the suspense thriller "Frenzy".  Other notable achievements included  John Boorman's exceptional "Deliverance" (making a hit out of  "Duelling Banjos"),  Martin Ritt's touching "Sounder" with Cicely Tyson, Laurence Olivier and Michael Caine in a fascinating tour de force which was also the final film in the illustrious career of Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Jacques Tati's "Traffic", the first pairing of Woody Allen and Diane Keaton ("Play it Again, Sam"), Martin Scorsese making an impression with "Boxcar Bertha" for the Roger Corman stable.Just a sampling of what waits in this edition of the long running series.

I must have been one of the few people who saw and enjoyed this "Hitchcockian" thriller back in 1979.  Don't know why this film didn't find an audience; some have said a poor marketing campaign and a trailer that gave the plot away as reasons.  Co-producer Michael Taylor in a very interesting on-camera interview for this DVD release denies this and like many a good film, it  just didn't click for some unknown reason.This is a very good suspense thriller, excellently directed by Jonathan Demme (twelve years later he would win Best Picture and Director Oscars for "The Silence of the Lambs")  and boasting strong performances from Roy Scheider and Janet Margolin.  Exciting and fast paced with an unusual plotline and featuring some superb location photography by Tak Fujimoto, this is a very enjoyable film. Loved the shots on a Connecticut railway station and the conclusion at Niagara Falls is breathtaking.  All this is played out with the assistance of another thrilling, pulsating music score by Miklos Rozsa.  It's very "Rozsa" - isn't that enough to excite you to another level of appreciation?The obvious references to Hitchcock are all there; Demme was not the first young director to pay homage to the "master".  Nods to classics like "Vertigo" and "North By Northwest" and even a Demme cameo.  Maybe there are others: "The Birds", "Marnie" to mention a couple that crossed my mind.

Except for the first three episodes of season five, this would be the last complete  season of the magical pairing of  Karl Malden and Michael Douglas and their crime solving adventures on the streets and environs of  San  Francisco.  A great show with three unsurpassed stars.  Quality  Quinn  Martin production values, always a fine batch of guest stars and excellent storylines.  Sadly missed when the show left the air waves after five seasons  (and many reruns on my local network ) but deep in my memories, now great to have the  DVDs to treasure and recall the golden years of  San  Francisco of the seventies.

This Harold Robbins potboiler which one book critic in the NY Times claimed " ...should have been inscribed on the walls of a public lavatory" was a massive best seller and when filmed by Joseph E. Levine and Paramount Pictures in 1964, despite generally negative reviews was a smash hit.  Obviously based on Howard Hughes, Jonas Cord Jr. is a young millionaire industrialist and movie mogul in the early days of Hollywood fighting with his inner demons, the ups and downs of power and the many women in his life.  The film, directed by Edward Dmytryk, starred George Peppard, Alan Ladd (in his last film role playing an ageing cowboy star and Cord's surrogate father, Nevada Smith), Carroll Baker (in a Jean Harlow role), Robert Cummings, Elizabeth Ashley, Martha Hyer,  Lew Ayres and Martin Balsam.The best part of the film and the most highly praised would be Elmer Bernstein's lush and exciting score, produced during one of the musician's most prolific and rich periods.  Dominated by his main theme for Jonas Cord and using many variations, all the main character's drive and ambition, sublime arrogance and carefree manner are all perfectly portrayed by the music.  Also  major highlights are the tender love theme for Jonas and Monica (Ashley) and Bernstein's use of "demented  piano figures to conjure the specter of madness, adding a disturbing singsong theme in airy high registers" in exploring Cord's fear of insanity.  Bernstein also includes some dance tunes in the spirit of the times and even some of his own western music to underscore Nevada Smith's films.With this special edition, Intrada gained access to the original soundtrack scoring sessions  and on this CD, they make their world premiere with a timing of 52:33. Plus we get the original re-recorded album that Bernstein produced for his Ava label. Also included is a 20-page booklet loaded with photos (even with an alternate cover) and informative notes on the film and music by John Takis (which this reviewer took some liberty with). All in all, a very special release with more than 78 minutes of great Elmer Bernstein  music from the golden sixties.

Entertaining, well made and very original gay themed comedy.  Credit to director Tom  Gustafson and his co-writer Cory  James  Krueckeberg and a fine cast for creating a very funny, at times thought provoking film which never loses its focus with a plot that never becomes too silly to not thoroughly enjoy.

For fans of film music and especially for admirers of the film scores of Maurice Jarre, this DVD/CD combination is a must. As the title announces, this is a concert tribute to the great director David Lean for whom Jarre composed some of his most memorable scores.  Featured are his selections from his Academy Award winning compositions: "Lawrence of Arabia", "Doctor Zhivago" and "A Passage to India" as well the underrated "Ryan's Daughter".  All wonderful listening experiences which you can hear separately on the CD disc or watch on the DVD with Jarre conducting the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London with the added bonus of the music being complimented by the actual film images and of Lean directing scenes. The warm admiration that Jarre has for Lean is obvious and refreshing to find two great talents on the same page. You can also watch the DVD concert with interesting and revealing comments by Jarre (in French with sub-titles) about the concert, working with Lean and the creation of film music.  An added extra is a terrific 35 minute interview conducted by Christian Lauliac in which M. Jarre discusses (in French) his long film career with insights into such personalities as Sam Spiegel, John Huston and Peter Weir as well as Lean.  Interesting to know that Spiegel chose the virtually unknown (ie outside of his native France) Jarre to score "Lawrence" on the basis of his ten-minute score for "Sundays and Cybele" and the complex issue over the conducting of the score due to British government funding.  Fascinating and rewarding and even by some weird chance you don't love his music, you'll certainly be won over by M. Jarre's candid charm.

All through my youth and beyond I was fascinated by the image of Peter Berlin or to be more honest, the sight of him in his always skin tight pants. Thanks to this insightful documentary, I have at last learned more about him and his career as one of the gay world's most outrageous exhibitionists. Still remarkably youthful and fit looking for someone of 70, Peter comes across as a pretty regular sort of guy who has lived a very full and satisfying life.  He apparently lived the life he wanted to as a first rate photographer (mainly of himself), mixing in arty circles in Europe and America, making a few early porn movies (with his partner Robert W. Richards, his relationship with the troubled Richards poignantly remembered by Peter) and now living modestly but with a fascinating lifetime of memories to cherish.Berlin hit his peak in the 1970s taking advantage of the new freedoms of gay sexual liberation. That incredible mop of blond hair, muscular body and sexual prowess always on display made Peter one of the most iconic figures of the gay lifestyle.  And unlike many other exhibitionists, he had the goods worth displaying whether in his tight jeans, thong, see-through tights and shorts, leather or sailor suits, most of which he designed himself. Fans of the Peter Berlin look should try and hunt down a book of his photographs. The one I have is "The Peter Berlin Collection", a 1990 book published in Berlin, Germany by  Janssen-Verlag.

The Royal Shakespeare Company's marathon production "The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby" was the big hit of the Broadway season, winning the New York Drama Critics Circle Award and the Tony for Best Play.  Each performance of this epic adaptation of the Charles Dickens classic ran for eight and a half hours in two parts with a one hour break.  Other highlights included the award winning musicals "Nine" and "Dreamgirls".  Charles Fuller's "A Soldier's Play" was the big event Off-Broadway, winning the Pulitzer Prize and the NY Critics Circle Award (for Best American Play). The latter had a cast including Adolph Caesar, Denzel Washington and Samuel L. Jackson.Amanda Plummer was featured in two hit plays "A Taste of Honey" and "Agnes of God", winning a Tony for the latter.  Some other notable plays were Beth Henley's "Crimes of the Heart" and Ronald Harwood's "The Dresser".All of the above are chronicled in the latest Theatre World, a superb compact record of not only the Broadway and Off Broadway season  but also providing an extensive coverage of national touring and professional regional companies throughout the United States. Plus the usual listings including Theatre World awards, biographical data and obituaries, all neatly compiled in this 255 page volume, boasting more than 500 photographs.

Another excellent chronicle of the theater year 1987-1988.  With some 500 well chosen photographs and a comprehensive listing of cast and credits for just about everything related to the American theater year, this treasured annual publishing event is the essential work for both the historian and the fan.  It should be noted that the actual Broadway coverage is relatively small compared to the extensive and fascinating listing of all the shows appearing Off-Broadway and in the various touring and regional companies.Bernadette Peters and the cast from "Into the Woods" grace the cover of this edition.  Among the other highlights of the season include the multi award winners: "Phantom of the Opera", 'M. Butterfly" (winner of the Tony for Best Play, Actor and Director), "Burn This" with John Malcovich and Tony-winning Joan Allen, "Macbeth" starring Christopher Plummer and Glenda Jackson.  The Off-Broadway "Driving With Miss Daisy" won the Pulitzer and the Cole Porter musical "Anything Goes" scored the Tony as Best Revival.All the usual invaluable sections are in this volume including Theatre World awards, biographical data and obituaries. The latter listed a heavy loss of talent including such icons as Geraldine Page, Bob Fosse and Michael Bennett.The Broadway year hit an all-time record in boxoffice sales, increased attendance and more playing weeks indicating that the New York theater scene promises to be robust for many years to come.

Reason for all to celebrate this publishing event: the 50th. anniversary edition of Theatre World.  To celebrate, John Willis and his crew have added a ten page photographic tribute to many of the momentous shows from 1944 through 1994.In this volume all the usual features we have come to love are all here: complete Broadway and Off-Broadway coverage plus touring and regional companies, Theatre World winners, biographical data and obituaries. The latter sadly reflects the devastating toll of AIDS on the theatre industry.Some of the outstanding Broadway productions included: Tony Kushner's "Angels in America :Perestroika" (Ron Leibman), "No Man's Land" with Jason Robards and Christopher Plummer, "Damn Yankees" (cover photo, with Victor Garber and Bebe Neuwirth), "An Inspector Calls" starring Rosemary Harris and Philip Bosco, "Beauty and the Beast", "Carousel", "Medea" with Diana Rigg, "Passion" (Donna Murphy), "Grease" and Nathan Lane in Neil Simon's "Laughter on the 23rd.
