Floor".As well as the extensive statistical listing of the all the shows, there are approximately 1000 excellent photographs to compliment this volume.

A selection of seven segments of "Life in Hollywood" which were shown in cinemas in 1927.  Nothing very exciting or illuminating but for people interested in the sights (no sound as these were silent films) of early Hollywood there is enough material here to entertain and amuse.  Amazing to see how many studios were operating at this time although most views appear to be from across the street or over the back fence. There are some inside shots of Universal City, Warner Bros., M-G-M and glimpses of such obscurities from the past such as  Christie Comedy Studios, Metropolitan, Educational Comedies and Pickford-Fairbanks.Lots of stars and directors on show although most studio scenes appear to be staged for the camera; obviously the attempt at keeping the mystique of Hollywood at the forefront for the audience was paramount in these short subjects.As you would expect from such an obscure collection, the picture quality is not great but more than watchable and the music soundtrack provided although a bit monotonous is in keeping with the sounds of the twenties. Thanks to the Alpha people for digging up this old curiosity piece.

You just have to love this collection of ten Universal-International sci-fi thrillers, mostly made in the fifties.  The films are no classics although the Jack Arnold directed  "The Incredible Shrinking Man" and "Tarantula" come close and most of the others are very entertaining and full of merit.  Like most films produced at Universal in the fifties, lots of fun, thrills and campiness.  A fine packaging job  with the films spread neatly over six discs along with some  groovy art work to compliment the plastic see-through box.

Another fabulous edition of the renowned Theatre World annuals.  An indispensable guide and history of the Broadway and Off-Broadway season for 1986-1987, highlighted by more than 500 superb photographs. The big critical hit of the year was August Wilson's triple Best Play winner "Fences" starring James Earl Jones, also the cover photo for this years edition.  Other hits included "Les Miserables", "Me and My Girl", "Starlight Express", "Arsenic and Old Lace" (with Jean Stapleton), "Cuba and His Teddy Bear" (Robert De Niro), "The Front Page" (Richard Thomas) and "A Month of Sundays" with Jason Robards.As always an extensive Off-Broadway coverage highlighted by such shows as "Safe Sex" with Harvey Fierstein, "The Widow Claire" (Matthew Broderick} and Colleen Dewhurst in "My Gene".Plus coverage of National Touring and Professional Regional Companies, Theatre World Award winners, biographical data and obituaries.

An absolute must for theatre goers and/or theatre historians.  Carrying on in the tradition of its founder Daniel Blum, John Willis has assembled the "complete pictorial and statistical record" of the 1973-1974 Broadway and Off-Broadway season with more than 750 priceless photos. However the editor wasn't particularly upbeat about the Broadway season quoting high costs and meagre profits.  Sound familiar? The big shows and performers of the year included: "Moon for the Misbegotten" (Jason Robards & Colleen Dewhurst), "Uncle Vanya" (George C. Scott & Julie Christie), Carol Channing in "Lorelei", the Andrews Sisters in "Over Here!", "Raisin", "Candide", Zero Mostel in "Ulysses in Nightown",  Liza Minnelli's one-woman show; plus the usual long runs and revivals.Plus one hundred pages devoted to Off Broadway; another hundred set aside for  Shakespeare Festivals,  Theatre World Awards, biographies and obituaries.

I was very young when Stanley Kramer came to town to shoot his adaptation of local writer Nevil Shute's controversial best seller "On The Beach".  I think this was the first big American production ever filmed in Melbourne and it's an extra bonus for a Melbourne native to look back after fifty-five years to see what the old city looked like - a very quiet sort of sleepy hollow  to what it is now, a massive metropolis bursting at the seams!  Ava Gardner made many disparaging comments about the Melbourne of 1959, much to the chagrin of Kramer, but she would be quite surprised if she saw the place now."On the Beach" was the second of four unforgettable masterpieces (and political statements) that Stanley Kramer made during the period of 1958-1961; the others being "The Defiant Ones", "Inherit the Wind" and "Judgment at Nuremberg".  The thought of nuclear warfare and possible annihilation were very real concerns for most of us around this time and will probably not have the same impact on younger audiences today.The film itself is first class drama with an excellent ensemble cast.  Gregory Peck, one of the most likable actors ever to star on the silver screen is his usual stoic self.  Ava Gardner is very good and believable as the vulnerable Moira (personally I think she  steals the film).  Fred Astaire fine in one of his best non-musical roles and Anthony Perkins and Donna Anderson are exceptional as the doomed young couple.  And they all succeed pretty well with their Australian accents and thanks to Kramer, they don't sound like Aussie caricatures.  And the local talent is well represented by John Tate and Lola Brooks, both delightful, as Admiral Bridie and his loyal Lt. Hosgood respectively.One of the highlights of course is the use of the Australian folk song "Waltzing Matilda" which is heavily used and very effective.  According to the film's composer Ernest Gold who loathed the melody, it was at the insistence of Kramer that it be used throughout the movie.  Gold considered its use as a challenge: "I said I'm going to call upon all my skills as a composer by variation, reharmonization, development, every musical device that I was aware of, to use that as a bit of thematic material and confine it essentially to say 'Australia'."  Suffice to say that along with all his original music, this score won an Academy Award nomination for Mr. Gold. (The soundtrack, coupled with Gold's bouncy, Italian flavoured "The Secret of Santa Vittoria" is available on the Film Score label: FSM Vol.5 No.7. Highly recommended.)

I donâ€™t know who came up with the idea that basic health requires eight hours of sleep. The only time I slept that many hours in recent years I was recovering from surgery in a hospital and taking prescription opiates. But on a recent morning, after using Sound+Sleep Mini, I woke up and realized Iâ€™d been asleep for over ten hours. I was so surprised I wanted to get on the phone and call everybody I know.I confess to being chronically suspicious of gadgets that promise to improve my life. Iâ€™d heard of machines that create white noise or reproduce sounds from nature â€” ocean waves lapping at the shore, birds twittering, logs fireplaces crackling in a fireplace â€” all promising ideal sleep. I thought it was just some sort of aural placebo until I started using Adaptive Sound Technologyâ€™s Sound+Sleep Mini.This little device doesnâ€™t give me sound sleep every night. I havenâ€™t duplicated that 10-plus hour snooze since that first episode, but I canâ€™t dispute the fact that I am indeed sleeping more hours and more soundly than previously.Thereâ€™s really no hocus-pocus about the experience. Sound machines have been around at least since the 1960â€™s. Many families use them to lull babies to sleep by masking intrusive sounds like vehicle traffic or noisy neighbors.An article in the New York Times stated: Used correctly, these gadgets could change your life â€” you might finally get a reprieve from your snoring spouse, or vice versa; you might finally get your baby to sleep (so you can spend more time with your snoring spouse), or you might finally drown out those unashamedly loud neighbors.The Sound+Sleep Mini is different from the other devices in at least two respects.It includes ASTâ€™s proprietary listening technology that can monitor the sounds in your environment and adapt the volume of the sounds coming from the device automatically. If your bedmate is snoring, it will detect that and increase the volume of whatever sound youâ€™ve selected.Fortunately, this is only an option. I turned it off because it was intrusive. Its monitoring was so sensitive that the volume would increase at the slightest change, even sliding my alarm clock across my nightstand. But I can see how this feature will be useful if the user lives in a noisy place where barking dogs, heavy traffic, and subway trains are be a factor.The second feature, which I found to be nique, is what the company calls SoundStories. Each sound the Mini produces can be modified with the press of a button so that you end up with as many as 48 combinations of sounds. For example, if you press the button to select the ocean, youâ€™ll at first only hear only waves. Press it again and you can add seagulls, fog horns, sea lions, and more. If you select rain, you can get a drizzle or a downpour.Regardless of which sound you select, you can increase or decrease the volume to suit your comfort level.Negri noise 2The unit includes the various whirring fan sounds that made ASTâ€™s LectroFan very popular. The fan sounds, which I prefer, can be changed from a deep turbine-like sound to a small desk fan.AST says the sounds it produces do not loop. They continuously change very subtly so that they donâ€™t become monotonous. The unit also comes with a timer that allows you to leave the sound on continuously or set to stop in 30 minute increments. I usually leave mine on all night except when Iâ€™m using the rain sound. Thirty to sixty minutes of rain is enough to put me to sleep.That reminds me of a caveat you should keep in mind: If your bladder is waking you up two or three times a night, a sound machine isnâ€™t going to enable you to sleep through those natural events. Just as well, wouldnâ€™t you say?Mini also has an audio input so if you want to listen to music instead of its sounds you can use the provided 5â€™ audio cable to connect an iPod, cellphone or other device and just use the Mini as a speaker. Audio performance is very good for music and voice playback, adding value and versatility to this special-purpose product.The Sound+Sleep Mini is a quality device that is small enough to take on trips so you can use it in a hotel room.Highly recommended. Time for a long nap!MyMac Review Rating is 9 out of 10.

You had one job, DeLonghi Safe Fan Heater. HEAT the room up. You failed.I really wanted to like you. The bathroom gets chilly in the winter, and we have already had a few cold days. Perfect to give you a test run. I like that you oscillate, that you have a timer, and that you have a safety plug for those "just in case I fall into a bathtub full of water while you are in it playing with your rubber duck" moments. But first and foremost, above all else, you need to actually WARM a room.Nope. Only ever blows luke-warm air.Don't buy this, or wait until the product is renamed "DeLonghi America HVF3555TB Bathroom Safe Fan Luke-Warm Air Blower". Otherwise, skip it.

This light is really cool! It helps to read the manual. but even if you don't, you will love this. I thought this would make a killer addition to my game room, and it does. Run music through the system, and the lights are in tune with the music. Neat! My kids also love to use it as a night-light, even though it actually lights up the entire room. There is an annoying buzz to it, but you don't hear it at all if music is playing. I find it very relaxing and almost meditative on it's own. Great product!

Fantastic story and writing. Of course, I expected as much from T.R. Harris. LOVE the sly nods to characters in his other books, but no spoilers here!By this book. It's just fantastic. And sadly, could be a primer for things to come...

Maybe the best thing about this watch is the fact that it's not really a watch at all. It's a small tire on your wrist, and I think it gives me superpowers. Why? Well, wearing this super large and heavy watch seems to block the fear in me, so that even when (okay, if) I am confronted with a mugger, I'm pretty sure my Swiss Legend watch will act as a Captain America shield. I'm pretty sure it can deflect a knife strike as well as any bullets fired at me. If I do ward off the attacker, and he/she starts to run, either throwing this watch at them will knock them out, or dropping it to the ground will cause them to loose their balance when the ground shakes.Besides its offensive and defensive capabilities, it also does a great job of telling time.

Growing up I missed the whole Transformers thing. But my son, on the other hand, really likes them. So having the opportunity to review this product was great. That's about all the greatness there was.It's really cheap. I have purchased not a few Transformers over the years for him, and while some are complex to actually transform, they were never cheap dollar store quality toys. This one is. Which is sad, because it's a HUGE toy, but it feels like it will break quickly. Once you transform it into a car, it does not even align correctly, something my seven year old thought was pretty lame.Come on, if you're going to charge $50 for a toy, it had better be WORTH $50. Drop that zero, make it $5, and it would be worth it.

The last "new" iron I have owned was twenty years ago. I thought it did a good job. Until, that is, I got the chance to use the D3040 from Black & Decker. I really didn't understand that the technology of an iron had really improved in, well, fifty years. But it has, and boy is this a great iron!I like the digital settings, and there is a ton of steam when you use it. It is easy to use, glides VERY well, and works VERY fast. It takes me half the time to iron my shirts than my old iron.You will like it!

I really like this watch. It is classy, feels durable, and is pretty easy to see the dials. The wrist band is great, and is very secure. I do wish it had a light, as you can't see it in the dark at all. It is also difficult to adjust the band, and of course there is no instructions in the box on how to do it. Trial and error. All that negative said, I do like this watch, and I have been wearing it instead of any other for a while.

This Lucien Piccard is a nice watch. Rose Gold seems to be the new Black, and my wife really likes the color. It's not too pink at all, and looks very good on her wrist. She also says the watch is comfortable to wear.One big problem: the instructions do not explain how to adjust the band. It was WAY too large for my wife's wrist, and for two days we could not figure out how to adjust it. It took hours of internet searching until we found a video of this model that actually showed how to adjust the hand correctly. Come on, Lucien Piccard, if someone is going to spend this much money on a watch, at least provide the tools needed to make sure people can actually wear and adjust it. Lazy.

These are SO good. My wife likes the Dark Chocolate type better, while I am all in for the Milk Chocolate. These, IMO, taste even better when allowed to be warmed up, like from being in your pocket, for a half hour. Otherwise they are a little hard-ish. Not HARD, but... well, they are just better this side of starting to melt. The caramel is very good, silky, with a full flavor. These are quickly becoming a favorite. My wife will soon hide this tin from me, I'm sure...

First, the good. This watch looks amazing, has a nice feel on your wrist, and the band if comfortable.Now the bad:Really? They used microscopic sized clock hands that is almost impossible to see. A watch can have multiple functions, but first and foremost, it's a WATCH TO TELL TIME! They made this watch so you can't TELL THE TIME! Stupid...Next, the band. There is no instructions on how to use this band. It look me fifteen minutes to figure it out. Stupid design.Lastly, when using this watch, I CAN'T TELL WHAT TIME IT IS! What more do you need to know to avoid wasting your money on this dumb product. Waste of a good design by some idiot who wen form over function.

The kids love it. Looks, it's October, the time of year here in Michigan when the weather goes from hot to cold. It was downright chilly last night, as an example, and my wife and I have not taken down the trampoline. That means my seven year old son was out there jumping on it (learning a lot of new tricks!) and when he came in, he felt very cold to me. We heated up some water in the microwave, put the Nestle Hot Cocoa Mix in, and warmed him up in minutes. Everyone loves the taste, the packaging is easy to tear to open, and with such a big box, you won't run out anytime soon. Easy to get the packages out. All in all, good stuff for cold days, and kids and adults love it! It's an American tradition!

I have a carpet cleaner we used once every few months. I usually just get the cleaner that is on sale when I run out. This is the first time using the Oxy Pro brand, and I have to say, i am impressed. First, it has a nice, clean smell. Sure, it's suppose to, it's a cleaner, right? Well, many other brands I have used in the past has more of a chemical smell, like you would smell in a hospital or hotel. Not pleasant, but gets the job done. The Oxy Pro also gets the job done, and it smells nice and clean.Speaking of getting the job done, the Oxy Pro does a fantastic job. I had a spot that had not come up with two other cleaners, but did this last go-round, and the only difference was using the Oxy Pro. And really, at the end of the day, isn't that what a carpet cleaner is suppose to do?

I really appreciate the AmazonBasics line, and for the Apple Lightning to USB cable, I can honestly say it works great. I have tried a few other, cheaper brands that do not support the "Apple Certified" logo, and  while some worked, many others did not. The iPhone would pop up a dialog saying something was not supported. Yeah, it's not just a cable, it has to be a GOOD cable to work. This cable does work, and works well. It is well constructed, does not feel like it will fry easily, and feels a little thicker than a standard Apple cable. Well worth your time and money

This multi-cooker works well, but (a) it is not as large as I thought it was and (b) HOT HOT HOT. This cooker gets VERY hot in operation. Like, almost too hot to touch. Still, I do rate this high because even with those two flaws, the cooker works very well. It is more complex than either my rice cooker or my much larger slow cooker, and I did need to read the instruction manual. I'm glad I did, it really helped in operating the unit.Cleaning is pretty simple. Cooking was great, and I found a few receipts to cook online in the cooker. Worked like a charm!I did steam some veggies, and that was fantastic. Very quick and easy to steam using this cooker.All in all, a well made cooker that you do want to read the manual, and don't touch the sides when it is cooking. It gets too hot. But for the price, I like it a lot!

When iPads first came out the thought of our kids grabbing our iPads and dropping them, such an expensive piece of electronics, left us in fear. However, as the iPad has evolved, their use in schools and at home has become generally accepted. Still, we are talking about an expensive piece of hardware, and no matter how well intentioned, or careful our kids try to be, accidents do happen.Kensington has designed the SafeGrip case for kids with just this situation in mind.The SafeGrip is made of a thick foam-like material that covers the entire iPad, except the screen and a square window in the back. This square cut out can be used to personalize the unit in multi-unit environments. It does come with a screen protector as well. â€œDesigned for kidsâ€ means a big, thick, handle to prevent drops (doubles as a stand), easily cleans up with soap and water, and even has a slot for a stylus.Since my kids are all grown up, I asked a co-worker, Marc Pessotti, who has two young children, if he wouldnâ€™t mind taking the SafeGrip out for a spin.Marc writes:The Kensington SafeGrip Case for the iPad Air 2 definitely exceeded my expectations. The case is made of a light weight foam that makes it easy to hold and did not slip off any surface I laid it down on. The case holds my iPad Air 2 firmly and the edges are well protected. The case also comes with a screen protector and visual step by step instructions to install it.I have had cases made from similar material for my iPhone 5 and those cases did not hold up well after a couple months of use. The light weight foam material began to stretch and become deformed, blocking the ports on my iPhone. With the SafeGrip Case this did not happen, and the case is still functioning well after a couple of months of use.This case is much thicker than your typical hard plastic cases and I was concerned about port accessibility. As it turns out, I was surprised and impressed with how easy it was to access  everything from the volume buttons to the headphone plug.TypeThe handle also acts as a stand for the iPad and is definitely useful, but not the most sturdy of stands. If the surface is not flat and solid, you wonâ€™t have much luck keeping the iPad upright. Being used by my 5 year old daughter, the case did get a bit dirty at times. Also, the case is easy to write on with markers and pens, but a damp cloth with just water will remove most things, including ink, fairly easy.StandThis case has held up well for over 2 months, but I am still skeptical of it lasting much more than 6 months. With all things said, I give this an 8 out of 10.The Kensington SafeGrip is available at Amazon and directly from the good folks at Kensington.MyMac Review Rating: 8 out of 10

Five colors are available. Free company shipping is offered in the 48 contiguous United StatesThis versatile external drive should be offered along with every iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch. The Seagate Wireless is an attractive, affordable, full-service external storage device that adds enormous capacity to the limited storage on portable iOS gear.Seagate WirelssThis colorful product has an unusual squarish shape with rounded edges, and a slightly-raised bottom area that facilitates hand-holding. Add content to it, including MacOS folders (hooray!), using the included USB2 cable, as you do with all external drives.foldersCharge Seagate Wirelessâ€™s internal 6-hour battery via the cable and any standard powered USB port. Connect the drive wirelessly to any Wi-Fi network via the free SeagateMedia iOS app.interfaceYou will be spending a load of time becoming comfortable with and then using this unusual custom app. It wonâ€™t win any iOS design awards, but it works perfectly, and it includes a comprehensive User Guide available in a zillion different languages.user manuallanguagesGive yourself up to an hour the first time you set up and grab content from your Seagate Wireless (this is its full name). Eventually you will be able to navigate the app and enjoy your movies, photos, music, and other items stored on this little wonder. Study the user guide and contact company support for additional assistance.networkNothing happens at warp speed; Wi-Fi service both to the drive and passing through to your wireless network takes a few minutes to connect. Ditto for streaming of your media. Itâ€™s all worthwhile, especially when your iOS device is nearly full and you can enjoy a giant movie file, including AirPlay to an Apple TV! (Additional streaming products also are compatible; I did not test any of them.)Up to three different devices can connect wirelessly to this innovative drive at the same time even when no Internet service is available, via the driveâ€™s built-in Wi-Fi network. Automatic iOS Camera Roll uploads can be configured for effortless backups of your precious photos.Donâ€™t confuse this 500GB product with the Seagate Wireless Plus, reviewed two years ago by Curt Blanchard here at MyMac. The Plus is available in three capacities, uses a different cable, has a generic appearance, and is more expensive for the same quantity of storage. Its app interface and operation are identical.Once you are up and running, the new Seagate Wireless is your constant companion whenever the built-in capacity on your iOS equipment is insufficient for your personal, work, academic, and other purposes.MyMac Review Rating is 9 out of 10.

I usually feel like Iâ€™m all thumbs when drawing on my iPad with a stylus. The tips are either soft and mushy or made of odd materials such as wire, hinged plastic, rubber, or even bristles. None are accurate enough for me. The new Stilo fine-tip stylus addresses these shortcomings.black-stilo-womanThe Stilo is 5-1/2 inches (14cm) long and is 1/2 inch (12.7mm) in diameter. The distinguishing feature of this pen is its firm, remarkably fine, 1.9mm tip. If youâ€™ve been frustrated with a blunt, rubbery-tipped stylus, youâ€™ll be impressed with the Stiloâ€™s fine, responsive tip. The drawing below is one-inch wide in the corner of an iPad Mini screen. You canâ€™t do that with a big, blunt stylus.TeenieStilo is powered by a single replaceable AAA battery that provides up to ten hours of continuous use. Insert the battery, turn it on and youâ€™re in business. A tiny LED indicates power. No pairing, no Bluetooth, just grab and go. The pen shuts itself off if it is unused for ten minutes. It has a small protective cap for the tip and is available in both a black and a white version.05_Stilo_hor_3000_bw_shadowThe Stilo pen works with almost all capacitive touch screens and will work with most screen protectors, even glass ones. The tip can be rotated to increase or decrease its sensitivity. Some screen protectors may require extra sensitivity and the pen can be adjusted to accommodate that.MaterA small whine: Creatives often complain about writing or drawing tools that are cylindrical. These tend to roll around your work surface and can even roll off your desk. If the battery cap on the top of the Stilo was hexagonal, the pen wouldnâ€™t roll away. It would also make the cap easier to unscrew when replacing the battery. Many writing instruments have pocket clips on them. They are almost never used for their intended purpose, the clips are there because they keep the pen from rolling.Stilo also makes a Precision Film for iPads (4th Gen, Air, Air 2, Mini 2 and 3) as well as for Samsung Galaxies and the Nexus 6 or 9.  All sizes are $19.99. The slightly grippy, plastic film surface provides friction that simulates the feel of pen or pencil on paper. Glass is slick and unforgiving, but I prefer it to an overlay of film. When using my fingers for gestures without the stylus, the plasticky surface of the film doesnâ€™t feel right to me. This is entirely a personal preference. If you are already accustomed to screen protectors, this may not be a concern.The Stilo is a well-made stylus whose specialty is accuracy. It is not pressure-sensitive. Youâ€™ll enjoy taking detailed notes and sketching small diagrams with this stylusâ€™ fine tip. Drawing is satisfying fun because of its responsiveness and near-zero latency.MyMac Review rating for the Stilo pen is 9 out of 10.Due to my personal preferences, I can only rate the Precision Film 7 out of 10.

Home automation and the Internet of Things arenâ€™t just pie-in-the-sky concepts any more. Theyâ€™re beginning to happen. iHomeâ€™s new iSP5 SmartPlug lets you control an electrical outlet in your home wherever you are with your iPhone. Itâ€™s also compatible with Appleâ€™s HomeKit so Siri will respond to your voice commands.Smart appliances such as thermostats, exterior door locks, and garage door openers can already be controlled by smartphones but these devices are expensive and often require professional installation. By comparison, the SmartPlug is a simple, inexpensive plug-and-play device. It connects wirelessly to your home Wi-Fi and is controlled with the iHome Control app (iOS and Android). Open the app and a single tap turns the power on or off.InHandEach SmartPlug comes with its own unique accessory code so you can have several of the devices around your home and control each individually. Because SmartPlugs are iOS compatible, you can set timers for each if desired. They can handle up to 1800 watts so larger appliances such as a window air conditioner, fan, or space heater can be controlled. Imagine the Jetson-style convenience of turning on your room air conditioner when you leave your office so your home will be comfortable when you arrive.TwoScreensIf you have several SmartPlugs installed, you can create and control Scenes. Set a Party scene where the lights go on and the music starts. Set a Prime Time scene where the TV turns on and several lights turn off. There are many flexible possibilities that are easy to set up. If you choose, you can also control zones of your house: Living room, Bedroom, Office, etc. When you are traveling, you can set lights to go on and off at times you preselect or you can do the same live from your phone.The iHome Control app allows you to add more SmartPlugs at any time. You can also add new users so both you and your spouse can control your home units. You can even set up your office so that only you can control the lighting and equipment there. The SmartPlug is designed so that two will fit, one above the other, in a standard electrical outlet.WallPlugEventually, most home automation devices will be able to communicate with each other as well as with you. Weâ€™re on the cusp of some very exciting Internet of Things technology. For now, itâ€™s fun to experiment with living in the future. iHomeâ€™s SmartPlug is an inexpensive, well-designed part of the first wave. Fair warning: SmartPlugs are addictive. Youâ€™ll want more than one.MyMac Review rating is an enthusiastic 10 out of 10.

Sibelius 8Perpetual license: $599Annual subscription (new users): $239Upgrade from all previous versions (1 to 7.5) of Sibelius, including one yearâ€™s upgrades: $89 per annumSwitch from Finale, Notion, Encore, Mosaic: $199Full licensing detailsJean Sibelius, the 150th anniversary of whose birth we celebrate this year (he lived from 1865 to 1957), officially composed only seven symphonies. Certainly only seven were published. Yet fragments of an 8th do exist; and indeed were performed in 2011â€¦ barely three minutes long, though. Sibelius certainly withdrew and tried to suppress his 8th.So Avid, who have owned the iconic score-writing software, Sibelius, since 2006, were faced with a something of a quandary when naming the latest release, which followed less than a year and a half after Version 7.5. Particularly with regard to since the short musical extract which plays over the programâ€™s splash screen on loading: itâ€™s traditionally been taken from the corresponding symphony number. (As version 8 loads we hear a few swelling bars from the first movement of the Sixth.)MyMac reviewed Sibelius 7.5 a year ago, and put the continued development of the product in the context of then recent changes at Avid. Happily, the software and company have held their own. They continue to provide an excellent environment in which to compose music â€“ many orders of magnitude above what the likes of GarageBand offers. Indeed, the hundreds of third party plugins, ancillary tools and score scanning and capturing software make Sibelius still the richest option for serious composers. Some of this comes bundled with Sibelius (8) in â€˜liteâ€™ versions â€“ see the end of this review.Version 8 itself, though, offers fewer new features than other upgrade versions have done. The only major new innovation â€“ but one that will be very useful to many who work this way â€“ is the addition of integrated control and data input via other devices that the keyboardâ€¦ Annotations and gestures on a tablet etc. The other major change is in Avidâ€™s pricing structure and policy.AnnotationsSibelius has long supported notes â€“ as in written comments in English or a localized language, as well as crotchets/quarter notes and quavers/eighth notes. Such additions â€“ usually above the staff â€“ can help you find your way around, act as reminders, or prompts: â€œthis needs to be completed next sessionâ€¦â€,  â€œdiscuss tempo with players at first rehearsalâ€, â€œchange back to arcoâ€, or â€œreturn to this passage and transpose after orchestrationâ€.Sibelius version 8â€™s new Annotate feature allows you greater flexibility in drawing directly onto the score with the appropriate input device â€“ mouse, trackpad, USB tablet, (Surface Pro 3) pen etc.Sibelius 8 AnnotationsYou can now circle items, write (or type) well-formatted comments or instructions for arrangers, players or students, for instance. Theyâ€™re part of the score. And you add them using a pen â€“ with the appropriate hardware environment â€“ or a mouse/finger (though this isnâ€™t really practical). Annotations are intelligently grouped: make a few annotations within a sufficiently short time â€“ even lifting the pen off your (tabletâ€™s) surface â€“ and theyâ€™ll be bound together. And handled in such a way that theyâ€™re fixed to the bar in question. You can control the color and pen width.Annotations can be toggled on/off (Review > Annotations > Annotate) â€“ for final printing, for example; and can be cut/copied and pasted.TabletIf your workflow emulates â€“ or if you prefer to use â€“ pen-and-paper techniques, then thereâ€™s another new feature in Sibelius 8: the program now works with touch screens and tablets on which itâ€™s installed. Optimized for the Microsoft Surface Pro 3 tablet, it allows note input and navigation through the score with the fingers, gestures, swipes and a deviceâ€™s onscreen keyboard and fretboard.Musical notes can now be input by tapping with the pen as you would click with a mouse pointer. A pen will also erase. To move around your score, touch a blank area and move your fingers. Intuitive. You can also pinch and zoom.Think long and hard about this before jumping to Version 8 on the strength of just this, though: Sibelius is such a rich environment that you can only ever do basic operations this wayâ€¦ youâ€™re always going to need a full QWERTY keyboard.Sibelius 8 GUIPricingSo itâ€™s probably the new pricing model which is the biggest change for Avid and Sibeliusâ€™ many users: while bearing firmly in mind that itâ€™s still arguably the most sophisticated, feature-rich and easiest-to-use notation suite available, the yearly $89 upgrade cost will seem high to many when the absence of major new functionality is considered.At the same time, itâ€™s to be noted that all licenses now include support which previously cost an extra $29. This means unlimited online cases, and one phone call per month as well as all software upgrades released during the term of the license. This applies until the end of June next year. Then youâ€™ll have a choice between a new perpetual license at the full-price of $599, or the renewable subscription starting at $9.99 a month (see this page), which would equate to almost six yearsâ€™ payments, by which time things are sure to have changed again.In the meantime, thereâ€™s all the more reason to stay with Sibelius and upgrade to version 8 if you believe that itâ€™s usually beneficial to have the latest version of a piece of software that you rely on, and if you also  think that Avid will have stiff competition in Steinbergâ€™s product, whose development is led by former Sibelius Product Manager, Daniel Spreadbury and so accept what Sam Butler (his successor) has saidâ€¦ that Avid has â€œa strong plan for the next few yearsâ€¦ Weâ€™re aiming for a steady release of features for Sibelius itself, including some much needed technical work under the hood as well as some attention to the notation and user experience side of the application.â€The full pricing structure (there are various combinations and options) can be found here; the usual 30-day trial period is also available.ActivationAlong with the new pricing models comes a revamp of the license activation procedureâ€¦ you now activate Sibelius on any computer by signing in to your Avid Master Account; not by user IDs and serial numbers etc. This account offers access to support, downloads and other resources.Sibelius 8 activationGiven the complexity of such a change, this worked really well in the upgrade performed â€“ independently of Avidâ€™s support team â€“ for this review. As said, the same is true of the other features â€“ new and existing â€“ in Sibelius 8.File CompatibilityIf there are no Annotations in your Sibelius 8 file, it can be opened directly in version 7.5. The ability to File > Export > Previous Version still works; and files can be saved to share or make available to users with versions all the way back to Sibelius 2. Avid does suggest that this apparent interchangeability between versions 8 and 7.5 is not to be relied on in future releases.Sibelius 8 needs Mavericks (OS X 10.9) or higher. The Sibelius 8 installer does an excellent job of transferring resources, files, and folders from previous versions.Like everything else covered in this review, it worked flawlessly.But the Sibelius forums and user groups online are always alive with those who â€“ for one reason or another â€“ prefer to stay with earlier versions, often 6, which was the last one before the hotly-debated ribbon was introduced. When MyMac looked at version 7 almost four years ago, though, and evaluated the ribbon, it was found perfectly usable; an improvement on 6 even. So an upgrade really is advisable. And preferably to Version 8 now.Scan and TranscribeAlso bundled with Sibelius version 8 (though not for the first time) are two other ways to input musical data. PhotoScore & NotateMe Lite  has a pretty good record of reading sheet music, PDFs, and even handwritten scores. You might want to base a set of variations of your own on an established theme, for example; or study Lisztâ€™s implied piano technique.Neutronâ€™s AudioScore Lite is for transcribing music from a CD, or and audio source â€“ such as  singing/playing an instrument through a microphone. The Sibelius + Ultimate Bundle has the non-â€˜Liteâ€™ versions of these.Conclusions: If you make your living from, or are a dedicated user of Sibelius, although $89 doesnâ€™t get you a great deal more than was part of Sibelius 7.5, itâ€™s worth the priceâ€¦ there are certainly bug fixes and â€˜invisibleâ€™ enhancements in Sibelius 8 that are well worth paying for. If youâ€™re cautious, you do still have almost a year to decide on your future strategy. Subscription-based pricing is certainly a trend on the increase; it does have advantages. Many users will also feel theyâ€™re more likely to get better support as a result, and need not worry about having to pay for upgrades.Pros: still the most flexible, fully-featured and reliable score notation available for OS X â€“ particularly in terms of its ability to work with third party virtual instrumentsCons: Version 8 has only one significant new feature; so it will be expensive for some users who perhaps do not use alternative input devices or gestures.System Requirements:Mac OS X 10.9 or 10.101 GB or more RAM1 GB hard disk space for Sibelius software only4 GB or more RAM recommended for the Sibelius Sounds library (technically an optional installation, but one which most users will want)36 GB (SSD preferred) additional hard disk space recommended for the Sibelius Sounds libraryOptical drive (for installation from the optional Media Pack DVDs)internet connection for software download and activationMyMac Review Rating: 9 out of 10

For the price, I am shocked that these do not include any noise-canceling technology. In fact, overall, I am somewhat disappointed in these Bose headphones.A little back story. Two decades ago, I had purchased a very expensive pair of Bose headphones. I purchased them from a high-end stereo store, and the salesman at the time (a friend) said that they were overpriced for the audio quality. "You're buying the name" he told me. My dad, though, had a pair of Bose speakers he had picked up on his way back from Vietnam, and I LOVED the audio quality. My friend told me I could get another pair of headphones for fifty bucks cheaper that sounded a lot better. I didn't listen, purchased the Bose, and went home to enjoy my CDs. A week later, I returned the headphones, and got the less expensive pair. (KOSS) My friend was correct after all. At that point, I swore off Bose as expensive but not as good in audio quality. I took on his mantra as my own. "Your buying the name."This brings us to these Bose headphones. They are the first Bose I have owned since the early 1990s. I didn't want to bias my opinion, so I went in with an open mind. Usually a fan nowadays of Shure and AKG, I was really interested to see (hear) if Bose had pushed past the "more money for less quality"Sadly, no.The first time I started to listen to them, I was happy. They sounded pretty full, bright, and clear. They do a decent job of blocking regular sounds, but are terrible on an airplane. After an hour, though, I realized that something was off. I switch over to my normal AKGs and found out that the Bose were mudding the bass. I didn't notice at first, but the more I listened, the more noticeable it became.I REALLY wanted to like these headphones. They are very comfortable to wear, a big selling factor for me. In comfort alone, I would rank these an almost perfect score. The audio controls for your Android phone works well, but sadly does nothing in an iPhone. This is an odd choice, as I have used plenty of headphones over the last few years that control volume and pause/play just fine on both Android and iOS. Either Bose skimped on the controls, or their marketing team decided to focus on Android for... well, whatever reason.Audio quality is good, not great, and not terrible. Comfort is amazing. At this price-point, I do expect a lot better. I have a pair of $79 Harman Kardon headphones that blow these away in audio quality. And, sadly, my friend from all those years is still correct: with Bose, you are buying the hype, not the quality.

We lost the sugarberry. This is a little plastic food thing that goes with StarLily, and she would make fun noises when "eating" it. My daughter is not happy.StarLily is a very fun, somewhat interactive toy that takes four batteries, makes fun and pleasing sounds, and has become a favorite toy for my daughter. So much so, in fact, that when the sugarberry became lost, days were spent looking for it, but alas, it has yet to be found.My younger son also likes StarLily, but pretends not to. It is, after all, a flying unicorn, and boys are not suppose to like those things. At least that's what he says, even though my wife and I have told him that it's okay to like any toy, regardless if it's made for a boy or girl. Perhaps, he has asked, there is a cool Dinosaur like StarLily that he could get. Or maybe a turtle. Regardless, he really likes it as well, almost as much as my daughter, and he REALLY wants one like it.That, in and of itself, should tell you a lot about the quality and desirability of the toy. Even boys want one ;-)The toy has held up very well over the last month, especially considering how much it is played with. The horn lights up with multiple colors, it responds to your touching and talking to it, and it moves around very realistically. (I like how it blinks it's eyes) There is an iPad app that goes along with it, but my daughter has not gotten around to using it with StarLily yet. The app is free on the iTunes store.All in all, this is a great toy, and while pricey, I think it's well worth it for the enjoyment my daughter (and secretly son) has gotten out of it!

After two weeks trying to get this to work with three different Android Phones, I give up. I can get it to pair just fine, but it simply does not work with any game. I tried using another BT game controller, and that works fine. Not so the Razer Serval. So this is a short review. It simply does not work at all for me. I hope if you buy it you have better luck than I did

Printing Bliss! That's the only way to describe my time using the Epson WorkForce ET-4500.The big news here is the cost of replacing the ink. Unlike the price of replacement ink in the past, you just refill the "tanks" on this new printer. And it takes a LOT more ink than before, but at half the price. This is a big deal, bigger than the tech press is giving it. For the past fifteen years, it cost almost as much to buy a new printer as it would be to buy the replacement ink. With the WorkForce ET-4500, Epson is changing this business model, and it is a massively welcome change!On to the printer itself.It's hard to find any faults with this machine. It prints very fast, It is both intuitive and easy to set up. Printing from both my PCs and Macs were painless and provided picture perfect prints every time. Replacing the ink is simple. The onboard control panel is easy to figure out quickly when you want to make a copy. It is wireless, which works well, but I mostly use it plugged into my network. Wireless, however, allows me to print from my iPhone, which is still a novel and cool thing to be able to do. And no, that aspect didn't require any setup on the printer at all, it did it right out of the box. (Once I joined the wireless network, which itself was simple)Obviously I have only had it for a few weeks, so I cannot really talk about the number of prints it boast per-ink. It says it will hold ink for two years worth of printing. That depends on how much printing you actually do I suppose.This is a larger printer, so keep that in mind if you want to put this in a smaller space. A "regular" AIO printer takes about 2/3rds the space this beast does!This printer is a welcome addition to our printing needs. Yes, it is more expensive than smaller printers, but Epson is trying (and will succeed based on this printer) to change the business of ink-jet printing. And change it for the better!

I don't usually enjoy in-ear headphones. I like the over-the-ear variety, but thought I would give these Bose SoundTrue headphones a try.The audio quality is first-rate. I was happy with the frequency response in both high, mid, and bass. Actually, the bass blew me away for in-ear headphones, as that is usually the weak spot in them.The reason I don't usually like in-ear headphones, especially the ear-buds that come with either the Android or iPhones, is that they are uncomfortable to wear. Not so these Bose! They are very comfortable, fit really well, and were a pleasant experience.The controls on the wire itself is intuitive and simple to use.They sound great!

I had been using Cascade dishwasher tabs, but we have not been happy with them as of late. They leave a lot of water stains, and don't seem to rinse well. So I was not thinking the Finish would work as well, as the Cascade cost more and I didn't have great luck a few years ago when I last used the Finish product. I have to say, though, that they must have changed up the formula, as we are VERY happy with this product. So much so, in fact, that I think this will now be our regular dishwasher tablet solution. No water marks, seems to really clean the dishes well, and each pellet is wrapped up separately, meaning they don't all stick together in the package like the cheaper brands do. Nice job!

As much as I like gaming on my iPad, there are still many types of games that I love to play but generally suck on the iPad. (for me!) I am a HUGE fan, for instance, of the GTA games. But a touch screen? Blah. But the iPad with this SteelSeries (Xbox-like) BT controller? WOW.Setting up the controller on my iPad could not be more simple. All I had to do was turn on the controller, go to BlueTooth on the iPad, select the controller, and that's it. Done. I then launched GTA San Andreas, and started playing. The game knew there was now a controller connected, it mapped the buttons to the same configuration as they would be on a PlayStation or Xbox, and I was up and running.Connecting and ease of use is one thing, but how does the controller feel and work? In a word: expected. When you first hold this controller, it should feel very familiar to you if you have ever used an XBox 360 controller. That's what my hand was telling my brain I was using. There are, of course, some differences, but for gamability, there are none. Zero. This felt great!The controller is super responsive. It works as expected, the batteries have a long life, and it makes gaming on my tablet a LOT more fun. I will also give it a go eventually with my computer, but it was the iPad I was most interested in using it with, and there, the SteelSeries Status XL rocked. Highly recommended!

Fantastic sponges. These are a lot more durable than the cheapies we usually pick up at the grocery store. They feel more durable in your hand, and don't easily shred when cleaning rough materials. They also seem to last longer, which is always a bonus! I also enjoy the scrubbing power without the super-abrasive side most sponges have, although there was that one case of burnt steak on a pan that these Scotch-Brite could not handle, and a really abrasive sponge did. Still and all, great product

My wife has been wearing these (they don't go with my eye color, alas...) and she likes them. When I showed her the picture, she thought that Amazon had actually sent the wrong ones. They are smaller than expected, and honestly, the Diamonds around the outside are very tiny and not easily seen. Looks more like a metal ring around the black than anything. Still, they were inexpensive, they are pretty, and my wife likes them, just not as much as she thought she would based on the pictures and description on Amazon

As a decriminating phone user, it's hard to impress me. I say that not to cast a bad light in the 8 XL from BLU, but rather so you know where I am at while writing this review. My regular phone is an iPhone 6 Plus, but I also own a few Android phones as well. And this is in fact an Android phone.First, the good. The battery life was pretty decent, but not top of class by any means. Better than average for sure.The screen is large!Full access to the Google App store. Here I found no apps that didn't work, even the more demanding ones. They all ran without a hitch.Set-up was very simple.It's Android, so you should have no problems there.Call quality was actually pretty decent!The badWell, the screen may be large, but it's about three years out of date. Compared to other Android phones of this size, it feels very dated.WiFi was spotty for me, even sitting a few feet from the WiFi router. Odd, that. Still, the LTE was great! Very fast (AT&T network for testing purposes)The build quality is just okay, not bad, but not really good, either. Feels like what it is: a cheap, large phone. The plastic cover is easy to remove, and it's nice that it does come with a protective case and screen protector.This is not gorilla glass, and for such a large screen, I worried about the long-term durability of it.Still and all, this is an unlocked large-screen Android phone for less than $150! I can totally see using this if I broke another phone between upgrade cycles, rather than having the other phone repaired. I will keep this charged and ready for "emergency" usage, or if I travel overseas.
Great book! If you like T.R. Harris, and who doesn't?, you will love this book. Highly recommended!

I love the idea behind this speaker, and the physical speaker itself is pretty cool. You can even buy a solar panel for the Braven. So why only three stars? Well, it's not for the portability or the design. Both are brilliant. It's for teh audio quality, which is average at best. I wish the sound quality matched the build quality, but it seems most of the R&D went to the outside, not the inside.

For the price, and the quality of paper, I was very impressed. This is a LOT of paper, enough to last our household at least two years. Of course, the younger kids also use it to color on, and it works equally as well in both our printers. I like that it is eco friendly, but I still want nice looking paper when printing. This does the job, will work equally well in a home/work place, and is a good price

Really? For the price they are charging for this set, I was expecting a LOT more. A few stencils, some colored pencils? This is very disappointing. I was expecting much more, and while the kids had fun with the set for about a half-hour, that was about it. Look elsewhere for this at a lower price, around $5.00, maximum.

First off, these towels are very absorbent, and feel nice and soft. Works well for Christmas time because of the colors, I suppose, but they are not holiday themed at all.I would have rated these higher, but after two washes, they are already starting to fray at the ends. 100% cotton hand towels should NOT start to fray after two washes, right? I have some that have laster ten years and looks good.In fairness, only the two write towels are displaying any fraying. The red and green are fine, and have actually been washed one more time than the whites.

Stand and fight, soldier! It's strange to hear this coming from a foot tall toy in 2015. I remember having GI Joe's back when I was a kid in the 70s, and this was the type of thing that was popular then. Captain America, of course, is reciting lines from the Avengers movies. And honestly, it's pretty cool. He has a few audio bytes, and they all sound pretty good for a toy. I'm not annoyed by them yet :-)My son loves this action figure. He wants some of the other Avengers and, of course, some bad guys to fight. The detail is really good on this figure, and I'm glad they used this costume rather than the one in the first Avengers movie, which kinda sucked.Good toy. $20 for this quality, detail, and neat features is a decent price.

I really put these bags through the stress test on Sunday. Decided to cook a Turkey. (It was good!) We ate about half of it, leaving a LOT of Turkey. Usually this could then be cut up and destined to make sandwiches the rest of the week. It was not to be, as the Turkey, stuffing, and gravy took a spill from the top of the oven onto the floor. Sigh. So disappointed. (And yes, it was MY fault.) So, clean... clean... turkey goes into the garbage. The garbage where the Hefty bag is. Now, with all the mess, turkey, used paper towels, etc... there was a LOT of stuff. More, it weighed a lot. Well, hey, I have to review these anyway, what better way, right?The conclusion? The Hefty bag passed with flying colors. I also like that they are not wrapped around each other, meaning it is very simple to pull one, and only one, bag out of the box at a time. I HATE the ones that are static clung to each other, hard to find where to rip the bag apart from the rest of the roll, etc. NOT so with the Hefty bag! Great stuff!

My wife is not a big jewelry wearing person. But when she saw the picture of this ring, she said she would love it. Well, she has been wearing it for weeks now, and really seems to like it a lot. Thank goodness the size was right!Rings are a personal thing. She does not like gaudy, but pretty. I don't know how I can quantify that, but she said this ring is very pretty, not gaudy at all. It does not roll around on her finger like a few other rings she wears from time to time. It seems durable, which I guess is important in a ring? She likes it, said she thought most women would as well. So there ya go!

I had the opportunity to get these for free. These are fantastic scissors for kids! We purchased two more packs and gave them to the kindergarten teacher at our sons school. She was ecstatic! They have a nice soft feel, and work really well in her class. They were inexpensive enough that we could easily afford it, and it meant a lot to the teacher. Would highly recommend these!

Wow. My dogs LOVE these things. I don't mind them, either. No to eat, silly! I can't stand dog (or cat) treats that leave your fingers smelling bad after giving your pet a treat. Yuck. But these? No smell, no crumbs, no anything. And honestly, our two dogs go NUTS for them. Seriously, I pull out this bag, and they are super hype. They really seem to like these a lot, so we will make this a semi-regular treat for them

I am really surprised at the quality of this cable. For the price of this 4 pack of cables I expected the cables to break within a few days but they are very sturdy. Like many others have said my previous lighting cables bring at the end right before the plug and this is due to it being bent the wrong way. These cables have more rubber support that holds it in place and makes it harder to bend. The cables also charge my iPhone 6 equally as fast as the original cable without the premium price which I am really happy about. We need better companies selling quality products like Kash Technology does. Overall for people who need cables and who do not want to spend a premium should buy these cablesI received this product to leave a honest and unbiased review

This charger is one of the best chargers I have ever used. I like that it includes a Quick Charge 2.0 port. Although I do not have a device that has Quick Charge built in my Note 3 charged much faster than through a standard port or outlet. I used my friends Note 4 to test the Quick Charge capabilities and I can say that it lives up to its name and charges the phone as fast as the Quick Charge allows it to.  I usually have at least devices connected at night and it has no problem charging it to full capacity in the morning. Surprisingly the charger does not get too hot when many devices are plugged into it.  I used it to charge my phone, Moto 360, and tablets and each port supplied the full amount of charge to my device which was pretty incredible. I would recommend this to anyone who would need a charger for their work desk or for multiple devices.I got this product in return for a honest and unbiased review

The windshield clamp is VERY strong, and you won't have a problem with it falling down. The phone holder opens up easily and each side has a groove of which your phone sits in. Each side of the clamp is rubberized and won't scratch or damage your phone. The mount swivels in two areas. First of which is the ball joint which turns your phone in any position. The second is the slider which tilts the phone high or low. Both joints are a little stiff. I put a little bit of house oil just to help them swivel just a little bit easier.This mount should accommodate most phones. The holder opens up to 4 inches and it fits my Nexus 5 easily. Something you should check on before ordering any car mount is your state laws. Some states allow dash and windshield mounts and others just allow dash mounts. I live in Michigan where both mounts are allowed but you should double check your state laws before using one or the other just to be on the safe side.All-in-all, easy to use phone mount. I would definitely recommend due to its simplicity and durability and the fact that Aukey offers you a 24 month warranty which gives you more than enough coverage if something goes wrong.I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review

These are really fun addition to taking pictures with you android or IOS device, You get 3 lenses and each has different effect ranging from fish eye (my favorite) wide angle and macro for shooting really detailed shots. Fish eye is just what it states in terms of how picture looks and what i liked about the AUKEY lens are the fit, i tested all 3 lens on a Nexus 6 which has a round camera just as the AUKEY lens are round so fit was really good and in no case with all 3 lens did i see the lens in a picture unless i had the fit not perfect so i moved to a Note 3 which has a square lens on device and results were the same, no lens or shadow in the pictures. The macro and wide angle lens are screwed together so don't be alarmed when you open the box and there's only 2 lens so to use the macro lens which is 10x zoom for really detailed close up shots just a simple un-screw from other lens (wide angle) and you will be able to shoot great detailed shots but you MUST be very close to subject and have a pretty stable hand but once you get the hang of it its a blast. Wide angle lens is great for group shots or pictures with multiple subjects in it.The package comes with 2 clips that hold the lens and attach to your device and there plastic and in no case of using these lenses for 1 week of pictures and taking clips on and off multiple devices did i see any scratches or even a start of a scratch on any of my devices.Package Content: Aukey 3-in-1 Smartphone Lens (Fish-eye lens x 1, Macro/Wide-angle lens combo x 1, 2 x clips, 1 x lens cloth, 18 months Worry-free warranty lots of fun and recommend these to anybody who likes taking pictures.I got this device for a honest and unbiased review

I am really happy with this product. I have been using this product for the past few weeks to listen to music while taking a shower. I would leave my phone all the way in the other room and there would be no muffling in sound. At almost full volume I find no problem with the sound and bass. I like the shockproof rubber that is all around the circumference of the device. The "wheel" design really keeps it from getting damaged. The only minor issue I had is figuring out how to use the buttons on the speaker. The buttons control a variety of things like the volume and track changing. I finally figured it out after reading the manual. I would suggest this to anyone who needs an outdoor speaker. I received this product for a honest and unbiased review.

Just like all of Aukey's battery pack this is advertised to have the correct power of 12000 mAh. It could charge my Galaxy Note 3 a little over three times. One thing that separates this from other battery packs is that it really charges my device very fast. I have used multiple battery packs and can say that this one charges my Note 3 as fast as my wall charger does which is very surprising. The Aukey is a very low profile device which easily fits in my pocket and bags. I highly recommend this product to anyone who wants a battery pack as an emergency back up power pack.I received this product for an honest and unbiased review.

I have used this product for a few months now. Although I rarely find use in using Cardboard it came in handy when I decided to use it. I was able to watch movies while sitting in bed as if I were watching it on a huge screen. Also when using it on YouTube it is pretty cool be able to watch the videos in 360 degree mode. Other than these two scenarios of usage Google has not come out with many optimized Cardboard apps. I would recommend this to who ever wants to get into VR in a cheap manner.

I received this lamp a few weeks ago and I am glad that I am using this on my desk. It came nicely packaged which many people overlook but I think the packaging shows something about this product. The lamp is very stylish and looks very modern meaning that its simply designed but looks very classy. The lamp doesn't have any physical buttons but it has a touch power button and four buttons beneath it that controls how bright or dim the light is. The lamp itself is adjustable and can be put at any angle that is wanted and also can be turned up and pointed to the ceiling. The light that this lamp produces lights up my whole room and even at the lowest setting it is sufficient enough for me to study and do things. The book of the lamp also has a USB port which is always useful to have especially in the electronics age. I would highly recommend this lamp to anyone who needs a new lamp and something a little more modern on their desk

I got my hands on both the 5DS and the 5DS R so I will be switching between the two when talking about my experience with the cameras. Both the 5DS and the 5DS R is nearly identical to the 5D Mark 3. The only noticeable difference is the mode dial which is a bit more coarser. The main selling point of this camera is the new 50 megapixel CMOS sensor. Although Canon and Sony has had higher resolution cameras over the last few years, Canon has finally released the big guns with the 5DS (R). This is something completely different for Canon who usually keeps the resolution in the low 20s. The camera produces such high quality images that it slows down my computer when loading the images. To compare, I have never had that problem with my 5D Mark 3.I tested both the 5DS and 5DS R with three lenses: the Canon 300 f/2.8, the Zeiss 85mm f/1.4 and the Zeiss 21mm f/2.8. I chose these three lenses because it represented a wide variety of situations a photographer may be in.Canon 300 f/2.8 (telephoto)This is one of my favorite lenses that I use a lot in wildlife including when I go to the zoo. For the purpose of testing, I kept the settings the same on my 5D M 3, 5DS and 5DS R. When comparing the resolution between the Mark 3 and the 5DS(R), I noticed a lot more detail when zooming into the picture. The resolution increased about 30% from the 5D 3 to the 5DS and on top of that the 5DS R had a 10% increase over the 5DS. Those tests were at the center of the image (lens). As you go out the edges of the image youâ€™ll notice a decrease in quality which to me wasnt that big of a deal. Even with the decrease in quality there was a 20% increase from the 5D 3 to the 5Ds.Zeiss 85mm f/1.4 (standard usage)With the Zeiss 85mm Otus things are just a bit different. The improvement between the 5D III and the 5DS is about 20% in the center, slightly less off-axis. The 5DS R version adds about 5% more resolution compared to the 5DS. I was a bit surprised at the result and repeated it several times to confirm the numbers and it was so. The reason I was surprised is the Otus is the highest resolving lens, and my first thought was it therefore would benefit the most from the higher resolution cameras.Zeiss 21mm f/2.8 (wide angle)Again, we see the resolution is greatly improved, with the 5DS MTF50 numbers about 30% higher than the 5D Mk III, even in the corners. Throughout most of the image, the 5DS R MTF50 numbers are about 10% higher than the 5DS. However, in the absolute corners there is only a small difference between the 5DS and 5DS R cameras. From other things we know about this lens, I would assume this is because the corner resolution with this lens is limited by astigmatism.I want to clarify this just a bit because depending upon how a tester is presenting data, you may see them present this corner data differently. Imatest doesnâ€™t measure astigmatism exactly, but does measure slanted lines that are nearly vertical and nearly horizontal. When I present corner data I average 8 numbers: the horizontal and vertical reading in each corner. Someone else may present only the best corner number, or the median corner number, or just vertical or horizontal numbers. This might have a corner number better or worse than what we are presenting.SummaryFor photographers who demand nothing but the highest resolution, you will love the newer 5DS and 5DS R. Landscape, bridal and studio photography are just some applications which I can see where the new models will shine with their 50-megapixel sensor. Based on the already competent 5D Mk III body, what you have is an amazing megapixel machine designed to delight every pixel peeper out there. The new 5DS and 5DS R shine brilliantly in a slow and deliberate photography workflow for which lighting level is not a concern.

This case is a very basic case. The case consists of a very thin layer of plastic all around the device with a clear back. If you need protection from the occasional drop this will be good for you but if you are prone to excessive drops you should pay a little extra for a more heavy duty case. I myself take care of my device very well so I found this case good for me and also it kept the profile of the phone very thin.

In years past, if someone asked me, "Hey, I found this Tom Robbins book lying around, so should I read it?" I would've said yes. No hesitation. No equivocation. "That guy," I'd say, "is a stylist. And I mean that in the best possible way."Because that's what Tom Robbins is, was, forever shall be: He's the god young writers pray to when they're lost and trying to find their voice. He's the mountain every working writer surveys when they're trying to put a sentence together that's more complicated than subject-verb-predicate.There was a time when he was the writer â€” the man that every itinerant scribbler (myself included) wanted to be â€” and when he was an out-and-out rockstar among word wranglers; someone who signed the breasts of ardent fans (something he writes about in his new memoir, Tibetan Peach Pie), debuted on bestseller lists (something else he writes about) and had searchlights painting the skies at his book signings (which, you guessed it, he also writes about).But were someone to come up to me with a copy of Tibetan Peach Pie and say, "Hey, someone just gave me a copy of Tom Robbins' new memoir. Should I read it?" I'd have a slightly different answer. "That guy," I'd say, "is a stylist. And I mean that in the best possible way. But man, you gotta really like Tom Robbins to want to read that one."And I'm not saying this because the book isn't beautiful. It is. Robbins has never met a pun, a blissfully crooked analogy, a magician's bit of verbal trickery that he didn't love (and lampshade, and then lampshade some more, with a grin and a wink as though to let everyone know that we're all in on the same joke).As such, his voice, stripped of its native Carolina drawl by force of will, "sounds as if it's been strained through Davy Crockett's underwear." In describing his reaction to seeing a Natalie Wood film at a tender age, he says his "scruffy whippersnapper heart opened like a sardine tin ... radiating such a vortex of woo woo love it would have made Saint Francis of Assisi seem like a mink rancher."Oh, and those ellipses in there? They're standing in for fifty or a hundred or two hundred additional words, descriptive and lovely and weighty and fierce, all describing his sudden, near-religious response to Tomorrow Is Forever. Why? Because Tom Robbins is, above all else, a stylist. He knows words the way a pool hustler knows chalk. And when he wants to make a point, he doesn't spare the printers any ink.But again, that's not why I'm adding the extra codicil to my usual blanket recommendation of all Robbins-alia. It's not because the man didn't live an interesting life (he was beloved of both Timothy Leary and the Hell's Angels, after all; drank beers with Shelly Duvall, dropped acid before it was cool, and was, briefly, suspected of being the Unabomber). And it's not because he can't tell a story (his evocations of the Depression-era South and the pre-Beatnik 1950's are the stuff of PBS documentaries, if PBS documentaries were regularly directed by the Coen brothers).But at a certain point little Tommy Rotten (his childhood nickname) grows up and becomes TOM ROBBINS, all caps. He becomes, right before our eyes, that young cosmic fool, burning up the landscape with his words and cleverness. He finds success and comfort â€” two things that are death to any memoir, unless they come only in the last couple of pages. And worse, he turns all that language on himself.See, that is the rough thing about reading this Robbins. Where, in every novel, he uses his black belt word-ninja skills to make us love the misfits and weirdos which populate his imaginary landscapes, here â€” by nature of the memoir as form â€” he is forced to speak about himself. And he does so the same way he spoke of Sissy Hankshaw, Wiggs Dannyboy, the Woodpecker and Plucky Purcell. This works well for tales of deformed hitchhikers and outlaw bombers, but it can become grating, navel-gaze-y and not-so-humble-brag-ish when it's Tom Robbins writing about Tom Robbins; when he has cast himself, by necessity, as the central hero in a book that reads nearly as weird and scattered and unlikely as some of his novels.So, going in, you gotta love Tom. You gotta be itching to know about his first acid trip, his feelings on tomato-and-mayonnaise sandwiches and his long list of ex-wives. You gotta imagine yourself washed up on a barstool in La Conner, Washington, trapped by a typhoon or a toad-rain or worse, and fortunate enough to find yourself sitting next to the now aged cosmic fool as he starts to talk and tell you the tales of how he got from Blowing Rock, North Carolina to here, consorted with artists and idiots, drank some beer, ran away with the circus, predicted the weather, loved some women, sired some children, traveled the world and, somehow, found the time to write a few books along the way.

Cibola Burn is a big book. Huge, really, both in terms of pages (nearly 600 in the version I got), and in pure authorial chutzpah. It is part four in the Expanse series, which has, thus far, included three books and a smattering of novellas. And it represents, for dedicated readers of James S.A. Corey (in real life, the two-man team of Daniel Abraham and Ty Franck) the biggest, most sprawling leap of an already sprawling tale.Cibola Burn opens a few years after the events of the last volume, Abaddon's Gate. Our own solar system is now linked to a thousand other worlds by way of the Ring â€” a huge, alien gate that allows travel outside the Sol system and into a larger universe teeming with habitable planets. Where in the previous books in the series, we were constrained merely to our own little celestial neighborhood â€” a couple planets, a few moons, a bunch of asteroids, starships, wars and rumors of wars â€” now there is simply ... more.More of everything. It's a land rush, with settlers already fanning out into alien space and various government bodies struggling to both contain the flood of humanity and deal with the colonists already breathing the alien air on Ilus â€” closest and most hospitable of the new worlds.But this is all backdrop, really. The authors start large, on a canvas suddenly stretched to encompass a thousand planets, but quickly narrow down to focus attention primarily on Ilus â€” on the colonists already there and those in orbit who want them gone. And while this new, nearly limitless world is big, the authors corral it with attention to purely human-scale details.Corey has a (two-handed) facility with the language of the small and uses it to give an almost comforting provincialism to the tale: Describing a newly (and banally) redecorated office aboard a former battleship turned space station, they write, "Sure, humans had invaded an extra-dimensional space with wormholes to points scattered across the galaxy, but they'd remembered to bring ferns."And then there's Capt. Jim Holden â€” Corey's long-standing protagonist and one of a handful of POV characters who move the plot along. Though you'll have a solid chunk of pages in the rearview before he appears, Cibola Burn lights up from the minute Holden steps to the stage as captain of the light frigate Rocinante.Holden is just one of those magic characters who feels lived in â€” an immediately recognizable archetype (the ex-military man now making do for himself and his crew) who doesn't appear to know he's an archetype. He is Malcolm Reynolds, Han Solo, or certainly one of their close friends. And honestly, despite one big explosion, several deaths, a shuttle crash and all manner of nefarious activities occurring before Holden makes his first appearance, Cibola Burn only truly takes off once he comes slouching into the tale.To say anything more would be unconscionably spoilery, but I can say this: Fans of the Expanse series likely already know that it has recently been picked up for several additional books and as a TV series, and you only get that kind of attention as a sci-fi author if you've got a bit of Michael Bay in your DNA.It takes some time to get there, but the second half of the book is a good payoff for all the exposition and pawn-moving you'll have to tolerate in the first. There are chases. Rescues. Escapes. Stuff blows up. And then, even though Holden has ostensibly been sent to Ilus on a diplomatic mission, even more stuff blows up.But hey, I'm not complaining. What could've been 600 pages of multiparty talks between competing economic and governmental factions over the legal questions of squatter's rights and planetary eminent domain instead devolves with reasonable speed into betrayal, gunplay and bloodshed â€” which is precisely what this kind of story is built to do. It isn't space opera in any pure sense. Cibola Burn is a bit too slick for that. In the end, it's more like epic sci-fi â€” the science fictional equivalent of A Song of Ice and Fire (which is maybe more than a little appropriate, since co-author Ty Franck has also worked as George R.R. Martin's assistant), only with fewer beheadings and way more spaceships.

Usually when someone steps from our world into a fantasy world, they're one of two sorts of characters. There's the Bookish Outcast for whom the portal fantasy is a literal manifestation of the act of reading as escape â€” and there's the Chosen One, an otherwise unremarkable or unlikeable character who has a Destiny waiting in the other world. There are of course dozens of variations on these roles, but often portal fantasies are more or less wish fulfillment: we want to escape, to be wanted, to be important or powerful or our best selves.It's rare and refreshing, then, to encounter a book where the fantasy world and its denizens actively do not want the protagonist, and are invested in keeping them out.Sophie Opal Hansa is a modern-day adventurer: a 24-year-old marine videographer, dabbler in bio sciences, cave-diver, rock-climber and long-distance swimmer, to name a few of her several interests. Though raised by loving adoptive parents, and though she has a great relationship with her genius gay brother, she longs to know about her birth family â€” and learns, messily and gracelessly, the extent to which she was desperately unwanted.Still reeling from the discovery, she unexpectedly foils an attempt on the life of her biological aunt, and in so doing is swept away with her to Erinth, a watery world where everything from language to fauna seems just slant of the Earth she knows. Sophie is eager to document everything about it â€” but no one wants to speak to her, and her aunt, rather than being grateful for the rescue, demands that she leave, hinting that Sophie's very presence in Erinth will bring misfortune to her kin.At first I thought Sophie insufferable. There's a bull-in-china-shop quality to her character, and it took awhile for the narrative to acknowledge this instead of just taking for granted that her brashness is an uncontested virtue. I found looking at Erinth through Sophie's probing, cataloging and entirely entitled gaze frustrating and annoying. But the introduction of her brother Bram as foil, the raised stakes of the intrigues around her, and Sophie's own development as a character eventually led me to root for her and better enjoy the book's fantastic world-building.And it is fantastic: It's suggested that Erinth might be a near-drowned future version of Earth (our modern-day Earth is named Erstwhile by Erinthians), one made up entirely of island nations.
